site_title: Singaporean linked to Wirecard scandal slapped with five more charges
summary: A Singaporean man, R Shanmugaratnam, has been charged with five additional counts related to the Wirecard scandal. He faces a total of 11 charges for allegedly falsifying letters stating bogus balances held in his company's accounts. Citadelle Corporate Services, one of the companies being investigated, has been ordered by the Monetary Authority of Singapore to stop its payment services in the city-state. Wirecard entities in Singapore will also cease payment services, affecting thousands of merchants using its payment terminals.

site_title: Seagram heiress jailed for bankrolling sex cult
summary: Seagram heiress Clare Bronfman, 41, was sentenced to over six years in prison for her role in a sex trafficking scandal linked to the cult Nxivm. Bronfman pleaded guilty to credit card fraud and harbouring illegal immigrants, spending tens of millions of dollars supporting the group. Her defence claimed she was unaware of the group's sexual abuse, but prosecutors said her support enabled the crimes. Four others have pleaded guilty, including actress Allison Mack, and Nxivm founder Keith Raniere faces life in prison.

site_title: US Senate passes stopgap to prevent government shutdown
summary: The US Senate passed a budget bill to prevent a government shutdown, extending funding until December 11. The bipartisan measure, which passed with 84 votes to 10, adds $8 billion in nutrition assistance and extends funding for community health centers. It also goes to President Donald Trump, who must sign it by October 1 to avoid a partial shutdown. The stopgap measure avoids addressing the broader fiscal year 2021 budget, which lawmakers are still negotiating.

site_title: Trump senior campaign adviser Parscale steps down after arrest
summary: US President Donald Trump's former campaign manager Brad Parscale has stepped down from a senior role at the campaign after his arrest at his home in Florida. Parscale was detained after his wife reported concerns for his well-being. He had previously been campaign manager for Trump's re-election effort but was pushed aside after a rally in Tulsa, Oklahoma, underperformed. Parscale cited "overwhelming stress" as the reason for his departure.

site_title: US dollar up after indecisive Trump-Biden debate
summary: The US dollar rose in Europe after a two-day decline, recovering from a two-month high, following a heated debate between US President Donald Trump and challenger Joe Biden. The dollar index reached 94.04, while the euro fell 0.3% to $1.1706. Despite market concerns over the election outcome, experts attribute the dollar's recovery to a natural pullback after a sharp depreciation and not directly linked to the debate.

site_title: 9,000 opportunities in professional services offered in last six months: MOM
summary: Ministry of Manpower reported 9,000 job opportunities in the professional services sector over the last six months, with 5,870 being jobs and 3,150 being traineeships and attachments. About 81% of these jobs are for professionals, managers, executives, and technicians (PMET) roles. The sector has seen uneven impact from COVID-19, with sub-sectors like architecture and engineering experiencing larger declines. However, consultancy, design, and marketing services have benefited from digitalization. Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing emphasized the sector's high growth potential and the need for Singaporeans to gain regional experience.

site_title: Singapore shares advance at Thursday's open; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.5% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 12.45 points to 2,479.07, driven by gains from Sembcorp Marine and DBS, as investors looked past tariff uncertainty and US economic data. The telco sector saw a change in leadership, with Singapore Telecommunications announcing CEO Chua Sock Koong's retirement and Yuen Kuan Moon's succession.

site_title: HDB names three new board members, reappoints chairman
summary: The Singapore Housing and Development Board (HDB) has named three new board members: Lee Yi-Jin, Commander of the Sixth Singapore Division, Singapore Armed Forces; Rita Soh, managing director of RDC Architects; and Tan Wah Yeow, non-resident ambassador to Norway. The new term of the HDB board will run from October 1, 2020, to September 30, 2022. Existing chairman Bobby Chin and several other directors have also been reappointed. The new board members bring diverse expertise in public service, accounting, and architecture.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 5.33 points, or 0.35%, to 1,499.49. Volume was 180.66 million lots worth about RM60.63 million.

site_title: American Airlines says to start furloughing 19,000 workers
summary: American Airlines will begin furloughing 19,000 workers on Thursday, following the US government's failure to reach a deal on fresh aid to the pandemic-hit air travel sector. The airline had promised to refrain from layoffs until September, but CEO Doug Parker stated that furloughs will occur due to the lack of agreement. However, if lawmakers reach a new assistance deal, the furloughs would be cancelled and the affected teams would be recalled. Airlines expect a full recovery until a vaccine is widely available, potentially late 2021.

site_title: Goldman Sachs cuts 'modest' number of jobs
summary: Goldman Sachs is undertaking "modest" staff cuts, affecting around 400 jobs, or approximately 1% of its workforce. The move follows other financial giants such as Wells Fargo and Citigroup, which have also reduced their staff in recent weeks. Goldman Sachs had previously suspended job reductions at the start of the pandemic, but has now made the decision to move forward with layoffs. The company did not specify which positions would be impacted.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs is undertaking "modest" staff cuts, a company spokesperson said on Wednesday, joining other financial giants in trimming its number of employees.

site_title: Security tight in Hong Kong ahead of expected banned China national day protest
summary: Security was tight in Hong Kong on October 1, 2020, ahead of an expected China national day march by pro-democracy protesters, despite authorities banning the demonstration. Police deployed 6,000 officers and conducted stop-and-search operations, arresting five people for inciting online participation. The event is seen as a challenge to Beijing's sweeping national security law, which has eroded liberties in the former British colony. Demonstrations have been smaller this year due to coronavirus restrictions, but some groups still called for protests, citing government suppression of free speech.

site_title: Government traineeship scheme eases out amid supply-demand mismatch
summary: Singapore's government-backed traineeship scheme, SGUnited Traineeships Programme, has been scaled back due to a supply-demand mismatch. With more positions available than applicants, Workforce Singapore is redirecting interest from fresh graduates to mid-career applicants under the SGUnited Mid-Career Pathways Programme. The scheme, which covers 80% of training allowances, has seen only 1,000 fresh graduates enroll in traineeships, far short of the initial target of 21,000 positions. Companies are being encouraged to offer positions to mid-career individuals instead.

site_title: Keppel associate Floatel's creditors extend forbearance to Oct 15
summary: Keppel associate Floatel International has extended its forbearance agreement with creditors to October 15, from September 30, for about $22.8 million in coupon payments. The agreement, signed in April, has been extended multiple times and relates to $400 million in senior secured bonds. Floatel is still in negotiations with key stakeholders and has assured that its operating vessels continue to function normally. Shares of Keppel Corp rose 1.8% following the news.

site_title: Lingering questions as Wirecard ends payment services in Singapore
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) has directed Wirecard to cease its payment services, requiring all related entities to return customers' funds by October 14. Wirecard, a German-based fintech, collapsed into insolvency in June after admitting to a massive accounting scandal. The move affects thousands of merchants in Singapore and has raised questions about the scale of Wirecard's operations in the country. The regulator's power to impose directives on Wirecard entities with a grace period to secure a licence has been highlighted as a potential regulatory loophole.

site_title: 7 takeaways from Mariah Carey's memoir
summary: Mariah Carey's memoir, "The Meaning of Mariah Carey," reveals her experiences with domestic violence, racism, and abuse. She recounts her childhood, including her brother's physical altercations with their mother and her own feelings of being an "ATM with a wig on" by her family members. Carey also shares her marriage to Tommy Mottola, which was marked by abuse and manipulation, and her subsequent escape with the help of baseball player Derek Jeter. The memoir also touches on her struggles with mental and physical health, as well as her experiences as a working mother.

site_title: Asia's capital raising rush delivers record fees for banks in third quarter
summary: Asia's equity capital markets generated a record $3.6 billion in fees for investment bankers in the third quarter, a 145% increase from the same period last year. This surge is driven by a rush to list on China's Star Market and technology deals. Total equity market capital raised in Asia reached $133.8 billion, with Chinese banks benefiting most from new listings on the Star Market. This marks a significant increase in fees, surpassing the $6.9 billion generated in the first nine months of 2020.

site_title: Acra, MAS, SGX RegCo update checklist guiding conduct of general meetings
summary: The Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra), Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), and Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) have updated a checklist to guide the conduct of general meetings for listed and non-listed entities in Singapore. The updated checklist allows issuers and non-listed companies to hold general meetings via electronic means until June 30, 2021, while maintaining safe distancing measures. The update follows recent relaxations of safe management measures and encourages the use of digital tools for shareholder engagement.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Europe: Stocks open higher after upbeat H&M, STMicro results
summary: European stocks rose 0.7% on Thursday, driven by upbeat results from H&M and STMicroelectronics. H&M's third-quarter profit exceeded analyst expectations, while STMicro reported forecast-beating results. H&M's shares jumped 5.6%, leading sectoral gains. The Stoxx 600 index and bourses in Paris and London also rose, with hopes of further US stimulus contributing to global sentiment.

site_title: Geopolitical divides present opportunities for localisation: panellists
summary: Geopolitical tensions are driving entrepreneurs to develop localized products and solutions, as global businesses face challenges in scaling internationally. Experts note that the type of service affects how localized it needs to be, with ride-sharing and food delivery requiring localized operations, while cloud-based and community-driven products can be globally competitive. The "regionalization of economic activities" has led to increased localization of capital markets, technology, and services, presenting opportunities for entrepreneurs to adapt to local regulatory concerns and consumer appetites.

site_title: SoftBank-backed used-car startup Kavak becomes first Mexican unicorn
summary: SoftBank-backed used-car startup Kavak has become Mexico's first tech "unicorn" after reaching a US$1.15 billion valuation in its latest funding round. Founded four years ago, Kavak has raised over US$400 million in total funding, with operations in Mexico and Argentina. The company plans to launch in Brazil early next year and aims to scale up faster, hiring 500 people within a year. Kavak expects to turn a profit in the next couple of years and is considering an initial public offering (IPO) in the next two to three years.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise but trade limited by Tokyo glitch, holidays
summary: Asian markets began the new trading quarter on a mixed note, with Tokyo's stock exchanges halted due to a computer glitch and several others closed for holidays. Despite the glitch, Sydney and Singapore rallied over 1% and Jakarta and Wellington also saw gains, driven by hopes of a fresh US stimulus package. Analysts expect the US stimulus to be a major factor in the region's markets, with some speculating it could be the "special sauce" in breaking the deadlock between lawmakers.

images.alt_text: Asian markets got the new trading quarter off to a stuttering start Thursday with Tokyo hit by a computer glitch and several others closed for holidays, though there were healthy gains elsewhere in the region on hopes for a fresh US stimulus package.

site_title: Building partnerships for peace in South-east Asia
summary: South-east Asia's progress on the UN's SDG 16, which aims to promote peaceful and inclusive societies, remains scarce. The region experienced an increase in internal conflicts and military expenditures, regressing on the goal. Building partnerships between private and non-profit sectors is crucial to contribute to peace. The global costs of violence and bribery amount to $14.5 trillion and $1.5-3 trillion respectively, hindering sustainable development. A lack of peace and effective laws hampers achieving the SDG 16 goal, emphasizing the need for collaborative efforts in the region.

site_title: Tech funding in Vietnam dips in H1 2020 after bumper 2019
summary: Tech funding in Vietnam decreased by 30% in the first half of 2020, following a bumper year in 2019, due to travel restrictions and global financial uncertainties. Despite this, Vietnam remains a popular destination for startup investments, with an upward trend in investor arrivals since 2014. The Covid-19 pandemic has created opportunities in education, healthcare, and financial services, according to a report by Do Ventures.

site_title: Covid-19 is speeding up digitalisation of trade processes in Singapore
summary: Covid-19 has accelerated the digitalization of trade processes in Singapore, with the pandemic hastening the adoption of digital technologies by at least five years. Remote working has become feasible and does not result in a dip in productivity, with 61% of Singaporeans preferring online services post-pandemic. The government is leveraging these trends to digitalize trade processes, having signed agreements with Chile, New Zealand, and Australia, and is working on a framework to shift global trade to a digitally enabled system.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary:

Indonesia detained an employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its new CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) will deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks rallied for a 5-day streak.

site_title: Singapore market drifts as investor focus shifts to US presidential debate
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2% on Wednesday, following a "train wreck" US Presidential debate, with CapitaLand Mall Trust and CapitaLand Commercial Trust leading the decline. The STI slipped 4.99 points to 2,466.62. However, Keppel Corp was the best performer, adding 3.5% to S$4.45, as analysts maintained "buy" ratings. Investors shifted focus to the US presidential debate, with some selling off Singapore shares due to concerns over the merged entity.

site_title: Category winners of EY Entrepreneur Of The Year 2020 Singapore named
summary: The 19th annual EY Entrepreneur Of The Year (EOY) 2020 awards in Singapore have named three category winners. They will compete to be named EY Entrepreneur Of The Year 2020 Singapore and represent the country at the 2021 EY World Entrepreneur Of The Year (WEOY) award. The winners include Duong Ba Tran, chairman of Truong Hai Auto Corporation in Vietnam, for the EY Asean Entrepreneurial Excellence award, and Hong Leong Group for the EY Family Business Award of Excellence. The winner will be announced on November 9, 2020, at a virtual celebration.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Aoxin Q&M Dental Group is in discussions with a third party about a possible transaction involving its stake in Panjin Aoxin Quanmin Stomatology Hospital Co. Kitchen Culture Holdings is partnering Ooway Technology to offer services on DHgate.com. Keppel Reit priced S$150 million of fixed-rate subordinated perpetual securities at 3.15% percent. Sunpower Group entered a strategic cooperation agreement with Sichuan Yongxiang to solidify its position in the renewable energy industry. Silverlake Axis' subsidiary will be dissolved, and Hong Leong Asia's subsidiary Airwell Air-Conditioning Technology will dispose of assets for a total cash consideration of S$28.3 million.

site_title: Disney to cut 28,000 jobs in one of biggest layoffs of Covid-19 era
summary: Disney to cut 28,000 jobs, marking one of the deepest workforce reductions of the Covid-19 era. The belt-tightening move affects its US resort business, including theme parks, cruise ships, and retail businesses. The layoffs include executives and salaried staff, with 67% of affected workers being part-time employees. The company aims to reduce costs as its slumping US resort business struggles to recover from the pandemic.

site_title: Tokyo: Trading halted for the day after glitch
summary: Trading on Tokyo's stock exchanges was halted for the day due to a technical glitch, with Japan Exchange Group stating that all listed stocks would remain suspended until further notice.

site_title: Shophouses on Baghdad Street, in Telok Ayer area up for sale
summary: Six shophouses on Baghdad Street and in the Telok Ayer area in Singapore are up for sale, with all sites zoned for commercial use and open to local and foreign buyers. There is no additional buyer's stamp duty imposed. The sale offers a unique opportunity for buyers to invest in Singapore's commercial properties.

site_title: Closing date for Teckwah's privatisation offer extended to Oct 13
summary: The closing date for Teckwah's privatisation offer has been extended to October 13, from September 30, following an extension by OCBC, which represents Clementine Investments. The offer, valued at 65 Singapore cents per share, aims to take Teckwah Industrial Corporation private, citing economic uncertainty. As of September 29, approximately 202.7 million shares, or 86.77%, have been accepted, with Clementine Investments holding a 61.06% stake. The offer was recommended by Teckwah's independent directors, and RHT Capital has been appointed as the independent financial adviser.

site_title: Tokyo: Glitch halts all trade on stock exchange
summary: A technical glitch halted all trading on Tokyo's stock exchanges on October 1, 2020, due to issues with market information delivery. The Japan Exchange Group stated that trading would resume when the problem was resolved, but no timeline was provided.

site_title: Asia family office commitment to ESG investing tested by virus
summary: Asia's ultra-rich family offices, such as the Tsao Family Office, are embracing sustainable investing principles despite the coronavirus-affected global economy. The Tsao Family Office has maintained its commitment to ESG investing, buying into funds such as the Brown Advisory US Sustainable Growth Fund and Robeco Sustainable European Stars Fund. Relatives have suggested a return to traditional investing, but the family office has prioritized its purpose and stayed the course. This trend suggests a growing acceptance of ESG investing among Asia's affluent families.

images.alt_text: As markets tumbled this year, Mary Ann Tsao faced a tough choice. Her fourth-generation family office in Singapore had adopted sustainable investing principles, but the coronavirus was trashing the global economy. Relatives suggested a return to the old ways.

site_title: Covid-19 presents an opportunity for boards to reboot
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has presented a unique opportunity for boards to reassess and reboot their strategic leadership and governance. Despite the challenges, it doesn't mean boards have failed or that governance is in crisis. The pandemic has made the role of directors even more challenging, but it can also be an opportunity for companies to adapt and improve their governance. By learning from the pandemic, boards can implement changes to better prepare for future uncertainties.

site_title: Singapore Tourism Board eyes 'cruises to nowhere' restart, new safety guidelines
summary: Singapore's Tourism Board is set to restart "cruise to nowhere" sailings from the city-state, with a new cruise certification benchmarked against global health safety and hygiene standards. The board has awarded a tender to DNV GL Singapore to create a cruise compliance audit and certification programme. The programme will help cruise lines meet the new safety guidelines, allowing them to resume sailing from Singapore. The project's value is S$145,000.

images.alt_text: Chan Brothers Travel will be partnering Dream Cruises to market and sell "cruises to nowhere" from Singapore, though sales have not been launched.

site_title: Malaysia needs to upgrade economy to escape middle-income trap: Fitch
summary: Malaysia's economy is expected to slow to 3.4% growth over the next decade, according to Fitch Solutions, due to middle-income trap factors such as a "brain drain" of talented individuals, political uncertainty, and reduced fiscal space. The country's average real GDP growth rate is projected to be slower than the past decade, hindering its ability to escape the middle-income trap. Fitch warns that Malaysia's failure to address these issues will impede its potential to upgrade the economy and attract foreign investment.

site_title: US: Stocks gain on stimulus talks, shrugging off Trump-Biden brawl
summary: US stocks gained on Wednesday, shrugging off a contentious presidential debate between President Donald Trump and former Vice-President Joe Biden. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin's comments reopened the door to a potential stimulus deal with congressional Democrats, boosting hopes. Despite a chaotic debate, investors focused on economic data, including a jump in private sector hiring and pending home sales. The gains were tempered by news of Disney layoffs and airline furloughs. Markets largely ignored the debate, with analysts noting it's unlikely to impact the election outcome.

site_title: Snowden ordered by judge to surrender book profits to US government
summary: US District Judge Liam O'Grady ordered Edward Snowden to surrender $4.2 million in book profits from his memoir "Permanent Record" due to not submitting the manuscript for government review before publishing. Snowden must also relinquish profits from unauthorized paid speeches and potential future profits from book adaptations. The government argues that Snowden breached secrecy agreements by publishing the book without review. Snowden's team claims the government's interpretation of the agreements is overly broad and would restrict future discussions.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher on stimulus, hopes of easing curbs
summary: Australian shares closed 1% higher, rebounding from a 2% drop in the previous session, driven by a proposed $1.5 billion stimulus package and hopes for easing COVID-19 restrictions. The S&P/ASX 200 index finished at 5,872.9. US stimulus talks also boosted sentiment, with Wall Street posting an upbeat close. Easing of border restrictions between Queensland and New South Wales and low new daily cases in Victoria also contributed to the market's gain.

site_title: Cathay open to employee ideas for restructuring plan
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd is open to employee ideas for its restructuring plan, following a newspaper advertisement by the Hong Kong Aircrew Officers Association (HKAOA) to drum up public support. The airline has declined to apply for government employment subsidies, fueling worries of layoffs. Cathay has been in talks with employee groups, including the HKAOA, and has welcomed all ideas for consideration in its planning. A restructuring plan is due to be announced in the fourth quarter, with pilots potentially offering concessions such as temporary salary cuts or unpaid leave.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end choppy September with a whimper
summary: European stocks closed nearly flat on September 30, 2020, after a choppy month, with the Stoxx 600 ending 0.1% lower and euro zone stocks slipping 0.3%. US stocks rose 1% on hopes of a COVID-19 relief package, lifting Europe out of the red. The third quarter ended nearly flat, with a 1.5% decline in September due to concerns over a second COVID-19 wave and Brexit uncertainty.

site_title: TikTok will be shut down if Oracle deal fails to meet US security needs
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin stated that if Oracle's deal for TikTok cannot meet US security requirements, the app will be shut down. The requirements include holding all code in the US, with Oracle responsible for rebuilding and sanitizing the code. Mnuchin emphasized that the deal must satisfy all US requirements to be successful.

site_title: Australia: Shares track Wall Street higher, set to snap 3-day losing streak
summary: Australian shares rose 0.9% in early trade, snapping a three-day losing streak, driven by a positive US session and easing restrictions in major states. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained, led by mining stocks, which climbed 2% after iron ore futures soared. Prime Minister Scott Morrison is set to announce A$1.3 billion in grants to manufacturers to revive the economy.

site_title: Shopee, Visa strike five-year regional partnership, target MSMEs
summary: Shopee and Visa have formed a five-year regional partnership to provide greater value, convenience, and security for shoppers and merchants in Southeast Asia. The tie-up aims to incentivize micro, small, and medium enterprises (MSMEs) to digitalize their businesses and adopt digital payments through Visa. Co-branded credit cards will be launched across selected markets, and Shopee will deepen its relationship with Visa's CyberSource platform to support transaction processing and fraud detection. The partnership is expected to support small businesses in the region as they recover and look towards future growth.

site_title: GIC, MassMutual to buy Blackstone's 36% stake in UK insurer Rothesay Life
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC and US-based mutual life insurer MassMutual have agreed to acquire Blackstone's 36% stake in UK specialist annuity provider Rothesay Life for an undisclosed sum. The deal values Rothesay at £5.75 billion and will make GIC and MassMutual equal 49% shareholders. The trio first invested in Rothesay in 2013, and the company has since grown its assets under management to £56 billion. Completion of the transaction is subject to regulatory approvals.

site_title: Gold gains on US dollar slide, hopes for US stimulus
summary: Gold prices rose 0.7% to $1,898.79 per ounce, boosted by a weakening US dollar and optimism over US stimulus talks. The dollar index fell 0.2% against rivals, making gold cheaper for investors holding other currencies. Spot gold has gained over 25% this year, driven by stimulus measures and a hedge against inflation. Market participants await US job data for clues on the economy's recovery pace, with some analysts warning that strong jobs data could make gold less appealing.

images.alt_text: Gold rose on Thursday, as an easing dollar and signs of progress in talks for fresh US stimulus measures bolstered the metal's appeal.

site_title: Singapore to allow visitors from Australia, Vietnam from Oct 8
summary: Singapore will lift border restrictions for visitors from Australia (excluding Victoria state) and Vietnam starting October 8. The decision is based on the countries' low risk of Covid-19 importation, with Vietnam having zero local cases and Australia at a low incidence rate. Visitors will need to undergo a swab test upon arrival and comply with other requirements, including activating the TraceTogether app. Singapore citizens, permanent residents, and long-term pass holders returning from these countries will also be able to take a Covid-19 test upon arrival.

site_title: Google unveils new Pixel handsets with 5G wireless
summary: Google unveiled two new Pixel handsets with 5G wireless capability, the Pixel 5 starting at $699 and the Pixel 4a 5G at $499. The phones will be available from October 15 in the US and other markets. The announcement puts Google ahead of Apple in the 5G smartphone race, with a competitively priced device. Google's Pixel handsets showcase the Android mobile system and offer powerful cameras and integrated artificial intelligence. The launch comes as the global smartphone market struggles due to the pandemic-induced economic crisis.

site_title: Seattle sets minimum wage for Lyft, Uber drivers
summary: Seattle has set a minimum wage of $16.39 per hour for Uber and Lyft drivers, the second US city to implement such a measure after New York in 2019. The move aims to provide drivers with fair pay and a safety net, but ride-hailing companies Uber and Lyft have criticized it as potentially destroying thousands of jobs and driving them out of the city. The policy will take effect from January.

site_title: Malaysia's FGV disappointed with US ban on its palm oil products
summary: Malaysia's palm oil producer FGV Holdings Bhd has expressed disappointment over the US ban on its products, citing allegations of forced labor and human rights abuses. The US Customs and Border Protection (CBP) issued the ban after a year-long investigation, which found abuse, deception, and physical violence. FGV claims to have taken steps to address the issues since 2015, but the ban is expected to have a minimal impact on total US imports of palm oil products. The company will continue to engage with the CBP to clear its name.

images.alt_text: Malaysian palm oil producer FGV Holdings Bhd has taken steps to fix allegations that it uses forced labour and is disappointed with the United States' ban on imports of its products over the claims, the company said on Thursday.

site_title: Singtel launches S$3 million package to foster digital inclusion
summary: Singtel launches a S$3 million initiative to foster digital inclusion, focusing on senior citizens and traditional SMEs in Singapore. The program includes transforming Senior Activity Centres into digital hubs, providing digital skills training to over 10,000 seniors, and offering digital consultations and solutions to 6,000 SMEs. The initiative aims to bridge the digital gap and help seniors and SMEs improve their quality of life and competitiveness.

site_title: US Q2 contraction sharpest in at least 73 years
summary: The US economy suffered its sharpest contraction in at least 73 years, with a 31.4% annualized decline in the second quarter due to coronavirus disruptions. This is the deepest drop in output since the government started keeping records in 1947. Despite this, economists predict a record 25% annual expansion in the third quarter. The labor market has shown signs of a gradual rebound, with 749,000 jobs added in September, but the persistent spread of the coronavirus and stalemate over federal aid remain challenges.

site_title: Analysts, investors cheer Keppel's O&M review
summary: Keppel Corp's O&M review has been well-received by analysts and investors, with shares rising 3.5% to S$4.45 on Wednesday. The review identified S$17.5 billion in monetizable assets, and DBS analyst Ho Pei Hwa believes the worst is over for Keppel, with operational improvements expected to drive a re-rating. Other analysts, including CGS-CIMB and OCBC, also upgraded Keppel to "buy" with price targets ranging from S$5.50 to S$6.46.

site_title: Link Asean Pandemic Recovery Fund to sustainability
summary: The Asean Pandemic Recovery Fund, set to launch in November, should be linked to the region's climate and sustainability commitments, according to experts. This would catalyze institutional investment in green infrastructure, building resilience against natural disasters and reducing high-emission development pathways. Key steps include establishing common definitions for green activities, adopting existing green standards, and adopting a blended finance approach to share ESG risks between the private and public sectors. Singapore is urged to take a leadership role in coordinating member states and establishing standardized ESG risk management frameworks.

site_title: IndoAgri Brazil JVs propose to reorganise and consolidate sugar assets, operations
summary: IndoAgri's joint ventures in Brazil have proposed reorganizing and consolidating their sugar assets and operations. The joint ventures, Companhia Mineira de Açúcar e Álcool Participações (CMAA) and Canápolis Holding, aim to form a single legal structure. CMAA will own the mills, while a newly-incorporated entity, Strebinger Participações, will hold the land. IndoAgri Brazil will retain a 36.21% stake in both entities, with CMAA having a 35% stake in CMAA and 30% in Canápolis. The reorganization will enable operating and management synergies due to the close proximity of the mills.

site_title: Japan's business sentiment perks up as hit from pandemic begins to ease
summary: Japan's business sentiment has improved, rising to minus 27 in September, the lowest level since June 2009, according to the Bank of Japan's "tankan" survey. This marks the first sign of improvement in 11 quarters, offering hope for Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's administration to revive the economy. Manufacturers and non-manufacturers expect business conditions to improve three months ahead, and big firms plan to raise capital expenditure by 1.4%. The economic recovery is expected to remain modest due to ongoing fears of a second wave of infections.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai, South Korea, Taipei: Markets closed for public holiday
summary: Financial markets in Hong Kong, Shanghai, South Korea, and Taipei are closed on October 1, 2020, due to public holidays.

site_title: Keeping the magic of filmmaking alive
summary: Singapore's filmmaking industry has faced a heavy blow from the pandemic, but three film producers, Nelson Mok, Fran Borgia, and Huang Junxiang, are leading the charge to revive it. They're pushing ahead with theatrical releases, pitching for film festivals, and working on remote post-production to keep the magic of filmmaking alive.

site_title: Food industry executives launch plant-based meat startup Next Gen
summary: German entrepreneur Timo Recker and a former Country Foods executive have teamed up to launch Next Gen, a plant-based meat startup in Singapore. Next Gen has secured US$2.2 million in seed funding, provided by its founder and CEO. This marks the second time Recker has founded a plant-based meat company, following the acquisition of LikeMeat by Livekindly co. earlier this year.

site_title: Singapore's electricity tariffs to rise 1.83 S cents per kWh in Q4
summary: Singapore's electricity tariffs will rise by 1.83 Singapore cents per kWh from October 1 to December 31, with a 9.3% increase for households. The tariff hike is due to higher energy costs, mainly from imported natural gas, and is the lowest in the last three years. The average monthly electricity bill for four-room HDB flats will increase by S$7.01 before GST. The price increase is based on quarterly reviews by the Energy Market Authority, which sets guidelines for the industry regulator.

site_title: CapitaLand Retail China Trust to add office and industrial assets
summary: CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) plans to expand its investment strategy to include office and industrial assets, offering greater access to a larger pool of investment targets and reducing tenant concentration risk. The diversification aims to provide a balanced and stable rental revenue, enhancing CRCT's ability to deliver stable and sustainable distributions to unitholders. This move is expected to bring attractive yields and increased capital appreciation potential, with a focus on long-term investment in China, Hong Kong, and Macau.

site_title: Brent pares losses, US crude up on stimulus hopes
summary: Global benchmark Brent crude pared losses on Wednesday, rising 8 cents to $40.95 a barrel, amid hopes for a US economic stimulus deal that would support the market. The US House of Representatives is poised to vote on a $2.2 trillion Democratic coronavirus bill, with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin expressing optimism for a breakthrough. This temporary strength is lending support to the market, with US crude prices up 93 cents to $40.22 a barrel.

site_title: Oei Hong Leong sues Raffles Education over proposed stake purchase
summary: Tycoon Oei Hong Leong has sued Raffles Education Corp (REC) over its plan to raise its stake in a Chinese property firm. Oei Hong Leong, who owns 13.05% of REC, is seeking to inspect certain documents related to the proposed acquisition and prevent the company from holding a shareholders' meeting to vote on the deal. REC's shareholders approved the acquisition with 78.6% in favor, and the company intends to defend Oei Hong Leong's lawsuit "vigorously".

site_title: Teckwah privatisation offer turns unconditional
summary: Teckwah Industrial Corporation has accepted an unconditional offer from Clementine Investments to take the company private, with the investment firm now owning 90.76% of the shares. The offer was initially conditional on reaching a 90% stake, and the company's shares will be suspended from trading as of the close of the offer. The offer price is 65 Singapore cents per share, with the closing date now set for October 13.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, Sembmarine, Keppel, New Silkroutes, CRCT
summary: Key developments in Singapore's stock market include: Singtel's CEO retirement and appointment of Yuen Kuan Moon, Sembmarine's possible O&M merger, Keppel Corp's asset monetization and strategic review, and New Silkroutes' CEO and finance director assisting the police force in investigations. Additionally, CRCT is expanding its investment strategy, while Indofood Agri Resources reorganizes its sugar assets in Brazil.

site_title: PE firm General Atlantic to invest in Reliance's retail arm
summary: Reliance Industries Ltd has secured a 36.75 billion rupee (S$683 million) investment from private equity firm General Atlantic for a 0.84% stake in its retail arm. The deal gives Reliance Retail a pre-money valuation of 4.29 trillion rupees, as the company expands its e-commerce venture and diversifies from its mainstay oil-and-gas business. This investment underscores growing interest in Reliance's plans and marks the latest addition to its retail arm's funding, which now totals around US$2.3 billion.

site_title: Anthem to pay nearly US$40m to settle data breach probe
summary: Anthem, the second-largest US health insurer, agreed to pay nearly $40 million to settle a data breach probe following a 2015 cyber-attack that compromised 80 million records. The company attributed the attack to a state-sponsored criminal group, stating it did not violate the law. The FBI and FireEye investigation found no evidence of resulting fraud. Anthem has committed to enhanced data security measures, aligning with its ongoing focus on protecting information.

site_title: HDB resale prices rise 1.4%: flash data
summary: Resale prices for Housing Board flats in Singapore rose 1.4% in the third quarter, reaching 133.7 on the resale price index. This marks a significant improvement from the previous quarters, with the market outperforming expectations. Experts attribute the increase to stimulus measures and past property curbs, which may have prevented buyers from overleveraging and selling flats at low prices. The HDB will release final figures on October 23, with 9,300 BTO flats set to be offered in November.

site_title: Insults and interruptions mar first Trump-Biden debate
summary: US President Donald Trump and Democratic rival Joe Biden clashed in a chaotic first presidential debate, marked by personal insults and interruptions. Trump repeatedly tried to goad Biden, claiming Democrats were trying to steal the election and refused to condemn white supremacist groups. Biden focused on Trump's record on the coronavirus pandemic, healthcare, and the US economy. The debate was seen as a sign of the contentious campaign ahead, with Trump's aggressive tactics drawing criticism.

images.alt_text: President Trump (left) and Mr Biden during the first debate in Cleveland, Ohio, on Tuesday. The two White House contenders talked over each other in a breathtaking political brawl.

site_title: Singapore, as a top financial hub, should ride blockchain wave
summary: Singapore, a top financial hub, is poised to capitalize on the blockchain wave, transforming its capital markets and maintaining its competitiveness. Blockchain technology offers efficiency, security, and transparency, automating transactions and reducing intermediaries. This will enable lower costs and faster settlement, attracting digital-asset exchanges and investors. The Monetary Authority of Singapore supports this shift with a pro-blockchain stance and regulatory framework, positioning Singapore for a slice of the global digital-assets trading market.

site_title: MediShield Life must be sustainable in the long run
summary: Singapore's MediShield Life scheme, introduced in 2015, is set to undergo premium hikes, sparking concerns about affordability, particularly for older policyholders. The proposed enhancements aim to expand benefits, including higher annual claim limits and mental health coverage, but may be offset by increased premiums. The scheme faces challenges, including rising healthcare costs, an ageing population, and overuse of care. To ensure long-term sustainability, MediShield Life must adopt a preventive approach, focusing on screenings, counselling, and lifestyle changes, rather than just treating illnesses.

site_title: Tower Transit edges out SMRT to win S$1.03b Bulim and Sembawang-Yishun bus packages
summary: Tower Transit Singapore (TTS) has won a S$1.03 billion, five-year contract for 56 bus routes in Singapore, edging out SMRT. The contract, which includes routes previously operated by SMRT, will begin in the second quarter of 2021. TTS demonstrated a strong commitment to enhancing inclusivity and commuter experience, with plans to hire more people with disabilities and recruit more Singaporeans. SMRT employees involved in the routes will be offered jobs by TTS, with employment terms not worse than those set out in their current agreement.

site_title: China's manufacturing sector continues to grow
summary: China's manufacturing sector continued to grow in September, with the official manufacturing Purchasing Manager's Index (PMI) at 51.5, up from 51.0 in August. A private survey also showed manufacturing activity expanding, with the Caixin/Markit PMI at 53.0. This marks the seventh consecutive month of positive economic activity. The growth is attributed to strong demand and supply, with orders rapidly increasing as the epidemic's impact fades. China's economy is expected to grow around 2% this year, avoiding a recession.

site_title: US bans imports from Malaysian palm oil company FGV
summary: The US has banned imports of palm oil from Malaysian company FGV Holdings, citing allegations of forced labor and human rights abuses. A year-long investigation by the US Customs and Border Protection agency revealed signs of forced labor, including abuse of vulnerable workers, deception, and physical violence. The ban, which came into effect immediately, follows similar allegations against other suppliers in the industry. Rights groups have long raised concerns about labor and human rights abuses in the palm oil industry, particularly in Malaysia.

site_title: Singapore sees modest monthly growth in August visitor numbers, hotel room revenue
summary: Singapore's tourism sector saw a 30.3% increase in international visitor numbers in August, with 8,910 visitors, compared to 6,840 in July and 1.74 million in the year-ago period. Hotel room revenue rose to S$58 million, but remained 84.9% lower than in August 2019. A significant jump in arrivals from China and South-east Asia, particularly Indonesia, contributed to the increase. Despite the modest growth, the industry still faces challenges due to the COVID-19 pandemic and international border controls.

site_title: Amazon to take Citigroup's office space in Singapore
summary: Amazon plans to lease three floors at Asia Square Tower 1 in Singapore, covering about 90,000 square feet, as part of its expansion in the country. The move comes as Chinese tech rivals, including Tencent Holdings, Alibaba Group Holding, and ByteDance, are also expanding in Singapore. Citigroup, currently the building's largest tenant, is trimming its office space due to its lease expiring soon. Amazon will move staff into the new offices early next year, and the lease is expected to last more than five years.

site_title: Shell to cut up to 9,000 jobs as virus accelerates overhaul
summary: Royal Dutch Shell Plc plans to cut up to 9,000 jobs as part of its restructuring efforts to focus on low-carbon energy amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The company expects sustainable annual cost savings of $2-2.5 billion by the end of 2022. CEO Ben van Beurden stated that Shell needs to be a "simpler, more streamlined, more competitive organisation" to remain competitive. The move reflects the shift to cleaner energy and lower sales in the third quarter, with oil-product volumes down 4-5 million barrels a day from a year earlier.

site_title: New Silkroutes CEO Goh Jin Hian, finance director William Teo assisting with CAD probe
summary: New Silkroutes Group CEO Goh Jin Hian and finance director William Teo are assisting the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) with investigations into possible false trading and market rigging. The allegations involve past share buy-backs and acquisitions of shares. Goh and Teo have not been arrested or charged, and their passports have been retained by the CAD. The company has stated that no charges have been made against the named parties and that they are suitable to continue in their roles.

site_title: After Xi's climate surprise, no biodiversity announcement
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping urged global cooperation to protect the Earth's biodiversity at a UN summit, but stopped short of making a major environmental commitment. He defended the "UN-centred international system" and the Paris climate accord, while other major countries including China, Brazil, and Russia have not signed on to plans to slash air pollution and transition to sustainable food systems by 2030. The UN's review found nations will miss all 20 targets to halt nature loss, and the WWF's Living Planet Index showed wild populations have plummeted nearly 70% since 1970.

site_title: SFA awards tender for 9 HDB carpark rooftop sites for urban farming
summary: The Singapore Food Agency (SFA) has awarded tenders for nine HDB carpark rooftop sites for urban farming. Six companies and an individual were awarded the tenders, with annual rents ranging from S$20,000 to S$90,000. The sites will be used for farming vegetables and other food crops, and will collectively produce around 1,600 tonnes of vegetables annually. The move aims to contribute to Singapore's "30 by 30" goal of producing 30% of its nutritional needs by 2030, and is part of the SFA's strategy to make more spaces available for commercial farming.

site_title: Federal Reserve extends share buyback ban on US banks into Q4
summary: The Federal Reserve has extended its ban on share buybacks by US banks into the fourth quarter, aiming to ensure they have sufficient capital to weather the coronavirus downturn. The ban, which applies to large banks with over $100 billion in assets, is part of a broader effort to support the banking system during the pandemic. The Fed has also capped dividend payments and tied them to recent income. The decision comes after the central bank conducted stress tests and found that the capital positions of large banks have remained strong.

site_title: FAA chief to put Boeing 737 MAX to the test
summary: US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) chief Steve Dickson is set to conduct a 2-hour evaluation flight of a Boeing 737 MAX aircraft, a key step towards the jet's approval to resume flying after two fatal crashes. Dickson, a former military and commercial pilot, will be joined by FAA and Boeing pilots on a flight from Seattle's King County International Airport. The test is a crucial milestone for the 737 MAX's return to service.

site_title: Covid-19 temporary relief changes come into effect
summary: Singapore's Covid-19 temporary relief framework changes came into effect on September 30, 2020, granting greater powers to government-appointed assessors of rental disputes and introducing mechanisms for parties to seek relief in specific situations. The amendments allow assessors to determine rent waivers in certain circumstances and provide relief for additional expenses, rent-free periods, and delayed delivery dates. Applications for relief must be submitted by May 31, 2021, and landlords or tenants with disputes over waived rent amounts can apply for an assessor's determination within 10 working days of receiving a tax authority's notice.

site_title: Singapore Aug bank lending falls for 6th straight session
summary: Singapore's bank lending in August fell for the sixth consecutive month, with business lending down 0.4% to S$423 billion. However, loans to the construction industry grew 0.8% to S$150 billion, while consumer loans rose 0.3% to S$255 billion. Total lending in August fell 1% year-over-year, marking the third consecutive weakening since June, driven by weaker business lending and shrinking consumer loans.

site_title: Home sales contracts hit record as low mortgage rates fuel housing rally
summary: US pending home sales surged 8.8% in August, reaching a record high, driven by low mortgage rates. This marks the fourth consecutive monthly gain, with pending sales jumping 24% compared to 2019. Analysts attribute the increase to low mortgage rates, which have fueled a housing rally as Americans seek more space. However, a shortage of homes and high unemployment threaten to derail the US economic recovery and affordability. Experts warn of a massive imbalance in the market, leading to further price increases and affordability challenges for buyers.

site_title: SunMoon posts net loss in Q1
summary: SunMoon Food Company reported a net loss of S$122,000 in the first quarter ended June 30, 2020, due to disruptions caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. Revenue rose to S$8.5 million, driven by expansion of product offerings in China markets. The company did not declare a dividend and plans to control costs, streamline supply chain management, and expand its agri-product segment to recover from the pandemic's impact.

site_title: Politics and practicality behind my move to become German-British
summary: A British citizen has been granted German citizenship, becoming a dual citizen 75 years after the end of World War II. The decision, made in August, was motivated by a desire to maintain European freedom of movement and demonstrate interest in a prosperous, integrated Europe. The process was smoother and less costly than the British approach, and the author believes it will set an example for future migration and integration. The move is seen as a positive step for the UK economy and the National Health Service, and the author hopes to harmonize German-British naturalization rules in the future.

site_title: Chinese regulators establish countercyclical capital buffer mechanism
summary: China's central bank and banking regulator have established a countercyclical capital buffer mechanism to prevent systemic financial risks. The mechanism will assess and adjust requirements regularly, effective immediately. This move aims to address concerns about financial stability, particularly in the context of China's slowing GDP growth. The mechanism is part of efforts to mitigate systemic risks and ensure financial stability in the face of global economic uncertainties.

site_title: FAA chief pleased with Boeing 737 MAX test flight
summary: US Federal Aviation Administrator Steve Dickson expressed satisfaction with a 737 MAX test flight, stating he "liked what he saw." The test, part of the FAA's recertification process, came after two crashes in 2019 killed 346 people. Dickson noted that while the MAX "responded well" during the two-hour test, more work is needed to recertify the jet. The FAA's next steps include reviewing public comments and finalizing pilot training. European Union air safety chief Patrick Ky previously stated the MAX could receive certification by the end of the year.

site_title: Micron yet to obtain new licences to sell to Huawei, pressuring sales
summary: Micron Technology Inc, a major maker of DRAM chips, has not yet obtained new licenses to sell to Huawei, a Chinese company under US restrictions, cutting its sales for the next two quarters. Huawei accounted for 10% of Micron's sales in the fiscal fourth quarter, but a new round of restrictions halted sales in September. Micron has applied for new licenses and expects to shift sales to other smartphone customers by the fiscal second quarter, with revenue jumping 24% to $6.06 billion in the quarter.

site_title: BlackRock, Aberdeen push for more women executives in Australia
summary: Australian investment firms BlackRock and Aberdeen are urging companies to appoint at least 40% of women to executive roles by 2030, with the goal of achieving 50% representation. Currently, only about a third of management roles are held by women. The firms, managing over $712 billion, have committed to pressing companies to set clear targets for achieving the goal, citing a financial risk of failing to consider 50% of the population for leadership positions. The move comes amid growing investor focus on corporate culture and a need for action to address slow progress on gender diversity.

site_title: Temasek's US$2.75b bonds oversubscribed
summary: Temasek Financial Limited priced an oversubscribed US$2.75 billion three-tranche deal of guaranteed long-dated bonds, with the 50-year bond priced at 2.5% and the 30.5-year bond priced at 2.25%. The bonds attracted a diverse investor base, with 55% of demand coming from fund managers and pension funds. The 50-year bond, Temasek's longest tenor debt yet, was issued below par and has a yield-to-maturity of 2.525% per annum.

images.alt_text: Temasek Financial (I) Limited (TFin-I) has priced an oversubscribed US$2.75 billion three-tranche deal of guaranteed long-dated bonds, drawing orders from a diverse investor base.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription, exceeding expectations. US stocks opened lower due to fresh tariffs on Canada by President Trump. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in H2, mirroring H1 losses. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for its £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case involving 285 trillion rupiah. OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, is a former DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and PBOC are set to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Philippine government seeks 540b peso budget support from central bank
summary: The Philippine government has requested 540 billion pesos (S$15.26 billion) in funding support from the central bank to finance measures to combat the economic impacts of the coronavirus crisis. This request comes as the World Bank predicts a 6.9% contraction of the Philippine economy this year, worse than the government's projected 5.5% decline. The central bank has already agreed to buy 300 billion pesos worth of government securities to help the country deal with the fallout of Covid-19.

site_title: MOM, IHRP to strengthen HR profession in Singapore
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) and Institute of HR Professionals (IHRP) in Singapore will work together to strengthen the HR profession through sector-specific HR playbooks, the national Human Capital Diagnostic Tool (HCDT), and HR capability building. Over 1,000 companies have used HCDT, with a goal of 5,000 assessments by 2025. The HR Industry Transformation Advisory Panel's recommendations aim to build HR capabilities and relevant skills for HR professionals, with plans to integrate HR capability building into enterprise support schemes and provide additional support for businesses implementing workforce strategies.

site_title: Singapore's allure as asset management hub set to continue
summary: Singapore's asset management industry remains a bright spot despite the pandemic, with total assets managed by Singapore-based asset managers surging 15.7% to S$4 trillion in 2019. The Variable Capital Companies (VCC) framework and the country's reputational strength continue to attract asset managers worldwide. The industry's resilience is attributed to its strong market performance, net inflows from investors, and a growing pipeline of talent. Despite challenges from abroad, Singapore is expected to maintain its position as a leading asset management hub, with the government's efforts to develop the country as an Asia-Pacific enterprise financing and infrastructure hub.

site_title: CapitaLand launches 2030 Sustainability Master Plan
summary: CapitaLand launches its 2030 Sustainability Master Plan, aiming to triple its sustainable finance portfolio to S$6 billion and significantly reduce carbon emissions by 78% by 2030. The plan focuses on three themes: building portfolio resilience and resource efficiency, facilitating future adaptive communities, and accelerating innovation in sustainability. The group plans to implement a green lease programme, reduce energy consumption to 35%, and boost renewable energy use to 35% over the next decade.

site_title: US airlines await roller coaster aid developments in Washington
summary: US airlines are awaiting developments in Washington over a fresh coronavirus aid package, hoping to avoid mass furloughs of tens of thousands of workers. Despite Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin's progress with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, a deal has not been reached, and airlines are still seeking $25 billion in payroll support. If no deal is reached, American Airlines and United Airlines will furlough 19,000 and 12,000 workers, respectively, on Thursday. Industry experts remain hopeful but not confident that a deal will be reached before the deadline.

site_title: Hong Kong's Lam hails 'return to peace', anniversary protests banned
summary: Hong Kong's leader, Carrie Lam, welcomed the city's "return to peace" after China's security law helped quash last year's democracy movement. Thousands of police were on standby during National Day celebrations, which were marked by grievances among Hong Kong residents worried about Beijing's crackdown on opponents. The city's anniversary protests were banned, highlighting the ongoing tensions between the two entities.

site_title: Thai tycoon bets on data centre demand boom from pandemic
summary: Thai billionaire Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi is investing 7.3 billion baht in a new data centre in Bangkok, driven by the pandemic's accelerated digital transformation and high demand for data storage services. The data centre, set to begin operation early next year, will cater to companies and individual consumers, and is expected to grow at a rate of over 20% per year. This investment is part of a broader trend of Thai companies, including Frasers Property and WHA Corp, increasing investment in technology and automation to attract local and global companies.

site_title: David Attenborough leads call for world to invest US$500b a year to protect nature
summary: British broadcaster David Attenborough calls for a global investment of $500 billion annually to protect nature, citing the planet's "grave jeopardy" due to climate change and species extinction. The appeal is backed by over 130 organizations, including Fauna & Flora International, amid UN-led efforts to halt biodiversity loss and redirect financing away from polluting industries. The initiative aims to reverse catastrophic biodiversity loss, with time running out, as UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres warns of a "war on nature" and the destruction of Earth's web of life.

site_title: Singapore tech investments on track to rival 2019 numbers: PwC
summary: Singapore's tech startups raised S$3.3 billion in capital over the first half of 2020, on track to rival 2019's S$6.5 billion, according to a PwC report. Despite the global pandemic, investments in tech startups remained steady, with notable funding for health and biotech sub-sectors. Fintech continued to be a stronghold, and later-stage funding, including Series A and beyond, saw significant growth. Experts expect the ecosystem to continue maturing, with a focus on resilient business models and emerging trends in healthcare and biotechnology.

site_title: US economy contracts at 31.4% in Q2
summary: The US economy contracted at a 31.4% annualized rate in the second quarter, the sharpest decline in at least 73 years, due to disruptions from the coronavirus. This is the deepest drop in output since the government started keeping records in 1947. The Commerce Department confirmed this in its third estimate of GDP. The contraction was previously reported at a 31.7% pace.

site_title: Facebook overhauls Instagram messaging, enabling cross-app chats with Messenger
summary: Facebook is replacing Instagram's direct messaging service with its Messenger app, enabling cross-app chats and introducing features like custom emojis, themes, and disappearing messages. The update will begin in a few unspecified countries and be rolled out globally soon. The goal is to build a single messaging platform across Facebook's services, including WhatsApp, with the aim of integrating end-to-end encryption. The move may raise antitrust concerns, as regulators have previously scrutinized Facebook's acquisitions of Instagram and WhatsApp.

site_title: DPM Heng to speak on progress in tackling Covid-19 on Monday
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat will deliver a ministerial statement on Monday about Singapore's progress in tackling Covid-19, fiscal position, and strategies for emerging stronger from the crisis. The statement will provide context for a Supplementary Supply Bill to implement previously-announced re-allocations of government funds. The bill will be debated by Parliament and will address additional Covid-19 support measures, following a general election in July. The full ministerial statement will be published on the Singapore Budget website.

site_title: Aoxin Q&M in talks with third party for 'possible transaction' of its wholly owned unit
summary: Aoxin Q&M Dental Group, a CATALIST-listed company, is in talks with a third party for a possible transaction involving its wholly owned subsidiary, Panjin Aoxin Quanmin Stomatology Hospital Co. The company has not made any decision or entered any agreement, and there is no certainty that the discussions will progress beyond the current stage. Aoxin Q&M Dental's shares last traded at 13.5 Singapore cents.

site_title: US firms added 749,000 jobs in September
summary: US companies added 749,000 jobs in September, a private report showed, with payrolls increasing after an upwardly revised 481,000 rise in August. The labour market is gradually recovering, but still 10 million below its pre-pandemic level due to the persistent spread of the coronavirus. The economic rebound depends on government control of the virus and passage of additional aid.

site_title: Sembmarine shares rise 1.4% in speculative play on firm's potential merger with Keppel
summary: Sembcorp Marine shares rose 1.4% on Wednesday after investors speculated about a potential merger with Keppel Corporation's offshore and marine (O&M) segment. Keppel's Vision 2030 update and CEO Loh Chin Hua's statement that "all options are available" sparked optimism, with analysts expecting a strategic review of the O&M segment. Sembmarine shares reached an intra-day high of 15.3 cents before closing at 14.6 cents. Analysts believe a merger is imminent, with one possibility being Keppel's divestment of its O&M business.

site_title: Trump has sold off America's credibility for his personal gain
summary: US President Donald Trump has undermined America's credibility in foreign policy, prioritizing personal gain over national interests. Last year, a phone call with Ukraine's government revealed Trump's associates asked officials to deliver on his political interests in exchange for military aid. Trump was impeached for this abuse of power. This incident is part of a pattern of Trump's personal priorities corrupting American foreign policy, with implications for future US interests.

site_title: Travel slump threatens 46 million jobs, aviation group says
summary: The Air Transport Action Group (ATAG) predicts that the travel slump due to the coronavirus may cost up to 46 million jobs globally, with 4.8 million aviation workers and over half of the 87.7 million total jobs supported by the sector at risk. Airlines are urging governments to lift travel curbs and roll out rapid Covid-19 testing at airports, citing a slow recovery. The warning was made after airlines cut their 2020 traffic forecast amid renewed outbreaks and travel restrictions.

site_title: Indonesia central bank relaxes short-term liquidity loan rules for banks
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, has relaxed rules for commercial banks offering short-term liquidity loans, setting the interest rate at 4.75% plus 100 basis points. The measures aim to strengthen the bank's role as lender of the last resort while maintaining good corporate governance. This is the fourth interest rate cut by the bank this year in response to the coronavirus pandemic. The widened criteria for collateral will allow banks to use a broader range of assets for these loans.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore-based asset managers' assets under management (AUM) increased 15.7% last year, according to a MAS survey. Tech investments in Singapore are on track to rival the S$6.5 billion raised in 2019, despite pandemic headwinds. Temasek priced its longest US$1 billion 50-year bond at 2.5%. Wirecard will cease payment services in Singapore and return customer funds by October 14. Changes to Singapore's Covid-19 relief framework took effect, including greater powers for assessors. The STI fell 0.2% after a "train wreck" US presidential debate.

images.alt_text: Total assets managed by Singapore-based asset managers grew 15.7 per cent to hit S$4 trillion in 2019, compared with a jump of 5.4 per cent previously.

site_title: Volvo parent to bring car-sharing subscription service to Europe
summary: Zhejiang Geely's Volvo parent, Lynk & Co, is launching a car-sharing subscription service in Europe, starting in Germany, France, and four other countries. Members pay 500 euros (S$801) per month, covering insurance and maintenance. The service aims to differentiate from others by offering month-to-month memberships. Lynk & Co anticipates having over 10,000 members by next year, with plans to increase to over 100,000 as the brand expands across the continent. The service is part of Geely's efforts to offer alternatives to car ownership, following other companies' mixed results in the market.

site_title: Caesars to buy William Hill for £2.9b in sports-betting drive
summary: Caesars Entertainment agreed to buy William Hill for £2.9 billion, expanding in the US sports-betting market. The US group will sell William Hill's UK operations and integrate the US business into Caesars with minimal job losses. If UK assets are not sold to Apollo, an auction process will be launched. The deal aims to capitalize on the fast-growing US sports-betting market.

site_title: Wirecard to cease payment services in Singapore, return funds to customers
summary: Wirecard's entities in Singapore, Wirecard SG, will cease payment services by October 14, returning all customers' funds. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) made this decision due to Wirecard's inability to continue processing payments for a significant number of merchants. Customers are encouraged to make alternative arrangements, as credit card payments and pre-paid card usage will be affected. Other e-payment services remain available.

site_title: US: Wall St gains at open after upbeat economic data
summary: US stocks rose at the open on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average increasing 0.23% to 27,514.64, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gaining 0.17% and 0.07% respectively. The upbeat data raised hopes for a domestic economic rebound, but investors remained cautious ahead of a tough election race.

site_title: Singapore private home prices up 0.8% in Q3 from previous quarter: URA flash estimate
summary: Singapore's private home prices rose 0.8% in Q3 from the previous quarter, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority's flash estimate. This follows a 0.3% increase in Q2. The increase was driven by non-landed properties in the Rest of Central Region and Outside of Central Region, as well as landed properties. The growth is attributed to HDB homeowners upgrading from BTO flats and demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf.

images.alt_text: The Urban Redevelopment Authority's (URA) flash estimate for the third quarter of this year showed that the overall price index for private homes in Singapore edged up 0.8 per cent over the preceding three months.

site_title: Total to increase investments in renewable energy production
summary: France's Total plans to increase investments in renewable energy production by 50% to $3 billion by 2030, aiming to become a major low-carbon power producer. The company expects to shrink oil product sales by 30% over the next decade, with electricity sales expected to reach 15% of revenue by 2030. Total aims to become one of the top five renewable power producers, competing with rivals like Iberdrola and Shell. The move diversifies the company's activities, increasing resilience and offsetting oil price volatility.

site_title: Electricity tariffs to rise 1.83c per kWh or 9.3% in Q4 on higher energy costs: SP Group
summary: Singapore's electricity tariffs will rise by an average of 1.83 cents per kWh (9.3%) from Oct 1 to Dec 31, mainly due to higher energy costs. The tariff increase affects households, with the average monthly bill for four-room HDB flats expected to rise by S$7.01. Despite the price hike, the revised tariff remains the lowest in the last three years. The price increase is based on quarterly reviews by the Energy Market Authority, which set guidelines for the industry regulator.

site_title: Keppel Reit prices S$150m subordinated perps at 3.15%, consolidate these with earlier tranche
summary: Keppel Reit priced S$150 million of fixed-rate subordinated perpetual securities at 3.15% and will consolidate these with an earlier tranche. The new securities will be issued on Oct 7 and listed on the Singapore bourse on or around Oct 8. Net proceeds will be used for financing or refinancing acquisitions and investments, as well as asset enhancement works, under Keppel Reit's S$1 billion multicurrency debt issuance programme, led by OCBC.

site_title: Britain's Morrisons creates 1,000 jobs to process Amazon orders
summary: Britain's Morrisons is creating over 1,000 jobs to process Amazon orders, expanding its capacity to meet increased demand during the Covid-19 pandemic. This move follows Amazon's expansion of its relationship with Morrisons, allowing Prime members to access the supermarket's full range on Amazon's website. The additional workers will process customer orders from over 50 stores across the UK, covering major cities and towns. This is part of a broader trend of the big four UK grocers adding capacity to their online home delivery operations.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.92 points to 1,504.82 on Wednesday, driven by higher volume. The gainers outnumbered losers 696 to 313, with the market closing at RM2.641 billion. The rally comes as investors look beyond recent US trade tensions, focusing on other factors such as mining and healthcare stocks.

site_title: CapitaLand Retail China Trust to diversify portfolio to include assets in office and industrial space
summary: CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) plans to diversify its portfolio to include assets in office and industrial space, moving beyond its focus on retail. The trust aims to invest in a diversified portfolio of income-producing real estate and related assets in China, Hong Kong, and Macau. This diversification is expected to provide greater access to attractive yields and capital appreciation potential, as well as reduce tenant concentration risk. The move is also expected to enhance the trust's ability to deliver stable and sustainable distributions to unitholders.

site_title: STI dips after 'train wreck' US presidential debate
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.2% after a "train wreck" US presidential debate, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 4.99 points to 2,466.62. Regional markets also declined, with the Nikkei 225 and Shanghai Composite falling 1.5% and 0.2% respectively. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.8% and Malaysia's KLCI added 0.06%. The decline was attributed to market volatility following the US presidential debate.

site_title: China preparing an antitrust investigation into Google: sources
summary: China is preparing to launch an antitrust investigation into Google, looking into allegations it has stifled competition by leveraging its dominance of the Android mobile operating system. The investigation was proposed by Huawei last year and is being reviewed by the State Council's antitrust committee. A decision may come as soon as October, and could be influenced by China's relationship with the US. China is also revamping its antitrust laws, which include increased fines and expanded criteria for judging market control.

site_title: ECB to consider inflation overshoot in echo of Fed strategy
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde suggests considering a Federal Reserve-style strategy allowing inflation to temporarily rise above the target. This could strengthen the bank's ability to stabilize the economy, as it raises inflation expectations and lowers real interest rates. The move is part of the ECB's strategic review, which also covers climate change and digitization. Lagarde's comments signal a possible change in the bank's goal, but she didn't comment on immediate policy changes.

site_title: Kitchen Culture ventures into fintech industry in partnership with Ooway Technology
summary: Kitchen Culture Holdings, a Catalist-listed kitchen equipment supplier, is partnering Ooway Technology to offer credit rating services and integrated supply chain finance solutions to merchants operating on DHgate.com in Hong Kong. The partnership aims to improve digital supply chain management in the China and ASEAN regions. Kitchen Culture will take a 30% stake in Ooway Technology, subject to shareholder approval, and will provide a 21.42% stake in its enlarged share capital. The deal is valued at S$23.9 million.

site_title: Hong Leong Asia unit to wind up after disposal of assets
summary: Hong Leong Asia's subsidiary, Airwell Air-Conditioning Technology, will dispose of assets for 141 million yuan (S$28.3 million) and wind up after the sale. The property in China, including land rights and facilities, is being sold to Taicang Loucheng High-tech Group. Airwell has been loss-making since 2012, with net losses of S$11 million and S$17.1 million in the last two years. The disposal is expected to result in a net gain of approximately 14 million yuan, with proceeds used to settle financial obligations. The move aims to improve the group's financial performance.

site_title: Singapore to unilaterally lift border restrictions for visitors from Australia and Vietnam from Oct 8
summary: Singapore will unilaterally lift border restrictions for visitors from Australia (excluding Victoria state) and Vietnam starting Oct 8. The decision is based on the two countries' successful control of the Covid-19 outbreak and low risk of importation. Visitors will need to take a swab test upon arrival and use the TraceTogether app during their stay. This move aims to resuscitate Changi Airport, which has been a crucial part of the Singapore economy, and signal to the world that Singapore is open for business.

site_title: Category winners of EY Entrepreneur Of The Year 2020 Singapore announced
summary: Three entrepreneurs have been named category winners in the 19th annual EY Entrepreneur Of The Year 2020 awards in Singapore. Richard Koh (financial technology), Eric Leong (industrial solutions), and Ian Ang (consumer products) were selected from 50 nominations. One of the winners will represent Singapore at the EY World Entrepreneur Of The Year award in 2021, with the winner to be announced on November 9. EY also honored Duong Ba Tran with the EY Asean Entrepreneurial Excellence award and Hong Leong Group with the EY Family Business Award of Excellence.

site_title: DPM Heng to make ministerial statement for upcoming debate on Covid-19 measures
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat will deliver a ministerial statement on Monday, outlining Singapore's progress in tackling Covid-19, the country's fiscal position, and strategies to emerge stronger. The statement will provide context for a Supplementary Supply Bill to implement previously-announced re-allocations of government funds. The statement will be delivered in Parliament at 1:30pm and the full text will be published on the Singapore Budget website afterwards.

site_title: Sunpower in strategic provider cooperation with Sichuan Yongxiang
summary: Sunpower Group, an environmental protection solutions provider, has entered a strategic cooperation agreement with Sichuan Yongxiang to solidify its position in the renewable energy industry. Under the agreement, Sunpower will supply key equipment or services for Sichuan Yongxiang's polycrystalline silicon projects, leveraging the latter's manufacturing and distribution capabilities for high-purity crystalline silicon and electronic grade polysilicon. This partnership aims to enhance Sunpower's offerings in the renewable energy sector.

site_title: Indonesia, Philippines well-placed for Asia's "Goldilocks" phase in 2021: report
