summary: Indonesia and the Philippines are well-positioned for Asia's "Goldilocks" phase of economic growth in 2021, according to a Morgan Stanley report. This phase is characterized by accelerating growth, rising inflation, and easy policy. The report notes that this trend is similar to 2003/04, 2005/07, 2009/10, and 2015/18, which were favorable for Asia, excluding Japan. The "Goldilocks" phase is seen as a sweet spot before macro stability risks prompt policymakers to tighten policies. Both Indonesia and the Philippines are considered better placed than their Asean neighbors in this environment.

site_title: OCBC partners SOCASH to offer cash withdrawal at over 1,500 shops
summary: OCBC has partnered with FINTECH startup SOCASH to provide its customers with cash withdrawal points at over 1,500 retail outlets, including supermarkets, convenience stores, and cafes. The service allows OCBC customers to withdraw cash digitally via the SOCASH app and select a nearby retailer to collect their money. This partnership aims to reduce reliance on traditional cash logistics processes and provide businesses with an alternative way to deposit cash into their corporate bank accounts.

site_title: Singapore's Covid-19 relief framework changes take effect, with more powers for assessors
summary: Singapore's Covid-19 relief framework has undergone changes, granting greater powers to government-appointed assessors of rental disputes. Assessors can now determine rent waivers in specific circumstances, such as maintenance or service charges, and landlords or tenants can apply for an assessor's determination within a set timeframe. Additionally, a new mechanism allows parties to seek relief in three situations related to Covid-19 delays or breaches in construction contracts, with applications due by May 31, 2021.

site_title: France's Veolia raises bid for Engie's Suez stake to 3.4b euros
summary: France's Veolia has raised its bid for a 29.9% stake in Suez owned by Engie to 3.4 billion euros, up from 2.9 billion euros. The offer, valued at 18 euros per share, is valid until the end of Wednesday. Veolia will only proceed with a full takeover bid for Suez if Engie agrees to the stake sale. The French finance ministry has urged Veolia to demonstrate a friendly approach to Suez, which has pushed back against the proposal. Suez shares rose 6.6% in early trading.

site_title: Europe: Stocks sapped by virus, US election worries
summary: European stocks declined 0.3% on Wednesday, tracking lower US Wall Street futures amid surging coronavirus cases and US presidential election concerns. Britain reported 7,143 new cases, while Germany considered tightening Covid-19 restrictions. However, optimism from German retail sales growth and China's solid factory activity offset losses. Defensive sectors like telecom and utilities helped limit declines, while growth-sensitive stocks like travel and banking fell.

site_title: GIC, MassMutual to buy Blackstone's 36% stake in UK insurer Rothesay Life
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC and US-based mutual life insurer MassMutual will acquire Blackstone's 36% stake in UK insurer Rothesay Life for an undisclosed sum, valuing Rothesay at £5.75 billion. The two companies will become equal 49% shareholders, with Rothesay continuing to provide bulk annuity solutions. The deal provides Rothesay with "exceptional long-term support" from leading institutional investors, and the UK insurer has seen significant growth in assets under management to £56 billion.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish higher
summary: Hong Kong shares closed higher on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.79% to 23,459.05, following factory data indicating China's economy is recovering from a pandemic-induced slowdown. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index slipped 0.20% and the Shenzhen Composite Index added 0.05%.

site_title: Australian regulator files suit against Allianz Australia over travel insurance sales
summary: Australia's corporate regulator, ASIC, has filed a lawsuit against Allianz Australia and AWP over alleged misleading sales of travel insurance products on Expedia websites. Between 2015 and 2018, the companies allegedly failed to disclose premium calculation methods and sold policies to ineligible customers. The ASIC is seeking monetary penalties against the companies. Allianz acknowledged the suit but declined further comment.

site_title: Silverlake Axis to liquidate wholly owned subsidiary in Japan
summary: Silverlake Axis, a MAINBOARD-listed fintech firm, announced that its wholly owned subsidiary, Silverlake Japan, will undergo a voluntary liquidation by its shareholder, effective October 1. The subsidiary provided system and business outsourcing services to Japanese banks and credit card companies. The liquidation process will not impact Silverlake Axis' net tangible assets or earnings per share for the 2021 financial year. The company's shares closed 1.7% lower on Wednesday at S$0.29.

site_title: Shophouses on Baghdad Street, Telok Ayer area up for sale
summary: Six shophouses, three in the Telok Ayer area and three on Baghdad Street, have been put up for sale in Singapore. The sites are zoned for commercial use, allowing both local and foreign buyers to purchase without additional buyer's stamp duty. The Telok Ayer shophouses, valued at S$31 million, are part of a portfolio of three conservation shophouses, while the Baghdad Street shophouses, valued at S$7.64 million, are up for sale as an entirety. Both sales are open to EOI until November 6 and 3, respectively, with immediate rental income available from fully-tenanted F&B establishments.

site_title: Hot stock: Sembmarine shares rise 2.8% as investors gain optimism on potential merger
summary: SembCorp Marine shares rose 2.8% after Keppel Corporation announced a strategic review of its offshore and marine (O&M) segment, including the possibility of a merger with rival SMM. Keppel's CEO stated that "all options" are available, including a merger or divestment. Analysts say investors are optimistic about a potential merger due to the need for Keppel to rightsize its operations and consolidate its yards. The review is expected to be completed by the end of the next three quarters, with SMM shares emerging as the most actively traded stock for the day.

site_title: Salesforce.com adapts its software for pandemic vaccine distribution
summary: Salesforce.com has adapted its software to aid in the distribution of pandemic vaccines. The company's Work.com for Vaccines platform will help track vaccine inventory, create online appointment portals, and monitor patient outcomes. This offering builds on previous tools for public health data analysis and contact tracing. Pricing for the new tools will be based on the unique requirements of each public agency or private healthcare organization, aiming to support the global effort to make vaccines widely available next year.

site_title: Sterling falls after Brexit bill opposed by EU passes UK Parliament
summary: Sterling falls after the UK Parliament approved the UK Internal Market Bill, which gives ministers the power to break the country's divorce agreement with the European Union. The bill, which was approved 340-256, passes to the House of Lords for debate. Despite initial concerns, market participants expect a Brexit deal, citing diminishing fears of a no-deal Brexit and the bill's temporary impact on negotiations. The British pound fell 0.3% versus the US dollar and 0.2% versus the euro following the bill's passage.

site_title: SFA awards tender for nine HDB carpark rooftop sites for urban farming
summary: The Singapore Food Agency (SFA) has awarded tenders for nine HDB carpark rooftop sites for urban farming. Six companies won the tenders, including IT Meng Landscape & Construction and Nature's International Commodity, which will pay annual rents ranging from S$20,000 to S$90,000. The sites will be used for farming vegetables and other food crops, with the potential to collectively produce around 1,600 tonnes of vegetables annually. This move aims to contribute to Singapore's "30 by 30" goal of producing 30% of its nutritional needs by 2030.

site_title: Etihad Airways yet to decide on future of its A380s: CEO
summary: Etihad Airways CEO Tony Douglas has stated that the airline is yet to decide on the future of its Airbus A380 fleet. Although passenger services have resumed, the A380s remain grounded due to the pandemic's impact on travel demand. Douglas believes the four-engined jet is "heavily handicapped" by its configuration and that smaller aircraft are more efficient and sustainable. He suggests that the retirement of A380s may accelerate globally, but has not specified when Etihad will make a decision on its A380s.

images.alt_text: Abu Dhabi's Etihad Airways is yet to make a decision on whether it ever resumes Airbus A380 flights, its chief executive officer (CEO) said.

site_title: Australia: Shares slump as Trump-Biden debate stokes caution
summary: Australian shares fell 2.3% on Wednesday, snapping a five-month winning streak, as investors tracked lower US stock futures following the first US presidential debate. The debate stoked caution and uncertainty ahead of the election, with US President Donald Trump casting doubt on accepting the election's outcome. The benchmark index lost 1.4% during the quarter, with miners and financials suffering major blows.

site_title: SoftBank's Fortress to put 60b yen in Japanese rental firm Leopalace21: Nikkei
summary: SoftBank's Fortress is set to invest 60 billion yen (S$778.2 million) in cash-strapped Japanese rental firm Leopalace21, providing both cash and debt to shore up its balance sheet. Leopalace21 has been struggling with stagnant apartment occupancy rates due to a construction scandal and weaker demand caused by the coronavirus outbreak. The investment is aimed at addressing the company's significant liabilities exceeding assets by 11.8 billion yen as of June.

site_title: Thailand eyes 50,000 foreign tourists in Q4, down 99.5%
summary: Thailand expects 50,000 foreign tourists in Q4 2020, down 99.5% from the previous year, with foreign tourist receipts at 4.5 billion baht. This is a significant decline from 6.74 million foreign tourists predicted for the year, down 83% from 2019. The tourism industry is seeking to gradually reopen to visitors and proposes allowing more foreign tourists from low-risk countries with no quarantine requirement. Next year's outlook remains uncertain, with predictions of 20 million foreign tourists in 2021.

images.alt_text: Thailand is expected to have 50,000 foreign tourists in the fourth quarter of 2020, down 99.5 per cent from a year earlier, an industry body said on Wednesday, as the country tries to support its battered economy by gradually reopening to visitors.

site_title: Thailand to consider fresh stimulus measures to revive economy
summary: Thailand is considering new stimulus measures to revive its economy, which has been impacted by the coronavirus pandemic. The government plans to offer tax incentives to middle and upper-income groups to boost consumption, in addition to cash handouts targeted at low-income groups. The measures, which may take effect in the fourth quarter, aim to cushion the blow from the pandemic, which has devastated tourism and manufacturing sectors. The central bank estimates the economy will take two years to return to pre-pandemic levels, prompting Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha to accelerate government spending.

site_title: Westgate, 313@somerset and Ang Mo Kio Hub among places visited by Covid-19 patients
summary: The Ministry of Health in Singapore has released a list of locations visited by Covid-19 patients while they were still infectious, including Westgate, 313@somerset, and Ang Mo Kio Hub. The list aims to inform others who were at the same locations at the same time, allowing them to monitor their health closely for two weeks. There were 23 new cases reported, with 16 migrant workers in dormitories being the majority, and 7 community cases, including 3 work permit holders. The number of new daily cases in the community has remained stable.

site_title: UK house prices post biggest annual increase since 2016
summary: UK house prices rose 5% in September, the largest annual gain since 2016, driven by a tax cut and post-lockdown demand. The average house price reached £226,129 (S$398,249). This contrasts with other parts of the economy, which remain struggling. Experts attribute the housing market's outperformance to a combination of pent-up demand and increased desire for larger homes as people work from home. However, analysts predict the boom will likely end as unemployment rises and aid packages expire.

site_title: Shell plans to cut up to 9,000 jobs in transition plan
summary: Royal Dutch Shell plans to cut up to 9,000 jobs, or 10% of its workforce, as part of a major overhaul to shift the oil and gas giant to low-carbon energy. The company aims to achieve annual savings of $2 billion to $2.5 billion by 2022. Shell's oil and gas production is expected to drop sharply in the third quarter due to the coronavirus pandemic and hurricanes. The company has already agreed to lay off 1,500 people and is targeting a total of 7,000 to 9,000 job cuts by the end of 2022.

site_title: Helen Reddy, singer of feminist anthem 'I Am Woman', dies at 78
summary: Singer Helen Reddy, known for the feminist anthem 'I Am Woman,' died at 78 in Los Angeles. Born in Australia, Reddy initially gained success in the US with 'I Don't Know How To Love Him' before 'I Am Woman' reached No 1 in 1972, launching her global stardom. She hosted a TV variety show and starred in films, becoming the world's top-selling female vocalist in 1973 and 1974. Reddy retired in 2002 due to dementia diagnosis in 2015. Her family said her voice will live on forever.

site_title: UK GDP collapsed slightly less than first thought in Q2
summary: Britain's economy shrank by 19.8% in Q2 2020 due to Covid-19 lockdown measures, a slightly smaller decline than initially estimated. This marks a record contraction in the second quarter. The UK's economy has since rebounded sharply since May, but Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey expects a 7-10% annual decline in Q3 GDP. Unemployment is set to rise, and some parts of the economy face Covid restrictions and headwinds from a recent surge in cases.

site_title: Vietnam tech investments soar in 2019 but dip in H1 2020
summary: Vietnam saw a 92% increase in tech investment value to $861 million in 2019, with late-stage deals accounting for the majority of capital invested. Despite a 22% drop in investment proceeds in the first half of 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic, Vietnam remains a hotspot for startup investments, particularly in education, healthcare, and financial services. Early-stage investment activities remained strong, with 98 deals worth less than $5 million. Investors from South Korea, Singapore, and Japan dominated the market, and Vietnam is expected to remain a top investment destination in the next 12 months.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower after Trump-Biden debate
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Wednesday, September 30, 2020, after the first US presidential debate between Joe Biden and Donald Trump turned into a shouting match. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 1.50% to 23,185.12, while the Topix index dropped 1.97% to 1,625.49. The decline was attributed to the heated debate, which traders considered a negative event for the market.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Wednesday after the first US presidential debate between Democrat Joe Biden and President Donald Trump, which turned into a shouting match.

site_title: UOB launches digital banking platform UOB Infinity for corporate clients
summary: UOB has launched UOB Infinity, a digital banking platform for corporate clients, starting with Singapore. The platform offers a customizable dashboard, real-time tracking of cross-border payments, and biometric login for secure transactions. Clients can manage domestic and cross-border banking activities, including payments and fund transfers, and receive notifications when payments are successfully credited. The move aims to increase corporate clients' use of digital banking services for better productivity and business performance, addressing concerns about the lack of real-time tracking for cross-border payments.

site_title: British finance chief in balancing act over virus plan
summary: UK Finance Minister Rishi Sunak faces a balancing act to pay for the government's emergency coronavirus response, which has led to record deficits and soaring debt. Total public debt reached £2.0 trillion (102% of GDP), prompting commentators to suggest a combination of taxation, inflation, spending cuts, and economic growth could help balance the books.

site_title: Singapore's tech investments on track to rival the S$6.5b raised in 2019: PwC
summary: Singapore's tech startups raised S$3.3 billion in capital in the first half of 2020, on track to rival the S$6.5 billion raised in 2019. Despite the global pandemic, investments in tech startups remained steady, with notable raises from companies like Grab and Ninja Van. The health and biotech sub-sectors saw significant growth, with investments more than doubling from 2019. The ecosystem is maturing, with increased investments in later stages, including Series A rounds and above.

site_title: HDB appoints to its board SAF commander, architect and ambassador
summary: The Singapore Housing and Development Board (HDB) has appointed three new board members to serve from October 1, 2020, to September 30, 2022. The new directors are Lee Yi-Jin, Commander of the Sixth Singapore Division, Singapore Armed Forces; Rita Soh, managing director of RDC Architects; and Tan Wah Yeow, non-resident ambassador to Norway. The HDB's chairman and several other directors were also reappointed for the new term.

site_title: Closing date for Teckwah's privatisation offer extended to Oct 13
summary: The closing date for Teckwah's privatisation offer has been extended to October 13 from September 30. Clementine Investments' voluntary conditional cash offer of 65 Singapore cents per share aims to delist the company from the mainboard, citing economic uncertainty. The offer has received 86.77% acceptance, with 202.7 million shares being owned or agreed to be acquired. Teckwah's independent directors recommended shareholders accept the offer, and an independent financial adviser has deemed the financial terms as fair and reasonable.

site_title: SMRT using Grab technology to streamline taxi operations
summary: SMRT Corporation has partnered with Grab to streamline taxi operations using Grab's technology. Starting October 1, SMRT drivers will use an enhanced Grab Driver app, replacing mobile display units in taxis, to manage earnings and receive jobs from SMRT's booking system, street hail, and Grab platform. The app will improve driver productivity and passenger experience with features like real-time updates and demand heat maps. The partnership aims to better prepare taxi drivers for a digitized marketplace and will be rolled out fleetwide by the end of the year.

site_title: Saudi economy shrank by 7% in Q2 showing depth of coronavirus hit
summary: Saudi Arabia's economy shrank by 7% in the second quarter, with the private sector and government sector recording negative growth rates of 10.1% and 3.5%, respectively. The non-oil sector, which is diversifying the economy, shrunk by 8.2%, while the oil sector declined by 5.3%. The economy's contraction is attributed to the COVID-19 pandemic and low oil prices, with consumer spending falling 5.5% year-on-year due to a tripled value-added tax. The recession is expected to have a weak impact on private sector job creation for nationals.

site_title: Broker's take: RHB upgrades China Aviation Oil to 'buy' as air traffic improves
summary: RHB upgraded China Aviation Oil (CAO) to 'buy' from 'neutral' due to improving China's aviation traffic, with domestic passenger volume and aircraft movements expected to grow during the upcoming Golden Week holidays. Analysts attribute the growth to strong control of COVID-19 cases, expanded domestic capacity, and price promotions. CAO's valuations remain compelling, with expected 30% profit growth in 2021 and a net cash position of US$406.7 million, equivalent to 72% of its market cap.

images.alt_text: Shanghai's Pudong International Airport in July 2020. RHB said the y-o-y higher domestic aircraft movement at the airport should support CAO's earnings recovery.

site_title: Surging prices turn pork into luxury holiday gift in China
summary: In China, surging pork prices have turned swine meat into a luxury holiday gift, with employees lining up to receive bags of fatty pork at a furniture store. The price surge, triggered by African swine fever, has pushed prices to record highs, with wholesale pork prices falling by almost 5% in September. However, prices remain 25% higher than a year ago, and the market is expected to remain tight. The Chinese government has increased sales from state pork reserves to try to damp prices ahead of holidays.

site_title: Alibaba expects first profit from its cloud arm this year
summary: Alibaba Group Holding expects its cloud services arm to turn profitable for the first time this year, driven by growing demand for internet computing and logistics services. The company's cloud business is expected to generate US$7 billion in annual revenue and will provide positive cash flow, according to CFO Maggie Wu. Alibaba's shares rose 4% in Hong Kong following the announcement, as the company aims to capitalize on China's economic recovery and its shift towards cloud-based collaboration and IT infrastructure upgrades.

site_title: MAS seen keeping monetary policy on hold on recovery hopes: poll
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), is expected to keep its monetary policy settings unchanged in October due to hopes for economic recovery, according to a Reuters poll of 13 economists. The poll cited easing of coronavirus curbs and expectations of fiscal policy driving a rebound as key factors. The MAS has managed monetary policy through exchange rate settings, and its accommodative stance is seen as necessary for a sluggish recovery. The government has injected nearly S$100 billion in stimulus into the economy, which is expected to contract a record 13.2% in the second quarter.

site_title: Bank lending in August falls for sixth straight session: MAS data
summary: Bank lending in Singapore fell for the sixth consecutive month in August, with a 0.4% decline in business lending and a 1% year-over-year contraction. Loans to manufacturers and financial institutions narrowed, while construction-related loans grew 0.8%. Consumer loans, however, saw a 0.3% increase, driven by a 13.7% jump in share financing. Total lending fell 1% from last year, marking the third consecutive weakening since June.

site_title: Amazon to take Citigroup office space in Singapore's finance hub
summary: Amazon is planning to lease three floors at Asia Square Tower 1 in Singapore's finance hub, covering approximately 90,000 square feet, as Citigroup trims its office space due to its lease expiring soon. Amazon staff are expected to move in early next year, while Citigroup will relocate some consumer banking staff to a new hub in Changi Business Park. This move comes as Amazon expands in Singapore, following Chinese tech rivals such as Tencent and Alibaba, which have established a presence in the city-state.

site_title: Malaysia must upgrade economy to escape middle-income trap: Fitch Solutions
summary: Malaysia's economy is expected to slow to 3.4% growth over the next decade, according to Fitch Solutions, due to factors such as extended political uncertainty, demographic changes, and reduced fiscal space. The country's middle-income trap is likely to hinder its ability to upgrade its economy, with a "brain drain" of talented non-Malay individuals seeking opportunities overseas. Political reforms, including affirmative action policies, are expected to be delayed, further hindering growth potential.

site_title: Trump and Biden go on the attack in fiery, chaotic first presidential debate
summary: In the first presidential debate, Republican President Donald Trump and Democratic rival Joe Biden clashed over their leadership on the coronavirus pandemic, economy, and taxes. Trump repeatedly interrupted Biden, while Biden called Trump a "clown" and a "racist." The debate highlighted the significant differences between the two candidates, with Biden questioning Trump's handling of the pandemic and Trump defending his approach. The debate marked a fiery and chaotic exchange, with the stakes high as the election approaches.

site_title: TikTok sweeps Britain but Norwegians watch more videos
summary: TikTok has gained a significant following in Britain, with 17 million regular users spending an average of 66 minutes per day on the app. This represents nearly half the number of Facebook users in the UK, despite Facebook having 37 million users. The app's growth is attributed to the rise in entertainment-seeking during the coronavirus lockdowns. A significant portion of users, particularly those aged 18-24, have adopted the platform, with one in four Britons using it every month.

site_title: Gold slips as US dollar firms after Trump, Biden face off
summary: Gold prices dropped 0.5% to $1,889.66 per ounce after the US dollar strengthened following the first US presidential debate between Donald Trump and Joe Biden. This marks the worst monthly fall since November 2016, with gold down 4% so far this month. The dollar index is on track for its biggest monthly rise since July 2019, with investors tracking the progress of a new US coronavirus relief bill. Despite the decline, gold has gained 25% so far this year due to monetary stimulus from central banks and governments.

site_title: Singapore-based asset managers' AUM jumps 15.7% last year: MAS survey
summary: Singapore-based asset managers' total assets under management (AUM) grew 15.7% to S$4 trillion in 2019, driven by strong market performance and net inflows from investors. The industry's AUM expanded at a 11% compound annual growth rate over the last five years. The alternatives sector saw 12% growth, led by private equity and venture capital managers, while traditional assets rebounded with 25% growth. 76% of AUM originated from outside Singapore, and 69% was invested in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Germany puts first auto boss on trial over 'dieselgate'
summary: Rupert Stadler, the former CEO of Audi, is the first top executive to stand trial in Germany over the "dieselgate" emissions cheating scandal. Stadler faces charges of fraud, falsifying certifications, and false advertising, along with two Audi engineers and former Porsche manager Wolfgang Hatz. The trial, which began on Wednesday, is expected to last until December 2022 and could result in up to 10 years in jail if found guilty. Stadler has consistently denied the accusations, and prosecutors claim he knew about the scam by the end of September 2015 but allowed thousands of vehicles with illegal defeat devices to be sold.

images.alt_text: Five years after "dieselgate" emissions cheating revelations rocked the car industry, ex-Audi CEO Rupert Stadler on Wednesday becomes the first top executive to stand trial in Germany.

site_title: Two key thrusts to help HR professionals step up as strategic partners in business transformation
summary: The HR Industry Transformation Advisory Panel (HRTAP) recommends two key thrusts to help HR professionals become strategic partners in business transformation. The first thrust focuses on building HR capabilities through sector-specific playbooks, HR capability building solutions, and employer data portals. The second thrust aims to uplift the HR profession with relevant skills and experience through a development pathway and skills badges. HRTAP sets targets to complete 5,000 HR capability assessments, increase IHRP certification, and confer 10,000 skills badges by 2025, with the goal of improving business outcomes and wage profiles for local HR professionals.

site_title: General Atlantic invests 36.8b rupees in Ambani retail unit
summary: General Atlantic invests 36.8 billion rupees (S$682.8 million) in Reliance Retail Ventures, a retail unit of billionaire Mukesh Ambani's Reliance Industries, valuing the business at 4.29 trillion rupees. The investment follows recent deals from KKR & Co and Silver Lake Partner, and marks General Atlantic's second investment in Ambani's consumer businesses. This deal further cements Ambani's focus on consumer businesses, tapping India's vast market of billion-plus consumers, and raises over US$20 billion for his digital services unit, Jio Platforms.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, rising 3.45 points or 0.23% to 1,507.35. Volume reached 257.48 million lots worth RM73.87 million, with 165 gainers outpacing 107 losers.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.2% or 3.91 points to 2,475.52, driven by gains from Singapore Telecommunications, Keppel Corporation, and DBS. The three banks rose after DBS announced it will redeem its preference shares and integrate its rewards app. Other active index counters include Sembcorp Marine, Genting Singapore, and OCBC, with Keppel chief executive officer identifying assets valued at S$17.5 billion for monetization.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall on caution ahead of US presidential debate
summary: Australian shares fell 1.5% on Wednesday, tracking overnight Wall Street losses, ahead of the US presidential debate. Despite a low number of new COVID-19 cases in Victoria, investors pulled out of risky bets, with energy stocks leading the decline. Santos fell 3% despite a state panel approving its Narrabri gas project, while tech stocks also dropped. The decline was part of a broader market downturn, with the S&P/ASX 200 index on track for a third straight day of losses.

site_title: China Evergrande rises 13.9% after deal with Hengda investors
summary: China Evergrande Group shares rose 13.9% after reaching a deal with investors of its unit Hengda Real Estate to ease cash-crunch concerns. The deal, worth 86.3 billion yuan (S$17.31 billion), prevents the debt-laden property developer from repurchasing their holdings. This move lifted Evergrande's shares to HK$18.80, the highest since August 21. The agreement alleviates concerns over the company's financial stability, providing temporary relief to investors.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS upgrades Keppel to 'buy', says O&M review could restore confidence
summary: DBS Group Research upgraded Keppel Corp to "buy" from "hold" following the conglomerate's recent price correction and strategic review of its offshore and marine (O&M) arm. The review aims to restore confidence among investors and unlock S$3-5 billion in assets over the next three years. Keppel shares jumped 6.1% to S$4.56, with a 12-month price target of S$5.50, representing a 28% upside. Analysts expect operational improvements and potential asset monetization, including landbank sales and mergers, to drive valuation rerating.

site_title: Pompeo due in Asia for talks on China, North Korea
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo will visit Japan, South Korea, and Mongolia starting next week, focusing on China and North Korea. Pompeo's Tokyo trip will include a four-way meeting with Australian, Indian, and Japanese counterparts, known as the "Quad," aimed at strengthening regional cooperation against China. This marks the first high-level meeting since Yoshihide Suga took office, following Shinzo Abe's succession.

site_title: US housing market to remain a bright spot in a weak economy
summary: The US housing market is expected to remain a bright spot in a weak economy, with house prices predicted to rise 4% this year and 3.5% in 2021 and 2022. Analysts attribute the trend to record-low interest rates, strong demand, and undersupply after a decade of underbuilding. Over 60% of analysts believe the trend will continue for at least another year, despite economic uncertainty and tight inventory levels.

site_title: New Asean regional centre to tackle future of work
summary: Singapore has launched the Regional Centre for the Future of Work (RCFW), a new regional centre to help Asean member-states prepare for the future of work. The centre will focus on three areas: embracing technology for inclusive growth, workplace safety and health for sustainable work, and tripartism. This move aims to tackle labour market challenges resulting from the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Republicans stay loyal to Trump despite concerns about his taxes
summary: US President Donald Trump remains popular among Republicans despite concerns over his taxes, with 88% of registered Republicans backing him over Democratic candidate Joe Biden. A Reuters/Ipsos poll found 51% of Americans believe Trump hasn't paid his fair share of income taxes, but only 3 in 10 Republicans agree. Most Republicans (7 in 10) see Trump as a successful businessman who knows how to avoid taxes, and 3 in 10 are concerned his personal finances influence his decisions.

site_title: China issues draft loss-absorbing capacity rules for systemically important banks
summary: China has published draft rules requiring its globally systemically important banks to meet specific total loss-absorbing capacity (TLAC) targets starting 2025. China's top four lenders, including Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, must hold at least 16% of risk-weighted assets by 2025 and 18% by 2028. The move aims to improve the risk-disposal mechanism at Chinese lenders and address a funding gap of 5.77-6.51 trillion yuan by 2024. The rules are part of a broader effort to ensure global systemically important banks have sufficient risk buffers in case of bankruptcy.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, DBS, Singapore Airlines, CCT, CMT, Teckwah
summary: Keppel Corp identified S$17.5 billion in assets for monetization over three years. DBS will redeem S$800 million preference shares on Nov 23. Singapore Airlines will offer ground-based experiences instead of "flight to nowhere" programs. CapitaLand Mall Trust and Commercial Trust's merger was approved by unitholders. Teckwah Industrial Corp's closing date for a private offer was extended to Oct 13. Envictus International Holdings' CEO will resign on Oct 1. Kitchen Culture Holdings requested a trading halt pending an announcement.

site_title: Accordia Golf Trust completes divestment, suspends trading in units
summary: Accordia Golf Trust (AGT) completes the 65.2 billion yen sale of its golf courses to its sponsor Accordia Golf for S$843.6 million. Trading of AGT units on the Singapore Exchange is suspended as of Wednesday. Unitholders will receive 70.66 Singapore cents per unit in the first tranche of the special distribution, with further announcements on the second tranche and trust winding-up to follow. AGT's 88 golf courses in Japan were sold with unitholder approval and the trust's winding-up process has begun.

site_title: World Bank seeks board approval for US$12b coronavirus vaccine financing plan
summary: The World Bank is seeking board approval for a $12 billion coronavirus vaccine financing plan to support poor and developing countries in securing vaccine doses. The plan aims to ensure equitable distribution, putting these countries on the same footing as richer nations. The World Bank will disburse grant or loan funding to countries, selecting vaccines that meet safety criteria, and will work with manufacturers to secure allocations for developing countries. The plan is part of the World Bank's $160 billion coronavirus aid financing pledge, amid fierce global competition for early vaccine doses.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally at Wednesday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks started the day with a 1.17% gain, reaching 23,548.89, as data showed China's economic recovery remains on track. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up, with the latter rising 0.32%. The gains follow a rally in Singapore and other Asian markets, despite US-EU trade talks and US tariff uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks started on Wednesday morning with healthy gains following another batch of data indicating China's economic recovery remains on track.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, following Wall Street's decline. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.34% or 79.06 points to 23,460.04, while the Topix index slipped 0.51% or 8.49 points to 1,649.61. Investors await the US presidential debate for fresh trading cues.

site_title: Temasek prices its longest US$1b 50-year bond at 2.5%
summary: Temasek, a Singaporean state investment firm, has priced its longest US$1 billion 50-year bond at 2.5% per annum, a record for the company. The bond is part of a US$2.75 billion three-tranche deal, which also includes a 30.5-year bond priced at 2.25% and a 10-year bond priced at 1%. The deal was oversubscribed, with orders reaching US$5 billion, and was supported by investors from Asia, the US, and Europe. The bonds are unconditionally guaranteed by Temasek and are expected to be listed on the Singapore Exchange on October 7.

images.alt_text: Temasek Financial (I) Limited (TFin-I) has issued below par a US$2.75 billion three-tranche deal of guaranteed bonds, which include a record 50-year tenor.

site_title: Yio Chu Kang Road childcare centre-approved site put on market
summary: A 999-year leasehold land plot in Singapore's Sengkang area is up for sale via expression of interest, with an expected price of over S$14.8 million. The site, which spans 10,851 sq ft, is currently approved for use as a childcare centre and offers vacant possession. Potential buyers can continue operations as a childcare centre or explore other uses under the prevailing Master Plan. The sale closes on November 5, following the recent sale of a nearby childcare centre site for S$25 million.

site_title: Neuron Mobility raises US$12m in extended Series A round
summary: Neuron Mobility, an e-scooter rental operator, has secured US$12 million in an extended Series A round led by Square Peg Capital and GSR Ventures. The company, valued at US$47.2 million, plans to use the fresh capital to accelerate its expansion in Australia and New Zealand, with a goal of operating in at least five more cities and creating around 400 jobs. The e-scooter startup sees the Covid-19 pandemic as a tailwind for the industry, with cities rethinking their transport systems and seeking safe, inexpensive, and socially-distanced travel options.

site_title: Hong Kong August home prices post biggest monthly drop since Feb
summary: Hong Kong's private home prices dropped 1.1% in August, their largest monthly decline since February, due to a new wave of coronavirus infections. The drop follows a 0.5% fall in July and erases gains made so far this year. Despite this, housing transaction volumes are expected to increase 25% in September, driven by eased social distancing measures and new property launches. This marks a rebound from July, which saw suppressed volumes due to the outbreak.

images.alt_text: Private home prices in Hong Kong fell 1.1 per cent in August, their biggest monthly drop since February, official data by the Rating and Valuation Department showed on Wednesday, as the financial centre was hit by a new wave of coronavirus infections.

site_title: Suspected ransomware attack disrupts hospital chain
summary: A suspected ransomware attack disrupted patient care at Universal Health Services (UHS), a large hospital chain in the US and Britain. The attack, linked to North Korean hackers using Ryuk malware, may have temporarily disrupted clinical and financial operations. UHS reported using backup processes to minimize disruptions, but ambulances and patients were redirected to other facilities. This incident is the latest in a series of cyberattacks on healthcare facilities, with hackers exploiting outdated systems and the pandemic's vulnerability.

site_title: New Zealand business confidence improves in Sept
summary: New Zealand business confidence improved in September, according to an ANZ Bank survey, with a net 28.5% of respondents expecting the economy to deteriorate over the year ahead, down from 41.8% in August. Business sentiment showed a 5.4% decrease in respondents expecting their own businesses to be weaker in the next 12 months. This uptick in confidence is attributed to growing optimism that the Covid-19 outbreak in the country is under control.

site_title: For Joe Biden, debate with Trump offers moment of truth
summary: US President Joe Biden is set to face off against Donald Trump in a highly anticipated debate, with potential for explosive exchanges. Biden aims to present himself as a calm, empathetic unifier, while Trump is expected to employ provocative tactics. The debate marks a crucial moment in the campaign, with Biden leading in polling just five weeks before the November 3 election. Biden's performance will be closely watched, as he seeks to counter Trump's accusations of diminished mental acuity and demonstrate his ability to unite a polarized nation.

site_title: Disney to cut 28,000 US employees due to coronavirus
summary: Disney announced plans to cut 28,000 US jobs due to depressed demand caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The cuts, primarily affecting part-time staff, are expected to help the company emerge as a more efficient operation when demand recovers. This move comes after Disney reported a $4.7 billion loss in the most recent quarter, largely due to the impact on its theme park business. The company's shares fell 1.5% after the announcement, but were boosted by increased demand for its streaming service.

site_title: SIA ditches idea for flight to nowhere; will instead offer ground-based experiences
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has launched "Discover Your Singapore Airlines", a suite of experiences offering behind-the-scenes tours, in-flight dining, and ground-based activities. The airline initially considered a "flight to nowhere" but decided against it due to environmental concerns. The programmes include "Inside Singapore Airlines", a family-friendly tour, "Restaurant A380 @Changi", a 3-hour dining experience on the A380, and "SIA@Home", a home delivery service for first-class and business-class meals. Bookings open on November 1, with pricing to be announced later.

site_title: TikTok launches US election guide to battle misinformation
summary: TikTok has launched a US election guide to combat misinformation, providing links to voter registration pages and election information from trusted sources. The guide will appear in the app's Discover page and on election-related search results. The move comes as the White House has targeted TikTok for a ban, with the company challenging the order in court. TikTok's efforts aim to protect the integrity of its platform and the US elections, while also helping younger voters make informed decisions.

images.alt_text: TikTok on Tuesday launched a US election guide as part of an effort to battle misinformation on the wildly popular video-sharing app that the White House has targeted for a ban.

site_title: China's factory activity expands at a faster pace in Sept: official PMI
summary: China's factory activity expanded at a faster pace in September, with the official manufacturing PMI rising to 51.5 from 51.0 in August, above the 50-point mark that separates growth from contraction. The sector is steadily recovering from the pandemic, driven by exports growth, pent-up demand, and stimulus-driven infrastructure expansion. While employment remained in contractionary territory, the services sector expanded at a faster pace. The economy is expected to expand 2.2% this year, the weakest in over three decades, amid growing tensions between China and the US.

images.alt_text: China's factory activity expanded at a faster pace in September thanks to a return to exports growth after several months of shrinking sales, bolstering a steady recovery for the economy as it rebounds from the coronavirus shock.

site_title: Biden releases latest tax returns hours before Trump debate
summary: US presidential candidate Joe Biden released his tax returns for the last four years, showing he paid $299,346 in federal income taxes for 2019. This contrasts with President Donald Trump, who paid only $750 in federal income taxes in 2016. Biden's move came hours before his debate with Trump, who faces criticism for his low tax payments. The release of Biden's tax returns is seen as an attempt to counter Trump's tax record and highlight his own financial transparency.

images.alt_text: Democratic White House hopeful Joe Biden released his tax returns for the last four years on Tuesday just hours before he debates President Donald Trump, who faces criticism for paying almost no federal tax.

site_title: Very nice! 'Borat' sequel coming to Amazon Prime
summary: Amazon Prime has acquired a sequel to the comedy film "Borat," with Sacha Baron Cohen reprising his role as the bumbling reporter from Kazakhstan. The follow-up, which has been shot covertly, is expected to be released before November's US election. The original film grossed over $260 million and earned an Oscar screenplay nomination, spawning catchphrases among devoted fans. The sequel will continue Cohen's gonzo-style comedy, going undercover to reveal people's biases and biases, and is set to premiere on Amazon Prime before the election.

site_title: STI retreats 0.5% in line with other Asian indices in muted trading
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) retreated 0.46% to 2,471.61 on muted trading, mirroring other Asian indices. Dairy Farm International, the top loser, fell 3.8% to US$3.76 despite "buy" calls from RHB and HSBC. Keppel Corp was the top performer, adding 2.6% to S$4.30 after announcing a strategic review of its O&M business. Regional markets finished mixed, with the Shanghai Composite climbing 0.21% and the Nikkei 225 advancing 0.12%. Analysts attributed the subdued market to the upcoming US presidential debate and potential foreign relations issues.

site_title: Singapore to explore reinstating essential travel to Sichuan
summary: Singapore plans to explore reinstating essential travel to Sichuan province in China, with the goal of reviving passenger traffic and increasing direct air services between Singapore and Chengdu. This move comes as trade between the two regions has seen a significant jump of over 20% compared to last year, with Singapore being Sichuan's largest foreign investor. The reinstatement of travel aims to support business exchanges and help both economies recover from the pandemic.

site_title: US: Stocks dip ahead of presidential debate
summary: US stocks declined on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones shedding 0.5% to 27,452.66, the S&P 500 falling 0.5% to 3,335.47, and the Nasdaq Composite Index losing 0.3% to 11,085.25. The dip comes ahead of the first presidential debate between Donald Trump and Joe Biden, following a New York Times expose revealing Trump paid no taxes for 10 years. Despite this, a top aide to Nancy Pelosi reported progress in stimulus talks, and consumer confidence jumped to 101.8 in September.

site_title: Buying the dip still a good strategy for today's fixed income market
summary: Investors can still benefit from buying the dip in the fixed income market, as central banks remain supportive and fiscal policy remains expansionary. Despite a rise in government bond yields, most fixed income products delivered negative or only marginally positive returns, and credit spreads have tightened. However, expected future returns have moderated, and risk reduction is recommended. Economic data continues to be better than expected, but considerable downside risks persist, including rising Covid-19 infection rates and geopolitical tensions.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slip after recent surge, all eyes on Trump-Biden debate
summary: European stocks slipped 0.5% on Tuesday after a recent surge, amid mounting coronavirus cases and investors waiting for the Trump-Biden debate. The Stoxx 600 closed lower, with banks and energy sectors falling more than 1.5%. Despite this, some investors remain optimistic on the medium-term, citing continued central bank and government stimulus. The debate is set to begin on Wednesday, with investors seeking policy outlook hints.

site_title: SBI Offshore proposes to liquidate to make cash exit offer
summary: SBI Offshore proposes to liquidate and undertake a cash exit offer by delisting from the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The company plans to convene an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to seek shareholder approval, with the liquidation process expected to start in early January 2021. The first interim distribution to shareholders is expected to be paid out between April and May 2021, with the final distribution and dissolution of the company to take place between mid-August and late November 2021. This comes after the SGX sent the company a notification of delisting following the failure to complete the proposed acquisition of the Berlitz group.

site_title: Oil falls over 3% as virus cases mount and US debate looms
summary: Oil prices fell over 3% on Tuesday as the US and Europe grappled with a surge in new coronavirus infections, sparking concerns about fuel demand. Investors remained cautious ahead of the US presidential debate. Oil prices dropped to their lowest in two weeks, with Brent futures for November delivery falling $1.40 to $41.03 a barrel. The US Energy Information Administration is set to release oil inventory data on Wednesday, which is expected to show increased crude stockpiles. The COVID-19 pandemic's impact on fuel demand and the global economy remains a major downside risk for crude prices.

site_title: ERA bags exclusive listing rights for Singapore properties on Fang.com
summary: ERA Singapore has secured an exclusive listing rights deal on Fang.com, a Chinese property portal, to expose its agents to Chinese investors and capture a larger share of the lucrative China market. The agency will pay listing fees for each property listing, and under the arrangement, ERA will subsidise on-boarding costs for its agents to market local properties to potential buyers in China remotely. ERA aims to capitalize on the growing demand for Singapore properties from Chinese buyers, who are the second-largest buyers of homes in the country.

site_title: Japan's factory output rises for third month in August
summary: Japan's factory output rose 1.7% in August, marking the third consecutive month of growth, driven by a rebound in car production. However, analysts warn that the recovery is expected to slow as coronavirus infections rise globally, impacting demand. Retail sales declined 1.9% in August, the sixth consecutive month, and sentiment among small and medium enterprises remains negative. The economy's recovery pace is expected to be slow, with manufacturers anticipating a 5.7% increase in output in September and 2.9% in October.

images.alt_text: Japan's factory output rose for the third straight month in August, in a positive sign for manufacturers as economic activity gradually recovered further from the impact of the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: UK, EU said to be closing in on Brexit deal, but both sides warn they are 'still far apart' on key stumbling blocks
summary: The European Union and the UK have begun their ninth and final round of trade negotiations, with both sides expressing cautious optimism about reaching a Brexit deal. Despite agreeing on a joint trade agreement text, key issues such as fishing quotas and state subsidy policies remain unresolved. The UK and EU have warned they are "still far apart" on these stumbling blocks, with the deadline for a deal set for October 15 to allow EU leaders to review the draft ahead of the UK's December departure.

site_title: Swiss reject anti-European Brexit virus
summary: Switzerland has rejected a proposal to end freedom of movement with the European Union, with 60% of voters saying no to the proposal in a referendum held on September 27. This outcome is seen as a reassuring signal for the rest of Europe, which has been grappling with the aftermath of the UK's Brexit vote. The decision underscores a strong Swiss streak of pragmatism and a rejection of populist policies that have gained traction in other European countries, including Italy and France.

site_title: Insurers and FCA seek clarity on business-interruption ruling
summary: Insurance firms RSA and other UK insurers are seeking clarity on business-interruption payouts related to the Covid-19 pandemic. The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has filed a "leapfrog" application to the Supreme Court, citing a recent trial court ruling that gave both parties something to be happy about. The ruling reduced the total liability for business-interruption claims linked to the virus, but insurers still dispute coverage for pandemics. A hearing on the application will take place on October 2.

site_title: HDB upgraders likely to sustain strong condo sales: DBS
summary: DBS Group Research predicts that HDB upgraders will sustain strong condo sales in Singapore, driven by stable demand despite the coronavirus pandemic. Recent sales volumes, such as the 566-unit Penrose at Sims Drive, show a 7% increase year-over-year, with 85% of buyers being Singaporeans. Analysts attribute the strong sales to pent-up demand, low interest rates, and sticky property prices, with some projects targeting the upgraders market expected to continue performing well.

site_title: Evergrande's race for cash could avert nightmare scenarios
summary: China Evergrande Group, the world's most indebted real estate company, faces a cash crunch that could lead to market-destabilizing consequences. To avoid this, the developer is exploring various funding options, including asset sales, stock listings, and a boost in holiday condo sales, which could raise up to $9.3 billion. The company has also planned a Hong Kong IPO and secondary stock sale, and may refinance existing debt, but faces challenges due to Beijing's restrictive funding policies and cautious banks.

site_title: Defying EU ultimatum, British MPs approve post-Brexit bill
summary: British lawmakers approved a post-Brexit bill to regulate the UK's internal market, defying an EU ultimatum. The bill passed 340-256, despite concerns over its potential impact on Northern Ireland's Good Friday Agreement. The government rejected EU warnings that the bill could jeopardize peace in Northern Ireland, and the EU has threatened to take Britain to court if the offending clauses are not revoked. The bill now heads to the House of Lords, where it faces opposition, but is still expected to become law in the coming weeks.

site_title: Amazon defends warehouse safety following report on injuries
summary: Amazon has defended its warehouse safety record following a report by the Center for Investigative Reporting that found 14,000 serious injuries in Amazon fulfillment centers in 2019. The report, citing internal documents, found the injury rate was 33% higher than in 2016 and nearly double the industry standard. Amazon stated that it takes workplace safety seriously and has implemented various measures to prevent injuries, including providing personal protective equipment and offering training programs. The company's injury rate has decreased in recent years, and it claims that the reported rate does not reflect the overall safety of its operations.

site_title: New Tuas Nexus facility can be poster child for regional foray into waste and water treatment
summary: Singapore's new Tuas Nexus facility, the world's first integrated waste and water treatment plant, has begun construction and is expected to be completed in phases from 2025. The facility, which will treat both solid waste and used water, is expected to result in 200,000 tonnes of carbon savings annually and 2.6 hectares of land savings. Industry experts say the project could spin off similar concepts elsewhere in the region, but few other nations may be ready yet due to differing infrastructure and regulatory frameworks.

site_title: IMDA, mobile network operators to hire, reskill 1,000 professionals for 5G
summary: The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) in Singapore has partnered with mobile network operators to hire and reskill 1,000 professionals to support the country's 5G rollout. The initiative includes 30% new roles and 70% upskilling of existing telecom professionals in areas like 5G networks, cybersecurity, and solution engineering. The goal is to create good jobs and opportunities for Singaporeans and develop a strong pipeline of 5G talent. The first wave of training will begin at the end of 2020, and the initiative aims to equip 5,000 professionals with 5G skills over three years.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Envictus International Holdings' CEO Khor Sin Kok will resign on Oct 1, with acting CEO Kamal YP Tan taking over. Mah Weng Choong will be redesignated from independent non-executive director to non-independent non-executive director due to a consultancy fee exceeding S$50,000. Tritech Group has developed an AI-based data analytics system to improve profit margins, while CPH has entered a S$22 million conditional sale and purchase agreement to acquire 100% of Shanaya Environmental Services.

site_title: Trust between tripartite partners, quick pivots the way for Singapore to tackle Covid-19
summary: Singapore's swift response to the Covid-19 pandemic, led by tripartite partners, helped mitigate its impact on employment numbers. Despite a 100,000+ job loss and 2.8% unemployment rate, concerted efforts, such as the National Wages Council and Jobs Support Scheme, have helped moderate the effects. The government has now pivoted to a new Jobs Growth Incentive scheme, signaling support for businesses to create jobs and encouraging hiring of locals.

images.alt_text: Since its launch, SGUnited Jobs and Skills has already matched 25,000 people to opportunities, says MOM's Aubeck Kam.

site_title: LVMH countersues Tiffany, claims 'mismanagement' scuppered deal
summary: LVMH, the world's largest luxury conglomerate, has filed a countersuit against Tiffany, claiming "mismanagement" led to the collapse of its $16.2 billion takeover bid. LVMH cited poor decisions by Tiffany's board and high dividends paid during the Covid-19 pandemic. Tiffany has denied the claims and is suing to force LVMH to go through with the bid. A US court has approved a fast-track trial set to begin in January, with both sides unlikely to reach a settlement amid an escalating war of words.

site_title: CMT and CCT unitholders vote in favour of proposed merger
summary: Unitholders of CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) and CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) voted in favour of a proposed merger to form a new real estate investment trust (Reit). The merger, expected to be completed on October 21, will create one of the largest Reits in the Asia-Pacific and Singapore by market capitalization. The merged entity, named CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT), will have a diversified portfolio of 24 retail, office, and integrated developments in Singapore and overseas. The merger was supported by 98.89% and 90.31% of CMT and CCT unitholders, respectively.

site_title: Reits may have higher yields but Reit perps' payout more certain
summary: Realty Investment Trusts (Reits) may offer higher yields, but perpetual bonds (perps) issued by Reits provide more certainty in terms of payouts. Perps have fixed coupons that can only be deferred in a non-cumulative manner, whereas Reits have discretion over dividend payments. Non-Reit issuers, such as Hotel Properties and Wing Tai Holdings, have also seen their perp coupons exceed their dividend yields. However, perps carry risks, including the potential for losses when a company's underlying exposure is impacted, and may not offer capital appreciation like equities.

images.alt_text: The bond-like stable yields of perps still appeal to a class of middle-aged investors in this low rate and volatile environment, said CFA Society Singapore's Chan Fook Leong.

site_title: HKEX chief to step down at end of 2020, ahead of schedule
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEX) announced that Chief Executive Charles Li will step down at the end of 2020, ahead of schedule. Calvin Tai, current Chief Operating Officer, will serve as interim CEO from January 1, 2021. This move is not a result of any external factors, but rather Li's own request.

site_title: US dollar slips as markets await presidential debate
summary: The US dollar index slipped from recent highs as markets awaited the first presidential debate between Donald Trump and Joe Biden. Despite concerns over the candidates' prospects, the dollar was capped by the ultra-dovish Fed and uncertainty over Trump's potential response to defeat. The greenback fell 0.1% against a basket of currencies at 1104 GMT, while riskier currencies strengthened, including the New Zealand dollar and Australian dollar. Markets also awaited developments in US fiscal stimulus talks and economic data, including German inflation.

site_title: Thailand to slowly restart tourism with flight from China
summary: Thailand is set to restart its tourism sector with a flight from China, marking a gradual recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. The first flight, carrying 120 tourists from Guangzhou to Phuket, is scheduled for next week. The government predicts 6.7 million foreign visitors this year, down from a record 39.8 million in 2019. To control the spread of the virus, tourists will need health insurance and a negative COVID-19 test, and will be required to stay in quarantine for 14 days.

site_title: Temasek issuing new bonds with record 50-year tenor
summary: Temasek Holdings is issuing a record 50-year bond with a new $25 billion guaranteed global medium-term note program. The bonds, which also include 10-year and 30.5-year tenors, will be unconditionally guaranteed by the investment firm. The deal aims to fund Temasek's ordinary course of business, with the net proceeds expected to be at least $500 million. Moody's and S&P Global Ratings have assigned Temasek an Aaa rating, reflecting its strong fundamental credit quality and conservative financial profile.

site_title: DBS to redeem all S$800m in preference shares
summary: DBS announced the redemption of its S$800 million outstanding preference shares on Nov 23. The redemption price will be S$100 per share, plus accrued but unpaid dividends, totaling S$800 million. The shares will cease trading on Nov 11 and be delisted on Nov 24. A record date to determine entitlement to the redemption price will be held on Nov 12. DBS obtained prior written consent from the Monetary Authority of Singapore and has satisfied redemption conditions.

site_title: Three areas where Asian firms are beating their Western counterparts
summary: Asian firms are outperforming their Western counterparts in three key areas: cost-to-income ratio, cashlessness, and food delivery. Asian banks have a lower cost-to-income ratio, with some countries averaging under 43%, compared to 59% in the US and 76.8% in Germany. China's Ant Group has become a model for a cashless society, with 1.3 billion users, while food delivery companies like Meituan-Dianping and Alibaba's Ele.me dominate the market in China, with a 90% market share. This success highlights opportunities for learning and growth from companies in both the East and West.

site_title: Some of Hong Kong's poor finally feel at home - in 290 sq ft flats
summary: Hong Kong's government has introduced transitional homes, 290 sq ft pre-fabricated dwellings, to ease the city's housing shortage. Over 200,000 people are waiting an average of 5.5 years for public housing, with more than 800 transitional homes built so far. The homes, built on idle land, provide a temporary solution for those in need. Residents, like the Lau family, who previously lived in cramped "coffin homes," now have more space and a sense of home. However, NGOs criticize the government for not doing enough, citing challenges with land and funding.

images.alt_text: Newly-built "module homes" are part of the government's latest initiative to ease a housing shortage.

site_title: Russian scientist behind Covid-19 vaccine defends 'wartime' roll-out
summary: Russian scientist Alexander Gintsburg defends the rapid development of the Sputnik V Covid-19 vaccine, stating that no corners were cut despite a tight deadline. The vaccine's preliminary results, based on the first six weeks of monitoring participants, will be shared, and Russia plans to become the first worldwide to announce data from a final-stage trial. Gintsburg says the vaccine has shown no serious side effects, with minor side effects reported among 14-15% of volunteers, and aims for a 75% efficacy rate.

site_title: COE supply expected to rise by 8% for Nov-Jan period: sgCarMart
summary: Singapore-based online car marketplace sgCarMart expects an 8% increase in certificates of entitlement (COEs) for the November 2020-January 2021 quota period, with approximately 14,950 COEs available for passenger cars. This projection is based on Land Transport Authority's passenger car deregistration numbers in August. COE supply for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp is expected to increase by 1%, while supply for cars above 1,600cc or 130bhp is expected to average 2,017, a 17% increase.

site_title: Coca-Cola to enter US alcoholic drinks market with Molson Coors tie-up
summary: Coca-Cola is set to launch its first alcoholic drink in the US, a Topo Chico sparkling water with a low-alcohol content, in partnership with Molson Coors Beverage Co. The beverage giant will roll out the drink in the first half of 2021, expanding its market beyond Latin America and Japan. This move is expected to strengthen Molson Coors' portfolio of low-alcohol spirits and compete with popular hard seltzers like White Claw. The launch marks Coca-Cola's entry into the US alcoholic drinks market.

site_title: DBS will redeem all S$800m in preference shares on Nov 23
summary: DBS Bank announced it will redeem all S$800 million in outstanding preference shares on November 23. The redemption price will be S$100 per share plus accrued but unpaid dividends. The shares will cease trading on November 11 and be delisted on November 24. DBS has obtained prior written consent from the Monetary Authority of Singapore and satisfied redemption conditions.

site_title: New platform launched to trial innovative built-environment solutions
summary: Singapore has launched the Built Environment Living Lab Framework (BE LLF), a platform for companies to test innovative technologies in urban spaces. The framework, launched at International Built Environment Week, aims to enable firms to trial new solutions that can benefit the built environment. Proposals can be submitted to the Built Environment Technology Alliance, and test-bedding will take place in urban spaces such as Punggol Town and Jurong Lake Gardens. The initiative is part of the government's efforts to promote industry transformation and leverage innovative technologies to tackle the challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: UniCredit sues Hin Leong, Glencore over 'sham' oil deal
summary: UniCredit has sued Hin Leong Trading and Glencore over a 'sham' oil deal. UniCredit financed a December delivery of 150,000 tonnes of fuel oil from Glencore for $37.2 million, but later discovered Hin Leong had a separate agreement to sell the cargo back to Glencore. UniCredit claims the deal was a sham, depriving them of security over the goods. The lawsuit follows a report by PwC stating that Hin Leong used at least 18 letters of credit to purchase cargo and sell it back to the seller simultaneously, raising liquidity to pay loans.

site_title: Citi to open its largest wealth hub globally in Singapore in December
summary: Citi is set to open its largest wealth hub globally in Singapore in December, featuring a 30,000 square foot facility with built-in facilities for tailored lifestyle events and investment seminars. The hub will employ over 300 relationship managers and product specialists, and will incorporate safe distancing measures, including portable plexi guard shields and antimicrobial coatings. The move aims to tap into Singapore's growing affluent segment and set the bank apart from competition, with plans to double its wealth management business by 2025.

site_title: Consumer confidence in US posts biggest gain in 17 years
summary: US consumer confidence surged in September by 15.5 points, the largest gain in 17 years, reaching 101.8, exceeding economists' forecasts. Despite optimism about job market and short-term outlook, Americans remain downbeat about the current state of the job market and coronavirus. A rise in infection rates and fiscal relief for the unemployed could weigh on confidence. Consumers expressed greater optimism about their financial prospects, with increased plans to make major purchases and buy homes.

site_title: Bank behind world's first green bond is set to blaze a new trail
summary: SEB AB, a Swedish bank, is set to issue the first sustainability-linked bond in the Nordic region, expected to come within a few months. Unlike green bonds, this instrument links borrowing costs to environmental, social, or governance goals, not specific projects. The move aims to boost supply to a market struggling to meet investor demand. This is part of a growing trend in sustainable finance, with global sustainability-linked bond issuance reaching $1.1 billion in the first half of 2020. The European Central Bank's acceptance of these instruments as collateral has also provided a boost.

site_title: Bank of England realistic about challenge of sub-zero rates for banks
summary: Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey acknowledged the challenges negative interest rates would pose for the banking system, but did not rule out using them to support Britain's economy. The central bank's reliance on retail deposits, which continue to offer positive rates, could reduce the effectiveness of negative rates. Bailey reiterated that the BoE was not ready to implement sub-zero rates, despite evidence suggesting they might be beneficial. The Bank of England is exploring the possibility of using negative rates in the fourth quarter.

site_title: MinLaw to curb number of owners a proxy can represent at meetings on enbloc sales
summary: The Singapore Ministry of Law (MinLaw) will restrict the number of owners a proxy can represent at general meetings for en bloc sales, capping it at 2% of total lots or 2 lots, whichever is higher. This move aims to curb proxy abuse. Alternative arrangements for meetings, including virtual AGMs, will continue until June 30, 2021. Real-time electronic voting is now allowed for certain types of meetings, including company general meetings, with safeguards in place.

site_title: Cybersecurity software firm McAfee files to go public
summary: Cybersecurity software firm McAfee Corp has filed to go public, listing a $100 million offering with the US Securities and Exchange Commission. The company, previously a unit of Intel Corp, has seen a 78% gain in shares of newly public software companies this year. McAfee reported a profit of $31 million on revenue of $1.4 billion for the 26 weeks ended June 27. The company's backers include TPG and Thoma Bravo, and the IPO follows a software IPO boom this year, with software companies accounting for $12.8 billion of the $102 billion raised on US exchanges.

site_title: Governments should not let Covid-19 fallout hurt fight against climate change
summary: Governments are struggling to balance their response to the Covid-19 pandemic with the need to address climate change. The unprecedented stimulus packages may lead to a large debt overhang, potentially delaying investments in low-carbon technologies. Despite record-low carbon emissions due to the pandemic, experts warn that the world cannot afford to slow down on the climate agenda. The International Energy Agency predicts a 6% drop in global energy demand, while the World Health Organization estimates a doubling of Covid-19 deaths. Governments must leverage pandemic lessons to better prepare for climate change, or risk another devastating shock.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust's preferential offering priced at S$2.34
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust has priced its preferential offering at S$2.34 per new unit, a 7% discount to the volume-weighted average price (VWAP) of S$2.5171. The issue is expected to raise about S$759.7 million, with 290 preferential offering units for every 1,000 existing units. The private placement also priced at S$2.35 per unit, with gross proceeds of S$575 million. The trust plans to use the funds to acquire a remaining 63.11% stake in AsiaRetail Fund and reduce existing debts.

site_title: CPH to acquire Shanaya Environmental Services for S$22m
summary: CPH Ltd, a Singapore-based printed circuit board manufacturer, has entered a S$22 million conditional sale and purchase agreement with Shanaya Environmental Services to acquire 100% of Shanaya's issued share capital. The deal includes a cash payment of S$3 million and the issuance of 3.17 billion new shares to Shanaya's directors at 0.6 Singapore cents per share. The acquisition is expected to result in a reverse takeover and will increase CPH's total shares to 4.4 billion.

site_title: The role of tax policies in shaping work trends
summary: A KPMG survey of 315 global CEOs, including 25 in Singapore, found three trends in the post-pandemic work landscape: continued use of digital collaboration tools for work-from-home (WFH), the widening of talent pools through remote hiring, and the de-densification of central offices. Tax policies can play a role in shaping these trends, with opportunities to incentivize emerging sectors like cloud and data services, and to encourage sustainable development in alternate CBD locations. The authorities can leverage these trends to gain a competitive edge in the post-Covid-19 economy, but will need to review employment laws and tax provisions to enable remote hiring and talent mobility.

site_title: JPMorgan pays US$920m, admits misconduct in spoofing probe
summary: JPMorgan agreed to pay over US$920 million to resolve US authorities' claims of market manipulation in metals futures and Treasury securities trading. The largest monetary penalty ever imposed by the CFTC, it includes a US$436.4 million fine, US$311.7 million in restitution, and US$172 million in disgorgement. The settlement ends a criminal investigation into six employees accused of rigging gold and silver futures prices for over eight years.

site_title: Vietnam's Q3 recovery weaker than expected: economists
summary: Vietnam's economy recovered in Q3 with a 2.6% year-on-year growth, falling short of economists' expectations of 2.7%. The recovery pace remains weak due to the temporary resurgence of Covid-19 cases in Danang and ongoing pandemic impact. Experts predict a 4% growth in Q4 and 2.8% full-year expansion, with the services sector expected to trail due to softer demand and limited tourism recovery.

site_title: Amazon unveils payment by hand-waving
summary: Amazon has unveiled Amazon One, a biometric payment system using palm recognition, to be made available to rival retailers and as a replacement for badge entry at stadiums or workplaces. The system uses unique palm signatures to identify individuals and authorize transactions. Amazon will install the system at its Amazon Go retail locations, starting with two stores in Seattle. The biometric data is protected by multiple security controls and never stored on the device, with images sent to a highly secure cloud area.

site_title: Insurers see long-lasting changes
summary: The International Union of Marine Insurance (IUMI) has identified four key challenges facing marine insurers: the Covid-19 pandemic, changing macro-economic and geopolitical situations, climate change, and data and digitalization. IUMI president Richard Turner stated that the pandemic has disrupted global trade and supply chains, leading to a reduction in premium base and increased risk accumulation. He also suggested that the pandemic may lead to a shift to more localized logistics and simpler supply chains. Climate change is expected to influence marine claims and pose a challenge to the industry, particularly due to rising sea levels and the shift towards greener economies.

site_title: Walmart said to be eyeing US$25b investment in Tata Group's 'super app'
summary: Walmart is reportedly in talks with Tata Group for a potential $25 billion investment in the conglomerate's "super app", set to launch in India in December or January. The app will integrate Tata's consumer businesses, including healthcare, grocery, insurance, fashion, and electronics. This investment would further strengthen Tata's digital presence in the Indian market.

site_title: MediShield Life to be enhanced, but premiums set to rise
summary: The MediShield Life insurance plan in Singapore is set to undergo enhancements, but premiums will rise for the first time since its launch in 2015. The plan has paid out S$3.5 billion for 2.3 million claims, with payouts increasing by 40% and claimants rising by 30% over the past four years. Proposed changes include a cut in proration for private hospitals, affecting private Integrated Shield plan holders as well.

site_title: Fighting 'missing trader' GST fraud in Singapore
summary: Singapore's tax authorities are cracking down on the "missing trader" GST fraud, a global problem where syndicates exploit the Goods and Services Tax (GST) regime to defraud tax authorities. The draft amendment bill proposes a new framework to deal with the issue, denying input tax claims to taxpayers who knew or "should have known" of a fraudulent arrangement. To qualify, taxpayers must demonstrate they took reasonable steps to determine the arrangement's legitimacy and arrived at a reasonable conclusion. The Comptroller of Goods and Services Tax may also impose a 10% surcharge on denied input tax claims.

site_title: Iata reduces air traffic outlook as crisis drags on
summary: Global airlines have reduced their 2020 traffic forecast to a 66% decline in full-year passenger traffic, down from a previously forecast 63%. The International Air Transport Association (IATA) attributes the decline to renewed coronavirus outbreaks and travel restrictions, which have halted the small summer rebound. Load factors plummeted to a record low of 58.5% in August, with cargo demand down 12.6% compared to the previous month. Airlines are urging governments to lift quarantines and travel curbs, instead promoting rapid Covid-19 testing at airports. Losses are expected to continue throughout 2020.

site_title: Phase 3 reopening will not see big jump in business: economists
