summary: Singapore's Phase 3 reopening, expected to relax border-control measures and social restrictions, may not lead to a significant boost in business due to global uncertainty and uneven recovery. Economists caution that demand will likely remain lacklustre for some time, with a focus on sectors such as food and beverage, wholesale trade, and hospitality. A smooth transition to Phase 3 could mean an upside to full-year growth forecasts, but firms remain cautious and expect a more incremental impact on growth.

images.alt_text: If larger social gatherings are allowed, this could boost the recreational, entertainment, MICE and some hospitality businesses, said Maybank KE's Chua Hak Bin.

site_title: Concentrated power in Big Tech harms the US
summary: The US government is taking steps to curb corporate monopoly power, with the Department of Justice expected to file a lawsuit against Google's search dominance. This move aims to address the concentration of power in Big Tech, which has diminished the US economy's vibrancy over the past 30 years. Critics argue that focusing solely on prices paid by consumers is insufficient, as digital transactions are valued in data, making it difficult to prove economic harm. Policymakers are now grappling with the issue of corporate power, with some advocating for a broader approach to curbing Big Tech, similar to what is happening in Europe.

site_title: Toshiba plans to exit money-losing LSI chip business
summary: Toshiba Corp plans to exit its money-losing LSI chip business, citing a need to boost profit margins and establish a sustainable business structure amidst market fluctuations. The company will relocate or offer early retirement options to 770 employees, incurring a cost of 11.8 billion yen. Toshiba's power management chip business will remain, while it will continue to support existing customers for its image recognition processors supplied to Toyota Motor. The decision comes as the global chip market is clouded by US-China tensions.

site_title: Kuwait's ruler Emir Sheikh Sabah dies
summary: Kuwait's long-serving Emir Sheikh Sabah al-Ahmad al-Sabah, 91, has died, according to an official statement. He ruled the Gulf Arab oil producer since 2006 and was a key champion of Arab detente, navigating regional tensions and promoting Gulf unity. Sheikh Sabah's designated successor is his brother, Crown Prince Sheikh Nawaf al-Ahmad al-Sabah, who will assume power and appoint a new crown prince after a meeting of senior family members.

site_title: Taiwan defence chief says no signs China is preparing for war
summary: Taiwan's Defence Minister Yen De-fa stated there are no signs China is preparing for war with Taiwan, despite repeated Chinese drills near the island. China claims Taiwan as its own, but Taiwan's forces are maintaining peacetime combat preparedness and have not stepped up their alert status. Yen vowed to defend the island's sovereignty and democracy, while Premier Su Tseng-chang said attackers would face a heavy price. The US has strengthened its support for Taiwan, including planned new arms sales, amid China's growing anger over the move.

site_title: Accrelist scraps plans to convert S$4m convertible loan
summary: Accrelist, a CATALIST-listed firm, has scrapped plans to convert its S$4 million convertible loan from Singapore Rixin Zhonghe Investment, citing continued uncertainty from the COVID-19 pandemic. The firm will continue making repayments, totaling S$3.7 million, and the remaining S$616,776 by December 31, 2020. Upon full repayment, Accrelist's obligations under the loan agreement will be discharged in full.

site_title: Keppel identifies S$17.5b of assets that can be monetised over time
summary: Keppel Corporation has identified S$17.5 billion of assets that can be monetized over time, with a focus on unlocking S$3-5 billion worth of value over the next three years. The company will conduct a strategic review of its offshore and marine (O&M) business, exploring options such as mergers, divestments, and restructuring. Keppel aims to transition into an "asset-light model" and has set a disciplined approach to capital allocation. The move is seen as a response to the company's recent financial struggles and comes as investors have expressed concerns about the quality of its assets, particularly in the O&M sector.

site_title: Change is the only constant, Singapore understands
summary: Singapore has emerged as a leader in embracing change, particularly in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic. The country has witnessed significant shifts in consumer behavior, with super apps, e-commerce, and streaming media experiencing massive adoption. Technology has accelerated digital transformation, with remote learning and telemedicine becoming more prevalent. Industries like logistics have also transformed, with the rise of cloud kitchens and digitized wet markets. Singapore's government is fostering a culture of empathy and trust, with initiatives such as training senior volunteers to become "Smart Nation Ambassadors." The country is also poised to accelerate sustainable investing, with a renewed focus on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors.

site_title: MediShield Life to be enhanced, but premiums set to rise
summary: Singapore's MediShield Life insurance plan to be enhanced with changes including higher claim limits and removal of exclusions, but premiums are set to rise by around 10% in the first year, with a further 30% increase in the second year. The government has committed $2.2 billion in premium subsidies and support over three years to cushion the premium hike. The changes aim to ensure greater parity in payouts between subsidized and private patients, with private Integrated Shield plans expected to also increase premiums.

site_title: Keppel seeks to unlock value for S$3-5 billion of assets over next 3 years
summary: Keppel Corporation plans to unlock value for S$3-5 billion of its S$17.5 billion assets over the next three years, primarily through monetization of landbank, non-core assets, and funds. CEO Loh Chin Hua stated that the company will explore both organic and inorganic options, including a strategic review of its offshore and marine business, and potential mergers or divestments. The move aims to boost growth initiatives and navigate the challenging global oil and gas industry amid low oil prices.

site_title: US goods trade deficit rises; inventories increase
summary: The US goods trade deficit rose 3.5% to $82.9 billion in August, driven by a 3.1% increase in imports to $201.3 billion, surpassing a 2.8% increase in exports to $118.3 billion. The increase was largely due to businesses rebuilding inventories depleted during the Covid-19 pandemic. Despite this, the wider trade deficit may not significantly impact the third quarter's GDP growth, which is expected to remain strong despite rising new coronavirus cases and slowing economic activity.

site_title: France to ban mink farms and wild animals in travelling circuses
summary: France plans to "gradually" ban mink farms, the use of wild animals in traveling circuses, and the breeding of dolphins and orcas in captivity. Environment Minister Barbara Pompili announced the measures, citing a change in attitude towards wild animals. The country's dolphinariums will no longer breed or bring in new dolphins or killer whales, but a ban on mink farms and circuses is expected in the "years to come." The government will offer aid packages to help affected circuses and dolphinariums adapt to the new regulations.

site_title: Redas calls for ABSD deferment for first-time HDB upgraders to private property
summary: Real Estate Developers' Association of Singapore (Redas) president Chia Ngiang Hong has urged the government to defer payment of the additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) for first-time HDB upgraders to private property for six months. Currently, HDB upgraders buying EC units receive ABSD remission, but those buying private homes face a 14-day payment deadline. Redas aims to ease cash flow for genuine first-time upgraders, who would benefit from an extended payment period. The government has been monitoring the residential property market closely, with Minister for National Development Desmond Lee emphasizing the need for resilience in the sector.

images.alt_text: Toasting amid safe distancing are (from left) Redas president Chia Ngiang Hong; Redas honorary secretary Chong Hock Chang; Minister for National Development Desmond Lee; Redas first vice-president Cheng Hsing Yao; Redas patron Kwee Liong Keng; Redas immediate past president Augustine Tan.

site_title: Thailand set to borrow US$46b to fund virus recovery
summary: Thailand plans to borrow $46 billion in the fiscal year starting October 1 to counter the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The borrowing will be used to finance economic stimulus programs, budget deficit, infrastructure investments, and bailout of pandemic-hit state enterprises. The public debt-to-GDP ratio is expected to widen to 57.23% in 2020-21, near the legal limit of 60%. The government has so far spent only about a third of its initial $1.9 trillion stimulus package, and economists predict the economy may contract less than 8.5% this year.

site_title: EY expands start-up incubator programme to Asean, goes virtual
summary: EY has expanded its start-up incubator programme, EY Foundry, to cover more markets in Southeast Asia and the Asia Pacific region, following successful runs in Singapore and Sydney. The virtual programme will offer up to 14 start-ups six months of participation in high-growth activities, including tailored learnings and EY piloting sessions. The programme focuses on tech start-ups in areas such as tax, fintech, and HR tech, and provides US$120,000 worth of Microsoft Azure credits. Applications are open until November 6, and successful applicants will be announced at a virtual launch event.

site_title: CapitaLand Mall Trust and CapitaLand Commercial Trust unitholders vote in favour of proposed merger
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) and CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) unitholders voted overwhelmingly in favor of a proposed merger to form a new real estate investment trust (Reit). The merger, expected to be completed on October 21, will result in one of the largest Reits in the Asia-Pacific and Singapore by market capitalization and total portfolio property value. The merged entity, named CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT), will have a diversified portfolio of 24 strategically-located and high-quality retail, office, and integrated developments in Singapore and overseas.

site_title: Philippines accuses Facebook of censoring pro-government content
summary: The Philippines has accused Facebook of censoring pro-government content, calling it a curtailing of freedom of speech. President Rodrigo Duterte warned Facebook to explain its content regulation in the country, following the dismantling of a Chinese-Philippine network for "coordinated inauthentic behavior". The administration denies allegations of allowing social media abuse to harass opponents. Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg has called for regulation of online content, and the government wants new policies to "level the playing field" on the platform.

site_title: Giant robot moving in Japan harbour entrances millions on Twitter
summary: A 25-tonne Giant Gundam robot, part of the Gundam Factory Yokohama tourist attraction, has captured the attention of millions on Twitter with motion test videos. The robot, which dwarfs boats in the harbour, is the centrepiece of the delayed attraction set to open on December 19. The mobile suit, operated by companies like Yaskawa Electric and Nabtesco, is part of the Gundam franchise, which debuted in Japan in the late 1970s and has gained a worldwide following.

site_title: Swatch shuts down some technology systems after cyberattack
summary: Swatch Group confirmed a cyberattack on its IT systems over the weekend, prompting the shutdown of some technology systems. The company, the world's biggest watchmaker, took a precautionary measure to protect its operations, but did not specify which systems were affected. The situation is expected to return to normal as soon as possible.

site_title: Michelin scraps 2020 Singapore guide after long restaurant closures
summary: The Michelin Guide will not release new recommendations for Singapore restaurants in 2020 due to the prolonged closures of eateries during the COVID-19 pandemic. Michelin's inspectors need to extend their inspection period to evaluate dining-in experiences, which were compromised during the closures. The guide will announce the 2021 selection in coming months. Two Singapore restaurants, Odette and Les Amis, currently hold three Michelin stars, with a total of 43 restaurants in the city-state.

site_title: Tritech builds AI-based data analytics platform to digitise business
summary: Tritech Group has developed an AI-based data analytics platform, ADAS, to digitize its engineering and water-related businesses. The system uses 4D analysis software to minimize manpower requirements and improve profit margins. The platform is part of the group's digital transformation journey, which has seen a significant increase in digital-related projects, with accumulated contract values growing from S$4.1 million to S$38.2 million from FY2014 to FY2020. The system is expected to enhance efficiency and productivity, and extend services to customers beyond Singapore.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 7.76 points to 1,503.90. The index saw a volume of 5.14 billion lots worth RM3.586 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 611 to 412.

site_title: HKEX chief Li to step down at end of 2020, ahead of schedule
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEX) announced that Chief Executive Charles Li will step down at the end of 2020, ahead of schedule. Calvin Tai, the current chief operating officer, will serve as interim CEO starting January 1, 2021. Li will remain a senior advisor to the board for 6 months. The company's chairman, Laura Cha, stated that the search for a permanent CEO is progressing well and will be updated when necessary.

site_title: Singapore to explore reinstating essential travel to Sichuan
summary: Singapore is exploring ways to reinstate essential travel to Sichuan province in China, following a strong interest from both business communities. Second Minister for Trade and Industry Tan See Leng announced plans to revive passenger traffic and increase direct air services between Singapore and Chengdu, the provincial capital. This move aims to "kick-start business exchanges" as both economies recover from the pandemic, with trade between Sichuan and Singapore reaching $1.25 billion in the first half of the year.

site_title: Britain hits Airbnb UK with extra US$2.3m tax bill after probe
summary: Britain's tax authorities have imposed an extra $2.3 million tax bill on Airbnb UK, following an investigation into the home rental company's tax arrangements. The UK arm of Airbnb paid 1.1 million in tax on its profits in 2019, compared to 146,000 pounds in 2018. The company has committed to working with HMRC and sharing data on host earnings. This comes as governments worldwide scrutinize Airbnb's tax practices, with HMRC expected to address issues over hosts' payment of tax in 2021/2022.

site_title: German solar battery maker sonnen expands capacity as power subsidies end
summary: German solar battery maker sonnen is expanding its capacity in Wildpoldsried as the 20-year subsidy program for renewable energy feed-in tariffs ends, making home storage systems more economical for homeowners. The company plans to invest in new facilities and scale up its business, both in Germany and internationally. With over 60,000 home storage batteries sold, sonnen employs 700 people across six countries. The expansion aims to capitalize on the growing demand for home storage systems as consumers shift to self-financing models.

site_title: Thai economy seen contracting less than forecast this year
summary: Thailand's economy is expected to contract less than initially projected, with a possible shrinkage of 7.8% instead of 8.5%, thanks to government stimulus measures. The finance ministry approved a $2.56 billion economic injection in the final quarter of the year. This news comes as the global economic landscape continues to evolve, with other countries facing economic challenges such as the UK's second consecutive month of economic contraction and rising US tariffs affecting the Asian garment industry.

site_title: Nokia wins 5G radio equipment contract from Britain's BT
summary: Nokia has secured a contract with Britain's BT to supply 5G radio equipment, making it BT's largest equipment provider. The deal comes months after the UK banned China's Huawei from 5G networks. The contract size was not disclosed. This marks a significant win for Nokia under its new CEO Pekka Lundmark, and it underscores the growing demand for 5G equipment in the UK.

site_title: Redas president calls for ABSD reprieve for first-time upgraders
summary: Singapore's Real Estate Developers' Association president, Chia Ngiang Hong, has urged the government to consider allowing first-time upgraders to defer payment of the additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) till six months after completion of a private property. This would help ease cash flow for genuine first-time upgraders. Minister for National Development Desmond Lee stated that the government will continue to monitor the sector's impact of the pandemic and adjust policies as necessary, while emphasizing the need for building resilience and transforming the construction and built environment sector for sustainability.

site_title: STI retreats 0.5% alongside muted trading in Asian markets
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) retreated 0.46% to 2,471.61 on Tuesday, amidst muted trading in Asian markets. Dairy Farm International was the top loser, falling 3.8% after a one-day loss of over 4%. Keppel Corp was the top performer, with shares rising 2.6% after announcing a strategic review of its O&M business. Asian markets finished mixed, with the Hang Seng Index dipping 0.85% and the Nikkei 225 advancing 0.12%. Analysts attributed the subdued market to investors' focus on the US presidential debate and potential foreign relations issues.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens flat ahead of first presidential debate
summary: Wall Street's main indexes fell slightly at the open on Tuesday as investors awaited the first presidential debate, staying cautious ahead of the event. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.09% to 27,560.24, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also fell 0.02% and 0.08% respectively. The muted trading was attributed to investors' focus on the upcoming debate and uncertainty surrounding US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Strong condo sales targeting HDB upgraders will likely sustain momentum: DBS
summary: DBS Group Research notes that strong condo sales targeting HDB upgraders are likely to sustain momentum in the Singapore property market. Recent sales volumes, particularly at the Penrose project, demonstrate a robust demand for private homes, with 7,600 units sold in the year to date, a 7% increase from the previous year. Analysts attribute this to pent-up demand, low interest rates, and sticky property prices, with some suggesting that the market may continue to do well, especially for projects targeting the upgraders market.

site_title: Goldman Sachs to launch foreign exchange pricing engine in Singapore
summary: Goldman Sachs plans to launch an electronic foreign exchange pricing engine in Singapore, aiming to deliver low-latency execution for its clients. The engine is part of the Monetary Authority of Singapore's strategy to develop the city-state into a global price discovery and liquidity centre for FX during Asian trading hours. The first clients are scheduled to go live in the first quarter of 2021, marking the fourth FX pricing engine Goldman Sachs supports globally. This move follows Barclays' announcement of a similar FX trading and pricing engine launch in Singapore later in 2021.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Temasek Financial has announced plans to issue 10, 30.5, and 50-year US dollar bonds under its US$25 billion guaranteed global medium-term note program. IMDA and mobile network operators will hire and reskill 1,000 professionals in 5G. Strong condo sales targeting HDB upgraders are expected to sustain momentum. Travel startup KKday has secured US$75 million in Series C funding. Unitholders of CapitaLand Mall Trust and CapitaLand Commercial Trust have voted in favor of a proposed merger. The Straits Times Index fell 0.5% alongside muted trading in Asian markets.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end lower
summary: Hong Kong shares ended lower Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index slipping 0.85% to 23,275.53, as traders focused on the first US presidential debate. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.21%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index on China's second exchange added 1.01%. The declines followed a previous day's rally, with traders brushing off new Trump threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets slip at open
summary: European stock markets declined at the open on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index falling 0.2% to 5,918.66 points, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 index losing 0.5% to 12,810.05 points. This follows a 3.2% gain on Monday. The decline is attributed to a decrease in mining and healthcare stocks, with the US-EU trade talks also drawing attention. Despite this, US indices, including the S&P 500 and Nasdaq, reached fresh records.

site_title: Tiffany sticks to its guns in push to uphold LVMH deal
summary: Tiffany & Co. has stood by its $16 billion sale to LVMH, dismissing the French luxury giant's claims to back out of the deal as "baseless and misleading." LVMH had attempted to terminate the purchase, citing the French government's request to delay the deal's closing and Tiffany's mismanagement during the pandemic. Tiffany's chairman, Roger Farah, accused LVMH of trying to evade its contractual obligation to pay the agreed-upon price.

site_title: South Koreans urged to avoid a surge of coronavirus over harvest holiday
summary: South Korea urged citizens to adhere to social distancing measures ahead of the Chuseok harvest holiday, despite a recent decline in new coronavirus cases. The Korea Disease Control and Prevention Agency reported 38 new infections, bringing the national tally to 23,699 cases and 407 deaths. Authorities warned that a surge in cases could occur if people fail to follow anti-virus measures, and imposed special measures, including temperature checks and restrictions on gatherings. The government also warned of strict punishment for those who participate in unauthorized rallies.

site_title: Majority of Hong Kong opposition lawmakers plan to remain in office
summary: A majority of Hong Kong's pro-democracy lawmakers, 16 of 23, plan to remain in office despite China's decision to extend their terms without a planned election. The decision comes after a survey of democracy supporters showed 47.1% in favor of lawmakers serving out their term, while 45.8% favored resignation. The split results may harden divisions within the pro-democracy camp, which has been weakened by China's clampdown on local opposition. The decision could also make it more difficult for the opposition to block Beijing-approved measures, potentially limiting their ability to challenge the city's Beijing-backed administration.

site_title: ERA Singapore sells house in eight minutes at its first virtual property auction
summary: ERA Singapore successfully held its first virtual property auction, selling a two-and-a-half storey semi-detached house for S$3.4 million in just eight minutes. Four groups of buyers made 15 bids, with the last seven bids fiercely contested within three minutes. The virtual auction attracted over 50 participants, with the number of registered individuals doubling compared to physical auctions. ERA Singapore's chief executive, Jack Chua, hailed the event as a "promising start" and plans to spearhead more innovative initiatives to boost the real estate market.

site_title: Changi Airport Terminal 1, Alexandra Village Food Centre and IMM among places visited by Covid-19 patients
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) in Singapore has released a list of locations visited by Covid-19 patients while they were still infectious. The locations include Orchis Food Court in Changi Airport Terminal 1, Alexandra Village Food Centre, and IMM, among others. Between Sept 15 and 25, a total of 27 new coronavirus cases were confirmed, with 17 being migrant workers living in dormitories. The number of new daily cases in the community has remained stable, with 57,451 patients fully recovered and 32 patients remaining in hospital.

site_title: Indonesia parliament passes President Joko Widodo's US$185b budget
summary: Indonesia's parliament approved President Joko Widodo's $185 billion budget for 2021, a 0.4% increase from the previous year. The budget aims to support economic recovery and has a smaller deficit forecast at 5.7% of GDP. Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati said the budget is both supportive and consolidative, with plans to reduce the deficit to below 3% by 2023. The budget allocates funds for infrastructure, health spending, and coronavirus vaccine procurement, aiming to boost growth and create herd immunity.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's parliament on Tuesday approved President Joko Widodo's US$185 billion budget for 2021, which his finance minister described as both supportive for Southeast Asia's largest economy and also the start of a fiscal consolidation.

site_title: Envictus group CEO Khor Sin Kok resigns
summary: Envictus International Holdings announced the resignation of CEO Khor Sin Kok on October 1, following the expiry of his leave of absence. Acting CEO Kamal YP Tan will take over as group CEO from the same date. Director Mah Weng Choong will be redesignated as non-independent non-executive director due to receiving a consultancy fee exceeding S$50,000 from a subsidiary. Envictus shares fell 19.7% to close at 9.8 Singapore cents.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher as US stocks gain, virus cases fall
summary: South Korean stocks ended higher on Tuesday, gaining 0.86% to close at 2,327.89, driven by US stock market gains and lower domestic COVID-19 cases. The Kospi index rose 19.81 points, marking a 0.1% monthly gain and a 10.4% quarterly gain. Markets will be closed for Chuseok holiday from Wednesday to Friday, before resuming trading on October 5.

site_title: Another childcare-related site for sale; EOI exercise at S$14.8m guide price
summary: A 999-year leasehold childcare centre site in Singapore's Sengkang area is up for sale via expression of interest, with a guide price of S$14.8 million. The site spans 10,851 sq ft and has a gross floor area of 19,431 sq ft. It is zoned "residential" under the prevailing Master Plan and has been previously approved for use as a childcare centre. The sale offers potential purchasers the option to continue operations as a childcare centre, saving the hassle of a tedious application process.

site_title: UOA unit proposes to sell Kuala Lumpur office tower at discount to UOA Reit
summary: A United Overseas Australia (UOA) subsidiary has proposed selling its Kuala Lumpur office tower, UOA Corporate Tower, to UOA Real Estate Investment Trust (UOA Reit) for RM700 million, a 2.5% discount to its market value. The sale will improve UOA Development's cash flow and boost earnings per share, while UOA Reit aims to acquire a strategically located property that can contribute to its long-term growth. The deal is expected to be completed in Q4 2020.

site_title: Built Environment Living Lab Framework to enable test-bedding of innovative solutions
summary: The Built Environment Living Lab Framework (BE LLF) has been launched to enable test-bedding of innovative solutions in urban spaces. The framework, announced by Singapore's Minister of State for the Prime Minister's Office and National Development, aims to support the adoption of fresh, innovative solutions in the built environment sector. It will allow companies to test their proposals in living spaces, with regulatory support provided for those that require it. The framework also aligns with the Skills Framework for Built Environment, which lists 49 job roles and 163 technical skills needed for the sector.

site_title: Australia: Shares give up early gains as miners, banks weigh
summary: Australian shares closed flat on Tuesday, giving up early gains, as miners and financials weighed heavily. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,952.1, little changed, despite rising 0.7% earlier in the day. Heavyweight financials fell 0.4%, with Commonwealth Bank and Westpac shedding 0.7% and 1.3%, respectively. Miners, reliant on exports to China, declined, while energy firms advanced 0.6%. The benchmark looked set to post its first monthly drop in six.

site_title: UK car dealer Pendragon turns profitable after first-half loss
summary: UK car dealer Pendragon has turned profitable for the first time in two years, posting an underlying profit of £7 million for July and August, following the easing of COVID-19 lockdowns. The company's first-half loss narrowed to £31 million, down from £32.2 million last year. However, Pendragon did not reinstate its full-year outlook due to uncertainties related to government support programs. The pandemic is expected to cost the company £44.1 million this year, and shares rose 3.3% following the announcement.

site_title: Gay, lesbian, bisexual Americans at higher risk for migraines: study
summary: US research found that lesbian, gay, and bisexual Americans are at higher risk for migraines, with nearly one-third experiencing migraines compared to 18% of heterosexual participants. A study published in the Journal of the American Medical Association Neurology revealed that LGB individuals are 58% more likely to get migraines than straight people. The study, conducted by the University of California - San Francisco, highlights a potential risk factor for migraines related to sexual orientation.

site_title: Vietnam economic growth picks up as new virus outbreaks tamed
summary: Vietnam's economic growth accelerated to 2.62% in the third quarter, surpassing the 0.39% growth in the second quarter. The country has managed to contain new coronavirus outbreaks, allowing it to resume economic activity sooner than many other countries. Exports rose 4.2% and industrial output increased 3.8% year-over-year, while consumer prices rose 2.98% and retail sales grew 4.9%. Despite this, growth remains below the pre-pandemic period, with the country's GDP still significantly lower than the 7.31% growth recorded last year.

site_title: Global coronavirus deaths pass 'agonising milestone' of 1m
summary: The global death toll from Covid-19 has surpassed 1 million, according to a Reuters tally, with over 5,400 people dying daily worldwide. The number of deaths has doubled in three months, with the US, Brazil, and India accounting for nearly 45% of global fatalities. Experts warn that official figures underrepresent the real toll due to inadequate testing and recording. The pandemic has led to changes in burial rites, with morgues and funeral businesses overwhelmed, and loved ones often barred from bidding farewell in person.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index closes higher
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index closed higher on Tuesday, rising 0.12% or 27.48 points to 23,539.10, amid cautious trade ahead of the first US presidential debate. The broader Topix index fell 0.23% or 3.83 points to 1,658.10. This move follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks, while Asia markets also saw gains despite new Trump threats.

site_title: Singapore startup grows prawn meat from stem cells
summary: Singaporean startup Shiok Meats has secured US$12.6 million in Series A funding to sustain its operations and research for at least three years. The company, which produces lab-grown prawn meat, aims to reduce production costs from US$3,500 per kilogram to US$50 per kilogram by 2022. With a post-money valuation of US$50 million, Shiok Meats joins the growing list of alternative protein companies, including Impossible Foods and Beyond Meat, as consumers increasingly prioritize nutrition and environmental concerns.

site_title: Travel startup KKday bags US$75m in Series C funding
summary: KKday, a Taiwanese travel startup, has secured US$75 million in Series C funding to develop its new booking management platform, Rezio. The platform, targeted at tour operators and activity providers, aims to reduce operational costs and increase efficiencies. Launched in Taiwan and Japan during the Covid-19 pandemic, Rezio has already seen adoption by over 300 providers, including HIS International, a large online travel agency in Japan. KKday plans to expand the platform to Asia and increase its team and operations in Japan, Korea, and South-east Asia.

site_title: SIA offers tours and inflight dining experiences
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has launched three behind-the-scenes experiences for the public, including a tour of its training facilities and a three-hour dining experience on a stationary A380 aircraft. The "Discover Your Singapore Airlines" programmes offer a glimpse into the airline's history and operations, with activities such as grooming workshops and flight simulator sessions. The experiences are available for booking starting November 1, with tours and dining experiences to be held on November 21-29.

site_title: Thailand to slowly restart tourism with flight from China
summary: Thailand is set to slowly restart its tourism sector with a flight from China, marking a gradual recovery from the coronavirus pandemic. The first flight, carrying 120 tourists from Guangzhou to Phuket, is expected to generate 1 billion baht in revenue and attract 14,400 tourists over the year. The government has set a target of 6.7 million foreign visitors this year, down from a record 39.8 million in 2019. Visitors will need to undergo health checks and quarantine, with Thailand aiming to prevent a second wave of infections.

site_title: Uber weighs purchase of BMW-Daimler ride-hailing venture
summary: Uber is considering a potential acquisition of Daimler and BMW's ride-hailing joint venture Free Now, which could boost its market share in Europe and Latin America. The deal, if agreed, could be complicated by the challenging ride-hailing market and varying transport regulations. Daimler valued the equity investment in Free Now at 618 million euros (S$990 million) at the end of June. This acquisition would follow Uber's recent efforts to shed minority holdings in several ride-hailing operations and comes as the company looks to expand its presence in Europe and Latin America.

site_title: Virtual AGMs allowed till next June; real-time electronic voting green-lit: MinLaw
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Law has extended virtual annual general meetings (AGMs) until June 30, 2021, and allowed real-time electronic voting for certain types of meetings, including general meetings of companies and business trusts. The ministry has also introduced new safeguards to prevent proxy abuse, including restrictions on the number of owners a proxy can represent at general meetings for en bloc sales. The changes aim to provide more convenience and engagement for virtual meetings while minimizing the risk of proxy abuse.

site_title: Microsoft 365 outage affects multiple services
summary: Microsoft 365 experienced a major outage affecting users' access to multiple services, including Outlook.com and Microsoft Teams. The outage was caused by a recent change introduced by Microsoft, which the company rolled back to mitigate the impact. Despite this, the issue persisted, and users reported difficulties accessing their services, including missing job interviews and college deadlines. Microsoft is working to evaluate other solutions and investigate the root cause of the outage. The company is rerouting traffic to alternate systems to provide relief to affected users.

site_title: Citi to open its largest wealth hub globally in Singapore in December
summary: Citi is set to open its largest wealth hub globally in Singapore in December, featuring over 300 relationship managers and product specialists. The 30,000 square-foot facility will include built-in facilities for client events and investment seminars, with safety measures such as plexi guard shields and antimicrobial coatings. The move aims to tap into growing wealth in Singapore, with Citi planning to double its wealth management business by 2025 and increase market share to 5%. The new hub is part of the bank's efforts to enhance its client value proposition and expand its wealth management business.

site_title: Warning signs are flashing ahead of Covid's second US Winter
summary: US public health officials are warning of a potential surge in Covid-19 cases, hospitalizations, and deaths as the winter season approaches. Despite a decline in hospitalizations and deaths over the summer, data shows a plateau in new cases, hospitalizations, and deaths, with the number of hospitalizations at around 30,000 and deaths averaging about 750 per week. Scientists fear that the virus will spread more readily in the winter, with warmer weather allowing it to continue spreading across the country.

site_title: Britain's Greggs to cut jobs as outlook uncertain
summary: Greggs, a British baker, plans to cut staff jobs and hours due to an uncertain outlook amid the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Despite seeing improved sales in September, the company warns of rising infection rates and potential supply chain interruptions. Like-for-like sales averaged 71.2% of their 2019 level in the 12 weeks to September 26, with a slight increase to 76.1% in the most recent four weeks. The company is launching a consultation with union and employee representatives to minimize job losses through reduced hours.

images.alt_text: British baker Greggs said on Tuesday its sales had improved in September after a slow August but cautioned that the outlook was uncertain because of Covid-19 and it would have to cut staff jobs and hours.

site_title: Razer, Funding Societies partner to provide merchant loans
summary: Razer Fintech, the fintech arm of Razer, partners with Funding Societies to provide short-term business financing to merchants through Razer Merchant Services. The platform aims to support over 20,000 micro, small, and medium enterprises in Malaysia and South-east Asia with quick, tailor-made loans. The loans will offer a waiver of the retention sum, minimal documentation, and flexible tenure of six to 18 months. The partnership follows a rise in demand for loan relief during the pandemic, with nearly half of Malaysian businesses surveyed urging government aid and incentives.

site_title: Indian house prices to fall 6% this year, risk to downside: poll
summary: Indian house prices are expected to decline 6% this year due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, which has hurt demand in the housing market. The decline is more severe than predicted three months ago, with prices expected to fall 3% next year. Most new housing projects are unsold or delayed, and job losses and pay cuts are expected to continue. Retail inflation remains above the central bank's target range, limiting support for the economy. The risk to the housing market outlook is skewed to the downside, with nine analysts predicting a longer recovery period.

site_title: China's top climate scientists plan road map to 2060 goal
summary: China's top climate research institute has outlined a plan to achieve carbon neutrality by 2060, with a gradual transition to renewable and nuclear energy over the next decade and a half, and a rapid acceleration after 2035. The plan aims to increase renewable energy to 20% of total energy consumption by 2025, and to phase out coal-fired electricity by 2050. China's energy demand is projected to peak around 2035, with total energy demand declining by 2035 and reaching 80% of total energy consumption by 2060.

site_title: In changing Saudi Arabia, first dog cafe delights pet lovers
summary: In Saudi Arabia, a dog cafe called The Barking Lot has opened in the city of Khobar, offering a unique experience for pet owners and their dogs. The cafe, which opened in June, is a first for the ultra-conservative kingdom, where dogs are considered unclean animals and are generally banned from public places. The adoption of strays has become more popular in the rapidly modernizing kingdom, and the cafe is part of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's "Vision 2030" plan to promote modernization. The cafe offers a welcoming space for dog owners and their pets to socialize and relax.

site_title: IMDA, mobile network operators to hire, reskill 1,000 professionals in 5G
summary: IMDA and mobile network operators in Singapore have partnered to hire and reskill 1,000 professionals to support the country's 5G rollout. Of these, 30% are new roles, while 70% are upskilled professionals in 5G network, cybersecurity, and solution engineering. The initiative aims to create good jobs and opportunities for Singaporeans, with the first wave of training set to begin at the end of 2020. IMDA plans to equip a total of 5,000 professionals with 5G skills over the next three years.

site_title: China's Kangtai gets approval for clinical trial of coronavirus vaccine candidate
summary: China's Shenzhen Kangtai Biological Products received regulatory approval for its coronavirus vaccine candidate, which triggered antibodies in mice and monkeys and showed tolerance in vaccinated monkeys. The company plans to launch a clinical trial as soon as possible. This comes amid a global rush for a COVID-19 vaccine, with at least 10 experimental projects led by Chinese scientists in human trials. Kangtai's inactivated vaccine candidate is similar to those used for other diseases, and the company has a deal to supply the vaccine developed by AstraZeneca and the University of Oxford.

site_title: Cathay Pacific pilots push for seat at table for restructuring talks
summary: Pilots at Cathay Pacific Airways are pushing for a seat at the table in restructuring talks, following the airline's decision not to apply for government employment subsidies. The Hong Kong Aircrew Officers Association (HKAOA) plans to run a newspaper advertisement to drum up public support, citing research showing that pilots are crucial to the city's global reputation. The airline has warned of reviewing all aspects of its business model, with several employees bracing for major job losses, similar to rival airlines Singapore Airlines and Qantas Airways.

site_title: Gold nudges up as US dollar tepid ahead of Trump-Biden debate
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,883.51 per ounce, driven by a weaker US dollar and prospects of further fiscal stimulus in the US. The dollar index drifted away from a two-month high, making gold cheaper for holders of other currencies. Investors await the first US presidential debate and developments on a new coronavirus relief bill, which could impact risk sentiment and gold prices. Gold has risen over 20% this year, supported by stimulus measures to revive economies.

site_title: UK carmakers form united front to save suppliers from Brexit
summary: UK carmakers, including Jaguar Land Rover and Nissan Motor Co, have formed a network to protect the industry's supply chain from the impact of Covid-19 and a potential no-deal Brexit. The "safe harbour" plan offers improved payment terms to suppliers in financial difficulty, with lenders providing financial assistance. The goal is to minimize the risk of insolvencies while adhering to UK and EU competition law. The move comes as the UK's transition agreement with the EU ends on December 31, and the industry faces uncertainty about tariffs on exports to the EU, the largest market for UK-made cars.

site_title: Asean regional centre launched to tackle the future of work
summary: Singapore has launched the Regional Centre for the Future of Work to help Asean member-states prepare for the future of work amidst the COVID-19 pandemic. The centre aims to address challenges such as lockdown measures, economic downturn, and heightened unemployment. Minister for Manpower Josephine Teo launched the centre, citing figures from the International Labour Organization that 35 million full-time jobs were lost in South-east Asia. The centre will champion embracing technology, workplace safety, and tripartite relations to promote inclusive growth.

site_title: Some of Hong Kong's poor finally feel at home in 290 sq ft modules
summary: Hong Kong's housing shortage has led to a new initiative: transitional homes made of prefabricated modules. The first 800 homes were built in 2020, with plans for 15,000 over the next three years. For the Lau family, a 290 sq ft module home in central Kowloon is a significant upgrade, tripling their previous space. The homes are built on leased land and can be reused, addressing the city's housing shortage and poverty issues. However, challenges persist, and NGOs criticize the government for not taking sufficient responsibility in developing transitional housing.

site_title: LVMH countersues Tiffany over cancelled US$16b buyout
summary: LVMH countersues Tiffany & Co, weeks after pulling out of a $16 billion US buyout, citing the French government's request to delay the deal's closing and Tiffany's mismanagement during the pandemic. Tiffany had sued LVMH to force the deal forward, claiming it was using the pandemic to negotiate a lower price. A Delaware Chancery Court trial is set for January 5 to decide whether LVMH must consummate the sale.

site_title: Chinese delivery firm ZTO Express up 9% in Hong Kong debut
summary: Chinese delivery firm ZTO Express debuted in Hong Kong, with shares trading 9% above the offer price of HK$218, reaching HK$237.60. The company raised US$1.27 billion to expand capacity and strengthen its network. This marks the 10th secondary listing in Hong Kong this year, totaling US$15.1 billion in fundraising.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Tuesday; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.5% to 2,496.28 points, with 92 gainers outnumbering 31 losers. Local lenders DBS, OCBC, and UOB also gained ground, while Accordia Golf Trust and Keppel Infrastructure Trust saw heavy trading. The move follows a sharp rise on Wall Street overnight, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 1.51% and the S&P 500 gaining 1.61%.

site_title: DBS to merge its Lifestyle app into PayLah! app
summary: DBS Bank will integrate its Lifestyle app into the PayLah! app over the next few months, allowing over 3.3 million cardholders to access personalised deals and conduct everyday transactions on a single platform. The move will benefit over 500 merchants, including Lazada and Shopee, and provide customers with easy access to consolidated deals. Cardholders can expect to receive personalised nudges and contextualised offers on the DBS PayLah! platform, with no impact on existing services.

site_title: Stratech unable to provide exit offer, to be delisted on Oct 23
summary: Stratech Group, a Singapore-based company, is unable to make an exit offer to settle its creditors due to insufficient funds. As a result, its securities will be delisted from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on October 23. The company's liquidators had initially requested an exit offer by September 25 but received none from its controlling shareholder, a bankrupt. The SGX had previously given Stratech more than three years to resume trading, which began in August 2017. Stratech's shares will cease to be traded on the SGX at the end of the month.

site_title: British house price boom to fizzle out next year: poll
summary: A Reuters poll of 22 property experts predicts British home prices will rise 2% this year, driven by a post-lockdown boom, but stagnate next year due to an expected spike in unemployment and the end of a property tax cut. Experts warn of a potential slowdown in the market, with 80% of respondents citing a risk to forecasts to the downside, and prices in London expected to flatline this year before recovering in 2022.

site_title: Australia sends troops to help contain virus on ore ship near Port Hedland
summary: Australian troops have been deployed to Port Hedland to help contain a coronavirus outbreak on a bulk carrier. 17 of the 21 crew members on board have tested positive, with 10 infected workers in hotel quarantine and 7 remaining on board as part of an 11-person crew. The deployment aims to prevent the spread of the virus to the wider community and maintain operations at the major iron ore loading port.

site_title: Google clamps down on apps dodging Play Store 30% cut
summary: Google is enforcing a rule requiring Android apps in its Play Store to use its payment system, which takes a 30% cut of transactions. The policy applies to fewer than 3% of developers with apps in the Play Store, and Google has been lax about enforcing the rule. The change comes after Epic Games' Fortnite was pulled from the Play Store and App Store after it bypassed revenue-sharing with Apple and Google. Google's new policy aims to improve user safety and will be easier to use alternative app stores starting with the next version of Android.

site_title: Asia: Stocks shrug off global rally; US dollar falls
summary: Asian stocks consolidated at the open on Tuesday, with the US dollar extending losses. The S&P 500 futures edged higher, led by banks, which rose the most in two weeks. The yen traded at 105.45 per US dollar, while the offshore yuan fell to 6.8162 per US dollar. Investors are cautious ahead of the US presidential debate and the September employment report, with some expecting the markets to be weak and volatile.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares inch up on Tuesday morning
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.6 points or 0.2% to 1,514.26, with a total of 405 million lots traded worth RM224.7 million. Gainers outpaced losers 321-103, indicating a stronger market.

site_title: Evergrande's race for cash could avert nightmare scenarios
summary: China Evergrande Group, the world's most indebted real estate company, is facing a cash crunch and potential market destabilization. However, the company has various funding options to restore investor confidence, including asset sales, stock listings, and increased holiday condo sales. Evergrande could raise up to $9.3 billion from stock sales, while a Hong Kong IPO could raise $1-2 billion. The company may also reduce land purchases and refinance existing debt. Strategic investors have the right to demand repayment by January 31, but some analysts doubt they will receive approval due to China's restrictive funding policies.

images.alt_text: Credit investors are once again contemplating nightmare scenarios for China Evergrande Group. But the world's most indebted real estate company has a series of funding options that could help it avoid a market-destabilising cash crunch.

site_title: ThaiBev announces new management line up to realise growth objectives
summary: Thai Beverage Public Co (ThaiBev) has announced a new management lineup to achieve its growth objectives. The executive committee has appointed five senior management staff and two senior vice-presidents, effective October 1. The appointments will focus on growth, diversity, brands, reach, and professionalism. Michael Chye Hin Fah will lead the beer product group to strengthen the company's commitment to the beer business. This move aims to drive growth and expand ThaiBev's presence in the market.

site_title: Despite virus threat, UK universities limit the damage
summary: UK universities, like Coventry University, are adapting to the coronavirus pandemic by limiting on-campus interactions and encouraging virtual social life. Despite restrictions, the university remains confident in retaining foreign students, who are a crucial source of income. Applications for international undergraduate admissions have seen a 9% increase, but concerns remain about drop-out rates and the impact of the pandemic on students' experiences. Universities are preparing for the end of the post-Brexit transition period and are urging undecided applicants to plan with confidence to study in the UK.

site_title: USP says Indonesia unit's employee misappropriated up to S$20,000
summary: USP Group's Indonesian subsidiary terminated an employee after discovering they misappropriated up to S$20,000 in funds since January 2020. The employee admitted to the misappropriation. The incident occurred while USP Group is facing a winding-up application.

site_title: Temasek to offer 10, 30.5 and 50-year US dollar bonds
summary: Temasek Holdings plans to issue three tranches of US dollar bonds: 10-year, 30.5-year, and 50-year bonds. The bonds will be unconditionally guaranteed by the Singapore state investment firm and will be issued under its $25 billion guaranteed global medium-term note programme. The net proceeds will be used to fund Temasek's ordinary course of business. Temasek has been assigned an overall corporate credit rating of Aaa by Moody's and AAA by S&P Global Ratings. The bonds will be listed and quoted on the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Soaring Amazon deforestation splits Brazil's agriculture lobby
summary: Brazil's largest soy farmers' lobby group, Aprosoja, has broken ties with the Brazil Agribusiness Association (Abag) over its support for measures to combat Amazon deforestation. The move highlights the industry's division on environmental protection, with Abag siding with NGOs and Aprosoja criticizing the association's stance. Deforestation in the Amazon has risen 34.5% in the past year, prompting concerns over the impact on European trade deals and the livelihoods of Brazilian farmers. The split reflects the growing divide between mainstream farmers and marginal producers accused of driving deforestation.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust's placement, preferential offering priced at bottom end
summary: FRASERS Centrepoint Trust's private placement closed 2.8 times subscribed, priced at S$2.35 per new unit, a 6.6% discount to its VWAP. The placement raised S$575 million, while a preferential offering also closed at the low end of its range, priced at S$2.34 per unit, and raised about S$759.7 million. The equity fundraising aims to raise around S$1.33 billion, financing the acquisition of AsiaRetail Fund and debt repayment.

site_title: Even as Americans grew richer, inequality persisted
summary: US wealth inequality remained high despite Americans growing richer, with median net worth increasing by 18% and median family income rising by 5% between 2016 and 2019. However, the wealthiest 1% of households still held nearly 40% of the nation's net worth, with the bottom half holding just 1%. Economists warn that the pandemic may have reversed progress for disadvantaged workers, leaving many households in a more precarious position.

site_title: Direct listings to take centre stage as Palantir, Asana debut
summary: Palantir Technologies and Asana are set to debut on the New York Stock Exchange via direct listings, marking the first time since Slack Technologies in June 2019. Palantir, backed by Peter Thiel, is expected to have a market value of over $20 billion, while Asana's valuation is estimated at around $5 billion. Unlike traditional IPOs, no capital is raised by the companies in direct listings. The listings are seen as a less-tested alternative route to market, with volatile markets and disrupted business models contributing to the trend.

site_title: Long-idled Caribbean refinery springs to life amid pandemic
summary: A Caribbean refinery in St Croix, US Virgin Islands, is reviving after being idle since 2012. The Limetree Bay refinery, which can process 150,000 barrels of crude per day, is expected to start producing market-ready gasoline by late October. The refinery's owners are positioning it to meet demand for International Maritime Organisation-compliant fuels, which could boost demand for cleaner-burning products. The revival comes as the oil industry struggles to recover from a pandemic-led collapse in fuel demand, with the International Energy Agency expecting to downgrade its forecast for oil consumption.

site_title: Palm oil's biofuel goals just got a whole lot harder to achieve
summary: Palm oil's bid to replace fossil fuel as an energy source faces significant challenges due to a sharp decline in gasoil prices, which has widened the premium for palm oil-gasoil spread to over $400 per ton, making palm biodiesel more expensive. This threatens Indonesia's biofuel fund and biodiesel mandates in top growers Indonesia and Malaysia, potentially derailing the industry's rally. The spread's width also raises concerns about backsliding on biodiesel mandates and subsidies, affecting palm prices and inventories.

site_title: Singapore trial begins on alleged 'ponzi' oil scheme involving C$175m
summary: A Singaporean trial has begun against Yau Kwok Seng, accused of masterminding a $175 million ponzi oil investment scheme that defrauded thousands of investors across Asia. Over 1,000 investors from Singapore, Malaysia, Hong Kong, and Macau lost money in the scheme, which promised 12% annual returns on crude oil barrels that did not exist. Yau, Capital Asia Group, and Capital Asia Group Oil Management are accused of structuring and selling a sham investment product, with the plaintiff seeking to show that Yau knew his Canadian counterpart was using investor funds to fund oil and gas properties, not crude oil barrels.

images.alt_text: Investors had the option of either taking delivery of the barrels or having Canadian-based oil and gas firm COGI sell the barrels on their behalf to third-party buyers.

site_title: Oil up 1% on economic hope; virus fears check price gains
summary: Oil prices rose 1% on Monday, with Brent crude settling at $42.43 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate at $40.60 a barrel. The increase was driven by hopes for a US stimulus package and a weaker US dollar, but concerns about the spread of COVID-19 and fuel demand kept prices from rising further. The global health crisis has slashed global fuel consumption, and rising virus cases in the US are fueling concerns about demand.

site_title: Local SME helps Coca-Cola automate key production step
summary: A Singaporean SME, PD Solutions, in collaboration with A*Star's Advanced Remanufacturing and Technology Centre (ARTC), has successfully automated a key production step for Coca-Cola's drinks, reducing the time taken from days to mere minutes. The new scheduling system uses customised algorithms to map out orders, reducing manual effort and increasing efficiency. The project has deepened PD Solutions' knowledge in the food and beverage industry and opened doors for the SME to work with larger organizations like Coca-Cola.

site_title: Tesla is trying to mine its own lithium after dropping M&A plan
summary: Tesla has secured lithium mining rights in Nevada, following a plan to extract the metal from clay deposits instead of buying a company. The move aims to cut battery costs by 50% and deliver on a promise to bring a $25,000 electric car to market. Tesla has secured 10,000 acres of lithium-rich clay deposits and plans to use a new, sustainable extraction method, but some analysts have raised skepticism about the unproven technology. The company has also struck a raw materials pact with Piedmont Lithium and is exploring other external supplier deals.

site_title: US$ hovers near 2-month high amid economic, political risks
summary: The US dollar hovered near a two-month peak against a basket of currencies due to economic and political risks, including a slowdown in the US recovery from the pandemic and uncertainties surrounding the US presidential election. The dollar index slipped to 94.21, while the euro rose 0.3% to US$1.1661. Investors are awaiting key economic data, including consumer confidence and jobs data, amid a large net short position in the dollar and a significant net long position in the euro.

site_title: FAs braced for CPFIS fee caps, may be spurred to sell higher cost funds
summary: Singapore's CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) is set to introduce fee caps on fund sales charges and portfolio wrap fees, effective October 1. The caps will slash sales charges to zero and cap wrap fees at 0.4% per annum. Financial advisors (FAs) are bracing for the change, which may lead to a surge in sales of higher-cost funds that pay higher trail fees. Industry experts express concerns that the caps may favor high-cost funds and commission-based advice over fee-based advice, potentially harming investors.

images.alt_text: "Advisers will be less motivated to use low-cost instruments for their clients ... The industry will be motivated to sell higher expense funds," says Providend's Mr Tan.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Frasers Centrepoint Trust, Singapore banks, ThaiBev, Sunpower
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust closed its private placement at the low end of the range, with new units priced at S$2.34. Singapore banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB saw their AA- ratings reaffirmed by Fitch Ratings, with no rating watch negative. ThaiBev appointed five senior management staff to help achieve growth objectives. Sunpower Group secured manufacturing and services orders worth S$15.3 million. A-Smart Holdings reported a net profit of S$86,000 for the six months ended July 31. Trading halts were requested by CapitaLand Commercial Trust and CapitaLand Mall Trust ahead of an extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: No walk in the park for SuperPark creditors, staff
summary: SuperPark Asia Group, the parent company of indoor parks in Singapore, Hong Kong, Bangkok, and Kuala Lumpur, is under interim judicial management due to significant liabilities of S$18 million. The group's financial woes began when promised funding from Finnish parent SuperPark Oy fell short, leading to cash shortages and liquidity issues. Employees and creditors have been left in limbo, with staff taking pay cuts and some being let go. The group's subsidiaries face eviction from their premises, with rent arrears exceeding S$1 million. A judicial manager has been appointed to oversee the situation.

images.alt_text: SuperPark Singapore in Suntec City has yet to resume operations, although other indoor playgrounds in the country reopened in July.

site_title: US: Wall Street closes higher as energy, financials lead broad rally
summary: US stocks rallied on Monday, closing higher as energy and financials sectors led the gains. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.51%, the S&P 500 gained 1.61%, and the Nasdaq Composite added 1.87%. Despite the rally, the indices are on track to close the books on their first monthly declines since March. Market leaders Apple and Amazon drove the gains, while US House of Representatives Speaker Nancy Pelosi hinted at possible progress on fiscal stimulus talks.

site_title: Penny stock's 1,500% rise fuelled by Reddit leaves CEO dumbfounded
summary: An Australian penny stock, BrainChip Holdings, experienced a 1,500% rise in 2020, fueled by a Reddit rally. The company, focused on artificial intelligence, has yet to commercialize its flagship product. The CEO is reportedly "dumbfounded" by the stock's rapid ascent and subsequent decline. Despite concerns about overheating, BrainChip still boasts a 762% year-to-date gain, one of the best in technology names in Asia-Pacific.

site_title: Indonesia fintech BukuWarung raises more funding; graduates from accelerator
summary: Indonesian fintech startup BukuWarung has raised an undisclosed amount of funding from prominent investors including Partners of DST Global, Soma Capital, and angel investors such as Plaid co-founder William Hockey. The firm has also graduated from Y Combinator and currently has over $8 million in funding. BukuWarung aims to expand its user base in Indonesia and develop monetizable financial services, with plans to integrate payment features and build a range of financial services on its app.

site_title: Pelosi says White House has to offer more on stimulus for a deal
summary: US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi stated that the White House needs to offer more spending for a fresh round of stimulus to strike a deal before the election. She emphasized the need for more funds to combat the pandemic, reopen schools and businesses, and help Americans hurt by recession. Pelosi reiterated her demands for at least $2.2 trillion in new aid, while President Trump has indicated support for up to $1.5 trillion in aid. The sides have been at an impasse since August, with time running out for a deal before the November 3 election.

site_title: Miners carve themselves an ugly heritage
summary: Rio Tinto's demolition of a 46,000-year-old Aboriginal site in Australia's Pilbara region has tainted the mining industry's image. Despite the destruction not being illegal, it highlights the lack of effective heritage protection under the 1972 Aboriginal Heritage Act. A proposed amendment to the law aims to empower landowner groups, but critics argue it doesn't address the underlying issues. An independent commission, comprising traditional owners, mining representatives, and academic experts, is needed to resolve disputes and provide a fair playing field for all parties.

site_title: United Airlines pilots approve pay cut to avoid job losses
summary: United Airlines pilots have agreed to accept lower minimum pay guarantees to prevent 4,000 of their members from being put on furlough. The deal, which won 58% support, reduces pilots' minimum guaranteed monthly hours to 60, 52, or 35 from 70, with cuts depending on seniority and aircraft type. The agreement will keep all 13,000 pilots on the payroll and avoid major displacement. The deal is part of a broader effort to reduce costs and avoid layoffs as the airline prepares for a potential recovery in customer demand.

site_title: Pushing the envelope with e-commerce
summary: Vital Solutions, a Singapore-based company, has transformed its business model from internet trading to a supply chain partner in the pulp and paper industry. Established in 2000, the company has grown to over $500 million in revenue, with offices in 10 countries and clients spanning 80 markets globally. Vital Solutions attributes its success to good planning, strategic supply chain, youth, and ambition, as well as partnerships with Standard Chartered Bank and clients like Foxconn and Colgate. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, the company remains committed to growth, with plans to expand into e-commerce and develop a platform for buyers and sellers to interact more efficiently.

site_title: Goldman consumer chief to give up post in leadership change
summary: Harit Talwar, Goldman Sachs' consumer chief who led the firm's five-year-old dive into mom and pop banking, is stepping down in a management shuffle. Omer Ismail will take over as global consumer head, while Talwar remains a partner and chairman of the business. The consumer unit, known as Marcus, has been a key strategy shift for Goldman, yielding a credit card tie-up with Apple and on the cusp of $1 billion in annual revenue. Talwar's departure follows a shift in focus, with Marcus now part of the wealth and asset management group.

site_title: Vicplas shares slump in active trading after board slashes dividend by half
summary: Vicplas International, a medical devices and pipes manufacturer, saw its shares slump 21.1% or 9.5 cents to 35.5 cents after its board proposed a 50% cut in the final dividend to 0.375 Singapore cents per share, citing a need to balance shareholder rewards with business development and capital preservation amid a challenging operating environment.

site_title: The automation of a key Coca-Cola production step
summary: A*Star scientists and experts from PD Solutions have automated the production scheduling of Coca-Cola's liquid concentrates at the Singapore plant, reducing the process from 1-2 days to near real-time. This digitalization was made possible using an off-the-shelf software application, improving efficiency and reducing downtime. The solution was developed in collaboration with Coca-Cola, marking a significant step in the company's digitalization efforts. The automation is expected to enhance the production process and improve overall operational efficiency.

site_title: China expects Golden Week tourism rebound
summary: China expects a significant rebound in domestic travel over the upcoming Golden Week holiday, with sold-out domestic flights and a surge in hotel bookings fueling optimism about the travel industry's turnaround. The eight-day holiday, traditionally one of China's busiest times for travel, is expected to see 600 million trips made, with spending on hotels recovering to last year's level or even growing slightly. Despite lingering coronavirus caution, the Chinese travel industry offers a contrast to other parts of Asia and the US/Europe, where the virus is still circulating and gatherings are restricted.

site_title: Geostrategic clashes centred on the Internet will result in lose-lose for all
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration is leading a campaign to politicize and nationalize the online universe, prioritizing geo-strategic and geo-economic rivalries with China. The White House has issued an executive order investigating transactions by Chinese-owned social media apps TikTok and WeChat, citing national security concerns. However, critics argue that this move prioritizes political interests over free-market principles and could lead to the Balkanization of the online universe, destroying the foundations of an open Internet and turning everyone into losers. The US-China tech rivalry threatens to become a winner-takes-all competition that could have devastating global consequences.

site_title: India bond traders expect government to raise second-half debt sales by a fifth
summary: Indian bond traders predict the government will increase its borrowing plan for the October-March period to six trillion rupees (S$112 billion), up from the existing five trillion rupees. This move could exacerbate high inflation, as the Reserve Bank of India is set to keep policy rates on hold. The decision comes as traders' worst fears may be realized, with the government's borrowing plan potentially surpassing expectations.

site_title: HSBC posts biggest intraday jump since 2009 after sell-off
summary: HSBC Holdings plc saw its largest intraday jump since 2009, rising as much as 9.9% in Hong Kong and 11.5% in London after its biggest shareholder, Ping An Insurance Group Co, increased its stake to 8%. The move comes after HSBC's shares plummeted to a 25-year low due to speculation about its inclusion on China's "unreliable entity" list. Ping An remains confident in HSBC's long-term prospects and believes the bank will restore dividends in the future.

site_title: MYP to sell ABI Plaza for S$200m to Artemis Ventures
summary: MYP, controlled by Indonesian billionaire Tahir's family, is selling ABI Plaza in Singapore for S$200 million to Singapore-incorporated investment holding company Artemis Ventures, linked to CapitaLand Fund Management. The sale marks a significant move by MYP, which has been facing financial challenges. The buyer's identity was not disclosed at the time of the announcement.

site_title: Chinese social media company Sina agrees to go private in sweetened US$2.6b deal
summary: Sina Corp agreed to go private in a US$2.6 billion deal led by Chairman Charles Chao, representing a 7.7% premium to its closing price. The offer was increased from an original proposal of US$41 a share. The Beijing-based company's equity value is implied at US$2.59 billion.

site_title: For people to trust AI, build fairness into it
summary: The use of AI raises concerns about fairness, as algorithms learn from biased data, leading to biased results. To build trust in AI, companies and governments must prioritize fairness and transparency, involving stakeholders and end-users in the decision-making process. This requires a human evaluation of AI fairness, taking into account societal norms and values. A more humane approach to AI development is necessary, balancing utility with humanity, and recognizing that humans have their own biases, but can be less biased when evaluating others. Ultimately, the fairness of an AI system is determined by its users, and organizations must lead by setting clear values and considering the needs and expectations of their users.

site_title: Debate unlikely to sway US election outcome
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to face Democratic challenger Joe Biden in the first presidential debate on Tuesday, with most voters likely already having made up their minds. Despite Trump's hopes that the debate could be a game-changer, polls show Biden leading in national and key swing states. Biden's campaign aims to portray Trump as unfit to lead, while Trump plans to attack Biden's record and portray him as weak and corrupt. The debate is unlikely to sway undecided voters, but will likely highlight existing biases and trends in the campaign.

site_title: Wilmar's China unit IPO meets 13.9b yuan fundraiser mark on overwhelming subscription
summary: Wilmar International's China unit, Yihai Kerry Arawana (YKA), successfully raised about 13.93 billion yuan (S$2.81 billion) through its initial public offering (IPO) on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange ChiNext Board. The IPO shares were oversubscribed, with offline investors subscribing 600.5 times and online retail investors 1,750 times. Strategic investors, including local sovereign wealth fund GIC, subscribed 4.18 billion yuan worth of shares. The listing is expected to take place by mid-October, subject to prevailing market conditions.

site_title: Full-scale Wagner returns to Europe with refugee-theme Walküre
summary: The Deutsche Oper in Berlin has resumed performances of Richard Wagner's Ring cycle, with Norwegian director Stefan Herheim's production of Die Walküre premiering on September 28, 2020. The production, which was delayed due to the pandemic, features a star-studded cast and a unique set design constructed from piano, suitcases, and video projections. The production's concept explores the themes of displacement, empathy, and the power of storytelling, reflecting Herheim's own experiences with refugee crises and the climate catastrophe. The cycle will run until October 11, with the remaining operas scheduled to premiere later this season.

site_title: In lockdown, an 86-year-old blogger stumbles on a new purpose
summary: An 86-year-old blogger, Hazell Jacobs, created a blog called Scarf Aid during the COVID-19 lockdown to connect with readers worldwide. Through her stories and memories, she found a new purpose and gave her readers a sense of hope. The blog, which featured brainteasers and historical facts, gained a devoted following, with readers seeking comfort and connection during a difficult time. Jacobs' story highlights the importance of connectedness for older adults, who are disproportionately affected by loneliness and isolation.

site_title: Singapore shares up again, along with regional markets
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 10.73 points or 0.43% to 2,483.01 on Monday, following a positive close on Wall Street and China's industrial profits growth for the fourth straight month. The top performer was Singapore Exchange, with shares adding 2.2% due to increased Central Depository account openings. Jardine Matheson fell 1.4% after announcing a share repurchase. Regional markets also finished higher, with the Hang Seng Index and Nikkei 225 advancing 1.04% and 1.32% respectively.

site_title: How Shinzo Abe mended Japan's relations with China
summary: Shinzo Abe, Japan's prime minister from 2006-2007 and again from 2012-2020, made significant efforts to mend Japan's strained relations with China. After a tumultuous start, Abe successfully improved relations through a combination of conciliatory gestures, strategic diplomacy, and a commitment to balance. Key milestones included a 2018 state visit to Beijing and a 2020 visit by Chinese President Xi Jinping to Japan, although the latter was cut short by the coronavirus. Despite his efforts, Abe's legacy on China-Japan relations remains complex and challenging, with some progress but also ongoing tensions over historical issues and territorial claims.

site_title: The virus sent droves to a small US town. Suddenly, it's not so small
summary: The small US town of Winhall, Vermont, has seen a significant population boom due to the COVID-19 pandemic, attracting residents from hotspots like New York and New Jersey. The town, with a pre-pandemic population of 769, now has over 1,000 residents, transforming from a quiet rural community to a bustling town. Local residents are adapting to the influx, with some running businesses and taking on new roles. The sudden growth is a significant change for the town, which is now struggling to accommodate its new residents and provide essential services.

images.alt_text: Anna White, 36, who grew up in Vermont and left the state for college, began looking to move back in July.

site_title: iX Biopharma unit obtains Australia licence to bring product testing in-house
summary: iX Biopharma's wholly-owned subsidiary iX Syrinx has obtained a Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) licence in Australia to conduct in-house product testing, improving speed-to-market and potentially saving on testing costs. The licence allows the company to conduct chemical and analytical laboratory testing, including raw material testing, stability testing, and finished product testing. This move will shift the laboratory testing operations in-house, complementing the company's fully integrated business model, and may result in cost savings.

site_title: Olam obtains S$200m Sora-pegged club loan from DBS, ICBC Singapore
summary: Olam International, an agri-food giant, has obtained a S$200m club loan from DBS and ICBC Singapore, pegged to the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (Sora). This marks Singapore's first Sora-pegged club loan and supports the country's transition to Sora as the new interest rate benchmark. The loan provides Olam with flexibility to adapt to the industry's shift towards Sora adoption. DBS and ICBC Singapore are committed to supporting the Monetary Authority of Singapore's vision, with DBS and ICBC set to benefit from the loan.

site_title: KKR buys stake in London office landlord Great Portland
summary: KKR & Co has acquired a 5.35% stake in London developer Great Portland Estates plc, investing in the company amidst a severe recession triggered by the Covid-19 pandemic. Great Portland, which owns mainly office buildings in central London, has fallen over 30% this year. KKR's stake, valued at £74.3 million, makes it the sixth-largest holder of Great Portland. The move comes as private equity firms deploy capital on shares and bonds in companies with strong track records but affected by negative sentiment due to the virus.

site_title: Australia extends airline relief ahead of expected deficit
