summary: The Australian government has extended a COVID-19 relief package for domestic airlines by four months until January 31, 2021, and March 28, 2021, for regional flights. The move aims to address uncertainty in the aviation industry due to border closures and cancellations. The government has already spent over A$150 million on the package since its introduction in April. An economics forecaster predicts a A$198.5 billion deficit, although the government's extension is seen as "better than expected" due to rising iron ore prices.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Meanwhile, Creative Technology warned of possible below-target H2 revenue and operating loss similar to H1. The Singapore stock market saw a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) are set to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case.

site_title: Chinese investors flock to newly launched funds targeting Ant IPO
summary: Chinese investors are pouring into newly launched mutual funds targeting Ant Group's upcoming $35 billion IPO, demonstrating strong demand for technology shares amid US scrutiny. Five funds, aiming to raise a combined $12 billion, have already reached their fundraising targets, with three expected to be sold out this week. Retail investors can buy into the funds directly or through Alipay, with up to 10% of the funds' value used to purchase Ant shares. The early interest underscores appetite for Chinese tech shares despite recent market corrections and US national security concerns.

site_title: Why Brexit breakthrough is only half the battle ahead
summary: A new round of Brexit talks began on Monday, with a breakthrough still uncertain. The negotiations are on a knife-edge, and the ratification process, a key stage in the complex dialogue, has received little media attention. Unlike the Brexit withdrawal deal, which was ratified quickly in late 2019 and early 2020, the ratification process for a future trade agreement may be more challenging. This oversight highlights the complexities of the Brexit process and the potential for further hurdles ahead of any potential agreement.

site_title: Worst could be over for retail Reits
summary: Singapore's retail Reits may have seen the worst, with suburban malls leading the recovery as consumers flock to local retailers. According to DBS Group Research, foot traffic at suburban malls has returned to 80-90% of pre-Covid levels, while those at Orchard Road and Harbourfront are at 70%. Analysts expect top picks such as Frasers Centrepoint Trust, CapitaLand Mall Trust, and Lendlease Global Commercial Reit to benefit from this recovery, with some even citing attractive valuations for SPH Reit and Starhill Global Reit.

site_title: Five members ousted from UN-backed responsible investment list
summary: Five investors have been removed from the United Nations-backed Principles for Responsible Investment (PRI) list due to failing to meet its minimum requirements. The PRI, which has over 3,000 signatories managing $100 trillion in assets, aims to promote sustainable investing. The removals are the first of its kind by the group, highlighting the importance of meeting its standards for asset managers seeking mandates from pension schemes. The PRI's standards include environmental, social, and governance (ESG) criteria.

site_title: Make public disclosure of the climate-crisis plans of businesses mandatory for sustainable economy
summary: The US government is considering making public disclosure of climate-crisis plans for businesses mandatory for a sustainable economy. This move comes amid a reversal of nearly 70 environmental rules during the current administration, with many large businesses already taking proactive steps to mitigate climate risks. The private sector recognizes the urgency of climate change and is attempting to protect its assets and investments. A mandatory disclosure requirement could help promote transparency and accountability in climate action, but the outcome is uncertain.

site_title: IPO of BTS' managing label subscribed over 1,000 times
summary: Big Hit Entertainment, the managing label of K-pop group BTS, priced its initial public offering (IPO) at 135,000 won (S$158) per share, at the top of its range, after receiving over 1,000 times the number of shares on offer. The IPO, valued at 4.8 trillion won, will raise 962.6 billion won and is the largest South Korean IPO since 2017, with some analysts predicting gross bids from retail investors could hit 100 trillion won. The central bank is closely watching the offer due to potential oversubscription.

site_title: Fitch affirms 'AA-' score on Singapore banks, holds negative earnings outlook
summary: Fitch Ratings has affirmed its 'AA-' credit ratings on Singapore banks, removing them from rating watch negative, citing consistent financial metrics. However, the agency maintains a negative outlook due to risks of business conditions and financial profiles deteriorating over the next 12-18 months. Key concerns include declining earnings, increased risk-weighted assets, and potential downgrade if the operating environment or financial profiles deteriorate beyond base-case expectations.

site_title: Trump paid 'only US$750 in income tax in 2016, 2017'
summary: US President Donald Trump paid only $750 in federal income taxes in 2016 and 2017, with no taxes paid in 10 of the previous 15 years, according to a report by The New York Times. Trump claimed heavy losses from his business enterprises to offset income from reality TV and endorsement deals. The disclosure came ahead of the 2020 presidential election, with Democrats seizing on the report to paint Trump as a tax dodger. Trump dismissed the report as "fake news," citing an ongoing audit as his reason for not releasing his returns.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: BigPay, a financial services venture of AirAsia, will expand its e-wallet services to Singapore with mobile money app and prepaid Visa card. The service will have two core features: payments and remittance, with 20,000 people on the waiting list for early access. Fitch Ratings has affirmed its "AA-" ratings on Singapore banks, removing them from rating watch negative due to consistent financial metrics. Meanwhile, A-Smart Holdings reported a net profit of S$86,000 for the six months ended July 31, reversing a net loss in the previous year.

site_title: Singapore set to fine-tune debt moratorium schemes
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to fine-tune its debt moratorium schemes, extending them to certain borrowers beyond December 31, 2020, while encouraging those with repayment ability to begin repayment before the moratoriums expire. This comes as the MAS warns of a "cliff effect" on the financial system if borrowers' repayment ability is only assessed at the end of the moratorium schemes. The regulator has already granted payment deferments to over S$15 billion worth of mortgages and S$11.4 billion worth of SME loans.

site_title: Electronic KYC, financing and 'smart' matching among OneSME trade platform features
summary: Singapore's OneSME trade platform launched on Monday to connect local small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) with businesses in China, aiming to boost trade between the two countries. The platform, developed by OneConnect Financial Technology, will provide a digital hub for B2B transactions, financing, and smart matching between buyers and sellers. It will initially focus on industrial equipment, medical devices, and food and beverage products, with plans to expand to other Asian markets in the future. The platform's eKYC solution and smart business matching algorithm will ensure secure and efficient transactions.

site_title: Saudi Arabia sends world-first blue ammonia shipment to Japan
summary: Saudi Arabia's state-owned oil company, Saudi Aramco, has shipped the world's first blue ammonia to Japan, where it will be used to produce electricity without carbon emissions. The 40-ton shipment is a significant step towards a low-carbon energy future, as blue ammonia can be burned in thermal power stations without releasing greenhouse gases. This move aims to counter Saudi Arabia's reputation for producing dirty energy and follows recent initiatives to reduce emissions, including plans to grow carbon-absorbing mangroves and develop a hydrogen-based ammonia plant powered by renewable energy.

site_title: Thailand extends state of emergency to Oct 31
summary: Thailand has extended its state of emergency until October 31, allowing the government to enforce mandatory quarantines and streamline disease-control plans. The country is preparing to reopen its borders to foreign visitors after a six-month gap, with the first 150 Chinese tourists arriving on October 8. Special tourist visas will be issued starting next month, requiring visitors to undergo Covid-19 testing and quarantine. Thailand aims to balance minimizing risks with re-opening for tourism, which accounts for about one-fifth of its gross domestic product.

site_title: LTA buys 40 more trains from Bombardier Transportation
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) in Singapore has purchased 40 new trains from Bombardier Transportation for approximately S$337.8 million. The trains will replace the existing second- and third-generation trains on the North-South and East-West Lines, starting from 2024. This is part of LTA's long-term fleet renewal program.

site_title: URA clampdown on option re-issue may have some cooling effect on property market
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has imposed new conditions on private housing developers, restricting the re-issue of option-to-purchase (OTP) agreements to buyers of the same unit within 12 months. This move aims to curb "financial discipline" in the property market amid the recession. Analysts predict a slight cooling effect on market activities, but some believe the impact remains to be seen. The new measures may lead to a more cautious approach by buyers, affecting affordability, while genuine demand from owner-occupiers and investors is expected to drive the private residential market.

site_title: Pelosi rallies US House Democrats on possible presidential election decision
summary: US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi is rallying Democrats to prepare for a potential presidential election scenario where Congress would decide the outcome if neither Joe Biden nor Donald Trump wins outright. Pelosi warns that President Trump could attempt to have mail-in ballots cut short, citing concerns over the security of mail-in ballots. Democrats fear they might need to capture additional Republican-held House seats, prompting Pelosi to call for an "all out effort" to win more delegations.

site_title: SoftBank brings food service robot to labour-strapped Japan
summary: SoftBank will bring a food service robot, Servi, to Japan to help restaurants cope with labor shortages amid the coronavirus pandemic. Developed by California-based Bear Robotics, Servi uses trays to carry food and drinks, navigating with 3D cameras and Lidar sensors. The robot aims to enhance efficiency and customer service in the socially distanced dining environment.

images.alt_text: The robot, named Servi, will act as a sort of waiter, using its layers of trays to carry food and drinks and its 3D cameras and Lidar sensors to navigate between the kitchen and tables.

site_title: Top US lands official served unlawfully for over a year, rules federal judge
summary: A federal judge in Montana ruled that William Perry Pendley, the acting director of the US Bureau of Land Management (BLM), served unlawfully for over 424 days. The judge ordered Pendley to leave the position and prohibited him from using any authority to make decisions about federal lands. The ruling prevented Interior Secretary David Bernhardt from picking another person to run the bureau, and Governor Steve Bullock of Montana called it a victory for the Constitution and public lands.

site_title: Senior university leaders in Singapore take pay cut
summary: Senior management at Singapore's six autonomous universities have taken a pay cut in response to the economic impact of COVID-19. The institutions have also increased financial relief for students, with some universities setting up funds to support students affected by the crisis. The pay cuts follow the National Wages Council's recommendation that employers consider reducing wages to cut costs and save jobs. The universities have disbursed millions of dollars in grants and funds to support students, with some receiving sums ranging from S$500 to S$3,000.

site_title: OneSME platform to help Singapore, China firms expand reach, boost trade
summary: Singapore and China have launched a digital trade platform, OneSME, to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) expand their overseas reach and tap demand from Chinese SMEs for Singapore products. The platform, developed by OneConnect Financial Technology, aims to provide SMEs with a new avenue for growth and digitization amid the COVID-19 pandemic. It connects business-to-business platforms in the two countries, offering functions to help SMEs transact across borders, expand, learn new skills, access financing, and digitalize their businesses.

site_title: Microsoft gets into 5G race with Azure cloud for telecom operators
summary: Microsoft has launched a new cloud platform, Azure, aimed at enabling telecom operators to build 5G networks faster, reduce costs, and sell customized services to business clients. The platform, acquired from cloud networking companies Affirmed Networks and Metaswitch, uses artificial intelligence to automate operations and could cut costs by 30-40%. Microsoft has partnered with telecom operators and network equipment firms to offer the platform, increasing competition for existing 5G service vendors. The move follows the US government's push for American companies to get involved in 5G development after banning China's Huawei.

site_title: 'Cautious optimism' in retail, F&B, but SMEs' outlook at record low
summary: Business sentiment among Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) has reached a record low, with the SBF-Experian SME Index falling to 46.3 in October 2020 to March 2021. Despite this, SMEs in the retail and food and beverage sectors show cautious optimism due to the gradual recovery of domestic demand and easing of COVID-19 measures. Turnover and profitability expectations for these sectors have bottomed out, while business expectations have turned positive. The Singapore economy is expected to contract by 5-7% in the full year, with the construction sector registering the largest decrease in sentiment.

site_title: FCT to price preferential offering at S$2.34 to S$2.42 per unit
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) is undertaking a private placement and non-renounceable preferential offering to raise between S$1.33 billion and S$1.44 billion. The offerings will partially finance the Reit's acquisition of the remaining 63.11% stake in AsiaRetail Fund and pare existing debts. The private placement will issue 236.1-244.7 million new units, while the preferential offering will offer 313.4-324.6 million new units to existing unitholders. The offerings are expected to close on Oct 7 and Oct 19, respectively, with the units listed on the same day.

site_title: NTT to take mobile unit Docomo private for US$38b, Nikkei reports
summary: NTT plans to take its wireless carrier unit NTT Docomo private with a US$38 billion tender offer, according to a Nikkei report. This would be Japan's largest ever tender offer. NTT already holds 66.2% of Docomo, and the deal would allow NTT to better handle the negative impact of lower mobile bills, a priority for newly appointed Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga.

site_title: Sunpower Group bags two contracts worth over 76m yuan
summary: Sunpower Group secured contracts worth over 76 million yuan from two repeat customers, Qixiang Tenda and Yangnong Chemical Group, with expected completion in 2021. The projects involve manufacturing and services for propane dehydrogenation plants and a demountable elevated flare system. The deals are expected to positively impact Sunpower's financial performance in FY2020 and FY2021. The company plans to expand its green investment business, with a portfolio of eight projects, aiming to build a "sizeable and valuable" asset portfolio by 2021.

site_title: China calls WTO ruling on Trump's tariffs 'objective and fair'
summary: China's ambassador to the World Trade Organization, Zhang Xiangchen, stated that a WTO panel's ruling on US tariffs against China is "objective and fair". The panel found that the tariffs breached trade rules due to being above maximum rates and applied only to China. China hopes the ruling will facilitate a prompt resolution of the dispute, while the US has yet to comment on the case. The US has blocked the appointment of WTO judges, potentially putting the dispute in a legal limbo if an appeal is pursued.

site_title: Goh Cheng Liang family buys Thye Hong's Garlick Ave GCB
summary: The Goh Cheng Liang family, owners of Wuthelam Holdings, has purchased a 101,550 sq ft freehold bungalow in Garlick Avenue for approximately S$93 million. The property is being sold by the Lee family from the Thye Hong group, which previously made biscuits. The sale, completed earlier this month, is expected to be finished by the end of the year. The property can be subdivided into five or six bungalows or redeveloped into a single grand mansion.

site_title: Credit Agricole to build its own Saudi Bank after stake sale
summary: Credit Agricole, a French lender, plans to build its own corporate and investment bank in Saudi Arabia after selling its 4% stake in Banque Saudi Fransi for $530.9 million. The sale ends Credit Agricole's decades-long investment in the Saudi bank and allows the firm to pursue its own path in the region. Credit Agricole will obtain a licence to operate on Saudi's capital markets and further develop its presence and activities in the country.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher led by banks, travel stocks
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Monday, with the Dow Jones rising 188.18 points, or 0.69%, to 27,362.14. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, with gains of 35.44 points, or 1.07%, and 170.82 points, or 1.57%, respectively. The gains were driven by beaten-down sectors, including banks and travel, following the longest weekly losing streak in a year.

site_title: Europe: Bank stocks bounce off record low, helping Europe recover some lost ground
summary: European stocks surged 2.2% on Monday, their largest percentage gain since mid-June, as investors snapped up beaten-down banking shares. The STOXX 600 index rebounded from a 3.6% drop last week, with HSBC and Commerzbank leading the gains. Investors have been cautious due to lower global borrowing costs, rising bad loans, and uncertainty over US fiscal stimulus and Brexit. Despite this, data showing China's industrial firms' profits growing for the fourth straight month and Europe's auto and industrial sectors outperforming helped drive the market up.

site_title: Black cab drivers says Uber decision is a 'disaster' for London
summary: A London judge has restored Uber's operating licence, sparking criticism from the Licensed Taxi Drivers' Association, who describe the decision as a "disaster" for the city. The association claims Uber prioritizes profit over safety, despite its efforts to change. The decision allows Uber to continue operating in London, raising concerns about the impact on traditional black cab drivers and the safety of Londoners.

site_title: US pension funds sue Allianz after US$4b in coronavirus losses
summary: US pension funds have filed lawsuits against Allianz, a top asset manager, for failing to safeguard their investments during the coronavirus market meltdown, resulting in estimated losses of around $4 billion. The lawsuits claim Allianz strayed from its strategy of using options to protect against a short-term financial market crash. Allianz has denied the allegations, stating they are "legally and factually flawed" and will defend itself vigorously. The suits include claims from pension funds for truckers, teachers, and subway workers, as well as the Metropolitan Transportation Authority in New York.

site_title: AirAsia's BigPay to launch payments, remittance services in Singapore
summary: BigPay, AirAsia's fintech venture, is launching payments and remittance services in Singapore, with early access available to 20,000 users. The mobile money app and prepaid Visa card will offer features such as payments, remittance, and money transfers to 10 markets. BigPay operates on a challenger bank model, aiming to provide affordable and efficient financial products. The launch follows BigPay's receipt of a licence from the Monetary Authority of Singapore and its expansion to other South-east Asia markets in 2021, with plans for new business lines and loans.

site_title: Taiwan gets rare win in China naming dispute
summary: Taiwan has won a rare victory in its naming dispute with China after the European Union intervened to correct a Global Covenant of Mayors for Climate and Energy designation listing Taiwanese cities as part of China. The designation change was reversed after the EU helped Taiwan, with the European Commission citing a "technical glitch" as the cause. The move comes as China has increased pressure on international groups and companies to refer to Taiwan as part of China. Taiwan's Foreign Minister Joseph Wu expressed gratitude for the EU's assistance, stating the change ensures Taiwan's participation is not under another country's umbrella.

site_title: EHT makes changes to board committees
summary: EHT appoints Lau Chun Wah as chairman of the special committee of the managers and nominating and remuneration committee, replacing Carl Gabriel Florian Stubbe. Tarun Kataria is also appointed to the nominating and remuneration committee. The new SC comprises Lau, Kataria, Kelvin Tan, and Salvatore Takoushian. The changes follow a month after Stubbe's departure from the board.

site_title: Tata Group courts investors for new digital platform
summary: Tata Group, a US$113 billion conglomerate, is in talks with potential investors to take stakes in a new digital platform, aiming to modernize its consumer businesses and compete with Amazon, Reliance Industries, and Flipkart in India's e-commerce market. The platform, set to launch by end-2020 or early 2021, will consolidate digital assets across various Tata businesses, including e-commerce, beverages, jewelry, and resorts. Discussions with investors are at an early stage, and no certainty exists about a deal. The move may help Tata pare debt, which reached US$14 billion for Tata Steel and US$6.5 billion for Tata Motors.

site_title: AirAsia looks to laying off staff
summary: Malaysia's AirAsia Group is considering layoffs of hundreds of employees as a measure to cope with the coronavirus pandemic. The airline's Malaysian unit and long-haul arm, AirAsia X Bhd, plan to cut staff, according to a report by Bernama. The move aims to reduce costs and adapt to the pandemic's economic impact. AirAsia has not commented on the matter.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's flagship budget airline AirAsia Group is looking at laying off hundreds of employees, as it sought to cope with the coronavirus pandemic, state news agency Bernama reported on Monday.

site_title: Britain to return looted 4,000-year-old plaque to Iraq
summary: Britain will return a 4,000-year-old limestone plaque to Iraq after an investigation found it was looted from an ancient Sumerian temple. The plaque, valued for its rarity with only 50 examples known, was sold online in 2020 with limited provenance. The British Museum, which initially displayed the item, will repatriate it to Iraq following a police investigation and the Iraqi government's permission. The return is part of the museum's efforts to combat illicit trade and damage to cultural heritage, with 154 Mesopotamian texts and other looted artefacts also scheduled for return to Iraq.

site_title: Malaysia's king to remain in hospital for follow-up treatment, says palace
summary: Malaysia's King Al-Sultan Abdullah will remain in the hospital for follow-up treatment after undergoing successful intervention for sports injuries. The king initially warded for food poisoning and was advised to rest in the national palace upon discharge. The king's hospital stay is not expected to impact his duties, as he will be resting at the palace. This decision comes amid opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim's bid to form a new government. The king's treatment and recovery are being closely monitored by medical experts.

site_title: Rio Tinto changes tack, ready for talks over Bougainville mine
summary: Rio Tinto is prepared to engage in discussions with stakeholders over allegations of human rights breaches at its former Bougainville copper mine in Papua New Guinea. The move comes after a complaint was filed with the Australian government by 156 community members, who claim the mine's waste has poisoned water sources and caused health problems. This change in stance marks a shift in Rio's approach to social responsibility, following its own controversies. The company will speak with current mine owners, governments, and the communities involved in the discussions.

site_title: A-Smart back in the black with H2 net profit of S$86,000
summary: A-Smart Holdings reported a net profit of S$86,000 for the six months ended July 31, 2020, reversing a net loss of S$2.12 million in the same period last year. The firm's net profit was largely driven by a substantial gain on liquidation of a subsidiary corporation and government grants. Revenue declined nearly 50% to S$1.78 million, mainly due to the Covid-19 outbreak and "circuit breaker" period.

site_title: EU and Britain far apart as key week of Brexit talks begins
summary: The European Union and Britain have made little progress in their Brexit talks, with EU officials stating that key differences persist over implementing the Withdrawal Agreement, particularly on the Irish border. Britain's proposed draft laws would undermine the agreement, sparking concerns of a no-deal Brexit. EU leaders will assess the talks at a summit next month, with a deadline of October or early November to seal an agreement. A failure to reach a deal could lead to tariffs and quotas, risking trillions of euros in annual trade and the fragile peace on the island of Ireland.

site_title: France unveils big budget as virus cases worsen
summary: France unveiled a 460-billion-euro budget plan on Monday, with a 100-billion euro "recovery plan" aimed at boosting the economy after a fresh spike in COVID-19 cases. The plan, partly funded by EU money, is designed to help the French economy rebound strongly next year by 8% after crashing 10% this year. The government imposed fresh curbs to limit the spread of the virus, including on restaurants and sports facilities, amid concerns about overwhelmed hospitals. The budget was criticized for its unrealistic growth forecast by France's high council for public finance.

site_title: Sabah poll result fails to dispel doubts over Muhyiddin's power hold
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin's ruling coalition won a narrow victory in Sabah state's election, but the outcome has failed to dispel doubts about his hold on power. The coalition won 38 of 73 seats, but coalition partner Umno initially sought to appoint its own candidate as chief minister, eventually agreeing on a compromise candidate. The narrow win has raised questions about Muhyiddin's grip on power, particularly amid tensions within his alliance with Umno. Anwar Ibrahim, opposition leader, remains a contender to oust Muhyiddin, and the king's hospitalization has raised concerns about the formation of a new government.

images.alt_text: Before Saturday's election, analysts said Mr Muhyiddin needed a solid victory to stop support within his coalition parties melting away.

site_title: Indonesia police fire warning shots at Papua student protest
summary: Indonesian police fired warning shots at a protest by hundreds of university students in Papua opposing the planned extension of a special autonomy status. The law, set to expire next year, aims to increase revenue and autonomy for the region, but critics argue it has not improved healthcare and education. The protest was part of ongoing tensions between security forces and separatist groups in Papua, following recent deaths and clashes. Police denied two students were hurt and three arrested, despite footage showing people running in panic after shots were heard.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.52 points to 1,511.66 on Monday, driven by a higher closing volume of 5.174 billion lots worth RM3.514 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 569 to 458. This marks a positive start to the week for Malaysian stocks, following a rally in Singapore and other markets.

site_title: PGGM buys minority stake in Eurofiber from Antin
summary: PGGM, a Dutch pension fund manager, has purchased a minority stake in Eurofiber, a fiber optic cable and data center operator in the Netherlands and France, from investor Antin for an undisclosed sum. The deal valued Eurofiber at more than 25 times its 2019 core earnings. PGGM's investment aims to strengthen the Dutch economy and provide a stable return for pension participants. This marks a significant transaction for Eurofiber, which was initially acquired by Antin in 2015 for 875 million euros.

site_title: 'Cautious optimism' in retail, F&B even as SMEs' business outlook dips to all-time low
summary: Singapore's SMEs, with the exception of retail and F&B sectors, report a record low business outlook of 46.3, according to the SBF-Experian SME Index. The index fell due to a 13.2% economic contraction in the second quarter and authorities' expectations of a 5-7% full-year contraction. However, retail and F&B SMEs show cautious optimism, with business expectations turning positive and turnover expectations bottoming out, despite the pandemic's ongoing impact.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore restricts private housing developers from re-issuing options to purchase for the same unit within 12 months. The government plans to calibrate debt moratoriums for borrowers beyond December 31. New trains worth S$337.8m will be introduced by LTA starting from 2024. Retail and F&B sectors show cautious optimism despite SMEs' business outlook hitting a record low. PayNow banks increase default limit to S$5,000 for ad-hoc transactions, while MYP sells ABI Plaza for S$200m. The STI rises for the second consecutive session on China's industrial profits growth.

site_title: China's Sina agrees to go private in sweetened US$2.6b deal
summary: China's Sina agrees to go private in a US$2.6 billion deal led by chairman Charles Chao, boosting its offer from US$41 to US$43.30 per share, a 7.7% premium to its closing price. The deal represents an 18% premium to a July proposal and follows other Chinese tech firms delisting from US exchanges or turning to domestic markets amid growing scrutiny. Sina, which operates Weibo, a Chinese equivalent of Twitter, went public in 2000 and is the latest in a series of Chinese companies to opt for a private listing.

site_title: Crypto broker sees users drawn to bots to beat volatile trading
summary: A Chinese brokerage, BitUniverse, is seeing users turn to bot trading to capitalize on price swings in the cryptocurrency market. The platform has a monthly trading volume of around $5 billion and 80% of its 100,000 users run automated trading algorithms daily. This is part of a growing trend in the $300 billion cryptocurrency market, where major exchange operators have not yet established a significant brokerage presence.

site_title: HSBC in final talks to sell French retail business at hefty loss
summary: HSBC is in final talks to sell its French retail business, valued at around $801.3 million, to Cerberus and another investment firm for a symbolic one euro provided the bank invests at least $500 million. The sale process comes as the bank struggles to attract interest due to heavy restructuring requirements. HSBC is working with Lazard to sell its 270 retail branches in France, which has previously posted a 225 million adjusted loss before tax. The sale is part of the bank's strategy to slash costs and improve returns for shareholders.

site_title: Money Hacks: Controlling your fund fees is key to investment success (Ep 80)
summary: Chris Lim and Gregory Van discuss the importance of controlling investment costs or fees to achieve investment success. They explore how Singapore's investment fees are higher than average globally and the "trailer" fee that can eat into returns. The duo also discuss ways to mitigate these costs, including potential rebates to investors. They conclude that a 1% fee difference over many years can result in significant compounding costs, emphasizing the need for investors to understand and manage their fees to maximize returns.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start week with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks started the week with gains, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.04% to 23,476.05, boosted by HSBC's stakeholder increasing its investment. This follows a strong lead from Wall Street. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.06% and 0.75%, respectively.

site_title: STI in second straight session of gains on China's industrial profits jump
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 10.73 points or 0.43% to 2,483.01, its second consecutive gain, following a fourth consecutive month of growth in China's industrial profits. The top performer was the Singapore Exchange, while Jardine Matheson fell after announcing a share repurchase. Regional markets, including the Hang Seng Index and Nikkei 225, also finished higher, despite a slight dip in the Shanghai Composite. The gains were attributed to a constructive tone for the start of the week and positive US stock market performance.

site_title: Zilingo CFO James Perry resigns to return to Citigroup for tech deals
summary: Zilingo's CFO James Perry has resigned to return to Citigroup as managing director and co-head of technology investment banking for Asia-Pacific. Perry joined Zilingo a year ago after securing a funding round, but the company has struggled since the coronavirus outbreak, trimming jobs and streamlining businesses. The move comes as tech deals in Asia Pacific surge, with a 54% increase in announced M&A deals to nearly $75 billion. Perry's departure is the latest high-profile exit for the once-flourishing startup.

site_title: Eurozone yields hold steady near recent lows on Covid concerns
summary: Eurozone bond yields remained steady near recent lows as investors weighed concerns over rising Covid-19 cases against signs of a strengthening economic recovery in China. German bond yields started the week at six-week lows, but analysts attributed this to already priced-in dovish policy from the European Central Bank. ECB policymaker Ignazio Visco expressed concern over the euro's strengthening exchange rate, warning it could drag inflation away from its goal if unchecked. The mixed signals left yields largely unchanged, reflecting a cautious market outlook.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust plans up to S$1.44b equity fundraising
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) is planning an equity fundraising of up to S$1.44 billion, comprising a private placement and a non-renounceable preferential offering. The private placement will raise S$575-675 million, while the preferential offering will raise at least S$746 million. The funds will partially finance the Reit's acquisition of the remaining 63.11% stake in AsiaRetail Fund and reduce existing debts. The equity fundraising will increase FCT's retail properties to 11 and its retail net lettable area to 2.3 million square feet, making it one of Singapore's largest suburban mall owners.

site_title: Singapore to calibrate debt moratoriums soon
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to calibrate debt moratorium schemes, extending them to certain borrowers beyond December 31, 2020. The regulator aims to ensure borrowers with the ability to pay start repayment before the moratoriums expire, addressing concerns about a "cliff effect" on the financial system. SMEs and property owners have been able to defer payments until December 31, with a total of S$15 billion in mortgages and S$11.4 billion in SME loans deferred.

site_title: Volkswagen, Chinese ventures to invest 15b euros in electric vehicles
summary: Volkswagen has announced a 15 billion euro investment in electric vehicles in China between 2020 and 2024, with plans to build 15 different models by 2025. The investment will be made in collaboration with local joint ventures and will involve sourcing EV batteries from CATL, Guoxuan, and A123. The German carmaker will start production at two Chinese factories in October, marking a significant expansion of its electric mobility efforts in the world's largest car market.

site_title: MYP to sell ABI Plaza for S$200m to CapitaLand fund entity
summary: MYP, a Singaporean real estate investment firm, plans to sell its 12-storey office tower ABI Plaza in Tanjong Pagar for S$200 million to a CapitaLand fund entity, Artemis Ventures. The sale is part of MYP's efforts to maintain a strong balance sheet and unlock the property's underlying value. The deal, which is expected to complete within 16 weeks, will result in a "book" loss of S$60.1 million but a "cash" profit of S$34.2 million.

site_title: Six strata-titled commercial units at Jalan Taman for sale with S$25m guide price
summary: Six strata-titled commercial units at 1 Jalan Taman are up for sale with a collective guide price of S$25 million. The units, ranging in size from 1,216 to 2,852 sq ft, are located within a four-storey commercial podium at St Michael's Place. Each unit's price ranges from S$2.35 million to S$5.95 million. If bought collectively, the combined strata size will be approximately 12,788 sq ft.

site_title: Abbott wins EU approval for smallest version of glucose monitoring device
summary: Abbott Laboratories has received European Union approval for the smallest version of its glucose monitoring device, FreeStyle Libre 3. The device, priced at $54, is a continuous glucose monitoring system that allows diabetics to track blood sugar levels without daily finger sticks. The Libre 3 sensor is worn on the upper arm for 14 days and can be automatically tracked on smartphones through the FreeStyle Libre 3 mobile app. This approval follows a 59.3% increase in worldwide sales of Freestyle Libre devices to $600 million in the first quarter of 2020.

site_title: Japan Airlines embraces gender neutral greetings
summary: Japan Airlines has announced it will ditch the phrase "ladies and gentlemen" in favor of gender-neutral greetings starting October 1. The airline will use phrases like "good morning" and "good evening" in all languages used by the airline, a first for major Japanese carriers. This move follows JAL's previous steps to promote LGBTQ+ inclusivity, including a trial "LGBT Ally Charter" flight and changes to spouse and family allowances. The decision aims to make the airline's announcements more inclusive and welcoming to all passengers.

site_title: Caesars says US$3.7b bid high enough for William Hill
summary: Caesars Entertainment has confirmed it made a US$3.7 billion bid for William Hill, which is likely to be accepted by the British gambling group's board. This bid surpasses Apollo Global Management's offer, with Caesars' existing joint venture with William Hill giving it an advantage. The deal could allow William Hill to expand its US market following the legalization of sports betting in 2018. Caesars plans to focus on William Hill's US assets and potentially break up the rest of the business if its bid is successful.

site_title: Malaysia's palace to issue statement on Monday: official
summary: Malaysia's palace will issue a statement on Monday amid opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim's bid to form a new government. Anwar claims to have secured a majority from lawmakers to oust Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin. However, he needs to convince King Sultan Abdullah that he has the necessary numbers to form a government. The king is currently recovering at a hospital and is not taking meetings for a week. The statement is expected to address the situation, but details are unclear.

site_title: Spirits maker Diageo says US business ahead of expectations
summary: Diageo, the world's largest spirits maker, reported a strong start to its fiscal year 2021, with its US business performing ahead of expectations. The company's shares jumped 6% following the announcement. CEO Ivan Menezes attributed the improved outlook to easing Covid-19 restrictions in many countries. This positive news contrasts with the overall economic uncertainty due to the ongoing pandemic and rising tariffs.

site_title: China wants to rely almost entirely on pork produced at home
summary: China aims to be almost entirely self-sufficient in pork production, targeting 95% domestic production by 2025, with large-scale hog farms dominating the industry. The goal is driven by African swine fever, which has reduced herds by nearly half, and a surge in meat imports. The country plans to expand imports of safe meat products, boost reliance on domestic supplies, and upgrade its slaughtering industry to meet growing demand for beef, mutton, and dairy products.

images.alt_text: China, the top pork consumer, has set a long-term goal to be almost completely self-sufficient in the staple, with big hog farms dominating the industry, as the nation seeks to reduce its dependency on food imports.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower on financials and consumers; NZ recovers
summary: Australian shares ended 0.2% lower at 5,952.3, weighed down by financials and consumer stocks. Heavyweight banks lost 0.6-1.1% amid profit-taking, while miners BHP and Rio Tinto declined 1.3-1.5%. In contrast, New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index rose marginally higher at 11,802.29, following Victoria's single-digit rise in new cases and easing of restrictions.

site_title: Thailand extends emergency ahead of easing ban on tourists
summary: Thailand extends a state of emergency until October 31 to prepare for the easing of its ban on tourists, following a six-month gap due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The country has managed to control local transmission and has reported only 59 deaths, with most recent cases in state quarantine. The government will issue special tourist visas starting next month, with the first 150 Chinese nationals arriving on October 8. Foreign visitors will need to undergo COVID-19 testing and quarantine, and the government aims to balance minimizing risks with re-opening for tourism.

images.alt_text: Thailand will extend a state of emergency through October as the tourism-dependent nation gears up for the re-opening of borders to foreign visitors after a six-month gap, while maintaining its relative success in containing local transmission of the coronavirus.

site_title: Huawei exec to accuse US of misleading Canada in extradition case
summary: Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou is set to accuse the US of misleading Canada in her extradition case, claiming the US provided an incomplete record of alleged crimes. Meng's lawyers argue the US charges against her, related to hiding Huawei's ties with a former subsidiary in Iran, are false and lack context. The defense plans to present this information in court, potentially disqualifying the US case. Meng's lawyers seek her release, citing the alleged misleading record.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher with eyes on US-China tensions
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Monday, driven by rallies on Wall Street, amid US-China tensions over technology issues. The Nikkei 225 index rose 1.32% to 23,511.62, while the Topix index gained 1.69%. Investors closely watched US-China tensions, but traders brushed off new Trump threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Air France leads tax pushback in climate versus recovery fight
summary: Air France-KLM is resisting new green taxes amid the coronavirus crisis, citing higher costs that will harm jobs and hinder development of lower-carbon technologies. The Franco-Dutch airline group, sustained by state-backed loans, faces higher duties in both France and the European Union. The EU's executive plans to cut greenhouse gas output by 55% in the next decade, and campaigners say new taxes are long overdue. However, crisis-hit airlines warn that the timing and severity of the taxes will be counterproductive, while campaigners argue that governments should use bailouts to force faster progress in reducing emissions.

site_title: Seoul: Shares jump most in two weeks on falling virus cases, upbeat China data
summary: South Korean shares surged 1.29% on Monday, the largest daily gain in two weeks, driven by easing domestic COVID-19 cases and upbeat China data. The country reported 50 new cases, the lowest in over a month, and China's industrial profits grew for the fourth straight month. Shares of Hyundai Motor and Kakao jumped 3.2% and 5% respectively, while South Korean chipmakers Samsung Electronics and DB Hitek rose on hopes of benefiting from US export restrictions on China's SMIC.

site_title: URA restricts re-issue of option to purchase for same unit
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has restricted private housing developers from re-issuing options to purchase (OTPs) for the same unit to the same buyer within 12 months of expiry. Developers are also prohibited from providing upfront agreements to re-issue OTPs. The URA aims to promote financial discipline in property purchases, advising buyers to commit to a purchase only when they are ready to exercise the OTP within its validity period.

images.alt_text: THE Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has restricted the re-issuing of options to purchase (OTPs) to buyers of the same unit.

site_title: US dollar near two-month high amid economic, political risks
summary: The US dollar reached a two-month high against a basket of currencies on Monday, amid economic and political risks. The dollar index stood near 94.530, driven by concerns about the economic recovery from the pandemic and US political uncertainties. Investors are cautious ahead of key economic data and the first US Presidential debate on Tuesday, with some speculators holding a large net short position in the dollar. The euro and British pound also traded lower, while the Turkish lira briefly dropped to a record low of 7.8000 per dollar.

site_title: Five groups ousted from UN-backed responsible investment list
summary: The United Nations-backed Principles for Responsible Investment (PRI) has removed five investors from its list, including four asset managers and one asset owner, for failing to meet minimum requirements. The delisted firms include BPE, Stichting Gemeenschappelijk Beleggingsfonds FNV, Corfina Capital, Primary Wave IP Investment Management, and Delta Alternative Management, which collectively manage assets of over $5 billion. The move aims to ensure members adhere to environmental, social, and governance-related issues in investment decision-making and follows criticism of the PRI's effectiveness in enforcing its principles.

site_title: Beijing asks frozen food importers to shun countries with severe coronavirus
summary: Beijing has urged frozen food importers to avoid countries with severe coronavirus outbreaks, citing risks of contamination. The move comes after several cases of imported seafood products testing positive for the virus. China has also suspended imports from Brazil, Indonesia, and Russia for a week or more. The Beijing Municipal Commerce Bureau warned importers to monitor overseas pandemic situations and improve reporting mechanisms if products test positive.

images.alt_text: China's capital called on importers on Monday to shun frozen food from countries suffering from severe novel coronavirus outbreaks after several cases of imported seafood products testing positive for the virus.

site_title: The case for digital business models in a new world
summary: A Singaporean food and beverage company rapidly transitioned to a digital business model during the pandemic, implementing a QR code payment solution that enabled customers to pay through their smartphones and iPads. The company's success in this area has encouraged it to explore similar digital solutions across its Asian Pacific markets. The shift to digital has been accelerated by the pandemic, with an estimated 70% of consumers in Southeast Asia expected to have gone online by the end of the year. This trend is expected to continue, with significant implications for businesses across various sectors.

site_title: Deliveroo to roll out grocery service; offer vouchers, free deliveries
summary: Deliveroo Singapore has launched a "booster" fund to support restaurants, customers, and non-profit partners during the coronavirus pandemic. The S$350,000 fund will provide free extended deliveries, restaurant vouchers, and donations to charity Food from the Heart. Deliveroo will also partner with Marks & Spencer to launch a grocery delivery service on Oct 12, offering discounts and vouchers for customers. The fund aims to help restaurants increase orders and revenues, and Deliveroo will donate S$1 for every social media submission to the #CleanPlateChallenge, with a total of S$10,000.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rally at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Monday, following last week's volatility. London's FTSE 100 index grew 1.4% to 5,921.64 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 index advanced 1.7% to 12,675.03 points. The Paris CAC 40 also rose 1.4% to 4,795.88 points. The rally was driven by gains in mining and healthcare shares, with US-EU trade talks in focus.

site_title: JPMorgan says usual hedges aren't working as they once did
summary: JPMorgan strategists have warned that traditional safe-haven assets, such as Treasuries and gold, are not providing adequate hedge protection against market downturns. Easy-money policies may be keeping investors in cash, discouraging them from investing in other asset classes. Despite this, JPMorgan still recommends holding a portfolio of hedges, such as the yen versus all currencies, as they have delivered gains in 60-80% of major stock-market downturns. The strategist also believes the equity correction is largely over, with a potential resolution within two months.

images.alt_text: Safe-haven assets seen as traditional hedges aren't panning out as they once did, according to JPMorgan Chase & Co.

site_title: ANA drops most since April after reports of raising S$2.6b
summary: ANA Holdings Inc. plummeted 8.5% in Tokyo trading, its largest intraday drop since April, after a report suggested the airline is considering a S$2.61 billion public share offering to raise 200 billion yen. The airline is also planning to cut costs by selling aircraft and disposing of non-core businesses. Analysts say the move is about survival, citing the industry's unlikely recovery from the coronavirus pandemic and the shift to video conferencing. ANA's shares are down 30.5% year-to-date.

site_title: Open for Christmas: Australia's virus hotspot could be near normal by summer
summary: Australia's city of Melbourne, a COVID-19 hotspot, is on track to return to near normal by Christmas, with a single-digit rise in new cases for the first time in three months. The easing of curbs, including a night-time curfew, will allow 127,000 people to return to work and is expected to boost the economy. Premier Daniel Andrews urged people to stick to strict social distancing rules, despite the lockdown's end. The downward trend in new infections bodes well for summer sporting events, such as the Australian Open tennis tournament.

site_title: From cars to jewellery, China's shoppers are spending again
summary: China's economy has resumed its surging ways after the COVID-19 pandemic, with shoppers spending on cars, jewelry, and other luxury items. The first major auto show since the pandemic opened in Beijing, featuring new models from Western and Chinese companies, saw strong demand for vehicles. Retail sales grew 0.5% in September compared to the same period last year, with midpriced restaurants and hotels seeing increased sales. The recovery in spending started with affluent consumers and is now spreading to middle-class families, with many low-income workers still struggling.

site_title: Amazon's pandemic-delayed Prime Day will start Oct 13
summary: Amazon's Prime Day, delayed due to the pandemic, will take place on October 13. The two-day shopping event will offer discounts to Prime members, with the goal of testing consumer spending habits. The move comes after Walmart launched its own subscription program, Walmart+, and Amazon aims to support small businesses affected by the pandemic. Shoppers who spend $10 with select small merchants on Amazon's marketplace will receive a $10 credit for Prime Day. Amazon is also using the event to test its growing warehousing and logistics operation ahead of a potentially record-breaking holiday shopping season.

site_title: Digital platform OneSME launched to promote trade between Singapore, China SMEs
summary: Singapore has launched OneSME, a digital trade platform connecting local SMEs with Chinese businesses, to promote trade between the two countries. The platform aims to help local SMEs expand their overseas reach and tap into Chinese demand for Singapore products. Developed by OneConnect Financial Technology and supported by the Infocomm Media Development Authority, OneSME was launched by Sim Ann, Senior Minister of State for Communications and Information and National Development. The platform is expected to facilitate business-to-business trade between Singapore and China.

site_title: Chinese investors flock to newly-launched funds targeting Ant IPO
summary: Chinese investors are flocking to newly-launched mutual funds targeting Ant Group's upcoming IPO, seeking strategic stakes. The funds, launched on Friday, have already reached their fundraising targets and stopped accepting new investments. Ant Group aims to raise about US$35 billion in a dual listing in Hong Kong and Shanghai's Star Market in October, potentially the world's largest IPO. Strong demand for technology shares underscores the interest in Chinese tech firms facing US scrutiny.

site_title: Siemens unleashes behemoth behind much of world's electricity
summary: Siemens Energy AG, a spin-off of Siemens AG, is set to list and allow investors to bet on the company's technology behind one-sixth of the world's electricity. The separation aims to focus on unique challenges, including oil and gas extraction and power generation. However, efforts to curb emissions may constrain the company's longer-term prospects. Despite these challenges, the listing marks a significant step in the company's evolution, enabling investors to make pure-play bets on its future performance.

site_title: Aldi UK to invest £1.3b as profits rise
summary: Aldi UK plans to invest £1.3 billion over the next two years, a 49% increase in 2019 profit, as it aims to expand its store network to 1,200 by 2025. The company will open around 100 new stores and upgrade over 100 existing locations, while also investing in distribution centers. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on shopper behavior, Aldi remains committed to its expansion plans.

site_title: SMIC's Hong Kong shares tumble after US tightens export restrictions
summary: US imposes export restrictions on China's SMIC, citing a risk of military use. SMIC shares tumble 7.9% to HK$17.12, the lowest since May 29. The company claims it has no ties with the Chinese military and has not received an official notice of the restrictions.

site_title: Malaysia's Aug exports drop 2.9% y-o-y, worse than forecast
summary: Malaysia's August exports dropped 2.9% from a year earlier, worse than forecasted 4.8% growth, due to declining shipments to key markets and demand for manufacturing, agriculture, and mining goods. Imports also shrank 6.5% from a year earlier. The trade surplus narrowed to RM13.2 billion, down from a historic high of RM25.15 billion in July. This marks a sharp dip from the 3.1% rise in July.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise but tempered by virus, election fears
summary: Asian stocks rose on Monday, driven by a strong lead from Wall Street and bargain-buying, but were tempered by concerns over the COVID-19 pandemic and the US presidential election. Tech firms led gains, while Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp fell after US export controls were announced. The World Health Organization warned that the global death toll could double without collective action. Asian markets were positive, with Tokyo, Seoul, and Taipei rising over 1%, while Hong Kong also rallied despite China's chipmaker SMIC tumbling.

site_title: New York City authorities worry over neighborhood coronavirus hotbeds
summary: New York City health authorities are concerned about rising coronavirus infection rates in several neighborhoods, particularly among the Orthodox Jewish community in Brooklyn. Six neighborhoods have seen rates spike, surpassing 5-6%, with over 23% of new cases citywide attributed to these areas. The increase coincides with the Jewish High Holidays and has raised fears of a second wave in the city, which reported a record 23,800 Covid-19 fatalities in the spring. Authorities have warned of sanctions for non-compliant schools, including inspections and fines, ahead of the planned October 1 reopening of public schools.

site_title: India's coronavirus infections cross 6 million
summary: India's coronavirus case tally surpassed 6 million with 82,170 new infections reported in the last 24 hours, according to the health ministry. Deaths from Covid-19 rose to 95,542, accounting for 1.6% of total cases. Globally, India ranks second in coronavirus cases, behind the US, which surpassed 7 million last week.

site_title: South Korea reports lowest coronavirus cases since new wave of outbreaks last month
summary: South Korea reported 50 new coronavirus cases on Monday, the lowest since a new wave of outbreaks last month, with 40 domestic and 10 imported cases. Total infections rose to 23,661, with 406 deaths. The Korea Disease Control and Prevention Agency has taken unprecedented social distancing measures, including a ban on on-site night-time dining, which may be relaxed if daily cases remain below 50. The government will review the policy after the Korean thanksgiving holidays, when tens of millions of people travel across the country.

site_title: Dreamworld Australia fined A$3.6m for water ride deaths
summary: Dreamworld Australia's owner, Ardent Leisure, was fined A$3.6 million for safety failures leading to the 2016 deaths of four people on the Thunder River Rapids ride. The company breached Queensland's workplace health and safety laws, but the maximum A$4.5 million penalty was not imposed.

site_title: Virus cases in hard-hit Australian state reach lowest in months
summary: Australian state Victoria recorded just five new coronavirus cases on Monday, marking the lowest daily rise in infections in months. Residents emerged from an almost two-month overnight curfew, with restrictions eased on industries and childcare centers reopening. Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews expressed optimism about the downward trend, suggesting further restrictions could be lifted if it continues. Despite easing of curfew, residents remain subject to a stay-at-home order and limited travel, with non-essential businesses still banned from reopening.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index up 0.30 points, or 0.02%, to 1,509.44. Volume was 226.25 million lots worth RM112.06 million, with gainers beating losers 279 to 77.

site_title: PayNow banks raise default limit to S$5,000 for ad-hoc transactions
summary: The Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) announced that all nine participating PayNow banks will allow ad-hoc transactions of S$5,000 or more, expanding the scope of payments to merchants and friends. This higher default limit applies to PayNow on both internet banking and mobile application channels, as well as scan-and-pay transactions and transfers initiated without adding the recipient as a payee. The change aims to provide customers with a wider range of payment options.

images.alt_text: THE Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) said on Monday that all nine participating PayNow banks will now allow ad-hoc transactions of S$5,000 or more, offering customers a wider scope of payments to merchants and friends.

site_title: Bats are the newest key to producing a fine bottle of Bordeaux
summary: Bats are being hailed as heroes in Bordeaux, France, for their potential role in boosting wine yields and quality. Winemakers have turned to local bats to help combat invasive pests, such as the European grapevine moth, which can cause gray rot and affect wine quality. Studies have shown that bats successfully eradicate these pests, and some winemakers believe they may improve overall wine quality by reducing the need for pesticides. The Bordeaux Wine Bureau is supporting the initiative, which has already gained traction in other French wine regions, with the goal of reducing pesticide use and promoting a more sustainable winemaking approach.

site_title: In Paris, a fashion eco-system on edge as shows disappear
summary: Paris Fashion Week is expected to be significantly impacted by the ongoing pandemic, with many luxury brands canceling or downsizing physical shows. Only 19 of 85 scheduled shows will feature socially distanced front rows, and many are instead holding small presentations or streaming videos. This shift has left caterers, make-up artists, and lighting specialists without work, with some businesses relying on partial unemployment aid. Despite the challenges, some designers are optimistic about the longer-term prospects for virtual fashion events and are planning smaller, more intimate shows to connect with buyers and media.

site_title: Saudi Arabia sends blue ammonia to Japan in world-first shipment
summary: Saudi Arabia has shipped the world's first 40 tonnes of blue ammonia to Japan, a low-carbon fuel produced by converting hydrocarbons into hydrogen and capturing carbon dioxide. The shipment is part of a partnership between Saudi Aramco, ACWA Power International, and Mitsubishi Corp to develop a US$5 billion hydrogen-based ammonia plant powered by renewable energy. The move aims to demonstrate the potential of hydrocarbons as a reliable and affordable source of low-carbon hydrogen and ammonia, as Saudi Arabia seeks to counter its reputation for producing dirty energy.

site_title: Hot stock: Medical-device maker Vicplas falls 30% after board trims dividend
summary: Vicplas International, a medical device maker, saw its shares plummet 30% after the company's board trimmed its dividend payout for the financial year ended July 31, citing a need to balance shareholder rewards with business development and capital preservation. Despite a 17.7% increase in net profit to nearly $5 million, revenue rose only 10.8% to $88.8 million, with the company aiming to diversify its manufacturing operations by potentially setting up a fifth plant outside China.

site_title: Wilmar's China unit IPO passes 13.9b yuan mark amid oversubscription of shares
summary: Wilmar International's China unit, Yihai Kerry Arawana (YKA), successfully raised about 13.93 billion yuan (S$2.81 billion) through its initial public offering (IPO) on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange ChiNext Board, exceeding the initial target of 13.9 billion yuan. The IPO shares were oversubscribed 600.5 times for offline investors and 1,750 times for online retail investors. Strategic investors, including local sovereign wealth fund GIC, also participated, with 30% of shares allocated. The listing is expected to proceed by mid-October, pending prevailing market conditions.

site_title: In lockdown, an 86-year-old blogger finds a new purpose
summary: An 86-year-old London blogger, Hazell Jacobs, found a new purpose during the COVID-19 lockdown by writing a blog called "Scarf Aid," where she shares stories and memories from her life through scarves she has collected over the years. The blog became a lifeline for many readers, particularly older adults who were struggling with loneliness and isolation. Jacobs' story highlights the importance of connectedness and purpose in older adults, particularly during the pandemic, and how it can lead to better mental and physical health outcomes.

site_title: SoftBank brings food service robot to labour-strapped Japan
summary: SoftBank's robotics arm will bring California-based Bear Robotics' food service robot Servi to Japan, launching in January, amid labor shortages and social distancing concerns. Servi, equipped with 3D cameras and Lidar sensors, will cost 99,800 yen ($1,301) per month. This marks a shift away from SoftBank's focus on humanoid robots, as seen with its Pepper robot. Servi has been tested by Japanese restaurant operators, including Seven & i Holdings, and leverages SoftBank's experience in bringing overseas technology to Japan.

site_title: SPH, News Corp Australia to bring digital marketing service for SMEs to Singapore
summary: SPH and News Corp Australia have partnered to bring News Xtend, a digital marketing service, to Singapore. The service will offer outcome-based digital marketing solutions for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) through a monthly subscription model. This partnership aims to expand SPH's advertising network, providing SMEs with an affordable and cost-effective digital marketing solution.

site_title: LTA buys 40 more trains from Bombardier Transportation for around S$337.8m
summary: Singapore's Land Transport Authority (LTA) has purchased 40 new trains from Bombardier Transportation for approximately S$337.8 million as part of the long-term fleet renewal programme for the North-South and East-West Lines. The new trains, starting from 2024, will replace the current second- and third-generation trains, and will feature integrated condition-monitoring features and improved passenger amenities. This purchase brings the total number of NSEWL trains supplied by Bombardier to 106.

images.alt_text: The new trains will arrive in batches, starting from 2024.

site_title: Gold inches higher on subdued US dollar; Trump-Biden debate in focus
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,861.02 per ounce on Monday, driven by a weaker US dollar amid growing political uncertainty ahead of the first presidential debate between Donald Trump and Joe Biden. The dollar index fell 0.2% against rivals, making gold more expensive for holders of other currencies. Speculators reduced their bullish positions in Comex gold and silver contracts, but prices are still up about 20% this year due to global stimulus efforts.

images.alt_text: Gold edged up on Monday as the US dollar slipped off a two-month peak it hit last week, due to caution as political uncertainty built ahead of the first presidential election debate between US President Donald Trump and his Democratic rival Joe Biden.

site_title: Beijing unveils new protections for health emergency whistleblowers
summary: Beijing has introduced new protections for health emergency whistleblowers, offering rewards and ensuring their safety and legal rights are protected. The city government will also allow workers to bypass the chain of command and report health risks directly to the local government without facing punishment if the information is found to be false. This move comes after criticism of the city's treatment of medical staff who initially reported on the Covid-19 outbreak in Wuhan. The measures are part of Beijing's efforts to improve early warning systems and address systemic flaws in handling epidemics.

site_title: Nadal begins 'most difficult' French Open as Serena tries again
summary: Rafael Nadal begins his "most difficult" French Open, seeking his 13th title, amid concerns over the new ball supplier, which he believes could pose physical problems for players. Meanwhile, Serena Williams attempts to clinch her 24th Grand Slam title, her first on clay, despite being short of preparation and dealing with lingering Achilles injury effects. Nadal faces Egor Gerasimov, while Williams takes on Kristie Ahn, as the tournament starts with overcast and chilly weather conditions.

site_title: Saudi Arabia says G-20 leaders summit to be held virtually on Nov 21-22
summary: Saudi Arabia announced that the G-20 leaders summit will be held virtually on November 21-22, focusing on protecting lives and restoring growth by addressing pandemic vulnerabilities and laying foundations for a better future. The G-20 has contributed over $21 billion to support diagnostics, therapeutics, and vaccines.

site_title: K-pop group BTS' label Big Hit prices IPO at top of range
summary: Big Hit Entertainment, the management label of K-pop group BTS, priced its initial public offering (IPO) at the top of its range, 135,000 won (S$158.16) per share, raising 962.6 billion won. This is South Korea's largest IPO in three years, surpassing Celltrion HealthCare's 1 trillion won in 2017. The IPO will increase Big Hit's total market value to approximately 4.8 trillion won, making it the first South Korean group to reach No 1 on the US Billboard Hot 100 singles chart.

site_title: Australia: Shares dip as miners, gold stocks weigh; New Zealand falls
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% to 5,951.5, weighed down by a drop in commodity prices, particularly iron ore and gold. Despite a jump in local tech stocks, optimism over eased restrictions in Victoria was not enough to offset the losses. Analysts cited fears of demand recovery for cyclical commodities due to rising COVID-19 cases globally. In contrast, New Zealand shares fell 0.4% to 11,744.61, with dairy producers a2 Milk and Synlait Milk affected by concerns over lower demand from Chinese resellers.

site_title: Top iron ore shipper says rally may cool as risks lie in China
summary: Australia's top iron ore shipper predicts a potential cooling of the price rally by the end of 2020 due to risks in China's steelmaking industry. The Department of Industry, Science, Energy & Resources cited potential shifts in Chinese steel output and a sharp contraction in global steelmaking if a second coronavirus outbreak occurs or Chinese government stimulus falls short of expectations. This warning contrasts with Citigroup's forecast of strong Chinese demand supporting prices in the $100-$120 per ton range for the rest of the year.

site_title: Westpac revises RBA rate call; now expects cut in November
summary: Westpac economists have revised their forecast for the Reserve Bank of Australia's interest rate cut, now expecting a cut in November instead of October. The predicted 15 basis point cut to 0.1% aims to give the government "clear air" to sell its budget. The decision is expected at the RBA's Nov 3 board meeting, where they also plan to commit to buying bonds in the 5-10 year maturities. This change follows a previous prediction of a cut in October.

site_title: Evergrande tries to stop bond rout from becoming downward spiral
summary: China Evergrande Group attempted to revive confidence in its finances by stating its operations are "stable and healthy" after record lows in onshore bonds and a worst-performing stock globally. The company has dropped total debt and financing costs since March and hasn't missed an interest or principal payment since its founding 24 years ago. Evergrande won approval to spin off its property management unit, paving the way for capital raising, and has agreed to repay $5.8 billion of bonds and loans over the next two months. A looming deadline for regulatory approval on a backdoor listing could impact the company's ability to raise funds.

images.alt_text: China Evergrande Group attempted to revive confidence in its finances, after fears of a cash crunch sent the property giant's onshore bonds to record lows and turned its stock into one of the worst performers globally.

site_title: Indonesia unions threaten strike over government's labour reforms
summary: Indonesian trade unions are threatening a national strike on October 6-8 to protest proposed labour reforms in President Joko Widodo's "Job Creation" bill. The reforms, which include cutting mandatory severance benefits to 23 times monthly wages, have been agreed upon by a parliament committee despite union opposition. The unions, representing five million workers, will hold rallies this week and demand the reforms be dropped. The government has argued the changes are necessary to attract manufacturing investment from China. A parliamentary vote is expected before the bill is finalized.

site_title: NZ's a2 Milk forecasts weaker revenue on disruption to Chinese sales
summary: New Zealand's a2 Milk Co Ltd forecasts lower first-half revenue due to disruptions to its informal Chinese sales channel, known as the "daigou" channel, which accounts for a significant portion of its infant milk formula revenue in Australia and New Zealand. The company expects revenue between NZ$725-775 million for the six-months ended December 2020, down from NZ$806.7 million reported a year ago. Shares plummeted 14.9% after the announcement, the company's worst daily performance since August 2019. Demand for its IMF brand in China remains solid, but the company believes the weak daigou trading is a short-term logistics issue.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.76% or 176.04 points at 23,380.66, driven by rallies on Wall Street. Investors are cautious about US-China tensions over technology issues.

site_title: TikTok gets reprieve as judge halts Trump download ban
summary: US District Judge Carl Nichols has halted the Trump administration's ban on new downloads of TikTok, effective until November 12, citing concerns that a temporary ban would be "devastating" for the company. The ban, aimed at addressing national security concerns over TikTok's Chinese parent firm, ByteDance, has been temporarily suspended after TikTok argued that a ban would irreparably harm its growth and reputation. The court has yet to consider the merits of the ban, and negotiations to restructure TikTok's ownership are ongoing.

images.alt_text: TikTok won a last-minute reprieve late Sunday as a US federal judge halted enforcement of a politically charged ban ordered by the Trump administration on downloads of the popular video app, hours before it was set to take effect.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Olam, DBS, Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust, iFast
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several companies saw new developments that may affect trading on Monday. Olam International obtained a $200 million loan from DBS and Industrial and Commercial Bank of China. Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust acquired a Seoul office building for $267.6 million. iFast Corp plans to launch a private fund manager business in China. SIIC Environment Holdings inked new wastewater-treatment contracts in China. iX Biopharma obtained a license in Australia to bring product testing in-house. Meanwhile, Lian Beng's acquisition of Thye Hong Centre raised questions about dividend distribution, and Geo Energy Resources faces lawsuits over a bid to buy an Indonesian company.

site_title: Vicplas full-year earnings grow 17.7% on boost from medical devices
summary: Vicplas International, a medical device and pipe manufacturer, reported a 17.7% increase in net profit to nearly S$5 million for its fiscal year ended July 31. Revenue rose 10.8% to S$88.8 million, driven by a 36.2% increase in revenue from the medical devices segment. The company faces uncertainties in international trading conditions due to US-China trade tensions and the Covid-19 outbreak. Vicplas plans to diversify and attract customers by establishing or acquiring a fifth plant outside China.

site_title: China's Ping An boosts stake in HSBC after historic plunge
summary: China's Ping An Insurance Group increased its stake in HSBC Holdings to 8% after the bank's shares plummeted to a 25-year low, citing a "long-term financial investment". The move comes as HSBC faces mounting difficulties, including surging loan losses and regulatory concerns. Ping An's stake has lost over $8.6 billion in value over the past three years, but the insurer remains committed to the bank. HSBC's CEO warned of potential bad loans and a shakeup of global operations amid the bank's struggles.

images.alt_text: China's Ping An Insurance Group raised its stake in HSBC Holdings after the shares slumped to the lowest in a quarter of a century, giving support to the lender that's facing mounting difficulties on several fronts.

site_title: Negative real yields on sovereign debt here to stay: poll
summary: Real yields on major sovereign bonds, such as US 10-year Treasuries, are expected to remain deeply negative, with only 20-30 basis point increases forecasted in a year. A Reuters poll of over 100 fixed-income strategists found that nearly three-quarters of respondents believed sovereign yields would stay around current levels or be range-bound, with low inflation expectations and central banks' pledges to keep benchmark policy rates near zero contributing to the trend.

site_title: Olam obtains S$200m Sora-pegged club loan from DBS, ICBC Singapore
summary: Olam International has secured a S$200 million club loan from DBS and ICBC Singapore, pegged to the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (Sora), marking a milestone in Singapore's transition to Sora as the new interest rate benchmark. The loan provides Olam with flexibility and adaptability as it shifts towards mainstream adoption of Sora-based markets. The move supports the Association of Banks in Singapore and the Singapore Foreign Exchange Market Committee's efforts to develop new Sora-based markets.

site_title: For Biden, debate with Trump offers moment of truth
summary: US President Joe Biden is set to face off against Donald Trump in a pivotal debate, with Biden aiming to present himself as a calm and empathetic unifier amidst a polarized nation. Biden has pledged action on climate change, racial injustice, jobs, student debt relief, and aid for pandemic-hit families, seeking to differentiate himself from Trump's bombast. Biden, 77, is expected to target Trump's claims of "rigging" the election and his diminished mental acuity, while Trump has repeatedly accused Democrats of dishonesty. The debate marks a crucial moment for Biden's campaign, just five weeks before the November 3 election.

site_title: Positive Covid-19 test rates top 25% in some US Midwest states
