summary: US Midwest states experience a surge in Covid-19 cases and hospitalizations, with positive test rates exceeding 25% in some states. North Dakota's rate averages 30%, while South Dakota's rate rises to 26%. Several states, including Minnesota and Montana, have positivity rates below 7%. Cases and hospitalizations set records in the region, with Wisconsin reporting more new infections than Florida. Hospitalizations surge across the Midwest, with Wisconsin, South Dakota, and Wyoming setting records.

site_title: British ministers prepare for social lockdown in northern Britain, London
summary: British ministers are planning a total social lockdown across northern Britain and potentially London to combat a second wave of Covid-19. Under the new measures, pubs, restaurants, and bars would be ordered to shut for two weeks initially. This comes despite Prime Minister Boris Johnson's earlier statement that any new national lockdown would threaten jobs, livelihoods, and human contact.

site_title: Australia extends airline relief package with budget deficit seen at A$198.5b
summary: The Australian government has extended a Covid-19 relief package for domestic airlines by four months until January 31, 2021, and flights to regional locations until March 28. The extension aims to address uncertainty in the aviation industry due to border closures and cancellations. The government has already spent over A$150 million on the package since its introduction in April. A budget deficit of A$198.5 billion is predicted, with Deloitte Access Economics forecasting a A$14 billion increase from the government's initial forecast.

site_title: TikTok will survive Donald Trump, US users say
summary: TikTok is expected to survive despite President Donald Trump's threats to force the Chinese-owned app to sell or spin off to an American company due to concerns over national security. Many US users, including aspiring political scientist Rebecca Fisher-Tringale, believe the platform will continue to thrive, citing its popularity and ability to provide a voice for young people. Experts say Trump's efforts are unlikely to succeed, as other US institutions will protect the platform where users feel free to express their opinions.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open on positive note
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened on a positive note, with the Hang Seng Index gaining 0.21% to 23,284.09, following a strong lead from Wall Street. The Shanghai Composite Index also rose 0.17%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index increased 0.31%. The gains were driven by healthy economic data indicating China's economy continues to improve.

site_title: Estee Lauder pays Nasa US$128,000 for photo shoot in space
summary: Estee Lauder is sending 10 bottles of its Advanced Night Repair skin serum to the International Space Station for a photo shoot, costing the company $128,000. The images will be used on social media and one bottle will be auctioned off for charity upon return to Earth this spring. This move is part of Estee Lauder's effort to tout its skincare innovation and comes as the company seeks to break through the glut of content in the beauty industry.

site_title: iX Biopharma unit obtains Australia licence to bring product testing in-house
summary: iX Biopharma's subsidiary, iX Syrinx, has obtained a Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) licence in Australia to conduct in-house product testing, improving speed-to-market and potentially saving on testing costs. This move allows the company to shift its laboratory testing operations in-house, reducing dependency on third-party laboratories and enabling faster product development. The licence was previously held by a sold business, Chemical Analysis Pty Ltd, and is expected to complement the company's integrated business model.

site_title: Singapore shares edge down at Monday's open; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.1% or 1.19 points to 2,471.09 on Monday, as local banks started the day weaker. Gainers outnumbered losers 72 to 48, with notable movers including Jiutian Chemical's 2% rise and Vicplas International's 22.2% drop. Banking stocks, such as DBS, UOB, and OCBC, declined 0.5-0.4%. Globally, stocks in the US and Asia rose, with the Nasdaq Composite Index jumping 2.3% and Tokyo stocks opening higher.

site_title: Market sees more volatility amid stimulus uncertainty
summary: US stocks fell slightly after a volatile week, extending the losing streak for the S&P 500 to four weeks. The market is uncertain due to reopened stimulus negotiations between Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi. The September jobs report and the Institute for Supply Management's factory survey may impact the market, with strategists warning of a prolonged and severe selloff if legislators are reluctant to pass fiscal giveaways. The COVID-19 pandemic also continues to affect the market, despite vaccine development progress.

site_title: Sick of staying home: China expects a Golden Week tourism rebound
summary: China expects a significant rebound in domestic travel over the upcoming Golden Week holiday, with some flights selling out and travel platforms reporting a surge in hotel bookings. The eight-day holiday from Oct 1 is seen as a turning point for the Chinese travel industry, which was severely impacted by the novel coronavirus for months. Despite lingering concerns over the virus, the sector is expected to recover, with 600 million trips estimated to be made during the holiday. Domestic air bookings have surged, and hotel bookings are up by over 50% compared to the same period last year.

site_title: Japan's retail property sector leads market rally as lockdowns ease
summary: Japan's retail property sector is leading a market rally as lockdowns ease, with the stock market rising nearly 9% since August. Foreign buying of properties, including shopping complexes and mixed developments, has driven the recovery. Japanese real estate funds and developers are focusing on the retail sector, which has bounced back by 90% to 120% year-on-year from June. The sector's cheapness, with major developers trading at an average 0.87 price-to-book-value, is also supporting its growth.

site_title: Opec turns 60 at 'critical moment' for virus-hit oil
summary: Opec, a 60-year-old oil cartel, faces a critical moment due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which has crushed crude demand and prices. Discord among members and threats from cleaner fuels have diminished its influence. Opec+ has taken a more prominent role, accounting for 50% of global oil output. The cartel has responded to surging energy supplies by curbing collective output, but its ability to steer the market has been questioned. Despite this, Opec still possesses the largest amount of accessible crude, potentially making it more important in the future.

site_title: Shoebox apartment market down on recession shakeout
summary: Demand for shoebox units in Singapore's primary market declined 25.6% year-on-year to 710 units sold in the first eight months of 2020, amid weaker supply and recession-induced pain for buyers. The proportion of small units sold in the primary market dropped to 12.1% of total non-landed private home transactions. However, the resale market saw a slight increase in demand, with 272 units sold. Analysts attribute the decline to recession, rising unemployment, and wage cuts, as well as reduced leasing demand for shoebox units due to economic headwinds.

site_title: Shareholders raise queries over acquisition of Thye Hong Centre by Lian Beng's unit
summary: Lian Beng's subsidiary SLB Development acquired Thye Hong Centre for S$112.5 million, raising questions about the company's ability to resume dividend distribution. Lian Beng stated it will consider resuming dividends when operations generate sufficient cash and profit. The company prioritizes ensuring resources to overcome pandemic-related challenges, including manpower shortages and safe-working practices. Occupancy remains stable in Singapore, but the UK hospitality sector is impacted. Shares fell 1.3% following the announcement.

site_title: World needs more cooperation, not less, to defeat Covid-19 and rebuild: Vivian tells UN
summary: Singapore's Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan urged the world to prioritize global cooperation to defeat Covid-19 and rebuild at the 75th UN General Assembly. He emphasized the need for vaccine multilateralism, equitable access to vaccines, and international cooperation to address the pandemic's devastating impact. Balakrishnan also highlighted the importance of open trading systems, supply chain connectivity, and rebuilding resilient societies, warning that protectionism and unilateral action will ultimately be self-defeating.

site_title: Tesla's US$25,000 car doesn't worry its biggest rivals in China
summary: Tesla's plan to release a US$25,000 car within three years has not deterred China's top electric vehicle (EV) startups, including WM Motor and Xpeng. Executives at these companies view Tesla as a partner, rather than a competitor, and believe their focus on smart, environmentally friendly cars will attract consumers. Despite Tesla's plans, EVs currently account for less than 5% of the market, and startups like WM Motor and Xpeng are accelerating the market's growth.

images.alt_text: Tesla plans to ship cars made at its Shanghai factory to Europe and other countries in Asia, including Singapore, Australia and New Zealand, as soon as the end of this year or early 2021.

site_title: Money FM: Podcasts of the week (Sept 21)
summary: A recent article discusses the potential benefits of maintaining remote working schemes post-COVID-19 for companies, which may increase revenues. Additionally, the article touches on the topic of blockchain and digital currencies reshaping the economy, but no specific details are provided. No other market-related news is mentioned in the article.

site_title: Hackers have infiltrated many of Washington State's agencies
summary: Hackers have launched a cyber-attack on Washington State, infecting multiple agencies with sophisticated malware, including Trickbot and Emotet. The attack, which began over a week ago, has exposed flaws in the state's security apparatus but has yet to significantly impact state operations. The attackers' motives are unclear, and it's not known if any data was stolen or if ransomware attacks will be deployed. The attack highlights the potential vulnerability of state computer networks, including election systems, ahead of the November presidential election.

images.alt_text: Cybereason's study found 7 in 10 respondents having been intoxicated while responding to ransomware incidents.

site_title: 'Two-headed beast': China's coal addiction erodes climate goals
summary: China's coal consumption surged in June, reaching near peak levels in 2013 despite its pledge to slash carbon footprint to zero by 2060. The country's reliance on coal, which powers its economic surge, threatens to nullify its low-carbon ambitions. China burns about half the world's coal, with annual emissions nearly tripling between 2000 and 2018, accounting for nearly a third of global greenhouse gas emissions linked to global warming. The recent increase in coal consumption may undermine China's efforts to meet its climate goals.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Capesize market saw a significant upward trajectory, with the 5TC index gaining over 50% in value, settling at $24,178. Brazilian trade activity drove the increase, with charterers understanding the change in the situation and fixing rates. The Panamax market also saw positive gains, led by solid mineral demand and US origins. However, the coal rates market was weak, particularly in the Indonesian/India coal runs. Owners faced downward pressure across the board, with rates for VLCC, Suezmax, and Aframax vessels also declining.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust justifies sale of Bedok Point in response to shareholders' queries
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) has defended the sale of Bedok Point for S$108 million, citing mall size constraints and stiff competition from newer retail offerings. Despite this, the sale is expected to optimize asset value and redeploy capital towards higher-yielding investments. The trust also plans to acquire ARF for S$1.06 billion, aiming to raise S$1.39 billion in equity to fund the acquisition and optimize portfolio performance. Unitholders will vote on the proposals at an EGM on September 28.

site_title: Judge prepares ruling after hearing on Trump TikTok download ban
summary: A federal judge is set to rule on a Trump administration ban on downloads of TikTok, a Chinese-owned video-sharing app. The ban, which would prohibit downloads of the app starting Monday, was challenged by TikTok, which argued it would be "punitive" and close off a public forum used by tens of millions of Americans. The judge heard arguments on the free-speech and national security implications of the ban, with TikTok lawyers saying it was "arbitrary and capricious" and would undermine data security. A deal to restructure TikTok's ownership is also underway.

site_title: Trump paid just US$750 in federal income tax in 2016: NYT
summary: US President Donald Trump paid just $750 in federal income taxes in 2016, the year he won the election, according to a report by The New York Times. This is despite him claiming to be a self-made billionaire and paying no income taxes for 10 of the previous 15 years. Trump immediately dismissed the report as "totally fake news," but the tax data reveals a pattern of significant write-offs and payments to the federal government, including millions from the 2013 Miss Universe pageant in Moscow.

site_title: Over 60% of Penrose condo units sold over the weekend
summary: Over 60% of Penrose condominium units were sold over the weekend, with 341 out of 566 units sold. The majority of buyers were Singaporeans, making up nearly 85%, followed by Singapore permanent residents and foreigners. The high sales numbers were attributed to the timing and pricing of the units.

site_title: China is building green cities, but struggling to find residents
summary: China is building eco-cities, such as Tianfu Park City, with government subsidies and tax breaks, but struggling to attract residents. The city, near Chengdu, features manicured grass and artificial lakes, but is far from bustling. Despite its green approach, critics say many eco-cities lack sustainable strategies, and residents may not feel the need to move to a newly built city. The government aims to limit the city's population to 6.3 million by 2030, but experts warn that it may not attract enough residents, mirroring previous experiences with eco-city projects.

site_title: Melbourne virus curfew to be lifted after nearly two months
summary: Melbourne's overnight curfew, imposed in August to combat a coronavirus outbreak, will be lifted on Monday, nearly two months later. The decision comes after a decline in active cases, with 16 new infections and two deaths reported in Victoria on Sunday. Residents will still be confined to within 5km of their homes, and fines for breaching restrictions will be increased. Other restrictions, such as limits on small religious services and visits to hospitals, will also be lifted, paving the way for the return of primary school students and childcare centers in mid-October.

site_title: Hong Leong's Penrose project about 60% sold
summary: Hong Leong Holdings sold 341 units of its 566-unit Penrose condominium in District 14, with nearly 85% of buyers being Singaporeans. The average selling price ranged between S$1,500 psf and S$1,700 psf, with keen interest from HDB upgraders across the island. The company attributed the strong sales to timing and pricing, citing a "current climate" where buyers are sensitive to market sentiments and project values.

site_title: China needs to step up global financial integration: official
summary: China needs to further integrate its capital markets and financial industry to avoid global isolation, said Lu Lei, deputy director of the State Administration of Foreign Exchange. China will conform to international rules and continue interest rate and exchange rate reforms. The country is accelerating financial market deregulation to counter the risks of decoupling economically and technologically with the world. China is also revising rules for private equity and overseas investment schemes to boost cross-border investment. The government aims to increase exchange rate flexibility to balance against economic volatility.

site_title: Bringing cheer to the elderly during mid-autumn festival
summary: Keppel Land, Tokio Marine Life Insurance Singapore, and care services provider Homage are teaming up to bring cheer to elderly seniors during the Mid-Autumn Festival. Keppel Land partnered with Lions Befrienders to deliver 100 care packs containing mooncakes and other food items to seniors in Jurong. Meanwhile, Tokio Marine Life Insurance Singapore delivered 200 boxes of mooncakes baked by stay-at-home mums to healthcare professionals and patients at Home Nursing Foundation. These initiatives aim to spread care and warmth to seniors who have been disproportionately impacted by the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Above: In celebration of the Mid-Autumn Festival, 25 volunteers from Keppel Land, led by Tan Swee Yiow (second from left), CEO of Keppel Land, packed and distributed care packs to 100 seniors living in Jurong.
Above: Tokio Marine Life Insurance Singapore staff with a patient of Home Nursing Foundation.

site_title: European airlines cutting fares in bid to woo back passengers
summary: European airlines are reducing fares to attract passengers as the Covid-19 crisis continues to impact air travel. Fares have been cut by 15% in southern Europe compared to the same period last year, with some routes seeing price drops of over 33%. Airlines aim to entice travelers to return to flying, with easyJet and Ryanair focusing on promotional offers and low-capacity flights. However, travel restrictions and quarantine measures could undo their efforts, and airlines have limited control over the pandemic's evolution.

site_title: US imposes restrictions on exports to China's top chipmaker
summary: The US has imposed export restrictions on Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp (SMIC), China's largest chipmaker, requiring US firms to apply for a licence to export certain products. The restrictions, which do not include SMIC on the US entity list, are aimed at reducing the risk of diversion to military end-use. The move is part of escalating tensions between the US and China in the technology sector, following the US blacklisting of Huawei. SMIC's shares have already slumped 23% following reports of the blacklist threat, with analysts warning that further restrictions could impact other Chinese companies.

site_title: Singaporeans want regional e-commerce players to step up their game: Blackbox
summary: Singaporean consumers, despite a 63% spike in online spending during the pandemic, are less than satisfied with their digital commerce experience, with over one-third expressing dissatisfaction. This comes as regional e-commerce players are urged to step up their offerings to meet consumer demands.

site_title: BOE's Tenreyro says evidence on negative rates is 'encouraging'
summary: Bank of England policymaker Silvana Tenreyro said evidence on cutting interest rates below zero is "encouraging," citing success in the euro zone and Japan in reducing companies' borrowing costs and boosting bank profitability. The Bank of England is considering the idea, but Governor Andrew Bailey has not ruled out its feasibility. Tenreyro expects Britain's economic recovery to lose pace due to Covid-19 flare-ups and a weak global outlook.

site_title: Apple's battle royale with Epic Games begins
summary: US district judge Yvonne Gonzalez Rogers will decide on Monday whether to force Apple to allow Epic Games to use third-party apps on its app store, but not to reinstate Fortnite. The decision will influence the future of app stores in the US and how technology platforms make money from developers. The ruling is expected to shape the app store model, with experts predicting that it may lead to changes in how Apple generates revenue. The outcome could have significant implications for the tech industry and the gaming sector.

images.alt_text: Financially, Apple does not have much to lose by kicking out Epic's battle royale game Fortnite, but there are broader risks for the tech giant.

site_title: The pillars of robust governance
summary: Key figures in corporate governance emphasize the importance of both diversity and independence among board members. While diversity brings different perspectives, independence is crucial in preventing groupthink and ensuring rational decision-making. Experts argue that boards should not be seen as an either/or issue, but rather as complementary aspects that work together to achieve better outcomes. The lack of diversity on corporate boards is a significant concern, and independence is more critical in preventing malpractice. Companies with strong governance and diverse boards tend to perform better and protect their value.

site_title: Malaysia's EPF becomes Riverstone substantial shareholder
summary: Malaysia's Employees Provident Fund (EPF) has become a substantial shareholder of Riverstone Holdings, acquiring 2 million shares for S$6,576,000. This increased the EPF's direct interest in the company from 4.86% to 5.13%. EPF Board of Malaysia's move follows a 119% increase in Riverstone Holdings' net profit to RM137.5 million (S$45.4 million) for its H1FY20.

site_title: Aviva-Singlife merger a sign of PE interest in Asia insurance assets
summary: Aviva has sold its Singapore operations to digital insurer Singlife for $2.7 billion, marking a significant deal in Southeast Asia's insurance sector. Global alternative asset firm TPG holds a 35% stake in the new group, with Aviva retaining 25% equity. The deal is expected to complete in January 2021 after regulatory approval. The partnership is seen as a sign of private equity interest in the insurance sector, which is attractive due to its potential for long-term returns and insulation from economic downturns.

site_title: BOE policymaker says evidence on negative rates is 'encouraging'
summary: Bank of England policymaker Silvana Tenreyro said evidence on cutting interest rates below zero is "encouraging," but the UK's economy is unlikely to experience a fast V-shaped recovery due to local Covid-19 flare-ups, rising joblessness, and a weak global economic outlook. The Bank of England has been investigating the idea, but governor Andrew Bailey has clarified it doesn't mean a commitment to going ahead. Tenreyro cited eurozone and Japan's success with negative rates, but warned that Britain's rebound will lose pace as Covid-19 cases rise again.

site_title: China's industrial profits grow for fourth straight month
summary: China's industrial profits grew 19.1% year-over-year in August, marking the fourth straight month of profit growth, driven by a rebound in commodities prices and equipment manufacturing. Industrial firm profits reached 612.81 billion yuan (S$123.6 billion). However, external pressures from rising tensions between the US and China cloud the global trade outlook, affecting raw material manufacturing and general equipment manufacturing profits. The country's economy faces challenges, including stagnation if it fails to rise up the value chain, and policymakers are under pressure to address these concerns.

images.alt_text: Profits at China's industrial firms grew for the fourth straight month in August, buoyed in part by a rebound in commodities prices and equipment manufacturing, the statistics bureau said on Sunday.

site_title: US dollar resumes its rally, showing strongest week since early April
summary: The US dollar has resumed its rally, posting its strongest weekly gain since early April, amid concerns over a slowing economic recovery, rising Covid-19 infections in Europe, and uncertainty about US stimulus. Orders for US capital goods rose 0.4% in August, while the dollar index gained 0.31% against a basket of major currencies. The euro fell 0.40% against the dollar, its largest weekly decline since early April, as the dollar strengthened against the yen and Swiss franc. The dollar's rally is seen as a response to increasing volatility ahead of the US elections and other global uncertainties.

site_title: Singtel unit NCS eyes regional growth
summary: Singapore-based ICT service provider NCS, a subsidiary of Singtel, is rebranding itself as a commercial services provider under new CEO Ng Kuo Pin. With a strong order book of S$3.2 billion, NCS is expanding into the Greater China and Australia regions, driven by the growth of digitalisation in the pandemic era. The company aims to leverage its experience in the public sector to drive innovation in the commercial world. NCS has set up three business units focusing on healthcare, communications, and financial services, and is actively recruiting talent in these markets.

site_title: Sport Singapore partners Dow to give 300,000 pairs of used shoes new lease of life
summary: Sport Singapore has partnered with Dow to collect 300,000 pairs of used shoes and upcycle them into new sports infrastructure, such as jogging tracks and playgrounds, over the next three years. The project aims to reduce textile and leather waste and promote sustainability in sports. The collected shoes will be ground into rubber granules and used to build the sport infrastructure, partially replacing recycled tyres. The initiative demonstrates a circular economy approach to address environmental concerns, with only 4% of textile and leather waste recycled in 2019.

site_title: 15 new coronavirus cases in Singapore, none in community
summary: Singapore reported 15 new coronavirus cases, bringing the total to 57,700. None of the new cases were community cases, with all 15 being imported cases. Five of the imported cases were placed on 14-day stay-home notice upon arrival. The number of unlinked community cases remains stable, averaging fewer than one case per day. 57,344 patients have recovered, and 25 remain in hospital, with 274 recuperating in community facilities.

site_title: UK's tighter Covid-19 restrictions may keep economy depressed
summary: The UK government's new job support scheme may not be enough to counteract the impact of tighter Covid-19 restrictions, which could keep the economy depressed and unemployment on the rise. The Bank of England is expected to boost the money supply further to support businesses and workers. Economists predict a 7% unemployment rate and a £370 billion debt in the 2020-2021 fiscal year, with the pound falling 5.3% from its early-September highs and the FTSE 100 down 26% from its pre-Covid-19 highs.

site_title: Danske scandal reveals top-down culture that silenced bankers
summary: Danske Bank, Europe's largest money laundering scandal, has yet to fully address its top-down corporate culture issues, according to Denmark's financial watchdog. The bank's management had been cut off from staff, leading to a culture where employees felt compelled to flag mistakes and speak up. Danske has implemented initiatives to correct the culture, including allowing employees to report irregularities more easily. However, employee morale remains low due to concerns over job cuts and a risk of being branded as "troublesome" for speaking up.

site_title: Addvalue's private placements issued at lower than market price prompts shareholders' queries
summary: MAINBOARD-listed Addvalue Technologies has issued private placements at lower than market prices, prompting shareholder queries. The company cited the speed and certainty of private placements compared to rights issues, which may take up to six months to conclude. Addvalue also noted its human-centric business model and lack of tangible assets, making it challenging to secure financial institutional backing. The company will consider a rights issue if market conditions permit.

site_title: European airlines cutting fares to woo back passengers
summary: European airlines are cutting fares to attract passengers and fill planes as travel restrictions and quarantine measures hinder air traffic. Fares were reduced by 15% in August compared to last year, with some routes seeing discounts of over 33%. Airlines are also focusing on profitable routes and promoting offers to stimulate traffic. However, the reimposition of restrictions could undo efforts, and consumers remain cautious about travel plans.

site_title: Shareholders raise queries over acquisition of Thye Hong Centre by Lian Beng's unit
summary: Lian Beng's unit SLB Development acquired Thye Hong Centre for S$112.5 million, sparking concerns about the company's ability to resume distributing dividends due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Lian Beng stated it will consider resuming dividends when operations generate sufficient cash and profit. The company is also facing challenges in the UK hospitality sector and expects further delays in the construction of Defu Industrial City. Shares fell 1.3% on Friday amidst uncertainty over the group's financial performance.

site_title: UK pubs count cost of an hour as curfew batters bruised bars
summary: The UK government has enforced a nationwide 10pm curfew for bars and restaurants, forcing establishments to close at 9:30pm to reduce gatherings and slow the spread of COVID-19. This move is expected to devastate the struggling pub industry, which has already seen a decline in sales and profits since the pandemic. The curfew will cut into the pubs' most profitable hours, with some managers estimating a loss of several million pounds per week. The industry's woes are compounded by the ongoing impact of Brexit on staffing and market values.

site_title: Japan's chipmaker Kioxia to scrap IPO plan as Sino-US tensions rise: Nikkei Business
summary: Japan's chipmaker Kioxia Holdings is scrapping plans for an initial public offering (IPO) due to rising tensions between China and the US. The decision comes after Kioxia set a tentative price range for the IPO, which was lower than the market value at which Bain Capital led the company's acquisition two years ago. The move is seen as a response to tighter US restrictions on Huawei Technologies, which could lead to oversupply and lower market prices in the memory chip market.

site_title: Has coffee been grounded?
summary: Brazil's Arabica coffee prices have fallen for eight consecutive days, marking the longest losing streak in three years. The price drop, from 123.05 cents/pound to 110.50 cents/pound, is attributed to a bumper crop, favorable weather, and increased production. The weak Brazilian real has also incentivized producers and traders to sell overseas. A symmetrical triangle formation suggests that the market is waiting for a potential breakout, with prices potentially rebounding to 113.10 cents/pound or higher. Concerns over the coronavirus pandemic and a surplus supply in agricultural commodities may further impact demand.

site_title: Synagie Corporation seeks opportunities to expand insurtech business
summary: Synagie Corporation, a Catalist-listed insurtech company, is seeking opportunities to expand its business. The company is in advanced discussions to bundle its accidental damage protection solutions with laptop and tablet tenders and to offer laptops on a Device-as-a-Service basis to small and medium-sized enterprises in Singapore. Additionally, Synagie is exploring partnerships to expand distribution channels for its mobile phone screen protection insurance products and offer extended warranty solutions. The company had previously announced plans to dispose of its e-commerce business for S$61.7 million to focus on its insurtech business.

site_title: Three dead in fire at Huawei campus in southern China
summary: A fire at an unfinished Huawei research facility in southern China's Dongguan city has resulted in the deaths of three people. The blaze occurred at a building under construction, which was intended to be a research base for the tech giant. All construction workers were initially evacuated, but a thorough search by firefighters later found three employees of the industrial park management company dead inside the building. The cause of the fire is under investigation.

site_title: Alphabet settles shareholder suits over sexual harassment claims
summary: Alphabet, the parent company of Google, has settled shareholder lawsuits over its handling of sexual harassment claims, agreeing to greater oversight by its board of directors and committing $310 million over the next decade to corporate diversity programs. The settlement also ends forced arbitration in individual cases of sexual harassment or assault and limits confidentiality restrictions when settling harassment and discrimination cases. Additionally, Alphabet will ban workplace romances between managers and subordinates and provide regular reports on the compensation of senior executives found to have engaged in serious misconduct.

site_title: Ex-Audi boss to stand trial for 'dieselgate'
summary: Former Audi CEO Rupert Stadler, 57, stands trial in Munich for his role in the "dieselgate" emissions scandal, five years after Volkswagen admitted installing cheating software in 11 million diesel engines. Stadler faces charges of fraud, falsifying certifications, and false advertising. He denies the accusations, and the trial is expected to run until December 2022, with defendants potentially facing up to 10 years in prison if convicted.

site_title: Opec turns 60 at 'critical moment' for virus-hit oil
summary: Opec, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, marks its 60th anniversary at a critical moment due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on crude demand and prices. The cartel, which currently comprises 13 members, faces challenges from discord among its members, threats from cleaner fuels, and the rise of the US as the world's largest oil producer. Despite losing market share, Opec still has a significant role to play due to its control over accessible crude and lower carbon emissions. Its ability to steer the oil market remains relevant, but its influence has diminished in recent years.

site_title: ShopBack and RedDoorz investigating data breaches
summary: ShopBack and RedDoorz are investigating data breaches that may have compromised customer personal data. ShopBack confirmed unauthorised access to its systems, but stated passwords are encrypted and credit card information is safe. RedDoorz found a breach in one of its IT databases, with no sensitive financial data compromised. Both companies are enhancing security measures and notifying affected customers. Singapore's Personal Data Protection Commission is also involved in the investigations, amid growing concerns over data protection and cybersecurity practices in the tech industry.

site_title: Pushan,11, shows his talent at Mandai
summary: 11-year-old Pushan Reddy Vutukur, from Singapore, showcased his talent at Mandai, finishing third in the swing competition. This marks a significant improvement from his ninth-place finish six months ago, which gave him the confidence to continue playing.

site_title: Teho's independent director assisting with CAD's investigations involving New Silkroutes
summary: Independent director Kelvyn Oo of Teho Intl is assisting the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) in investigations into New Silkroutes Group, a health-care provider. The CAD is looking into a possible offence under Chapter 289 of the Securities and Futures Act. Oo, formerly New Silkroutes' executive director, left the company on August 1 to pursue other opportunities. Teho Intl stated that Oo's assistance in the investigation does not compromise his duties as an independent director, and the company's business and operations are unaffected.

site_title: China says WHO gave blessing for coronavirus vaccine emergency use programme
summary: China launched its emergency COVID-19 vaccine program in July, with the World Health Organization (WHO) reportedly giving its blessing for the move. Despite ongoing Phase 3 clinical trials, hundreds of thousands of essential workers and high-risk individuals have been vaccinated, raising concerns about efficacy and safety.

site_title: Wariness among Reit managers, trustees as contentious merger proposals move forward
summary: Reit managers and trustees are wary of proposed mergers, citing concerns about conflicts of interest and unitholder support. The merger between CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) and CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) has been announced despite initial confusion over its nature. In contrast, the merger between Sabana Reit and ESR-Reit is expected to face opposition from minority investors who claim the consideration offered is a steep discount. Meanwhile, an annual report addendum for Sabana Reit revealed the manager's independent director had previously received payments from a related company, sparking calls for further regulatory oversight.

site_title: Commerzbank poaches Deutsche Bank senior exec as new CEO
summary: Commerzbank has appointed Manfred Knof, head of Deutsche Bank's retail business in Germany, as its new CEO, effective January 1. Knof succeeds Martin Zielke, who resigned amid a revolt by Cerberus, a private equity investor. The move allows Commerzbank to implement a new strategic plan, which includes branch closures and staff reductions to save costs. Chairman Hans-Joerg Vetter stated that the bank is not a "restructuring case" but must become more efficient. The appointment follows months of turmoil and comes as Commerzbank and Deutsche Bank had previously been in merger talks that were called off.

site_title: Epic Games battles to get Fortnite back in App Store
summary: Epic Games is attempting to get Fortnite back on Apple's App Store after being removed due to a dispute over the 30% commission fee Apple charges for transactions. The tech giant is challenging Apple's practice, which also affects other app developers, and has formed a coalition with other major app makers to push for new terms. A federal judge will hear the case on Monday, which may determine whether Fortnite will be restored to the App Store.

images.alt_text: Epic Games will strive anew Monday to convince a judge that its hit title Fortnite should be restored to Apple's App Store, despite sidestepping the tech titan's standard commission on transactions.

site_title: Robert Gore, inventor of Gore-Tex, dead at 83
summary: Robert Gore, inventor of Gore-Tex, died on September 17 at 83, due to cancer. His accidental invention of Gore-Tex in 1969, created while trying to make plumber's tape, led to a billion-dollar material used in various applications. Gore's work as a chemical engineer at W.L. Gore & Associates was marked by a failure that ultimately led to his groundbreaking discovery.

site_title: Trump picks Barrett as he moves to tilt US Supreme Court rightward
summary: President Donald Trump nominated Amy Coney Barrett, 48, to the US Supreme Court, setting the stage for a rightward shift of the top US judicial body. Barrett, a devout Roman Catholic and conservative, has pledged to become a justice in the mold of Antonin Scalia. If confirmed, she would become the fifth woman on the court and push the conservative majority to 6-3, potentially curbing abortion rights, expanding religious rights, and striking down gun control laws. Senate Republicans are expected to quickly confirm her, with hearings set to begin on October 12.

site_title: Startup Hims nears a deal to go public via Oaktree SPAC
summary: Hims Inc, a Silicon Valley telemedicine company, is nearing a deal to go public through a merger with Oaktree Acquisition, a blank-cheque company. The deal could value Hims at about $1.6 billion, with Oaktree raising $75 million to fund the transaction. Hims, known for online prescriptions for conditions like hair loss and erectile dysfunction, has raised $197 million from investors and expanded into urgent care and mental-health services during the pandemic. The deal, if finalized, would be the latest startup to go public through a SPAC, following property startup Opendoor's $4.8 billion merger earlier this month.

site_title: Anwar power grab bid adds to risks besieging Malaysian assets
summary: Malaysia's markets are facing turbulence amid a power grab bid by opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim, who claims enough lawmaker support to form a government. Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin rejects the assertion, raising the odds for early polls and disrupting stimulus policies. The country's benchmark equity index has retreated 6% since hitting its year-to-date high, and the ringgit has weakened in September. The king is set to play a key role in resolving the crisis, and investors are concerned about the impact on economic policies and the global recovery.

site_title: Australia PM on not sharing vaccine: History will be 'severe judge'
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison emphasized the importance of sharing COVID-19 vaccines globally, warning that history will judge nations that don't cooperate. In a UN message, Morrison stated that whoever develops a vaccine must share it, calling it a "global responsibility." He also voiced support for the Covax initiative, which aims to distribute 2 billion doses by late 2021. Morrison's stance contrasts with the US, China, and Russia, which have resisted global efforts to collaborate on a vaccine.

images.alt_text: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison on Friday insisted that any nation that develops a Covid-19 vaccine share it universally, warning that history will be a "severe judge" if not.

site_title: Japan is paying firms to make things at home. But China's pull is still strong
summary: Japan is providing $23 million in government subsidies to encourage domestic production of goods, particularly masks, as the country seeks to diversify its supply chains from China amid the pandemic. The move aims to reduce reliance on China, which has locked down factories and commandeered supplies, and follows years of stop-and-go efforts. Despite growing concerns about doing business in China, many Japanese companies remain committed to the market due to its enormous size, cheap labor, and efficient infrastructure. Japan is instead focusing on managing the risk of its relationship with China through diplomatic channels and incentives for domestic production.

site_title: Facebook gets reprieve from Apple on live events cut
summary: Facebook has struck a deal with Apple, temporarily waiving the 30% commission on revenue from paid events on the iOS platform until the end of the year. This move aims to help pandemic-hit performers earn money during the pandemic. Gaming creators, however, will still be required to use Apple's payment system. The reprieve is seen as a win for Facebook, but the issue remains a point of contention between Apple and other app developers who argue the commission is an abuse of its position.

site_title: Mitsubishi to cut 500-600 jobs to reduce costs: source
summary: Mitsubishi Motors plans to cut 500-600 jobs, mostly management employees, through voluntary retirement in Japan to reduce costs. The move is part of a restructuring plan to cut 20% of fixed costs by shrinking workforce and production. The company expects a net loss of 360 billion yen (S$4.7 billion) in the financial year to March 2021, hurt by the coronavirus pandemic and falling sales in key markets. This is the latest step in Mitsubishi's efforts to address declining sales and profitability.

images.alt_text: Mitsubishi Motors will seek voluntary retirement from 500 to 600 employees, mostly in management, in Japan from mid-November to cut costs, two sources familiar with the matter told Reuters on Saturday.

site_title: Oil falls on mounting Covid-19 cases, supply concerns
summary: Oil prices fell over 2% on the week due to a surge in Covid-19 cases globally and rising oil supply. Brent crude futures settled at $41.92 a barrel, down 2 cents, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures dropped 6 cents to $40.25 a barrel. The US is seeing a rise in infections, with over 200,000 deaths, and fuel consumption remains sluggish. Global supply is expected to increase in coming weeks, with Libyan production and Iranian oil exports rising, further pressuring prices.

site_title: Japan PM Suga 'determined' to hold Olympics despite pandemic
summary: Japan's newly elected Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga has stated his determination to host the postponed 2021 Tokyo Olympics despite the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. Suga said the Games will be safe and secure, with measures such as rigorous testing and potentially mandatory vaccinations planned. Despite concerns from medical experts and waning enthusiasm in Japan, organizers are working to make the event possible. The postponement has also created logistical headaches and extra costs, with cost-saving measures being considered.

site_title: Reits (September 26-27, 2020)
summary: Realtors in Singapore reported a surge in demand for prime projects above the S$3,000 per square foot (psf) benchmark, driven by a Q3 wave of condo launches. In contrast, US mortgage rates climbed for the first time in five weeks, while UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high. Manhattan rents reached another record, with further increases expected. WeWork secured new tenants and filled more space at its Singapore location, and New World is selling China property assets after a loan deal. Goldman Sachs also acquired a significant hotel and retail portfolio in Seoul.

site_title: Ex-Deutsche Bank gold traders found guilty in spoofing trial
summary: Former Deutsche Bank traders Cedric Chanu and James Vorley were convicted of fraud for manipulating gold and silver prices through "spoofing" between 2008 and 2013. The traders placed bogus trade orders, cancelling them before execution, to mislead other traders and influence prices. Chanu was found guilty on seven counts, while Vorley was convicted on three. Sentencing is set for January 21, with both men facing up to 30 years in prison, but the government is expected to seek around four or five years.

site_title: Rocked by allegations, Novena Global Healthcare board takes over running of firm from Loh cousins
summary: Novena Global Healthcare Group's board has taken control of the firm after allegations surfaced about forged audit signatures and concerns over the company's accounts. The board, comprising of four directors excluding the Loh cousins, is led by Sinopharm Capital and other investors. The move comes amid investigations into the Lohs' business dealings, including a police report filed by Ernst & Young alleging unauthorized use of signatures on NGHG's financial statements. The board plans to appoint solicitors and cooperate with authorities investigating the allegations.

site_title: US maintains plan for TikTok download ban; court to rule
summary: The US government maintains its plan to ban new downloads of TikTok, a move that could be challenged in court. US District Judge Carl Nichols is set to rule on TikTok's request to block the order, which would take effect at 11:59pm on Sunday. The ban, announced by President Donald Trump, is aimed at addressing national security concerns, but TikTok argues it could cause irreparable harm to its 100 million US users. A tentative deal to transfer ownership of TikTok to a new entity, including Oracle and Walmart, has been proposed, but its status remains unclear.

site_title: Playing pros take to part-time teaching during barren spell
summary: Singapore professional golfers are taking part-time teaching jobs during the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the Asian Tour and Asian Development Tour schedules. The difficult patch has prompted flexible arrangements for the golfers, who are trying to make ends meet.

site_title: Japan's Suga makes fresh pitch for meeting with Kim Jong Un
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga declared his willingness to meet North Korea's Kim Jong-Un without preconditions, aiming to normalize ties by resolving nuclear and abduction issues. Suga emphasized the importance of establishing a constructive relationship for regional peace and stability. His remarks, recorded a week earlier, showcased continuity with his predecessor Shinzo Abe's policy, who also offered to meet Kim with little success. Suga vowed to prioritize human development and tackle the coronavirus pandemic, including offering loans to developing countries.

images.alt_text: Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga declared his willingness to meet North Korea's Kim Jong-Un without preconditions, affirming the policy of his predecessor in his debut speech to the United Nations.

site_title: Chanel's green bond comes with penalty if targets missed
summary: Chanel has issued a 600 million-euro green bond, linked to environmental sustainability targets, marking a significant move by the luxury brand to demonstrate its commitment to reducing carbon emissions. The bond includes penalties for missing targets, avoiding "greenwashing" criticism. Chanel achieved "carbon-neutral" status last year and is now seeking to refinance £600 million of Covid loans. The bond has been well-received, with demand nearly three times the deal size, and is considered investment-grade.

site_title: Old sins cast long shadows at China Environment
summary: The Singapore bourse regulator, SGX RegCo, has publicly reprimanded China Environment and its former executives over false statements and disclosure failures in its FY2013 and FY2014 annual reports. The reprimand cited non-existent trade receivables and an undisclosed corporate guarantee for a 20 million yuan loan. Former executives, including Huang Min, Wu Jida, and Chiar Choon Teck, have been reprimanded for failing to demonstrate character and integrity. This comes after China Environment shares were suspended since June 2016.

site_title: UK pledges over 340 million pounds for WHO, calls for end to 'ugly rifts'
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson will pledge a 30% increase in funding for the World Health Organization (WHO), totaling over 340 million pounds. He will also call for reforms to the global health body and revive cross-border cooperation to end "ugly rifts." Johnson will present a five-point plan to improve the international response to future pandemics, citing the Covid-19 pandemic as a catalyst for increased trade barriers.

site_title: Used-clothing platform Poshmark says it filed to go public
summary: Poshmark, an online resale marketplace for second-hand clothing, has filed confidentially for an initial public offering (IPO). The California-based company had previously put off a potential IPO to focus on boosting sales and improving execution. The IPO details, including the number of shares and price range, have not been determined. This marks Poshmark's return to the public market after initially considering an IPO last September.

site_title: Income investors must be on the right side of change
summary: Income investors must shift their focus from traditional value or growth stocks to fundamental business characteristics, such as cash-generative businesses with strong balance sheets. Despite the COVID-19 disruption, the fundamental objective of income investing remains relevant, offering attractive returns in low-interest-rate environments. However, maintaining discipline on valuation is crucial to avoid overpaying for desirable characteristics. As the market continues to rise, investors must remain focused on sustainable dividend growth and balance sheet strength. Discipline on valuation and a long-term perspective are key to unlocking wealth creation in the current market environment.

site_title: Help for Singapore food manufacturers to go digital
summary: Enterprise Singapore (ESG) and FairPrice have launched YummySG!, an online initiative to help Singapore food manufacturers diversify their revenue streams. The platform, hosted on FairPrice Online, brings together local products under the Singapore brand to increase visibility and differentiate them from other products. Participating companies can list new products, reach 1.5 million shoppers, and benefit from increased marketing efforts and data sharing. ESG will also provide support in product development, packaging design, and retail strategies. Several companies, including Chocoworks and Thong Siek Food Industry, have already joined the initiative.

site_title: Europe: Consumer stocks help UK shares end harsh week higher
summary: UK shares ended a tumultuous week on a high note, outperforming European peers, after a near 44% surge in bookmaker William Hill on takeover offers. Apollo and Caesars Entertainment made undisclosed offers for the British betting firm, lifting consumer stocks and the mid-caps index 1.4% higher. The FTSE 100 index rose 0.3%, while the pan-European STOXX 600 index declined 0.1%. The moves countered fading hopes of economic recovery and uncertainty surrounding Brexit and COVID-19 restrictions.

site_title: Corporate real estate investors refocusing strategies
summary: Corporate real estate investors are shifting their strategies due to the pandemic's impact on office spaces. Investment volume declined 29% globally to $321 billion in the first six months of 2020. The shift to remote work and increasing demand for sustainable and tech-equipped offices are driving these changes. Investors must now meet occupiers' complex demands, leading to a reevaluation of their property portfolios. This adjustment is expected to continue as the pandemic's effects on the economy persist.

site_title: Safeguards to prevent abuse of tourism voucher scheme
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) is implementing safeguards to prevent abuse of the SingapoRediscovers Vouchers, a S$320 million tourism voucher scheme aimed at supporting the industry. The vouchers, worth S$100 each, will be distributed through the SingPass system and have clear expiry dates to minimize potential savings. Experts warn of risks of abuse, including misuse as alternative sources of money, business owners taking kickbacks, and inflation of prices. The STB is working with government agencies to develop necessary safeguards, including data analytics and surprise audits, to address potential fraud and resale.

site_title: American Air gets US$5.48b loan in upsized deal
summary: American Airlines has secured a US$5.48 billion loan from the US Treasury, increasing its cash pool to support operations until travel demand returns. The loan, backed by the airline's loyalty program, was initially set at US$4.75 billion but was upsized after rivals opted out. This deal makes American the first major carrier to tap US loans included in the US$2 trillion Cares Act for economic relief from the coronavirus pandemic. The loan carries an interest rate of around 3.5 percentage points above the London Interbank Offered Rate.

site_title: MOH, MAS to tighten watch on IP insurers over unfair claim rejections
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) and Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will increase surveillance on integrated shield plan (IP) insurers to prevent unfair claims assessments. Following Aviva Singapore's decision to stop claims for diagnostic endoscopies, MOH and MAS clarified that policy holders would not receive lower payouts than those covered by MediShield Life (MSHL). The agencies will enhance surveillance efforts, provide guidance on medical necessity, and require insurers to follow policy terms and conditions. Insurers found to have unfair practices will face action, including fines.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: iFast Corp plans to launch a private fund manager business in China by early next year. Boldtek Holdings has requested extra time to issue its annual report and hold its AGM due to audit delays. Geo Energy Resources is involved in a lawsuit in Indonesia related to a bid to buy a company. Memiontec Holdings secured three new contracts worth S$17.8 million, bringing its order book to S$65 million.

site_title: I am always competitive, whether it is social or business golf
summary: There is no article provided for me to summarize. The given text appears to be a collection of news article titles and publication dates, but no article content is provided.

site_title: Malaysia power struggle could drag on as king recuperates in hospital
summary: Malaysia's King Sultan Abdullah is under observation at a hospital for a week, delaying a potential meeting with opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim to form a new government. Anwar claims a "strong, formidable" majority, but the king's decision to cancel their scheduled meeting leaves the outcome uncertain. Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin has dismissed Anwar's claims, challenging him to prove it through a constitutional process. The power struggle comes as the country struggles to stabilize its economy after the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: US August new-home sales at its highest since 2006
summary: US new-home sales surged 4.8% in August to the highest level in 14 years, driven by low borrowing costs and a desire for new homes amid the pandemic. The median selling price decreased to $312,800, and the number of homes for sale dropped to an almost three-year low. Sales have increased 77% in the last four months, with the South region leading the way. The housing market momentum is expected to be short-lived due to job cuts and potential future aid package issues.

site_title: Are you getting the best deal from your investment manager?
summary: A potential conflict of interest arises when an investment manager recommends a service provider, potentially receiving a referral fee, which may not be in the best interest of the client. The CFA Institute requires investment professionals to disclose referral fees to their employer, clients, and prospective clients. In a case study, a portfolio manager's arrangement with a small broker/dealer is undisclosed, violating the Referral Fees Standard. Both parties involved benefit from the arrangement, but clients may not receive the best services, highlighting the need for transparency and disclosure.

site_title: Open banking a bigger threat to Singapore banks than digital entrants: report
summary: A report by DBS Group Research suggests that open banking in Singapore may pose a bigger threat to traditional banks than digital entrants. Open banking enables consumers to aggregate and compare information across institutions on a single platform, potentially disrupting the banking industry. Digital banks, on the other hand, face challenges in acquiring and developing customer stickiness to turn a profit, given Singapore's relatively well-banked population. A platform-based lending model, where digital banks act as a platform to connect customers to various financial providers, is likely to deliver higher profitability and scalability.

images.alt_text: Ant Group's funds are from other financial institutions and it merely serves as a lending platform with a credit scoring system based on alternative data analytics and an internal credit score.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Dow extend longest losing spree in a year
summary: US stocks, including the S&P 500 and Dow, opened lower on Friday, extending their longest losing streak in a year. Fears over the economy's future, still dominated by the coronavirus, weighed on investor sentiment. The Dow Jones fell 0.45% and the S&P 500 0.31%, while the Nasdaq Composite gained 0.08%. The losses mark the longest losing streak in a year for the S&P 500 and the Dow.

site_title: FCT provides updates on portfolio tenants' sales, shopper traffic and asset valuation
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) reported a 2.2% year-on-year decline in portfolio tenants' sales in August 2020, while shopper traffic fell 36.4% from the previous year. The trust's portfolio includes several retail properties, with the latest valuations approved by its board of directors. FCT plans to acquire the remaining 63.1% of AsiaRetail Fund for $1.06 billion, raising up to $1.39 billion in equity to fund the acquisition.

images.alt_text: FCT's portfolio includes Causeway Point, Northpoint City North Wing (including Yishun 10 retail podium), Waterway Point, Changi City Point, YewTee Point, Bedok Point and Anchorpoint.

site_title: Southern Alliance Mining full-year profit tumbles 30% to RM62.1m on tax expenses
summary: Southern Alliance Mining (SAM) reported a 30% decline in full-year net profit to RM62.1 million, driven by tax expenses. Revenue rose 34% to RM254.2 million, largely due to increased sales volume and higher selling prices. The company attributed the positive revenue growth to the dynamic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the iron ore price. SAM has proposed a final dividend of 0.6 Singapore cent per share for fiscal 2020, subject to shareholder approval.

site_title: Exxon narrows bidders for US$3b assets in Malaysia
summary: ExxonMobil has narrowed the list of bidders for its US$2-3 billion oil-producing assets in Malaysia, with UK-listed EnQuest and Kuala Lumpur-traded Hibiscus Petroleum among the chosen companies. The US oil major started the process to sell its Malaysian assets last year as part of its global divestiture programme. The assets include a 30% stake in the offshore Tapis Blend operations and production sharing contracts covering 2.4 million acres offshore. Deliberations are ongoing, and representatives for the companies involved have declined to comment.

site_title: Singapore industrial output up a surprise 13.7% in August
summary: Singapore's industrial output surged 13.7% in August, exceeding expectations of 2.2% growth and marking the first expansion after three months of contraction. The electronics cluster drove the growth, with output rising 44.2% year-over-year, while the precision engineering and biomedical clusters also saw significant increases. Economists are optimistic about manufacturing, with full-year growth expected to reach 2.5%, driven by strong demand for semiconductors and IT equipment.

site_title: 'Can't lose' trades falter with inflation expectations flagging
summary: US inflation expectations have faltered, casting doubt on the sustained economic recovery. Despite unprecedented Federal Reserve stimulus and a $2 trillion federal spending package, prices have not risen as expected. This shift may impact asset diversification and dollar-denominated investments. As a result, investors are now looking for alternative safe havens, and Asia is expected to drive growth in dollar-denominated assets.

site_title: The next financial crisis may be coming soon
summary: A new financial crisis may be looming, with 20% of global businesses surveyed by Oxford Economics citing a 20% probability of a financial crisis over the next two years. This fear is fueled by high leverage in the financial sector, making it difficult to predict the scale of eventual credit losses from the ongoing pandemic. While central banks have pledged to intervene, the risk of a credit crunch is still a concern, with banks facing increased stress and potential solvency issues, particularly in countries with weaker financial systems.

site_title: Pine Capital about to lose listing sponsor
summary: Pine Capital, a Catalist-listed investment firm, is set to lose its listing sponsor on September 27 due to compliance concerns. The board is in talks with potential new sponsors, but warns that the process may take up to a month. The firm's compliance issues have led to Asian Corporate Advisors terminating its sponsorship, effective the end of the month.

site_title: Tech shares lead as US stocks end week on positive note
summary: US stocks ended the week on a positive note, with tech shares leading the market higher. The Nasdaq Composite Index rose 2.3% to 10,913.56, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 gained 1.3% and 1.6% respectively. Despite lackluster economic data, investors remained optimistic, with tech shares driving the gains.

images.alt_text: Despite lackluster economic data, Wall Street stocks posted their best session of the week on Friday, with tech shares leading the market higher.

site_title: Studying the hard truth about luck
summary: A psychologist and sociology professors suggest that college admissions may need to be reevaluated to bring fairness to the education system. A lottery system could be implemented, where applicants are selected at random, rather than relying on standardized tests and competition. This idea is based on the concept of luck and the fact that many successful individuals attribute their achievements to luck rather than hard work. Research in Singapore found that students attribute their success to luck, despite having attended elite schools and having a strong academic background. The solution acknowledges the existence of luck and promotes empathy, rather than perpetuating the idea that hard work alone determines success.

site_title: Police probe New Silkroutes over possible Securities and Futures Act breach
summary: New Silkroutes Group, a health-care provider listed on the Mainboard, is under police investigation for a possible breach of the Securities and Futures Act. The Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) has requested information and documents, and the company will cooperate fully. One director, senior management, and former executives are assisting the investigation. The probe is not expected to affect the company's operations or management. New Silkroutes' business will continue as usual, and the company will provide updates on the matter as significant developments occur.

site_title: FTSE Russell says China to be included in global bond index
summary: FTSE Russell has announced that China's sovereign bonds will be included in its global bond index, starting in October 2021. This move is seen as a milestone, increasing foreign investment in China's bond market, which is expected to attract $140 billion in inflows. The inclusion marks a significant shift, with China being viewed as a developed market rather than an emerging one. This decision is expected to boost the yuan, with the currency having surged 3.6% this quarter, and will also impact China's benchmark CSI 300 Index.

images.alt_text: The inclusion gives foreign investors yet another way to invest in Chinese debt, and should prompt inflows into the world's second-largest bond market.

site_title: Strength in the dollar pushes gold lower
summary: The gold market declined this week due to the US dollar's strength, with gold futures falling to two-month lows. The decline was fueled by the Federal Open Market Committee's lack of new stimulus measures and the European Central Bank's liquidity provision to European banks. However, gold prices received a boost from unexpected US weekly initial unemployment claims and efforts by US lawmakers to agree on a fiscal stimulus. Despite central banks maintaining dovish stances, gold prices are expected to remain elevated due to ongoing Covid-19 spread and heightened global tensions.

site_title: STI closes higher on unexpected strength of factory output
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.88% on Friday, driven by a surprise surge in factory output, which exceeded expectations with a 13.7% year-on-year increase in August. The Straits Times Index (STI) climbed to 2,472.28 points. Market strategist Geoff Howie attributed the gains to renewed hopes for US fiscal stimulus ahead of the presidential election. Despite weaker Europe, Singapore's industrial production numbers held ground, boosting key cyclicals.

site_title: AnAn International unit to take majority stake in French heating system installer
summary: AnAn International, a Singapore-based fuel oil trader, is acquiring a 70% stake in French heating system installer SARL ANEO for 2.31 million euros (S$3.7 million). The deal, part of AnAn's five-year strategic plan, aims to expand the company's knowledge in the energy sector. The seller will receive an earn-out of up to 280,000 euros if certain financial thresholds are met. The transaction is expected to narrow AnAn's loss per share.

site_title: Evergrande gets nod from Hong Kong Exchange to spin off management unit
summary: Evergrande Group, a Chinese developer, has received approval from the Hong Kong stock exchange to spin off its property management unit. The move aims to raise $1 billion to $2 billion in capital, helping the company replenish its finances after facing a cash crunch. The unit, valued at $11 billion, will file a listing application in the coming weeks. This restructuring comes as strategic investors demand $19 billion in January if Evergrande cannot complete a targeted listing in China.

site_title: MNACT expands investment mandate, acquires 50% stake in Seoul office building
summary: MAPLETREE North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) is acquiring a 50% stake in Pinnacle Gangnam, a 20-storey office building in Seoul's Gangnam business district, for 228.9 billion Korean won (S$267.6 million). The acquisition is expected to raise MNACT's distribution-per-unit (DPU) by 0.4% and net property income (NPI) yield. The property has a gross floor area of 44,444 sq m and an occupancy rate of 89.6%. The acquisition is expected to enhance MNACT's geographical and income diversification and provide greater stability in the long term.

site_title: OK Lim slapped with second charge of abetting Hin Leong worker in forgery
summary: Singapore tycoon OK Lim, founder of oil trader Hin Leong Trading, has been charged with a second count of abetting forgery, carrying a mandatory 10-year jail term. The latest charge alleges Lim instigated an employee to create a false email and forged Inter-Tank Transfer certificate to secure over US$56 million in trade financing. Lim faces additional charges, and police investigations will be completed before the case's next hearing on November 23. Lim is out on bail of S$3 million.

site_title: Nadal's Parisian procession threatened by long lay-off
summary: Rafael Nadal is set to compete in the rescheduled French Open, but his long lay-off due to the COVID-19 pandemic has raised concerns about his form. The 12-time winner has only played three matches in the last six months, and his shock quarter-final defeat to Diego Schwartzman hinted at rustiness. Despite this, Nadal is considered a clear favourite for the men's singles title, with Dominic Thiem and Novak Djokovic also vying for the championship. Meanwhile, Simona Halep is the top contender in the women's draw, with Serena Williams and Garbine Muguruza also in contention.

site_title: Ant Group launches blockchain trade platform with bank partners
summary: Ant Group has launched Trusple, a blockchain trade platform in partnership with major banks, including DBS, StanChart, BNP Paribas, Citibank, and Deutsche Bank. The platform uses blockchain technology to facilitate trade and trade financing, enhancing transparency in complex supply chains. Member banks will offer payment guarantees, while financing banks will automatically dispatch payments upon buyer acknowledgement. This aims to improve digital trade processes for corporates, especially small- and medium-sized enterprises, and mitigate the risk of late payments.

site_title: Singapore and Japan launch travel lane for business professionals
summary: Singapore and Japan have launched a "residence track" for business professionals, allowing work pass holders to travel between the two countries without a controlled itinerary. This new travel lane, which was previously only available for short-term and essential business, aims to facilitate more frequent travel between the two nations. The new arrangement is subject to safeguards, including a 14-day quarantine period, and will be made available on the websites of the two countries' ministries of foreign affairs by September 30.

images.alt_text: More business executives and professionals will now be able to travel between Singapore and Japan, using a new "residence track" announced by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MFA) on Friday.

site_title: Free the Apps!
summary: Apple's 30% commission on app store transactions is at the center of a federal court hearing, potentially sparking a protracted fight over app store operations. The commission, affecting a minority of apps, discourages smaller developers from applying to the store. Epic Games' lawsuit against Apple and Google over fees has raised concerns about the company's market dominance. A judge will consider whether to compel Apple to allow Fortnite back into the App Store, with estimates suggesting Apple collects $15-19 billion annually in fees from the App Store.

site_title: Singapore Exchange to delist China Great Land, as listing transfer plan goes nowhere
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has decided to delist China Great Land Holdings, a cash company under judicial management since May 2019, due to a failed listing transfer plan. The company must propose an exit offer within a month. The SGX rejected multiple applications for the transfer and flagged concerns about the suitability of Singapore Edutainment Associates Global, the proposed new listing entity. Trading in China Great Land shares was suspended in July 2018. The company must now inform the SGX of its planned exit offer and provide updates.

site_title: Evergrande gets Hong Kong exchange nod to spin off management unit
summary: China Evergrande Group has received approval from the Hong Kong Stock Exchange to spin off its property management unit, paving the way for a potential $1 billion to $2 billion capital raise. The move aims to replenish the company's finances, which are under pressure due to a $19 billion debt repayment deadline to strategic investors. The property management unit, valued at $11 billion, offers a stable business model with recurring fee revenue and low leverage, making it attractive to investors. The spin-off could help Evergrande reduce its net debt to equity ratio.

site_title: China says annual production capacity of virus vaccine to reach 610m
summary: China's Covid-19 vaccine development programme is in a "leading position" and aims to reach an annual production capacity of over 600 million doses by the end of 2020 and at least 1 billion doses annually next year.

site_title: Boeing 737 MAX could get EU clearance 'by year's end'
summary: The European Union's air safety chief, Patrick Ky, announced that Boeing's 737 MAX airliner may receive certification to fly again in Europe by the end of the year. The aircraft has been grounded for 18 months following two deadly accidents in Indonesia and Ethiopia, resulting in 346 fatalities. Despite initial hurdles, Ky expressed optimism about overcoming the remaining challenges, including pilot training, and obtaining approval from the US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) and individual nations. This would mark a significant step towards the 737 MAX's return to service.

images.alt_text: Boeing's troubled 737 MAX airliner, grounded for 18 months after two deadly accidents, could receive certification to fly again in Europe "by the end of the year", the European Union's air safety chief said Friday.

site_title: Long-stop date for Artivision Tech reverse takeover pushed back to end-2020
summary: Artivision Technologies, a Catalist-listed video solutions provider, has pushed back the long-stop date for its planned reverse takeover (RTO) deal with Mobile Credit Payment to December 31, 2020. The deal, announced in May 2018, involves Artivision giving up a 70% stake in exchange for MC Payment's electronic payment and online retail business. The company has until February 28, 2021, to complete the transaction and meet requirements for a new listing on the Singapore bourse. The board reports good progress in the due-diligence exercise and will provide updates to shareholders.

site_title: Citadel Securities doubled profit as dominance grew in wild 2020
summary: Citadel Securities, a market-making firm led by Ken Griffin, reported a significant doubling of profit in the first half of 2020, reaching $2.36 billion, due to its dominance in the US equity market. The company handled over a quarter of all US equity volume and generated $3.84 billion in revenue, surpassing 2019's total revenue. Citadel's growth is attributed to its insulation from the pandemic and its ability to capitalize on the market's rollercoaster ride, with its market share increasing in the US options and retail markets.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 8.34 points to 1,509.14, closing higher on Friday. The index saw 5.172 billion lots worth RM3.959 billion traded, with 572 gainers outnumbering 446 losers.

site_title: Vodafone wins international arbitration against India in US$2b tax case: sources
summary: Vodafone has won an international arbitration case against India in a US$2 billion tax dispute. The Hague-based tribunal ruled that India's tax imposition on Vodafone was in breach of an investment treaty agreement with the Netherlands. The government must cease seeking the dues and pay £4.3 million in partial compensation for Vodafone's legal costs. The tax dispute stems from Vodafone's acquisition of Indian mobile assets in 2007. This victory marks a significant win for Vodafone, with India facing over a dozen international arbitration cases against companies over retrospective tax claims and contract cancellations.

site_title: How to overcome executive loneliness
summary: A senior executive shares his personal account of overcoming executive loneliness, depression, anxiety, and substance abuse, offering a roadmap for recovery. After hitting rock bottom, he found solace in Alcoholics Anonymous and gradually regained his physical fitness through exercise and triathlons. He also found purpose by giving back through charity work and pursuing a passion for cycling. The executive emphasizes the importance of taking stock of oneself, seeking help, researching mental health issues, and maintaining healthy relationships to overcome the growing mental health crisis among business leaders.

site_title: Memiontec Holdings bags three contracts worth S$17.8m
summary: Memiontec Holdings, a water-treatment company listed on the CATALIST exchange, secured three new contracts worth S$17.8 million. The contracts, part of its order book valued at S$65 million, are expected to boost revenue and earnings per share for the 2020-2022 period. The construction works will be carried out progressively, with a positive impact on the company's earnings per share for the 12 months to December 31, 2020.

site_title: Google's search business targeted in looming US antitrust case
summary: The US government is preparing an antitrust lawsuit against Google, accusing the company of crushing competition in the online search market. Google controls 90% of the US search market and is accused of skewing search results to favor its own products and using its power to shut out rivals. The Justice Department has been investigating Google for 14 months, with the lawsuit potentially impacting the company's highly-profitable search business, valued at over $100 billion annually.

site_title: Social media deal earns advertisers' 'likes', but not yet all their dollars
