summary: Hong Kong activist Joshua Wong was arrested for "unlawful assembly" over a 2019 protest against a government mask ban, his third case since China imposed a national security law in June. Wong, 23, vowed to continue resisting China's crackdown on dissent, stating he would not surrender. The arrest is the latest in a string of government critics being targeted, with two of Wong's former comrades already facing charges under the new law. Wong faces three separate cases, including violating the unconstitutional anti-mask law.

site_title: Why we need to put a number on our natural resources
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is exploring the value of natural capital, including whales, as part of a broader push to quantify the impact of natural resources on the economy. The initiative, led by IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva, aims to shift the global green debate from a narrow focus on carbon emissions to a wider discussion on biodiversity and natural capital. A report by the Paulson Institute and others estimates that protecting nature could prevent up to 50% of species extinction and cost between $600 billion and $820 billion per year. The effort reflects a growing recognition that natural capital is essential for the economy and that assigning a value to it is crucial for effective conservation and climate action.

site_title: Trump jeered as he visits Ginsburg's casket at US Supreme Court
summary: US President Donald Trump visited the late Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg's casket outside the US Supreme Court, where he was met with jeers and boos. The moment highlighted the public flashpoint surrounding Ginsburg's death ahead of the Nov 3 presidential election. Trump has installed two top court picks since taking office and plans to unveil his latest choice on Saturday. Ginsburg's death has drawn sharp battle lines between Republicans and Democrats, reshaping the election and prompting Democrats to push for voter turnout. Trump had previously criticized Ginsburg publicly.

site_title: Trump sued by niece Mary alleging family defrauded her
summary: President Donald Trump was sued by his niece Mary for allegedly conspiring with his brother and sister to defraud her of tens of millions of dollars. The lawsuit, filed Thursday, claims that Trump, Robert Trump, and sister Maryanne failed to follow through on a pledge to watch over her interests after she inherited minority interests in the family business. The suit comes months after Mary Trump's tell-all book and brings potentially damaging allegations less than six weeks before the presidential election.

site_title: Indonesia gives free Bali staycations to test tourism readiness
summary: Indonesia is offering free 2-night staycations to 4,440 residents of Bali, starting Oct 7, to test its coronavirus health protocols and promote tourism. This 7-week dry-run aims to assess the island's readiness to welcome international tourists after a devastating economic impact from the pandemic. The staycations will include local tours and participants are expected to promote "New Normal Bali" on social media. The move comes as Indonesia reported a record 4,634 new coronavirus cases, with a total of 262,022 cases and 10,105 deaths.

site_title: Japan to seek US$242b for debt servicing
summary: Japan's Ministry of Finance is seeking approximately $242 billion in debt servicing for the fiscal year starting April 1, a 9.2% increase from the current fiscal year. This marks the third consecutive year the government is seeking a budget request for debt redemption and interest payments on a budget-request basis. The government's massive outstanding debt, topping twice Japan's $5 trillion economy, contributes to the increase. The budget request will be scrutinized by the finance ministry in late December, amid uncertainty over the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Wealthy Britons step up citizenship shopping to thwart Brexit
summary: Wealthy British entrepreneurs are increasingly seeking citizenship in EU countries to maintain EU travel rights post-Brexit. Investment firms report significant year-on-year increases in interest from clients seeking citizenship in Cyprus, Greece, Malta, Portugal, Austria, and Caribbean islands. This trend is driven by the uncertainty surrounding a post-Brexit trade deal between Britain and the EU. As UK passport-holders lose their EU freedom of movement rights, investment immigration firms are advising clients on applications for residency and citizenship to maintain access to the EU.

site_title: Rare Botticelli portrait could reach US$100m at auction
summary: A rare 15th-century portrait by Sandro Botticelli, "Young Man Holding a Roundel," is expected to sell for over $100 million at Sotheby's auction in New York. It is one of only a dozen of his portraits known to survive today and has the highest estimate for an Old Master in Sotheby's history. The painting, acquired by Sotheby's owner in 1982, depicts an unknown young man dressed in a simple tunic with a blue sky behind him. The sale could surpass the previous record of $110 million for Claude Monet's "Meules" in 2019.

site_title: OCBC prices S$200m in 3% perpetual capital securities, first callable in 2030
summary: OCBC priced S$200 million in 3% perpetual capital securities, first callable in 2030, with net proceeds used for general corporate purposes. The capital securities are expected to qualify as Additional Tier 1 capital with a "Baa1" rating from Moody's Investors Service. Holders will receive semi-annual distributions at 3% per annum until the first reset date of Sept 30, 2030, and potentially higher rates thereafter. The securities will list on the Singapore bourse on Oct 1, following a private placement under OCBC's US$30 billion global medium-term note programme.

site_title: Norges Bank surprises market as rate hike remains years away
summary: Norway's central bank, Norges Bank, ruled out interest rate hikes for the coming years due to the ongoing pandemic's uncertain economic environment. Governor Oystein Olsen stated that the policy rate will remain at zero until economic conditions normalize. This decision led to a slump in the krone, as some investors had expected a more hawkish signal. The bank's decision reflects a cautious approach to monetary policy amidst global economic uncertainty.

site_title: US new-home sales climb to 1 million rate, fastest since 2006
summary: US new-home sales rose to a 1 million annualized pace in August, the highest level since 2006, driven by record-low mortgage rates and a shrinking supply. Sales increased 4.8% from July, with the median selling price decreasing to $312,800. The demand for new homes has surged 77% over the last four months, with the South region leading the way. The supply of new homes has fallen to a three-year low, and it would take 3.3 months to exhaust the current supply.

images.alt_text: Sales of new homes in the US unexpectedly advanced for a fourth month in August to the highest level in almost 14 years as record-low mortgage rates continued to entice buyers into a market with ever-shrinking supply.

site_title: Hong Lai Huat board stands by carrying value assessment for properties
summary: Hong Lai Huat Group, a Singapore-listed property developer, has engaged independent valuers to assess its properties held for sale, valued at S$25.2 million. The group's board believes the methodologies for determining carrying values are reasonable. The company also clarified the valuation of biological assets, S$5.89 million, as immature cassava that has not been harvested. Shares ended at S$0.145, down 0.8 cent or 5.23%, following the announcement.

site_title: Bankrupt Hanwell Holdings executive chairman resigns after 'oversight'
summary: Hanwell Holdings' executive chairman Allan Yap, 64, has resigned as chairman of the company and Tat Seng Packaging Group, citing a disqualifying bankruptcy. The move came after a late-night bourse filing revealed the oversight on Wednesday. Yap stepped down on Thursday, effective immediately. The company had no prior knowledge of the bankruptcy.

site_title: Thai parliament delays decision on constitution changes
summary: Thailand's parliament voted to delay making a decision on amending the constitution, as demanded by anti-government protesters who have been demonstrating for nearly two months. The parliament, dominated by pro-government lawmakers, opted to set up a committee to study the process of constitutional amendment instead. The vote effectively delays the decision to November, according to pro-government lawmaker Chinnaworn Boonyakiat.

images.alt_text: Thailand's parliament voted on Thursday to delay making a decision on whether it will amend the constitution, as demanded by anti-government protesters who have demonstrated nearly every day for more than two months.

site_title: 15 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, none in the community
summary: Singapore reported 15 new Covid-19 cases on September 24, bringing the total to 57,654. The cases include 10 migrant workers in dormitories and 5 imported cases, with none in the community. All imported cases were placed on stay-home notices. The number of new daily community cases has remained stable, and the number of unlinked cases has also remained stable. 42 patients were discharged, leaving 28 in hospital and 266 in community facilities.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 4.32 points to 1,500.80. Volume reached 5.898 billion lots worth RM4.559 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 578 to 451.

site_title: Risk agility and instinctive decision making in a world fraught with uncertainty
summary: The Covid-19 pandemic has accelerated the demise of traditional business models, highlighting the need for risk agility and instinctive decision making in a world fraught with uncertainty. Fragile systems crack under unexpected events, while antifragile systems can resist shocks. Businesses must develop resilience, become more agile, and expand their horizons to thrive. Instinctive leaders make decisions unafraid of course corrections, weighing empirical data and intuition to guide their decision-making process. Embracing risk agility and relying on instinctive decision making can enable companies to survive and possibly thrive in an increasingly uncertain future.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end sharply lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.82% on Thursday, mirroring losses in Asia and the US, amid concerns over a spike in virus infections and stalled US stimulus talks. The Hang Seng Index fell to 23,311.07, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 1.72%. The decline follows a rout on Wall Street.

site_title: King Wan Corp can meet payment obligations, board says after bourse query
summary: King Wan Corp, a Singapore-listed building and construction services provider, can meet its payment obligations in the next 12 months, according to the board. The company cited an average monthly cash balance of S$5 million and continued support from banks, with 87% of ongoing mechanical and electrical projects resumed work by November 2020. The board attributed the company's net comprehensive loss to a fair-value loss in equity securities and assured that the group is not in default for any outstanding loans.

site_title: Mitsubishi UFJ Lease to buy Hitachi Capital in deal worth US$2.8b
summary: Mitsubishi UFJ Lease agreed to buy Hitachi Capital in a US$2.8 billion deal, with the new company set to be established in April. The transaction will create a combined entity with assets worth 10 trillion yen and nearly 10,000 employees, as well as revenue of around 1.4 trillion yen. The deal will help the new company compete with global competitors, according to a joint statement from the companies.

site_title: Hiap Tong Corp has enough resources to carry on despite virus hit to construction, says its board
summary: Hiap Tong Corp, a Singapore-listed crane provider, says it has sufficient financial resources and banking facilities to continue operations despite the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the construction sector. The company has managed costs and monitored cash flow, and maintains sufficient banking facilities. The gearing ratio increased to 0.62 times due to new accounting standards, but the board believes it has safeguards to prevent concentration of authority. The board also stated that it found it best to adopt a single leadership structure, despite founder Ong Teck Meng holding dual roles.

site_title: As Covid-19 cases surge, UK unveils plans to save jobs
summary: The UK has unveiled a new jobs support scheme to help firms keep employees employed but on shorter hours as COVID-19 cases surge. Finance Minister Rishi Sunak announced the "Economic Winter Plan" to support people's jobs, offering a wage subsidy to encourage workers to return to viable jobs. The plan also includes a cut to value-added tax for hotels, cafes, and restaurants until March 31. The government aims to prevent unemployment from rising to 7.5% by the end of the year, down from 4.1% in July.

site_title: Cineworld swings to loss, says may need to raise more money
summary: Cineworld, a major cinema operator, has reported a US$1.64 billion pretax loss for the first half of 2020 due to pandemic-related closures and delayed movie releases. The company, which reopened 561 out of 778 sites, may need to raise additional liquidity if governments impose stricter restrictions, potentially forcing the closure of its theatres. Cineworld is in talks with lenders to avoid a loan default and has highlighted the strong performance of recent film releases, including Christopher Nolan's "Tenet".

images.alt_text: Cineworld said on Thursday it might need to raise more money if it is required to shut its theatres again following fresh pandemic curbs, as one of the world's biggest cinema operators swung to a US$1.64 billion loss for the first half.

site_title: Dogs used to detect coronavirus in pilot project at Helsinki airport
summary: Dogs have been trained to detect coronavirus at Helsinki-Vantaa airport as part of a pilot project. The dogs are trained to sniff passenger samples, and their efficiency has been shown to be 100-per-cent sensitivity. The dogs' ability to detect cases of the virus is comparable to the time it takes for patients to show symptoms, five days before clinical symptoms appear. This method is being tested alongside usual testing, and its potential for widespread use is being discussed, including the possibility of using dogs to screen passengers in a similar way to customs dogs.

site_title: AGC seeks to be heard at Ms Parti Liyani's complaint hearing
summary: The Attorney-General's Chambers (AGC) is seeking leave to be heard at the application hearing of Parti Liyani's complaint against Deputy Public Prosecutors Tan Wee Hao and Tan Yanying, who prosecuted her for theft. The AGC also seeks to submit court notes and evidence related to the case, including extracts from the record of proceedings and the prosecution's closing submissions. Parti Liyani, a former maid, was acquitted of theft on appeal to the High Court earlier this month. The hearing is set to take place in the coming days, with Senior State Counsels representing the prosecutors if approved.

site_title: South Korea says North Korea killed its citizen, burned body
summary: A South Korean government employee, 47, was fatally shot and his body burned by North Korean military personnel near the Northern Limit Line border. The man, who worked for South Korea's fisheries ministry, was trying to defect but was believed to be a coronavirus carrier, prompting harsh treatment by North Korea. The incident sparked criticism from South Korea's presidential office, which called for an apology and vowed to strengthen border security. The shooting occurred around the same time as South Korean President Moon Jae-in urged world leaders to end the Korean War, highlighting tensions between the two nations.

site_title: JPMorgan Joins rivals in pausing London office return plans
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co has paused plans to bring back more workers to its London office, following the UK government's urging to work from home due to a surge in virus cases. The bank will wait for guidance before increasing the number of workers returning to UK sites, including Canary Wharf. This decision follows similar moves by Goldman Sachs Group and Citigroup, and contradicts Wall Street banks' advocacy for the return of workers to improve productivity and maintain company culture. JPMorgan will maintain a minimum presence in the office, allowing staff to work from home if needed.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's banking system is expected to recover early, with a low negative impact, by the end of 2022, according to S&P. A Singaporean firm, Q Investment Partners, launched a $52 million fund for student accommodation in the UK. Most Singapore investors stayed invested in their portfolios during the pandemic, with over 80% remaining invested. Reits (real estate investment trusts) are diversifying, with Capitaland Commercial Trust and CapitaLand Mall Trust already adopting a diversification strategy. UOB launched a partnership network for digital payments and rewards redemption, and M1 is launching its non-standalone 5G network.

site_title: US$940b food-waste problem has Walmart, Impossible Foods pledging to help
summary: Major US retailers and food suppliers, including Walmart and Impossible Foods, have pledged to cut food waste in half by 2030 as part of the "10x20x30" initiative. The global food-waste problem, estimated at $940 billion, accounts for one-third of all food produced and contributes to 8% of global greenhouse gas emissions. Companies have agreed to measure and publish data on their food loss, and suppliers such as Campbell Soup and Kellogg have already started making changes to reduce waste. The effort aims to reduce pressure on nature and emissions.

site_title: Netflix, Amazon Prime are latest weapons in India's telecom war
summary: India's telecom price war has intensified with freebies such as Netflix and Amazon Prime subscriptions. Reliance Jio Infocomm, the country's largest telecom company, launched a new postpaid plan with 75GB data and access to Netflix, offering a 20% discount to Bharti Airtel. Analysts expect other carriers to follow with similar tie-ups to retain monthly bill-paying customers. The move comes as the demand for online entertainment content increases due to pandemic restrictions, with several big-budget local films released on streaming platforms this year.

images.alt_text: After announcing the first tariff increase in three years in 2019, telecom carriers are offering incentives such as subscriptions to services from Netflix to Amazon Prime to win customers in a content-hungry market.

site_title: Even before proposed merger, CCT and CMT have already been diversifying: managers
summary: Capitaland Commercial Trust (CCT) and CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) have been diversifying their portfolios even before a proposed merger. The Reit managers stated that the merged entity would benefit from combined domain expertise, cost savings, and potential synergies. CCT has been focusing on integrated developments, while CMT has redeveloped a pure retail mall into an integrated development. The Reits' pro forma accretion to distribution per unit (DPU) is expected to increase due to the consolidation of portfolios and unlocking of synergies. However, unitholders have expressed concerns about the feasibility of the proposed terms and the impact of retail rent correction on the merged entity's DPU.

site_title: Broker's take: CGS-CIMB upgrades ThaiBev to 'add' as share price back at low levels
summary: Brokerage firm CGS-CIMB upgraded ThaiBev to 'add' from 'hold', citing the company's share price falling below its minus-two standard deviation level and dwindling Covid-19 cases in major markets. Analysts expect improved beer and liquor volumes in Thailand and Vietnam, driven by government stimulus measures, and raised FY20 earnings per share estimates. The target price remains at 70 Singapore cents, with the risk-reward ratio skewed to the upside for longer-term investors.

site_title: Iraq oil minister expects deal to up oil exports
summary: Iraq's Oil Minister Ihsan Abdul Jabbar expects a deal with Opec+ soon to increase the country's crude oil exports. This comes as Iraq has failed to fully comply with Opec+ oil output reductions, mainly due to low oil prices affecting its finances. The agreement is expected to last until the end of 2021, amid rising global oil prices and the ongoing impact of the coronavirus pandemic. Abdul Jabbar stated that negotiations are ongoing, aiming to contribute to a global oil price recovery.

site_title: Thailand takes first legal action against Facebook, Twitter over content
summary: Thailand has taken legal action against Facebook and Twitter for ignoring court-issued takedown orders. The digital ministry filed complaints with cybercrime police after the companies missed 15-day deadlines. Google, which was originally suggested for action, complied with a takedown order for YouTube videos. This marks Thailand's first legal action against major internet firms.

site_title: Delta in talks to defer 40 Airbus jet deliveries beyond 2020
summary: Delta Air Lines is in talks with Airbus to delay at least 40 aircraft deliveries beyond 2020 due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on the travel market. The airline plans to bolster its cash stockpile by raising $750 million from a sale-leaseback deal for nine Airbus jets. Delta aims to reduce capital spending by $3.5 billion this year, part of which involves working with manufacturers to optimize aircraft delivery timing. The move underscores pressure on Airbus and Boeing, with both manufacturers working to preserve orders amid reduced demand for new aircraft.

site_title: Singapore's total population falls to 5.69 million
summary: Singapore's total population fell to 5.69 million in June 2020, a 0.3% drop, mainly due to a reduction in foreign employment in the services sector. The non-resident population declined 2.1% to 1.64 million, while the citizen population grew 0.6% to 3.52 million. The permanent resident population remained stable at 0.52 million. The government's immigration framework has been stable, with about 30,000 new permanent residents accepted annually. The population is aging, with the median age increasing to 42.2 years, and the proportion of citizens aged 65 and above projected to rise to 23.7% in 10 years.

site_title: M1 is third telco to launch non-standalone 5G; mobile plan available from Friday
summary: M1, a KeppeL Corp-owned telco in Singapore, launched its 5G non-standalone network on Thursday, becoming the third mobile operator to offer this service in the country. Customers can access the network by adding a 5G Booster pack to their existing mobile plan and can connect to the network in select areas starting from Friday. This move follows similar launches by StarHub and Singtel earlier this month.

site_title: Seoul: Shares close at near two-month low as economic recovery falters
summary: South Korean shares closed at a near two-month low on Thursday, down 2.59% at 2,272.70, due to a faltering economic recovery amid a resurgence in Covid-19 cases. The benchmark Kospi was led by losses from market heavyweight Samsung Electronics, Hyundai Motor, and biopharmaceutical firm Celltrion. US business activity cooled in September, and South Korea reported 125 new Covid-19 cases, denting sentiment. Foreigners were net sellers of 195.9 billion won worth of shares, and the won declined 0.71% against the US dollar.

site_title: Active managers are suffering a perilous pandemic
summary: Active managers in the US and globally are struggling to deliver outsize returns, with only a third of equity fund managers and less than 10% of bond portfolio managers beating their respective benchmarks in the first half of 2020. This performance continues to undermine the argument for active management, with fewer than 3% of bond managers outperforming their index over a 10 or 15-year period. The industry faces an existential crisis as investors increasingly turn to lower-cost index tracking products.

site_title: Nobel winners to get 10m Swedish crowns as prize money increased
summary: The Nobel Foundation has increased the prize money for this year's winners to 10 million Swedish crowns (approximately $152,000), up from the previous amount. This decision, made by the foundation's head, Lars Heikensten, aims to stabilize the foundation's finances, which were affected by the global credit crunch in 2008-9. The prize money has varied over time, with a previous high of 10 million crowns in 2000. Heikensten stated that the foundation will continue to raise the prize money "from time to time."

site_title: Google partners banks to streamline PayNow transfers
summary: Google has partnered with several banks in Singapore to integrate PayNow transfers into its Google Pay app, allowing users to make real-time money transfers across multiple bank accounts on one platform. This move aims to tap into the surge in digital payments amid COVID-19 restrictions. The partnership, which includes DBS, OCBC, and Standard Chartered, is the first non-bank payments app to offer PayNow transfers for corporates and individuals, with four million users already on the PayNow rails.

site_title: Veolia could raise bid for Suez stake, CEO says
summary: Veolia's CEO, Antoine Frerot, stated that the company may increase its bid for a 29.9% stake in Suez, a French utility, to 2.9 billion euros. Veolia has already proposed selling Suez's French water activities to Meridiam Infrastructure if the acquisition goes through to preserve competition and employment. Suez has rejected the initial bid, but has said it will consider a higher offer. The company is working on a rival bid, and its French water business has been put in a foundation to preserve its "integrity."

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower on prolonged economic recovery fears
summary: Australian shares closed 0.8% lower at 5,875.9, tracking declines on Wall Street amid fears of a prolonged global economic recovery. US business activity fell in September, while Eurozone business growth stalled, casting doubts on global growth. Energy and tech stocks declined, with Beach Energy and Oil Search falling. The decline was attributed to worries about the US recovery and growth in Europe, with top analysts warning of trouble for the market.

site_title: Auction house Phillips commissioning its own US$200,000 jewels
summary: Auction house Phillips is launching an online jewelry retail platform called Flawless, featuring a commissioned line of jewelry from designer Shaun Leane. The initial collection includes 12 pieces, ranging from $10,000 to $200,000, and represents a departure from traditional auction model. Phillips is aiming to turn its jewelry department into a standalone retail operation, following similar moves by other auction houses such as Christie's and Sotheby's. The platform will offer luxury jewelry from well-known brands and Leane's unique designs, with a physical exhibition to be held in Southampton from October 15-25.

site_title: Trump refuses to promise transfer of power if he loses US vote
summary: US President Donald Trump refused to guarantee a peaceful transfer of power if he loses the November election to Joe Biden, saying "we'll have to see what happens." Trump expressed concerns about mail-in ballots, claiming they are vulnerable to mass fraud, despite no evidence of widespread issues. His comments sparked criticism, particularly as he prepares to nominate a new Supreme Court justice and faces potential court challenges against mail-in ballots, potentially leading to a contested election result.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump on Wednesday refused to clearly guarantee a peaceful transfer of power should he lose the upcoming US election in November to Joe Biden.

site_title: State investors plan to take private HK-listed BMW China partner Brilliance: sources
summary: State-backed investors, led by Liaoning Provincial Transportation Investment Group, are planning to take BMW's Hong Kong-listed Chinese joint-venture partner Brilliance private. The $4.6 billion take-private deal could attract other Chinese state-backed investors and may occur as early as the fourth quarter. Brilliance is 30% owned by Huachen Automotive Group, which is majority-owned by the provincial state asset regulator. The deal would mark the latest move targeting beaten-down Hong Kong-listed stocks.

site_title: Japan's car lobby says domestic auto sales recovering, warns on consumer spending
summary: Japan's car lobby reports domestic vehicle sales sharply recovered in September, reaching almost the same level as the previous year. The recovery comes after the government lifted a lockdown in May. However, the car lobby warns that the coronavirus pandemic will continue to weigh on consumer spending, despite the economy showing some signs of life. Japan's economy suffered its worst postwar contraction in the second quarter.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes down more than 1.1%
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index closed down 1.1% on Thursday, following a rout on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index fell 258.67 points to 23,087.82, while the Topix index lost 17.81 points to 1,626.44. The decline was attributed to global market volatility.

images.alt_text: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index closed down more than 1.1 per cent on Thursday, weighed down by a rout on Wall Street.

site_title: UOB launches partnership network to simplify digital payments, rewards redemption
summary: UOB has launched a partnership network with Visa, SP Group, and Grab to simplify digital payments and rewards redemption for its customers. The partnership allows customers to add their Visa credit and debit cards securely into popular apps using UOB's mobile banking app, UOB Mighty, without manual card input. This service is now available on Fitbit Pay for UOB Visa cards and will be expanded to UOB Mastercard cards in the coming months. The partnership also enables customers to offset their SP Group utility bills with UOB rewards points, providing a seamless and fuss-free cashless payment option.

site_title: Hot stock: Wilmar sees active trading after announcing China unit's IPO price
summary: Wilmar International's shares saw active trading after announcing the proposed listing of its China subsidiary Yihai Kerry Arawana (YKA) with an issue price of 25.7 yuan per share, expected to raise 13.9 billion yuan. The stock reached a high of S$4.425 before dipping to S$4.24, then recovered to trade at S$4.37. Almost 20 million shares worth S$85.9 million changed hands. The IPO is expected to raise S$2.81 billion for the company.

site_title: China halts funding for property sale by Li Ka-shing's CK Asset: sources
summary: China's financial regulators have instructed local banks to halt credit support for the HK$2.5 billion sale of Chengdu Le Parc, a high-end residential and commercial development by CK Asset Holdings, citing concerns of risk. The sale was meant to be financed by buyers, but regulators are now investigating "hoarding behaviour" and punishing those responsible. The move comes amid China's efforts to control property prices, and it's unclear if it's related to billionaire Li Ka-shing's company, which has faced criticism from state media. CK Asset's shares have dropped 32% this year.

site_title: ABS chairman emeritus Lopez quits as broadcaster rebuilds
summary: ABS-CBN chairman emeritus Eugenio "Gabby" Lopez III has quit his roles in the Philippine media company and other family ventures due to personal reasons. His resignation comes amid the company's struggles following the rejection of its bid to renew a franchise, leading to a 45% workforce reduction and a 5.6 billion peso impairment charge. Lopez's departure may shield ABS-CBN from potential political threats, as he had been a target of President Rodrigo Duterte's attacks over biased news coverage. A new director, Mario Luza Bautista, has been elected to fill the vacant seat.

site_title: Gold extends losses to fourth day on US dollar rally
summary: Gold prices fell to their lowest in over two months, dropping 0.4% to $1,855.72 per ounce, as the US dollar rallied and investors worried about further stimulus measures for the US economy. The dollar index reached an eight-week high, making gold more expensive for holders of other currencies. US Federal Reserve officials signaled they would keep monetary policy easy for years, but investors remain skeptical about a nascent economic recovery.

site_title: Office sector in Asia-Pacific more resilient than other regions: C&W
summary: The Asia-Pacific office sector is expected to be more resilient than other regions due to its strong economic fundamentals and lower adoption of work-from-home practices. According to Cushman & Wakefield, net office demand in the region will remain positive from 2020 to 2030, with a forecasted growth of 729 million square feet. However, the sector will face a 4.5% drag from increased flexible working, and office rents in emerging markets will experience a shallow decline. Advanced markets, such as Singapore and Japan, will see weaker rental growth and a sharper peak-to-trough decline in office rents.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets slide at open
summary: European stock markets slid at the start of trading on Thursday, following falls in Asia and overnight on Wall Street. London's FTSE 100 index dropped 1.3% to 5,825.18 points, while the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices lost 1% and 1.2% respectively. The decline was attributed to global economic uncertainty, particularly with US-EU trade talks in focus.

site_title: Caught in China-US trade war, Taiwan offers support to chipmakers
summary: Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen has pledged support to the island's semiconductor industry, which is caught in the China-US trade war. Companies like Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) are key suppliers to Apple and Qualcomm, while China is trying to develop its own chipmakers. Tsai promised to help the industry overcome difficulties and consolidate its leading position, focusing on material supplies, technology autonomy, and localisation of equipment manufacturing. The government aims to boost the industry's competitiveness and make Taiwan a global leader in semiconductors.

site_title: Hong Kong says social media used in 20% of its stock manipulation cases
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission found that 20% of market manipulation schemes being investigated involve "ramp and dump" scams conducted via social media, targeting local retail investors who account for 10% of Hong Kong-listed shares' trading value. These scams often affect small-cap stocks with wild price swings and sudden crashes. The SFC has taken a more active role in policing the market, but the issue remains a concern for Hong Kong's financial markets.

site_title: Airbus-backed startup sees drones reseeding fire-ravaged forests
summary: A startup backed by Chris Sacca and Airbus is using drones to aid in re-seeding fire-ravaged forests, providing real-time data and an aerial feeding system to restore native species. Dendra Systems and Seattle-based DroneSeed claim their drones can sow seeds six times faster than manual planting methods, helping to prevent issues like weed invasion and soil erosion. The companies are working with global resources giants and expect high demand as climate change worsens wildfires. Artificial intelligence software is used to identify and tackle issues before they become major problems, promoting ecosystem restoration.

site_title: Ex-president Sarkozy to learn fate in cash-from-Libya case
summary: A Paris appeals court will rule on a legal challenge by ex-president Nicolas Sarkozy and former aides against an investigation into claims that Libyan money was used in his 2007 election campaign. Sarkozy has been charged with taking bribes and concealing embezzlement of Libyan funds, but denies the charges. He and his former ministers challenge the investigation on procedural grounds, also seeking to invoke head-of-state immunity. This is the latest in several investigations into Sarkozy since he left office, including one looking into claims of cash payments and another related to fake invoices.

site_title: Billionaire property heir has big bets on troubled Hong Kong
summary: Billionaire property heir Adrian Cheng is betting big on Hong Kong's troubled real estate market, with a $5 billion expansion strategy. As CEO of New World Development, Cheng is trying to pivot the company beyond Hong Kong's shores into mainland China's "Greater Bay Area." However, this strategy comes with a high debt-to-equity ratio of 42%, and Cheng is borrowing money and selling assets to fund it. The company's earnings are expected to drop 12% due to the pandemic, and investors are taking a wait-and-see approach, with shares down 11% in 2020.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.65 points, or 0.04%, to 1,495.83. The market saw 227 losers and 86 gainers, with volume reaching 210.75 million lots worth RM58.51 million.

site_title: Japan bank mishandles postal shareholder votes for 1,000 firms
summary: A person with direct knowledge of the matter stated that Sumitomo Mitsui Trust Bank failed to count some postal votes for approximately 1,000 companies in Japan ahead of annual general meetings. This oversight occurred despite the bank's receipt of the votes before the deadline. The incident highlights Japan's reliance on analog processes and paperwork for shareholder meetings, which hinders efficiency. Sumitomo Mitsui Trust Bank plans to hold a news conference to explain the findings and has vowed to complete its investigation.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Thursday; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.4% to 2,471.96 on Thursday, tracking Wall Street losses. Losers outnumbered gainers 110 to 33, with Sembcorp Marine, ComfortDelGro, and Thai Beverage among the most active counters. The three banks - DBS, OCBC, and UOB - also fell. The Infocomm Media Development Authority partnered with the banks to develop banking solutions, while DBS and Keppel Corp explored joint digital opportunities.

site_title: Asia: Markets sink again as virus, stimulus, election fan fears
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Thursday, driven by a perfect storm of concerns including rising virus infections, new lockdowns, a slowing economic recovery, and stalled US stimulus talks. Investors are digesting the possibility that growth expectations may not materialize, with the International Labour Organization reporting a 17.3% decline in global working hours. The US stock market also saw steep losses, with the tech-heavy Nasdaq leading the way, amid fears of a second wave of coronavirus and concerns over the US presidential election.

site_title: China has a new richest person, with Jack Ma dethroned
summary: Zhong Shanshan, a Chinese bottled-water and vaccine tycoon, has become China's wealthiest person, surpassing Jack Ma with a net worth of $58.7 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. Zhong's fortune has jumped $51.9 billion in 2020, more than anyone else, while tech stocks stumbled and Tesla's Elon Musk saw his fortune drop by almost $10 billion. Zhong now ranks 17th globally and second in Asia, ahead of Charles Koch and Phil Knight.

site_title: Most Singapore investors stay invested in their portfolios throughout pandemic: poll
summary: A survey by Fidelity International found that over 80% of Singapore investors remained invested in their portfolios despite the pandemic's impact on the markets. The value of Singaporean investments decreased by 36% due to Covid-19, the highest among the four markets surveyed. The poll of 2,434 investors in Singapore, China, Hong Kong, and Japan took place from July 29 to August 3.

site_title: TikTok urges court to block Trump's ban on app in US
summary: TikTok is urging a federal court to block US President Donald Trump's ban on the app, citing "confusing and contradictory statements" about the ban as motivated by election politics rather than national security concerns. The Chinese-owned app has 100 million US users and a deal to restructure ownership was thrown into doubt after Trump vowed to block a deal allowing its Chinese parent firm ByteDance to retain control. A preliminary injunction is sought to prevent "devastating harm" to TikTok if the ban is found to be unlawful.

images.alt_text: TikTok is urging a federal court to block US President Donald Trump from banning the video app, arguing the move is motivated by election politics rather than legitimate national security concerns.

site_title: Airline passengers want to see barriers to boost confidence: industry execs
summary: Airline passengers want visible plastic barriers in the cabin to boost confidence in flying during the pandemic. Industry executives said passengers don't trust industry assurances about air quality onboard. Embraer is studying reusable plastic barriers, but faces challenges in making them lightweight and non-flammable. Airlines are also considering private business class seating, touchless lavatories, and permanent freighter conversions. Companies like Singapore Technologies Engineering have developed prototypes for barriers and pods, and some airlines are interested in lie-flat seating options on narrowbody planes. The goal is to reassure passengers about risk and improve overall flying experience.

site_title: Singapore's resilient savers, and a question over the widening wealth gap
summary: Singapore households have seen asset growth of 5% in the first six months of 2020, despite the COVID-19 pandemic, reflecting a disciplined savings approach. A separate survey found that nearly 8 in 10 respondents prioritized essential spending and tracked their finances. However, the data also suggests a widening wealth gap, with low-income earners bearing the brunt of the economic slump. According to DBS, a third of its customers experienced a decline in income of over 10% in the first half of 2020, with the lower-income group most affected.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall over 1% as data signals slow global recovery
summary: Australian shares fell over 1% on Thursday, tracking a decline in global economic recovery signals. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 1.6% due to cooling business activity in the US and Europe, and a halt in business growth in the Euro zone. The decline was also attributed to a surge in Covid-19 cases and fresh restrictions, leading to a drop in gold prices and mining stocks. Technology stocks also fell, with Afterpay experiencing its largest intraday drop since September.

images.alt_text: Australian shares fell more than 1 per cent on Thursday, as concerns about the global economic recovery escalated after data showed that business activity in the United States and Europe cooled this month due to new restrictions to quell the coronavirus.

site_title: UN, Britain to co-host climate summit on Dec 12
summary: The United Nations and Britain are set to co-host a global climate summit on December 12, the fifth anniversary of the Paris Agreement, to increase momentum ahead of COP 26 in Glasgow in November 2021. UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres and British Prime Minister Boris Johnson will convene global leaders to rally greater climate action and ambition. The summit aims to address the climate emergency and the UK will lead by example, keeping the environment on the global agenda and serving as a launch pad for a global green industrial revolution.

site_title: Alibaba fintech arm eyes record IPO with Hong Kong-Shanghai listing
summary: Alibaba's fintech arm, Ant Group, plans a record-breaking IPO with a potential listing of up to $35 billion in Hong Kong and Shanghai, valuing the company at $250 billion. The company will not seek cornerstone investors, aiming to raise the funds for cross-border payments and R&D expansion. This move is seen as a boost for Hong Kong, which has been facing potential fallout from Beijing's national security law, and comes as US markets lose out due to Washington's scrutiny of Chinese tech firms.

site_title: Strong v-shaped recovery for Asean+3 in 2021: AMRO
summary: The ASEAN+3 Macroeconomic Research Office (AMRO) has forecast a strong V-shaped recovery in GDP growth for the region in 2021, with a 6.7% expansion. This is driven by the effective containment of the pandemic and smooth exits from policy measures. Nine of 14 members are expected to contract in 2020, with some experiencing significant declines. The region's growth is expected to decline by 0.3% in 2020, with severe containment measures affecting the economies.

images.alt_text: We are projecting a strong V-shaped recovery in GDP growth in 2021, particularly for the Plus-3. The region as a whole is projected to expand at 6.7 percent, with all economies forecast to return to positive growth-predicated on the effective containment of the pandemic, both regionally and globally, and on the assumption that exits from policy measures proceed smoothly.

site_title: Election data software vendor Tyler Technologies tells US local government clients it was hacked
summary: Tyler Technologies, a US company that provides election data software to local governments, announced it was hacked. The breach occurred in the company's internal systems, but it did not affect clients' software. Tyler said it was working to restore its systems and notified law enforcement. The company's chief information security officer advises counties to reset passwords and assumes hackers could access systems remotely. The incident is a concern for election security, but it's unclear if any client data was compromised.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares see more losses at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 0.86% on Thursday, following a sell-off on Wall Street due to virus-containment fears and stagnant US stimulus talks. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 23,537.83, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.51%. The losses come as traders remain cautious amid global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Axiata's unit plans biggest Bangladesh IPO in a decade to expand
summary: Axiata's Bangladesh unit, Robi, plans to raise 5.24 billion taka (S$82.9 million) in an initial share sale, the country's largest IPO since 2010. The venture, between Axiata and India's Bharti Airtel, aims to expand in Bangladesh, where the Asian Development Bank forecasts a 5.2% growth this year. The IPO will help Robi grow its network, following a 38% rise in Bangladesh's benchmark DSE Broad Index since its March low.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Wilmar, Dairy Farm, Hanwell, Tat Seng, Medtecs, Aspen
summary: Singapore stocks saw new developments on Thursday, with Wilmar International's China unit set to raise 13.9 billion yuan (S$2.81 billion) through a listing. GIC will be a strategic investor. Keppel Corp and DBS will jointly explore digital opportunities. GuocoLand sold a building in Shanghai for 610 million yuan (S$122.8 million). Hanwell Holdings and Tat Seng Packaging Group failed to act on their executive chairman's bankruptcy despite the law prohibiting it. Dairy Farm International is slashing prices of 650 products by 20%.

site_title: China running 380 detention centres in Xinjiang: researchers
summary: China has a network of over 380 suspected detention facilities in the Xinjiang region, according to Australian researchers. This number is 40% greater than previous estimates and indicates a growing expansion of detention centers despite China's claims of releasing many Uighur detainees. The facilities are believed to be holding over one million Uighurs and other Turkic-speaking residents, sparking concerns over human rights abuses.

site_title: Hatten Land unit to issue RM15.7m 6% notes due 2021
summary: Hatten Land's subsidiary MDSA Resources will issue RM15.7 million (S$5.1 million) of 6% notes due 2021 to repay outstanding notes. Noteholders of the first issuance have agreed to subscribe for the new notes. The medium-term note programme was established in 2017. Kenanga Investment Bank is the principal adviser and lead arranger for the programme.

site_title: BreadTalk, Adera to create fintech and digital solutions for SMEs
summary: BreadTalk Group, a recently delisted food and beverage player, is forming a joint venture with Singapore-based technology services group Adera AI to develop fintech and digital solutions for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The JV aims to create digital tools for data analytics, operational efficiency, and decision-making, as well as a blockchain-based supply-chain financing platform. The first batch of solutions is expected to be rolled out by Q1 2021, with initial deployments in BreadTalk's F&B establishments.

site_title: Singapore firm launches S$52m fund for student accommodation in the UK
summary: A Singapore-based private equity firm, Q Investment Partners, launched a £30 million (S$52.13 million) fund to invest in student accommodation in the UK. The fund will develop a portfolio of five purpose-built assets in London, Edinburgh, and Bath through a joint venture with local partners. Despite the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic in the UK, the investment aims to capitalize on the growing demand for student accommodation in the country. QIP's largest fund to date, the initiative is seen as a strategic move to expand its presence in the UK market.

site_title: ByteDance applies for tech export licence in China amid TikTok deal talks
summary: ByteDance, the owner of TikTok, has applied for a tech export license in China amid ongoing deal talks over its US operations. The application was submitted to Beijing's municipal commerce bureau, awaiting a decision. China recently revised its list of restricted technologies, giving Beijing more control over exports. The move comes as ByteDance considers its US operations amidst potential regulatory scrutiny. The company's application status is unclear, but the move suggests a strategic response to China's new export regulations.

site_title: WeWork China gets US$200m investment, appoints new acting CEO
summary: WeWork China's unit has received a US$200 million investment from existing investors Trustbridge Partners and Temasek Holdings, with Trustbridge taking a majority stake. Michael Jiang, a Trustbridge executive, has been appointed as the acting CEO. This investment comes after WeWork China slashed its cash burn rate and secured a US$1.1 billion financing commitment from SoftBank Group. The company's management shake-up continues, with ongoing lawsuits over a US$3 billion tender offer to existing shareholders.

site_title: Australia's Westpac bank agrees record fine for money-laundering
summary: Australia's Westpac bank has agreed to pay a record AU$1.3 billion fine for over 23 million breaches of money-laundering laws, including failures to monitor international payments suspected of funding child exploitation. The fine exceeds a provision of US$900 million and is the largest civil penalty in Australian history. Westpac's CEO, Peter King, apologized for the bank's failings and stated that the bank has beefed up its financial crime monitoring capabilities and undertaken a cultural and governance review to prevent future breaches.

site_title: US: Stocks end sharply lower, Dow -1.9%, Nasdaq -3.0%
summary: US stocks plummeted on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 1.9%, the S&P 500 down 2.4%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index down 3.0%, amid worries over a potential coronavirus second wave and an increasingly contentious US presidential election. Analysts cited fresh restrictions in Europe and the lack of stimulus spending in Washington as contributing factors. Despite some sector-specific gains, including Nike's 8.8% rise on strong digital sales, overall market sentiment remained bearish.

site_title: Australia to overhaul bankruptcy laws to help firms over Covid-19
summary: Australia is overhauling its bankruptcy laws to help businesses affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. The proposed rule changes allow small businesses with liabilities under A$1 million to trade while restructuring debt, rather than being placed in administration. The changes, effective January 1, 2021, adopt elements of the US Chapter 11 bankruptcy process, enabling businesses to restructure debts while maintaining control. The reforms aim to keep more businesses in operation and Australians in jobs, supporting the economy amid the pandemic.

site_title: Most UK firms unprepared for end of Brexit transition: BCC
summary: A survey by the British Chambers of Commerce found that 51% of UK firms are unprepared for the end of the Brexit transition period, with just over three months to go. The government has warned of potential 100 km-long queues of lorries and extra trade paperwork. Despite government efforts, businesses remain concerned about the impact of Brexit and the ongoing pandemic, with some struggling to plan due to financial constraints. The UK economy also contracted for the second month, adding to economic uncertainty.

site_title: UK cancels autumn budget, readies new virus measures
summary: The UK government has canceled its planned autumn budget due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, citing uncertainty and long-term planning difficulties. Chancellor Rishi Sunak will instead announce new measures to protect jobs, following a surge in cases and the introduction of nationwide restrictions. Prime Minister Boris Johnson has also advised people to work from home and implemented new rules to stem the spread of infection, including early pub and restaurant closures. The government aims to provide reassurance and support to businesses and individuals to help them navigate the economic challenges posed by the pandemic.

site_title: Most Singapore employers to retain flexi-work arrangements even post-Covid: survey
summary: Most Singapore employers plan to retain flexible work arrangements even post-Covid, with 95% currently in place and 61% intending to continue. A survey of 3,200 employers and job candidates found 94% have implemented flexible work arrangements, and 60% intend to continue. Despite concerns about productivity, firms are willing to extend flexible working arrangements to meet job seekers' expectations.

site_title: Singapore banking system may be among first to recover: S&P
summary: Singapore's banking system may be among the first to recover to pre-Covid-19 levels, according to S&P Global Ratings, with expected recovery by the end of 2022. The country's banking system was identified as an "early-exiter" with low negative impact on recovery prospects. This classification is based on the absence of a significant hit on its banking industry country risk assessments and limited effect on financial institution ratings.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index down 0.57% or 133.80 points at 23,212.69, and the Topix index down 0.56% or 9.14 points at 1,635.11. The decline was attributed to a rout on Wall Street. However, the dollar-yen rate remained stable, supporting the downside.

site_title: Former 'world's heaviest man' defeats coronavirus
summary: A 36-year-old Mexican man, Juan Pedro Franco, who once weighed 595kg, has recovered from COVID-19 after a successful weight loss journey. Franco's significant weight loss, achieved through dieting, exercise, and stomach-reduction surgery, helped him overcome the disease. His case highlights the risks of COVID-19 for those with underlying conditions such as diabetes, high blood pressure, and obesity. Franco's recovery is a rare exception, and his doctor notes that patients with these conditions are more susceptible to serious complications from the virus.

site_title: Europe: Travel rebound, Adidas support stocks despite mixed data
summary: European stocks rose on Wednesday, recovering from the worst selloff in three months, as travel stocks rebounded and Adidas, Puma, and JD Sports gained. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.6%, with London's FTSE 100 up 1.2%, despite data showing euro zone business growth halted in September due to Covid-19 restrictions. Investors are awaiting further stimulus from central banks and governments to battle the economic fallout of the health crisis.

site_title: Automakers sues US government over tariffs on Chinese imports
summary: Major automakers Tesla, Volvo, Ford, and Mercedes-Benz have sued the US government over tariffs on Chinese imports, seeking to have customs duties paid on imports returned with interest. The lawsuits claim the tariffs, imposed amid a trade dispute between the US and China, are "arbitrary, capricious, and an abuse of discretion." The automakers are asking for the tariffs to be revoked and any money paid to import parts returned, citing a trade deal signed earlier this year that partially ended the dispute. The US government imposed tariffs on over $500 billion in Chinese imports.

site_title: China's slow consumption recovery upset by wary low-income households
summary: China's economy is recovering slowly from the COVID-19 pandemic, but consumer spending remains weak, particularly among lower-income households who are cautious about spending due to lingering lockdown fears. Despite factories rebounding quickly, consumer confidence has picked up gradually, complicating President Xi Jinping's efforts to reduce the country's dependence on volatile overseas markets. This uneven recovery may put pressure on policymakers, with China's GDP growth expected to slow in the near future.

site_title: Tech giants strike deal with advertisers over hate speech
summary: Tech giants Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube have agreed with global advertisers to define hate speech, aiming to steer clear of toxic content. This deal establishes a common set of definitions for hateful posts, addressing long-standing issues with balancing free expression and content moderation. The agreement is a step towards purging hate speech from online platforms, but critics may still argue that it stifles free expression.

site_title: UK's Sunak to throw lifeline to some furloughed workers
summary: UK Finance Minister Rishi Sunak plans to announce new job support measures to replace the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme, which expires on October 31. The new plans will likely include wage subsidies for staff returning to work part-time, but will not target specific sectors. The announcement comes as the UK faces rising unemployment fears, with the Bank of England forecasting a 7.5% unemployment rate by the end of the year. The measures aim to provide reassurance to workers and businesses amid the economic uncertainty caused by the COVID-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: British finance minister Rishi Sunak will announce new plans to support jobs on Thursday, as fears mount of a surge in unemployment when an existing 52 billion pound (S$90.6 billion) support programme comes to an end in just over a month.

site_title: Trump's spectacular trade failure
summary: US President Donald Trump's trade policies have led to a significant erosion of the global multilateral trading system, established by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) and the World Trade Organization (WTO). Since 2017, the US has shifted towards bilateralism and protectionism, resulting in increased tariffs and trade deficits. Trump's policies have failed to achieve their stated goals, including reducing bilateral trade imbalances and increasing US exports. The WTO has been severely undermined, and the US has lost market share to foreign competitors. The article concludes that Trump's approach has inflicted great harm on US firms and households.

site_title: India lawmakers back controversial labour reforms
summary: Indian lawmakers have backed long-pending labour reforms, including measures to make it harder for workers to strike and easier to hire and fire. The reforms, part of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's push to revive the pandemic-hit economy, were approved by the upper house of parliament on Wednesday. The new laws include a 14-day notice period for strikes and provisions for accident and life insurance, maternity benefits, and pensions for 400 million workers. The opposition has expressed concerns over the rushed implementation and restrictions on strikes.

site_title: Human links still tops for financial advisers to thrive
summary: Wealth management in Asia is expected to thrive despite the COVID-19 pandemic, as clients increasingly turn to human financial advisers for guidance. Despite digitalization, human links remain crucial for building trust and providing personalized advice. A recent survey found that 94% of Singaporeans value face-to-face financial advice, and 63% prioritize honesty when seeking a financial adviser. Financial advisers can leverage technology to enhance their services, but human interaction and emotional support are essential for making major investment decisions. As the industry adapts to the new normal, a combination of human expertise and technology is key to meeting client expectations and improving the business model.

site_title: Morgan Stanley fund bets on India bank winners
summary: A Morgan Stanley fund is betting on private Indian banks to outperform state-owned lenders during the pandemic. Co-manager Kristian Heugh expects banks with strong deposit franchises and quality underwriting standards to gain market share. The fund holds HDFC Bank, which has "industry-leading digital capabilities" and a lower cost base, despite facing regulatory scrutiny. This bet is seen as a long-term opportunity, as the fund has gained 37% this year and is looking past short-term uncertainty. Heugh believes HDFC can continue taking loan and deposit market share from weak public sector banks.

site_title: Britain finally launches virus app in England and Wales
summary: Britain has finally launched its COVID-19 tracking app in England and Wales, four months behind schedule, amid surging cases. The revamped app, developed with Apple and Google, uses Bluetooth to alert users if they've been in close contact with someone who tests positive. The tool offers features like booking tests and checking into venues using QR codes, but its effectiveness remains uncertain due to lack of published pilot test results. The app aims to reach 10-30% of the population to stem virus transmission, but confidence in the government's handling of the pandemic remains low.

site_title: Shippers to pay more for cargo in 2021, freight broker says
summary: Shippers are expected to pay more for cargo in 2021 due to a shortage of truck drivers and increased demand for freight, according to CH Robinson Worldwide Inc. CEO Bob Biesterfeld. The pandemic drove many small truckers out of business, reducing truck capacity just as retailers restock, leading to market tightness and pricing inflation. Air-freight capacity remains constrained, and the need for vaccine distribution will create further logistics bottlenecks. This trend is expected to continue, with digital freight brokers and legacy companies competing for market share.

site_title: Luxury Geneva hotels face 'life-threatening' Covid-19 crunch
summary: Luxury hotels in Geneva face a "life-threatening" crisis due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Travel restrictions, event cancellations, and prolonged closures of restaurants and museums have severely impacted the sector, with night stays shrinking by 63% compared to last year. The city's hotel density, one of the highest in the world, is under threat of closures and bankruptcies, with some hotels already forced to shut down. Authorities are urged to create a fund to help hotel owners and find a balance between health and economic interests to mitigate the crisis.

site_title: Wilmar's China unit listing to raise 13.9b yuan; GIC among strategic investors
summary: Wilmar International's China unit, Yihai Kerry Arawana (YKA), plans to raise 13.9 billion yuan (S$2.81 billion) through a proposed listing, with Singapore's GIC as a strategic investor. The issue price is 25.7 yuan per share, translating to a 31.12 times price-to-earnings multiple. 20 strategic investors, including state-owned and sovereign wealth funds, have been allocated 30% of the IPO shares, with GIC allotted 472.5 million yuan. The listing is expected to take place by mid-October, subject to market conditions.

site_title: California to ban sale of petrol-powered cars by 2035
summary: California Governor Gavin Newsom ordered all passenger vehicles sold in the state to be zero-emission by 2035 to combat climate change and air pollution. The transportation sector is the largest contributor to California's carbon pollution, with parts of the state having some of the most toxic air in the country. Regulations will be developed to mandate zero-emission vehicles by 2035 and medium- and heavy-duty trucks by 2045, where feasible. The order does not ban existing petrol-powered cars, but aims to speed up the creation of charging networks for electric cars.

site_title: Oil edges higher after US crude, fuel stockpiles draw down
summary: Oil prices edged higher on Wednesday, supported by US government data showing a drop in crude and fuel inventories. Brent crude rose 5 cents to $41.77 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude gained 13 cents to $39.93 a barrel. Inventories fell by 1.6 million barrels for crude, 4 million barrels for gasoline, and 3.4 million barrels for distillates. However, concerns about the ongoing coronavirus pandemic and rising infections in countries like India and France limited gains.

site_title: Shopify says 'rogue' employees stole data from merchants
summary: Shopify discovered that two rogue employees stole data from over 100 merchants, potentially exposing consumer information. The employees accessed customer transaction records, including emails, names, and order details, but not sensitive payment information. Shopify terminated the employees' access and is working with the FBI and other agencies to investigate. The company is taking steps to prevent similar incidents and has apologized for the incident, which has affected fewer than 200 sellers.

site_title: Asian business confidence rebounds in Q3, but pandemic casts shadow: poll
summary: Asian business confidence has rebounded in the third quarter, with the Thomson Reuters/Insead Asian Business Sentiment Index jumping to 53 from an 11-year low of 35 in the second quarter. The survey of 103 companies across 11 Asia-Pacific countries found that 28% of firms were positive about their outlook, up sharply from 7.6% in the second quarter. However, lingering uncertainty over the pandemic and a global recession remain top concerns, with over two-thirds of companies flagging the pandemic as a major risk.

site_title: China has no reason to approve 'dirty' TikTok deal: China Daily
summary: China's state-backed newspaper, China Daily, says it has no reason to approve a proposed deal between ByteDance, the owner of TikTok, and US companies Oracle and Walmart. The deal, aimed at allowing TikTok to operate in the US despite a planned ban, would see ByteDance own 80% of a new US subsidiary. China Daily calls the deal "dirty and unfair" and says China will not give its approval due to "bullying and extortion" by the US government. The US wants ByteDance to relinquish ownership of TikTok within 90 days.

site_title: IMDA partners DBS, OCBC, UOB on e-invoicing
summary: The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) has partnered DBS, OCBC, and UOB to develop banking solutions leveraging the nationwide e-invoicing network InvoiceNow and the PayNow e-payment system, utilizing the Unique Entity Number for businesses to send and receive invoices and collect payments.

site_title: Walmart to hire 20,000 holiday staff to meet online demand
summary: Walmart plans to hire over 20,000 workers for the US holiday season, its first large seasonal hiring in five years, to meet expected surge in online shopping amid the pandemic. The starting hourly rate is $15.75, increasing to $23.75. Walmart aims to compete with Amazon.com and has introduced a subscription delivery service, Walmart+. The retailer expects customers to start holiday shopping early, with a focus on toys, pet products, and outdoor gear.

site_title: Singapore households see asset growth of 5% in first half 2020
summary: Singapore households experienced a 5% asset growth in the first half of 2020, according to the Allianz Global Wealth Report. This growth is a positive indication for the year if no sharp economic slump occurs. The report also found that liabilities contracted by 1.3%, and the debt ratio fell to 65.1%, the lowest value since the 2008 crisis. Globally, private households recorded a 1.5% growth in financial assets, driven by bank deposits and precautionary savings.

site_title: Fed not planning big changes to Main Street lending: Powell
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell stated that the central bank is not planning major changes to its Main Street Lending Program, which has seen low uptake from small-to-medium sized businesses. The program, launched to support Americans during the pandemic, has been criticized for its slow start and limited adoption. Powell emphasized that the Fed has "done basically all of the things that we can think of" to help businesses, but is not considering further major changes to the facility. The program has utilized only about 0.3% of its $600 billion capacity.

site_title: Musk's lofty goal for US$25,000 model falls short of giant leap
summary: Tesla Inc. announced a plan to build a $25,000 car by 2023, citing innovations such as dry electrode technology and battery integration. However, the goal falls short of investor expectations for a significant leap forward. The company aims to cut battery costs in half and achieve 20 million cars per year by 2025, with vertical-integration improvements to reduce costs. Despite the underwhelming announcement, Tesla investors remain optimistic, with Gene Munster stating that traditional auto is in a "tighter spot" and Tesla investors want the company to deliver a cheap car soon.

images.alt_text: Tesla's cheaper car will come from cutting the cost of batteries in half, based on a series of innovations.

site_title: Malaysia PM calls for stability as Anwar claims majority backing
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin urged stability after opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim claimed a majority of lawmakers back him to form a government. Anwar stated he would meet the king soon, while Muhyiddin insisted he remains the legitimate prime minister and urged the people to reject destabilizing moves. A joint statement from various parties reaffirmed support for Muhyiddin, who also announced additional stimulus measures to boost the economy. The situation remains uncertain, with experts warning of a potential period of intense negotiation and fluidity in the political situation.

site_title: Neo Group defends property foray ahead of shareholder vote
summary: Neo Group, a Catalist-listed Singaporean company, is venturing into the property business through a joint venture with Boldtek Holdings. The move aims to generate new revenue streams from rent and management fees. Despite concerns over Boldtek's financial performance, the board defended the partnership, citing its networks and experience in the property sector. The joint-venture company will have a half-stake in Neo Group, and the board expects the diversification to strengthen the company's income base and enhance shareholder value.

site_title: China eyes climate battle leadership with 2060 carbon neutral goal
summary: China has set a goal to become carbon neutral by 2060, a move hailed as a major stride forward by environmental activists. The pledge, which includes reaching peak emissions in 2030, was made by President Xi Jinping in a virtual address to the UN General Assembly. The goal is seen as a significant step forward, but some climate scientists are cautious, citing the need for more specific and ambitious targets. The move contrasts with the US withdrawal from the Paris climate accord under President Trump.

site_title: Koh Boon Hwee, investment veterans launch South-east Asian VC
summary: A new venture capital firm, Altara Ventures, led by five private capital veterans, plans to raise over US$100 million for regional tech investments in South-east Asia. The fund focuses on early-stage opportunities in fintech, consumer tech, enterprise software, logistics, healthcare, and edtech. Altara has already invested in three regional startups and is expecting to make 4-5 investments per year. The fund's partners, including businessman Koh Boon Hwee, have stellar credentials, having made angel investments in over 100 companies and managing private equity investments.

site_title: CDCs' contributions are vital in times of crisis, says PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong commended the country's five Community Development Councils (CDCs) for their efforts during the COVID-19 pandemic, citing their S$20 million voucher scheme and job search assistance. The CDCs have also provided student meals to low-income families and have been strengthened with a S$75 million grant. Lee urged the newly sworn-in mayors to build on these efforts, emphasizing the need for "strong, passionate leaders" to fulfill their duties well.

site_title: US dollar clings to two-month highs
summary: The US dollar maintained its two-month high on Wednesday, driven by positive US economic data and concerns over a second wave of coronavirus infections in Europe. Eurozone business growth stalled, and Britain's economy lost momentum, raising fears of a weakened economic recovery. The dollar index rose to 94.25, while the euro fell to a two-month low of $1.1671. The pound also fell to a two-month low, but recovered some losses. The US dollar is expected to continue to gain as the coronavirus impacts European sentiment, but may be volatile due to uncertainty over the US presidential election.

site_title: COEs end mixed in latest tender as premiums stay high
summary: COEs in Singapore ended mixed in the latest tender, with premiums remaining high. The COE for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp closed at S$38,504, while commercial vehicle COE ended at S$28,589. Motorcycle premium decreased to S$7,331. The smaller supply of COEs and dealers' promotions kept premiums buoyant.

site_title: Business activity down in September; economy losing momentum: IHS Markit
summary: US business activity declined in September, with the Composite PMI Output Index dropping to 54.4 from 54.6 in August, indicating a loss of momentum in the economy. The services sector retreated, while manufacturing firms signaled an acceleration in activity. Economists expect an ebb in economic momentum as fiscal stimulus ebbs, and the coronavirus crisis remains a concern. The economy is expected to rebound at a record 32% annualized rate in the third quarter, but risks are tilted to the downside for the coming months.

site_title: Market's deep discount to Keppel's O&M arm unwarranted: CGS-CIMB
summary: Keppel Corp's shares are trading at a new trough valuation of 0.7 time price-to-book-value (P/BV) ratio, lower than past oil and global financial crises. Analysts at CGS-CIMB see this as unwarranted and an opportunity to accumulate the stock, citing a S$3.5 billion order book and expected profitability in 2021. The brokerage maintains an "add" call and S$6.46 target price, while DBS Equity Research keeps its "hold" rating with a S$5.50 target price.

site_title: Huawei chairman urges US to reconsider 'attack' on global supply chain
summary: Huawei chairman Guo Ping urged the US to reconsider its trade restrictions on the Chinese telecommunications giant, citing challenges to production and operations due to modified sanctions. The US imposed new curbs on September 15, barring US companies from supplying or servicing Huawei, affecting its smartphone chip stocks. Huawei is exploring alternatives, including using Qualcomm chips, but hopes the US government will reconsider its policy to allow continued purchases from US companies. The restrictions have already led to a shortage of Kirin chips powering high-end phones, causing prices to spike.

images.alt_text: "We hope the US government can reconsider its policy, and if the US government allows it, we are still willing to buy products from US companies." - Guo Ping, chairman of Huawei

site_title: Luxury living reimagined - in the new BTLuxe
summary: The Business Times introduces BTLuxe, a luxury living reimagined section, featuring the best in fashion, jewelry, watches, and more. The inaugural issue taps expertise from six industry leaders on navigating the pandemic crisis and shaping the new normal. The issue also covers the Fall/Winter fashion season, the Watches and Wonders show in Shanghai, and features a stunning apartment design by Andre Fu. BTLuxe aims to redefine luxury, focusing on leisure and social connection in uncertain times, and will be published on Fridays.

site_title: 8 in 10 see Singapore going cashless in a decade: StanChart survey
summary: Nearly 80% of Singapore consumers expect the country to go fully cashless in the next decade, according to a Standard Chartered survey of 12,000 consumers aged 18 and above. The pandemic has led to a shift towards online banking and shopping, with 50% of Singaporeans preferring online purchases to in-person transactions. Consumers are also becoming more cautious with their spending, prioritizing needs over wants and using digital tools to track and manage their finances.

site_title: Singapore brand has cachet, but what values should it embody?
summary: Singapore's cachet in consumer lifestyle products is being reevaluated, with the government considering introducing a Singapore brand for various sectors. However, the question remains whether the Singapore brand can represent a supportable offer and story that resonates with consumers. The country's credentials in consumer lifestyle products are limited, with no strong brand essence in unprocessed foods. A more holistic approach, including greater policy support for local industry and educating consumers about the advantages of local produce, may be necessary to persuade price-sensitive consumers to pay a premium for freshness, traceability, and transparency.

site_title: Chairman of Hanwell and Tat Seng declared bankrupt but status not disclosed by firms
summary: Singapore-listed companies Hanwell Holdings and Tat Seng Packaging Group's executive chairman Allan Yap was declared bankrupt in August over debts of HK$685 million. Despite Singapore's Companies Act prohibiting a bankrupt from being a director, neither company has made an announcement about Yap's status. Yap remains chairman of both companies, which has raised concerns about the law's enforcement. Tat Seng has stated it will look into the matter and may make an announcement, while Hanwell has not responded.
