site_title: US existing home sales approach 14-year high; prices scale record peak
summary: US existing home sales surged to a 14-year high in August, reaching a seasonally adjusted annual rate of six million units, driven by record-low mortgage rates and a pandemic-fueled migration to suburbs. Existing home prices jumped 11.4% to a record $310,600, but this may squeeze first-time buyers out of the market. Demand was skewed toward single-family homes, and existing home sales rose 10.5% on a year-on-year basis.

site_title: EHT scrapping all master leases after 'multitude of defaults'
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) is scrapping all master lease agreements (MLAs) with its 18 properties due to "a multitude of defaults" by master lessees, including unpaid rent and insurance premiums. The termination is expected to occur 10 days after notice delivery. EHT's managers cited the need for control and potential temporary arrangements for the properties, and the termination is a required condition for lenders' consent to continued forbearance arrangements. A request for proposal (RFP) process is underway to inject fresh capital into EHT as part of its restructuring plan.

site_title: Buyer fails to extend due diligence for ABI Plaza
summary: A private fund managed by CapitaLand has failed to extend its due diligence period for ABI Plaza in Tanjong Pagar, a 12-storey freehold office tower, after the exclusivity period ended. The fund had initially sought to buy the property for above S$200 million, but the owner, MYP, is not keen on an extension. Meanwhile, the PIL Building in Cecil Street has been rejected by the URA for the CBD Incentive Scheme due to its site area of 1,812 sq m, which does not meet the minimum plot-size requirement. Agents are trying to interest replacement buyers.

site_title: Wirecard: the rise and fall of a fintech giant in Asia
summary: Wirecard, a German fintech company, has collapsed after its CEO was arrested for alleged fraud and the company filed for bankruptcy protection. Despite its subsidiaries not being involved in the misdeeds, Wirecard's remaining business is in serious trouble. The company's Asian operations, which earned almost half of its revenues, are particularly vulnerable, with many clients jumping ship after the scandal broke. The Singapore subsidiary is closely monitored by the Monetary Authority of Singapore, and its future is uncertain.

site_title: ST Index claws back losses to finish 0.72% higher
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 17.85 points higher, or 0.72%, at 2,481.14 on Wednesday, snapping a four-day losing streak. US gains drove the market, but investors remain cautious, with central banks' policy efforts seen as potentially reaching a saturation point. Advancers outpaced decliners 244 to 153, with top performers including CapitaLand Commercial Trust and Singapore Airlines.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Acromec consolidated its stake in Golden Harvest Engineering for S$550,000, taking a 60% interest in 2016. Kepel Corp and DBS will jointly explore new digital opportunities. Del Monte Pacific reported a 9.9% year-on-year increase in sales to US$413.1 million, narrowing net losses to US$3.25 million. GuocoLand sold a Shanghai building for S$122.8 million in cash. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed.

site_title: Indonesia starts developing controversial food estate project
summary: Indonesia has initiated a food estate project spanning 770,000 hectares, aiming to reduce reliance on food imports. The project, led by former rival-turned-minister Prabowo Subianto, will cover rice, corn, and other crops in Central Kalimantan, North Sumatra, and other regions. Green groups warn of the risk of forest fires due to dried-out peatland, while the government seeks to ensure self-sufficiency in food production amid food scarcity warnings by the United Nations. The project aims to produce 1.4 million hectares of crops by 2025, with a focus on cassava and its flour.

site_title: Trial to let top execs skip stay-home notice, take Covid-19 test instead
summary: Singapore authorities announced a pilot program allowing senior executives to skip the 14-day Stay-Home Notice and instead take a Covid-19 test upon return from international travel. The travel pass will permit travel to "quite a wide range of countries" and allow work events within the workplace. The initial phase will have a limited number of passes issued to monitor public health outcomes. The move is part of the gradual easing of Covid-19 control measures, also allowing more employees to return to the workplace with safe-management measures in place.

site_title: PwC, 2 law firms could earn S$17m from Hin Leong's rescue bid
summary: PwC and two law firms, Rajah & Tann and Drew & Napier, could earn up to S$17.3 million in fees from the court-supervised rescue bid for debt-hit Hin Leong Trading. PwC's Goh Thien Phong and Chan Kheng Tek, appointed as interim judicial managers, could receive S$10 million, while Rajah & Tann and Drew & Napier could earn S$3.8 million and S$3.1 million respectively. The fees are charged for over nine months of work on the case involving Singapore's largest oil trader, which has been affected by an oil slump and fraud allegations.

images.alt_text: PwC and legal firms Rajah & Tann and Drew & Napier could pocket up to S$17.3 million in fees from the court-supervised bid to rescue debt-hit Hin Leong Trading (HLT), say court documents.

site_title: OCBC's shift from offshore exposure to sustainable financing no less challenging
summary: OCBC has reduced its exposure to the offshore support vessels (OSV) sector, shifting towards sustainable financing. The bank's sustainable finance portfolio now exceeds its OSV loans, accounting for 5% of its total loan portfolio. Analysts note that sustainable finance is on an upward trajectory but faces challenges, including quantifying green impact and certifying green credentials. OCBC's goal of $25 billion in sustainable finance by 2025 is seen as ambitious, but the bank expects sustainable finance to continue growing despite the OSV sector's decline. Experts warn that banks must increase green and sustainable exposure to mitigate risks.

site_title: Deconstructing learning, reconstructing education
summary: The decision to reopen university campuses amidst the COVID-19 pandemic has sparked controversy, with some institutions suspending in-person classes due to safety concerns. However, others argue that campuses are essential for certain courses, such as nursing and chemistry, which require a physical environment. The question remains whether the non-financial benefits of campus life outweigh the risks, particularly for less privileged students who may struggle with remote learning. As the debate continues, the future of in-person higher education remains uncertain.

site_title: Giant Singapore to slash prices of 650 products by 20% amid pandemic
summary: Dairy Farm International, the parent company of Giant Singapore, has announced a 20% price reduction across 650 products, effective immediately. The move aims to alleviate financial anxiety amid the COVID-19 pandemic and provide customers with more stable prices on essential products. The price reductions will last for a minimum of six months, and the company has also introduced a new house brand, Meadows, which is gaining traction and outperforming leading brands.

site_title: Mentorship programmes that help beneficiaries dream big
summary: A mentorship program called Her Rise Above, founded by Sapna Kewalramani, provides customized one-to-one sessions to women with caregiving responsibilities, enabling them to start and grow home-based businesses. The program has mentored 10 women, with three completing the six- to eight-week program. Participants receive training in business skills and soft skills, and have seen significant growth, with some taking on part-time jobs and selling their products. The program aims to empower women, build financial independence, and contribute to the economy, addressing a need flagged by the National Volunteer & Philanthropy Centre.

site_title: Investors eye Chinese government bonds as WGBI inclusion decision looms
summary: Investors are watching as FTSE Russell is expected to add Chinese government bonds to its World Government Bond Index (WGBI) following an annual review. This move could be a significant step for Chinese bonds, as investors seek safe-haven assets in a zero-interest-rate world. China's recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic and market reforms are creating an ideal backdrop for this inclusion, which could boost the country's bond market and attract more investors. The decision is set to be announced on Thursday.

site_title: 46 years on, inventor of Rubik's Cube still learning from it
summary: Hungarian inventor Erno Rubik, creator of the Rubik's Cube, is still learning from it 46 years after its invention. Born in 1944, Rubik, 76, was a shy architecture professor who spent months struggling to unscramble the cube before solving it in 1974. He initially thought the cube's complexity would make it unsolvable, but its popularity grew to over 350 million cubes sold globally. In his new book, "Cubed," Rubik explores the cube's nature and its impact on people, revealing a deep connection to the puzzle and its evolution over time.

site_title: Singapore deflationary pressure eases in August
summary: Singapore's deflationary pressure eased in August, with core inflation at -0.3% compared to -0.4% in July. This slowdown is attributed to smaller falls in service costs and goods prices. Headline inflation remained flat at -0.4% year-on-year. Economists predict inflation will remain in negative territory for the rest of the year, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) projecting an average inflation of -1 to 0% for the year.

site_title: Del Monte trims Q1 net loss to US$3.5m as Covid-19 spurs sales growth
summary: Del Monte Pacific reported a net loss of US$3.25 million in Q1 2020, down from US$38.3 million in the previous year, driven by a 9.9% year-on-year sales growth to US$413.1 million. The company attributed higher sales to the pandemic, particularly in the US and Philippines, with operating profit rising to US$20.7 million. Del Monte expects to return to profitability in FY2021 and is exploring e-commerce opportunities to strengthen its core business and expand its product portfolio.

site_title: TransferWise lowers fees by 15%; net profit more than doubles
summary: TransferWise, a UK-based payments startup, has reduced its money transfer fees by 15% for its 8 million customers globally, with net profit more than doubling to £21.3 million. The firm's revenue jumped 70% to £302.6 million, driven by growth in its Asia-Pacific business, which is expected to sustain its growth momentum amid macro uncertainties. The fee reduction will impact 76% of customers, with some routes being up to 30% cheaper. TransferWise's CEO expects the Asia-Pacific business to continue growing, with Singapore being the strongest market.

site_title: How did China defeat Covid-19?
summary: China successfully contained the Covid-19 epidemic in just three months, a feat achieved through strong leadership, a comprehensive mechanism, and broad support. The country's swift response, starting from January 2020, was marked by a nationwide lockdown, testing, and contact tracing. China's early action and decisive measures allowed it to contain the outbreak, while many other countries continue to struggle. The country's success serves as a model for other nations to follow in their efforts to combat the pandemic.

site_title: No Signboard's lead independent director resigns; board looking to fill vacancy
summary: The lead independent director of No Signboard Holdings, Ivan Khua, resigned due to "current and future business and other commitments" that may conflict with his duties. The board, which now has only two independent directors, plans to fill the vacancy within two to three months. The company will review its composition and board committee memberships to ensure compliance with corporate governance and Catalist rules. The departure leaves the audit and remuneration committees without the required minimum members.

site_title: Rare 700-year-old Chinese scroll goes under the hammer in Hong Kong
summary: A 700-year-old Chinese scroll titled "Five Drunken Princes Returning On Horseback" from the Yuan Dynasty is set to be auctioned off in Hong Kong for $10-$15.5 million. The scroll, painted by master Ren Renfa, was once owned by Chinese emperors and features five princes and attendants on horseback. It has a history of being part of the Forbidden City collection and has passed through various notable owners, including the last emperor Pu Yi. The scroll will be showcased alongside other rare artworks at an upcoming Sotheby's auction on October 8.

site_title: Singapore maritime bodies seek proposals to electrify harbourcraft
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) and the Singapore Maritime Institute (SMI) have launched a joint call for proposals to electrify harbourcraft in Singapore. The proposal deadline is October 31, with a budget of SGD 9 million from the Maritime GreenFuture Fund to co-fund harbourcraft projects. The aim is to develop commercially ready, fully electric harbourcraft and interoperable shore charging infrastructure, with a focus on scalability and viable business models. The initiative seeks to spur collaborative efforts between industry and academia to drive innovation and transformation in the shipping industry.

site_title: Fed not planning 'major' changes to Main Street programme, Powell says
summary: Fed Chair Jerome Powell stated that the Main Street Lending Program will not undergo significant changes. Despite initial concerns, companies have only used the program "modestly," and credit is readily available to them. Powell acknowledged that if the economy worsens, the program may take on a heavier load. The Fed's lending and corporate bond purchase programs aimed at Main Street companies and local governments have been criticized for their limited impact, with Democratic Representative Jim Clyburn calling for the Fed to use its power to help regular people and small businesses.

site_title: US: Nike lifts S&P 500, Dow ahead of business activity data
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 opening higher, driven by Nike's record high following a strong quarterly earnings report. The Nasdaq Composite dropped, however. Investors await domestic business activity data to gauge the pace of an economic rebound.

site_title: US Justice Department's case against Google to focus on search engine dominance
summary: The US Department of Justice is planning to focus its lawsuit against Google on the company's dominance in internet search, potentially triggering separate lawsuits from US states over its control in other business segments. The DOJ will argue that Google's search engine harms rivals and consumers, according to presentations to state attorneys-general. This move could lead to a wave of lawsuits against Google in other areas, such as advertising and e-commerce.

site_title: The bigger picture behind illicit money flows
summary: A recent investigation by BuzzFeed News and the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists (ICIJ) analyzed over 2,100 suspicious transaction reports (SARs) filed by global banks between 1999 and 2017, revealing nearly US$2 trillion in suspicious transactions. The report highlights the need for regulators to tighten relationships with banks to detect and prevent money laundering. To balance false positives with the risk of penalizing legitimate customers, regulators should focus on improving network analyses and data analytics. The investigation's findings align with ongoing efforts to combat money laundering, including Singapore's regulatory framework and the use of machine learning by local banks to identify red flags.

site_title: BT boss to lead UK telco-equipment vendor task force
summary: Britain has established a task force to advise on opening its telecoms equipment market, following China's Huawei's ban from participating in the UK's 5G rollout. Former BT boss Ian Livingston will lead the task force, which aims to boost competition and build a more diverse telecoms supply chain. The task force will include industry experts and will work closely with operators, vendors, and suppliers to create a strategy for the sector. The goal is to create a more competitive market, with the government committed to delivering "gigabit-capable" broadband nationwide by 2025.

site_title: US business activity dips in September
summary: US business activity dipped in September, with the IHS Markit US Composite PMI Output Index falling to 54.4 from 54.6 in August. The services sector retreated, while manufacturing activity accelerated, offsetting the decline. The drop in the index suggests a loss of economic momentum, with expectations of a rebound in GDP growth in the third quarter. Economists call for another aid package to support the fragile recovery, citing uncertainty over the COVID-19 pandemic and the presidential election.

site_title: Thailand to start legal action against Facebook, Google, Twitter over content
summary: Thailand's digital ministry plans to file complaints against Facebook, Twitter, and Google for ignoring court-issued takedown orders. The move comes after the US companies missed deadlines to comply fully with requests to remove content. This marks Thailand's first cases against major internet firms. Digital minister Puttipong Punnakanta stated that the ministry sent warnings twice but received no compliance, prompting the legal action. The cybercrime police will be notified, and the complaints will be filed this week.

site_title: Mars drops Uncle Ben's brand image after racial stereotyping row
summary: Mars is changing the name and branding of its Uncle Ben's rice products after criticism for promoting racial stereotypes. The company will drop the logo of an elderly African-American man wearing a bow tie and replace it with a new orange package featuring the name "Ben's Original" in blue font. This move follows similar actions by PepsiCo and ConAgra Brands, which have also dropped racially insensitive branding amid a national debate over racial inequality in the US. The new packaging is set to hit stores in 2021.

site_title: Cross-border efforts and guidelines key to combating financial crime
summary: Global efforts to combat financial crime intensified after the 2001 World Trade Centre attack, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore issuing guidelines for financial institutions. A leaked review of suspicious activity reports reveals over $2 trillion in suspicious transactions between 2000 and 2017, with some institutions continuing to allow illicit flows despite filing reports. The Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN) received just 0.02% of the estimated 12 million suspicious activity reports filed during this period. The findings highlight the need for cross-border data sharing and best practice guidelines to combat emerging financial crimes.

site_title: Lender Keppel Corp extends KrisEnergy restructuring deadline to end-November
summary: Keppel Corp has agreed to a US$10.8 million drawdown on its credit-facility agreement with KrisEnergy, extending the deadline for the troubled upstream oil-and-gas group's debt restructuring to November 30. The move aims to support KrisEnergy, preserve the development project of offshore oil-and-gas asset Cambodia Block A, and avoid adverse consequences associated with not achieving first oil production by December 31, 2020. The company's shares have been suspended since August 2019.

site_title: With Chinese mining operations stymied, AsiaPhos mulls business restructuring
summary: AsiaPhos, a phosphate miner listed on the Catalist, is considering a business restructuring exercise due to regulatory issues in China halting its mining operations. The potential restructuring may involve buying other businesses and could transform the company into a more suitable listing platform. The board warned that negotiations with the Chinese government could take years and require substantial funding. The company's shares remain unchanged, and shareholders are advised to exercise caution as there is no certainty on the restructuring and potential acquisition.

site_title: Maersk to ship cargo between UAE and Israel
summary: Maersk, the world's number one container line, will transport ocean cargo between the UAE and Israel, following the establishment of full ties between the two countries. This move is a sign of business opening up, as Israel and the UAE lifted the boycott on trade between the Gulf Arab state and Israel. Maersk will use its existing services to connect UAE ports with Israeli ports, including Haifa and Ashdod. This partnership is part of growing economic collaboration between the two countries, with DP World also exploring a direct shipping line between the two Middle East nations.

images.alt_text: Danish shipping giant Maersk said it will now transport ocean cargo between the United Arab Emirates and Israel, a further sign of business opening up after the two countries established full ties.

site_title: Citigroup pledges over US$1b to combat racial inequality
summary: Citigroup has pledged over $1 billion to combat racial inequality through a three-year initiative. The program will provide greater access to banking and credit for communities of color, increase investment in Black-owned businesses, and expand homeownership among Black Americans. The move comes amid a national reckoning on race in the US, following police killings of Black Americans, and is part of a broader effort by US companies to address economic and racial inequality, with nearly $2 billion pledged so far.

site_title: GuocoLand to sell Shanghai building at post-tax loss in 610m yuan deal
summary: MAINBOARD-LISTED developer GuocoLand is selling a building in Shanghai, Guoson Mall, for 610 million yuan (S$124.3 million) in a loss-making deal. The property had a net book value of 576 million yuan, resulting in a expected net loss of about S$13.5 million due to taxes. The sale was made on a willing buyer, willing seller basis, and includes a cultural centre and underground commercial area.

site_title: Study scheme document before deciding how to vote on Sabana-ESR Reit merger: Sabana Reit's trustee
summary: Sabana Reit's trustee has urged unitholders to review a forthcoming scheme document before voting on the planned merger with ESR-Reit. The document will include an independent financial adviser's opinion on the deal's terms. The trustee has addressed concerns over potential conflicts of interest, stating the Monetary Authority of Singapore does not prohibit owning stakes in two Reit managers managing the same property class. Quarz Capital Management has opposed the deal, citing an implied offer price of 37.7 Singapore cents per unit as too low. The merger is expected to proceed after a formal offer.

site_title: Hyundai discussing concessions with EU regulators over Daewoo deal
summary: Hyundai Heavy Industries Holdings is discussing concessions with EU regulators over its $1.8 billion bid for Daewoo, amid concerns it could inflate prices and reduce competition in cargo shipbuilding. The deal would grant Hyundai a 21% market share, reinforcing its top position in the sector. The European Commission, which launched a full-scale investigation in December, declined to comment. The move aims to address overcapacity in the sector, with rivals in China and Singapore making inroads. Hyundai's bid is seen as a response to the sector's challenges.

site_title: ST Engineering dissolves inactive Saudi Arabia naval joint venture
summary: ST Engineering has dissolved its inactive Saudi Arabia naval joint venture, ZHR Marine, due to lack of active projects. The joint-venture, formed with Raytheon and Zamil Group, had an issued capital of 3 million riyals. The liquidation is not expected to significantly impact ST Engineering's financials. The company cited ZHR Marine's inactivity as the reason for the dissolution, which will result in a loss of S$1.08 million.

site_title: Thai royalists march against calls for amending constitution
summary: Hundreds of Thai royalists marched to parliament on Wednesday to oppose calls for constitutional changes, citing concerns that the proposed amendments would benefit politicians and undermine the monarchy. The protests, which drew tens of thousands of people last weekend, seek to change the 2017 constitution, which was engineered by former junta leader Prayuth Chan-ocha to ensure his continued prime minister position. The parliament is set to consider amending the constitution on Thursday, with protesters planning to rally outside.

images.alt_text: Hundreds of Thai royalists marched to parliament on Wednesday to oppose calls from anti-government protesters for changes to the constitution as the assembly met to consider amending it.

site_title: Ant plans US$17.5b Hong Kong IPO, no cornerstones
summary: Ant Group plans to raise US$17.5 billion in its Hong Kong IPO, aiming for one of the largest equity deals in the financial hub. The fintech giant won't seek cornerstone investors, betting on strong demand. Ant plans to issue 11-15% of its shares in the Hong Kong sale, with the remaining 85-90% going to Shanghai. The company is seeking a valuation of US$250 billion, with a potential IPO size of US$35 billion. Ant received approval from regulators in Shanghai and is seeking a listing hearing in Hong Kong, with a possible listing date of October.

site_title: World's workers lost US$3.5t in wages amid pandemic: UN
summary: The coronavirus pandemic has led to a significant loss of wages for global workers, with the International Labour Organization (ILO) estimating a US$3.5 trillion drop in earnings, equivalent to 5.5% of the global GDP. By mid-year, global working hours had declined by 17.3% compared to last December, resulting in nearly 500 million full-time jobs lost. The ILO warns that the situation could worsen if second waves of infections bring tighter restrictions, and urges policymakers to balance economic recovery with controlling the pandemic.

images.alt_text: The coronavirus pandemic is taking a heavier toll on jobs than previously feared, the UN said Wednesday, with hundreds of millions of jobs lost and workers suffering a "massive" drop in earnings.

site_title: Muhyiddin calls for stability as Anwar claims majority
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin urged stability as opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim claimed a majority of lawmakers to form a government. Anwar stated he would meet the king after recovering from treatment, while Muhyiddin's administration remains firm, citing the need for due process. A joint statement from parties supporting Muhyiddin reaffirmed his legitimacy, and he announced additional stimulus measures to boost the economy. The situation remains fluid, with lawmakers calling for early polls to settle months of uncertainty.

site_title: Accordia Golf Trust manager U-turns on currency hedging for divestment deal
summary: Accordia Golf Trust has entered into a foreign-exchange forward contract to hedge 38.7% of the purchase price of its golf courses, valued at S$327.8 million. The manager initially stated it wouldn't hedge, but now believes it's necessary to maximize returns for unitholders. The contract locks in a favorable yen-to-Singapore dollar exchange rate and mitigates against potential yen softening, which could reduce distributions. The divestment deal, worth 65.2 billion yen, is set to be completed on September 29.

site_title: Credit Suisse, UBS held tie-up talks backed by both chairmen
summary: Switzerland's two largest banks, UBS and Credit Suisse, held tie-up talks that received backing from both chairmen, Axel Weber and Gionatha De Santos, respectively, in discussions earlier this year. However, talks have since stagnated. A merger of equals was considered, with staff working under Weber examining the possibility. Both banks declined to comment on the matter.

site_title: Fragrance Group to get new CFO on Nov 2
summary: Fragrance Group, a Mainboard-listed property player, will appoint Angela Lim as its new CFO on Nov 2, replacing Chen Loong Mey who is resigning on Oct 12. Mey, 43, has been CFO since Aug 2017, and her departure was approved by the board based on Lim's qualifications and experience. The company's shares closed up 0.1 Singapore cent, or 0.88%, at S$0.115 following the announcement.

site_title: Eurozone business growth stagnates as virus resurges
summary: Eurozone economic activity stagnated in September due to a resurgence in the coronavirus, with the PMI index falling to 50.1 points, barely above the 50-point level indicating growth. Germany led the recovery, but at a slower rate, while France's services sector saw business activity deteriorate for the first time in four months. The rest of the eurozone, including Spain and Italy, suffered a rapid slowdown, with staff cuts at a slower pace. The recovery appears to be grinding to a halt, with optimism relying on falling Covid-19 infection rates.

site_title: CSC Holdings' patented construction site solutions trim costs, raise productivity
summary: CSC Holdings, a groundworks engineering firm, has developed two patented solutions to trim costs and boost productivity. The mobile site reporting (MSR) system digitizes site data, achieving 25% savings on manpower and 150% improvement in site recording efficiency. The reinforced concrete (RC) pile handler increases pile handling by 50% and saves 71% on manpower and 73% on pile installation costs. The solutions, developed with $370,000 in support from Building and Construction Authority schemes, aim to build resilience in the face of the COVID-19 pandemic and its impact on foreign workers.

site_title: Singapore mulls region-free business travel pass for senior executives
summary: Singapore is considering a region-free business travel pass for senior executives who need to travel regularly for official purposes. The pilot program would allow these executives to travel to "quite a wide range of countries" without a 14-day Stay-Home Notice, instead opting for a Covid-19 test upon return. The pass will not supersede existing travel restrictions and will be announced by the Ministry of Trade and Industry. This move aims to ease measures to control the Covid-19 pandemic and allow more employees to return to the workplace with safe-management measures in place.

site_title: LHN takes 40% stake in Bukit Timah Shopping Centre car park for S$16.2m
summary: LHN Ltd, a real estate management service provider, has acquired a 40% stake in Bukit Timah Shopping Centre's car park for S$16.2 million through a joint-venture company. The leasehold property has 381 parking spaces with a remaining tenure of 862 years. LHN aims to increase income sources and grow its car park facilities management business. The JV company is held by LHN Parking (GMT) subsidiary, GMTC vehicle, and SM Venture, with the remaining 60% stake held by the latter. This deal expands LHN's portfolio of properties.

site_title: Neo Group defends diversification plans, debt levels ahead of shareholder meeting
summary: Neo Group is diversifying into property development, investment, and management through a joint venture with Catalist-listed Boldtek, aiming for new revenue streams. The company's board defends its plans, citing strong operating cash flows and reduced gearing. Neo Group's core business will focus on widening its catering market share and expanding its food manufacturing business, with plans to raise capacity and introduce new products. The company faces no liquidity or debt-refinancing issues and expects to move into new premises by end-2021.

site_title: Ex-maid Parti Liyani seeks court nod for inquiry against two prosecutors
summary: Ex-maid Parti Liyani is seeking a court's permission for an inquiry into the conduct of two prosecutors, Tan Wee Hao and Tan Yanying, who handled her case in which she was acquitted of theft charges. The inquiry would precede a disciplinary tribunal to determine if there are grounds for disciplinary action against the prosecutors. Ms. Parti's lawyer filed the complaint after a High Court judge overturned her conviction, citing issues with the case handling, including a break in the chain of custody of evidence and statements taken without an interpreter.

images.alt_text: The former maid of prominent businessman Liew Mun Leong is seeking the court's permission for an inquiry into the conduct of the two prosecutors in her case.

site_title: J&J kicks off final study of single-shot Covid-19 vaccine in 60,000 volunteers
summary: Johnson & Johnson has started a Phase III trial of its single-shot Covid-19 vaccine, involving 60,000 volunteers, in an effort to simplify distribution and administration. The trial aims to test the vaccine's effectiveness in preventing moderate to severe Covid-19 after a single dose. Results are expected by the end of the year or early next year, and the company plans to manufacture up to 1 billion doses in 2021. The trial will be overseen by an independent monitoring board to ensure vaccine safety and effectiveness.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's core inflation eased slightly to -0.3% in August, remaining in negative territory for the seventh straight month. Esco Group plans to add 100 positions in Singapore to fuel expansion, while Eagle Hospitality Trust scraps all master leases due to defaults. Elite Commercial Reit sees rising demand for UK properties due to tenant hiring plans. ST Engineering dissolves an inactive Saudi Arabia naval joint venture. The Straits Times Index rose 0.72% to 2,481.14, recovering from previous losses.

site_title: Richard Li's FWD plans up to US$3b Hong Kong IPO
summary: FWD Group, backed by billionaire Richard Li, plans to raise up to US$3 billion in a Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO), making it Asia's largest insurance IPO since Japan Post Holdings in 2015. The IPO is expected to further boost Hong Kong's IPO market, dominated by Chinese companies. FWD, founded in 2013, has US$50.9 billion in assets under management and over 7.5 million customers across Asia. Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan, Morgan Stanley, and HSBC are among the banks selected to work on the potential share sale.

site_title: Malaysia unveils additional RM10 billion economic stimulus measures
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin announced an additional RM10 billion economic stimulus package to aid industries and citizens affected by the coronavirus pandemic. The package includes RM7 billion in cash aid, assistance for small businesses, and a wage subsidy scheme. The announcement comes as Muhyiddin faces a challenge from opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim, who secured a strong majority in parliament to form a new government. The stimulus measures aim to support the country's economic recovery amidst the pandemic.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 9.30 points to 1,496.48. The market saw a significant decline in trading volume, with 8.453 billion lots worth RM4.325 billion. The number of losers outpaced gainers 896 to 246.

site_title: COEs end mixed in latest tender as premiums stay at their highest levels this year
summary: COE premiums remained at their highest levels this year in the latest tender, with certificates of entitlement for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp closing at S$38,504. Commercial vehicle COE ended at S$28,589, and motorcycle premium finished at S$7,331. The mixed results were attributed to new car launches and dealer promotions, which kept premiums buoyant despite a smaller supply of COEs.

site_title: JPMorgan to move 200b euros of assets to Germany in Brexit shift
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co is relocating approximately 200 billion euros of assets from the UK to Frankfurt, Germany, as a result of the UK's exit from the European Union. The move will make JPMorgan one of the largest banks in Germany, with a potential boost to its balance sheet. The relocation is part of the bank's efforts to strengthen its operations in Germany and expand its presence in investment banking, corporate banking, and wealth management. The move is expected to be completed by the end of the year.

site_title: CDCs vital in times of crisis, says PM Lee at swearing-in of mayors
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong commended the Community Development Councils (CDCs) for their efforts during the Covid-19 outbreak, citing their role in providing financial assistance and support to households and small businesses. The CDCs have benefited over 8,000 hawkers and enterprises with S$20 million in vouchers. Lee urged the newly sworn-in mayors to build on these efforts, emphasizing the need for "strong, passionate leaders" to fulfill their duties.

site_title: Europe: Stocks extend recovery ahead of PMIs; Adidas jumps
summary: European stocks rebounded 0.7% ahead of business activity data, with the FTSE 100 jumping 0.9% and the DAX rising 1%. Adidas surged 4% after Nike's strong earnings and forecast. Investors await data on the euro zone and UK, amid concerns of a resurgence in Covid-19 cases and potential economic recovery stalling.

site_title: Former Ferrari chief to replace Carey as F1 CEO: reports
summary: Former Ferrari team principal Stefano Domenicali is set to become the new CEO of Formula One, replacing Chase Carey. Domenicali, 55, will take over after Carey's early departure following the US group Liberty Media's takeover in 2017. The news was confirmed to team bosses, with Carey remaining as chairman in some form. Domenicali previously led Ferrari from 2007 to 2014 and has held senior management roles at Audi and Lamborghini. He will oversee the sport's new five-year commercial deal, the Concorde Agreement, which guarantees motorsport's sustainable future.

site_title: STI claws back losses from previous days' fall, rises 0.72%
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.72% to 2,481.14, snapping a four-day losing streak, following US gains. Key performers included CapitaLand Commercial Trust and Singapore Airlines, which both rose 3.0%. However, investors remain cautious, with market strategist Pan Jingyi citing uncertainty over Fed talks and economic data. The US Federal Reserve's central bankers had expressed caution on the economy, which may impact Asian markets.

site_title: Bumpy recovery ahead for Malaysia: DBS
summary: Malaysia is expected to experience a bumpy recovery due to its -5.5% GDP growth in 2020, the worst since the Asian Financial Crisis. However, a 6.0% GDP growth in 2021 is projected, driven by the global recovery and low base. Inflation is expected to average -1.1% and the overnight policy rate will remain at 1.75%. Exports and industrial output have recovered, and business loan growth has picked up with government support measures. Domestic demand is still declining, but tentative signs of bottoming out are emerging.

images.alt_text: On the domestic demand front, overall business and consumer sentiments have declined due to the dire economic outlook and poor employment prospects. However, there are tentative signs of bottoming out.

site_title: Singapore consumers move towards cashless, cautious spending: StanChart poll
summary: Singapore consumers are shifting towards cashless and cautious spending amid the COVID-19 pandemic, with 50% preferring online purchases over in-person card or cash payments, up from 35% before the outbreak. Nearly eight in 10 respondents expect the country to go fully cashless in the next decade, and about four in five said the pandemic has made them more careful with their spending. Consumers are prioritizing essentials and digital devices over wants, and are more likely to track their spending and use budgeting tools.

site_title: vCargo Cloud launches platform to digitalise global trade, improve SME access
summary: vCargo Cloud has launched GUUD, a digital trade platform aimed at improving global trade access and processes for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) through digitalisation. The platform follows the UN/CEFACT Buy-Ship-Pay model, streamlining trade processes like compliance, shipping, and payments on one integrated platform. GUUD builds on vCargo Cloud's existing initiatives, including its logistics platform and trade finance portal, and is supported by 16 countries, including Singapore and Indonesia. The platform seeks to bring stakeholders closer together to improve access to global markets for SMEs.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise most in over two months on rate-cut bets
summary: Australian shares rose 2.4% on Wednesday, the largest gain in over two months, as investors expect the Reserve Bank of Australia to cut interest rates in two weeks. The ASX 200 index snapped a four-session losing streak. Financial sector stocks, including the big-four banks, surged 1.9-2.9%. Tech stocks and buy-now-pay-later sector stocks also gained, with Afterpay jumping 2.9%. The central bank held its official cash rate at a record low but hinted at further easing amid the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Keppel, DBS ink deal to work on 5G and other digital business solutions for clients
summary: Keppel Corp and DBS have signed a memorandum of understanding to explore new digital business solutions, including 5G banking solutions and digital supply chain financing. The three initiatives, set to be rolled out this year, aim to improve services for customers and suppliers. The collaborations are not expected to significantly impact Keppel's financials.

site_title: PwC, two law firms could earn S$17m in fees to rescue troubled Hin Leong
summary: PwC and two law firms, Rajah & Tann and Drew & Napier, could earn up to S$17.3 million in fees for their roles in rescuing debt-hit Hin Leong Trading. PwC's Goh Thien Phong and Chan Kheng Tek, appointed as interim judicial managers, received S$10 million, while Rajah & Tann's fees could reach S$3.8 million and Drew & Napier's estimated at S$3.1 million. The lucrative fees are attributed to the complexity of HLT's case, including allegations of fraud and misconduct.

site_title: NutryFarm gets SGX query after share price doubles
summary: The board of NutryFarm International, a mainboard-listed technology provider, denied knowledge of undisclosed recent developments that led to its share price doubling. The company's shares surged to an intra-day high of 12.1 Singapore cents after trading resumed, prompting queries from the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The unusual trading activity occurred despite the company's directors stating they are unaware of any undisclosed developments.

site_title: BlackRock, Sands Capital lead US$300m investment in Byju's
summary: Byju's, an Indian online education startup, raised approximately US$300 million in funding from BlackRock, Sands Capital, and Alkeon Capital, valuing the company at around US$11 billion. Existing investors, including Tiger Global and General Atlantic, also participated in the round. This investment comes as the country's pandemic challenges spread and closes schools, increasing demand for digital learning tools. Byju's aims to simplify math and science concepts for students through games and videos, with over 70 million registered users and 4.5 million paid subscribers.

site_title: Ellen DeGeneres is selling US$10m of art in Hamptons: sources
summary: Television host Ellen DeGeneres is selling over $10 million worth of art in the Hamptons, according to sources. The art pieces, including works by Alexander Calder, Jean-Michel Basquiat, and Francois-Xavier Lalanne, were sold through private dealers in East Hampton. The sales come as DeGeneres faces controversy surrounding allegations of a toxic work environment on her show. The items, including a Basquiat painting, have already found new homes, with some priced between $500,000 and $1 million.

site_title: IMDA partners DBS, OCBC, UOB on e-invoicing through banking solutions
summary: The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) has partnered DBS, OCBC, and UOB to develop banking solutions for e-invoicing through the PayNow e-payment system. The partnership aims to enhance business efficiency, reduce costs, and facilitate seamless payments. With the nationwide e-invoicing network, InvoiceNow, now on board 25,000 companies have registered, up from 1,000 in 2020. The three banks expect the launch to drive greater adoption of e-invoicing, creating a virtuous circle of digital solutions.

site_title: Crisis-hit Qantas ends 30-year Wallabies sponsorship
summary: Qantas has ended its 30-year sponsorship of the Australian rugby team, the Wallabies, due to the financial crisis caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The airline cited the cost of sponsorships as a major factor in its decision, with annual payments reportedly worth A$5 million. The move is a significant blow to Rugby Australia, which lost almost A$10 million last year and axed 47 workers. Qantas will continue to support Australian sports teams and athletes through in-kind support, such as flights and Olympic and Paralympic athlete support.

site_title: E-commerce firm Zall to expand Singapore operations
summary: Zall Smart Commerce Group, a Chinese e-commerce firm, is expanding its Singapore operations and investing in the country's business-to-business e-commerce sector. The company plans to increase its recruitment efforts and expand its Commodities Intelligence Centre (CIC) platform, which has seen significant growth despite the COVID-19 pandemic, with $1 billion in sales revenues in the first half of 2020. Zall aims to enable small and medium enterprises to trade more freely across the region, with a focus on building resilient supply chains.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the day with gains, driven by a healthy Wall Street lead, despite growing concerns about spiking coronavirus infections. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.11%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained. The gains were attributed to a positive US market, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Esco Group will add 100 positions in Singapore to fuel expansion
summary: Esco Group, a Singapore-based life sciences company, plans to hire around 100 positions to fuel expansion in the biotech sector. The new hires will support research and development efforts through Esco Ventures X, its incubation arm. The positions will be filled in various fields, including biomedical research, chemistry, and manufacturing. This move comes after the company achieved a 30% surge in top-line growth due to the pandemic. Esco Group aims to widen its reach in the biotech sector, following successful deals with Takeda Pharmaceutical and other biotech startups.

site_title: Thai central bank holds off on further stimulus, slightly upgrades 2020 GDP forecast
summary: Thailand's central bank kept its key interest rate unchanged at 0.50% for a third consecutive meeting, as expected. The Bank of Thailand upgraded its 2020 GDP forecast slightly to a 7.8% contraction, but still expects the economy to take at least two years to return to pre-pandemic levels. Private consumption and investment are expected to improve, but the tourism industry remains severely impacted by a ban on foreign tourists. The central bank remains ready to use monetary policy tools if necessary and emphasizes the need for fiscal policy to reignite the economy.

site_title: At least 380 whales dead in Australia mass stranding
summary: At least 380 long-finned pilot whales have died in a mass stranding in Macquarie Harbour, Tasmania, Australia. Rescuers have freed around 50 whales, with 30 remaining alive. The incident is the largest mass stranding ever recorded in Tasmania and likely the biggest in Australia's history. The cause of the stranding remains unknown, but experts suggest it may have been due to the whales going off track after feeding or following a straying individual. Officials are now focusing on disposing of the whale carcasses and monitoring the remaining survivors.

site_title: China will boost investment in strategic industries: state planner
summary: China plans to boost investment in strategic industries, including core tech sectors like 5G, AI, and chips, to ensure stable supply chains. The National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) also aims to accelerate development of new materials and vaccine innovation. This move aims to drive economic growth and address supply chain risks.

site_title: Singapore core inflation rises marginally to -0.3% in August
summary: Singapore's core inflation rose marginally to -0.3% in August, its seventh consecutive month in negative territory. The moderation in decline was attributed to smaller falls in services, retail, and other goods costs. Headline inflation, which includes all items, remained at -0.4% year-on-year, unchanged from the previous month. Economists expect core inflation to average between -1 and zero percent in 2020, with external sources of inflation remaining benign due to weak global demand and low oil prices.

site_title: Gold may hit record before year end on election risk: Citi
summary: Citigroup predicts gold prices may hit a record before the year-end due to election uncertainty in the US, which could lead to increased volatility and demand for the metal. The bank's forecast suggests a surge of over $200 for bullion futures from current levels. Gold prices have been affected by the US presidential election, with the election day set for November 3, and Citi's outlook reflects rising investor concern about the outcome, particularly with the potential nomination of Donald Trump.

site_title: Indonesia starts developing controversial food estate project
summary: Indonesia has begun developing a massive food estate project spanning over 770,000 hectares to increase self-sufficiency in rice and other crops. The project, led by former rival Prabowo Subianto, aims to curb reliance on food imports and follows a failed attempt by former President Suharto in the 1990s. Critics warn of the risk of devastating forest fires due to dried-out peatland, while the government seeks to ensure food security amid the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Hot stocks: Medtecs, Aspen sustain rallies amid active trading
summary: Medtecs International and Aspen (Group) Holdings saw significant gains in their share prices amid active trading on the Singapore Exchange. Medtecs rose 9.3% to S$1.29, while Aspen gained 10.8% to 20.5 cents, driven by news of Aspen's glove unit appointment and production capacity increase. The stock price uptrend began on Monday, with Medtecs increasing by over 20% for the week. Aspen is also constructing a glove manufacturing facility in Malaysia, targeting completion by March 2021.

site_title: Paytm exec says India's secondary listing plan would be undue burden
summary: A senior executive at Paytm, Madhur Deora, expressed concerns that India's plan to require secondary listing on an Indian stock exchange for companies opting to list overseas first would unfairly penalize Indian firms. Deora stated that companies should be allowed to list wherever they want, benefiting both the companies and the digital ecosystem. This comes as India works on forging rules to enable Indian startups to list overseas and access deeper capital pools.

site_title: BOJ's Kuroda vows to keep firms funded amid economic uncertainties
summary: Bank of Japan governor Haruhiko Kuroda has vowed to continue supporting corporate funding amid economic uncertainties, particularly due to the ongoing coronavirus crisis. Kuroda stated that the BOJ will monitor developments carefully and take additional easing steps if necessary, potentially extending the March 2021 deadline for programs aimed at pumping money to companies hit by Covid-19. The BOJ has kept monetary policy steady and upgraded its view on the economy, but warned of risks such as the pandemic's fallout, US-China tensions, and protectionism, which may impact corporate and household growth expectations.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan (BOJ) governor Haruhiko Kuroda said the central bank will continue to work closely with the government to ease corporate funding strains, as the coronavirus crisis keeps the economic outlook highly uncertain.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks recoup early losses on tech gains
summary: South Korean stocks closed flat on Wednesday, recouping losses in the afternoon session, despite global economic recovery concerns. The Kospi index rose 0.03% to 2,333.24, driven by tech gains from Samsung and SK Hynix. The won edged up, while the benchmark bond yield fell. The UK tightened social restrictions, stoking worries about lockdowns and the global economy. South Korea reported 110 new coronavirus cases, and a supplementary budget was approved to aid households and small businesses. Foreigners were net sellers of 58.1 billion won worth of shares.

site_title: Citi closes market making business in retail options: FT
summary: Citigroup Inc has closed its market making business in retail options, citing an inability to compete in a technology arms race. The decision was made at the start of last month, with the bank maintaining its market making operations for institutional investors and high-net-worth customers. Citi pulled out due to the challenges in providing fast and reliable services on Wall Street, according to the Financial Times.

site_title: Amazon launches climate-friendly programme to help shop for sustainable products
summary: Amazon has launched a climate-friendly programme to help customers shop for sustainable products. The programme, called "Climate Pledge Friendly", labels over 25,000 products, including groceries, electronics, and fashion items. The move is part of Amazon's goal to be net carbon neutral by 2040, as announced by CEO Jeff Bezos. The company will also invest $2 billion in the Climate Pledge Fund to support sustainable development and reduce climate change. This initiative comes after Amazon faced pressure from environmental activists and employees to address climate change.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines defers payments on RM1.5b Islamic bonds
summary: Malaysia Airlines has deferred payments on RM1.5 billion Islamic bonds by six months, from September 30 to March 31, 2021. The move was made to address the airline's financial challenges amid the COVID-19 pandemic. CIMB Investment Bank, the facility agent, issued the deferral notices on behalf of Malaysia Airlines. Payments will resume on the next periodic distribution date, March 31 next year.

site_title: 12 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, with one in the community
summary: Singapore reported 12 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 57,639. One case is a community case, a work pass holder, while four are imported cases under stay-home notices. No new community cases were reported for the second day in a row. 21 cases were reported on Tuesday, including 20 in dormitories and one imported case. 57,247 patients have recovered, and 37 remain hospitalized. Globally, the outbreak has infected over 31.7 million people and claimed over 974,000 lives.

site_title: Asia: Markets struggle again as virus trumps Wall Street bounce
summary: Asian markets struggled on Wednesday, mirroring US losses despite a Wall Street rally, as concerns over the virus and economic recovery persisted. The US Federal Reserve warned of a slower recovery if no stimulus package is passed, while US stocks broke an extended run of losses on Tuesday. New containment measures in the UK and China's ongoing tensions with the US added to the gloom, with Asian markets drifting down, except for Jakarta, Bangkok, and Wellington.

site_title: UK finance firms revert to home working as government advice shifts
summary: UK banks and insurers are reversing their plans to return to office-based work, following the UK government's shift in guidance. Barclays is ordering 1,000 staff to work from home, while Societe Generale is adapting its position in line with government guidance. This decision comes after many employees tried to return to the office just days ago. The changes reflect the ongoing impact of the pandemic on workplace arrangements and the need for flexibility in the finance sector.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks edge down after long weekend
summary: Tokyo stocks closed marginally lower on Wednesday, influenced by a long weekend and concerns over rising coronavirus cases in Europe and the US. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.06% to 23,346.49, while the Topix index fell 0.13% to 1,644.25. The declines followed a positive trend in other markets, including the US, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged towards fresh records despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality Trust to scrap all master leases after 'multitude of defaults'
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) has issued notices of termination to its 18 properties, citing "multitude of defaults" by master lessees under master lease agreements. The termination is set to occur 10 days after notice delivery. EHT's managers described the current arrangement as "unviable". The move comes after a series of defaults by the master lessees, which are part of EHT sponsor Urban Commons.

site_title: Sony slides 2% as Microsoft flashes cash to boost games lineup
summary: Sony's shares slid 2% after Microsoft announced a $7.5 billion acquisition of Bethesda Softworks, bolstering its games lineup and cloud gaming expansion. The deal helps Microsoft close the gap with Sony's PlayStation 5, which analysts expect to outsell Xbox consoles in November. The acquisition also brings titles like "Deathloop" and "Ghostwire: Tokyo" to Xbox. Industry analysts predict further consolidation as established players like Amazon and Google move into gaming.

site_title: Malaysia's August CPI falls 1.4% y-o-y, more than forecast
summary: Malaysia's consumer price index (CPI) fell 1.4% in August, exceeding the forecasted 1.2% contraction, marking the sixth consecutive month of decline. The drop was primarily driven by lower retail fuel prices, with the transport sector index falling 9.9% on-year.

site_title: Fujifilm's Avigan shown to be effective in Phase Three trial for Covid-19
summary: Fujifilm Holdings announced that its Avigan drug has shown effectiveness in reducing viral loads and symptoms of COVID-19 patients in a Phase Three clinical study. The study, involving 156 patients, found that those treated with Avigan improved after 11.9 days, compared to 14.7 days for a placebo group. Regulatory approval in Japan is now likely, following months of delays. The results have boosted Fujifilm shares, which jumped 4.5% in Tokyo, and the Japanese government has pledged to donate Avigan to countries on request.

site_title: Malaysia's Smart Glove picks banks for RM1b IPO
summary: Smart Glove, a Malaysian disposable glove maker, has selected banks Affin Hwang Investment Bank and RHB Bank for its planned RM1 billion initial public offering (IPO). The offering could take place next year, with the company joining peers like Harps Holdings in seeking listings in Malaysia. Founded in 1994, Smart Glove makes gloves for various industries, including medical and food and beverage, and has operations in Malaysia and Indonesia. Details on the IPO, including size and timing, are still being deliberated.

site_title: Australia preliminary retail sales down 4.2% in Aug, Victoria hit hard
summary: Australia's preliminary retail sales fell 4.2% in August from the previous month, with Victoria bearing the brunt of the downturn due to a strict lockdown. Retail sales declined across most states, except for food retailing. Excluding Victoria, the rest of the country's retail trade fell 1.5% in August. The decline was largely attributed to the lockdown in Victoria, which saw many businesses shut down.

site_title: Walmart plans to hire 20,000 holiday staff to meet online demand
summary: Walmart plans to hire 20,000 holiday staff to meet online demand ahead of the US holidays. The company, aiming to compete with Amazon, will offer starting hourly rates of $15.75, increasing to $23.75. This is Walmart's first large seasonal hiring in five years. The retailer expects a surge in online shopping and has introduced a subscription-delivery service, Walmart+, to match Amazon Prime. Walmart will also increase its availability of popular items, including toys, pet beds, and outdoor gear.

images.alt_text: Walmart will recruit more than 20,000 workers ahead of the US holidays to prepare for an expected surge in online shopping amid the pandemic, its first large seasonal hiring in five years.

site_title: Yuan weakens as renewed virus fears buoy US dollar
summary: China's yuan weakened against the US dollar on Wednesday, reaching its weakest level in a week, amid renewed global concern over a new wave of coronavirus cases and strong US housing data. The yuan opened at 6.7920 per dollar, 141 pips weaker than Tuesday's close, and touched a high of 93.99 on the Thomson Reuters/HKEX Global CNY index, near a five-month high. Despite this, analysts predict the yuan will strengthen before the end of the year, with UBS raising its forecast to 6.7 per dollar from 6.8.

site_title: Bank Indonesia policy to remain accommodative amid limited recovery
summary: Bank Indonesia's policy will remain accommodative to aid the country's recovery from the coronavirus pandemic. The recovery is limited and uneven, with slow loan growth due to weak domestic demand and banks' risk aversion. To support the economy, the central bank will guarantee liquidity and direct monetary policy towards an accommodative stance. This move is seen as a response to potential relocation of companies worth US$600 million from China to Indonesia, which could boost the national economy. The accommodative policy aims to provide ample liquidity and support economic growth.

site_title: Singapore maritime bodies seek proposals to electrify harbourcraft; S$9m to co-fund projects
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) and the Singapore Maritime Institute (SMI) launched a joint call for proposals to electrify harbourcraft, aiming to support the industry's low-carbon transition. The Singapore harbourcraft industry will receive S$9 million from the Maritime GreenFuture Fund to co-fund harbourcraft projects. Proposals should focus on developing commercially ready, fully electric harbourcraft and interoperable shore charging infrastructure. The deadline for submission of white papers is October 31, with a focus on viable business models for scalability.

site_title: India's Reliance says KKR to invest 55.5b rupees in retail arm
summary: US private equity firm KKR & Co invests 55.50 billion rupees (S$1.03 billion) in Reliance Industries' retail arm, giving the unit a pre-money valuation of 4.21 trillion rupees. This investment translates to a 1.28% stake in Retail Ventures. Reliance, controlled by Mukesh Ambani, aims to expand its online presence to compete with Walmart's Flipkart and Amazon's Indian arm, with KKR's investment supporting this expansion.

images.alt_text: US private equity firm KKR & Co will invest 55.50 billion rupees (S$1.03 billion) in Reliance Industries' retail arm, giving the unit a pre-money valuation of 4.21 trillion rupees, the Indian conglomerate said on Wednesday.

site_title: Robo-adviser Syfe gets US$18.6m led by Peter Thiel's Valar Ventures
summary: Syfe, a digital wealth manager, has secured a US$18.6 million Series A funding round led by Valar Ventures, backed by Peter Thiel. Existing investor Unbound also participated. This funding round follows Syfe's S$5.2 million seed round in 2019. The investment aims to support Syfe's growth and expansion in the wealth management industry.

site_title: Malaysia's Anwar says has 'formidable' majority of MPs to form a new government
summary: Malaysian politician Anwar Ibrahim claims to have a "strong, convincing, formidable majority" to form a new government, surpassing the 112 MPs needed to control Parliament. Anwar, who leads the Pakatan Harapan coalition, has 91 MPs, including those from the Perikatan Nasional alliance, after meeting with the Malaysian King. He declined to give an exact number, but is expected to announce it after meeting with the King. Anwar accuses the current government of Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin of "collapsing."

images.alt_text: Malaysian politician Anwar Ibrahim said on Wednesday that he has a "strong, convincing, formidable majority" to form a new government, and claimed that the government of Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin has "collapsed".

site_title: Morgan Stanley's US$4.3b fund bets on India bank winners
summary: Morgan Stanley's US$4.3 billion Asia Opportunity fund is betting on private Indian banks to gain market share from state-owned lenders. Co-manager Kristian Heugh expects banks with strong deposit franchises and quality underwriting standards to thrive. He highlights HDFC Bank and ICICI Bank as potential winners, citing their lower cost bases and digital capabilities. Despite regulatory scrutiny and share price declines, Heugh believes HDFC's strong risk management processes will enable it to continue gaining market share from weaker public sector banks.

site_title: Gold inches higher on US-China tensions, recovery woes
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,902.04 per ounce, supported by US-China tensions and economic recovery concerns. The US dollar's strength capped gains. The move follows recent US tariffs on Canada and threats to others, which have kept markets on edge.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 2.84 points, or 0.19%, to 1,508.62. Volume reached 385.13 million lots worth RM385.13 million. Gainers outpaced losers 212 to 127.

site_title: Acromec acquires remaining 40% stake in engineering firm
summary: Acromec has acquired the remaining 40% stake in Golden Harvest Engineering for S$550,000. The acquisition complements Acromec's maintenance segment business and increases its recurring revenue base. Golden Harvest provides maintenance services for air conditioning and mechanical ventilation systems in buildings. The deal marks Acromec's expansion into the engineering services sector, further enhancing its existing maintenance segment business.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, down 0.44% or 103.86 points to 23,256.44, following a long weekend. This comes as investors try to catch up with global markets that lost heavily earlier in the week. The broader Topix index also fell 0.43% or 7.03 points to 1,639.39.

site_title: Australia: Shares jump 1.3% on Wall Street rebound, easing border curbs
summary: Australian shares rose 1.3% on Wednesday, tracking a tech-led rebound on Wall Street, and eased border restrictions in Queensland and New South Wales. The S&P/ASX 200 index climbed to 5,861.70, supported by a stronger market sentiment and the Reserve Bank of Australia's assessment of monetary policy options. Healthcare and financial sector indexes also gained, driven by a rise in oil prices and upgrades to "outperform" by brokerage Bernstein.

site_title: China anti-graft body probes chairman of state-owned Everbright unit
summary: China's anti-corruption body has launched an investigation into Zhu Huimin, chairman of state-owned Everbright Industry Group, for suspected disciplinary violations, including corruption. The investigation was announced by the Central Commission Discipline Inspection office in northeast China's Heilongjiang province. Zhu's alleged "serious violations of Communist Party's discipline and law" are under scrutiny. This move comes as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares ease at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks started the day slightly lower, extending a three-day losing streak, amid concerns over rising virus infections and fresh containment measures. The Hang Seng Index dipped 0.07% to 23,701.12. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.14% and the Shenzhen Composite Index edged up 0.19%. The losses follow a mixed day in the US, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: US House adopts bill to avoid government shutdown
summary: The US House of Representatives adopted a budget bill to avoid a government shutdown, extending funding through early December. The bipartisan text includes $8 billion in nutrition assistance for schoolchildren and families, as well as funding for farmers with increased accountability. The deal follows a compromise between Democrats and the White House, and still requires Senate backing and President Trump's signature. The short-term bill extends funding through December 11, averting a potential shutdown just days before the fiscal year ends.

site_title: Reserve Bank of New Zealand holds rates, says prolonged support may be needed
summary: New Zealand's Reserve Bank held its official cash rate at 0.25%, as expected, amid the coronavirus pandemic. The bank warned of prolonged economic support and potential use of additional tools, including a negative interest rate and foreign asset purchases, to meet inflation and employment targets. The large-scale asset purchase programme was retained at NZ$100 billion. Economists expect the OCR to be cut into negative territory early next year, following a 75 basis points cut in March.

site_title: Trump administration plans two meetings on Big Tech on Wednesday
summary: US President Donald Trump plans to meet with state attorneys general on Wednesday to discuss removing a liability shield protecting social media companies, amid efforts to move against the industry accused of stifling conservative voices. The meeting comes after Trump signed an executive order and backed legislation to regulate tech firms' content moderation decisions. The Justice Department is also holding a call with state officials to discuss an investigation into Alphabet's Google, with a complaint expected to be filed against the company next week.

site_title: TransferWise posts fourth year of profit; net profit twice that of last FY's
summary: TransferWise, a fintech unicorn, has reported its fourth consecutive year of profit, with a net profit of £21.3 million (S$37.42 million) in FY2020, more than doubling from the previous year. Revenue jumped 70% to £302.6 million, driven by growth in cross-currency transfers, particularly from Europe and the US. The company has expanded its customer base to 8 million worldwide, with a focus on digital alternatives during the Covid-19 crisis, and now serves 54 currencies over 2,500 routes.

site_title: Asian business confidence rebounds sharply, pandemic casts shadow: poll
summary: Asian business confidence has rebounded sharply in the third quarter, with the Thomson Reuters/Insead Asian Business Sentiment Index jumping to 53 from an 11-year low of 35 in the second quarter. Despite easing coronavirus restrictions, lingering uncertainty over the pandemic and global economic risks continue to cast a shadow. Companies across 11 Asia-Pacific countries reported a positive outlook, with 28% of firms expressing confidence, up from 7.6% in the second quarter.

site_title: Broker's take: CGS-CIMB says Keppel's trough valuation unwarranted, keeps 'add'
summary: Keppel Corp's shares are trading at a trough valuation of 0.7 time price-to-book-value (P/BV) ratio, the lowest since the 2009 global financial crisis. Analysts at CGS-CIMB say this is unwarranted, given the company's offshore and marine (O&M) business order book of S$3.5 billion, which should guide the yard into profitability in 2021. The brokerage maintains its "add" call and S$6.46 target price, citing a conservative forecast of S$500 million and S$1 billion in order wins for 2020 and 2021, respectively.

site_title: Elite Commercial Reit sees rising demand for UK properties on tenant's hiring plans
summary: Elite Commercial Reit, a UK-focused real estate investment trust (Reit), sees rising demand for office space despite the Covid-19 pandemic. The Reit's primary tenant, the UK government's Department of Work and Pensions (DWP), is hiring more staff, leading to increased utilization of the Reit's assets. This counter-cyclical trend is expected to provide stable cash flows for the Reit, with 82% of its assets being social infrastructure facilities used by the DWP. Despite new restrictions, the Reit's CEO remains positive about its ability to generate cash flows and deliver stable returns to unitholders.

site_title: Australia extends relaxation of company reporting rules amid coronavirus pandemic
summary: Australia has extended its temporary relaxation of company reporting rules for six more months, until March 23, 2021, amid the coronavirus pandemic. This move aims to shield businesses from lawsuits by allowing them to avoid releasing earnings forecasts. The government amended corporate laws in May to protect companies from liability for market statements made during the pandemic, citing uncertainties and the threat of opportunistic class actions. This move is part of Australia's regulatory relief efforts during the crisis.

site_title: Japan factory activity struggles to recover as output falls: PMI
summary: Japan's factory activity continued to decline in September, with the manufacturing PMI index remaining below the 50.0 threshold for a 17th month. Output contracted at a faster pace, and new order inflows fell for the first time in four months. Despite this, future output views rose to a two-year high. The service sector showed slight improvement, with the services PMI index contracting at its slowest pace in seven months. The overall composite PMI edged up, indicating a slight improvement in the economy's recovery from the pandemic.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Wednesday's open tracking US gains; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.3% or 8.17 points to 2,471.46 at 9:04am on Wednesday, tracking gains from the US market. Tech stocks led the gains, with Venture Corporation, AEM Holdings, UMS Holdings, and Hi-P International opening higher. Banking stocks were mixed, while major US indices closed in positive territory on Tuesday.

site_title: Tesla maps road to cheaper batteries for electric cars
summary: Tesla is slashing battery costs by 56% to speed a global shift to renewable energy, aiming to have a $25,000 model available in three years. The company is refining a new battery manufacturing process, enabling the production of more affordable electric vehicles. CEO Elon Musk expressed confidence that Tesla can make a compelling $25,000 electric vehicle in the near future, with a goal of transitioning the world to sustainable energy as soon as possible.

images.alt_text: Tesla on Tuesday said it is slashing battery costs to speed a global shift to renewable energy, and could have a US$25,000 model available in three years or so.

site_title: Feuding minority shareholder agrees to exit India's Tata group
summary: India's Tata group will likely gain control after the Shapoorji Pallonji (SP) Group, a minority shareholder, agrees to exit the conglomerate. The decision follows years of a bitter battle after the ouster of former chairman Cyrus Mistry in 2016. The SP Group will likely sell its 18.4% stake to Tata Sons, allowing the holding company to boost its control of the conglomerate, which operates in over 100 countries. The move ends a seven-decade-long relationship between the two companies, with the SP Group stating that a separation of interests would best serve all stakeholders.

site_title: Facebook says fake accounts from China aimed at US politics
summary: Facebook has removed 155 fake accounts, 11 pages, 9 groups, and 6 Instagram accounts linked to China, targeting US politics, particularly in the 2020 presidential race. The campaign, which focused on the Philippines and South East Asia, was aimed at influencing US politics but had a limited impact. The accounts used techniques to circumvent China's Great Firewall and posed as locals to build an audience. Facebook did not connect the campaign to the Chinese government, and the operation had been active since at least 2018.

site_title: SRX launches community tool on its mobile app
summary: SRX, a property tech platform, has launched a community tool on its mobile app, called SRX Community, which allows members to connect with their neighbors and stay updated on local events. The tool enables digital communities for apartment blocks and their surrounding neighborhoods, promoting social interaction and community engagement among members.

site_title: Bank of East Asia presses ahead with life insurance sale
summary: Bank of East Asia (BEA) is pressing ahead with a potential sale of its life insurance assets, as part of a strategic review, according to people familiar with the matter. Plans include exploring a sale of its life insurance unit and a bancassurance partnership, which could raise around $500-$600 million. The proposal still requires final approval from the bank's directors and may change. Shares of BEA rose 3.5% in early Hong Kong trading following the report.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Tech plays, Singapore Exchange, Singtel, QAF, Aspen, Keppel
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article:

Several Singaporean stocks experienced significant price movements on Wednesday, including Venture Corporation, AEM Holdings, and Hi-P International, which saw selling pressure. Singapore Telecommunications (Singtel) fell to its lowest in 12 years, while QAF revised its fiscal 2020 outlook. Aspen Holdings invested RM105 million in a rubber glove joint venture and announced a new chief operating officer. Keppel Corp's asset-management arm reached the halfway mark of its US$500 million real estate investment fund. Meanwhile, Wilmar International requested a trading halt pending an announcement. Asian Healthcare Specialists redeemed a convertible bond issuance.

site_title: No-deal Brexit will hit UK economy more than Covid-19: study
summary: A new study by UK in a Changing Europe warns that a "no-deal" Brexit could be three times more costly to the UK economy in the long term than the coronavirus outbreak. The study predicts a 5.7% hit to gross domestic product over the next 15 years, compared to a 2.1% hit from Covid-19. The think-tank says the negative impact of a no-deal Brexit will be more significant in the long run, despite the economic effects of the pandemic being more immediate and visible.

site_title: UK MPs agree compromise for contentious Brexit bill
summary: UK MPs agree on a compromise for the Brexit bill, requiring a parliamentary approval for the date when the government's proposed override powers come into effect. The bill still allows for the UK to breach the Brexit treaty, but addresses some concerns from MPs. The EU has demanded Britain withdraw clauses conflicting with the divorce deal, threatening possible legal action.
