The bill will now proceed to further debate and a vote in the House of Commons before being scrutinized in the House of Lords.

site_title: Death toll from India building collapse jumps to 26
summary: A three-storey apartment block in Bhiwandi, near Mumbai, India, collapsed on Tuesday, resulting in a death toll of 26. Rescuers from the National Disaster Response Force have pulled 20 survivors from the rubble, with around 12-15 people still believed to be trapped. The cause of the accident is unclear, but building collapses are common during India's monsoon season.

site_title: Twitter probes alleged racial bias in image cropping feature
summary: Twitter is investigating an alleged racial bias in its image-cropping feature, which users claim favors white faces over black. The feature, which automatically crops and selects parts of images, has been criticized for its potential impact on representation and diversity. Twitter has acknowledged the complaints and will review the function to ensure it is fair and unbiased. The company aims to address the issue and provide a more inclusive experience for its users.

site_title: 'Covid catalyst' spurs firms to transform and thrive: Chan
summary: Singapore Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing says the Covid-19 crisis has been a "Covid catalyst" for digital transformation, enabling firms to thrive in crisis. He warns that failing to transform now may see Singapore's hub status bypassed. Chan emphasizes that the pre-Covid world will not return, and firms must adapt to survive and thrive.

site_title: World should not be dominated by China-US 'rivalry': Macron
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron warned world leaders not to be dominated by a power struggle between the US and China, calling for a "modern new consensus" on tackling global challenges. Macron emphasized the need for multilateralism, citing the coronavirus crisis as a test of global cooperation. He urged leaders to seize the opportunity to "clearly lay out our choices and build new alliances" and to ensure the foundations of the UN organization are not swept away by the pandemic. Macron also warned of the dangers of dependence on certain powers and the need for Europe to forge its own defense strategy.

site_title: Luxury Geneva hotels face 'life-threatening' corona crunch
summary: Luxury hotels in Geneva, Switzerland are facing a "life-threatening" crisis due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with night stays shrinking by 63% in the first seven months of the year. The sector, which was previously thriving with 3.2 million night stays annually, is now expected to see a 75% decline. Hotels are struggling to stay afloat, with some at risk of closure, and the city's hotel association is urging the government to create a fund to help cover losses and find a balance between health and economic interests.

images.alt_text: Behind its deep-red awnings, Richemont's blinds have been closed since July, after the coronavirus pandemic left the usually bustling five-star Geneva hotel starved for high-paying customers.

site_title: Airline travel shifts towards last-minute bookings, domestic trips: Skyscanner
summary: The air travel market has shifted towards last-minute bookings and domestic trips due to the novel coronavirus pandemic, favoring low-cost carriers with competitive pricing. According to a Skyscanner report, this trend will continue as consumers adapt to an uncertain future for business travel. This change is expected to benefit low-cost carriers, while full-service airlines may face reduced profits. The trend is also expected to increase demand for one-way flights, further shifting the industry's dynamics.

site_title: Nike smashes revenue, profit estimates on North America online boom
summary: Nike Inc reported a 9% increase in shares after beating analysts' estimates for quarterly revenue and profit, driven by a surge in online sales in North America. Digital sales rose 82% in the first quarter, with online sales now accounting for nearly a third of total revenue. Nike's net income rose to $1.52 billion, and revenue fell 0.6% to $10.6 billion. The company's focus on direct-to-consumer sales has helped it overcome the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on brick-and-mortar sales.

site_title: China luxury spend expected to jump 30% this year
summary: Chinese luxury spend is expected to increase by 30% this year, driven by high-income mainland shoppers as the country's post-pandemic economic rebound. This is a contrast to the global luxury industry, which is projected to shrink 45% in 2020 due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic in Europe and the US.

site_title: Oil edges up a day after selloff; rangebound ahead of US crude stocks data
summary: Oil prices edged up on Tuesday, rebounding from a previous day's selloff, ahead of weekly US inventory figures. Brent crude rose 28 cents to US$41.72 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude settled up 29 cents to US$39.60. Analysts expect limited impact from renewed lockdown restrictions in Europe on fuel demand, and major oil-producing nations' supply restrictions have kept the market in a range. Weekly US inventory data is expected to provide further insight into the market's direction.

site_title: US: Stocks advance cautiously after Powell, Mnuchin testify
summary: US stocks advanced cautiously, marking the first positive session in three, following testimony from top government officials. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.5%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index gained 1.1% and 1.7% respectively. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin expressed openness to more fiscal stimulus despite stalled talks. Investors sought deals after tech stocks fell, and Amazon was a big winner, while Tesla's shares declined due to tempered expectations for its "battery day" presentation.

images.alt_text: Major US indices closed in positive territory on Tuesday for the first time in three sessions after testimony from top government officials rekindled hopes for more stimulus from Congress.

site_title: In major move, China sets 2060 goal to go carbon neutral
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping announced that China will peak greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 and become carbon neutral by 2060, a major step forward for climate activists. This goal, the most concrete yet announced by China, accounts for one quarter of the planet's emissions and aligns with the Paris climate accord. Xi also emphasized the need for a green focus as the world recovers from the Covid-19 crisis. The move is seen as a significant shift in China's climate policy and could have global implications for reducing emissions.

site_title: Justice Ruth Ginsburg loved opera, and opera loved her back
summary: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg's love for opera was unmatched, with a lifelong passion for the art form that spanned over 75 years. She saw her first opera at age 11 and became an avid attendee, often attending dress rehearsals and performances. Opera's themes of underdogs and struggle resonated with her, as seen in her work on cases like the father seeking child care support. Ginsburg's love for opera was not just a hobby, but a source of escape and a way to connect with the world. She was a friend and supporter to many opera companies, including the Washington National Opera and Glimmerglass Festival.

images.alt_text: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg (accompanied by the tenor Lawrence Brownlee) after appearing in the speaking role of the Duchess of Krakenthorp in Donizetti's La Fille du Régiment at Washington National Opera in 2016.

site_title: EU top court backs crackdown on short-term home rentals in setback to Airbnb
summary: The European Union's top court has backed efforts by cities to regulate short-term home rentals, dealing a setback to Airbnb. The ruling, which supports France's measure to fine owners for renting second homes without permission, says the law is proportionate and aims to combat housing shortages. The Luxembourg-based Court of Justice of the European Union ruled that the French measure is justified as it addresses a public interest issue and does not cover the rental of own or primary homes. This decision is seen as a blow to Airbnb, which operates in many EU cities.

site_title: Australian central bank assessing various policy options to revive economy
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is assessing various monetary policy options, including currency market intervention and negative rates, to revive the economy. Deputy Governor Guy Debelle stated that the central bank is considering options to lower longer-dated government bond rates and buying bonds with maturities beyond three years. Foreign exchange intervention is also being considered, although its effectiveness is uncertain. The RBA has maintained its "highly accommodative settings" since March, and lower interest rates are being explored as a potential alternative to negative rates.

site_title: UN chief warns against 'new Cold War'
summary: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres warned against a new Cold War between the US and China, urging the world to focus on the COVID-19 pandemic instead. He called for a universal ceasefire by the end of the year and criticized right-wing movements for failing to contain the virus. The warning comes amid rising tensions between the US and China, with President Donald Trump blaming Beijing for the pandemic and accusing China of spreading disinformation.

site_title: Negative real yields to support Asian bonds, but investors need to remain cautious
summary: Negative real yields on government bonds are driving investors to seek higher returns in emerging markets and Asian bonds, particularly corporate bonds. Despite concerns over credit and macro risks, Asian corporate bonds have shown a lower default rate compared to Europe and the US, and their interest coverage ratio is relatively high. Asian economies, especially China, are recovering from the pandemic, and the region's bond market is offering attractive valuations. However, investors should remain cautious due to the ongoing health crisis and the potential for market volatility, and should focus on disciplined credit selection to navigate the market.

site_title: Friedman was wrong - look at income inequality
summary: A growing body of evidence suggests that Milton Friedman's doctrine of "maximising shareholder value" has contributed to income inequality and negative social consequences. Critics argue that prioritizing profits over people has led to CEOs and shareholders accumulating wealth, while employees and customers suffer. Examples include Enron, WorldCom, and Nortel scandals, as well as the rise of pharmaceutical prices and Boeing's 737 Max disaster. The Business Roundtable has recently revised its mission statement to include a commitment to stakeholders beyond shareholders, but many companies remain focused on short-term profits.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rebound slightly, supported by oil and tobacco
summary: European stocks closed higher on Tuesday, partially recovering from a selloff triggered by fears of new lockdowns due to rising Covid-19 cases. Oil and tobacco shares led the gain, with Royal Dutch Shell and BP jumping 3% and British American Tobacco gaining 4.1%. Despite concerns about travel demand, consumer confidence rose to -13.9 in September, and rating actions boosted shares. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.2%, while the German DAX and Italy's FTSE MIB also gained.

images.alt_text: A jump in oil and tobacco shares helped European stocks close higher on Tuesday, with the main indexes partially recovering from a selloff triggered by fears of new lockdowns as Covid-19 cases spike across the continent.

site_title: US home shopping boom buoys shipping lines half a world away
summary: A US home shopping boom has led to record-high sea freight rates on the Trans-Pacific route, benefiting Asian container shipping companies. Exports of household appliances and electronics from South Korea to the US surged 51% and 169% respectively in August, with shipping rates on the Trans-Pacific route tripling from this year's low in March. This increased demand is expected to continue until the end of the year, with companies like HMM and Moller-Maersk reporting improved earnings.

site_title: T S Eliot's estate donates Cats royalties to Brontë Museum
summary: The Brontë Parsonage Museum in Haworth, UK, received a £20,000 donation from the estate of T.S. Eliot, thanks to the success of the musical "Cats." The museum was facing a £500,000 loss due to the pandemic, but the donation gives it hope. The connection between Eliot and the Brontës is through a Yorkshire philanthropist, Sir James Roberts, who donated the parsonage to the Brontë Society in 1928. The donation was discovered on the museum's crowdfunding campaign page and has been described as a "very special moment" by the head of communications.

site_title: New Aviva boss moving fast to shrink British insurer
summary: Aviva's new CEO, Amanda Blanc, is rapidly implementing her plan to reverse the company's share slump by selling off non-core businesses. The UK-based insurer has already sold its Singapore business for $2.7 billion and is exploring the sale of its French unit, valued at approximately $4.8 billion. Other potential divestments include its Italian non-life insurance business and joint ventures in Turkey and India. The divestments could generate billions of pounds to return to shareholders or deploy in core operations, and are seen as a boon for investment bankers.

site_title: Tritech responds to SGX's queries about its sanitiser and cleaning product
summary: Tritech Group has responded to queries from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) regarding its newly developed sanitiser and cleaning product, VaVie Clean Wash Sanitize (CWS). The company has received in-principle approval from the National Environment Agency (NEA), Health Sciences Authority (HSA), and Singapore Food Agency (SFA) for the manufacture and sale of the product, with the agencies deeming the ingredients as non-hazardous and of food-grade quality. However, Tritech clarified that the agencies did not authorise or endorse the product, and its statement was intended to inform shareholders and the public of the clearance obtained.

site_title: Regional listcos eye better profits, margins amid diversification into healthcare products
summary: Companies in Singapore and Malaysia are diversifying into healthcare products and services, including Covid-19-related products, to capitalize on high demand. Aspen Group, a real estate developer, has surged 167.9% after announcing its entry into the glove-making business, while Ta Yang Group has seen its share price rise 129% after entering the mask market. Other companies, such as Komarkcorp and Q&M Dental Group, are also exploring new opportunities in the healthcare sector. Despite potential risks, investors are optimistic about the immediate positive impact of diversification, with some companies expecting significant increases in profits and margins.

site_title: Sri Lanka unveils controversial bill handing more power to president
summary: Sri Lanka's ruling party unveiled a constitutional amendment granting unprecedented power to President Gotabaya Rajapaksa, removing oversight on human rights and government spending, and allowing him to appoint Supreme Court judges. The move sparked protests in parliament and opposition claims of a power-grab. The bill's introduction raises concerns about erosion of democratic institutions and potential human rights abuses.

site_title: Powell sees 'highly uncertain' path for economy despite 'marked' gains
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell stated that the US economy has shown "marked improvement" since the pandemic, but the path ahead remains uncertain and the Fed will take additional action if needed. A full recovery is likely to come only when people are confident it is safe to re-engage in activities, with the coronavirus under control. Powell emphasized the Fed's commitment to using its tools to support the economy and limit lasting damage.

site_title: Tech stocks reverse rally to lead markets rout in Asia, US, Europe
summary: Asian stock markets tumbled on Tuesday, following a sell-off in Europe and the US, with tech stocks leading the rout. The Singapore market fell 0.9%, while Shanghai and Hong Kong markets sank by 1.3% and 1%, respectively. The Nasdaq's FAANG counters, including Facebook, Amazon, and Apple, contracted by between 0.3% and 12.5% in value over the past month. Analysts attribute the sell-off to investor repositioning and positive developments on the vaccine front, but note that local tech stocks still offer longer-term investment merits due to lower valuations.

site_title: Singtel hits 12-year low amid heavy trading
summary: Singtel's share price hit a 12-year low of S$2.16, down 2.3% from the previous day, amid heavy trading. The counter has slumped nearly 36% year-to-date. Despite being the most widely owned stock in Singapore, Singtel's financial metrics are deteriorating, with analysts warning of a significant decline in earnings. The company's dividend yield is currently 5.6%, below its peak of 6.9% in 2020, and Standard & Poor's forecasts a 11-13% decline in reported Ebitda to S$3.9-4.1 billion in fiscal 2021.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Asian Healthcare Specialists redeemed S$4 million of a convertible-bond issuance to Temasek Holdings' Heliconia. Incredible Holdings secured up to S$9.41 million in interest-free loans. Hengyang Petrochemical Logistics consolidated its stake in a principal subsidiary for S$7.33 million. QAF Ltd downgraded its Australia-based pork production revenue guidance to A$395 million, contrary to reports of A$80-100 million offers for its primary production business.

site_title: STI dips further on virus resurgence fears, Wall Street tumble
summary: Singapore shares slid 0.9% on Tuesday, extending their decline amid fears of a coronavirus resurgence and a potential Wall Street retreat. The Straits Times Index closed at 2,463.29. CapitaLand Reits were among the biggest decliners, with CapitaLand Commercial Trust tumbling 4.05%. The UK and Hong Kong also extended social distancing measures to combat Covid-19 infections. Investors are increasingly cautious, with Oanda senior market analyst Jeffrey Halley warning of deeper downward corrections to come.

site_title: Oakwood launches day-use workspaces across Asia-Pacific
summary: Oakwood, a subsidiary of Mapletree Investments, has launched day-use workspaces at 17 properties across the Asia-Pacific region. The "Work from Oakwood" solution, available daily from 7am to 7pm, includes free Wi-Fi, snacks, and hand sanitizers. The move responds to sustained safe-distancing measures at workplaces, aiming to provide a safe and flexible workspace option for employees.

site_title: Wirecard woes mount for EY as clients leave
summary: Germany's third-largest bank, KFW, may drop Ernst & Young (EY) as its auditor amid the ongoing Wirecard accounting scandal. EY has been criticized for its role in the scandal, which has led to a 99% loss in Wirecard's value. Several companies, including Commerzbank and DWS Group, have already moved away from EY due to concerns over conflicts of interest. The German government is reviewing KfW's auditing process, and EY's future as its auditor is uncertain.

site_title: Airlines call for Covid-19 tests before all international flights
summary: Global airlines are calling for airport Covid-19 tests for all departing international passengers to replace quarantines, citing the need for a solution to the travel slump. The International Air Transport Association (IATA) supports the use of rapid antigen tests, which can be administered by non-medical staff, and expects them to be available and rolled out under globally agreed standards by late October. Airlines believe this will boost passenger confidence and help save the winter travel season. The tests are expected to be affordable, with prices starting at $7 each.

site_title: State of union in UK: Why Brexit should not be followed by 'Scoxit'
summary: Support for Scottish independence is surging, with polls showing up to 55% of the population favoring secession from England, Wales, and Northern Ireland. First Minister Nicola Sturgeon plans to hold a new referendum, which would require UK government approval, but Prime Minister Boris Johnson may face a politically indefensible decision if the SNP wins the next national elections. A forthcoming bill will set out the proposed referendum question, potentially setting the stage for a significant challenge to the UK's territorial integrity.

site_title: Credit Suisse, UBS step up fight for China bankers in talent war
summary: Credit Suisse and UBS are engaging in a talent war in China, with both firms hiring analysts and bankers from global and local firms. Credit Suisse hired 12 analysts, mostly from UBS, while UBS has recruited over 40 people. Other foreign firms, such as Morgan Stanley, are also expanding their presence in China, with plans to double their headcounts in the next few years. This intensifying competition for financial talent in China is driven by the growing demand for banking services in the country.

site_title: Empathy, meritocracy should be guiding principles to hiring: TMF
summary: Singapore's government has struck a balance between motivating fair employment and supporting local talents. The minimum salary requirement for foreign professionals has been raised to S$4,500 for new applicants, with further increases to S$5,000 for financial services sector workers and S$2,500 for mid-skilled foreigners. This balance is crucial to avoid short-sighted protectionist policies that can harm trade and investments. TMF Singapore's managing director, Edmund Lee, emphasizes the importance of empathy and meritocracy in hiring, and believes Singapore remains a compelling destination for businesses due to its stability and streamlined processes.

images.alt_text: Mr Lee notes that a carrot and stick approach tends to be more effective at motivating action in people.

site_title: SGX, India bourse operator agree to work together on Nifty futures contracts
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) and India's National Stock Exchange (NSE) have agreed to work together on Nifty futures contracts. The deal, announced in a joint statement, marks headway in talks after India's main stock exchanges stopped licensing securities to foreign exchanges in 2018. The NSE-IFSC-SGX Connect will see Nifty futures contracts on the SGX executed in Gujarat International Finance Tec-City (Gift City), creating a bigger liquidity pool for Nifty products. The exchanges aim to develop the infrastructure and ensure member readiness prior to implementation, with the goal of broadening participation and deepening liquidity.

site_title: Everton Road shophouse up for sale with S$7.5m guide price
summary: A freehold conservation shophouse at 9 Everton Road in Singapore is up for sale via expression of interest (EOI) with a guide price of S$7.5 million. The two-storey property, situated in the Blair Plain conservation area, has a built-up area of about 4,000 sq ft and is zoned for residential use. The site is near Outram Park and Cantonment MRT stations, offering convenient access to the central business district. Only four units have transacted in the area in the last two years, making this a rare opportunity for discerning buyers or investors.

site_title: Covid-19 Support Grant extended to end-Dec; new eligibility criteria added
summary: Singapore's Covid-19 Support Grant (CSG) will be extended to December 31, with revised eligibility criteria. From October 1, applicants must not own more than one property and demonstrate job-search or training efforts to qualify for the grant, which provides up to $800 a month for three months. The grant supports unemployed and part-time employees affected by the pandemic. Over $90 million has been disbursed to 60,000 residents since its launch in May. Existing recipients can apply for an additional three months of support from October 1.

site_title: UK may see renewed economic downturn on new restrictions
summary: The UK may experience a renewed economic downturn due to new social and economic restrictions to combat a predicted winter Covid-19 surge. The Bank of England's prediction of a V-shaped recovery has shifted to a W-shaped one, with a down wave in the fourth quarter of 2020. The FTSE 100 index has slipped to 5,831, and the pound traded at around 1.28 against the US dollar. The restrictions, including a 10pm curfew and distanced table service, may impact pubs and restaurants, leading to business closures and job losses.

site_title: Tencent's WeChat app sees surge in download before US ban
summary: US tech giant Apple and Google are set to remove WeChat from their stores due to a national security ban. Despite the ban, WeChat's downloads surged by 28 times in the US between Friday and Saturday, with 54,000 downloads. WeCom, a related office collaboration app, also saw a significant increase in downloads. Tencent, WeChat's parent company, has denied its apps pose a national security risk, and the company may face challenges if updates for existing US users are affected. A US Commerce Department challenge to the ban is expected.

site_title: Wall Street is rooting for neither Trump nor Biden
summary: The US stock market's performance during the 2020 presidential election is being reevaluated, with research suggesting it has no clear bias towards either Trump or Biden. Despite polls favoring Biden, stock prices have been volatile, and market trends are normal in the run-up to an election. Historically, the market's fluctuations are not indicative of a candidate's economic priorities, but rather a natural response to uncertainty and market forces.

site_title: Rich Capital to commission review to protect JV investments, look into potential breaches
summary: Rich Capital Holdings, a Singapore-listed property developer, has commissioned an independent review to protect its investments in joint venture Oxley Karya Indo Batam (OKIB) and investigate potential breaches of regulations and listing rules. The review follows the disabling of Rich Capital's banking tokens for OKIB's Maybank accounts and an unauthorized debit from another JV bank account. The review aims to strengthen internal controls and impose further safeguards, with the findings and recommendations to be reported to the authorities and the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: HK retail, F&B operators await return of tourists for survival
summary: Hong Kong's retail and food and beverage sectors are struggling due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, with the number of private-sector retail establishments decreasing to 61,650 in June, the lowest level in a decade. Bars and pubs reopened last Friday, but many operators are awaiting the return of tourists to survive. The sector's decline is attributed to months of travel restrictions and distancing measures, which have hollowed out the retail scene. Economists predict that a quarter of retail stores will shut by the end of the year, and many businesses fear they will only be able to survive for up to six months without government support.

images.alt_text: Months of travel restrictions and distancing measures are hollowing Hong Kong's retail scene out to levels not seen in a decade.

site_title: Ellen DeGeneres apologises over toxic workplace allegations
summary: Ellen DeGeneres apologized for a toxic workplace culture at her show, addressing allegations of sexual misconduct, racism, and intimidation. The apology came after a report by BuzzFeed News and rumors on social media, following the firing of three high-level producers in August. DeGeneres acknowledged her privilege and power, taking responsibility for the issues and promising "necessary changes" following an internal investigation. The 62-year-old comedian and host denied allegations that her offstage personality differs from her TV persona, stating she is "a work in progress."

site_title: Indonesia revises 2020 GDP forecast to a deeper slump
summary: Indonesia revised its 2020 GDP forecast to a deeper slump, expecting a contraction of 1.7% to 0.6% on an annual basis, down from a previous range of 1.1% to 0.2%. The revised forecast takes into account a new third-quarter GDP outlook of 2.9% to 1% contraction, with potential negative growth in the October-to-December period. The country's GDP shrank 5.32% in the April-to-June period, and the government plans to accelerate spending to support the economy amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Getting logistics back on track - how to strengthen weak corporate supply chains
summary: Global supply chains are struggling to recover from the Covid-19 pandemic, with many companies relying heavily on international sourcing and logistics chains that lack diversification and resilience. To address this, companies in Singapore and South-east Asia can spread risk by diversifying suppliers and sourcing goods closer to home. This can involve increasing inventory and stockpiles closer to point of sale, reducing reliance on just-in-time logistics, and exploring alternative countries like Thailand and Vietnam for manufacturing. Transparency, diversification, and domestication are key to building robust supply chains, and companies must adapt to changing consumer demand and expectations for quicker regional delivery times.

site_title: Trump lashes China as UN warns against 'Cold War'
summary: US President Donald Trump blamed China for unleashing the coronavirus pandemic, calling it the "China virus," and criticized China's carbon emissions and dumping of plastic. The UN warned against a new "Cold War" between the US and China. Trump also announced the US withdrawal from the World Health Organization, citing the organization's alleged ties to China. China's President Xi Jinping rejected Trump's claims, urging the world to avoid "politicizing" the fight against coronavirus.

site_title: Ralph Lauren to cut jobs as retailer speeds shift to e-commerce
summary: Ralph Lauren is cutting jobs as it accelerates its shift to e-commerce. The company expects to make pretax charges of $120-160 million and annual savings of $200 million starting in its next fiscal year. The restructuring comes amid declining sales and economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic. CEO Patrice Louvet said the changes are to match shifts accelerated by the pandemic, including digital transformation and simplifying team structures.

site_title: Keppel O&M wins S$200m jobs; Keppel Capital fund in first property investment
summary: Keppel Corporation's offshore and marine arm, Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M), secured two contracts worth S$200 million, one in the US and the other in Singapore. Separately, its asset-management arm raised half of its target commitments for a US$500 million regional real estate investment fund focused on private education assets.

site_title: Sequoia Capital China raising at least 15b yuan in new yuan-denominated fund: sources
summary: Sequoia Capital China is raising at least 15 billion yuan in a new yuan-denominated fund, its sixth, as the world's second-largest economy recovers from a virus-induced slump. The fund will focus on sectors such as industrial technology, healthcare, and consumer media. This move is seen as a way for the company to build a war chest and capitalize on China's economic growth.

site_title: China ETFs give retail investors access to soaring tech, Ant stocks
summary: China's four major fund houses are launching exchange-traded funds (ETFs) that give retail investors access to the country's tech firms, including Ant Group. The ETFs, tracking the Star 50 Index, opened for subscription and are expected to attract up to $4.01 billion. The funds target investors with insufficient capital to buy stocks directly on the Star Board, with a minimum investment of $1,000. This move aims to bring in incremental flows to the board, ensuring its stable development, as index-tracking flows are key to its growth.

site_title: US dollar gains pause, Aussie $ recovers lost ground
summary: The US dollar's gains against other currencies paused as European equity markets rose, with the US dollar index reaching its highest in six weeks earlier in the session. Riskier currencies recovered some losses as investors feared new Covid-19 lockdowns would impact the global economic recovery. The US dollar was flat at 93.532 versus a basket of currencies, still up 0.6% on the week, while the Australian dollar was flat and the New Zealand dollar rose 0.1%.

site_title: OECD sees 'solid basis' for finalising global tax talks
summary: The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has a "solid basis" for finalizing global tax talks, according to Pascal Saint-Amans, the OECD's head of tax. Technical blueprints for agreements on taxing big digital companies and a global minimum corporate tax will be published on October 12. Leadership from the US, European countries, and other nations is seen as crucial for completing the negotiations, which aim to update international tax rules for the digital age.

site_title: Strengthening the EU-Asean partnership is a necessity
summary: The European Union and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) must strengthen their partnership to address the Covid-19 pandemic and its socio-economic impact. The EU has mobilized over 800 million euros to support Asean in tackling the virus, while Asean has received 400 million euros in guarantees to support the COVAX initiative for a global vaccine supply. The EU and Asean are also working together to reboot their economies, promote deeper Asean economic integration, and enhance connectivity. They aim to finalize trade agreements, launch an EU-Asean energy dialogue, and conclude a Code of Conduct in the South China Sea to uphold the rules-based international order.

site_title: Microsoft buys video-game maker ZeniMax Media
summary: Microsoft has acquired ZeniMax Media, the parent company of Bethesda, in a $7.5 billion deal, gaining control of popular gaming titles such as The Elder Scrolls, Fallout, and Wolfenstein. This move counters criticism that Microsoft's Xbox consoles lack high-quality exclusive games, narrowing the gap with rival Sony. The acquisition increases Microsoft's lead in game studios to 23, and analysts praise the deal as a "major coup" for the company, demonstrating its commitment to improving its game options for Xbox users.

site_title: SGX questions Viking Offshore & Marine's planned S$12.1m sale of main office
summary: Viking Offshore & Marine, a distressed offshore and marine firm, is being questioned by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) over its planned S$12.1m sale of its main office. The company plans to lease the properties after the sale to minimize disruptions and maintain operations. The sale price was determined at arm's length, taking into account the company's financial condition and debt repayment obligations. A valuation of the properties will be commissioned before a definitive agreement is entered into, and the transaction will need shareholder approval under Catalist rules.

site_title: Fed's Powell sees 'highly uncertain' path for economy despite 'marked' gains
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell stated that the US economy has shown "marked improvement" since the pandemic, but the path ahead remains uncertain and the central bank will take further action if needed. The economy still lags behind pre-pandemic levels, and a full recovery is unlikely until the coronavirus is under control. Powell emphasized the Fed's commitment to supporting the economy, but critics argue that more can be done, particularly for small businesses, and lawmakers are pressing for additional stimulus.

site_title: What investors with US$3.4 trillion are buying during Covid-19
summary: Major asset managers are shifting their focus to value-driven investments amid the COVID-19 pandemic, avoiding overheated stock markets. Assets like convenience stores, pipelines, and automaker bonds are being targeted, while sectors like healthcare and technology are seen as overvalued. Investment managers are cautious about the potential for a second downturn after stimulus measures end and before mass vaccinations enable economies to restart. They're also looking into staycations, digital investments, and green rebound opportunities as governments pump-prime economies.

site_title: Let's keep decarbonisation global
summary: Singapore's Minister for Transport, Ong Ye Kung, emphasized the importance of global cooperation in decarbonizing shipping, as the International Maritime Organization (IMO) aims to reduce total annual greenhouse gas emissions by 50% by 2050. A webinar on the topic highlighted the need for collaboration among stakeholders across the energy and maritime transport value chains. The IMO's leadership was stressed as a crucial factor in achieving this ambitious goal, with Singapore pledging to contribute to the global effort. Decarbonization is seen as a shared responsibility, requiring collective action from the international maritime community.

site_title: Weak travel demand aside, SIA has major problems to fix
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is facing major problems despite weak travel demand due to factors beyond its control. The airline's investments in struggling foreign airlines NokScoot and Virgin Australia, which filed for liquidation and voluntary administration, respectively, have resulted in significant losses. These investments could have been reduced or avoided if SIA had been more cautious. The airline's top brass should not be unfairly penalized for circumstances beyond their control.

site_title: China's Xi says no intention to fight 'a Cold War or hot one' with any country
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping stated that Beijing has no intention to engage in a 'Cold War or hot one' with any country, emphasizing the need for dialogue and negotiation to resolve disputes. Tensions between China and the US have been escalating due to the coronavirus pandemic, with the US accusing China of a lack of transparency. Xi called for a global response to the virus and greater role for the World Health Organization. UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres also warned of the risks of a new Cold War, urging the world to avoid a technological and economic divide.

site_title: US existing home sales near 14-year high
summary: US existing home sales surged to a nearly 14-year high in August, reaching a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6 million units. This represents a 2.4% increase from the previous month, fueled by record-low interest rates and a pandemic-fueled migration to suburbs. The median existing house price jumped 11.4% to a record $310,600, with sales concentrated in the $250,000 to $1 million price range. Despite record-high prices, existing home sales increased 10.5% on a year-on-year basis, with gains in all four regions.

site_title: HSBC paves way for SMEs to access receivables finance quicker
summary: HSBC has closed the first receivables financing deal on Singapore's Networked Trade Platform (NTP), allowing small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to access funding in just 15 minutes, down from a day traditionally. The NTP, launched in 2018, digitizes paperwork to simplify government certification and commercial services. This move paves the way for SMEs to quickly access funding, streamlining the process and reducing waiting times.

site_title: Hengyang Petrochemical to pay 36m yuan for full control of main subsidiary
summary: Hengyang Petrochemical Logistics is acquiring a 35% stake in Hengyang Holding Pte Ltd for 36 million yuan (S$7.33 million) in cash. The deal, under a conditional sale-and-purchase agreement, will turn HHPL into a wholly-owned subsidiary, expected to improve Hengyang Petrochemical's profitability and enhance shareholders' value in the long term. The transaction was approved by the company's board and filed with the bourse.

site_title: UN chief warns against 'new Cold War'
summary: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres warned against a new Cold War between the US and China, urging the world to prevent conflicts and focus on the Covid-19 pandemic. He called for a universal ceasefire by the end of the year, citing partial successes in ceasefires in Cameroon, Colombia, and others. Guterres also criticized right-wing movements, stating that populism and nationalism have failed to contain the virus. The UN chief expressed concern about the growing divide between the US and China, which he said could lead to a "Great Fracture" in the global economy.

site_title: QAF lowers FY2020 guidance for Australian meat business, refutes news of sale offers
summary: QAF Ltd lowered its FY2020 guidance for its Australian meat business, citing a slight decrease in expected net revenue and Ebitda. The company refuted reports of sale offers for its Australian primary production business, Rivalea, stating that the sale process is in its preliminary stages and subject to conditions. Rivalea's projected net revenue and Ebitda for FY2020 are A$395 million and A$36 million, respectively, down from previous guidance.

site_title: Airline SAS rescue plan on track after shareholders greenlight
summary: SAS, the Swedish-Danish airline, has received approval from shareholders to proceed with its recapitalisation plan, aimed at securing its future after the pandemic collapse in air travel. The plan, which includes a debt-to-equity conversion, was agreed upon with top shareholders in June and met all material conditions after an extraordinary general meeting voted in favour of the board's proposals. This move is seen as a key step in the airline's recovery plan.

site_title: Tesla signals entry to Singapore with job ads
summary: Tesla has posted job advertisements for senior developers in Singapore, signaling its entry into the city-state. The move comes after Tesla began advertising for store leaders and sales advisers in Singapore in July. The company has previously expressed concerns about Singapore's support for electric vehicles, but the city-state plans to phase out fossil fuel-powered vehicles by 2040. Shipments of Tesla cars made in Shanghai to Singapore could start as early as the end of this year or early 2021.

images.alt_text: Tesla has posted fresh job advertisements for roles based in Singapore, signalling that Elon Musk's electric-vehicle (EV) maker is preparing to set up shop in the city-state it has so far skirted.

site_title: Tropical Storm Beta floods Houston, dumps rain on Gulf Coast
summary: Tropical Storm Beta is flooding Houston with 6-12 inches of rain expected along the Gulf Coast, with some areas getting up to 20 inches. The storm is expected to stall, causing highways to shut and water levels to rise. Buffalo Bayou in Houston has risen 15 feet and Brays Bayou has risen 21 feet, with roads underwater and suburban school districts closed. While not as severe as Hurricane Harvey in 2017, the flooding is still causing disruptions, with the city asking non-essential employees to stay home.

site_title: Covid-19 Support Grant extended to end December, but with revised eligibility criteria
summary: The Covid-19 Support Grant (CSG) in Singapore will be extended to the end of December with revised eligibility criteria. Starting October 1, applicants must not own more than one property and demonstrate job search or training efforts to qualify. This change aims to ensure support is given to those with less means. The grant, initially set to end in September, will provide up to S$1,000 per month to eligible individuals and families affected by the pandemic.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as tech stocks bounce
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday, led by a bounce in technology-related stocks. The S&P 500 rose 0.45% to 3,295.75, while the Nasdaq Composite gained 0.88% to 10,873.30. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.08% to 27,170.34, despite uncertainty over US fiscal stimulus. The market's gains come despite ongoing tariff uncertainty and mixed views on the Fed's future moves.

site_title: Swee Hong rejigs board ahead of delisting
summary: Swee Hong, a construction company set to delist, has terminated its general manager, Moorthy Varadhan, effective immediately. Varadhan, who oversaw projects and administration, will remain on the board as a non-executive director. The company's appeal against delisting was rejected by the Singapore Exchange, and trading in its shares has been suspended since May 2019. The board acknowledged Swee Hong's financial difficulties, stating it could not make an exit offer to shareholders. The delisting is expected to occur on Wednesday.

site_title: Sri Lanka unveils controversial Bill handing more power to president
summary: Sri Lanka's ruling party unveiled a constitutional amendment granting unprecedented power to President Gotabaya Rajapaksa, removing oversight on human rights and government spending, and allowing him to appoint Supreme Court judges. The move has sparked protests and opposition claims of a power-grab, with critics warning of an "elected dictatorship." The bill is likely to be passed due to the ruling party's two-thirds majority in parliament, and has drawn international criticism, including from the UN human rights chief.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 6.35 points to 1,505.48, closing higher on Tuesday. Volume reached 6.544 billion lots worth RM3.918 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 599 to 431.

site_title: IEV Holdings calls for Oct 15 shareholder vote on planned change of core business
summary: IEV Holdings, a Catalist-listed oilfield services company, is set to hold a shareholder vote on October 15 regarding the sale of its main operating unit for S$200,000, yielding S$95,000 in net proceeds. The sale is considered an interested-person transaction under Catalist rules. After the sale, IEV Holdings plans to sell its healthcare, post-partum care, and wellness-services businesses, and also seek shareholder approval for a name change to Medi Lifestyle Ltd.

site_title: Deutsche Bank to close 20% of domestic branches in coronavirus shift
summary: Deutsche Bank plans to close 20% of its domestic branches in Germany, shuttering around 400 of its 500 branches, primarily in urban areas. The move aims to save costs and adapt to changing customer habits during the coronavirus pandemic. The bank, which is undergoing a global overhaul, will focus on digital services and complex advisory services via phone or video chat. This strategy is similar to that of its rival Commerzbank, which recently closed 200 of its 1,000 branches.

site_title: SGX presses Vibrant Group for more details on impairment loss and board policy
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has pressed Vibrant Group for more details on its impairment loss of nearly S$17.5 million in its latest financial statements. The company had previously stated that it had provided for an impairment loss of S$8.16 million for loans to third parties. The SGX has also inquired about the adequacy and effectiveness of Vibrant's internal controls and risk-management systems, as well as the company's progress in implementing a board diversity policy. The bourse operator has asked for more information on these matters for the third time in a month.

site_title: Get serious! Careless French public riles Covid medics
summary: France is experiencing a resurgence of COVID-19 cases, with intensive care wards in Marseille's public hospitals full. Private hospitals like Clinique Bouchard-Elsan are handling the overflow, with staff expressing frustration over the lack of social distancing. The country has imposed new restrictions in cities like Lyon and Bordeaux to slow the spread. With no vaccine in sight, French President Emmanuel Macron aims to avoid a nationwide lockdown, but the balance between containing the virus and allowing citizens to live their lives remains a challenge.

site_title: Hot stock: Singtel sinks to 12-year low
summary: Singtel's share price plummeted to a 12-year low of S$2.17, a 1.8% drop from its previous close, with over 33.7 million shares traded. The company remains the most widely owned stock in Singapore, but its share price has skidded since the start of the year. Analysts have maintained "buy" recommendations, citing the stock's past performance and dividend yield, which is still above the trough of 2.6% for the quarter ended Sept 30, 2000.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's trade minister Chan Chun Sing emphasized the need for firms to transform digitally to thrive in a post-Covid world. Keppel O&M secured two contracts worth S$200m, while HSBC introduced a receivables financing platform to facilitate SME access to funding. A review is underway at Rich Capital Holdings to protect JV investments and investigate potential breaches. The STI closed 0.9% lower due to renewed virus fears, ending at 2,463.29.

site_title: A London caper with a car James Bond would never drive
summary: Thieves stole a valuable collection of handguns used in James Bond films, including a .22-calibre Llama pistol and a Walther PPK, from a London home. The burglars used a nondescript Vauxhall hatchback to escape, and police are still searching for four of the stolen firearms. The stolen guns, including a Smith & Weston .44 Magnum, are "very distinctive" and will likely be recognized by the public. No arrests have been made, and the theft has left the collector devastated.

site_title: Intel gets US licences to supply some products to Huawei
summary: Intel has received US licences to supply certain products to Huawei, a move that comes as US authorities have imposed curbs on US companies from supplying or servicing Huawei due to national security concerns. The licences were granted after Intel and other companies, such as SMIC and SK Hynix, applied for permission to continue supplying products to the Chinese tech giant. Huawei denies spying for Beijing, and the move is seen as part of the US-China tech rivalry in 5G technology, where the US is concerned that China may gain an advantage.

site_title: HSBC paves way for SMEs to access receivables finance via Networked Trade Platform
summary: HSBC has launched a receivables finance programme on Singapore's Networked Trade Platform (NTP), enabling small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to access funding in just 15 minutes, down from a day. The programme allows SMEs to send receivables finance transactions directly to HSBC via a single interface, streamlining the process and reducing manual data transfer. This move aims to support SMEs' cash flow needs and is part of HSBC's strategy to scale up its SME business in Singapore.

site_title: Asian Healthcare Specialists finishes early bond redemption under deal with Heliconia unit
summary: Asian Healthcare Specialists has redeemed S$4 million of its 2018 convertible bonds with Heliconia unit Vanda 1 Investments, bringing an end to the investment agreement. The company had previously redeemed S$1 million and agreed to an early redemption and termination deal in July. This move comes as part of a partnership to pursue healthcare investments in South-east Asia, following a successful co-investment vehicle's healthcare-related investment of over S$10 million. The company's shares rose 2.7% to S$0.19 following the announcement.

site_title: Johnson warns restrictions could last six months
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has announced new restrictions in England to combat a fast-spreading second wave of Covid-19. People are advised to work from home where possible, and bars and restaurants are ordered to shut earlier, with only table service allowed. Face-masks will be required in more settings, and businesses that break rules will be fined. Schools and universities will remain open. Johnson warned that further restrictions could be brought in if the new measures do not work, and the government expects the number of new cases to reach 50,000 per day by mid-October.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson told people on Tuesday to work from home where possible and ordered bars and restaurants to shut earlier in a bid to tackle a fast-spreading second wave of Covid-19.

site_title: SRX launches community tool on its mobile app
summary: SRX Property has launched a community tool on its mobile app, called SRX Community, which enables members to connect with their neighbors and stay informed about local events. The tool, built on its existing MySG Home service, allows members to join pre-existing community groups based on their tracked addresses, with personal details protected. The move aims to foster community engagement and build on SRX's existing property tracking and notification services.

site_title: Nobel Peace Prize ceremony scaled back due to virus
summary: The Nobel Peace Prize ceremony in Oslo will be scaled back due to the novel coronavirus pandemic. Unlike previous years, the ceremony will not be held in Oslo's City Hall, which can accommodate 1,000 guests, but instead in the auditorium of Oslo University, which can host around 100 people. The banquet is also cancelled, and it is uncertain whether this year's laureate(s) will be able to travel to Oslo to accept the prize in person. The Nobel Institute is considering holding an online ceremony, with an in-person invitation postponed until next year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close with more losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed with significant losses on Tuesday, following a global market downturn. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.98%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined by 1.29% and 1.09%, respectively. The losses were attributed to government-imposed containment measures due to a spike in infections.

site_title: Tritech responds to SGX's queries over its sanitiser and cleaning product
summary: Tritech Group has responded to Singapore Exchange (SGX) queries regarding its sanitiser and cleaning product, VaVie Clean Wash Sanitize (CWS). The company has written to three government public-health agencies to obtain approval and clearance for its product's manufacture and sale. The agencies have given in-principle approval, with no objections or specific licence requirements. This approval is based on responses from the National Environment Agency, Health Sciences Authority, and Singapore Food Agency.

site_title: Credit Suisse CEO sees slowdown at wealth unit
summary: Credit Suisse CEO Thomas Gottstein expects the wealth management business to slow down in the third quarter, but revenue and trading will keep pace with earlier this year. He also warned that international mergers, including a potential merger with UBS, are complicated by regulatory approvals and "too big to fail" concerns. Banking consolidation is expected to pick up, but Gottstein cautioned that cross-border deals are more complex than in the past.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse Group chief executive officer Thomas Gottstein said he expects the wealth management business to slow down in the third quarter while revenue and trading will keep pace with earlier this year.

site_title: Keppel Capital surpasses half of target commitments for new US$500m fund
summary: Keppel Capital's US$500 million regional real estate investment fund has surpassed half of its target commitments, with a 70% stake in a Chinese school and other assets in the pipeline for Australia, China, Singapore, South Korea, and Vietnam. The fund aims to reach US$1.2 billion in assets under management. CEO Christina Tan attributes the reception to the fund's defensive asset class and investors' confidence, despite the pandemic. The transactions are not expected to impact Keppel's earnings.

site_title: Incredible Holdings could borrow up to S$9.41m from controlling shareholder
summary: Incredible Holdings, a CATALIST-listed apparel retailer, has secured up to S$9.41 million in loans from companies linked to its controlling shareholder, Mission Well. The loans, which can be repaid in cash, new shares, or a mix of both, will primarily fund business operations, including new acquisitions, financing, and corporate working capital. The bulk of the loan, up to S$9.1 million, is an interest-free facility extended by Mission Well, owned by executive director Christian Heilesen, who holds a 28.15 stake in Incredible.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower as rising Covid-19 cases stoke lockdown worries
summary: Australia's shares fell 0.7% on the ASX 200 index, marking a fourth straight session of losses, due to rising Covid-19 cases in Europe and concerns about potential lockdowns. Mining stocks led the decline, with BHP Group, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals falling. Oil prices plummeted overnight, and iron ore prices dropped for a second session. The decline in commodity prices sapped global risk appetite, with investors worried about a deeper economic slowdown.

site_title: UK watchdog proposes ban on car, home insurance 'loyalty penalties'
summary: Britain's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) proposes banning "loyalty penalties" in car and home insurance, where insurers charge more to repeat customers than new clients. The rule change aims to save consumers £3.7 billion over 10 years. Existing customers will pay no more than new clients for renewals, and insurers must report data to the FCA to ensure fair value. The proposals are open to public consultation until January, with final rules to be published next year.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks post worst fall in a month on Europe lockdown concerns
summary: South Korean stocks plummeted 2.4% on Tuesday, marking the sharpest decline in a month, amid concerns over new coronavirus restrictions in Europe. The benchmark Kospi index fell 56.80 points, with major heavyweights like Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix also experiencing significant losses. Meanwhile, LG Chem surged 5.1% ahead of Tesla's "Battery Day" event, while the Bank of Korea maintained its economic growth projections despite tightened social distancing measures.

site_title: UK electricity price spike raises questions for national grid
summary: The UK's National Grid Plc warned of a spike in electricity prices due to calm weather and warm temperatures, resulting in a 10-fold increase in prices. The company paid a nuclear station not to generate power, reducing the grid's buffer. This incident raises concerns about grid management and potential higher bills for consumers, potentially elevating the issue into a politicized debate.

site_title: SGX and India's National Stock Exchange drop arbitration, agree to work on trading link
summary: SGX and India's National Stock Exchange (NSE) have dropped arbitration proceedings and agreed to work on a trading link, the NSE International Financial Service Centre (IFSC)-SGX Connect. The model will see Nifty futures contracts on the SGX executed in Gujarat's Gift City, with statutory regulators providing fresh clarifications on its rollout. The exchanges aim to develop a connectivity infrastructure incorporating international best practices, creating new value for existing and new customers. The deal paves the way for a bigger liquidity pool for Nifty products and strengthens the capital market ecosystem in Gift City.

site_title: TUI says cost cutting target in sight as it slashes overheads
summary: TUI, the world's largest tour operator, is making progress on its cost-cutting target of 30% as it struggles with a collapse in demand for holidays due to the coronavirus. The company aims to save 300 million euros through projects across its operations, and has already cut jobs and reduced capacity for the fourth quarter. With 2 billion euros in cash and available facilities, TUI is focusing on lower-risk destinations to attract customers.

site_title: New Aviva boss Blanc moves fast to shrink British insurer
summary: Amanda Blanc, Aviva's new CEO, has taken decisive action to reverse the company's share slump by selling control of its Singapore business for $2.7 billion. The company is also exploring the sale of its French unit, valued at around $4.81 billion, and Italian non-life insurance business, with potential buyers including AXA, Allianz, and Apollo Global Management-backed Athora Holding. The divestments could generate billions of pounds for shareholders or deployment in core operations, and are seen as a boon for investment bankers in a year of European mergers and acquisitions.

images.alt_text: Aviva's new boss Amanda Blanc is not wasting any time.

site_title: Coronavirus: No new locations or new clusters announced on Tuesday; no new cases in the community
summary: Singapore reported 21 new coronavirus cases on Tuesday, bringing the total to 57,627. The cases included one imported case and 20 migrant workers in dormitories. There were no new community cases or clusters, maintaining a stable number of daily cases and unlinked cases. 21 cases were discharged, with 57,247 patients fully recovered and 301 recovering in community facilities.

site_title: Beazley sees Covid-19 claims doubling to US$340m, shares slide
summary: Specialist insurer Beazley forecasts Covid-19 claims to double to US$340 million, with most increases due to cancelled events. The estimate, net of reinsurance, offsets growing insurance premium rates and improves overall business prospects. Beazley's shares plummet 15% due to the claims rise, which analysts attribute to exhaustion in the reinsurance market. The company expects conferences to resume only in the second quarter of 2021. If accurate, this prediction could result in further US$50 million in claims.

site_title: Indonesia revises GDP forecast to deeper contraction for 2020
summary: Indonesia's finance minister revised its 2020 GDP forecast to a range of -1.7% to -0.6%, down from -1.1% to 0.2%, citing a flattening economic recovery since easing coronavirus curbs in June. The third-quarter GDP forecast was also revised to -2.9% to -1.0%. Economic activity has improved, but the recovery is slowing.

site_title: Empty UN summit for world in crisis
summary: The United Nations General Assembly is holding a virtual summit due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with leaders sending pre-recorded messages instead of attending in person. US President Donald Trump skipped the event, and the US was represented by a deputy UN envoy. Despite the lack of in-person meetings, the UN is moving ahead with thematic meetings on major issues such as climate change and the pandemic. World leaders, including French President Emmanuel Macron and German Chancellor Angela Merkel, emphasized the need for multilateral diplomacy to address global problems.

images.alt_text: The United Nations General Assembly, the annual extravaganza of world leaders' speeches and round-the-clock diplomacy, opens Tuesday in a quiet hall as a virtual summit addresses the global crisis of Covid-19.

site_title: Suez hits back in takeover fight with promise of US$1.2b shareholder windfall
summary: Suez, a French waste and water management firm, is countering a hostile takeover bid from Veolia with a promise of a $1.2 billion shareholder windfall. Suez plans to return 1 billion euros ($1.6 billion) to shareholders by mid-2021, citing a successful strategy revamp that is delivering results faster than expected. The firm's chairman, Philippe Varin, has described Veolia's plans as "unrealistic." Engie, the owner of a 29.9% stake in Suez, is considering a higher offer for the stake.

images.alt_text: French waste and water management firm Suez, subject of a hostile takeover bid from rival Veolia, on Tuesday said it would hand back more than one billion euros (S$1.60 billion) to its shareholders by the middle of next year.

site_title: Singapore stocks end Tuesday lower on renewed virus fears, STI down 0.9%
summary: Singapore stocks ended the day lower, down 0.9% to close at 2,463.29, due to renewed fears of a coronavirus resurgence and a potential Wall Street retreat. The benchmark Straits Times Index declined as lenders DBS, UOB, and OCBC fell, while aviation-related stocks also declined. Only five of the 30 constituent stocks ended in the green, with Jardine Matheson Holdings being the top advancer. The global recovery risk is seen as rising due to the possibility of national-level lockdowns in major economies.

site_title: Airbus CEO: We can't guarantee no compulsory layoffs
summary: Airbus CEO Guillaume Faury stated that the company is taking measures to cut costs without resorting to compulsory redundancies, but cannot guarantee they won't happen due to the ongoing pandemic's impact on air travel. Airbus has already announced plans to shed 15,000 posts worldwide, and Faury warned staff that the company may need to implement compulsory layoffs if air travel fails to recover.

site_title: Airline travel shifts toward last-minute bookings, domestic trips: Skyscanner
summary: The air travel market has shifted toward last-minute bookings and domestic trips due to the coronavirus pandemic, with one-way flights and searches for travel within a week increasing. Low-cost carriers are benefiting from competitive pricing, while full-service airlines face uncertainty in business travel. Skyscanner reports a 20% increase in global domestic travel searches and a 60-70% decline in website visits. The International Air Transport Association forecasts it will take until 2024 for travel to return to pre-crisis levels.

site_title: 'Work from home': Johnson starts to shut down the UK again as Covid-19 spreads
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson will tell people to work from home and impose new restrictions on pubs, bars, and restaurants as part of measures to tackle the second wave of the Covid-19 outbreak. He will stop short of a full national lockdown and restrict table service to hospitality venues by law. Pubs, bars, and restaurants will close at 10 pm from Thursday, and the hospitality sector will be restricted to take-away services only. Johnson emphasizes the need for people to work from home if possible to control the virus and protect the NHS.

site_title: Proptech startup Ohmyhome launches in the Philippines
summary: Ohmyhome, a proptech startup, has launched in the Philippines, its third location after Singapore and Malaysia. The company aims to tackle traditional property pain points in the Philippine real estate industry, such as lack of transparency and slow feedback. Ohmyhome will offer a full suite of end-to-end property services, including professional real estate agents and mortgage, and is targeting 2,000 listings and 80 transactions in the first quarter. The company believes the Philippine property market will remain resilient due to unmet demand for housing and investors' interest in long-term investments.

site_title: Europe: Stocks edge higher at open
summary: Europe's stock markets rose on Tuesday, recouping losses from the previous day's sell-off, driven by investors seeking bargains amid fears of a deadly second coronavirus wave. The FTSE 100 index gained 0.3%, while the CAC 40 rose 0.1% and the DAX 30 climbed 0.6%. Asian markets continued to fall, extending losses from the previous day's global rout. Fading hopes for a new US stimulus also contributed to the downbeat mood.

site_title: Oakwood launches day-use workspaces at 17 Asia-Pacific properties
summary: Oakwood, a subsidiary of Mapletree Investments, has launched day-use workspaces at 17 Asia-Pacific properties in response to sustained safe-distancing measures. The "Work from Oakwood" solution offers guests luxury personal space, residential comfort, and work amenities, including free Wi-Fi and printing services. The day-use workspaces will be available daily from 7am to 7pm, and guests can also use recreational facilities like fitness centers and pools. This move aims to drive business amidst travel restrictions, with the first day-use workspace opening at Oakwood Studios Singapore with a minimum booking of seven days.

site_title: Are exotic skins out of fashion?
summary: Stockholm Fashion Week has banned exotic skins from its virtual catwalk, following in the footsteps of London Fashion Week, which outlawed fur in 2018. Luxury brands like Burberry, Gucci, and Prada have already dropped exotic skins due to animal-welfare concerns. The move is partly driven by the pandemic, which may be linked to illegal wildlife trafficking. Experts warn that boycotting exotic skins could lead to habitat destruction and increased risk of zoonotic diseases, but some argue that the luxury industry is actually protecting habitats by valuing and conserving exotic species.

site_title: India's fortunes diverge from rest of South Asia as virus surges
summary: India's economic recovery from the coronavirus outbreak is expected to lag behind its South Asian peers due to its failure to effectively contain the virus. The country is now one of the world's virus hotspots with over 5.5 million cases. In contrast, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, and Bangladesh have made significant progress in controlling the virus, resulting in a faster rebound in activity and less severe GDP drop. India is expected to post a double-digit slump in 2020, while its neighbors are expected to recover at a faster pace.

site_title: UK hotelier Whitbread plans to cut almost a fifth of staff
summary: UK hotel operator Whitbread plans to cut 6,000 jobs, approximately 18% of its workforce, due to the pandemic's impact on tourism. The company hopes to achieve this through voluntary departures, with the remaining cuts to be discussed with worker representatives. Comparable sales plummeted 78% in the UK in the first half, prompting the decision.

site_title: Apple's partner Pegatron plans to invest US$1b in Vietnam plant: state media
summary: Taiwan's Pegatron, a manufacturing partner of Apple, Microsoft, and Sony, plans to invest US$1 billion in a plant in Vietnam, with the goal of creating 22,500 jobs and contributing around 100 billion dong (S$5.9 million) to the state budget per year. This investment is part of a three-phase plan, with initial investments of US$19 million and US$481 million, and a third phase expected in 2026-2027. Pegatron would join Apple's two other iPhone assemblers, Wistron Corp and Foxconn, in developing more capacity in Vietnam, amid efforts to skirt US tariffs on Chinese goods.

site_title: Permira buys German specialty pharma group Neuraxpharm
summary: Permira has agreed to buy German specialty pharma group Neuraxpharm for approximately 1.6 billion euros, valuing the company at 13 times its expected 2021 core earnings. The deal, worth 2.56 billion SGD, is expected to result in a gross multiple on invested capital of 3.5 times and a gross internal rate of return of 36%. Apax, the seller, acquired Neuraxpharm in 2016 and strengthened the company through add-on acquisitions. The deal is seen as benefiting from an expected surge in demand for Neuraxpharm's central nervous system products.

site_title: American Airlines begins scheduling Boeing 737 MAX pilot training
summary: American Airlines has begun scheduling Boeing 737 MAX pilot training for November, indicating a potential return to service for the grounded jet. The training plans are non-definitive and can be cancelled if the MAX is not recertified by the Federal Aviation Administration and Boeing. The airline remains in contact with the FAA and Boeing, suggesting progress in the certification process.

site_title: Sterling falls to two-month low ahead of new UK restrictions
summary: The British pound fell to a two-month low against the dollar on Tuesday, dropping 0.51% to US$1.2751, ahead of new mobility restrictions to combat the second wave of the coronavirus outbreak. The restrictions, announced by Prime Minister Boris Johnson, include working from home and limiting pubs, bars, and restaurants. This move is seen as a step short of a full national lockdown, which was imposed in March. The pound's decline is a response to the uncertainty and economic concerns surrounding the new restrictions.

site_title: Sequoia Capital China raising 15b yuan in new yuan fund: sources
summary: Sequoia Capital China is raising at least 15 billion yuan (S$3.01 billion) in a new yuan-denominated fund, its sixth, to focus on sectors such as industrial technology, healthcare, and consumer media. The firm is expected to fully close the fundraising in the coming weeks, with a final fund size of 18 billion yuan. The move comes amid US-China tensions over technology and concerns about Chinese firms' ability to access private capital overseas.

site_title: Rich Capital plans review to protect JV investments, look into potential breaches
summary: Rich Capital Holdings, a Singapore-listed property developer, plans to conduct an independent review to protect its investments in the joint venture Oxley Karya Indo Batam (OKIB). The review comes after the disabling of Rich Capital's banking tokens for OKIB's Maybank accounts and unauthorized debit from another JV bank account. The audit committee has commissioned the review to address "external forces at play and potential internal issues" and will report its findings to the authorities and SGX's regulatory arm.

site_title: Fed chief Powell slated for first of week's three congressional appearances
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell is set to testify before Congress for the first time this week, addressing lawmakers' concerns about the central bank's emergency measures to combat the coronavirus pandemic. Powell will discuss the Fed's programs to help small businesses and its efforts to limit economic inequality. He will also address the ongoing economic recovery, stating that while progress has been made, the path ahead remains uncertain and that additional federal stimulus may be needed. The hearings come six weeks before the presidential election, a key issue in the pandemic response.

images.alt_text: US Federal Reserve (Fed) chair Jerome Powell on Tuesday makes the first of three appearances on Capitol Hill this week to address lawmakers' questions and concerns about the raft of emergency measures the central bank has taken to blunt the hit to the economy delivered by the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Tencent's WeChat app sees downloads surge before US ban
summary: US tech giants Apple and Google plan to remove Chinese messaging app WeChat from their stores due to national security concerns, but a judge blocked the move on Sunday. Despite the ban, WeChat saw a surge in downloads in the US, with 54,000 installations between Friday and Saturday, a 28-fold increase from the previous week. WeCom, an office collaboration app, also saw a significant jump in downloads. The US Commerce Department will challenge the order, and Tencent has warned that updates for existing US users may be affected.

site_title: Hong Kong extends social distancing measures for another week
summary: Hong Kong extends social distancing measures for another week due to persisting signs of hidden Covid-19 transmission, despite moderating numbers. The city has reported just two new local cases, with four imported. Chief executive Carrie Lam urged businesses to exercise self-discipline, especially with school campuses starting to reopen. The measures, which include limits on public gatherings and extended hours for bars and restaurants, will remain in place until at least September 29.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong will extend virus-related social distancing measures for another week, amid persisting signs of hidden Covid-19 transmission, chief executive Carrie Lam said.

site_title: Coronavirus dampens seasonal cheer in China's Christmas production hub
summary: China's Christmas production hub, Yiwu, faces bleak prospects due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The city, which exports 80% of global Christmas consumer goods, has lost nearly half its clients and expects a poor year, with many sellers left holding excess stock. Wholesale prices for decorations remain low, and finding alternate buyers has been difficult due to the pandemic and China's reluctance to celebrate Christmas domestically. The pandemic's impact on international business travel and entry bans have significantly reduced the city's usual flow of customers.

site_title: Honduran coffee exports likely to rise 14% next season
summary: Honduran coffee exports are expected to rise 14% during the 2020/2021 season, driven by favorable weather conditions and new plantations coming online. The country is forecast to ship 6.28 million 60-kg bags, up from 5.52 million bags in the current season. This growth is attributed to a good winter and new areas entering production, according to Francisco Ordoñez, president of the national coffee institute IHCAFE.

site_title: Wirecard woes mount for Ernst & Young as clients leave auditor
summary: Germany's third-largest bank, KfW, may drop Ernst & Young as auditor due to its role in the Wirecard accounting scandal. Commerzbank and DWS Group have already moved away from EY, citing conflicts of interest and poor work. The German government is reviewing the auditing of KfW, and other companies are expected to follow, as management teams seek to show they're taking allegations seriously. EY has denied allegations of failing in its duty and has faced criticism for its consulting divisions and potential conflicts of interest.

site_title: Gold edges higher as US dollar halts surge on Covid worries
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,918.20 per ounce, as the US dollar held steady despite concerns over fresh coronavirus lockdowns in Europe. The US dollar index declined 0.1% against its rivals, after reaching its highest in over a month. Gold has risen nearly 26% this year, driven by economic uncertainty and safe-haven demand. Other precious metals, including silver, platinum, and palladium, also gained ground, with silver rising 1.1% and palladium up 0.5%.

site_title: Meal delivery startup Freshly is said to plan 2021 US listing
summary: Freshly Inc, a meal delivery startup, plans to go public in 2021 with a valuation of over $1 billion. The company, which delivers ready-made meals, has already sold over one million dishes per week. Freshly has interviewed potential advisers and is exploring options including a sale or merger with a special purpose acquisition company. This comes as competitors Blue Apron and HelloFresh have seen significant growth during the pandemic, with Blue Apron's stock more than doubling since 2017.

site_title: New York police officer charged with spying for China
summary: A New York police officer, born in China, has been charged with espionage for gathering information about the city's Tibetan community on behalf of the Chinese government. The 33-year-old officer, who had been granted political asylum in the US, was directed by Chinese consulate members and allegedly accepted tens of thousands of dollars for his service. He faces four counts, including enlisting in the service of a foreign country and obstructing a public service. The officer is currently suspended without pay and has been taken into custody.

site_title: BlackRock, JPMorgan climate votes at odds as new rules loom
summary: Top US asset managers BlackRock and JPMorgan Chase & Co are divided in their support of climate-related proxy resolutions, with BlackRock offering little backing and JPMorgan supporting them roughly half the time.
