Climate-focused shareholder organizations found that other fund firms supported the resolutions about half the time or more. The findings come ahead of a key rulemaking, prompting criticism that BlackRock hasn't backed up its vows to prioritize climate matters.

images.alt_text: Top US asset managers BlackRock and JPMorgan Chase & Co were divided in their support of climate-related proxy resolutions at corporate meetings this year, two analyses showed on Tuesday, underscoring the industry's mixed appetite for the vehicles ahead of a key rulemaking.

site_title: E-sports startup Ampverse closes pre-Series A round for regional expansion
summary: E-sports startup Ampverse has secured pre-Series A funding for regional expansion, with an oversubscribed round led by investors from the global gaming, media, and technology sectors. The Singapore and Thailand-based startup will use the funding to double its headcount, develop proprietary technology solutions, and create a bespoke content studio. Ampverse aims to further expand in South-east Asia, leveraging the region's vast opportunities for growth in the video-gaming industry.

site_title: The flight goes nowhere. And it's sold out.
summary: Airlines are offering "flights to nowhere" as a way to keep staff working and satisfy travelers' itch to fly during the pandemic. These flights, which start and end at the same airport, have sold out quickly, with Qantas announcing a seven-hour flight over Australia and Royal Brunei offering similar experiences. The practice has also sparked criticism from environmental groups, who argue that it is unnecessary and contributes to greenhouse gas emissions. Despite this, airlines claim to be offsetting their carbon emissions and offering luxurious experiences for passengers.

site_title: Beijing unlikely to approve ByteDance's TikTok deal with Oracle: Global Times
summary: ByteDance's proposed deal with Oracle and Walmart to restructure TikTok into a US subsidiary, TikTok Global, is unlikely to receive Chinese government approval, according to the state-backed newspaper Global Times. The deal requires four American board seats and a US-approved "national security director," which China objects to as "bribery" and "bullying style." China views the deal as a threat to national security and interests, and may block it, potentially leading to a shutdown of TikTok in the US.

site_title: Hong Kong-listed semiconductor maker ASM Pacific plans to go private: sources
summary: ASM Pacific Technology, a Hong Kong-listed semiconductor equipment manufacturer, is in talks to go private with potential investors. The company aims to eventually relist itself on Shanghai's Star Market, which has higher valuations. ASM's parent, ASM International, supports the proposal but will not divest its 25% stake. A potential deal would cost outside investors at least $3.2 billion, based on ASM's current market value of $4.2 billion. This follows a trend of Hong Kong-listed companies announcing take-private deals worth over $17.8 billion this year, citing undervalued shares.

site_title: Major cruise lines will all require Covid-19 tests and masks: trade group
summary: Major cruise lines such as Carnival Corp and Royal Caribbean Cruises will require COVID-19 tests for guests and crew, as well as masks when social distancing isn't possible, according to a trade group announcement. This move aims to help the pandemic-crippled industry sail again. The measures were announced by Cruise Lines International Association, representing major cruise lines, after joint health panel recommendations from Royal Caribbean and Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings.

site_title: US judge fast-tracks Tiffany's case on US$16b LVMH deal, sets January trial
summary: A US judge has fast-tracked Tiffany & Co's lawsuit against LVMH, setting a four-day trial starting January 5, 2021, over the luxury goods conglomerate's attempt to back out of its $16 billion deal to acquire Tiffany. The deal hit a snag after LVMH cited a French government intervention and Tiffany's weakening performance due to Covid-19. LVMH claims it can defeat Tiffany's accusations and convince the court that the deal's conditions are no longer met, while Tiffany's chairman says the company has acted in good faith.

site_title: Asia: Markets track US, Europe rout as restrictions return
summary: Asian markets continued their losses following a US and European rout, as governments imposed new containment measures to combat a second wave of virus infections. The US stock market fell due to uncertainty over a new stimulus package amid Capitol Hill hostilities sparked by Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg's death. Markets are concerned about the potential return of strict stay-at-home rules in the northern hemisphere winter, and the US may experience another virus cycle.

site_title: Xi's push to end poverty underpins party support in rural China
summary: China's President Xi Jinping is likely to announce the completion of his goal to eradicate extreme rural poverty by the end of this year, a promise he made in 2016. Over 10 million people have been resettled in government-built housing since then, with the number of extremely poor rural residents falling to 5.5 million last year. Success will boost public support for the Communist Party, which is crucial for maintaining its one-party rule. However, critics argue that the government's focus on absolute poverty ignores the "near poor" who are more affected by economic hits, such as the pandemic and floods.

site_title: Apple chief says fires and storms show impact of climate change
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook stated that recent wildfires, hurricanes, and floods serve as strong evidence of climate change, urging those denying its reality to reconsider. Cook cited these disasters, including the US West Coast wildfires, as proof of the impact of greenhouse gases on weather patterns. He expressed hope that these events will convince skeptics, including US President Donald Trump, of climate change's validity. Cook also addressed antitrust concerns, stating Apple has no monopoly power, and acknowledged the challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic, which has led to widespread remote work.

site_title: China ETFs give retail investors access to soaring tech, Ant stocks
summary: China's largest fund houses are launching four exchange-traded funds (ETFs) that track the Star 50 Index, giving retail investors access to the nation's soaring tech firms, including Ant Group. The ETFs, which require a minimum investment of 1,000 yuan, are expected to attract up to 20 billion yuan in subscriptions. The launch comes ahead of Ant Group's expected listing on the Star Board, which could raise a combined $35 billion, making it the world's largest initial public offering. The new funds aim to bring in incremental flows to the board and provide retail investors with access to the market.

site_title: Trump to meet state attorneys general to discuss key US tech liability shield
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to meet with a group of Republican state attorneys general to discuss revising a key law that shields social media companies from liability for user-posted content. The law, which allows companies to remove lawful but objectionable posts, is seen as a major issue in protecting consumers and ensuring informed rights. Trump aims to hear the attorneys general's perspectives on the matter, with White House spokesman Judd Deere stating that online censorship affects consumers and protecting them is crucial. The meeting is expected to focus on revising the liability shield law.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump plans to meet on Wednesday with a group of Republican state attorneys general about revising a key law that shields social media companies from liability for content posted by their users and allows them to remove lawful but objectionable posts.

site_title: US home shopping boom buoys shipping lines half a world away
summary: A US online home shopping boom has driven up transpacific sea freight rates to record highs, benefiting Asian shipping companies. Exports of household appliances and electronics from South Korea to the US increased 51% and 169% respectively in August. Shipping rates on the transpacific route have nearly tripled from March's low, with a 40-foot container from Shanghai to Los Angeles costing $3,922. This surge in demand has boosted earnings for companies like HMM Co and AP Moller-Maersk, with profits expected to continue until the end of the year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open on Tuesday with more losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks began Tuesday with more losses, following a heavy sell-off in New York and Europe, due to worries about lockdown measures in response to fresh virus infections. The Hang Sang Index dropped 0.46% to 23,839.67, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 0.79% and 0.81%, respectively.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks began Tuesday morning with more losses following a heavy sell-off in New York and Europe, fuelled by worries about the reimposition of some lockdown measures in some countries in response to a fresh wave of virus infections.

site_title: Tokio Marine Life Insurance Singapore makes C-suite appointments
summary: Tokio Marine Life Insurance Singapore has appointed three senior executives: Edwin Peh as CFO, Esmond Chan as COO, and Goh Kay Yiong as CIO. Peh brings nearly 25 years of experience in the life insurance industry, while Chan has 27 years of experience at NTUC Income. Goh has over 17 years of experience in the financial services industry. The appointments aim to enhance the insurer's finance, operations, and investment management capabilities.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit low as miners drag; US stimulus woes weigh
summary: Australian shares hit a three-month low due to miners and energy stocks being pressured by overnight US Wall Street losses. Concerns about a delayed US stimulus package and new lockdowns in Europe and the UK spurred fears of a slower global recovery, affecting equity markets. Major miners BHP Group and Rio Tinto fell 2% each, while gold stocks declined 3.3% to their lowest since September 14.

site_title: Singapore brand mark to be introduced for local lifestyle products
summary: Singapore will introduce a national brand mark for local lifestyle products, starting with food and beverage, fashion, beauty, and homeware in November. The move aims to deepen trust and premium for local brands, following the country's strong growth in the food manufacturing industry, which has seen a 6.45% annual growth rate. The brand mark will also contribute to Singapore's food security and resilience, creating jobs for local residents and boosting the global value chain.

site_title: Climate change since 2000 will cut US growth over next 30 years: CBO
summary: The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) projects that climate change since 2000 will slow US economic growth by 0.03% annually from 2020 to 2050, reducing real US GDP output by 1% over 30 years. This slowdown is due to various climate-related factors, including drought, damage to factories from intense storms, and extreme heat. The CBO's long-term budget outlook also predicts that US federal government debt will reach nearly double the country's GDP output in 2050 due to increased borrowing and interest costs.

site_title: Musk sees no immediate boost from 'Battery Day' tech unveil
summary: Elon Musk stated that improvements unveiled at Tesla's "Battery Day" event won't reach "serious high-volume production" until 2022, disappointing analysts who expected significant advancements. Musk said the announced upgrades would mainly impact long-term production, particularly for the Semi, Cybertruck, and Roadster, but would not be ready for mass production until 2022.

site_title: HSBC orders social media blackout after suspect funds report
summary: HSBC has ordered its staff to stop posting on all social media accounts until at least 11am UK time Tuesday, following the release of leaked suspicious activity reports revealing the bank's involvement in transactions linked to money laundering and a Chinese Ponzi scheme. The bank's shares fell 2.7% in Hong Kong as a result. HSBC has denied being a "safer institution" than it was in 2012, stating it has made significant efforts to combat financial crime. The bank operates dozens of social media accounts worldwide, providing customer information.

site_title: Huawei plans more cuts to jobs, investment in Australia
summary: Huawei plans to further reduce staff numbers and investment in Australia due to strained relations with Canberra. The company, which was banned from supplying equipment for 5G mobile networks in 2018, has already cut 1,000 jobs and terminated A$100 million in research and development investments. Huawei's chief corporate affairs officer, Jeremy Mitchell, stated that the 5G ban has cost the company 1,000 high-tech and high-wage jobs from the economy. The company's Australian operation now has fewer than 200 staff members.

site_title: Ethical chocolate gets a boost with cocoa-trading giant Olam tracing origins
summary: Olam International, the world's third-largest cocoa processor, has made significant strides in tracing the origins of the majority of the beans it buys, with 60% of its purchases being traceable to individual farms or cooperatives. The move aims to increase sustainability efforts, particularly in addressing child labor, deforestation, and poverty. Olam's technology allows it to track 600,000 tonnes of cocoa in nine countries, and the company plans to work with governments and other suppliers to reach the full supply chain. This step comes as the European Union and US lawmakers introduce legislation to hold companies accountable for human rights abuses and environmental harm in their supply chains.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall as new virus curbs in Europe fuel growth concerns
summary: South Korean stocks fell 2% on Tuesday, tracking global losses due to new coronavirus restrictions in Europe. The Kospi index dropped 46.34 points to 2,343.05, with most market heavyweights, including Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix, slumping. LG Chem rose 5.1% ahead of Tesla's "Battery Day" event. South Korea reported 61 new coronavirus cases, lower than the previous day. Foreigners sold 71.7 billion won worth of shares, contributing to the decline.

site_title: China fines Luckin Coffee, associated firms combined 61m yuan
summary: China's markets regulator fined 45 firms, including Luckin Coffee, 61 million yuan (S$12.2 million) for acts linked to Luckin's falsification of financial records and misleading the public. Luckin booked 2.25 billion yuan in fake sales through coupons from April 2019 to end of 2019, and also inflated other figures such as revenue, costs, and profit in the same period.

site_title: Garuda boss says bankruptcy off table despite Covid strains
summary: Indonesia's flag carrier Garuda Indonesia has ruled out bankruptcy despite struggling with the COVID-19 pandemic, which has decimated air travel demand worldwide. The airline is expecting a 8.5 trillion rupiah (S$790.4 million) government loan to help it recover. Garuda's President Director Irfan Setiaputra said better loan terms on aircraft loans will help the company avoid bankruptcy, citing confidence from aircraft lessors. The airline is taking steps to cut costs and renegotiate with lessors to improve its financial situation, with passenger numbers expected to return to 50% of pre-pandemic levels by the end of the year.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed for holiday on Tuesday
summary: Financial markets in Japan are closed on Tuesday for a public holiday, with trading resuming on September 23. In other markets, Singapore's stocks rallied for a fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data, while the US stock market edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq indices rose, despite mixed Federal Reserve views. Meanwhile, eSIM platform Airalo raised $220 million in new funding, lifting its valuation past $1 billion.

site_title: Migrant factory workers in Thailand launch legal action after wages expose
summary: Migrant factory workers in Thailand are taking legal action against a garment factory owner, Kanlayanee Ruengrit, who was ordered to pay 3.48 million baht in compensation to 26 workers who lost their jobs due to a raid by labor officials. The workers, who were making goods for major brands including Starbucks and Walt Disney, were underpaid and faced retaliation after speaking out. A civil lawsuit has been filed on their behalf, and the owner faces a fine of up to 20,000 baht and/or a year in prison if found guilty.

site_title: Everton Road shophouse in District 2 for sale with S$7.5m guide price
summary: A freehold conservation shophouse at 9 Everton Road in District 2, Singapore, is up for sale via expression of interest (EOI) with an indicative price of S$7.5 million. The two-storey shophouse has a built-up area of about 4,000 sq ft and is situated in the Blair Plain conservation area, near Outram Park MRT station. The sale is seen as a rare opportunity for discerning home seekers or investors, with only four units having transacted in the area in the last two years. The EOI exercise will close on October 20.

site_title: Here's what investors with US$3.4t are buying during Covid
summary: Sovereign wealth funds, pension firms, and asset managers are cautious in the post-COVID-19 market, avoiding overheated stocks and focusing on value. Many are investing in "less loved" areas such as retail, infrastructure, and convenience stores. They also see opportunities in bonds, particularly carmaker bonds, and are looking for digital, transport, and social infrastructure investments. Some, like Australia's sovereign wealth fund, are keeping a cautious stance, while others, like Temasek Holdings, are optimistic about China's consumer technology and life sciences sectors.

site_title: Top GameStop investor wants to turn retailer into Amazon rival
summary: Ryan Cohen, the entrepreneur behind Chewy.com, is pushing GameStop to become an Amazon rival by broadening its online selection, improving customer service, and investing in digital infrastructure. Cohen, who owns nearly 10% of GameStop, is in talks with management and board members to implement his vision, which includes offering a wide range of merchandise and services, and competing directly with Amazon. The move aims to revitalize the struggling retailer, which has seen declining sales and a net loss in recent years, and capitalize on the upcoming console upgrade cycle.

site_title: Reserve Bank of Australia assessing various policy options to revive economy: Debelle
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia is assessing various monetary policy options to revive the economy, including currency market intervention, negative rates, and buying bonds with maturities beyond three years. Deputy Governor Guy Debelle stated that the bank is considering these options to meet its inflation and employment goals, which are not currently aligned. The bank has maintained its highly accommodative settings since the coronavirus crisis, and Debelle noted that a lower exchange rate would be beneficial for the Australian economy.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, UOB, OCBC, Keppel, SingHaiyi, Fragrance
summary: Singaporean banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC are using data to customize personal finance, with DBS converting customer data into hyper-personalized recommendations. DBS also handled approximately $4.5 billion in suspicious transactions between 2000 and 2017. Keppel Corporation secured two contracts worth $200 million, while SingHaiyi Group accepted a tender offer to sell 17.5 million stapled securities for $15.9 million. Fragrance Group saw its first-half cost of sales increase due to a new project in Australia.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.02 points to 1,499.45. Trading volume reached 568.88 million lots worth RM227.45 million, with losers beating gainers 333 to 170. This follows a global stock market trend, with US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, and Singapore's STI index rising 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Tuesday's open; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.3% at Tuesday's open, with the Straits Times Index (STI) losing 7.18 points to 2,478.53. The decline was driven by a regional rout on Monday, largely due to Covid-19 resurgence in Europe and the UK. Key bank stocks, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB, also fell, with DBS losing 1% due to handling of suspicious transactions. The decline was part of a global trend, with Wall Street stocks dropping for a third straight session and the FTSE 100 marking its worst day in over three months.

site_title: Chinese hotel giant eyes foreign deals as global brands languish
summary: China's largest hotel operator, Huazhu Group, is eyeing foreign acquisitions as the country's domestic travel market recovers. Despite global peers like Marriott International and Hilton Worldwide International struggling due to travel restrictions, Huazhu's occupancy rate reached 69% in the second quarter, outperforming its rivals. The company aims to expand globally, with plans to open over 1,600 new hotels this year and reach 10,000 hotels by 2023. However, Chinese companies may face resistance in acquiring foreign assets due to rising tensions with countries like the US, Australia, and Canada.

site_title: Europe: FTSE 100 sinks over 3% on lockdown fears, banks slide
summary: The FTSE 100 index in Europe plummeted 3.4% to a two-week low on Monday, with travel stocks and banks heavily affected by fears of more coronavirus-related lockdowns. HSBC and Standard Chartered slid on reports of illicit funds, while British Airways-owner IAG dropped 12.1%. Investment directors warned of a significant economic impact, with unemployment concerns rising.

site_title: Oil falls 5% as economic outlook dims with rising virus cases
summary: Oil prices plummeted 5% on Monday as rising coronavirus cases fueled concerns over global demand, while a potential Libyan production restart bolstered oversupply fears. Brent crude fell 3.96% to $41.44 a barrel, and US crude dropped 4.38% to $39.31 a barrel. Rising cases in Europe and potential lockdowns cast doubt on economic recovery, prompting a risk-averse market shift.

site_title: 'Covid catalyst' should spur firms to transform digitally to thrive: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing emphasized the need for firms to transform digitally to thrive in a post-Covid-19 world, warning that failing to adapt could lead to being overtaken by others. He noted that digitalization has allowed firms to transcend geographical limitations and access new markets. The government will provide support for firms to cope with the transformation, and the Singapore Business Federation and Infocomm Media Development Authority have renewed their commitment to drive digital transformation among the business community through various initiatives.

site_title: Apple CEO impressed by remote work, sees permanent changes
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook expressed support for remote work, stating that some new work habits will remain after the pandemic. Despite the challenges of working remotely, Cook said Apple created products on time and predicted a shift towards virtual work. He noted that remote work is "not like being together physically" and sparks creativity through impromptu meetings. Cook also emphasized the importance of policy over politics in company discussions. He hopes 10-15% of Apple employees will return to the office by next year, with the majority returning to the company's Silicon Valley campus.

site_title: Theresa May says government putting UK integrity at risk, could damage Northern Ireland peace
summary: Former UK Prime Minister Theresa May warns that the government's plan to break its EU exit treaty could damage the UK's integrity and peace in Northern Ireland. She stated that this would lead to communities losing trust in the UK government, potentially threatening Northern Ireland's continued membership in the UK. The Belfast Good Friday Agreement, which established the peace process, is at risk of being undermined by the government's actions.

site_title: Trump says aides rejected his request to adjust value of US dollar
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that his aides rejected his request to adjust the value of the US dollar to counter China's alleged currency manipulation. Trump claimed China deliberately weakens the yuan to gain a competitive advantage, but China denies this. The US Treasury Department has not commented on the matter, and the department's long-delayed semi-annual currency report is expected to be released soon. The yuan has firmed for eight weeks against a softening dollar, contradicting Trump's claims.

site_title: Trump administration designates several US cities hotbeds of 'anarchy'
summary: The Trump administration designated New York, Seattle, and Portland as "jurisdictions permitting anarchy," threatening to withhold federal aid over civil unrest. The move aims to bolster President Trump's "law and order" image ahead of the November election. The Department of Justice cited a spike in shootings, protests, and looting in these cities, including reduced police budgets in New York. The mayor of New York City, Bill de Blasio, dismissed the move as "another one of President Trump's games," saying it's unconstitutional and will be challenged in court.

site_title: Emmys hit new ratings low despite praise for 'remote' ceremony
summary: The 72nd Emmy Awards, held remotely due to the pandemic, drew an all-time low of 6.1 million viewers, down from 6.9 million last year and 10.2 million the previous year. Despite technical challenges, the ceremony was well-received, marking a trend of declining ratings for major award shows.

site_title: UK house prices up by most since 2016 as Britons seek more space
summary: UK house prices rose 5% from last year, the largest increase since September 2016, driven by Britons' desire for more living space and a tax break on purchases. The largest price gains were seen in regions outside London, with average prices reaching £319,996. The pandemic has fueled a boom in the property market, with sales of three and four-bedroom homes more than doubling. However, rising unemployment and expiring tax breaks may weigh on prices in the coming months.

site_title: US economy to recover only when people feel 'safe' from virus: Powell
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell said the economy will only recover when people feel safe to resume normal activities due to the coronavirus. Despite some sectors rebounding, viral infections remain widespread and Congress is deadlocked on additional spending. Powell stated that a full recovery will depend on controlling the virus and policy actions at all levels of government. The Fed has rolled out trillions in liquidity, but lawmakers have been unable to agree on more support for the economy, with White House advisor Larry Kudlow expressing confidence in a self-sustaining recovery.

site_title: Centurion invites noteholders to exchange, sell S$60m due-2022 notes
summary: Centurion Corp is inviting noteholders of its existing S$60 million due-2022 notes to exchange them for new 3.5-year notes at a premium or sell them for cash at par. The company plans to redeem all outstanding notes on Feb 1, 2021, and is offering an exchange premium of 0.25% of the principal amount. Noteholders will receive accrued interest and a principal amount of the new notes. The new notes will carry a 5.75% coupon until April 11, 2023, and an 8.25% coupon thereafter.

site_title: US: Stocks fall again on virus, fading stimulus odds
summary: US stocks fell for a third consecutive session on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 1.8% and the S&P 500 1.2% lower. The decline was driven by worries about the latest coronavirus surge and dwindling chances of another US stimulus bill, following the death of US Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg. Other factors, including a surge of Covid-19 cases in Europe and a drop in major banks, contributed to the market's downturn.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore stocks rallied for the fifth consecutive day ahead of the release of GDP data. NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potentially lower-than-target H2 revenue and similar operating losses. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case, and London's Heathrow eyed higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. MAS and the PBOC announced plans to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Talk show host Ellen DeGeneres apologises over toxic workplace allegations
summary: Talk show host Ellen DeGeneres apologized for a toxic workplace culture at her show, addressing allegations of fear, racism, and intimidation among employees. DeGeneres acknowledged her privilege and power, taking responsibility for the issues and stating that her program is starting a "new chapter" with necessary changes. Three high-level producers were let go following an internal investigation by Warner Media. DeGeneres denied allegations that her offstage personality differs from her on-air persona, saying she is the same person seen on TV, and expressed regret for not engaging more meaningfully with critics, calling her apology a "platitude."

site_title: Airbus unveils concepts for hydrogen-powered plane
summary: Airbus has unveiled three concepts for zero-emission hydrogen-powered planes, aiming to achieve a carbon-free commercial aircraft by 2035. The "ZEROe" initiative includes conventional and blended wing body designs for turbofan and turboprop engines, which would burn liquid hydrogen stored in the rear fuselage. Airbus plans to develop a demonstrator by 2021 and expects to assess promising architectures by 2025. Challenges include safely storing liquid hydrogen during flight and reducing costs, which proponents say will decrease with infrastructure investment and rising demand.

site_title: Australia to invest A$18b in energy technology to cut emissions
summary: Australia plans to invest A$18 billion over 10 years in low-carbon energy technologies, including hydrogen, energy storage, and carbon capture, to reduce emissions. The government aims to cut costs in these technologies, such as battery storage (less than A$100 per megawatt hour) and carbon capture (less than A$20 per tonne). The plan stops short of proposing a net-zero emissions target by 2050 or a carbon price, instead focusing on driving investments through cost-effective technologies. This move aims to balance emissions reduction with economic growth.

site_title: Trump vows to block any TikTok deal that allows Chinese control
summary: US President Donald Trump vowed to block any TikTok deal that allows Chinese control, amid a restructured ownership plan that would make Silicon Valley giant Oracle the data partner and retail giant Walmart a stakeholder in a new entity called TikTok Global. Trump stated that Oracle would own the controlling interest and that ByteDance, TikTok's Chinese parent firm, would have "nothing to do with it." The deal, which was initially touted as a possible solution to a US-ordered ban of TikTok, remains uncertain due to differing accounts on the American and Chinese shares of the new firm.

site_title: England to require earlier 10pm closing time for pubs, eateries after virus spike
summary: England to require earlier 10pm closing time for pubs, eateries after virus spike. The move, announced by Prime Minister Boris Johnson, aims to control a second wave of Covid-19 infections and protect the NHS. The new rules will restrict table service only, and pubs and restaurants must close at 10pm from Thursday. The decision comes as the country faces an exponentially growing death rate from Covid-19, with the alert level moving to Level 4, indicating high or rising exponentially transmission.

site_title: Diamonds are forever and for moments like no other
summary: The world's top diamond producers have launched a celebrity-led campaign, "Only Natural Diamonds," to counter the pandemic's damage to the gems market. Actress Ana de Armas is the new ambassador for the Natural Diamond Council's campaign, which aims to promote natural diamonds and tap into consumers' desire for luxury and meaning. The campaign, similar to past marketing strategies, features glamorous ads and celebrity endorsements, and is seen as a response to the pandemic's impact on the global diamond market.

site_title: Britain plans law to safeguard City of London's global standing
summary: Britain plans to introduce a new Financial Services Bill to safeguard the City of London's global standing after its departure from the European Union. The bill aims to create a modern and flexible financial regulation system, maintaining the UK's world-leading prudential standards and promoting openness to international markets. The move comes as the UK's financial sector faces challenges from EU regulations, with the EU granting temporary access to UK clearing houses but limiting direct services to customers. The bill is expected to bolster the UK's global competitiveness and openness.

site_title: Thailand removes plaque critical of monarchy after protest
summary: Thai authorities removed a plaque critical of the monarchy during a protest, which drew tens of thousands seeking greater democracy. The plaque, installed by protesters, proclaimed Thailand "belongs to the people, not the monarchy." The Fine Arts Department and Bangkok Metropolitan Administration removed the plaque and filed a complaint against the protesters for breaking the law on ancient monuments. The protest group is pressing for the resignation of Prime Minister Prayut Chan-Ocha and a rewriting of the constitution, including reforms to the monarchy.

site_title: Domestic tourism, last-minute bookings key to saving Asia's travel sector
summary: Asia's travel sector is expected to undergo significant changes due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Business travel is likely to be forever changed, with remote working practices becoming more prevalent. Leisure travel will also shift towards smaller, domestic trips, with tourists becoming more cautious about international destinations. Domestic tourism is seen as a potential savior, with countries like Indonesia and China experiencing increased bookings. Last-minute bookings are also on the rise, with flight bookings being made 17 days later on average, down from pre-pandemic levels. The industry must reinvent itself to adapt to these changes and prepare for a post-pandemic recovery.

site_title: No partnership between Huttons Group, Century 21
summary: Century 21 has clarified that it is not considering a partnership with rival Huttons Group, following an announcement that caused concern among its agents. The clarification comes after Huttons said it was embarking on "a new chapter of growth" with partners from Savills and Century 21. Over 100 Century 21 associates have joined Huttons since March, but the companies will remain separate entities.

site_title: Thailand set to become South-east Asia's IPO star this year
summary: Thailand is poised to become the largest initial public offering (IPO) market in South-east Asia this year, with SCG Packaging Pcl's $1.27 billion offering kicking off on Monday. The company's IPO has raised nearly $3 billion from Thai IPOs so far in 2020, with 677 million new shares allocated to local and foreign funds. This surpasses the region's total of $4.23 billion from first-time share sales, which is down 21% from last year.

site_title: Scandal-hit Loh cousins seeking to offload their stake in Axington
summary: Singaporean duo Nelson and Terence Loh, amid mounting public scrutiny and a police report, are seeking to offload their stake in Catalist-listed Axington Inc. The Loh cousins have approached several parties to buy out their Axington stake, driven by a looming loan of S$20 million. The move comes as the company faces public scrutiny and a potential accounting scandal.

site_title: Norway wealth fund may move US$50b into US stocks from Europe
summary: Norway's $1.15 trillion sovereign wealth fund may shift $50 billion into US stocks and reduce its European holdings, following a proposal by the government and the central bank. The changes aim to better represent the global distribution of value creation in listed companies. The fund currently holds 2.6% of European shares and 1.5% of North American shares, but the proposed changes would shift the focus to US stocks, with a greater weighting towards North America and a reduced weighting towards Europe. The changes must be approved by parliament.

site_title: Yangon in lockdown as Covid-19 infections soar ahead of Myanmar elections in Nov
summary: Myanmar has locked down most of Yangon province for two weeks due to a record surge in Covid-19 infections, ahead of the general elections scheduled for November. The lockdown restricts travel and limits family gatherings, while essential services and government employees are allowed to operate. The nation has reported 5,805 cases and 94 deaths, with a surge in new cases on Sunday, a single-day record. About two dozen parties are calling for the vote to be postponed, but the ruling party favors proceeding with the election on schedule.

site_title: Tenet leads US box office again, while Mulan sales drop in China
summary: US movie theater attendance slumped over the weekend, with Tenet remaining the top-grossing film despite a 26% drop in ticket sales. Tenet earned $4.7 million, while Disney's Mulan dropped 72% to $6.5 million in mainland China. The decline in attendance is attributed to continued theater closures and audience wariness, with some studios delaying big releases, including Warner Bros' Wonder Woman 1984. About 58% of North America's 6,000 theaters are open, and industry representatives say awareness and safety precautions are crucial to attracting audiences back to cinemas.

site_title: Anna Netrebko hospitalised with Covid-19
summary: Russian soprano Anna Netrebko has been hospitalized with pneumonia caused by COVID-19, she announced in an Instagram post. The 5-day hospital stay follows her recent performances at the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow, where she was in close contact with a singer who later tested positive for the virus. Netrebko's decision to perform despite the risk has sparked concern among opera companies, but her manager says she is recovering and was not among those who tested positive.

site_title: UOB lags local peers in green banking: Maybank-KE
summary: UOB lags behind local peers in green banking, with only 14% of its incremental lending in 2019 going towards sustainable uses, compared to 35% for peers. The bank faces environmental, governance, and social risks, including exposure to multiple ESG risks and mis-selling incidents. Despite this, analysts at Maybank-Kim Eng maintain a "hold" recommendation, citing typical risks for a systemically important bank with regional presence. The bank's ESG committee has identified 19 material ESG factors, and its sustainable financing has increased by 94% in 2019.

site_title: 'Don't touch the marble': visiting the Taj in a pandemic
summary: The Taj Mahal in Agra, India, reopened on September 21, 2020, after a six-month hiatus due to the pandemic. To prevent the spread of COVID-19, special rules were introduced, including a ban on touching the white marble walls. Visitors were also required to wear masks and maintain social distancing. The move aimed to balance the desire for tourists to experience the iconic monument with the need to protect public health during the pandemic.

site_title: Keppel O&M clinches two contracts worth a total of about S$200m
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) has clinched two contracts worth about S$200 million, one in the US and the other in Singapore. The US contract involves constructing a high-specification trailing suction hopper dredger for Manson Construction Co. in Seattle. In Singapore, Keppel O&M will work on a floating storage and regasification unit (FSRU) conversion. These projects represent Keppel's ninth newbuild dredger and fifth FSRU conversion, further expanding the company's offshore and marine capabilities.

images.alt_text: Keppel AmFELS, a Keppel O&M wholly-owned subsidiary, will build the largest US hopper dredger for Manson Construction Co.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: MindChamps PreSchool, a Singapore-listed education provider, will open its 40th pre-school in Singapore by year-end, at the Hard Rock Hotel at Resorts World Sentosa. Meanwhile, NutryFarm International plans to raise S$720,000 from placement agreements, and Elec & Eltek International will be delisted after privatisation. UG Healthcare Corp's three-for-one share split will take effect on Oct 2, and SingHaiyi Group accepted a tender offer to sell 17.5 million stapled securities in Australia for A$16.1 million.

site_title: Why UN has enduring relevance at 75
summary: The United Nations is celebrating its 75th anniversary, highlighting its enduring relevance despite criticism. Global challenges such as the pandemic can be best addressed through international cooperation, often led by the UN. Despite US President Donald Trump's "America first" platform, the UN has maintained its legitimacy and played a critical role in promoting peace, dialogue, and cooperation. However, the US's disengagement from international institutions and rising tensions with China pose significant challenges to the UN's continued success. A shift in US leadership and cooperation with China on key issues like climate change may be necessary to ensure the UN's long-term relevance.

site_title: Race superhero series Watchmen amasses 11 awards at virtual Emmys
summary: Watchmen swept 11 awards at the virtual Emmys, including four major categories, at the first major Covid-era awards show. The dark superhero series, which tackles US racism, won for its timely blend of sociopathic superheroes and political satire. Creators dedicated their win for best limited series to African-American victims of the 1921 Tulsa massacre. Fellow HBO show Succession won big in the drama categories, while Schitt's Creek performed a clean sweep of the night's comedy prizes, marking the first ever comedy acting clean sweep for a series.

images.alt_text: Damon Lindelof (far left) and Cord Jefferson after receiving the Emmy for Watchmen during the remote 72nd Primetime Emmy Awards on Sept 20.
Above: Host Jimmy Kimmel and actress Jennifer Aniston disinfecting ballots.

site_title: STI, regional stocks slide on virus resurgence in certain countries
summary: Singapore shares fell 12 points to 2,485.71 as regional markets declined due to a resurgence of Covid-19 in Europe and the UK. The Straits Times Index closed 0.48% lower, with only three stocks rising. The decline was attributed to a "drip-feed of negativity" ahead of US elections, with volatility expected to rise. The Nikkei 225 was the only Asian market to buck the trend, rising 0.18%.

site_title: CGS-CIMB initiates coverage on SBS Transit with 'add' call
summary: Singapore bus and train operator SBS Transit has been initiated coverage with a "add" call by CGS-CIMB, with a target price of S$3.40. Analysts Ong Khang Chuen and Darren Ong believe the worst is over for SBS, with ridership expected to return to 90% of pre-Covid levels by FY21, driving a 35% increase in net profit. The analysts also view SBS as a beneficiary of Singapore's public policy favoring public transport, offering long-term structural growth and defensive earnings.

site_title: Market share gains give PropNex ringside seat in buoyant home sales market
summary: PropNex, Singapore's largest real estate agency, has seen a significant gain in market share amid the pandemic crisis. The company, led by Ismail Gafoor, credits its sales people as the main reason for its performance, with a force of 8,748 agents contributing to its economy of scale. PropNex has increased its market share in all segments, including new launches and resale markets, with 68.7% and 54.7% respectively in Q2 2020. The company's asset-light model and focus on technology have enabled it to maintain a strong performance, with net profit surging to S$16 million in H1 2020.

site_title: Maxwell House up for collective sale at S$295m reserve price
summary: Maxwell House, a 13-storey commercial building in Singapore, has been launched for collective sale at a reserve price of S$295 million. The site area spans 41,801 sq ft and is zoned for mixed-use commercial and residential development, with a potential gross plot ratio of 5.6. The property consultant Cushman & Wakefield expects strong interest from potential developers due to the site's location near the central business district and conservation shophouses. The tender for the site will close on November 12 at 3pm.

images.alt_text: Situated in an area mostly comprising retail, F&B outlets and offices, 20 Maxwell Road will be "one of the rare exceptional residential plots" available on the market, says Cushman & Wakefield.

site_title: Let genuine HDB upgraders off the hook for ABSD, PropNex CEO suggests
summary: Ismail Gafoor, PropNex CEO, suggests the government consider delaying the levying of additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) for HDB upgraders buying private property within the six-month disposal period. This would address the issue of repeated OTPs. A similar dispensation is already given to HDB upgraders buying executive condominiums, allowing them a six-month disposal period.

site_title: Playing the digital field
summary: The Louken Group, a branding and communications outfit, is embracing digital strategies to transform and meet changing trends. Founded in 2001, the company has shifted its focus from traditional branding to digital marketing, with a emphasis on three pillars: brand strategy, user design experience, and digital marketing. Louken's CEO, Luke Lim, notes that digital will become the core of the discussion, and the company is leveraging its digital capabilities to expand its services. The group has also established a corporate incubator for technology startups, which has helped accelerate innovation and growth. As the pandemic forces businesses to transform faster, Louken believes this is the best time to embrace digital strategies and prioritize branding and marketing.

site_title: Justice Ginsburg's death is a political earthquake
summary: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg's death at 87 has sent shockwaves in the US, particularly with the upcoming presidential election. Her replacement on the Supreme Court could significantly impact issues like economic inequality, race relations, and healthcare. The choice is seen as a crucial factor in the election, with both Democrats and Republicans anticipating a potential Supreme Court showdown. President Trump plans to nominate a woman, with two female Appeal Court judges, Barbara Lagoa and Amy Coney Barrett, on his shortlist. The move could energize Trump's base but alienate suburban voters, potentially affecting the election outcome.

site_title: Yen hits 6-month high against US dollar
summary: The Japanese yen reached a six-month high against the US dollar, gaining for the sixth consecutive session, amid a global economic downturn and rising Covid-19 cases. Stock markets in the US, Asia, and Europe fell on Monday, increasing investor demand for the perceived safe-haven currency. The yen's surge is attributed to a combination of factors, including economic uncertainty and the threat of new lockdowns, which has made investors seek refuge in the Japanese currency.

site_title: ByteDance says TikTok will be its subsidiary under deal with Trump
summary: ByteDance has agreed to make TikTok its subsidiary under a deal with US President Donald Trump's administration. Oracle and Walmart will own 12.5% and 7.5% stakes, respectively, in TikTok Global, a newly created US company. ByteDance will own 80% of TikTok Global, contradicting earlier claims that US investors would be majority owners. The deal values TikTok Global at over $50 billion and includes plans for an initial public offering. ByteDance will retain control over the app's algorithms and data.

site_title: The case for having a Singaporean run a homegrown bank
summary: A Singaporean running a homegrown bank is argued to be beneficial due to the country's highly protected domestic market. The Singapore dollar banking market is dominated by local banks, which enjoy oligopolistic advantages, making it more suitable for local management. Foreign banks, on the other hand, primarily focus on non-Singapore dollar activities, such as asset management and private banking. The article suggests that DBS's success is a result of a team effort, rather than solely due to a non-homegrown CEO like Piyush Gupta.

site_title: Ant Group to lift IPO funding target to US$35b: sources
summary: Ant Group is seeking to raise at least US$35 billion in its initial public offering, up from an earlier target of US$30 billion, following increased investor interest and a valuation of about US$250 billion. The fintech giant's simultaneous listing in Hong Kong and Shanghai may be the biggest IPO ever, surpassing Saudi Aramco's record sale. Ant received regulatory approval in Shanghai and is set to clear the next hurdle with a hearing with the Hong Kong stock exchange. The company's revenue and profits have been growing, with 72.5 billion yuan in revenue in the first half of the year and a 21.1 billion yuan profit.

site_title: Virtual AGMs leave shareholders wanting the real thing
summary: Virtual annual general meetings (AGMs) have become the norm, but companies and shareholders express concerns about the lack of "human touch" in this format. Amendments to the Covid-19 (Temporary Measures) Act allow virtual AGMs and shareholder meetings until June 30, 2026. Shareholders may find virtual AGMs unsatisfying, potentially eroding relationships with companies. To avoid this, more efforts are needed to balance the benefits of virtual meetings with the need for human interaction and engagement.

site_title: Jakarta readies more beds as virus overwhelms health system
summary: Indonesia's capital, Jakarta, is expanding its COVID-19 hospital capacity to 10,000 beds amid a record increase in virus cases. The city's health system is "already overwhelmed" with ambulances running non-stop to transport patients. The country reported 4,176 new infections, bringing the total to 248,852, with a quarter of cases in Jakarta. Social distancing measures have been reinstated and those testing positive are being isolated instead of quarantined at home. The government is preparing to open another hospital tower to alleviate the strain on the healthcare system.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's capital is adding thousands of beds to house Covid-19 patients as its health system struggles with record increases in virus cases.

site_title: Former world leaders urge ratification of nuclear arms ban treaty
summary: Fifty-six former world leaders from 20 NATO countries, Japan, and South Korea have signed an open letter urging their current leaders to ratify the Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons. The treaty, negotiated in 2017, aims to ban nuclear weapons and prevent their use, testing, development, and possession. The signers, who include former prime ministers, presidents, and foreign ministers, say the risks of nuclear-weapons use have escalated and that the treaty provides a foundation for a more secure world. The letter comes as North Korea has hinted at resumed testing of its atomic arsenal and the last nuclear arms-limitation pact between Russia and the US is set to expire in February 2021.

site_title: STI reflects local market more than local economy
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) has undergone changes since its inception in 1967, but its methodology remains unchanged. The index is still dominated by the services sector, which has been impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite this, the STI has generated an annualized price return of 6% since its base price in 1966. The index has seen significant changes, including the addition of new companies and Reits, but its 30-stock constituent limit remains unchanged. Experts suggest exploring a more Singapore-centric stock benchmark or enhancing the index's methodology to better reflect the local economy and serve investors.

site_title: Harnessing the power of digital workers
summary: Singapore companies that have adopted robotic process automation (RPA) face challenges in fully leveraging the technology. A recent survey found that even firms that have adopted RPA struggle to prepare staff for its benefits. RPA played a key role in handling the Covid-19 pandemic, and it could be a solution to local productivity challenges. However, staff preparation remains a significant hurdle to its successful integration.

site_title: Jet fuel now so cheap it's being blended for use by ships
summary: Jet fuel prices have plummeted from around $70 a barrel in January to $20 in early May, now trading at $41. Due to reduced airline consumption, straight-run kerosene is being blended into very low-sulfur fuel oil for the maritime industry, increasing its use in shipping fuel. Higher amounts of diesel and vacuum gasoil are also being added to shipping fuel, a shift caused by the coronavirus pandemic. This unusual blending process highlights the current market dynamics and the impact of the pandemic on fuel demand.

site_title: Firms to improve credit assessment as more consumers struggle with credit card bills
summary: Singaporean businesses plan to enhance their digital capabilities for assessing customer creditworthiness due to the rising number of consumers struggling with credit card bills amid the Covid-19 pandemic. 23% of consumers in Singapore face difficulties paying credit card bills, up from 11% pre-pandemic. Experian's survey of 300 consumers and 90 businesses found that businesses that invest in analytics capabilities will be able to leverage data-driven decisioning to reduce risk exposure and engage digital consumers. Globally, the number of consumers having difficulty paying bills has doubled since the pandemic began.

site_title: Harnessing the power of digital workers
summary: Singapore's digitalisation efforts, particularly Robotic Process Automation (RPA), have shown promise in boosting productivity. In the fight against Covid-19, RPA played a key role. Meanwhile, a startup by NUS researchers aims to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. In other news, SMEs face challenges, including vacant units and poor footfall. OCBC targets S$5 billion in loans for serial entrepreneurs by 2028, while Shatec cuts staff and puts its Orchard campus up for sale. Local businesses also adapt to changing times, such as rebranding heritage and modernising traditional snacks.

site_title: EU gives banks 18-months to cut 'excessive' reliance on UK clearers
summary: The European Union has given banks 18 months to reduce their reliance on UK-based derivatives clearing houses, which will cease to serve EU customers after the UK's departure from the EU in December. The EU executive has approved a proposal allowing clearing houses in Britain to continue serving EU customers until mid-2022, giving market participants time to shift their positions. The move aims to prevent a disruption in the financial market and to reduce the reliance on UK-based clearing houses.

site_title: Geylang's Advance Apartment owners expect bids of over S$26.5m
summary: The Advance Apartment in Geylang, Singapore is now available for collective sale by tender, with owners expecting bids exceeding S$26.5 million. The 8-storey development, built in 1989, has an area of 11,429 sq ft and is zoned for residential or institutional use. The site's locational attributes are expected to appeal to small and mid-sized developers, and its proximity to the Paya Lebar regional centre and Kallang River rejuvenation plans are seen as growth potential. The tender closes on October 27.

site_title: Elec & Eltek to delist on Friday
summary: Elec & Eltek International Company will be delisted from the Singapore and Hong Kong stock exchanges on Friday, following Kingboard Investments' unconditional takeover of the remaining minority shareholders' stakes. The investors who did not accept the offer will receive the same value as the offer price, S$3.10753 per share. Once the compulsory acquisition exercise is completed, E&E will become a wholly-owned subsidiary of Kingboard.

site_title: Delistings and survival of the fittest mark today's equities sector
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is facing a decline in initial public offerings (IPOs) and delistings, with 18 new listings and 24 delistings in 2018 and 2019. However, this trend is not unique to SGX, and companies are citing low valuations, compliance costs, and the need for flexibility as reasons for exiting the market. The COVID-19 pandemic has exacerbated the trend, with fewer companies seeking to list and more seeking to delist. Regulators are urging caution, but some argue that the trend may be a natural consequence of an evolving market, where companies are increasingly taking private and seeking alternative sources of capital.

site_title: Hong Kong has effective anti-money laundering supervision, says regulator
summary: Hong Kong's banking regulator, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), has confirmed that the financial hub meets international standards on anti-money laundering (AML). Despite media reports revealing some leading banks, including HSBC and Standard Chartered, had moved allegedly illicit funds over nearly two decades, the HKMA stated that it requires banks to implement effective AML systems. The regulator's risk-based supervision is assessed as effective by the Financial Action Task Force, an international standard setter. The HKMA does not discuss individual cases, and no further action has been taken.

site_title: China goes all out to avert unemployment crisis
summary: China's government has launched measures to combat an unemployment crisis, including sending graduates to work in the countryside, pushing people to start online businesses, and requiring state-owned companies to create new jobs. The goal is to alleviate economic pressure and avoid a significant increase in unemployment. These efforts aim to mitigate the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the country's labor market.

site_title: Singapore banks juice up data drive to customise personal finance
summary: Singapore banks, particularly DBS, are enhancing customer data analysis to provide personalized financial recommendations. By the first quarter of 2021, DBS will roll out features such as customized market insights, stock recommendations, and bill payment capabilities. This move aims to deepen customer engagement and compete with digital banking startups.

site_title: Deutsche Bank leaders were warned of compliance lapses: Report
summary: Deutsche Bank's top leaders were warned about serious compliance failures in 2013 and 2014, exposing the bank to money launderers. The supervisory board and committees, including chairman Paul Achleitner, were informed of anti-money laundering problems, including the mirror trade scandal in Russia. Despite this, Achleitner has avoided being dragged into the worst of the issues, with the bank investing heavily in boosting oversight and settling probes. An ongoing US Department of Justice inquiry remains.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank's top leaders were warned multiple times about serious compliance failures that exposed the bank to money launderers, a news investigation shows.

site_title: With gold rallying, investor attention drawn to ESG issues
summary: Gold's recent surge has drawn investor attention to environmental, social, and governance (ESG) issues in the mining industry. Investors are increasingly demanding companies prioritize ESG topics, such as community relations, safety, and corporate governance. Despite gold's limited utility in advancing a green economy, top gold producers say they can reach high ESG standards by focusing on these areas. The industry has faced a checkered reputation on ESG issues, but high-profile incidents and rising investor scrutiny have brought ESG to the forefront, with governance being a key area of focus.

site_title: Raffles Hotel GM: Recovery to pre-Covid levels likely only in 2023 or 2024
summary: Raffles Hotel Singapore's General Manager, Christian Westbeld, expects a drawn-out recovery to pre-Covid levels, likely only in 2023 or 2024. Despite the hotel's busy "manpower-intensive" mooncake promotions and growing staycation business, Westbeld believes a prolonged recovery is manageable. The hotel has started engaging with luxury travel partners globally and has seen regional recovery by the second half of 2021. Safety measures remain in place, and the hotel is exploring new business opportunities, including its "Work from Suite" program.

site_title: HBO dramas dominate ratings-challenged virtual Emmy awards
summary: HBO dominated the virtual Emmy Awards, winning 30 awards, including the top drama prize for its series "Succession." "Watchmen" earned the most awards with 11, solidifying HBO's reputation as a leader in television. Despite a 14% drop in total audience to a new low, HBO's wins set a standard for new streaming services. Netflix, which had the most nominations, failed to capture top prizes, while "Schitt's Creek" won all seven comedy awards.

site_title: Europe ready to talk tougher with Beijing amid China-US spat
summary: The European Union and China held a video conference on September 14, with EU leaders expressing concerns over China's human rights record and demanding reciprocity in trade negotiations. China's President Xi Jinping urged cooperation to counter the US's dismantling of global governance, but was rebuffed on human rights issues. The EU has since pledged to introduce a European Magnitsky Act, and is set to engage in dialogue with the US on China. The EU's tougher stance on China is seen as a response to China's growing strength and the US-China spat, with EU leaders seeking to build a new trans-Atlantic agenda with the US.

site_title: ByteDance, Oracle at loggerheads over terms of TikTok agreement
summary: ByteDance and Oracle are at odds over the terms of an agreement allowing TikTok to continue operating in the US. ByteDance claims it will own 80% of TikTok Global, a new US company, while Oracle and Walmart said majority ownership would be in American hands. The White House referred to a statement by President Trump, who said Oracle and Walmart would have "total control" over TikTok, but the Commerce Department postponed a ban on downloads due to the ongoing negotiations. The deal's future remains uncertain, with China's foreign ministry yet to comment on the agreement.

site_title: Microsoft buys ZeniMax for US$7.5b
summary: Microsoft has acquired ZeniMax Media, the parent company of Bethesda Softworks, for $7.5 billion in cash. This deal strengthens Microsoft's Xbox video game offering with the studio behind titles like Fallout and Doom. Bethesda's games will be integrated into Microsoft's Xbox Game Pass subscription service. The acquisition is expected to close in the second half of 2021 with minimal impact on Microsoft's adjusted operating income. The deal marks Microsoft's latest move to bolster its gaming presence, following its failed bid for TikTok's US assets.

site_title: The erosion of the UK's moral authority and the rule of law
summary: The UK Parliament's decision to pass a controversial bill undermining international law has sparked concerns over the erosion of the country's moral authority and the rule of law. Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon warned of a gradual decay of the international order and the subordination of the rule of law to domestic politics. The bill's unilateral powers to ministers in areas yet to be agreed with the EU have damaged the UK's international reputation, with experts warning that the country's moral authority is hard-earned and easily lost.

site_title: Data can help traditional small businesses succeed in a pandemic
summary: Small businesses in Singapore, particularly those relying on traditional models, have had to adapt to the pandemic by shifting to digital technologies. A Nielsen study found that consumers' dine-out habits are likely to change permanently. To overcome this, businesses can adopt digital tools and take advantage of government assistance, such as the SG Digital Office. Leveraging external data, including social media and news searches, can help businesses stay informed and make informed decisions. Governments can also promote inclusion and development by collating key data and insights and packaging them in reports and resources for the business community.

site_title: Keppel Capital ties up with S Korea pension fund for investment
summary: Keppel Capital, the asset management arm of Keppel Corp, has partnered the National Pension Service of Korea (NPS) to explore investment opportunities in private infrastructure in Asia. The cooperation will bring together the asset management expertise of both NPS and Keppel Capital, leveraging Keppel's track record in developing and maintaining real assets. The partnership, which builds on an earlier commitment by NPS, has no expected material impact on Keppel's net tangible assets or earnings per share.

site_title: Lufthansa to cut more jobs as it loses 500m euros a month
summary: Lufthansa plans to slash more jobs, on top of 22,000 previously announced cuts, amid ongoing losses of 500 million euros a month due to the coronavirus pandemic. The airline will reduce its fleet by 150 planes by 2025 and book 1.1 billion euros in impairment. Managers will also face job cuts, with one in five positions to go. The airline will engage in talks with labor representatives to limit redundancies. The decision follows a government bailout worth 9 billion euros and a resurgence in infections across Europe.

site_title: ECB wants to cut reporting burden for banks
summary: The European Central Bank aims to simplify reporting requirements for banks, reducing the industry's estimated 4 billion euros spent annually on reporting. The ECB seeks standardized reporting templates, a central data collection point, and improved data sharing to increase data quality and reduce costs. While significant changes are possible, they will likely take years to implement, and are mandated by the European Banking Authority in some cases. The goal is to reduce the burden on banks and enhance authorities' monitoring capabilities.

site_title: Goldman Sachs shakes up M&A ranks with new global co-chairs
summary: Goldman Sachs has promoted Michael Carr, Dusty Philip, and Gilberto Pozzi to co-chairs of its global mergers and acquisitions business, alongside Tim Ingrassia and Gene Sykes. The three new co-chairs will focus on critical advisory work and drive execution on important M&A transactions. Stephan Feldgoise and Mark Sorrell will replace them as co-heads of global M&A, navigating complexities despite travel restrictions and Covid-19 uncertainty. The leadership shake-up aims to free up senior bankers for new business-generating roles.

site_title: HSBC, StanChart fall to 22-year lows on reports of illicit money flows
summary: HSBC and Standard Chartered plummeted to 22-year lows after media reports revealed the banks and others, including Barclays and Deutsche Bank, allegedly moved illicit funds despite red flags. Over 2,100 suspicious activity reports were leaked, showing banks moved funds for companies in offshore havens and didn't know the ultimate owner. The banks claim to have complied with regulations, but the reports raise concerns about their anti-money laundering efforts.

site_title: UG Healthcare stock split to take effect on Oct 2
summary: UG Healthcare Corp, a Malaysian glove maker, will split its existing ordinary shares into three, effective October 2, to boost trading liquidity and broaden the shareholder base. The share split was approved by shareholders last Friday and the register of members and share transfer books will be closed on October 1 at 5pm.

site_title: Banks in Singapore handled about US$4.5 billion in suspicious transactions: FinCEN leaks
summary: Banks in Singapore handled approximately US$4.5 billion in suspicious transactions between 2000 and 2017, according to leaked FinCEN files. DBS Bank, CIMB Bank, and Deutsche Bank processed the largest sums. The transactions, totaling US$3 billion received and US$1.5 billion sent, were reported in 1,781 suspicious activity reports. The findings come from the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists (ICIJ).

site_title: Kitchen Culture will put pivot to artificial intelligence to Oct 7 shareholder vote
summary: Kitchen Culture Holdings, a Catalist-listed kitchen-equipment supplier, plans to invest in a Chinese financial technology firm, Ooway Technology, which runs an AI-based credit management platform. The company will take a 30% stake in Ooway Technology. A shareholder vote is scheduled for October 7 to approve the investment. This move marks a pivot for Kitchen Culture to leverage artificial intelligence technology, and the company's board has announced an extraordinary general meeting to be held electronically.

site_title: Illumina to pay US$7.1b for cancer test developer Grail
summary: Illumina Inc. is set to acquire cancer test startup Grail for $7.1 billion in cash and stock, with Illumina being the largest shareholder with a 14.6% stake. Grail, founded in 2016, is developing a blood test to identify early-stage cancers and is backed by Jeff Bezos and Bill Gates. The deal is expected to be announced later, marking Illumina's expansion into the cancer testing market.

site_title: Vendor takes China Real Estate Grp to court over aborted subsidiary consolidation
summary: China Real Estate Grp, a CATALIST-listed company, has been taken to court by a vendor over aborted plans to consolidate its stake in a Chinese real estate developer. The vendor seeks 9.8 million yuan (S$1.98 million) in damages, including a late-payment penalty, after the sale-and-purchase agreement was terminated in April. China Real Estate Grp maintains that the agreement was terminated due to unmet conditions and is seeking legal advice from Shanghai Hiways Law Firm, stating that the vendor's claim is without basis.

site_title: Meghan, Harry 'did not collaborate' with recent book
summary: Meghan Markle's lawyers denied that she and her husband Prince Harry collaborated with the authors of the book "Finding Freedom", which details their life together. Associated Newspapers sought to amend its defense, arguing that Meghan and Harry "co-operated" with the authors. However, Meghan's lawyer Justin Rushbrooke stated that they "did not collaborate" with the authors, and that extracts of a letter in the book were "lifted" from articles under dispute. The case is part of Meghan and Harry's ongoing battle with the media, with estimated costs totaling around $3.8 million.

site_title: SingHaiyi to reduce Cromwell stake to 1.6% for A$16.1 million
summary: SingHaiyi Group is selling approximately 17.5 million stapled securities of Cromwell Property Group for A$16.1 million, reducing its stake to 1.6%. The sale, valued at A$0.92 per security, represents a 14.9% premium to the previous price. The proceeds will be used to repay bank loans, enhancing the company's financial flexibility. This sale follows SingHaiyi's previous sale of three million stapled securities in November for A$3.96 million.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Study suggests dengue may provide some immunity against Covid-19
summary: A new study in Brazil found a link between dengue fever and Covid-19, suggesting that exposure to the mosquito-transmitted illness may provide some level of immunity against Covid-19. The study, led by Miguel Nicolelis, compared the geographic distribution of coronavirus cases with the spread of dengue and found that places with lower Covid-19 infection rates had suffered intense dengue outbreaks. The study suggests an immunological cross-reactivity between dengue and Sars-CoV-2, potentially offering a new avenue for protection against Covid-19.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Monday, down 7.20 points to 1,499.43, with volume reaching 7.025 billion lots worth RM3.552 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 873 to 275.

site_title: PBOC issues draft guidelines to expedite bond investment
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), has issued draft guidelines to simplify rules and regulations for inbound bond investment. The guidelines aim to expedite foreign institutional investors by relaxing repatriation rules and removing restrictions on spot foreign exchange transactions. The PBOC will seek public comment on the draft guidelines until October 20.

site_title: Boon Tat Street death: Man jailed 8 years for killing son-in-law
summary: A 72-year-old Singaporean businessman, Tan Nam Seng, was sentenced to 8.5 years' jail for fatally stabbing his son-in-law, Spencer Tuppani, in 2017. Tan had become unhinged over his daughter's treatment and suspected Mr Tuppani of planning to cheat him out of his business. The sentence was reduced from the maximum 12 years due to Tan's major depressive disorder, which impaired his mental responsibility. The incident occurred outside a coffee shop in Boon Tat Street, where Tan had fatally stabbed Mr Tuppani in front of a crowd.

site_title: Norway wealth fund may move US$50b into US stocks from Europe
summary: Norway's $1.15 trillion sovereign wealth fund is considering shifting $50 billion into US stocks, a move that would cut its European holdings. The proposal, submitted to parliament, aims to better represent the global distribution of value creation among listed companies. The fund's manager and the Norwegian central bank previously recommended the change, citing the need for a more diversified portfolio. The shift is expected to prioritize US companies, with Canada also being considered. The proposal's goal is to ensure the fund's investments are more representative of the global market.

images.alt_text: The proposal to parliament follows an earlier recommendation by the Norwegian central bank, the fund's manager, and could add investments of US$50 billion in US stocks.

site_title: STI falls 0.48% on first trading day of the week, alongside regional markets
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.48% to 2,485.71, mirroring regional markets due to a resurgence of COVID-19 in Europe and the UK. The benchmark index declined despite three stocks advancing, led by Jardine Matheson Holdings and Sembcorp Industries. Analysts attribute the downturn to an "added drip-feed of negativity" ahead of the US elections and the coronavirus lens.

site_title: US: Wall St falls on virus fears, stimulus uncertainty
summary: US stocks fell on Monday due to concerns over fresh coronavirus-driven lockdowns and stimulus uncertainty. The Dow Jones Industrial Average hit a near two-month low, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declining. The Dow dropped 172.71 points, or 0.62%, to 27,484.71, while the S&P 500 fell 33.90 points, or 1.02%, to 3,285.57. The decline was attributed to fears of another economic hit, with Congress unable to agree on fiscal stimulus.

site_title: New Australian project behind jump in H1 2020 cost of sales, says Fragrance Group
summary: Fragrance Group, a Singapore-based property developer, reported a 53% increase in first-half cost of sales to S$43.7 million due to a new Australian project, NV Apartment. The project contributed S$38.5 million in revenue, while overall revenue rose 118% to S$60.6 million. Other operating expenses increased by S$3.8 million, mainly due to higher depreciation and amortization, professional fees, and payroll expenses. The company's counter shed 0.1 Singapore cent to S$0.114 after the announcement.

site_title: MindChamps PreSchool to open 40th pre-school in Singapore by year-end
summary: MindChamps PreSchool, a Singapore-based education provider, plans to open its 40th pre-school by year-end. The new facility, a franchisee operation, will be located at the Hard Rock Hotel at Resorts World Sentosa. As part of its opening promotion, new enrolments will receive complimentary resort membership, free parking, and a Sentosa Islander Pass. This expansion brings the total number of MindChamps centres in Singapore to 50, including 9 company-owned and operated centres and 41 franchised centres.

site_title: NutryFarm International to issue 19m new shares to two private investors
summary: NutryFarm International plans to issue 19 million new shares to two private investors, raising net proceeds of S$720,000 for working capital purposes. The shares are priced at S$0.04 apiece, a 8.1% premium over the last market day's volume-weighted average price. Businessman Cheng Meng and mining businessman Alex Loo will each hold 11.5% and 4.9% stakes, respectively, after the placement exercise.

site_title: LCT board names independent financial adviser for co-founder's takeover bid
summary: The board of LCT Holdings has appointed Novus Corporate Finance as the independent financial adviser for a takeover bid by co-founder Du Junhong. Du, who has a 19.72% stake in the company, has made a S$0.60 per-share offer to buy all ordinary shares, valuing LCT at S$21 million. The deal requires the approval of other co-founders with a combined 27.65% stake. The independent directors will receive advice from Novus Corporate Finance, and shareholders are advised to exercise caution when dealing with their shares until further notice.

site_title: Myanmar election results predictable but outcome could complicate foreign relations
summary: Myanmar's November general elections are predicted to favor the ruling National League for Democracy (NLD), which will likely re-elect President Win Myint. However, the outcome could complicate foreign relations due to the ban on mass gatherings and Covid-19 restrictions, which may disenfranchise ethnic minority voters. The election commission may announce no-voting zones, mainly in conflict-affected areas. A postponement is unlikely, but a public health crisis could force a delay. The international community may view the results with reservations, complicating Myanmar's relationship with Western governments amid the humanitarian crisis.

site_title: Scandal-hit Loh cousins seeking to offload Axington stake
summary: The Singaporean duo Nelson and Terence Loh, facing scrutiny over a £280 million bid for Newcastle United, are seeking to offload their stake in Catalist-listed Axington Inc amid a looming debt of over S$20 million. The Loh cousins have approached parties to buy out their stake, with a sense of urgency due to the debt. Axington's board has been whittled down to two independent directors following a series of bizarre events and an en masse board resignation.
