summary: Singapore reported 18 new COVID-19 cases, including one in the community, on Sunday, bringing the total to 57,576. The cases include 15 imported cases and 3 foreign workers living in dormitories. One community case, a 22-year-old Singaporean man, is currently unlinked. The Ministry of Health has released the list of locations visited by infectious patients, and close contacts have been notified. 71 cases were discharged on Saturday, with 57,127 fully recovered and 27 patients remaining in hospital.

site_title: Director activity continues to build pace
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 0.4% over the five local trading sessions from Sept 11 to 17, despite a 0.1% decline in the Nikkei 225 Index and Hang Seng Index. The iEdge S-Reit Leaders Index gained 3.1% during the same period. In other news, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, while Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in the second half of the year. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks rallied for the fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Tencent gaming unit must pay US$8.5m in 'freemium' dispute
summary: Tencent Holdings' gaming unit, Supercell, was ordered to pay $8.5 million in royalties to Gree Inc for patent infringement in popular online games such as Clash of Clans and Clash Royale. A federal jury found Supercell infringed on four patents related to "freemium" games, which are free to download but generate revenue through in-game purchases. The jury also deemed the infringement willful, allowing the judge to potentially triple the amount. Supercell had denied using the patented technology, but the jury rejected their invalidity arguments.

site_title: Requisition notice by Oei Hong Leong 'without merit', will not be convening EGM: Raffles Education
summary: Raffles Education said a requisition notice by Oei Hong Leong and Shantanu Prakash to hold an EGM is without merit. The proposed resolutions pertain to management issues outside the shareholders' province, so the board will not convene an EGM. Oei Hong Leong is seeking to oust Chew Hua Seng as chairman and CEO, while Prakash is calling for a special auditor to review the company's joint venture with Educomp Solutions due to concerns of forgery and extortion. The board will not take action on these matters.

site_title: Indonesia, US agree on infrastructure finance agreement
summary: Indonesia and the US have signed an agreement to strengthen infrastructure financing through private sector investment, bolstering the development of capital markets and financial instruments. The agreement aims to facilitate and reduce barriers to private sector investment in infrastructure, improving asset recycling capacity and credit enhancement. The move supports the US Government's Indo-Pacific Strategy, complementing efforts under the Enhancing Development and Growth through Energy (Asia EDGE) and the Infrastructure Transaction and Assistance Network (ITAN).

site_title: UBS looking at virtual reality tech for traders: FT
summary: UBS is experimenting with virtual reality headsets to simulate the trading floor experience for its bankers, citing the need for a safe return to the office amid soaring coronavirus infection rates. The bank has used Microsoft's HoloLenses with its London traders, with UBS's UK head Beatriz Martin stating that "if people really can't come to the office, can we create a virtual presence?" This move follows setbacks for other investment banks, including Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase, who have had to quarantine groups of traders due to positive test results.

site_title: Billionaire Ron Perelman selling almost everything as pandemic roils his empire
summary: Billionaire Ronald Perelman, 77, is selling most of his assets amid financial challenges. His wealth has dropped from $19 billion to $4.2 billion in two years due to the pandemic's impact on his Revlon cosmetics company. Perelman is selling his Gulfstream 650, 257-foot yacht, and hundreds of millions of dollars of art, including works by Jasper Johns, Gerhard Richter, and Cy Twombly. He aims to reduce debt and convert assets to cash to invest in new opportunities. Proceeds will help pay down loans from Citigroup and JPMorgan Chase.

site_title: Tractor giant Deere plans to expand in Australia, New Zealand
summary: Deere & Co, a tractor giant, plans to expand in Australia and New Zealand, targeting growth in construction, forestry, precision agriculture, turf, and mining operations. Luke Chandler, former chief economist, will lead the expansion efforts. Key areas of focus include road building and government infrastructure projects, as well as boosting precision agriculture for Australian farmers to compete globally.

site_title: TikTok sues Trump administration to block US ban
summary: TikTok has sued the Trump administration to block a US ban, citing a lack of evidence and First Amendment free-speech rights. The ban, set to take effect on November 12, was issued due to concerns over the app's Chinese ownership. The company claims the ban would "destroy an online community" and that the US government has "ignored evidence" of its commitment to user privacy. TikTok is currently in talks with Oracle about a possible deal to address the government's concerns.

site_title: Zoox gets driverless car test permit in California, a win for Amazon
summary: Zoox Inc, acquired by Amazon in June, has received a permit from California state authorities to test its driverless vehicles without a backup driver. This permit allows the company to test two autonomous vehicles on specified streets near its Foster City headquarters. This marks a win for Amazon, which has been expanding into self-driving technology. Other companies holding permits include Waymo, AutoX, and Nuro Inc.

site_title: Disgraced Harvey Weinstein loses top royal honour
summary: Queen Elizabeth II has stripped Harvey Weinstein of his Honorary Commander of the Civil Division of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire, a royal honour he received in 2004 for his contribution to the British film industry. Weinstein, serving a 23-year jail term for rape, had his honour withdrawn due to the "predatory sex crimes" he committed. This decision follows similar actions taken against Rolf Harris and other individuals who have had their honours removed for bringing the royal honour system into disrepute.

site_title: AstraZeneca, under fire for vaccine safety, releases trial blueprints
summary: AstraZeneca released trial blueprints for its coronavirus vaccine, amid public pressure and concerns over vaccine safety. The move comes as Americans become increasingly wary of accepting a vaccine. Regulators are under pressure to release a vaccine before the US Election Day on November 3. Experts say the release of trial protocols reflects public pressure, and public confidence is crucial for the vaccine's success.

site_title: Eurozone yields nudge up, little concern around Italian local elections
summary: Eurozone government bond yields rose slightly, supported by the European Central Bank's dovish statements and the Bank of England's potential interest rate cut. Italian 10-year bond yields also increased, despite upcoming local elections, which investors deemed unlikely to impact the government. The European Central Bank may need to introduce fresh stimulus measures to support the eurozone's uneven recovery and inflation target.

site_title: Bond market shows US is leading in race to reflate economy
summary: The US economy is emerging as a leader in the global effort to rekindle inflation, with the Federal Reserve planning to hold interest rates near zero until at least 2023. Consumer prices in the US are expected to modestly exceed 2% in the coming years, in contrast to Europe and Japan, where deflation fears have reawakened. The Fed's new inflation policy, including aggressive bond buying and liquidity programs, is seen as a key factor in the US's ability to reflate its economy more convincingly than its peers.

site_title: Scaling up, French firm fashions fish skins for luxury market
summary: A French company is collecting fish skins that would otherwise be discarded, transforming them into luxury leather products such as watch straps and wallets. The company, founded by three friends, is targeting the high-end fashion market with its environmentally-friendly leather. This revival of the traditional craft is driven by its eco-friendly credentials, but has yet to break into the luxury industry. The company aims to capitalize on the growing demand for sustainable luxury goods.

site_title: IPO frenzy this week nets billions for venture-capital backers
summary: Venture capital firms are expected to receive billions of dollars from initial public offerings (IPOs) this week, with companies like Snowflake Inc and Unity Software Inc raising significant funds. Early investors, including Sequoia Capital and Sutter Hill Ventures, are set to reap substantial returns, with some shares valued at over $10 billion. The strong market for technology stocks is driving companies to go public, with venture capitalists citing robust demand and the benefits of increased credibility for enterprise technology companies.

site_title: Europe: Stocks trim second weekly gain as travel shares sink
summary: Europe's stocks fell 0.7% at close, trimming their weekly gain to 0.2%, as travel and tourism industries were weighed down by quarantine requirements and reduced capacity by Ryanair Holdings. Banks and carmakers also underperformed, with the Stoxx Europe 600 Index nearing a narrow trading range since June, despite some sector gains. European regulators move closer to lifting a ban on dividends, but strategist Sylvain Goyon says the index is already pricing a better-than-anticipated economic recovery.

site_title: EU looks to fast 5G, supercomputers to boost virus-hit economy
summary: The European Commission is urging EU countries to collaborate on rapidly deploying fibre and 5G networks to boost the region's economy, which has been impacted by the coronavirus outbreak. The commission aims to develop best practices, provide timely access to 5G radio spectrum, and enhance cross-border coordination. Additionally, it proposes investing €8 billion in supercomputing technologies to maintain Europe's technological lead in the international race. The EU executive emphasizes the importance of high-speed internet and 5G for businesses, public services, and citizens.

site_title: Caixa, Bankia form Spain's biggest bank in 3.8 billion euro deal
summary: CaixaBank has agreed to buy Bankia in a 3.8 billion euro deal, creating Spain's largest lender. The combined bank will deliver cost cuts and increased revenue of about 1.1 billion euros, with Bankia investors receiving a 20% premium to the bank's closing price. The acquisition is expected to be approved in November and complete in the first quarter of 2021, with CaixaBank CEO Gonzalo Gortazar remaining in his role. The deal aims to strengthen the Spanish banking sector and create a "Spanish champion" with economies of scale.

site_title: Private equity using loans for payouts at fastest pace in years
summary: Private equity firms are investing at the fastest pace in years, with about $8.6 billion of dividend recapitalization deals launched this month, surpassing the previous record of $9.9 billion in September 2017. These deals, which refinance debt and fund payouts, account for a quarter of this month's $31.5 billion of loan launches. Companies such as Ellucian and ECi Software Solutions are using the loans to refinance debt and fund payouts, with leverage increasing in some cases. The surge is driven by low investor demand and cheap borrowing costs.

site_title: Taiwan pledges deeper US ties as Chinese jets harry island
summary: Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen pledged deeper ties with the US during a dinner meeting with visiting US Undersecretary for Economic Affairs Keith Krach. The meeting comes as China sent 18 fighter jets to harass the island in response to Krach's visit, which marked the most senior US State Department official to come to Taiwan in four decades. Tsai expressed hope for increased cooperation on promoting peace and stability in the Indo-Pacific region, and emphasized the need for deeper economic ties between Taiwan and the US.

site_title: Thai protesters challenge monarchy as huge protests escalate
summary: Thousands of protesters in Bangkok, Thailand, marched to present demands for reforms to curb King Maha Vajiralongkorn's powers, openly challenging the monarchy. The protesters, who have been demonstrating for two months, broke a taboo on criticizing the monarchy, which is illegal under lese majeste laws. The Royal Palace has not commented on the protests.

images.alt_text: Openly challenging the monarchy of Thai King Maha Vajiralongkorn, thousands of protesters marched in Bangkok on Sunday to present demands that include a call for reforms to curb his powers.

site_title: Vale's mining dams still a risk, company must do more: Brazil prosecutor
summary: Brazilian iron ore miner Vale has not complied with safety commitments made after two deadly mining disasters since 2015, according to federal prosecutor Edison Vitorelli. Twenty-nine dams used by Vale remain at elevated safety risks, posing a threat to the company's plans to recover lost production and grow to 450 million tonnes per year. The prosecutor's task force has requested Vale's top executives in charge of safety be removed and an external expert be brought in to revamp the company's safety strategy. Vale denies the allegations, claiming it has complied with commitments and is on schedule to fulfill them.

site_title: Next Insurance is said to seek US$2.25b value in funding round
summary: Next Insurance, a Palo Alto-based insurtech startup, is in talks to raise US$250 million in a funding round valued at approximately US$2.25 billion. Alphabet Inc's CapitalG is reportedly leading the round, which would double the company's valuation from its last fundraising. Next Insurance, which caters to small businesses, is backed by investors including Redpoint Ventures and Nationwide Mutual Insurance. The funding round has not been finalized, and its terms may still change.

site_title: Ant-backed brokerage Paytm Money looks to tap India's stock trading mania
summary: Paytm Money, backed by Chinese billionaire Jack Ma's Ant Group, is expanding its stock trading platform in India, aiming to become a top broker and help retail investors avoid losses. The app, which made zero-fee stock trading available last month, plans to use algorithms to notify users of profitable trades and offer investor education resources. The move is stoking competition among Indian brokerages, which are offering easy-to-use platforms and minimal charges to attract young, smartphone-savvy investors. Paytm's parent company, One97 Communications, is valued at $16 billion, and the app could potentially tap into its 80 million user base, drawing 10 million users into the stock market.

site_title: Unity Software soars in blockbuster NYSE debut
summary: Unity Software made its highly anticipated New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) debut, with shares soaring to US$68.35, giving the gaming platform a market value of around US$18 billion. The company's stock debuted at US$75 per share, exceeding its initial public offering (IPO) price of US$52 per share. Unity's CEO John Riccitiello attributed the strong debut to sustained demand for new stocks and the company's ability to compensate employees with more transparency. The IPO marks the second US$1 billion-plus software IPO this week, following Snowflake Inc's record-breaking listing.

site_title: JPMorgan's top Europe bankers see rising M&A as crisis wanes
summary: European companies are actively pursuing mergers and acquisitions despite the COVID-19 crisis, according to JPMorgan's top bankers in Europe. The bank's co-heads, Dorothee Blessing and Conor Hillery, report a rise in dealmaking activity as economic signs improve and stock markets buoy. Strategic M&A dialogue continues, with companies looking to invest in the future rather than just defensively. European banking is tipped for consolidation, and JPMorgan expects more deals in the sector, while IPO activity in Europe is also picking up.

site_title: US says UN sanctions on Iran to be reimposed Saturday. What does that mean?
summary: The US has announced that all UN sanctions on Iran will be reimposed on Saturday, despite opposition from 13 UN Security Council members. The sanctions, which include a conventional arms embargo, were set to expire on October 18 under a 2015 nuclear deal. The move is seen as a response to Iran's alleged breaches of the deal, and the US plans to issue an executive order allowing it to impose US sanctions on anyone violating the UN arms embargo. The remaining parties to the nuclear deal, including Britain, France, and Germany, have said they are committed to maintaining the agreement.

site_title: Swedbank is being investigated for suspected market abuse
summary: Swedbank, a Swedish bank, is under investigation by the Swedish Financial Supervisory Authority for suspected market abuse related to its money-laundering scandal. The investigation covers transactions between September 2018 and February 2019 and pertains to disclosure of insider information. The bank has already been fined a record four billion kronor for handling suspicious transactions and remains under international investigation for allegedly allowing over $100 billion in suspicious cash to flow through its operations. The bank's shares fell 5.5% on the news, and it is taking steps to prevent future breaches.

site_title: Game maker Scopely in talks for funding at US$3b value
summary: Scopely, a mobile game developer, is in talks with investors Wellington Management and NewView Capital to raise at least $200 million at a valuation of $3 billion. The company, which publishes games such as Star Trek Fleet Command and Scrabble Go, is cash flow positive with $475 million in bookings last year. This funding round would increase Scopely's valuation from $1.9 billion in March. The company has accelerated its growth this year, and its acquisition of FoxNextGames from Walt Disney Co. in January has contributed to its growth.

site_title: US dollar falls against the yen, sterling dips on Covid worries
summary: The US dollar fell against the yen for the fifth consecutive day, reaching a seven-week high, amid concerns over a resurgence of COVID-19 cases in Europe and the US fiscal stimulus negotiations. The yen's value rose due to investor safety-seeking amid these concerns. Meanwhile, sterling fell after the UK discussed negative interest rates and considered a second national lockdown due to rising COVID-19 cases in the UK. The dollar index also registered its first weekly decline since August, attributed to investor nerves ahead of the US election and US-China tensions.

site_title: Lululemon defies brick-and-mortar woes in plan to add stores
summary: Lululemon Athletica plans to expand its brick-and-mortar stores across the US, despite the pandemic's impact on the apparel industry. CEO Calvin McDonald believes the company's small, profitable stores serve as anchors for loyal customers and will continue to grow. Lululemon has paid full rent throughout the crisis and is taking a long-term view with landlords. The company aims to double its revenue in the men's category by 2023 and will unveil its own footwear line within 12-18 months. This expansion strategy is expected to benefit the company's shares, which have climbed 31% this year.

site_title: Ex-Campari CEO accused of serving up a cognac deal tip at dinner
summary: Former Campari CEO Marco Perelli-Cippo is accused by French regulators of tipping off a friend, Davide Blei, about a potential Grand Marnier acquisition deal. Blei bought Grand Marnier shares after the dinner, making 34,000 euros, and claims he bought based on intuition. Perelli-Cippo denies the allegations, saying he never mentioned the deal. The Autorité des Marchés Financiers (AMF) is seeking a 120,000 euro fine for Blei and 60,000 euros for Perelli-Cippo.

site_title: Singapore police probe firm owned by Loh cousins
summary: Singapore police are investigating a complaint from Ernst & Young that a firm owned by Loh cousins, Terence and Nelson, allegedly used unauthorized signatures on financial statements. The firm, Novena Global Healthcare Group, is a subsidiary of the Bellagraph Nova Group, which is bidding for Newcastle United. The police received the complaint and are looking into the matter. The Loh cousins' other firm, Bellagraph Nova Group, has faced scrutiny over suspect claims and doctored photos, with investors and businesses distancing themselves from the group. The Singapore corporate regulator is also taking enforcement action.

site_title: US: Wall Street posts third week of declines as tech slide drags on
summary: US stocks fell for the third week in a row as technology shares declined for a third consecutive day, dragging the Nasdaq and S&P 500 down. Apple and other tech giants led the decline, with the S&P 500 technology index falling 1.7%. Despite the decline, strategists say the market is experiencing a rotation out of high-flying tech stocks and into other sectors, driven by profit-taking and adjustment. Investors are also watching rising coronavirus cases overseas.

site_title: Schroders buys £2.2b family office in wealth push
summary: Schroders has agreed to acquire London-based family office Sandaire for £2.2 billion, expanding its wealth management services for ultra-high-net-worth clients. Sandaire will become part of Schroders' Cazenove Capital division, with founder Alex Scott becoming chairman of global family-office services. The acquisition aims to fuel growth and create one of the UK's top multi-family offices, with a focus on serving clients in Asia, the Channel Islands, and Switzerland. The deal is subject to regulatory approval.

site_title: Oil flat as Libya developments counter Opec+ boost
summary: Oil prices remained unchanged on Friday, despite a Libyan commander's announcement to lift a blockade on oil exports for a month, and supportive signals from an Opec+ meeting. US oil futures rose 14 cents to settle at $41.11 a barrel, and Brent crude fell 15 US cents to settle at $43.15 a barrel. Analysts predict a supply deficit and higher prices, with Goldman Sachs forecasting a 3 million bpd deficit by the fourth quarter.

site_title: US Supreme Court Justice Ginsburg dies at age 87 from pancreatic cancer
summary: US Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, a liberal icon, died at 87 due to pancreatic cancer complications. Her death gives President Trump an opportunity to expand the conservative majority on the court, potentially shifting the balance further to the right. Ginsburg was a champion of women's rights and a tireless advocate for justice, leaving behind a legacy that will be remembered by future generations. A private interment service will be held at Arlington National Cemetery.

site_title: SIA pilots taking deeper pay cuts to avert layoffs
summary: Singapore Airlines' local pilots will take deeper pay cuts to avert layoffs, with First Officers facing a 15-18.5% cut and Captains facing a 25-28.5% cut. The airline has reached an agreement with the Air Line Pilots Association - Singapore to mitigate further job losses. The restructuring aims to reduce the airline's headcount by 4,300 positions, with 2,400 staff to be let go through retrenchments and the remaining 1,900 roles to be eradicated through natural attrition and other measures.

site_title: Warehouse rents in Asia-Pacific hold steady on e-commerce demand: Knight Frank
summary: Prime warehouse rents in Singapore held steady at 0.6% decline to S$1.80 psf pm in H1 2020, supported by e-commerce demand and production of essential commodities. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, Knight Frank expects rents to remain stable until the end of the year, with modest growth expected in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Airbus wins lawsuit over payments to consultants linked to scandal
summary: Airbus has won a Paris lawsuit over unpaid fees to a Hong Kong consulting firm, Samwell International, which was linked to a bribery scandal. A Paris appeals court dismissed the 1.5 million euro lawsuit, backing an arbitration court's ruling that suggested Airbus's contracts with Samwell were "tainted with corruption." The decision opens a window into arbitration disputes between Airbus and its intermediaries as the company faces global bribery investigations. Airbus had agreed to a 3.6 billion euro settlement to resolve bribery allegations.

images.alt_text: Airbus won a Paris lawsuit over its decision to halt payments to a Hong Kong consulting firm after an internal review suggested the contractor may have been connected to a larger bribery scandal at the planemaker.

site_title: Small tech stocks soar as the future arrives early
summary: Small tech stocks have surged, with companies like Fastly (up 310%), Zscaler (up 180%), Chegg (up 75%), and Veeva (up 90%) experiencing significant gains despite a deep economic downturn. The novel coronavirus pandemic has accelerated trends of remote work and online shopping, driving demand for digital services and products. Investors are betting on these companies' ability to thrive in the pandemic's aftermath, and their success is being fueled by increased consumption of technology to work from home.

site_title: Support people rather than jobs for a more resilient post-Covid economy
summary: A more resilient post-Covid economy can be achieved by prioritizing support for people over jobs, according to a recent analysis. European countries that focused on job retention schemes experienced relatively low unemployment rates, while the US, which provided enhanced jobless benefits to individuals, saw a significant spike in unemployment. As the pandemic persists, supporting workers rather than jobs is crucial, particularly for lower-skilled workers who are disproportionately affected by the crisis. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development recommends adjusting responses to Covid-19 to support workers rather than jobs.

images.alt_text: As time passes, job retention schemes will, in any case, become more and more unfair, because they provide much greater support for those who previously had jobs than for young people who are entering the labour market for the first time.

site_title: Ryanair cuts capacity further, citing travel restrictions
summary: Ryanair cuts its October capacity by 20% due to continued EU travel restrictions, citing "damage caused by continuous changes in travel restrictions" as the reason. The airline now expects to fly about 40% of its capacity from last October, down from a previous target of 50%. This move may require further capacity cuts for the rest of the winter unless EU governments ease restrictions. Ryanair's share price fell 4.5% following the announcement.

site_title: Inflows from retail investors to boost recovery plays in South-east Asia: UBS
summary: Retail investors in South-east Asia have been increasing their equity market participation, with $6 billion in buying power in Singapore over the past six months. This trend is observed across the region, driven by savings being deployed in capital markets, pushing prices higher. UBS is bullish on recovery plays, focusing on sectors like hotels, food and beverage, and suburban malls. The shift in supply chains due to the pandemic is also expected to benefit Asean, with firms looking to diversify production away from China.

site_title: Japan consumer prices fall at fastest pace in 4 years
summary: Japan's core consumer prices fell at their fastest pace in almost four years in August, driven by government-sponsored discounts for domestic travel. The core consumer price index (CPI) declined 0.4% from a year earlier, mainly due to a 32% drop in accommodation prices. The central bank may monitor job growth in guiding policy, signaling a readiness to ramp up stimulus if deflation risks increase.

site_title: US housing starts fall more than forecast in August
summary: US housing starts fell 5.1% in August to a 1.42 million annualized rate, following a 17.9% surge in July. The decline reflects less apartment construction and a drop in the South due to tropical storms. This pause in momentum marks a shift for the housing market, which has been a key driver of the economy. The decrease is attributed to a decline in construction, rather than a sharp slowdown in demand.

site_title: Singaporean admits supplying luxury goods to North Korea
summary: A Singaporean man, Chong Hock Yen, has pleaded guilty to supplying luxury goods worth almost US$200,000 to North Korea in violation of UN sanctions. The luxury items included perfume, cosmetics, watches, and musical instruments, supplied to firms in North Korea over nearly six years. This is the latest in a series of cases in which Singaporean companies and individuals have been charged for supplying banned goods to the isolated country. The UN Security Council has imposed punishing sanctions on North Korea in response to its ballistic missile and nuclear tests.

site_title: HSA rejects claim it had approved Tritech's cleaning product
summary: The Health Sciences Authority (HSA) in Singapore has denied approving the manufacture and sales of Tritech Group's cleaning product, VaVie Clean Wash Sanitize. Tritech had claimed the product was approved by the National Environmental Agency (NEA), Singapore Food Agency (SFA), and HSA. HSA stated that the product is not under its purview as it is intended for external surfaces and not a health product. This clarification follows Tritech's earlier statement, which was later retracted.

site_title: US to ban TikTok, WeChat from Sunday: officials
summary: The US will ban WeChat and TikTok from US app stores starting Sunday, citing national security concerns. Current TikTok users will see little change, and additional technical transactions for TikTok won't be barred until November 12. ByteDance, TikTok's owner, is in talks to create a new company, TikTok Global, to address US concerns about user data security. The ban affects new US downloads, but existing US users will remain accessible, and US companies can continue to do business with WeChat outside the US.

images.alt_text: The Trump administration will ban WeChat and video-sharing app TikTok from US app stores starting Sunday night, a move that will block Americans from downloading the Chinese-owned platforms over concerns they pose a national security threat.

site_title: Singapore insurers extend premium-deferment measures
summary: Singapore's General Insurance Association and Life Insurance Association have extended premium-deferment measures for policyholders, allowing them to pay premiums up to six months late without losing coverage. The measures come amid a weak economy and soft labor market due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Insurance companies, including NTUC Income, are offering flexible payment plans and interest waivers to help policyholders struggling with cash flow. The extensions are expected to provide continued support to policyholders facing financial difficulties caused by the pandemic.

site_title: Should cholesterol-lowering medication be started in the young?
summary: Researchers suggest starting cholesterol-lowering medication in young individuals with elevated cholesterol to improve outcomes. A recent case of a 20-year-old with multiple risk factors for heart disease and stroke resulted in near complete occlusion of the middle cerebral artery, a potentially life-threatening condition. Early treatment of elevated cholesterol in children can lead to better outcomes, contradicting the common perception that strokes primarily affect the elderly.

site_title: China's wealthy 'little sisters' powering the economy
summary: China's "little sisters" - independent women in their 30s - are driving the country's economy with their spending power. They prioritize financial stability, travel, and luxury items, and are increasingly open about their desires for independence, shifting societal norms. The term, used to avoid citing a woman's age, has gained popularity due to TV shows and media attention. This demographic is expected to generate $4.5 trillion to $18 trillion in the market over the next decade, influencing consumer spending and entertainment industries, with luxury brands and investment funds catering to their needs.

images.alt_text: The women's market is expected to generate between 4.5 trillion and 5 trillion yuan this year and up to 18 trillion yuan over the next decade.

site_title: The income edge in the stock market
summary: Investing in the stock market can be a lucrative long-term strategy, with a 10-year horizon offering a 83% chance of growth and a 2% chance of losing money when dividends are included. The Straits Times Index shows that over any 5-year period, there's a 40% chance the index would be lower, but this risk is significantly reduced when dividends are considered. Investing regularly, with a disciplined approach, can help mitigate the risks and maximize returns, making it a more attractive option for those seeking long-term growth.

site_title: Higher gold prices no boon for pawnbrokers
summary: Singapore's gold prices hit an all-time high in August, but the number of clients pawning their gold has only seen a slight increase, with many opting to sell instead. The pandemic remains a significant factor, leading to reduced expenditures and household expenses. Despite this, some pawnbrokers, such as ValueMax and Maxi-Cash, have reported revenue increases due to improved contributions from their pawnbroking and trading businesses, with the latter benefiting from rental rebates and cash grants. The industry expects demand to remain high, even if the pandemic eases, as consumers become more value-driven and environmentally conscious.

site_title: Some wishes come true for active funds in weekly Nasdaq shakeout
summary: Active funds in the Nasdaq 100 have fared relatively well despite a volatile week, with some managers using the dip to add positions in internet and software companies. The benchmark's equal-weight version rose 0.7% this week, outperforming the cap-weighted version, which fell 0.6%. Funds heavily tilted to megacap FAAMG shares have greatly outperformed, with those holding at least one-fifth of their portfolios in these stocks averaging a 10% return this year. Managers are now using the dip to add tech exposure, with 60% of funds favoring the sector, but risk of excessive enthusiasm and a bursting tech bubble remain concerns.

site_title: STI ends mostly unchanged; SGX shares jump 5%
summary: Singapore stocks ended Friday broadly unchanged, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing 3.07 points or 0.12% lower at 2,497.71. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) shares jumped 5.12% to close at S$9.03 after announcing the listing of the world's largest Chinese pure-government bond exchange-traded fund (ETF). Goldman Sachs upgraded its call on SGX to "buy" from "neutral", raising its price target to S$10.

site_title: What impact will US elections have on the stock market?
summary: US stock market performance in November will be heavily influenced by the upcoming elections. Polls suggest a likely Democratic win, but the analysis highlights the unreliability of polls and suggests the elections will be closer than expected. Historically, incumbent party wins result in positive stock market performance (+16%), while incumbent party losses result in negative performance (-8%). Investors should track betting website odds and the US equity market's performance from the end of the national conventions to the elections, which has a high correlation in predicting the outcome.

site_title: Synagie to partner computer manufacturers to expand insurtech business
summary: Synagie Corporation, a Singapore-listed insurtech company, is partnering with leading computer manufacturers to expand its business. The company will bundle its accidental damage protection solutions and third-party administration services in major government tenders for laptops and tablets. Synagie is also in discussions with a computer manufacturer to offer laptops on a "device-as-a-service" basis to small and medium-sized enterprises in Singapore. The company aims to focus on its insurtech business after disposing of its e-commerce business for S$61.7 million.

site_title: Asian financial leaders agree to make 'all policy efforts' to fight pandemic
summary: Asian financial leaders from China, Japan, South Korea, and Southeast Asia agreed to make "all policy efforts" to combat the economic impact of the pandemic and defend a multilateral trade system. They pledged to reduce vulnerabilities, support sustained recovery, and uphold an open and rule-based multilateral trade system. The leaders also signed a bilateral currency swap arrangement and vowed to boost the Chiang Mai Initiative Multilateralisation to enhance regional financial stability.

images.alt_text: The pandemic has triggered deep downturns in regional economies, disrupted global trade and supply chains, and increased market volatility.

site_title: PSD unveils changes in permanent secretary appointments; MAS reshuffles senior posts
summary: The Public Service Division of Singapore has announced changes to permanent secretary appointments, effective October 19. Chia Der Jiun, deputy managing director of MAS, will leave to become second permanent secretary (Manpower), while Lai Wei Lin will be appointed permanent secretary (Law). MAS also made several senior management changes, including the appointment of Jacqueline Loh as deputy managing director (Corporate Development) and Gillian Tan as assistant managing director (Development & International). Ravi Menon thanked Chia for his 16 years of service.

site_title: New Parma owner promises exciting football in long-term project
summary: The new US owners of Parma FC, led by Kyle Krause, have vowed to build a long-term future for the Italian football club, prioritizing the development of young players and creating an exciting team to watch. Despite Italy's bureaucratic hurdles, Krause is committed to renovating the Stadio Tardini. The club aims to become more competitive, with a focus on youth development and a long-term vision, rather than seeking immediate success. Parma's goal is to eventually achieve European success, but this will take time and patience.

site_title: Google removes Paytm mobile app from store over policy violations
summary: Google removed the Paytm mobile app from its Android store due to policy violations, specifically related to online casinos and unregulated sports betting. The US tech company stated that it does not allow apps that facilitate paid tournaments to win real money or cash prizes. Paytm assured users that their money was safe and that the app would be back soon. This move follows Google's strict policies on gambling-related apps.

site_title: Welcome to the era of vaccine diplomacy
summary: The UAE has approved a new China-based Sinopharm vaccine, demonstrating the benefits of fast vaccine approval in improving a nation's standing and access to vaccine doses. Russia and China have also approved vaccines, with Russia aiming for wider distribution this autumn. However, the risks of speed in vaccine approval are also evident, as seen in the recent debate over resuming the AstraZeneca trials in the US. The decision on vaccine policies for individual nations will depend on the actions of other nations, highlighting the need for global cooperation in vaccine diplomacy.

site_title: Judge cites 'clear case of balance sheet insolvency' for placing KS Energy and its key unit under IJM
summary: A Singaporean judge has placed oil services group KS Energy and its key unit under interim judicial management (IJM) due to a "clear case of balance sheet insolvency". The decision was made after OCBC's application to place the company under IJM was granted. The judge noted that a scheme of arrangement would require the creditor bank's backing, indicating the company's financial struggles. The judge also highlighted the need for a "white knight" to rescue the company, suggesting a significant financial challenge ahead.

site_title: Why consultation papers matter
summary: Singapore's consultation papers on financial regulations aim to protect investors and promote transparency in corporate reporting. Responding to these papers is crucial, as investors' input helps shape policies that safeguard their interests. The financial sector relies on investors' funds, which can be a significant source of capital for development projects and loans. Ignoring consultation papers can lead to slower economic growth and decreased investor protection. By advocating for transparency, fairness, and professionalism, investors can contribute to shaping a better financial market, ultimately benefiting the broader economy.

site_title: Ascendas Reit to purchase suburban office building in Sydney for A$167.2m
summary: Ascendas Reit is acquiring a suburban office building in Sydney, Australia, for A$167.2 million (S$161 million) from Frasers Property Industrial and Winten Property Group. The 9-storey building, MQX4, will have a total net lettable area of 19,384 sq m, with a 6.1% net property income yield for the first year. The completion is expected in mid-2022, with a three-year rental guarantee for vacant spaces, and will be funded by Ascendas Reit through internal resources and existing debt facilities.

site_title: No exclusivity arrangement to sell assets: OUE C-Reit
summary: OUE C-Reit's manager has denied entering an exclusivity arrangement to sell any of its assets, contradicting a recent article. The manager stated it explores potential acquisitions and divestments as part of its proactive asset management strategy to maximize returns for unitholders. It receives unsolicited expressions of interest in its assets, which will be evaluated carefully for the best interests of all unitholders. The Reit's units closed down 0.5 Singapore cents to 37.5 Singapore cents following the announcement.

site_title: A big push to lead a healthy lifestyle
summary: Asics president and COO is using technology to reach out to customers during the COVID-19 pandemic and recession, emphasizing the importance of leading a healthy lifestyle. The global sports industry has been significantly impacted, with sporting events being postponed or cancelled due to the pandemic. Asics is adapting to the "new normal" of virtual sports events and a growing trend towards healthier living. The company is utilizing technology to engage customers and promote a balanced lifestyle.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Medtecs International, a medical apparel maker, received a query from Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) regarding its unusual price movements on Friday, marking the second query in three months. The company's stock closed at S$1.07, down 9.32% from the previous day. Meanwhile, Mermaid Maritime's wholly-owned subsidiary will invest in a new joint venture (JV) called ZeaQuest, focusing on robotics and AI technology for commercial subsea engineering services, with an initial investment of 77.5 million baht.

site_title: Reits (September 19-20, 2020)
summary: Realty Investment Trusts (REITs) experienced fluctuations in September 2020. US mortgage rates rose after five consecutive weeks of declines, affecting the housing market. Meanwhile, a Q3 wave of condo launches in Singapore is anticipated to test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf. In the US, Manhattan rents reached a record, with predictions of further increases. Other market trends include a rebound in UK homebuyer demand, Goldman Sachs' acquisition of Seoul hotel and retail assets, and New World's sale of China property assets. WeWork secured new tenants at 21 Collyer Quay in Singapore.

site_title: Ryanair cuts capacity further, citing travel restrictions
summary: Ryanair has cut its October capacity by 20% due to continued EU travel restrictions, citing "mismanagement" of air travel and economic activity. The airline now expects to fly 40% of its October capacity, down from 50% previously. If restrictions remain, further capacity cuts may be needed across the winter period, with empty seats expected to be over 30% on October flights. The airline's share price fell 4.5% following the announcement.

site_title: Camsing Healthcare receives letter of demand from Rajah & Tann
summary: Camsing Healthcare received a letter of demand from law firm Rajah & Tann for S$16,118.13, related to outstanding invoices for legal services. The demand must be paid within seven days or the firm will initiate legal action. The company is reviewing the demand and will update shareholders on any developments. Trading of Camsing Healthcare's shares remains suspended until conditions are met.

site_title: India's Modi defends new law as critics warn of risks to farmers
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi defended new laws aimed at reforming the Agriculture Produce Marketing Committee (APMC) Act, which critics warn could harm farmers. The laws, passed by India's lower house of Parliament, require growers to sell produce only at regulated wholesale markets, potentially limiting their options and prices. Modi claims the legislation will "unshackle" millions of farmers, but opponents argue it could lead to market manipulation and reduce their bargaining power. The laws have sparked protests from opposition parties and some farming bodies.

site_title: US: Nasdaq opens higher as tech selloff calms
summary: The Nasdaq Composite rose 63.17 points or 0.58% to 10,973.45 at the open, shaking off a two-day decline in technology stocks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 37.11 points or 0.13% to 27,864.87, while the S&P 500 opened flat at 3,357.38. The gains were despite concerns over rising coronavirus cases and a patchy economic recovery.

site_title: Trump to block US downloads of TikTok, WeChat on Sunday: officials
summary: The US Commerce Department will issue an order on Friday banning new US downloads of Chinese-owned messaging app WeChat and video-sharing app TikTok starting on Sept 20. The ban, which could be rescinded by President Trump, aims to protect US users' data and address concerns about the security of the apps. ByteDance, TikTok's owner, has been in talks with Oracle to create a new company, TikTok Global, to address US concerns. The ban will not affect existing users or transactions outside the US.

site_title: At the cutting edge of biotechnology
summary: iX Biopharma, a Singapore Exchange-listed specialty pharmaceutical company, focuses on developing novel wafer formulations to improve quality of life for those suffering from pain and other health conditions. The company has developed a drug carrier platform called WaferiX, which allows for sublingual administration of pharmacologically active compounds. Its flagship product, Wafermine, is in the process of being licensed out, with a Phase III clinical trial program underway. The company also has a nutraceuticals division, Entity Health, and has partnered with Cannatrek to supply its CBD product, Xativa, to the Australian market.

site_title: Ant Group wins Shanghai OK for launch of giant dual IPO
summary: China's Ant Group has received Shanghai Stock Exchange approval for a domestic IPO, bringing the financial technology firm closer to a dual-listing worth up to $30 billion. Ant plans to list in Hong Kong and Shanghai's Star Market, with a potential IPO as early as October, pending Hong Kong Stock Exchange approval. The company aims to open books after China's National Day holiday and go public by the end of next month, subject to change.

site_title: Porsche Taycan 4S: A true blue Porsche
summary: Porsche has launched the Taycan 4S, a luxury all-electric sports sedan in Singapore, with prices starting from S$485,988. The 4S, Turbo, and Turbo S variants will be available for launch next Tuesday, with customer test drives following the day after. The Taycan is positioned as a statement-making vehicle, with high prices and ample space for charging, making it suitable for households with land. The all-electric sports sedan aims to electrify the luxury segment in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Given that Porsche has been pushing the limits of mechanical performance for the better part of seventy years, it was only a matter of time before the brand would start to push the limits of electric performance as well.

Given that Porsche has been pushing the limits of mechanical performance for the better part of seventy years, it was only a matter of time before the brand would start to push the limits of electric performance as well.

site_title: Startups race to develop tech that can clear workplaces of Covid
summary: Smithfield Foods, the largest pork company in the world, is investing in ionized hydrogen peroxide vapour technology to reduce the spread of COVID-19 in its workplaces. Developed by Dayton, Ohio-based Extreme Microbial Technologies (EMT), the technology uses a coated honeycomb matrix to neutralize pathogens on surfaces. While experts question its effectiveness in preventing airborne transmission, some companies, including Chipotle Mexican Grill and Graeter's Ice Cream, have installed similar systems. EMT aims to make $10 million in sales this year, with a projected $72 million in 2022, as the pandemic creates a growing demand for the technology.

site_title: Fearing supply shortfall, EU wants to buy more Covid vaccines: sources
summary: The European Union is considering raising funds to purchase more Covid-19 vaccines due to concerns about a potential global supply shortfall. The EU executive, the European Commission, estimates that 2.4 billion doses will be available globally next year, which could outstrip demand. The EU wants to boost its emergency fund, which has so far made available 2 billion euros, to secure more vaccines and share excess doses with poorer countries. This move could limit vaccines available to poorer countries, contradicting the EU's public stance on sharing vaccines globally.

site_title: Japan's Suga aims to get flaghsip digital agency running by autumn 2021: Nikkei
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga aims to launch his digital agency by autumn 2021, accelerating the digitalization of Japan's government administration. Suga had asked the government to speed up preparations, with Digital Transformation Minister Takuya Hirai announcing a schedule for the project. This move is part of Suga's key pledge to modernize the government's outdated administration.

site_title: TikTok owner more certain of Beijing nod on Oracle deal
summary: ByteDance, owner of TikTok, is gaining confidence that its proposed alliance with Oracle will pass China's regulatory approval. Beijing may allow the deal as long as it doesn't involve the transfer of TikTok's AI algorithms, even if ByteDance cedes majority control over the app. This comes despite China's assertion of its right to block critical technologies. A private deal between ByteDance and Oracle is likely to be greenlit, providing a resolution to the ongoing political clash over TikTok.

site_title: US details up to US$14b in new aid for farmers
summary: The US Agriculture Department has announced a new round of Covid-19 aid for farmers, totaling up to $14 billion. The program aims to support growers of major crops and livestock, with a focus on those impacted by the pandemic. This is the second round of aid, following a $19 billion relief program announced in April. The package will largely be funded by the Commodity Credit Corporation and includes money for specialty crops and dairy farmers. The aid is designed to help farmers cope with the economic impact of the virus.

site_title: Corporate cost-cutting taking the sweet out of mooncakes
summary: Corporate sales of mooncakes are expected to decline by 50% this year due to the economic climate and COVID-19, with tighter belts and shuttered offices reducing seasonal company gift-giving. Retailers are turning to new online marketing channels to make up for the loss, but buyers are unlikely to see significant sticker price markdowns at premium retailers. Some companies, such as DBS, are continuing to support the tradition of buying mooncakes for personal consumption or as gifts for friends and family, but overall, the industry is bracing for a sharp drop in sales.

images.alt_text: Traditional baked mooncakes from Hua Ting at Orchard Hotel.
Red date mooncakes with wolfberries and pumpkin seeds from the Singapore Marriott Tang Plaza Hotel.

White lotus paste with macadamia nut mooncakes from the Si Chuan Dou Hua restaurant chain. Retailers are bracing themselves for a sharp drop in sales - at least 50 per cent in the corporate segment, said a spokesperson for Pan Pacific Hotels Group.
Assorted nuts, white lotus and lychee rose, white lotus are two new mooncake flavours from Teochew heritage bakery Thye Moh Chan. The company fears corporate orders will fall 5 to 10 per cent.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 6.44 points lower on Friday at 1,506.63, due to a decrease in volume to 6.866 billion lots worth RM5.067 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 628 to 441.

site_title: STI ends Friday barely changed at 2,497.71, shares in SGX up more than 5 per cent
summary: Singapore stocks ended Friday at 2,497.71, barely changed, with the Straits Times Index (STI) 0.12% lower. The SGX was the strongest performer, up 5.12%. The market saw an evenly split advancers and decliners, with 202 stocks advancing and 202 declining.

site_title: The good, the bad and the 'radically dishonest'
summary: Researchers in Spain have identified three profiles of dishonesty and cheating patterns in lab experiments, including "honest" individuals who report the truth, "liars" who report the opposite, and "radically dishonest" individuals who don't roll at all and claim a reward. A third group, "cheating nonliars," flips multiple times until they get a desired outcome. The study also found that some individuals, known as "submaximising," knowingly break the rules but don't want to maximize the reward. The findings suggest that dishonesty is a complex issue with developmental and childhood roots, and that it's essential to have a more precise language to describe different types of dishonesty.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: High Court Justice Aedit Abdullah granted OCBC's application to place KS Energy and its key unit under interim judicial management, citing a "clear case of balance sheet insolvency". The Public Service Division announced changes in permanent secretary positions, while Singapore insurers extended premium deferment relief measures. Warehouse rents in Asia-Pacific are expected to remain stable, and retail investing in South-east Asia is expected to drive stock market gains. Singapore stocks ended Friday broadly unchanged, with the STI ending at 2,497.71.

site_title: Macquarie prepares intel analytics seller Nuix for US$1.5b IPO
summary: Macquarie Group is preparing to list its majority-owned software provider Nuix in a deal valued at close to US$1.5 billion, alongside Morgan Stanley. Nuix, which analyzes thousands of documents for high-profile investigations, is expected to list before Christmas, pending market conditions. The company has seen revenue growth of over 15% per year, reaching A$175 million in fiscal 2020. This listing would be the largest since fintech firm Tyro Payments' IPO last year, and would be a significant milestone for the data-analysis programme seller.

site_title: ECB moves closer to lifting bank dividend ban by next year
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is moving closer to lifting its ban on bank dividend payments by next year, with several members of the supervisory board favoring a return to dividends. The ban, initially intended to conserve capital and keep lending during the pandemic, has led to a decline in bank stocks. Proponents argue that well-capitalized banks need to reward shareholders to retain confidence and viability, while regulators consider economic indicators and data on loan volumes to make a decision. The ECB will review its stance in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Indonesia should manage central bank messages to keep investors' faith: S&P
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, maintains its credibility with investors despite parliamentary proposals to overhaul its mandate. S&P Global advises that the bank's communication and policy implementation will be key to maintaining credibility, as changes could negatively impact investor confidence and weaken the sovereign rating. The agency warns that financial market implications could arise, potentially affecting monetary flexibility and rating support.

site_title: Malaysia's medical glove makers struggle to meet demand due to labour shortage
summary: Malaysia's rubber glove manufacturers, struggling to meet demand due to a labor shortage, could have lost around RM7.6 billion in revenue. The industry's trade association, Margma, estimates a 36.7% increase in export revenue to RM29.8 billion and 9% increase in export volumes to 240 billion pieces of gloves this year. The major bottleneck is the shortage of workers and raw materials, with strict overtime rules also hindering productivity. Margma president Denis Low has urged the government to allow foreign workers to work in factories to meet the growing demand.

site_title: Europe: Stocks struggle as virus worries weigh on fragile recovery
summary: European stocks declined 0.1% in early trading on Friday, weighed down by concerns over the resurgence of coronavirus cases in France and the UK, which raised doubts about the continent's economic recovery. Despite dealmaking activity, travel and leisure stocks led the losses, while Spain's Bankia and Germany's Covestro saw gains. Market sentiment remained fragile, with private equity firm Apollo Global Management exploring a potential takeover of Covestro.

site_title: SIA pilots agree to deeper pay cuts amid Covid-19
summary: Singapore Airlines pilots agree to deeper pay cuts amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The pay cuts range from 10% to 50% and will be implemented starting October 1, 2020, to help the airline mitigate job losses. The cuts are in addition to a previous 10% cut in monthly variable component salaries. The airline expects to operate at under 50% of its capacity at the end of the fiscal year, with around 50 pilots retrenched.

site_title: Ascendas Reit to purchase suburban office building in Sydney for A$167.2m
summary: Ascendas Reit has agreed to purchase a suburban office building in Sydney, Australia, for A$167.2 million. The building, MQX4, will feature 19,384 sq m of office and retail space on 3,308 sq m of freehold land. Frasers Property Industrial and Winten Property Group will design and build the development, which will be Ascendas Reit's fifth suburban office asset in Australia. The acquisition is part of Ascendas Reit's expansion plans in the country.

site_title: Arm rival SiFive says Nvidia deal spurs interest in its technology
summary: SiFive, a rival to Arm in supplying chip designs, reports increased interest from customers after Nvidia's $40 billion acquisition of Arm. The deal has sparked concerns about Nvidia raising prices or limiting access to Arm technology, but SiFive CEO Patrick Little says customers are seeking more strategic partnerships. Several top semiconductor companies already work with SiFive, and the company has received over $185 million in funding. This renewed interest has reignited interest in RISC-V, an open-source chip technology not controlled by any one industry player.

site_title: BOJ's Kuroda says globalisation will be sustained despite Covid-19
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that globalization will continue despite the COVID-19 pandemic, with supply chains becoming more diversified and resilient. Kuroda emphasized the need for regional financial cooperation to provide a safety net in case of future shocks. He also encouraged the use of the crisis to accelerate digitalization and innovation. Japan's economy is expected to continue improving, albeit at a moderate pace, and the Bank of Japan will continue to support the economy in cooperation with the new government. Kuroda urged firms to resist protectionism and instead adapt to the changing global landscape.

images.alt_text: Globalisation will be sustained and supply chains will be diversified as firms adjust to novel coronavirus disruption, Japan's central bank governor said on Friday, challenging an assumption the virus will lead to fragmentation of world trade.

site_title: 11 new coronavirus cases in Singapore, with one imported
summary: Singapore reported 11 new coronavirus cases, with one imported from India, on September 18, 2020, marking the lowest daily figure in about six months. The sole community case is unlinked and a 30-year-old Singaporean man, while the imported case is a work permit holder who returned on September 6. The total number of cases now stands at 57,543, with 32 discharged and 407 recovering.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the week on a positive note, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.47% to 24,455.41. The Shanghai Composite Index also gained 2.07% to 3,338.09, while the Shenzhen Composite Index climbed 1.51% to 2,219.91. Despite concerns over a new US stimulus package, traders remained optimistic, with gains attributed to a rally in Singapore stocks and a surge in the valuation of eSIM platform Airalo.

site_title: China's Tencent rebrands WeChat work app ahead of Trump ban
summary: Tencent Holdings rebranded its WeChat Work office collaboration app to WeCom ahead of a US ban on WeChat-related transactions. The move is seen as a potential alternative to WeChat, which boasts over a billion users in China and 19 million daily active users in the US. WeCom allows users to link their WeChat accounts and access its features without downloading the app. US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross is set to release regulations clarifying which WeChat transactions will be prohibited, but it's unclear if WeCom falls under the ban.

site_title: SoftBank exits cellphone distributor Brightstar in telecoms sell-down
summary: SoftBank Group will sell US cellphone distributor Brightstar to a newly formed subsidiary of private equity firm Brightstar Capital Partners for an undisclosed price, with a 25% stake in the subsidiary. The sale marks SoftBank's latest move away from the telecoms industry, as it slashes holdings in wireless carrier SoftBank Corp to 40%. The transaction is expected to close by March 31, 2021, and is part of SoftBank's efforts to build a cash pile and shed lower-growth businesses.

site_title: Apple to launch first online store in India next week
summary: Apple is set to launch its first online store in India on September 23, coinciding with the country's holiday season. The move aims to provide customers with a direct shopping experience and offer personalized devices with engravings. Apple currently sells its products in India through third-party vendors and e-commerce operators. The online store will be available in English and Hindi, and will also allow Mac customers to configure their laptops according to their needs. This launch presents a challenge for bricks-and-mortar retailers, but also offers opportunities for growth in the competitive Indian market.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher; clock fourth straight weekly gain
summary: South Korean stocks closed higher on Friday, marking their fourth consecutive weekly gain, with the Kospi index rising 0.66% to 2,412.40. Foreign investors poured in 143.6 billion won worth of shares, while the won logged its sharpest gain in near six months. The country also reported 126 new Covid-19 cases, but a healthcare treatment approved for clinical trials boosted the healthcare index. The won rose 1.22% to 1,160.3 per US dollar, its largest weekly gain since early June.

site_title: TikTok and Instagram face off for luxury influencers
summary: TikTok is gaining ground on Instagram as a platform for luxury influencers, with brands like Louis Vuitton, Christian Dior, and Balenciaga creating content on the short-form video app. Instagram, however, is betting on its Reels feature to stay relevant, and is seeing promising results from influencers and brands posting on the platform. Despite this, TikTok's youthful focus and user-generated content may give it an edge, and Instagram must convince luxury brands to invest time and money in Reels to avoid becoming a fashion victim in the battle for short-video supremacy.

site_title: EU climate chief says now's the time for jumbo green bond sale
summary: The European Union's climate chief, Frans Timmermans, says the bloc is poised to sell up to 225 billion euros in green bonds, the largest issuance globally last year, to help reduce and eliminate carbon emissions. The bonds, backed by all EU governments, will fund climate action and make Europe the world's first climate-neutral continent by 2050, with a 55% emissions cut by 2030. The move aims to promote sustainable investment and drive a radical overhaul of the European economy, including stricter emissions caps and higher costs for emitters.

site_title: Warehouse rents in Asia-Pacific hold steady on e-commerce demand: Knight Frank
summary: Asia-Pacific warehouse rents remained stable in the first half of 2020, defying economic downturns. Prime warehouse rents in Singapore declined only 0.6% to S$1.80 per square foot per month, driven by e-commerce demand and essential commodity production. Knight Frank expects rents to hold steady until the end of the year, with only 4% of existing stock slated for completion. Online consumption accounted for 20% of retail consumption in developed Asia-Pacific markets, driving demand for warehousing. Market conditions are expected to remain stable or improve in 16 of 17 cities tracked.

site_title: Retail frenzy to drive stocks gains in South-east Asia: UBS
summary: Retail investors in South-east Asia are driving stock market gains, with UBS predicting a sustainable boom. Valuations remain cheap, and earnings are recovering, making Singapore and Malaysia the preferred markets. Retail investors, accounting for 40% of trading volumes in Thailand and Malaysia, are snapping up stocks from hotels, food and beverage, and malls. The MSCI Asean Index is down 22% but has the potential to recover with retail investing momentum. UBS expects institutional investors to reassess the region, benefiting from government support and a faster economic recovery.

site_title: Synagie to partner computer manufacturers to expand insurtech business
summary: Synagie Corporation, a listed insurtech company, is partnering with leading computer manufacturers to expand its business. The company will bundle its accidental damage protection solutions and administration services in major government tenders, and explore partnerships with consumer electronics stores. Synagie is also in discussions to offer laptops on a "device-as-a-service" basis to small and medium-sized enterprises. The company is shifting focus from its e-commerce business, which it plans to sell for S$61.7 million, and expects organic growth in its insurtech business due to market uncertainties.

site_title: PSD announces changes in permanent secretaries; MAS reshuffling senior posts
summary: The Public Service Division of Singapore has announced changes in permanent secretary positions, effective October 19, 2020. Chia Der Jiun will leave MAS to become second permanent secretary (Manpower), while Lai Wei Lin will be appointed permanent secretary (Law) and Loh Khum Yean will continue as permanent secretary (Public Service Division). MAS also announced senior management changes, including the appointment of Jacqueline Loh as deputy managing director (Corporate Development) and Gillian Tan as assistant managing director (Development & International).

site_title: Hillhouse targets over 20b yuan for new yuan-denominated fund: sources
summary: Private equity firm Hillhouse Capital Group is raising a yuan-denominated fund targeting over 20 billion yuan (S$4.01 billion) as the Chinese economy normalizes. The fundraising follows a revival in private equity activity in Asia, with only a little over US$6 billion raised for Asia-focused funds in the first half of the year. Hillhouse's largest dollar-denominated fund is also being raised, targeting US$13 billion, with a focus on venture investment, growth-stage companies, and buyout deals.

site_title: International lenders back US$9.5b financing for Russian Arctic LNG project: document
summary: International lenders, including French state investment bank Bpifrance, China Development Bank, and Germany's Euler Hermes, have lined up $9.5 billion in financial support for Russia's Arctic LNG 2 project, which aims to process gas from the Gydan Peninsula and ship 80% of liquefied natural gas (LNG) to Asia. The project, valued at $21 billion, is expected to reach its full capacity of almost 20 million tonnes per year by 2026, despite climate concerns. The support highlights the importance of the project for Russia's energy industry and its plans to raise its share in the global LNG market.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end higher on hopes for new government
summary: Tokyo shares rose on Friday as investors remained optimistic about the new government of Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga. The Nikkei 225 index increased 0.18% to 23,360.30, while the Topix index rose 0.49% to 1,646.42. The gains were driven by hopes for policy changes under Suga's leadership.

site_title: LinkedIn, Zynga tech veterans join hunt for SPAC targets
summary: LinkedIn co-founder Reid Hoffman and Zynga founder Mark Pincus are launching a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) to invest in technology startups, seeking to avoid the pitfalls of ultra-wealthy investors who have dominated the SPAC market. The pair raised $600 million and are looking for a target to help it grow without losing its "growth mindset". They're entering a crowded field, with 102 SPACs raising over $39 billion in IPOs this year, and are not ruling out traditional IPOs.

site_title: LSE in talks to sell Italy stock exchange to Euronext
summary: The London Stock Exchange (LSE) has entered exclusive talks with Euronext to sell Borsa Italiana, Italy's stock exchange, as part of regulatory remedies for its US$27 billion purchase of Refinitiv. Offers for Borsa valued it up to four billion euros. Euronext won exclusivity by teaming up with Italy's Cassa Depositi e Prestiti and Intesa Sanpaolo, with both becoming shareholders in the French exchange operator. The deal would create a leading player in continental European capital markets, with Borsa Italiana maintaining its functions and Italian identity.

site_title: UK retail recovery continues apace in August
summary: British retail sales volumes rose 0.8% in August, slightly above forecast, and are now 4.0% higher than pre-Covid levels. This marks the second consecutive month of gains, with sales previously overtaking pre-Covid levels in July. The sector's recovery is outpacing the overall UK economy, which contracted for the second month in a row.

images.alt_text: British retail sales extended gains last month, as parts of the sector enjoyed a much faster rebound than most of the economy, official figures showed on Friday.

site_title: Gold firms on economic worries, stimulus hopes
summary: Gold prices rose 0.5% to $1,951.32 per ounce, driven by concerns over the US economic outlook following gloomy jobs data. Central banks pledged further stimulus to revive their economies, boosting gold prices. US gold futures were also 0.5% higher. The increase follows a one-week low in the previous session, as investors seek safe-haven assets amid economic worries.

site_title: Ericsson to buy wireless networking firm Cradlepoint in US$1.1b deal
summary: Ericsson has agreed to buy US-based wireless networking company Cradlepoint in a $1.1 billion deal, giving it access to tools for connecting devices using Internet of Things over 4G or 5G networks. The transaction is expected to close before the end of 2020, impacting Ericsson's operating margins and cash flow. Cradlepoint, founded in 2006, will become a subsidiary of Ericsson and will continue to operate with its current sales and gross margin. The deal is Ericsson's largest in over a decade and remains consistent with the company's 2022 financial targets.

site_title: Seoul city seeks 4.6b won in damages from church over new Covid-19 outbreak
summary: The Seoul metropolitan government is seeking 4.6 billion won in damages from the Sarang Jeil Church for allegedly disrupting COVID-19 tracing and testing efforts, contributing to the country's largest cluster of infections. The church's actions, including providing inaccurate member lists, are believed to have aggravated the outbreak, which has driven triple-digit increases in daily cases for over a month. The city government and the National Health Insurance Service will also sue the church for related losses.

site_title: Australia: Shares drop on Victoria's virus woes; NZ at one-month low
summary: Australian shares fell 0.3% to 5,864.5, marking a second session of losses, amid worries over the coronavirus hotspot Victoria, experimental Covid-19 vaccines, and the US elections. Mining stocks rose 1.8% for their best weekly gain in six, while gold stocks also gained. In New Zealand, the benchmark index dropped 1.2% to its lowest close in over a month, as the country's economy hit a record low in the June quarter.

site_title: Carmakers cry foul as EU's climate plan takes aim at industry
summary: The European Union's 2030 Climate Target Plan aims to reduce carbon-dioxide emissions by 55% from 1990 levels, but carmakers are criticizing the lack of government support needed to achieve the targets. The industry requires a dense EU-wide charging network and bigger incentives to make zero-emission vehicles affordable. Carmakers like BMW and the European Automobile Manufacturers Association (ACEA) are warning that the targets will be a burden on suppliers, employment, and economic growth. The industry is also concerned that the rise of electric vehicles will hinder demand for internal-combustion engine components and lead to job losses.

images.alt_text: Carmakers baulked at the European Union's (EU) plan to set stricter emissions limits for the next decade, saying they lack the government support needed to achieve the targets.

site_title: Watchmaker Maurice de Mauriac has a mechanism to avoid supply crunch
summary: Swiss watchmaker Maurice de Mauriac is confident it can maintain production despite a supply crunch caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. Key supplier Swatch Group halted deliveries of mechanisms, but Maurice de Mauriac has used existing stock and is in talks with ETA to obtain more. The company, which produces around 300 watches per year, has also organized events to drum up interest in its niche brand. Despite a decline in the Swiss industry, Maurice de Mauriac remains optimistic and continues to use its existing stock and partner with ETA to meet demand.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 7.13 points, or 0.47%, to 1,505.94. Volume reached 165.95 million lots worth RM74.45 million.

site_title: Asia: Markets drift as rally stalls, stimulus row dents optimism
summary: Asian markets experienced a mixed day on Friday as investors struggled to reignite the rally, citing a stuttering economic recovery and US lawmakers' failure to agree on a new stimulus. The US Congress is at odds over a potential $2.2 trillion package, while the Federal Reserve has indicated it will keep interest rates low for at least three years. The lack of fiscal support has raised concerns about the economy's fragile recovery, with the Fed warning of significant risks. Markets in Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Seoul rose, while Tokyo was marginally up, but Sydney, Singapore, and Manila saw slight losses.

site_title: Judge cites 'clear case of balance sheet insolvency' for placing KS Energy, key unit under IJM
summary: High Court Justice Aedit Abdullah has granted OCBC's application to place embattled oil services group KS Energy and its key unit KS Drilling under interim judicial management (IJM). The judge cited a "clear case of balance sheet insolvency" and noted that a miracle is needed for KS Energy to recover without OCBC's cooperation. The companies face significant debts, with OCBC holding 61.1% of KS Energy's liabilities and 86.1% of KS Drilling's liabilities. The judge's decision allows for IJM to be appointed, pending a full JM hearing, which is seen as a likely outcome.

site_title: Apple to launch first online store in India next week
summary: Apple plans to launch its first online store in India on September 23, coinciding with the country's festive season. The company currently sells its products through third-party vendors and e-commerce firms. Apple's online store will offer assistance in English and Hindi, allowing customers to engrave products in multiple languages. The move is seen as a strategic step to tap into India's huge growth prospects for smartphone makers.

site_title: Wall Street firms struggle to keep up in China mutual fund boom
summary: Foreign asset managers, including BlackRock and Vanguard Group, are struggling to compete in China's $3.4 trillion mutual fund industry. In the first eight months of the year, funds backed by international firms raised $470 billion from retail investors, less than half the amount raised by their Chinese rivals. Chinese funds have tapped into local talent and social media influencers to boost their popularity, giving them a significant edge. Foreign companies are facing challenges in terms of autonomy, talent retention, and distribution power, with many seeing their market share forecasted to decline to 15% by 2030.

site_title: SoftBank Group to sell Brightstar in latest asset sale
summary: SoftBank Group to sell US cellphone distributor Brightstar for an undisclosed price, as part of its efforts to raise cash. The transaction, expected to close by March 31, 2021, involves the sale of Brightstar Global Group to a newly formed subsidiary of Brightstar Capital Partners for cash and a 25% stake in the subsidiary.

site_title: China begins military drills as senior US official visits Taiwan
summary: China has begun combat drills near the Taiwan Strait, amid growing tensions with the US over its close relationship with Taiwan. The drills were announced on the same day US Undersecretary for Economic Affairs Keith Krach began meetings in Taipei. China has denounced the US-Taiwan ties as "collusion" and warned that any attempt to use Taiwan to control China will be met with a "necessary response." The drills come after China carried out large-scale drills off Taiwan's coast last week and China's fighter jets crossed the mid-line of the Taiwan Strait in July.

site_title: EU travel industry steps up quarantine pushback
