summary: European Union travel and tourism leaders have urged European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen to push governments to end quarantine requirements, instead adopting coordinated restrictions and testing. The appeal comes as data shows a "double-dip" air traffic slump, with passenger numbers down 73% in the first two weeks of September. Industry groups, representing over 5,000 companies and millions of workers, warn that failure to implement a common "traffic light" system will kill the potential recovery of the tourism sector, which generates 10% of EU economic output and employs 12% of the workforce.

site_title: Storm Noul makes landfall in Vietnam, kills at least one person
summary: Tropical storm Noul made landfall in Vietnam, killing at least one person and injuring another. The storm hit Danang and veered north to Thua Thien Hue province, causing heavy rain, downed trees, and damaged houses. Authorities had evacuated up to half a million people but downgraded the storm to a low-pressure system, warning of potential floods and landslides. The storm followed Vietnam's long history of destructive storms, with 132 people killed and 207 injured in the country last year.

images.alt_text: Tropical storm Noul made landfall in Vietnam on Friday, killing at least one person and triggering heavy rain in the central parts of the country, though authorities later downgraded the weather system.

site_title: China, Japan, South Korea agree to make 'all policy efforts' to fight pandemic
summary: China, Japan, and South Korea agreed to make all policy efforts to combat the pandemic, vowing to defend the multilateral trade and investment system. The commitment comes after the coronavirus triggered deep downturns in regional economies and highlighted the importance of maintaining an open and rule-based multilateral trade and investment system. The three countries also pledged to strengthen the Chiang Mai Initiative Multilateralisation, a web of multilateral currency-swap arrangements, to assist regional economies dealing with crisis situations.

site_title: Citigroup to hire 6,000 youth in Asia as unemployment soars
summary: Citigroup plans to hire 6,000 young people in Asia over the next three years to combat youth unemployment, which has doubled in some countries. The bank will also offer 60,000 job training opportunities across its retail and institutional businesses. Citi has pledged a $35 million investment to improve employability for low-income and underserved youth by 2023. The move aims to address the Asia-Pacific region's youth unemployment crisis, with 700 million people under the age of 24, accounting for nearly half of the region's unemployed.

site_title: Australia: Shares shed early gains as Covid-19 hotspot reports more cases
summary: Australian shares fell marginally on Friday, giving up early gains of 0.65%, as a rise in daily new infections in Victoria, Australia's Covid-19 hotspot, dashed hopes for a swifter recovery. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,882.5, on track to snap a fourth consecutive weekly decline. The state reported its biggest daily rise in new infections in over a week, leading to concerns about lockdown restrictions. Financials offset gains in miners, contributing to the flat trading session.

site_title: Malaysia cuts medical tourism targets as border control tightens
summary: Malaysia is reducing its target for medical tourists due to tightened border controls and ongoing coronavirus resurgences. The country expects to earn RM800 million in revenue from medical tourists in 2021, down from RM1.7 billion in 2019. Malaysia has allowed medical tourists from six countries, including Singapore, and banned citizens of dozens of countries with high case numbers. The country plans to focus on improving services for specific treatments, such as cancer and fertility, during the slow period. Revenue from medical tourism is expected to be significantly lower than initial targets.

site_title: Singapore shares inch up at Friday's open; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.1% at the opening of trading on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 2,502.96 points. The gains followed a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, despite US Federal Reserve stimulus doubts. The benchmark index saw 68 gains and 47 losses, with 39.1 million securities changing hands.

site_title: Australia looks set to ease border limits and allow more citizens home
summary: Australia is set to ease border limits and allow more citizens to return home, with the government planning to increase the weekly cap by 2,000 to 6,000 people, starting from next Friday. This move comes after a downward trend in coronavirus infections, with Queensland state partially reopening its borders to residents of Canberra, which has had no new infections in 10 weeks. The country has reported over 26,800 cases and 829 deaths, with Victoria's rolling average of new infections decreasing, raising hopes for easing of strict lockdown measures before October 26.

site_title: Federal Reserve weighs extending bank dividend caps as stress tests resume
summary: The Federal Reserve is considering extending dividend payment and share buyback caps for US banks, scheduled to lapse at the end of the third quarter. The caps, imposed in June, restrict banks from increasing investor payouts and ban buybacks. The decision will be made in two weeks, with banks potentially resuming buybacks in the fourth quarter if allowed. The Fed released hypothetical stress tests, simulating economic damage from the pandemic, to evaluate banks' resilience.

site_title: Singapore insurers extend premium deferment relief measures
summary: Singapore insurers, the General Insurance Association of Singapore (GIA) and the Life Insurance Association, Singapore (LIA), have extended premium deferment relief measures to help policyholders pay premiums during the Covid-19 pandemic. The measures include a second Deferred Premium Payment (DPP) window for new applications until March 31, 2021, and flexible premium instalment plans for general insurance policyholders until December 31, 2021. This aims to maintain insurance coverage while providing support to policyholders facing financial difficulties. Monetary Authority of Singapore deputy managing director Ong Chong Tee welcomed the measures, saying they will enable affected policyholders to maintain their policies or consider alternate coverage.

site_title: Rockefeller family's Manhattan apartment listed at US$11.5m
summary: A Manhattan co-op owned by former US Vice President Nelson Rockefeller for nearly 60 years has been listed for sale at $11.5 million. The 3,990 sq ft, 4-bedroom unit on the 15th floor of 812 Fifth Ave features a 295 sq ft terrace overlooking Central Park. Luxury sales are struggling amid the pandemic, with only one signed contract for a Manhattan co-op priced over $10 million in August. The listing agent believes buyers are seeking "trophy" properties, despite weaker market activity at the high end.

site_title: Qantas CEO Joyce's pay falls 83% because of coronavirus pandemic
summary: Qantas CEO Alan Joyce's total pay fell 83% to A$1.7 million due to the coronavirus pandemic, pushing him out of Australia's top-paid bosses. The decline was partly due to not receiving 345,000 shares associated with a long-term incentive program. Joyce took no salary from April to July and returned to 65% of his base salary in August. The airline has announced plans to cut 8,500 jobs and most staff remain stood down, receiving government support. Joyce's salary cuts follow similar moves by rival airlines Singapore Airlines and Cathay Pacific Airways.

site_title: Biden lambastes Trump over 'close to criminal' Covid-19 response
summary: US Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden criticized President Donald Trump for his handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, calling it "close to criminal" and blaming him for thousands of unnecessary American deaths. Biden made the comments during a town hall-style event in Scranton, Pennsylvania, where he emphasized the need for a coordinated national response if he is elected. The event came after Trump defended his administration's response to the outbreak despite acknowledging the virus's deadliness in March. Biden's comments follow his recent travel to swing states for campaign appearances, which have been largely empty due to the pandemic.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat ahead of long weekend
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on Friday, September 18, 2020, ahead of a long weekend, due to cautious trading. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.03% to 23,326.05, while the Topix index increased 0.04% to 1,639.12. Investors were influenced by a stronger yen and recent falls on Wall Street.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open Friday's session with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened Friday with a 0.17% gain, adding 40.28 points to 24,381.13. Investors remain cautious following a negative day on Wall Street due to global economic recovery worries. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index remained flat, while Singapore stocks notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Moutai ladles out value from its punch bowl
summary: Kweichow Moutai, China's largest liquor distiller, plans to issue bonds to buy a stake in Guizhou Expressway, a struggling highway operator. The move aims to help the local government pay off its massive debt. Moutai's parent company will sell up to 15 billion yuan in bonds, and its finance subsidiary will invest in fixed-income securities. This diversification move comes as Moutai's sales rise alongside public spending on infrastructure projects. The company's market value has increased by $10 billion, despite the move erasing some of its market capitalization.

site_title: Fonterra posts huge profit after revamp
summary: Fonterra, New Zealand's largest dairy exporter, has posted a net profit of NZ$659 million for the 12 months to July 31, rebounding from a NZ$605-million loss the previous year. The turnaround comes after the company restructured its operations to focus on core business, including writing down over NZ$800 million in assets, including investments in China. Fonterra's profit announcement marks a significant return to profitability after two years of heavy losses.

site_title: Roadblocks loom for best-performing Malaysia bonds
summary: Malaysian bonds, the best performers in Asia this quarter, face challenges as demand at recent debt auctions falters, diminishing expectations for another interest-rate cut, and concerns about possible exclusion from a key global bond index. The bid-to-cover ratio at recent auctions has fallen to 1.47 times, the lowest this year, and a key test of investor demand looms. The rally is driven by expectations of interest-rate cuts, but markets are now doubting there's much room left, and a possible exclusion from the World Government Bond Index could lead to outflows from index-following funds.

site_title: China to suspend imports from Indonesian seafood producer for one week
summary: China will suspend imports from Indonesian seafood producer PT Putri Indah for one week after a batch of frozen hairtail fish tested positive for the coronavirus. This suspension follows China's previous policy of halting imports from companies testing positive for the virus for a second time. The move aims to ensure food safety and prevent the spread of COVID-19.

images.alt_text: China will stop accepting import applications from Indonesian seafood producer PT Putri Indah for one week after a batch of frozen hairtail fish from the company tested positive for the coronavirus, the customs office said on Friday.

site_title: Japan's Aug consumer prices fall at fastest pace in four years
summary: Japan's core consumer prices fell 0.4% in August, the largest drop in four years, amid deflation risks and economic challenges. The Bank of Japan may increase stimulus if job losses heighten the risk of deflation. New Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga has pledged to contain COVID-19 and retain growth policies while pushing reforms. The economy shrank 28.1% in April-June, its worst postwar contraction. The core-core price index, excluding food and energy prices, also fell 0.1% in August, its first drop since March 2017.

site_title: Mermaid Maritime unit to invest 77.5m baht for stake in AI, robotics JV
summary: Mermaid Maritime's wholly-owned subsidiary will invest 77.5 million baht (S$3.4 million) for a 50% stake in ZeaQuest, a joint venture with AI and Robotics Ventures Company, to develop robotics and AI technology for commercial subsea engineering services.

site_title: Goldman CEO renews attempts to sell his ski estate
summary: Goldman Sachs CEO David Solomon is attempting to sell his 33-hectare ski estate in Aspen, Colorado, for approximately US$25 million. The 13,000-square-foot mansion features panoramic views of the Aspen upper valley. Solomon had previously listed the property for US$36 million in 2017 but failed to find buyers. With rising demand for homes in less-densely populated areas, Solomon hopes to attract serious interest this time around. The sale comes amid a surge in single-family home sales in Aspen, which increased 440% in August from a year earlier.

site_title: Two-thirds of Japan public support new PM Suga: polls
summary: Two-thirds of Japan's public support new Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga, according to domestic polls. A Kyodo telephone poll showed 66.4% support, while a Nikkei newspaper survey found 74% backing his cabinet. Suga pledged to contain COVID-19 and push reforms, and a majority of respondents (55.1%) believe the lower house should be dissolved for an election shortly before or at the end of its current term. Suga aims to address the coronavirus outbreak and revive the economy, rather than calling a snap election to solidify his power.

site_title: Twitter tightens security for politicians and journalists
summary: Twitter has implemented enhanced security measures for high-profile politicians, journalists, and campaigns ahead of the US presidential election. The measures include stronger password requirements, two-factor authentication, and more sophisticated systems to detect suspicious activity. The company aims to prevent hackers from taking over accounts, following a July incident where dozens of high-profile accounts were compromised through a spear phishing attack. Twitter's safety team emphasized the need for these precautions, citing concerns about the potential for malicious activity to sway elections or cause conflict.

site_title: UK employers scale back hiring plans for 2021: CBI
summary: UK employers plan to cut recruitment or freeze hiring due to the coronavirus pandemic, with 51% of companies intending to maintain or increase staffing and 46% planning reductions. This represents a sharp turnaround from last year, when most companies expected to hire more staff. The CBI's chief policy director attributed the shift to the ongoing pressure on firms and the UK labor market. The figures come as the government faces pressure to extend the furlough scheme to slow job losses, with unemployment expected to reach 7.5% by the end of the year.

site_title: Facebook to curb private groups spreading hate, misinformation
summary: Facebook has implemented measures to curb private groups spreading hate and misinformation, following a crackdown on malicious content. Over a year, the platform removed 1.5 million pieces of content for violating hate policies, with 91% detected by automated software. Administrators of groups taken down for rule-breaking will face temporary restrictions, and users will need moderator permission for new posts. Facebook will also archive inactive groups and stop showing health-themed groups in recommendation results to promote authoritative sources.

site_title: Banks restart job cuts with global losses topping 60,000
summary: Banks worldwide are cutting jobs, with a combined 63,785 positions lost this year, the deepest in half a decade. Lenders, including Citigroup and HSBC, have restarted job cuts after a pause during the lockdown, surpassing the previous year's losses. This increase in job losses is attributed to the ongoing global economic downturn, resulting in significant losses for banks.

site_title: Covid's hidden crisis: Stranded ship crew
summary: Hundreds of thousands of seafarers have been stranded at sea for months due to COVID-19 curbs, causing operational nightmares in shipping and bottlenecks in global supply chains. This crisis has taken a toll on seafarers' mental health and fatigue, while also increasing shipping costs. The situation is described as an "operational nightmare" by those in the shipping community, highlighting the need for innovative solutions to address this pressing issue.

site_title: Zopim co-founder eyes post-Covid travel surge with startup GoTrippin
summary: Royston Tay, co-founder of Zopim, is launching a new traveltech startup called GoTrippin, which aims to aggregate travel content and allow users to plan trips and itineraries. Tay sees post-Covid travel surge and believes a new wave of travel startups will emerge to capitalize on the trend. The platform is currently testing its approach and plans to expand beta tests in the coming months, with no plans to raise capital until it sees significant traction.

site_title: Banksy's attempt to trademark a graffiti image is thrown out
summary: Banksy's attempt to trademark his iconic "Flower Thrower" graffiti image was rejected by the European Union's intellectual property office. The artist had applied for a trademark without text, but the EU deemed it invalid due to the need to reveal his identity. In response, Banksy created a pop-up store to showcase his merchandise, but the EU's decision throws out his efforts to deter merchandisers from cashing in on his work. The decision maintains Banksy's anonymity while also preventing others from profiting from his image.

site_title: MBS hires law firm to probe over US$1b in money transfers
summary: Marina Bay Sands (MBS) has hired a law firm, Davinder Singh Chambers, to investigate employee transfers of over US$1 billion in gamblers' money to third parties. This comes after a US$9.1 million lawsuit was settled out of court, with MBS agreeing to reimburse the full amount. The investigation follows earlier scrutiny by US and Singapore authorities, including a probe by the Singapore Police Force and the US Department of Justice. MBS maintains that it has taken steps to strengthen its control measures, but shares of its parent company, Las Vegas Sands, fell 8.9% due to the ongoing scrutiny.

site_title: Thai protesters critical of monarchy to stage largest event yet
summary: Thai protesters, led by students, plan the largest gathering yet, with up to 100,000 expected at Thammasat University on Saturday, despite the university's ban. The protesters demand changes to the constitution to remove military influence and for a new, democratic election. The protests, which have been ongoing since July, have already led to 14 arrests and 61 people facing charges, including sedition. The government, led by Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha, is considering amendments to the charter and has appealed to the protesters to avoid the risk of virus infection.

images.alt_text: Thai protest leaders are planning the biggest gathering since the 2014 military coup, as they seek to build momentum in months-long demonstrations for greater democracy and reform of the country's powerful monarchy.

site_title: Ex-FBI chief Comey to testify to US Congress ahead of election
summary: Former FBI Director James Comey will testify to the US Congress on September 30 about his role in the "Crossfire Hurricane" investigation into Russian election interference. The Senate Judiciary Committee hearing, 34 days before the November election, comes amid allegations of a double standard in how Comey treated Hillary Clinton's campaign versus Donald Trump's. Republicans have criticized Comey, and Trump has repeatedly attacked him, calling him a "disgraced liar and leaker." Other key figures, including Andrew McCabe and Peter Strzok, may also testify.

site_title: Credit Suisse teams up with Qatar for direct lending venture
summary: Credit Suisse and Qatar Investment Authority (QIA) are partnering to establish a multibillion-dollar direct lending platform, investing in US and European companies. The financing will consist of secured loans, mainly targeting upper middle-market and large-cap businesses. This partnership follows a trend among sovereign wealth funds seeking higher yields in private markets. The QIA platform will be part of Credit Suisse Asset Management's Credit Investments Group, and is seen as a sign that investors believe the worst of the COVID-19 pandemic may be over. The venture aims to capitalize on the growing private debt asset class.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse Group and Qatar Investment Authority (QIA) are joining forces to set up a multibillion-dollar platform to invest in direct lending.

site_title: Oil rises 2%, reverses loses as Opec+ addresses market weakness
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Thursday, reversing losses, as Opec+ announced it would crack down on countries failing to comply with output cuts and planned an extraordinary meeting if oil markets weaken further. The producer group reaffirmed its 7.7 million barrel-per-day output target, but pressed laggards like Iraq, Nigeria, and the UAE to cut more barrels to compensate for overproduction. The news bolstered prices, overshadowing bearish US economic news and the restart of US offshore production after Hurricane Sally.

images.alt_text: Oil prices rose more than 2 per cent on Thursday, turning positive as Opec and its allies said the producer group would crack down on countries that failed to comply with output cuts and planned to hold an extraordinary meeting in October if oil markets weaken further.

site_title: US: Stocks fall amid doubts on stimulus prospects
summary: US stocks fell on Thursday due to uncertainty over government stimulus and mixed economic data. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.5%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.8% and 1.3%, respectively. Comments from Democratic Speaker Nancy Pelosi and White House Chief of Staff Mark Meadows suggested a stalemate on additional stimulus, which analysts fear will weigh on the economy. Economic data showed jobless claims inching lower but housing starts falling short of expectations, further exacerbating market concerns.

site_title: Europe: Sliding banks put an end to stocks' winning streak
summary: European shares ended a four-day winning streak, with banks and technology stocks contributing to the decline. The Stoxx 600 fell 0.5% and the German DAX dropped 0.4%, while France's CAC 40 fell 0.7%. The UK's FTSE 100 remained steady despite the Bank of England's interest rate speculation. The decline was attributed to near-zero interest rates and a technology stock sell-off on Wall Street.

site_title: Half of Covid-19 patients suffer ongoing fatigue: study
summary: A new study found that 52% of patients and hospital staff who had Covid-19 reported persistent fatigue, regardless of the severity of their initial infection, 10 weeks after "clinical recovery." The study, which tracked 128 participants, also found that women and those with a history of anxiety or depression were more likely to experience fatigue. Researchers are calling for further study on the long-term effects of Covid-19, citing the significant burden of lingering symptoms and the need for early intervention.

site_title: SIA, Singtel among top 100 companies in Refinitiv's 2020 diversity index
summary: SINGAPORE Airlines (SIA) and Singapore Telecommunications (Singtel) have been recognized among the top 100 most diverse and inclusive organizations globally by Refinitiv's 2020 Diversity & Inclusion (D&I) Index. They were among 21 Asia-Pacific companies to make the Top 100 list. This recognition highlights their commitment to diversity and inclusion.

images.alt_text: SIA is in 31st place of Refinitiv's 2020 Diversity & Inclusion Index with an overall score of 73.25.

site_title: Las Vegas homebuyers are bidding up prices in collapsing economy
summary: In Las Vegas, median home prices have surged 10% to $335,000 in August, outpacing annual growth of 6.7% in February, before the pandemic. High demand from out-of-state buyers, driven by record-low mortgage rates and Nevada's lack of income tax, is fueling the price increase. However, experts warn that this trend may reverse when owners resell properties, with CoreLogic projecting a 7.8% price decline by next July.

site_title: Moderna shares Covid-19 vaccine trial blueprints, will others follow?
summary: Moderna, a US biotech firm, has become the first to publish the blueprints of its Covid-19 vaccine trial, increasing pressure on other companies to follow suit. The trial, which involves 30,000 participants, aims to verify the vaccine's safety and effectiveness. Moderna's CEO, Stephane Bancel, expects results by November, with approval by October unlikely. The move comes amid growing concerns about potential political interference in the approval process, with President Trump touting a vaccine approval by October.

site_title: Rich nations snap up coronavirus vaccine stocks
summary: Rich nations, accounting for a fraction of the global population, have bought up over half of the promised Covid-19 vaccine stocks. US President Donald Trump pledged to begin inoculating Americans within weeks. The move has raised concerns about vaccine equity. The European Union will support multilateral bodies, such as the WHO, in their efforts to distribute vaccines more equitably. The global death toll from the virus has surpassed 940,000, with over 30 million infected.

site_title: Fed defends 'pedal to the metal' policy
summary: The US Federal Reserve has defended its aggressive monetary policy, stating it's not concerned about creating future asset bubbles. Despite slashing interest rates and launching unprecedented asset purchases, Fed Chair Jerome Powell said the decade-long US economic expansion lacked a financial bubble. The Fed will continue to purchase $120 billion in government bonds each month and won't raise interest rates until at least 2023, allowing some inflation to build.

site_title: Now is the time for China to win friends: Chan Chun Sing
summary: China has an opportunity to win friends by reaching out to the world post-pandemic, according to Singapore's Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing. He believes that China's benevolence and connection with the world can inspire other nations. Chan emphasized the importance of trade and cooperation between China and the US, despite their competition, and Singapore's role as a bridge between the two. He also stated that Singapore will need to constantly re-evaluate its business model in a post-pandemic world.

site_title: Finders, keepers? On Citi's US$900m error
summary: Citi has mistakenly paid out over $900 million to a group of lenders expecting an interest payment on behalf of Revlon Inc. The bank is suing 11 lenders who claim the money is part of Revlon's debt, while at least one lender has returned the funds. The case raises questions about whether courts follow the "finders, keepers" rule in cases of mistaken payments, and whether the lenders are entitled to keep the money despite knowing it was a mistake. The case is set for a November trial, and negotiations may lead to a settlement.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Figtree Holdings' wholly-owned subsidiary Figtree Real Estate is acquiring a 27.5% interest in DC Alliance for A$2.75 million, its first strategic investment in a data centre. DC Alliance owns a Tier III co-location data centre in Perth, Australia. Meanwhile, SLB Development has entered into a sale and purchase agreement to acquire Thye Hong Centre in Singapore for S$112.5 million. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times.

site_title: In Japan's foreign policy, Suga can counter chaos with pragmatism
summary: Japan's new Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga has taken office after Shinzo Abe's sudden resignation, marking the country's first new leader in nearly eight years. Suga's pragmatist approach is seen as a necessary counter to the chaos in the world, including the US-China confrontation and the COVID-19 pandemic. With his experience as Chief Cabinet Secretary, Suga is expected to prioritize the Japan-US relationship, maintain the Free and Open Indo-Pacific vision, and strengthen ties with countries like the UK and Australia. His focus on domestic policy includes administrative reform and digital transformation.

site_title: Snowflake raises US$3b in blockbuster IPO
summary: Snowflake, a cloud data warehouse startup, raised over US$3 billion in its IPO, with shares doubling and finishing at US$254. The company, valued at US$70 billion, has grown rapidly since its founding eight years ago, despite not being profitable. Revenue jumped to US$264.7 million last year, while net loss grew to US$348.5 million. Snowflake provides online data storage and management, leveraging data centers hosted by Amazon, Google, and Microsoft. The IPO is seen as validation of the growing demand for enterprise software.

site_title: As deadline looms, negotiators scramble on TikTok deal structure
summary: US and Chinese negotiators scramble to find a new ownership structure for TikTok by September 20, amid concerns of Chinese espionage. A deal with Silicon Valley-based Oracle as the US technology partner appears to be taking shape, with Oracle potentially hosting TikTok's data as a minority shareholder. However, US officials remain concerned about security and algorithm control, with some reports suggesting Oracle's deal may not fully address these concerns. A possible Beijing veto and potential ban in the US if no deal is reached looms large, while analysts say it's difficult to craft a deal that satisfies both countries.

site_title: Top Glove banks on product line diversity as glove sales continue rising
summary: Top Glove Corporation reported a 17-fold increase in net profit to RM1.29 billion for the fourth quarter of its fiscal year, driven by rising glove sales amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The company advises customers to switch to latex gloves due to a potential global shortage of high-quality non-latex gloves. Top Glove's diversified product mix is expected to help maintain its share of the disposable gloves market, with a proposed final dividend payout of 11.8 sen per share. The company plans to list in Hong Kong in six to nine months to expand its reach to a bigger market.

site_title: ADB invests US$95m in Clifford Capital to support sustainable infrastructure
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has invested US$95 million in Clifford Capital Holdings, a sustainable infrastructure financing company, to support growth in Asia. The partnership will focus on renewable energy sources such as solar and wind. The ADB will hold a 10.8% stake in the company once all equity capital is fully deployed by 2024.

site_title: London firms are dumping office space as workers stay home
summary: London firms are rapidly dumping office space due to the pandemic, with over 1 million square feet available for sublet since June, equivalent to two Gherkin skyscrapers. This trend is largely driven by employees working from home, with businesses offering excess space as a result. The city's second-hand space has surged 21% since June, compared to a 1% increase for the rest of the UK. This shift poses a threat to developers of new buildings, offering tenants a cheaper alternative.

site_title: Filming resumes on 'The Batman' movie after coronavirus shutdown
summary: Filming on Warner Bros' 'The Batman' movie has resumed in the UK after a two-week shutdown due to a coronavirus case on set. The person who tested positive was reportedly Robert Pattinson, although the studio didn't confirm or deny the information. The production had taken precautions to prevent the spread of the virus before resuming filming.

site_title: US dollar's gains from post-Fed meeting fizzle out
summary: The US dollar experienced a brief surge after the Federal Reserve left interest rates on hold, but its gains were largely erased as markets digested the policy statement. The dollar index rose 0.32% before falling nearly flat. The Fed pledged to keep rates near zero until at least the end of 2023, with some strategists arguing that any US dollar strength is likely to be temporary. The dollar's weakness helped stem selling pressure on other currencies, such as the euro and Australian dollar.

site_title: Covid-19 turmoil creates fresh openings for new startups
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has created opportunities for new startups to emerge, according to startup veterans and investors. Despite tougher funding, entrepreneurs can capitalize on permanent disruptions caused by the crisis. The founders of two Singapore startups that were set up during the 2008 Global Financial Crisis believe that turbulence can help startups refine their business strategy. This shift in perspective is seen as a positive development for the startup ecosystem.

site_title: Sydney's new suburbs are too hot for people to live in
summary: Sydney's western suburbs are being developed to accommodate nearly half of the city's expected population growth over the next 20 years, despite being plagued by extreme heat. The region's housing estates, industrial precinct, and airport are set to be built in areas with temperatures often reaching 80°C, posing health risks to residents. Experts warn that as global temperatures rise, some cities may become uninhabitable, and Sydney's approach may serve as a model for other cities facing similar challenges.

site_title: SGX to list world's largest Chinese government bond ETF
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) announced the listing of the world's largest Chinese government bond ETF, the ICBC CSOP FTSE Chinese Government Bond Index ETF, starting on September 21. The ETF, managed by CSOP Asset Management, has attracted US$676 million in assets under management and is priced at US$10 per share. The listing is seen as a low-cost and liquid avenue for global investors to access China's bond market, which is the second-largest in the world after the US. The ETF replicates the performance of fixed-rate government bonds issued in mainland China and is expected to attract significant inflows, potentially exceeding US$150 billion.

site_title: Electronics rebound will give lasting boost to Singapore exports: Analysts
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) grew 7.7% in August, surpassing forecast expectations. This marks the third straight month of growth, driven by a rebound in the electronics manufacturing industry. Analysts believe this trend will provide a lasting boost to Singapore's exports, positioning the country as a global hub for advanced chip packaging. The strong performance is seen as a positive development for the country's economy, with Temasek predicting that the "worst of the headwinds are now probably behind us".

images.alt_text: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) outshone market watchers' expectations in August, clocking year-on-year growth of 7.7 per cent.

site_title: UOB issues S$120m green loan for healthcare complex
summary: UOB has issued a S$120 million green loan to The Farrer Park Company, the first healthcare facility in Singapore to receive such a loan. The loan will support the company's efforts to ensure environmentally responsible operations and refinance its integrated healthcare and hospitality complex, Connexion. The facility has been certified a Green Mark Platinum building and aims to achieve at least 30% energy savings. The loan is issued under UOB's Real Estate Sustainable Finance Framework, which aims to encourage companies to consider green financing in their sustainability efforts.

site_title: Singapore shares end lower following Fed disappointment
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.17% lower at 2,500.78 after the US Federal Reserve announced it would keep interest rates low without further stimulus measures, causing global markets to decline. However, Singapore's S-Reits, such as Mapletree Commercial Trust, Ascendas Reit, and CapitaLand Commercial Trust, rose amid news of Chinese tech giants like Tencent and Alibaba investing in Singapore, as investors seek yield in a low-interest-rate environment.

site_title: Greed is good - except when it's bad
summary: Milton Friedman's 1970 essay "The Social Responsibility of Business Is to Increase Its Profits" revolutionized free market capitalism, influencing leaders like Ronald Reagan and Margaret Thatcher. The essay advocated for prioritizing shareholders and profits, shaping corporate priorities 50 years later. Friedman's ideas continue to hold sway over large parts of the corporate world, with his theories on the primacy of shareholders remaining influential.

site_title: GovTech licenses smart thermal scanner software to 3 SMEs and a non-profit body
summary: GovTech has licensed its smart thermal scanner software, SPOTON, to four Singapore-based distributors, including a non-profit organization, for mass temperature screening. The software, which can screen up to 10 people at a time, will be used in high-traffic venues such as malls and offices to minimize congestion. GovTech will provide the software for free and technical support, while the distributors will purchase hardware and provide after-sales support. The agency aims to meet public demand for an affordable and effective temperature screening solution.

site_title: When to stop working from home? How about never, workers say
summary: US workers prefer continuing to work from home at least a few days a week, citing a preference for the work-from-home lifestyle over returning to traditional office settings. This trend is becoming a significant topic of discussion in virtual workplaces as companies struggle to get employees to return to the office. Many employees have grown accustomed to the flexibility and comfort of working from home, and some are hesitant to give up the benefits it provides.

site_title: Mid-East pact a diplomatic win for Trump, but no electoral lift
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration has signed a Middle East peace agreement with the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain, marking a new power balance in the region. While hailed as a diplomatic win, the deal is unlikely to sway American voters in the upcoming presidential election. The agreement reflects a shift in regional politics, with Arab Sunni states prioritizing cooperation with Israel against a common enemy, Iran, over resolving the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. This new reality is expected to transform the Middle East in the coming years, regardless of Trump's and Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu's departure from office.

site_title: US homebuilder optimism is fuelled by low mortgage rates
summary: US homebuilder optimism reached a record 83 in September, driven by low mortgage rates, according to the National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo Market Index. This marks a 5-point increase from the previous month and the highest level in 35 years of the survey. The surge in builder sentiment has contributed to the pandemic economy, with low mortgage rates fueling a housing boom.

site_title: Meadows warns any TikTok 'repackaging' won't meet US goals
summary: US White House Chief of Staff Mark Meadows expressed concerns that Oracle's bid for TikTok may not meet President Donald Trump's national-security goals, as the deal could retain Chinese control over the company. Under the proposal, Oracle would acquire a minority stake and have access to TikTok's source code, but ByteDance would retain a majority of the company's assets. Trump has threatened to ban the app, citing national security concerns, and Meadows' comments suggest the deal's success is uncertain.

site_title: Will OUE Commercial Reit sell some of its assets?
summary: OUE Commercial Reit, a real estate investment trust sponsored by OUE, is open to selling some of its assets, including its 67.95% stake in One Raffles Place, valued at S$2,950 psf. The Riady family, behind OUE, is willing to consider offers for the Reit's assets, particularly OUE Downtown Office and Crowne Plaza Changi Airport. Potential buyers, including global property consulting groups, have expressed interest in the properties. The divestments may be driven by challenges from the Covid-19 pandemic, including low demand for hotel and office assets.

site_title: Caring for your mind and body
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

Wellness practitioners in Singapore are offering alternative self-care treatments, including head reflexology, scalp and hair treatment, and mental health coaching. Vesure Hair Therapy offers 45-minute head reflexology sessions for $58, while ThoughtFullChat provides daily bite-sized coaching to mental health professionals for $169 a month. Meanwhile, Pablo Blau's salt room offers a 45-minute facial for $89, and Virgin Active's Yoga for Every Body program combines Ayurveda and yoga to suit each individual's dosha. These treatments aim to promote relaxation, improve circulation, and address various health concerns, catering to the growing demand for holistic wellness in Singapore.

site_title: Will cybersecurity blunders hurt chances of digibank hopefuls?
summary: Singapore's digital banks face scrutiny over data privacy lapses, with Grab fined S$10,000 for compromising 21,500 drivers' and passengers' data and Razer exposing 100,000 customers' info. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has strengthened its regulatory regime, making cybersecurity practices legally binding for MAS licence holders. Experts warn that digital banks must meet higher security standards, as a data breach could have disastrous consequences, and that the "attack surface" is wider due to complex digital products. Digital bank aspirants must demonstrate their capabilities in building a secure platform to avoid denting their ambitions.

site_title: Kuroda says BOJ will work closely with Suga's government
summary: BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated the central bank will maintain close coordination with Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's government to pull Japan's pandemic-hit economy out of its slump. The BOJ will keep its key interest rate and asset purchases unchanged, aiming to achieve a 2% inflation target. Kuroda's comments aimed to reassure investors about the BOJ's easing policies and its relationship with the government.

images.alt_text: Mr Kuroda's comments indicate that little change is likely for now, unless the pandemic worsens or there is a run on the markets.

site_title: CEOs of bigger Singapore firms more optimistic now: KPMG
summary: Singapore CEOs are more optimistic about their firms' medium-term future and the economy, with nearly half less confident about global growth prospects and over half more confident about Singapore's prospects. A KPMG survey of 25 CEOs from firms with annual revenue over $500 million found that supply chain risk is the top concern, followed by a return to territorialism and talent risk. The survey also showed that CEOs expect their digital business models to accelerate, and many plan to downsize offices due to remote working.

site_title: Opec+ may hold extraordinary October meeting if oil market worsens
summary: Opec+ may hold an extraordinary meeting in October if oil markets worsen, according to Saudi Energy Minister Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman. The group, led by Russia, pressed for better compliance with oil output cuts as uncertainty over the global economic outlook persists. Despite rising Covid-19 cases, Opec+ maintained its current 7.7 million barrel-per-day production target. The group will also push laggards like Iraq, Nigeria, and the UAE to cut more barrels to compensate for overproduction.

site_title: Manhattan condo developer may face foreclosure on 4 projects
summary: Manhattan condo developer HFZ Capital Group, led by Ziel Feldman, may face foreclosure on four properties after years of struggling sales. A $89.5 million slice of junior mezzanine debt tied to the projects will be sold at a public auction on November 12. The four buildings, including The Astor and 88 Lexington Ave, carry a combined $258.6 million in debt. The sale could allow buyers to assume full ownership and potentially pay off senior lenders. Defaults and foreclosures are expected to increase as the pandemic slows purchases and debt becomes less available.

site_title: Wilmar shares rise on China unit's IPO nod
summary: Wilmar International's shares rose 1.16% on Thursday after its Chinese unit, Yihai Kerry Arawana (YKA), received final approval from the China Securities Regulatory Commission for an initial public offering (IPO). The listing is expected to take place by mid-October and could help "unlock value" for the company's assets in China. Analysts from CGS-CIMB maintain their "add" recommendation, citing the potential for the IPO to catalyze Wilmar's share price and boost its value.

site_title: F&B staff crunch returns along with business pickup
summary: The food and beverage (F&B) industry in Singapore is facing a manpower crunch as business activity picks up after the Covid-19 pandemic. Despite efforts to hire replacement staff, many establishments struggle to fill vacancies, particularly managerial positions, due to Singaporeans' reluctance to take up roles in the sector. Foreign workers, who were initially hired to fill gaps, are now facing tighter regulations and longer waiting times for work pass applications. Industry players are exploring alternative solutions, such as digitalization and automation, and are urging the government to provide more support and access to information on available jobs.

site_title: US Fed to keep interest rates near zero, with eye on inflation
summary: The US Federal Reserve announced it will keep interest rates near zero until inflation reaches the 2% target and exceeds it "moderately" for some time. The decision, made on the eve of the presidential election, aims to support economic activity and bring millions of Americans back to the labor market. The Fed expects the economy to shrink 3.7% this year, but sees unemployment falling to 7.6% by year's end. The decision drew two dissents, with some policymakers arguing the guidance went too far or not far enough in managing the economy.

site_title: From lemak to laut
summary: Lemak Boys, a new nasi lemak shop in Singapore, has drawn controversy over its "Peranakan" origins, but its food has won over critics. The restaurant offers traditional and modern Asian fare, including addictive sambal and light coconut milk-infused rice. Lemak Boys has received a 7/10 rating from The Business Times. In contrast, Laut, a meat-free bar with a thoughtful approach to food and aesthetics, has also received a 7/10 rating for its experimental dishes and unique flavors.

site_title: After 43 years, a noted New York wine sentinel stands down
summary: Joseph DeLissio, a 65-year-old New York wine sentinel, has retired after 43 years as wine director of The River Café. DeLissio, known as Joey D in the wine world, oversaw the restaurant's wine list, which has grown from 12 bottles in 1977 to over 800 choices. He played a significant role in shaping American wine culture and was a key figure in the rise of California wine. DeLissio's decision to retire comes during the pandemic, which has severely impacted the restaurant industry, and he says he is finally able to retire due to health care issues.

site_title: New sex assault allegation made against Trump
summary: A former model, Amy Dorris, has accused US President Donald Trump of groping and forcibly kissing her in 1997 at the US Open tennis tournament in New York. Dorris, 48, described the incident, claiming Trump shoved his tongue down her throat and touched her breasts and back without consent. This is the latest allegation against Trump, who has faced over a dozen claims of sexual misconduct. Trump's lawyers have denied the allegations, suggesting they may be politically motivated.

site_title: LVMH says no need to fast-track decision on Tiffany's lawsuit
summary: LVMH has asked a US court to reject Tiffany's request to fast-track its lawsuit over the troubled $16 billion acquisition. Tiffany is seeking to have a ruling before a Nov 24 deadline, but LVMH claims there is no need for expedited proceedings, citing a lack of reason from Tiffany. LVMH also accuses Tiffany of trying to avoid scrutiny of its management of the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: MetLife to buy Versant Health for US$1.68b
summary: MetLife has agreed to buy vision-care benefits company Versant Health for US$1.68 billion, with the deal expected to close in the fourth quarter of 2020. The acquisition will establish MetLife as the third largest vision insurer in the US, with the addition of Davis Vision and Superior Vision brands. Versant has over 33 million members in the US across its vision care plans. The deal is expected to enhance MetLife's managed vision care offerings.

site_title: Covid-19 putting the brakes on mobility? It's the opposite, really
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has surprisingly boosted mobility, rather than hindering it. The pandemic has led to increased adoption of digital payments, enhanced safety measures, and a push for climate-friendly transport modes. Ride-hailing services have seen a surge in demand, particularly among vulnerable groups such as the elderly and those with mobility constraints. Governments and businesses have also strengthened their commitment to safety, innovation, and environmental conservation, with initiatives like autonomous vehicle trials and electric vehicle adoption. As people continue to work from home and travel for essential services, average commuting distances have fallen, paving the way for a potential revival of micro-mobility.

site_title: Uber to seek partial sale of US$6.3b Didi stake
summary: Uber is seeking to sell part of its $6.3 billion stake in Didi Chuxing, a Chinese ride-hailing company, as it looks to raise cash and boost its share price. The sale is part of Uber's efforts to shed minority holdings and consolidate operations. SoftBank Group, a major shareholder in both companies, is in discussions with other investors to acquire a minority of Uber's 15% stake. The sale comes after Uber wrote down its Didi stake to $6.3 billion in the first quarter due to regulatory troubles and the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Firms not surprised by S$10b cut in forecast for construction demand
summary: Singapore's Building and Construction Authority (BCA) lowered its forecast for this year's construction demand by S$10 billion, from S$28 billion to S$33 billion to S$18 billion to S$23 billion. The reduction is attributed to a slow recovery in the sector since resuming operations, with some projects postponed to 2021. Experts expect the private sector to recover slower, but the lower demand may help alleviate a manpower shortage caused by border closures. They also anticipate an upswing in disputes as temporary relief moratoriums end, but hope for a more positive outlook in 2021.

site_title: US jobless claims resume drop in sign of gradual improvement
summary: US jobless claims decreased by 33,000 to 860,000 in the week ended Sept 12, signaling a gradual improvement in the labor market. Continuing claims fell by almost 1 million to 12.6 million. Economists had expected initial claims of 850,000 and continuing claims of 13 million. The decline marks a continuation of the trend seen in recent weeks, indicating a potential slowdown in the labor market recovery.

site_title: SLB Development to acquire Thye Hong Centre for S$112.5m
summary: SLB Development has entered into a sale and purchase agreement to acquire Thye Hong Centre, a six-storey industrial building, for S$112.5 million. The acquisition is part of the company's long-term growth strategy to expand its business through property redevelopment. The deal is expected to be completed on Dec 17, 2020, using long-term bank borrowings and internal funds. The land area is approximately 5,952 sq m, held on trust by the vendor for Thye Hong Properties. The acquisition aligns with the company's goal to redevelop the land for future use.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as labour market recovery slows
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened lower on Thursday due to high levels of weekly jobless claims and technology-related stocks. The Dow Jones fell 198.20 points, or 0.71%, to 27,834.18, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite dropped 38.63 and 254.42 points, respectively, at the opening bell. The decline was attributed to concerns about the labour market recovery slowing down.

site_title: BOE steps up talks on negative rates amid uncertain outlook
summary: The Bank of England has stepped up talks on implementing negative interest rates amid uncertainty in the economy. Despite maintaining key interest rates at 0.1% and asset purchases at £745 billion, policy makers acknowledged a risk of elevated unemployment and vowed to adjust monetary policy accordingly. The move comes as the UK economy shrinks for the second month, posing a fresh blow to Prime Minister Starmer. Officials will engage in structured discussions with the Prudential Regulation Authority later this year on implementing subzero rates.

site_title: SIA, Singtel among top 100 companies in Refinitiv's 2020 diversity index
summary: SINGAPORE Airlines (SIA) and Singapore Telecommunications (Singtel) have been recognized among the top 100 most diverse and inclusive organizations globally by Refinitiv's 2020 Diversity & Inclusion Index. SIA ranked 31st with an overall score of 73.25, while Singtel ranked 35th with an overall score of 73. The index showed a 53% increase in Apac region board diversity over the last five years, with Malaysia and Singapore seeing significant increases in board gender diversity.

site_title: Top Glove looks to list in Hong Kong after 'supernormal' pandemic demand
summary: Malaysia's Top Glove Corporation plans to list in Hong Kong within 6-9 months after "supernormal" demand for disposable gloves during the Covid-19 pandemic boosted its quarterly profit to a record 1.29 billion ringgit. The company's quarterly revenue rose 161% year-on-year, and it expects to continue delivering solid results in 2021. With demand remaining high, Top Glove estimates a 25% growth in sales volumes next year and plans to expand its capacity to produce 100 billion glove pieces per year.

site_title: Chinese HR company 51job gets US$5.3b takeover approach
summary: 51job, a Chinese human-resources company, received a US$5.3 billion takeover approach from DCP Capital Partners. The non-binding offer values the company at US$79.05 per share, a 16% increase from Wednesday's closing price. The American depositary receipts jumped to US$79.11. This comes after 51job's shares declined 20% this year. The offer is subject to due diligence and other conditions.

site_title: Two-thirds of Japan public support new PM Suga
summary: New Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's government is backed by 66.4% of the public, according to a Kyodo news agency poll. Suga, who took office on Wednesday, aims to contain the COVID-19 outbreak and revive the economy. A majority of respondents, 55.1%, want the lower house of parliament to dissolve for an election, potentially allowing Suga to solidify his power. Suga played down speculation of an early election, focusing on addressing the coronavirus outbreak and economic recovery.

images.alt_text: New Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's government was backed by 66.4 per cent of the public, Kyodo news agency said on Thursday, citing the results of its telephone poll conducted on the first two days of his administration.

site_title: Petronas pays US$700m in taxes to Sarawak
summary: Petronas, Malaysia's state energy firm, paid over US$700 million in sales tax to the state of Sarawak, settling a long-standing dispute. The payment comes after Petronas reported its first quarterly loss in nearly five years due to a coronavirus-related demand slump. The settlement could encourage other energy-rich states in Malaysia to demand similar payments, potentially hurting Petronas' finances. The payment is part of a larger settlement agreement reached earlier this year, and Petronas will make the remaining payment upon assessments by Sarawak authorities.

site_title: EU unveils conditions for gigantic recovery fund disbursements
summary: The European Union has unveiled guidelines for the disbursement of its recovery funds, worth hundreds of billions of euros, to EU member states. The funds will be used for digital infrastructure projects, low-carbon economy transition, and structural reforms. Governments must submit plans that include at least 37% of expenditure related to climate and 20% related to digital. If compliant, the funds can be disbursed in the second quarter of 2021, providing a boost to cash-strapped economies. The guidelines aim to ensure the funds are used effectively in supporting the EU's post-pandemic recovery.

site_title: US housing starts drop as multi-family home construction slumps
summary: US housing starts dropped 5.1% to 1.416 million units in August, after strong gains in the prior three months. The decline was largely due to a 22.7% slump in multi-family housing starts. However, single-family home construction increased 4.1% to 1.021 million units. The housing market remains supported by low interest rates and demand for suburban and low-density properties. Despite a strong labor market, unemployment has disproportionately affected low-wage workers, typically renters.

images.alt_text: US homebuilding fell in August after strong gains in the prior three months, but the housing market remains supported by record low interest rates and demand for properties in the suburbs and low-density areas as many people work from home.

site_title: Online shopping shift could hurt local brands more in Singapore amid Covid-19: STB and Visa study
summary: A recent study by the Singapore Tourism Board (STB) and Visa found that online shopping may disproportionately hurt local brands in Singapore amid the Covid-19 pandemic. For every S$100 spent on local brands, only S$2 was transacted online, compared to S$25 for the Singapore retail average. This suggests that local brands face a more challenging future as more people shift to online shopping.

site_title: Philippines package aids Covid-19 fight, but limited growth impact: economists
summary: The Philippines' second stimulus package, worth 140 billion pesos, aims to strengthen the government's Covid-19 efforts, but economists say it has limited economic impact. The package's total size is 4.1% of GDP, with forecasters expecting a 7.9% GDP contraction in 2020 and 7% growth in 2021. Reliefs for individuals and businesses may help revive domestic consumption, while gradual economic reopening is expected to aid recovery, with inflation retreating to 2.4% in August.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 18.21 points lower to 1,513.07 on Thursday, with volume reaching 7.494 billion lots worth RM6.184 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 768 to 376.

site_title: Opec+ presses for compliance with oil cuts
summary: Opec+ pressed for better compliance with oil output cuts amid falling crude prices and uncertain global economic outlook. The group's technical panel, led by Saudi Arabia and Russia, is unlikely to change its 7.7 million barrel per day output reduction target, citing rising Covid-19 cases as a potential energy demand curb. Despite initial indications of a decline in oil stocks, the panel warned of uncertain energy demand due to the ongoing pandemic. Opec+ aims to maintain its current output reduction target of 8% of global demand.

site_title: Singapore tops smart city index for second straight year
summary: Singapore has topped the 2020 Smart City Index for the second consecutive year, ranking 109 cities globally based on residents' perceptions of infrastructure and technology in five areas. The city scored high in health and safety, activities, and opportunities, but fared poorly in recycling services and online voting. IMD professor Arturo Bris noted that each city is unique, and Singapore's ranking doesn't provide a blueprint for other cities. The top 20 cities include Helsinki, Zurich, and Vancouver, with Taipei and Auckland also ranking in the top 20.

site_title: China has historical opportunity to win friends at a time of need: Chan Chun Sing
summary: China has a historic opportunity to win friends and influence globally by showcasing benevolent behavior, Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing said. He emphasized the importance of maintaining connections with the world, citing China's prosperous era during times of global trade and exchange. Chan also noted that Singapore, as a bridge between the US and China, is always looking for new areas of cooperation and welcomes other countries to trade on the Singapore platform, even if they are not physically present.

site_title: Covid-19 test kit launched by local company accelerates diagnosis
summary: Veredus Laboratories launched a Covid-19 test kit that accelerates diagnosis by reducing processing time from over two hours to 90 minutes. The kit uses polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing and can detect the virus directly from a sample, stabilizing viral RNA with a preservation buffer. The test kit has obtained provisional authorization from the Health Sciences Authority for hospitals and medical clinics, and a saliva testing kit is also available, requiring less medical personnel for swabbing. Both kits have achieved a 99% accuracy rate in detecting Covid-19.

site_title: 18 new Covid- 19 cases in S'pore, lowest daily figure in 6 months; Sim Lim Square among places visited by patients
summary: Singapore reported 18 new Covid-19 cases, the lowest daily figure in 6 months, with 15 cases residing in dormitories and 3 in the community. The cases include one asymptomatic community case detected through routine testing and two imported cases from France and India. The average number of community cases decreased from 2 to 1 in a week. With 71 patients discharged, 56,940 have recovered, and 42 remain hospitalized.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets fall at open on Fed warning
summary: Europe's stock markets plummeted at opening on Thursday, mirroring earlier sell-offs in Asia and the US, following a warning from the Federal Reserve about an uncertain outlook for the US economy. The FTSE 100, DAX 30, and CAC 40 indices dropped 1.1%, 1.5%, and 1.4% respectively. The sell-off was attributed to the Fed's warning, which raised concerns about the economic recovery.

site_title: Figtree to enter Australian data centre market with 27.5% stake in DC Alliance
summary: Figtree Holdings, a Catalist-listed company, is acquiring a 27.5% stake in DC Alliance for A$2.75 million, its first strategic investment in a data centre. DC Alliance owns Pier DC, a Tier III data centre in Perth, Australia, which has a capacity for 1,000 racks and up to eight MW of power. The deal positions Figtree for growth in Australia's data centre market, projected to reach A$6 billion by 2025, driven by cloud adoption and government policies.

site_title: Sunpower Group secures contract worth over 150m yuan from Sinopec
summary: Sunpower Group has secured a contract worth over 150 million yuan from Sinopec, a repeat customer. The contract involves manufacturing and supplying liquefied natural gas vaporisers for Sinopec's LNG receiving terminal in Shandong province. Sunpower will utilize its proprietary LNG regasification technology, with delivery expected to be completed by FY2021. The contract is expected to have a positive impact on the group's financial performance in FY2020 and FY2021.

site_title: Next joins Zara, H&M in recovery from Covid-19 lockdowns
summary: Next, a UK retailer, has raised its pre-tax profit forecast for the year to £300 million, joining Zara and H&M in reporting better-than-expected recoveries from Covid-19 lockdowns. This is Next's second profit upgrade since the pandemic, following a July increase after stores reopened. The company's previous worst-case scenario was a loss of £150 million.

site_title: ADB invests US$95m to support sustainable infrastructure development via Clifford Capital
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has invested $95 million in Clifford Capital Holdings (CCH) to support sustainable infrastructure development in Asia. The investment, comprising $50 million from ADB and $45 million from the Leading Asia's Private Infrastructure Fund, aims to unlock renewable energy sources such as solar and wind. ADB will hold a 10.8% stake in CCH and earn a board seat, with the partnership expected to spur growth in sustainable infrastructure financing in Asia.

site_title: Bank Indonesia holds rates as governor defends independence
summary: Bank Indonesia left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 4% for a second month, defying expectations of a 25 basis-point cut. Governor Perry Warjiyo defended the bank's independence amid proposals to change its mandate, stating that all policies aim to encourage growth and cooperate with the government for stability. The rupiah remains under pressure, down 6.6% against the dollar this year, and liquidity conditions remain ample, but monetary expansion is largely stuck in the banking sector. The central bank may consider rate cuts in coming months due to dimming growth outlook and subdued inflation.

site_title: John Lewis scraps bonus for first time since 1948
summary: John Lewis Partnership, a British employee-owned retail company, has announced it will not pay staff an annual bonus for the first time in over 70 years due to a significant loss of £55 million (S$96.6 million) in the first half of the year. The loss was largely driven by a 10% drop in sales at John Lewis, which was closed for three months during the Covid-19 pandemic. The decision not to pay the bonus, which was once as high as 24% of a worker's salary, is part of a turnaround plan led by Sharon White, the company's new CEO.

site_title: Emirates airline to produce kosher meals as Israel beckons
summary: Dubai-based Emirates airline plans to produce kosher meals in partnership with "Kosher Arabia" at a dedicated facility in the UAE, set to be operational by January 2021. The move comes after the UAE and Israel signed a normalization deal, with Emirates expected to start flying to Israel by the end of the year. The airline already offers kosher meals through an outsourced supplier, but the new facility will increase production capacity. The partnership is seen as a response to growing demand for kosher food in the region, particularly with the normalization of ties between the UAE and Israel.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close well down
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.56% on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 384.78 points to 24,340.85, amid concerns over the US economy's recovery. This follows a sell-off on Wall Street. The Shanghai Composite Index declined 0.41%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.08%. The losses were attributed to investor anxiety about the US economy's trajectory.

site_title: CEOs more confident about country, company prospects than global economy: KPMG poll
summary: A KPMG survey of 25 Singapore CEOs with annual revenue over US$500 million found that they are more confident in the medium-term future of their firms and the Singapore economy, despite a bleak global outlook. Nearly half are less confident about global growth prospects, while over half are more confident about Singapore's prospects and their own companies. The top risk cited by Singapore respondents is supply chain risk, followed by territorialism, talent risk, and reputational risk. The survey also showed that the COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated digital business models and led to changes in office space and talent acquisition.

site_title: Australia: Miners drag shares lower on weak iron ore prices; NZ dips on GDP jolt
summary: Australian shares fell 1.2% to close at 5,883.2, pressured by heavy losses in miners as iron ore prices tumbled for a third consecutive day. Iron ore futures dropped due to rising supply concerns and lower demand from China. New Zealand's benchmark index slipped 0.3% to 11,777.13, amid a record 12.2% quarter-on-quarter contraction in the economy. The US Federal Reserve maintained interest rates near zero, sparking concerns about the impact on young job seekers.

site_title: Gold drops as greenback rises on Fed's upbeat economic view
summary: US gold prices fell 0.8% to $1,943.70 per ounce as the US dollar rose after the Federal Reserve signaled a favorable economic recovery picture, but stopped short of offering further stimulus. The dollar index reached a one-week high, while silver, platinum, and palladium also declined. Investors were less inspired by the Fed's meeting, which suggested lower interest rates and quantitative easing would continue to support gold prices in the long term.

site_title: Biden warns UK on Brexit: No trade deal unless you respect North Irish peace deal
summary: US Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden warned the UK that a trade deal will be impossible unless the Northern Irish peace deal is respected. Biden stated that the Good Friday Agreement must be protected to prevent a hard border. UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson unveiled legislation that could break parts of the Brexit treaty, prompting EU concerns. Biden retweeted a letter from a US congressman calling on Johnson to uphold the 1998 peace deal, warning that Congress would not support a free trade agreement if Britain fails to respect its commitments.

images.alt_text: US Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden warned the United Kingdom that it must honour the Northern Irish peace deal as it extracts itself from the European Union or there would be no US trade deal.

site_title: Richard Branson joins blank-cheque frenzy with US$400m deal
summary: Richard Branson has joined the blank-cheque listing frenzy with a $400 million deal through VG Acquisition, a special purpose acquisition company. Branson sold Virgin Galactic Holdings and bought 11.5 million shares of VG Acquisition for $25,000. The company plans to list units on the New York stock exchange and target various businesses for a merger, including travel, financial services, and renewable energy. This deal follows a series of similar listings by other billionaires, including Chamath Palihapitiya and Bill Ackman, and is part of the growing trend of blank-cheque listings.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall on tech selloff, foreign profit-taking
summary: South Korean shares fell 1.22% on Thursday, dragged down by technology stocks and foreign profit-taking after the Kospi index hit a two-year closing high earlier in the week. The benchmark index closed at 2,406.17 points, down 29.75 points. Analysts attributed the decline to the US Federal Reserve's cautious stance on offering further liquidity, denting investor sentiment.

site_title: Firms to improve credit assessment as more consumers struggle with credit card bills
summary: About 7 out of 10 consumer-facing businesses in Singapore plan to improve their digital credit assessment capabilities due to rising consumer struggles with credit card bills. A survey by Experian found 23% of Singapore consumers face challenges paying credit card bills, up from 11% before the pandemic. To address this, businesses will enhance their digital credit assessment tools in the next 12 months.

site_title: Digital health firm Joint Academy raises US$23m in Kinnevik-led funding round
summary: Swedish digital health firm Joint Academy has raised $23 million in a funding round led by Kinnevik to expand internationally. The company, which connects patients with chronic joint pain to physical therapists, plans to use the funds to expand in Europe and the US. This round brings Joint Academy's total funding to $34.2 million since its 2014 founding. The company has connected 25,000 patients with licensed therapists through its app, and Kinnevik's CEO called Joint Academy an example of a digital healthcare initiative that can support traditional healthcare systems.

site_title: ECB gives banks reprieve from leverage rule to withstand pandemic
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) announced it will allow eurozone banks to exclude certain central bank exposures, including deposits, from the calculation of a key capital requirement until June. This move aims to help banks withstand the pandemic. The exclusion would raise the aggregate leverage ratio by about 0.3 percentage points, based on end-March 2020 data. The ECB's decision provides a reprieve to banks, allowing them to maintain their capital buffers.

site_title: CSOP to launch world's largest Chinese government bond ETF on SGX
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is set to launch the world's largest Chinese government bond ETF, the ICBC CSOP FTSE Chinese Government Bond Index ETF, managed by CSOP Asset Management. The ETF has attracted $676 million in initial assets under management and will start trading on September 21. It replicates the performance of fixed-rate government bonds issued in mainland China, as measured by the FTSE Chinese Government Bond Index. The fund was developed in partnership with ICBC Wealth Management and ICBC Asset Management (Global) as investment advisors.

site_title: World Bank's IFC warns of Asia-Pacific 'financial crisis'
summary: The World Bank's International Finance Corp (IFC) warns of a potential financial crisis in the Asia-Pacific region due to rising insolvencies caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Vice-President Alfonso Garcia Mora predicts a 30% increase in bankruptcies, citing the lack of regular monitoring of loan repayments by central banks as a major concern. This, he warns, is "very dangerous." The IFC's warning comes as many firms have been granted loan moratoriums, but central banks are not requiring financial institutions to assess their solvency.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: ADB invests US$95m in sustainable infrastructure via Clifford Capital, with a 10.8% pro forma shareholding by 2024. BCA cuts 2020 construction demand forecast to S$18-23 billion, down from S$28-33 billion. Singapore exports rose 7.7% in August, beating forecasts. The world's largest Chinese government bond ETF is set to launch on SGX. Singapore tops the smart city index for the second year, while SIA and Singtel rank among the top 100 companies in Refinitiv's 2020 diversity index. The STI closed 4.37 points lower at 2,500.78 following Fed disappointment.

images.alt_text: In its first investment in a local entity since setting up shop in Singapore earlier this year, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) will inject US$95 million into Clifford Capital Holdings (CCH), spurring growth in the Temasek-backed company - especially in the area of sustainable infrastructure financing in Asia

site_title: Marina Bay Sands hires law firm to probe US$1b in transfers: sources
summary: Marina Bay Sands, a casino in Singapore, has hired law firm Davinder Singh Chambers to investigate employee transfers of over US$1 billion in gamblers' money to third parties. The probe comes after a patron sued the casino, alleging that S$9.1 million was transferred without his knowledge. The casino has previously settled the lawsuit and maintained that no patron funds were transferred contrary to the client's intent. The investigation adds to scrutiny from the US Department of Justice and Singapore authorities, who are also looking into anti-money laundering procedures and third-party transfers.

site_title: STI slips 4.37 points to close at 2,500.78 on Thursday following Fed disappointment
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 4.37 points to close at 2,500.78 on Thursday, following the US Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates low without further stimulus measures. Despite this, Singapore stocks performed relatively well, with Wilmar International and Mapletree Commercial Trust rising 1.16% and 2.5% respectively. The rally was also driven by investments from Chinese technology giants in Singapore, and the ongoing hunt for yield in a low-interest-rate environment.

site_title: 'Last mile' dilemma may have been solved by a CEO in the Nordics
summary: A Nordic shopping mall operator, Citycon, may have solved the "last mile" delivery dilemma for online retailers by building a click-and-collect service, allowing consumers to shop online and pick up goods from a convenient location. CEO F Scott Ball believes this service will reduce delivery costs and give consumers another reason to visit shopping centers. While Citycon's plan is similar to efforts in the US and other countries, it faces the challenge of convincing multiple retailers to unite under one umbrella.

site_title: Top Glove Q4 net profit soars 1,646%, expects 'fresh highs' in FY21
summary: Top Glove Corporation reported record net profit of RM1.29 billion (S$423.8 million) for its Q4 2020, a 1,646% increase from the previous year. The company also saw a 162% increase in revenue to RM3.1 billion. Strong demand for gloves, driven by the Covid-19 pandemic, fueled the growth, with the company expecting "fresh highs" in FY21. Top Glove plans to invest RM8 billion in capital expenditure from FY21-26 to expand its capacity and meet growing global demand for gloves.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on US falls
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Thursday due to disheartening US high-tech share falls. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.67% and the Topix index 0.36%. The Bank of Japan's unchanged policy failed to support the market. This comes as investors were also influenced by US-EU trade talks and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: ByteDance is playing chicken with Trump on TikTok
summary: ByteDance, the parent company of TikTok, is set to maintain majority ownership after a deal with Oracle, despite the tech giant gaining full access to the app's codebase. Oracle's partners, including General Atlantic and KKR, will collectively hold a minority stake. The agreement, reportedly finalized, would grant Oracle significant control over TikTok's development but leaves ByteDance in charge.

site_title: Japan government contacted Toshiba shareholders before AGM: sources
summary: Japan's government contacted Toshiba Corp shareholders ahead of the annual meeting, inquiring about potential collaborations with other investors, according to sources. This move has raised questions about interference in governance, following calls for an investigation into uncounted votes at the July 31 shareholder meeting. The Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry (METI) representatives made at least three such calls to foreign shareholders.

site_title: China's biggest bank falls short in bid to replenish capital
summary: China's largest bank, Industrial & Commercial Bank of China (ICBC), fell short in its bid to raise $4.4 billion in dollar-denominated bonds, instead raising $2.9 billion.
