The bank's attempt was hindered by increased competition from Chinese dollar debt sales. ICBC's bond offering, the largest by a Chinese lender since 2017, aims to replenish capital amid the worst downturn in at least a decade. China's four biggest banks face a capital shortfall of $220 billion to meet global capital rules, with the gap expected to increase over the next few years.

site_title: BCA cuts 2020 forecast for projected construction demand by S$10b
summary: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) has cut its forecast for this year's projected construction demand in Singapore by S$10 billion to S$18 billion to S$23 billion. The revised forecast is attributed to a drop in private-sector construction demand and postponements of public sector projects due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite this, the BCA expects demand to recover to some extent from 2021, driven by public residential developments and infrastructure projects.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares start Thursday's session with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened Thursday with losses, falling 0.20% due to concerns over US stimulus talks. The Hang Sang Index dropped 49.22 points to 24,676.41. Shanghai and Shenzhen composite indices also declined 0.20% and 0.28%, respectively. The decline comes after the Federal Reserve head stressed the need for more cash to boost the struggling economy.

site_title: Thai Aug domestic car sales drop 12.1% y-o-y: industry federation
summary: Domestic car sales in Thailand dropped 12.1% year-over-year in August to 68,883 vehicles, marking a 15th consecutive month of decline due to the coronavirus outbreak. However, sales increased 16.1% from July, boosted by easing virus restrictions, a motor sales event, and new car model launches. This contrasts with a 24.8% decline in July. Thailand remains a significant vehicle production and export hub for top automobile manufacturers.

site_title: GovTech licenses smart thermal scanner software to SMEs, non-profit organisation
summary: GovTech has licensed its smart thermal scanner software, SPOTON, to four Singapore-based distributors for mass temperature screening, aiming to meet public demand for an affordable, accurate, and effective solution. The distributors, including a non-profit organization, will assemble and sell the scanners, with GovTech providing training and technical support. The software can screen up to 10 people at once and detect high temperatures and non-wearing face masks, with plans for a second version with advanced features expected in early 2021.

site_title: ByteDance rival Kuaishou aims to raise up to US$5b in Hong Kong IPO: sources
summary: Chinese online short video startup Kuaishou aims to raise up to $5 billion in a Hong Kong IPO, targeting a valuation of over $50 billion. The company, backed by Tencent Holdings, operates its eponymous app in China and overseas equivalents, with 430 million monthly active users. Kuaishou's IPO plans come as rival ByteDance faces US government concern over data security, and it would be a boost to Hong Kong's status as a global capital markets centre.

site_title: Urban farming startup Infarm reaps US$170m in funding
summary: Infarm, a Berlin-based urban farming startup, raised US$170 million in its Series C funding round, led by LGT Lightstone. The investment will expand the company's network under cultivation by 10 times in Europe, North America, and Asia over the next five years. Infarm aims to turn a profit by 2023 and plans to increase its area under cultivation to five million square feet by 2025. The company, which uses cloud-computing to manage indoor farming, has already struck supply deals with major food retailers.

site_title: UOB issues S$120m green loan to The Farrer Park Company to refinance integrated complex
summary: UOB has issued a S$120 million green loan to The Farrer Park Company to refinance its integrated healthcare and hospitality complex, Connexion. This is the first green loan for a healthcare facility in Singapore. The loan supports the company's environmental responsibility and will help Connexion meet its Green Mark Platinum certification requirements, including achieving at least 30% energy savings. The loan is a significant step towards sustainable financing in Singapore's healthcare sector.

site_title: Australia's unemployment rate unexpectedly declines to 6.8%
summary: Australia's unemployment rate unexpectedly dropped to 6.8% in August, after a 22-year high of 7.5% in the previous month. Employment surged by 111,000, exceeding economists' predictions of a 50,000 decline. This unexpected jump led to a decrease in the unemployment rate, despite an increase in part-time work. The data contradicts previous expectations and may indicate a shift in the labor market.

site_title: Snowflake raises US$3b in blockbuster IPO
summary: Snowflake, a cloud data warehouse startup, raised over US$3 billion in its IPO, with shares doubling in value, finishing the day at nearly US$254. The company, founded eight years ago, grew quickly, reaching a valuation of over US$70 billion despite not being profitable. Snowflake's revenue jumped to US$264.7 million last year, with over 3,100 customers, including major brands like Adobe and Sony. The IPO's success could bode well for other tech startups planning to go public.

site_title: Bank of Japan holds fire, sees economic gloom lifting slightly
summary: The Bank of Japan maintained its monetary policy steady, keeping the short-term interest rate target at -0.1% and capping 10-year government bond yields around zero. The central bank slightly upgraded its view on the economy, suggesting no immediate expansion of stimulus is needed to combat the coronavirus pandemic. Markets are now focusing on the potential collaboration between the BOJ and new Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga to support the economy. The decision marks a slight shift in the bank's stance, as it previously indicated no expansion of stimulus was needed.

site_title: StarHub unit bags RM270m sustainability-linked loan from CIMB
summary: StarHub subsidiary MALAREN International secured a RM270 million (S$88.7 million) sustainability-linked term loan from CIMB Bank. The loan's interest is linked to achieving CDP Climate Change Scores between FY21-23, with interest savings available if targets are met. This is StarHub's first sustainability-linked loan, and CIMB's first in Malaysia and Singapore. The agreement aims to proactively drive a sustainable business and enhance company performance.

site_title: Asia: Stocks slip as Federal Reserve warns of 'uncertain' outlook
summary: Asian markets declined on Thursday following a negative US market lead after Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell expressed concerns about the US economy's uncertain outlook and called for additional stimulus. Despite low interest rates, lawmakers remain divided on a new fiscal package. The news contradicts President Trump's claim of a potential vaccine being available as early as next month. Markets in Singapore and Europe saw gains, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq in the US reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall as mining, tech sell-off offsets Federal Reserve stance
summary: Australian shares fell 0.5% to 5,924.5, driven by a decline in mining and tech stocks, despite the Federal Reserve's low-rate stance. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite ended in the red, with tech sector leading the decline. Local tech shares, including Afterpay and Computershare, dropped 2-3%. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.5% as investors shrugged off dire economic data.

site_title: Genetic-sequencing firm Illumina nears deal to buy healthcare startup Grail: sources
summary: Genetic sequencing firm Illumina is in talks to acquire cancer-detection startup Grail for over $8 billion, according to sources. This deal would be Illumina's largest acquisition and would put the company in direct competition with its customers. Grail, which had a valuation of $6 billion, raised over $1.9 billion from its previous fundraisings. The acquisition could be announced as early as this week, but no final decision has been made.

site_title: Australian regulator dares Facebook to block news content
summary: Australia's top antitrust regulator, Rod Sims, has warned Facebook that if it stops Australians from sharing news content, the company will be "weakened" and users will seek news elsewhere. Facebook has threatened to block news sharing in Australia if the proposed law becomes law, which would force the company to pay local media outlets for content. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) is negotiating with Facebook before making a formal recommendation to the government. The proposal aims to address a market power imbalance and ensure the future of Australian society, with Sims stating that a competitive market wouldn't require such a measure.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Thursday's open after upbeat exports data; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.2% at Thursday's open, driven by upbeat non-oil domestic exports data, which grew 7.7% in August, exceeding analyst forecasts. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 4.42 points to 2,509.57, with Sembcorp Marine and Wilmar International being among the most active stocks. Meanwhile, Singapore banks recorded losses due to wage freezes, and Wall Street stocks finished lower, while Tokyo stocks opened lower due to falls on Wall Street.

site_title: Amazon cranks up its music service with podcasts
summary: Amazon has added podcasts to its music streaming service, competing with Spotify and Apple. The service, available in the US, UK, Germany, and Japan, includes popular podcasts like RadioLab and original shows from notable figures such as DJ Khaled and Will Smith. The move follows a trend of podcast growth, with 37% of US adults listening to podcasts in the past month, according to Statista. The addition is seen as a way for Amazon to enhance its music and entertainment offerings, with a focus on convenience and original content.

site_title: Hot stock: Wilmar shares surge after China unit gets IPO nod
summary: Wilmar International shares surged 2.1% on Thursday after its Chinese unit, Yihai Kerry Arawana, received final approval for an initial public offering (IPO) on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange's ChiNext Board. The listing is expected to take place by mid-October, and analysts believe it could catalyze Wilmar's share price and unlock value for its Chinese assets, which make up 60% of its earnings. The IPO pricing will be based on investor demand and YKA's 2019 recurring earnings.

site_title: Asian airlines turn to 'flights to nowhere' to get travellers back in the skies
summary: Asian airlines, including Qantas, EVA Airways, and ANA Holdings, are offering "flights to nowhere" to attract travelers and generate revenue amidst the COVID-19 pandemic. These scenic flights take off and land at the same airport, often with unique experiences and themes. Tickets for these flights have sold out quickly, with prices ranging from $228 to $3,787. The concept is not new, but has gained popularity as a way for airlines to stay afloat and keep pilots' licenses current.

site_title: Reserve Bank of Australia policy measures working as expected: official
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) says its monetary stimulus measures are working as expected, with interest rates lowered to a record low and credit supply improved. The RBA's policy measures, including an "unlimited" government bond buying program and a cheap funding facility for banks, have helped lower interest rates for borrowers to historic lows. Housing loan applications have increased, but lending to small and medium-sized businesses has remained little changed due to uncertainty and caution from banks. The RBA's data collection project has provided early insights into the effectiveness of its policies.

site_title: Chip group to warn Trump administration against blacklisting China's SMIC
summary: US chipmakers and suppliers, represented by the SEMI industry group, plan to warn the Trump administration against blacklisting China's SMIC, citing it would harm US industry and national security. The move would make it harder for US companies to supply SMIC, which accounts for $5 billion in annual US origin equipment sales. The Commerce Department has not commented on the proposal, which comes amid scrutiny of SMIC's relationship to the Chinese military.

site_title: Japan's reappointed finance minister Aso says will prod regional banks to pursue reforms
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso has vowed to encourage regional banks to pursue reforms to survive headwinds, including a dwindling population. Aso stated that mergers and reducing the number of banks are options, but not the only solutions. Japan's regional banks face eroded profits due to ultra-low interest rates and a declining local population, with increasing credit costs expected amid the pandemic. Aso's reappointment follows Yoshihide Suga's cabinet changes, which retained about half of Shinzo Abe's lineup.

images.alt_text: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso said on Wednesday he will encourage regional banks to push through reforms to survive headwinds such as a dwindling population.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Wilmar, Singtel, SGX, Mapletree Commercial Trust, Dyna-Mac, Keppel
summary: Wilmar International's Chinese unit has received final registration approval for a Shenzhen Stock Exchange listing. Singtel, Singapore Exchange, and Mapletree Commercial Trust emerged in the top three of the newly launched Singapore Board Diversity Index. Dyna-Mac Holdings entered into a five-year MoU with Keppel Shipyard to explore business opportunities. LHN will buy a property for S$18.1 million, while Secura Group secured a S$10.7 million security contract. LCT Holdings is set to be taken private by its co-founder for S$21 million.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.11 points, or 0.20%, to 1,534.39, as shares opened higher on Thursday. The market saw 366.40 million lots traded worth RM190.07 million, with gainers beating losers 331 to 81. This follows a broader regional market trend, where Singapore's STI increased 0.4% and the US markets edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: New Zealand economy shrinks record 12%, enters recession
summary: New Zealand's economy has contracted by a record 12% in the June quarter, confirming a Covid-19-induced recession. The decline, the largest on record, occurred during a strict lockdown from late March to late May. The data also marks the first time New Zealand has entered a recession. Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern heads into the general election amidst the economic downturn.

site_title: UK's Johnson says he has 'every hope' of avoiding no-deal with EU
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson expressed confidence that Britain and the EU will avoid a "no-deal" Brexit at the end of the year, despite talks being deadlocked. He defended his government's new legislation that would break international law, which has sparked criticism from EU officials and some UK MPs. The UK Internal Market Bill, which would override parts of the Brexit treaty, has put trade talks with the EU at risk. Johnson has vowed to implement the bill, despite warnings from US Democrats and former UK prime ministers that it could damage Britain's global reputation.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality Trust issues demand to some master lessees to pay rent or vacate
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) has issued "pay/perform or quit" statutory notices to its master lessees in US states requiring them to pay outstanding rent and/or perform defaulted non-rent obligations within 3-15 days. If not met, the master lessees must vacate the property and surrender it. This move aims to address the financial difficulties faced by EHT due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The trust is seeking to recover its outstanding rent and maintain control over its properties.

site_title: UK government reaches deal with Conservative rebels
summary: The UK government has reached a deal with Conservative rebels to avert a rebellion over the Internal Market Bill, which would break international law. The bill, aimed at ensuring the UK's four constituent nations can trade freely, has been heavily criticized by some within the party. A compromise was reached, giving lawmakers a veto on using the bill's most controversial powers, and Justice Secretary Robert Buckland said the government will be able to get the legislation through with its big majority.

images.alt_text: Justice Secretary Robert Buckland (above) says he has been involved in some of the conversations with leading party rebel Bob Neill.

site_title: Federal Reserve says outlook uncertain, stimulus 'essential'
summary: The Federal Reserve has pledged to continue boosting the US economy with low interest rates to aid in the recovery from the pandemic, citing an uncertain outlook and the need for additional government stimulus. Fed Chair Jerome Powell stated that the initial government stimulus was "essential" but more aid will likely be needed, particularly for the 11 million people still out of work. The Fed aims to keep interest rates low until maximum employment is achieved, allowing inflation to rise above 2%.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday, tracking falls on Wall Street. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.20% to 23,428.56, while the Topix index slipped 0.07% to 1,643.16. The move follows a day after Japan's parliament elected Yoshihide Suga as the country's new prime minister.

site_title: ING-led banks win access to Citi accounts linked to failed Agritrade
summary: A Singapore court ordered Citigroup and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group to share account details linked to failed commodities firm Agritrade International. The 15 banks, led by ING, aim to recover funds allegedly lost due to alleged fraud. Agritrade's collapse is linked to US$1 billion exposure and a US$3.5 billion debt from Hin Leong Trading's collapse. The banks will use the shared information only for legal proceedings, with the goal of tracing, locating, and recovering funds. Agritrade's judicial manager has filed an application to wind down the firm.

site_title: Trump says no TikTok deal yet amid security concerns
summary: US President Donald Trump stated he is not ready to approve a deal for an American company to partner with Chinese-owned TikTok, citing security concerns. Trump previously mentioned Oracle was "very close" to agreeing to become TikTok's trusted technology provider, but no such deal has been reached. Trump will meet with officials on Thursday to discuss the issue, which has been a major point of contention for Washington regarding national security threats.

site_title: PropNex Realty to roll out S$7.3m career enhancement package for agents
summary: PropNex Realty, a subsidiary of PropNex Limited, will roll out a S$7.3 million career enhancement package to equip its 8,700 sales agents with skills to perform in the new norms of the real estate industry. The package includes digital transformation tools, training subsidies, and support for agents' expenses. PropNex also announced a partnership with Mediacorp and 99.co to hold a virtual Singapore Property Show 2020, featuring 20 new launch projects and digital tours. The initiative aims to help agents adapt to the post-pandemic real estate landscape.

site_title: Huawei phone prices rise in China on fears of chip shortage
summary: Chinese consumers are buying Huawei smartphones at higher prices due to concerns about the company's access to US technology, potentially cutting off production of premium handsets. Prices have risen by 400-500 yuan (around $57-$71 USD) for new and used Huawei phones, with the Porsche design model of Huawei's Mate 30 increasing from 10,000 yuan to 14,000 yuan. This surge in demand is driven by fears of a potential chip shortage and Huawei's reliance on US technology.

images.alt_text: Chinese consumers are rushing to buy smartphones from Huawei Technologies featuring its high-end Kirin chips, fearing curbs on the firm's access to US technology will soon cut off production of its premium handsets.

site_title: Oil up more than 4% as US stockpiles fall, hurricane hits output
summary: Oil prices surged over 4% on Wednesday, driven by a drawdown in US crude and petrol inventories and Hurricane Sally's impact on US offshore production. US crude stocks fell to 496 million barrels, their lowest since April, while petrol stocks dropped 400,000 barrels. The storm forced the shutdown of roughly 500,000 barrels per day of offshore oil production. Brent crude settled at $42.22 a barrel, up $1.69 or 4.2%. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and International Energy Agency also cut their demand outlooks, which may limit further output curbs.

site_title: US: Stocks end mostly lower as Federal Reserve pledges to keep rates low
summary: US stocks ended mostly lower on Wednesday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index falling 0.5% and 1.2% respectively. The Federal Reserve kept interest rates low and offered a cautious outlook on the economy, with Fed Chair Jerome Powell stressing the need for more stimulus from Washington. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.1% to close at 28,032.38. Despite mixed economic data, FedEx and Snowflake saw significant gains after reporting better-than-expected profits.

site_title: Singapore exports rise by 7.7% in August as electronics recover from year-ago low base
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) rose 7.7% in August, beating forecasts of a 3.3% expansion, driven by growth in electronics and non-electronics shipments. Electronics exports expanded 5.7% year-over-year, fueled by a 7.1% increase in integrated circuits, while non-electronics NODX grew 8.3%. The increase was partly due to a low base effect and strong shipments of non-monetary gold, which surged 55.1% year-over-year. Exports to top markets, including China, the EU, and the US, were expansionary, despite declines in exports to some key destinations.

site_title: Bank of England gears up for next stimulus push
summary: The Bank of England is expected to signal its readiness to pump more stimulus into the UK economy, amid a jump in unemployment and a possible Brexit shock. The BoE has already cut interest rates to a record low and ramped up its bond-buying program, and may consider expanding its bond-buying further. Investors expect a signal of intent to do more, rather than a concrete plan, at the end of its September meeting. The UK economy has suffered a 20% contraction and monthly output is 12% below pre-Covid levels, with trade talks with the EU at risk of collapse.

site_title: Covid-19 cuts marine refuel demand, driving consolidation among bunker suppliers: IBIA
summary: Global marine fuel demand is expected to fall by 7-17% in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic, leading to consolidation among bunker suppliers. Low demand, low margins, and increased counter-party risk are among the challenges faced by the industry. Singapore, the world's top bunkering hub, has seen year-on-year growth in marine fuel sales, while other hubs like Fujairah have experienced a significant drop in demand. Industry experts predict further consolidation through mergers and acquisitions or attrition, with some firms potentially forced to quit the market.

site_title: Fires continue to rage in US as smoke reaches Europe
summary: Devastating wildfires in the US West Coast continue to rage, with 79 large fires burning across the country. The blazes, which began in mid-August, have spread smoke across the US and even reached Europe, with thick smoke visible over 8,000km away. California has registered some of the worst air quality in the world, with over 17,000 firefighters battling 25 major blazes. The disaster has exacerbated the issue of global warming, with climate experts linking the intense blazes to rising temperatures and droughts. The economic impact is expected to be staggering, with estimated damages of over $20 billion.

site_title: Lightspeed swoops in on bright spots in S-E Asian startups
summary: US-headquartered venture firm Lightspeed Venture Partners has launched its Singapore office, expanding its South-east Asian operations. The firm, which recently raised US$4 billion in fresh capital, is bullish on South-east Asian startups that can fill "infrastructure gaps" amid the Covid-19 outbreak. Lightspeed has backed several South-east Asian startups, including Grab, Chilibeli, and NextBillion.ai, and plans to deploy its capital globally, including in the region. The firm's Singapore office houses its South-east Asian operations and is poised to support local startups in the coming months.

site_title: Barclays to launch FX trading and pricing engine in Singapore
summary: Barclays is set to launch its FX trading and pricing engine in Singapore in mid-2021, its fourth electronic FX trading hub globally. The move aims to strengthen the bank's FX presence in the Asia-Pacific, following existing hubs in New York, London, and Tokyo. The engine will provide increased price discovery, lower latency, and improved quality of execution for local and regional market participants, with the technology for one-month non-deliverable forwards (NDFs) offering more accurate prices at higher speeds. This is part of Singapore's efforts to become the top FX trading centre in the Asia-Pacific.

site_title: Temasek's enhanced stake may fortify minority shareholders' faith in Sembmarine
summary: Temasek's enhanced stake in Sembcorp Marine (SMM) may boost minority shareholders' confidence, following the company's 5-for-1 rights issue at a discounted price. SMM's shares have fallen 45% since the announcement, but Temasek's 5.35 billion shares, equivalent to a 42.6% stake, could influence the share price. A merger between SMM and Keppel Corp's O&M arm is speculated, but the companies have not confirmed it. Temasek's control and potential strategic moves may benefit most minority investors, and minority shareholders who participated in the discounted rights issue may be better off than those who did not.

site_title: US seeks to recover US$300m more in 1MBD assets held in Britain
summary: The US Department of Justice is seeking to recover an additional $300 million in assets allegedly linked to the 1MDB scandal, tracing it to an escrow account in the UK. The assets, valued at $4.5 billion, were stolen from the Malaysian fund through a global scheme involving high-level officials, including former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak. The US has already recovered or assisted in recovering nearly $1.1 billion in assets, bringing the total value of assets sought to $2.1 billion. The assets include movie posters and a line of credit from Venezuela's state oil company to Saudi's PetroSaudi Oil Services.

site_title: Sony PlayStation 5 console to launch in November
summary: Sony's PlayStation 5 console will launch in November, with two versions available: a premium model priced at US$500 and a digital edition priced at US$400. The consoles will be released on November 12 in select countries and a week later in the rest of the world. Microsoft's Xbox Series X, launching on November 10, will also compete in the market, with a similar price point. The launch coincides with a surge in video game spending during the pandemic, with US$3.3 billion spent on gaming hardware in August alone.

site_title: Jack Ma's Ant Group wants tech analysts to help cover its stock
summary: Ant Group, backed by Jack Ma, has asked at least seven brokerages to provide research coverage of its stock ahead of a potential IPO, which could be the world's largest. The request was made verbally by Ant's investor relations division, targeting Chinese and international securities firms. This move aims to build anticipation and gather market feedback before the IPO. The exact timing of the IPO has not been announced, but the company is racing to make it happen.

site_title: US churches going digital boosts NZ's Pushpay
summary: US churches shifting online during the coronavirus pandemic has boosted New Zealand's Pushpay Holdings, a digital payment platform, 96% this year, making it the top performer on the S&P/NZX 50 Gross Index. The company facilitates cashless donations and live-streamed sermons, attracting more engagement and donations. With a focus on US churches, Pushpay aims to reach 50% of churches with at least 200 average weekly attendees, potentially reaching annual revenue of over $1 billion.

site_title: Firms need data, tech capabilities to emerge stronger from Covid-19 crisis
summary: Singaporean businesses need to leverage technology and data to emerge stronger from the Covid-19 crisis, according to a panel discussion at the DBS Digital Day event. Minister for Communications and Information S. Iswaran emphasized the importance of data aggregation and analysis, while Amazon Web Services' Conor McNamara highlighted the need for resilient technology platforms and data analytics. The government is also providing support for businesses to capitalize on Singapore's digital economy, including initiatives such as the National Innovation Challenges and the SMEs Go Digital programme.

site_title: LCT Holdings co-founder seeks to take it private in S$21m deal
summary: LCT Holdings co-founder Dr. Du Junhong has offered to take the property investment company private in a deal valued at S$21 million, valuing the company at S$0.60 per share. The offer, made through investment vehicle Superior Partners Limited, has been accepted by the company's co-founders, who hold a 27.65% interest. The move aims to give the company greater control and flexibility in an uncertain economic environment, with no immediate plans for major changes or restructuring.

site_title: Brazil central bank maintains key interest rate at 2%
summary: Brazil's central bank maintained its benchmark interest rate at 2% for the ninth consecutive month, amid uncertainty over the coronavirus pandemic. The decision marks a record low and is expected to remain at 2% until the end of the year. Despite a forecast of 1.94% inflation for the year, the bank cited concerns over the economy's growth rate and an expected increase in inflation in the short term. The decision also follows a surge in food prices, including rice and black beans, due to a depreciation of the Brazilian real against the US dollar.

images.alt_text: Brazil's central bank maintained its benchmark interest rate Wednesday at two per cent, a record low, highlighting its "caution" in the face of uncertainty related to the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: The Hut Group shares jump in London debut
summary: The Hut Group's shares jumped over 30% in its London debut, raising £1.88 billion in a £5.4 billion valuation. The company, which operates retail brands, sold 376 million shares to raise funds despite concerns over corporate governance. Founder Matthew Moulding will remain chairman and CEO, holding superior voting powers. Despite this, investors and some analysts welcomed the deal, citing a strong IPO environment. Major investors, including BlackRock and the Qatar Investment Authority, also participated in the deal, which is seen as a boost to the UK's IPO market.

site_title: Japan's new PM Yoshihide Suga targets structural reform
summary: Japan's new Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga is focusing on structural reform as his key strategy to reshape economic policy, despite doubts from economists about the effectiveness of monetary policies. Suga aims to modernize bureaucracy, tackle regulatory issues, and improve administrative efficiency, similar to his predecessor Shinzo Abe's "Abenomics" plan. He has already announced plans to reduce mobile phone fees and has appointed experienced officials to key economic posts, but the extent of his reform efforts remains unclear, and his approach may be seen as too micro-oriented.

site_title: TPG nears deal for student housing: sources
summary: TPG Capital is in advanced talks to acquire a student housing portfolio from Preferred Apartment Communities for approximately US$480 million. The eight properties serve schools including Florida State University, Baylor University, and Arizona State University. The deal comes as the pandemic forces universities to adapt, with schools reopening in "some fashion" for the fall semester. Preferred Apartment's shares spiked 7.2% before paring gains amid the talks, while TPG declined to comment on the transaction. The deal is not final and could still fall apart.

site_title: Spotify steps up antitrust war over Apple One bundling
summary: Spotify is urging EU competition authorities to investigate Apple's One bundled subscription services, claiming they disadvantage competitors and favor Apple's own services. Spotify states that Apple's practices will cause irreparable harm to the developer community and threaten consumer freedoms. This move marks Spotify's escalation of antitrust criticisms of Apple, highlighting concerns over the tech giant's dominant position and unfair business practices.

images.alt_text: Sweden's global number one music streamer Spotify is urging EU competition authorities to probe Apple's One bundled subscription services as it steps up its antitrust criticisms of the US tech titan.

site_title: Singtel, SGX, MCT lead new index on board diversity
summary: The Singapore Board Diversity Index, launched by Willis Towers Watson, ranks primary-listed companies on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on the basis of corporate board diversity. 704 companies were assessed and scored in eight areas, with Singtel emerging in first place with a score of 31.25, followed by SGX and Mapletree Commercial Trust. The index aims to push for greater diversity in companies as asset managers like BlackRock and State Street Global Advisors have taken steps to vote against companies without diverse boards. The launch of the index comes ahead of the SGX's one-third independent director requirement by January 1, 2022.

images.alt_text: Singtel, the Singapore Exchange (SGX) and Mapletree Commercial Trust have emerged in the overall top three places in a newly launched Singapore Board Diversity Index.

site_title: STI climbs 0.78% to 2,505.15 ahead of US Fed policy meeting
summary: Singapore stocks ended 0.78% higher at 2,505.15 ahead of the US Fed policy meeting. Sembcorp Industries led the gain with an 8.9% rise to S$1.34. ComfortDelgro and Wilmar International also rose, while DBS, OCBC, and UOB fell. Shinvest Holding jumped 21.38% to S$3.35 after announcing the proposed disposal of its stake in a Chinese company. The Straits Times Index finished close to its intra-day high of 2,508.16.

site_title: India's Times speeds up push into digital services
summary: Times Group, publisher of India's largest English-language newspaper, is accelerating its push into technology services to boost revenue. The company aims to reach $1 billion in revenue from digital services by 2025. Times Internet, its digital arm, owns popular news websites and fintech firms, and is exploring a potential 10% stake sale. The goal is to leverage the shift from traditional print media to online platforms, with a focus on deeper audience engagement.

site_title: Facebook plans Ray-Ban smart glasses as it eyes AR
summary: Facebook plans to launch Ray-Ban smart glasses, a move into wearable tech, in partnership with EssilorLuxottica. The glasses, set to debut next year, will connect to smartphones and represent an early step towards creating augmented reality glasses. According to CEO Mark Zuckerberg, the glasses will be a key step towards augmented reality, with the ultimate goal of creating futuristic eyewear that enhances real-world views.

site_title: Europe: Retail rally helps stocks rise
summary: European stocks rose 0.6% as retail stocks surged after Inditex's strong results, despite a stronger pound hitting Britain's FTSE 100. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index gained for the fourth straight session, while Spain's Inditex shares jumped 8.1% and the broader retail sector rose 1.3%. Other notable gains included The Hut Group's 25% surge and Deutsche Post AG's 1.9% rise, driven by strong earnings from FedEx Corp.

images.alt_text: Retail stocks surged after strong results from Zara-owner Inditex on Wednesday, but it was a mixed session for the wider European market, with Britain's exporter-heavy FTSE 100 hit by a stronger pound.

site_title: America's K-shaped recovery to worsen jobs inequity in real estate
summary: The US economic recovery is experiencing a "K-shaped" recovery, where high-paid workers have fared better than low-wage counterparts. The pandemic has exacerbated income, racial, and gender disparities, with industries like finance and real estate recovering faster and paying more. The leisure and hospitality industry, which employs one in nine people, has struggled to recover, leading to a slowdown in consumer spending and a rise in foreclosures. The real estate market has surged, but this has not helped low-income Americans, who are struggling to afford housing and mortgage payments.

site_title: Air New Zealand plans to cut up to 385 more cabin crew jobs
summary: Air New Zealand plans to cut up to 385 more cabin crew jobs due to reduced demand on North American routes, bringing the airline's total Covid-19 related job losses to around 37% of its workforce. The airline aims to reduce its widebody cabin crew by 385, following previous job cuts of 4,000. The cuts are proposed to be carried out by December, with redundancies as the last resort, and are in consultation with unions.

site_title: Lufthansa CEO prepares staff for deeper job and fleet cuts
summary: Lufthansa CEO Carsten Spohr is preparing staff for deeper job and fleet cuts, exceeding the existing plan of 100 jets and 22,000 full-time positions. The airline, which accepted a 9 billion-euro bailout, now expects a recovery of air traffic until the middle of the decade. Seat reservations are at less than 10% of year-ago levels, and Lufthansa plans to focus on customers and sustainability, with a goal of offering 25% of year-ago seats. The company may borrow money to repay government loans and could consider leasing or buying new aircraft, including the Boeing 777X.

site_title: Thailand plans 51.6b baht of cash handouts to boost consumption
summary: Thailand plans to distribute 51.6 billion baht in cash handouts to boost domestic consumption and support its economy, which contracted in the second quarter due to the coronavirus pandemic. The plan will provide 1,500 baht to 14 million low-income earners and 30 billion baht to 10 million people to buy goods in the final quarter. The handouts will be financed by government borrowing and require cabinet approval. The government also plans to revise smart visa rules to attract long-term investors.

site_title: EU chief calls for unity to confront crises
summary: European Union (EU) President Ursula von der Leyen outlined ambitious goals to ensure the bloc's resilience and unity in the face of future crises. She pledged to cut the EU's greenhouse gas emissions by at least 55% by 2030 and invest 20% of a $1.2 trillion economic recovery fund in digital projects. Von der Leyen also called for greater investment in technology to compete with China and the US, and urged EU countries to work together on a unified foreign policy. Despite challenges, including Brexit and climate change, the EU is seeking to rebuild solidarity among member states.

site_title: Wilmar gets final registration nod for China unit's IPO, eyes listing by mid-Oct
summary: Wilmar International's Chinese unit, YIHAI Kerry Arawana (YKA), has received final registration approval from the China Securities Regulatory Commission for its listing on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange's ChiNext Board by mid-October. YKA's listing will be carried out through the issuance of new shares, accounting for at least 10% of its issued share capital. Strategic investors, mainly state-owned funds and sovereign wealth funds, have subscribed for approximately 30% of YKA's initial public offering (IPO) shares. The listing is expected to boost Wilmar's China operations and increase market visibility.

site_title: Flow of China tech firms to Singapore bodes well for jobs, property sector
summary: Chinese tech firms are increasingly setting up shop in Singapore, drawn by the country's favorable business environment, workforce, and infrastructure. Analysts predict this trend will boost the local job and property markets. Chinese companies such as Tencent Holdings have established a presence in Singapore, and experts expect more firms to follow. The country's neutrality in the US-China trade war and lack of restrictions on foreign ownership also make it an attractive destination. As a result, Singapore's tech sector is poised for growth, with demand for office space, data centers, and other infrastructure expected to increase.

site_title: We're happy - despite the pandemic
summary: A recent survey conducted by TEDxSingapore found that despite the pandemic, Singaporeans are surprisingly happier than expected. The survey, which included a similar poll from 2019, showed a similar level of contentment for 2020, with respondents prioritizing "meaning," "purpose," and "gratitude" over material pursuits. However, the small sample size and limited demographic scope of the survey raise concerns about the results' generalizability.

site_title: Australian government lawyer names China in foreign interference probe
summary: Australia has named China in a foreign interference probe, with the country's government acknowledging the investigation into alleged plots to influence an Australian politician. The Australian Federal Police and ASIO declined to comment on the connection to a June raid on a New South Wales politician's offices. China dismissed the allegations as an anti-China smear, while the government's solicitor stated that the suspected offences related to dealings with Shaoquett Moselmane on behalf of the People's Republic of China.

site_title: Home improvement stocks vie with tech for investor revisit
summary: Home improvement stocks have surged 23% this year, outpacing the MSCI AC World Index, as the pandemic has driven a boom in DIY projects. However, analysts are skeptical about the sustainability of this trend, citing easing lockdowns and the end of government stimulus payments. Stocks in the home improvement sector are trading at record levels, with high valuations, and are expected to face tough sales and earnings comparables next year, which could disappoint investors. Analysts believe the post-pandemic shift towards vacations and activities outside the home will reduce demand for home improvement projects.

site_title: Teckwah directors recommend shareholders accept privatisation bid
summary: Teckwah Industrial Corporation's independent directors recommend shareholders accept a voluntary conditional cash offer of S$0.65 per share from Clementine Investments, a consortium of Teckwah's three largest shareholders, to take the company private. The offer price represents a premium of 17.8% over the volume-weighted average price (VWAP) of Teckwah shares on Aug 7. The offer closes on Sept 30, and the company's shares have consistently traded at a discount to the trailing net asset value (NAV) per share.

site_title: Boeing MAX crashes 'horrific' result of lapses by company, regulator
summary: Congressional investigators blame Boeing and the FAA for the 737 MAX crashes, citing "repeated and serious failures" by the companies. The report attributes the crashes to faulty technical assumptions by Boeing's engineers, lack of transparency, and insufficient oversight by the FAA. The crashes were not isolated incidents, but rather the result of a series of failures. The report calls for an overhaul of the US aviation regulatory system to prevent similar tragedies in the future.

site_title: Travel agencies see limited benefit from tourism vouchers
summary: Singapore's SingapoRediscovers vouchers, aimed at boosting the tourism industry, have generated cautious optimism among travel agencies. The vouchers, worth S$100, can be used for hotel stays, attraction tickets, and local tours, and will be accessible from December to June 2021. Attractions can increase operating capacity to 50% and outdoor shows to 250 people, with safety measures in place. While some agencies expect benefits, others remain uncertain about the impact, with hotels and attractions expected to gain the most from the scheme.

site_title: BP's clean energy push starts with 5-year dash on solar and wind
summary: BP plans to boost wind and solar power over the next five years, aiming to approve over 20 gigawatts of renewable energy projects by 2025, with 83% of that capacity being solar. This expansion will help the company achieve its goal of eliminating net greenhouse gas emissions from BP and its customers by 2050. BP's in-house trading operations and access to low-cost funds are expected to boost returns on renewable energy projects, with solar power being a key component of the company's low-carbon transformation.

site_title: Bejing demands private sector's loyalty as external risks rise
summary: China's ruling Communist Party is demanding increased loyalty from the private sector amid growing external risks, including US hostility and the coronavirus pandemic. Despite President Xi Jinping's pledge to support the sector, the party has tightened its grip on private businesses by taking stakes or installing officials in large firms. This move aims to ensure the private sector's loyalty and stability as China's economy faces slowing growth and increasing pressure on policymakers. The demand for loyalty comes as China's GDP growth is set to slow, raising concerns about the country's economic future.

site_title: Total unit signs deal with Singapore LNG Corp for solar energy system
summary: Total Solar Distributed Generation, a subsidiary of France's Total, has signed a deal with Singapore LNG Corp to install a 600 kW rooftop solar power system at the Singapore LNG terminal. The system will generate 800 MWh of renewable energy and reduce carbon dioxide emissions by 300 tonnes annually. The installation is expected to be completed by the fourth quarter of this year, with the goal of achieving a solar target of 2 GW of peak power by 2030.

site_title: Asia-Pac - a showcase of why EVs are the future
summary: Asia-Pacific is poised for rapid growth in electric vehicles (EVs), with predictions that more than half of cars sold will be electric by 2040. The region's extreme population density and air pollution concerns make EVs an attractive solution. Grand View Research forecasts Asia-Pacific will see the highest EV growth, with China already holding the largest EV fleet. By 2025, one-fifth of vehicles in South-east Asia are expected to be electric, according to the International Renewable Energy Association. This growth could lead to significant economic and social benefits, including improved productivity and reduced air pollution.

site_title: Unfriended abroad, China's tech giants seek home comfort
summary: China's tech giants, including Huawei, TikTok, and ByteDance, can rely on their massive domestic market to weather international challenges, such as US-led campaigns against them. Despite espionage concerns and diplomatic feuds in key markets like the US, Australia, UK, and India, Chinese firms have a 900 million-strong user base at home. This provides opportunities for companies to develop China-specific apps and services, despite the country's tightly controlled internet. Despite security allegations, Chinese tech firms remain major players globally, with growing ambitions in areas like autonomous vehicles and quantum computing.

site_title: US dollar falls as markets bet on more Fed easing
summary: The US dollar fell across the board as markets anticipate the Federal Reserve's decision on Thursday, with expectations of potential policy easing. The Chinese yuan reached its highest level since May 2019, while the Japanese yen made significant gains. The Fed's economic projections and inflation outlook will be closely watched, with investors betting on a wait-and-watch approach. Meanwhile, investors are bullish on China's economy, with the yuan and yen making gains.

site_title: Apple rolls out virtual fitness service, subscription bundle, catering to WFH
summary: Apple has rolled out a virtual fitness service and a subscription bundle, Apple One, targeting customers working from home during the pandemic. The company also introduced a new Apple Watch Series 6 that monitors blood oxygen for $399 and a basic Apple Watch SE for $279. This holiday-season launch focuses on services that drive Apple's growth strategy, following the company's shift towards remote work.

site_title: Time to relook Singapore office Reits as China tech giants spur demand: DBS
summary: DBS Group Research has reiterated its positive stance on Singapore office Reits, citing the expansion plans of Chinese tech giants such as Tencent, Alibaba, and ByteDance. The analysts expect the entry of these firms to spur demand for office space, particularly in Grade A prime central business district areas like CCT and Keppel Reit. With limited supply until 2022 and high occupancy, DBS believes the market is poised for an upcycle, benefiting these landlords. The analysts have "buy" calls on Keppel Reit and Mapletree Commercial Trust, with target prices of S$1.35 and S$2.25 respectively.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Dyna-Mac Holdings has entered a five-year MoU with Keppel Shipyard to explore potential business relationships. Camsing Healthcare has been told by its majority shareholder to refrain from appointing an independent firm to review internal controls, despite a Singapore Exchange Regulation notice. Yoma Strategic Holdings has cancelled its shareholders' trip due to travel restrictions. KrisEnergy's Vietnam offshore farm-out deal has been delayed to Dec 31. DBS is awaiting the financial review of Sen Yue Holdings' subsidiary before extending banking facilities.

site_title: Four debut novels make 2020 Booker Prize shortlist
summary: The 2020 Booker Prize shortlist features four debut novelists: Avni Doshi (Burnt Sugar), Diane Cook (The New Wilderness), Brandon Taylor (Real Life), and Douglas Stuart (Shuggie Bain), alongside Zimbabwean author Tsitsi Dangarembga and Ethiopian-American Maaza Mengiste. The six-strong shortlist, announced by a panel of five judges, showcases a diverse range of stories from different settings, including post-colonial Zimbabwe, 1930s Ethiopia, and modern-day India. The winner will receive £50,000 and international attention, with the announcement set for November 17.

site_title: Does Covid-19 mark the death of financial globalisation?
summary: COVID-19 has accelerated concerns that economic globalisation is dying, with supply chain disruptions and protectionist policies on the rise. Despite a near-unanimous consensus that trade globalisation is net positive, countries are abandoning their commitment to free trade. The pandemic has exacerbated trade de-globalisation, with the US-China trade war and rising nationalism contributing to the trend. This shift could have significant economic implications, with potential losses for import-competing sectors and firms, and a decline in global trade.

site_title: BOE readies for action as UK faces a turbulent end to 2020
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) is expected to prepare for further monetary stimulus as the UK's economic recovery from the coronavirus pandemic falters. Job losses are mounting, new restrictions are being implemented, and trade talks with the EU are in peril. Economists predict the BOE's bond-buying programme will be expanded again before the end of the year, possibly adding £50 billion to the £745 billion programme. A rate cut is also likely, with some predicting a reduction as early as February, as the UK faces a turbulent end to 2020.

site_title: Netanyahu nominated for Nobel Peace Prize after Gulf accords
summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has been nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize after the normalization accords with the UAE and Bahrain were signed at the White House. Netanyahu was nominated by an Italian parliament member, Paolo Grimoldi, who also mentioned his dialogue with Saudi Arabia. The nomination is seen as a recognition of Netanyahu's efforts to normalize relations with Arab countries, and he may share the prize with US President Donald Trump, who was also nominated. The Norwegian Nobel Committee receives hundreds of nominations each year.

site_title: On Best World International and the long road ahead
summary: A commentary in The Business Times questioned the credibility of Best World International (BWI) following a PwC audit report. The author, a retired analyst, defended BWI's audit report, stating that it cleared up concerns about the legality of BWI's China business and allayed fears of financial shenanigans. The author also disputed claims that Changsha Best, a majority-owned entity, should be considered a subsidiary, citing the lack of control. The author concludes that BWI's shares are an inexpensive way to participate in the Asian consumer space and remains a patient shareholder, despite the company's remaining challenges on the long road ahead.

site_title: Why digital transformation efforts fail
summary: Digital transformation efforts often fail due to a lack of alignment within senior management and a misunderstanding of the term. According to research, 70% of organisational digital journeys hit roadblocks and fail. To avoid this, businesses should carefully map out and clarify the nature of their digital journey, whether it's transformation, integration, or optimisation. This involves defining objectives and expectations, obtaining senior management buy-in, and implementing success metrics. Starting small, staying humble, and testing and learning are also key to achieving digital transformation goals.

images.alt_text: Digital transformation is the evolution of new business operations, outputs and outcomes. Think about how Netflix has redefined the way we access entertainment and the impact it has had on the industry, from cinemas to movie rental stores.

site_title: Safe distancing: Flouting of rules will only prolong existing measures
summary: Singapore's dining restrictions may not be lifted soon due to continued breaches of safe management measures. Education Minister Lawrence Wong warned that enforcement agencies will take immediate action against offenders, and that complacency could jeopardize the goal of relaxing current restrictions. The government is prioritizing keeping infection numbers down and complying with existing measures to ease restrictions further. Non-compliance risks fines, forced closure, and prolonging the suffering for diners and establishments.

site_title: Global recession in 2020 not as deep as expected: OECD
summary: The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has revised its forecast, predicting a global recession in 2020 will be less severe than initially expected, with a contraction of 4.5% this year and a 5% return to growth in 2021. This contrasts with previous forecasts of a 6% contraction and 5.2% growth. The pandemic's economic impact is still uncertain, with countries' efforts to counter the effects seen as a factor in the revised forecast.

images.alt_text: The global recession this year will not be as deep as expected as a result of countries' efforts to counter the economic fallout from the novel coronavirus pandemic, the OECD said on Wednesday.

site_title: Movie theatres returned. Audiences didn't. Now what?
summary: Movie theaters reopened in the US in late August, but audiences didn't return, with Tenet, a $200 million film, collecting only $29.5 million in its first two weeks. Analysts say the industry is under threat, with studios postponing big movies and theaters facing uncertainty over reopening in New York and Los Angeles. The pandemic has reduced consumer comfort with indoor movie theaters, and streaming services are becoming a growing threat to theaters. Experts warn that the future of the theater business is uncertain, with no clear timeline for improvement.

site_title: LHN unit buys Balestier property for S$18.1m under plans for co-living business
summary: LHN Limited has agreed to buy a four-storey property in Balestier, Singapore for S$18.1 million to operate as a co-living space. The 406.7 sq m building is currently vacant, with the first floor tenanted. The acquisition is part of LHN's plans for a co-living business.

site_title: MedTech Innovator seeks to spotlight Asia-Pacific startups to investors
summary: MedTech Innovator, a US nonprofit accelerator, aims to spotlight Asia-Pacific medtech startups to investors amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The organization seeks to match startups with medical giants for mentoring and global investors for funding, particularly in complex device segments such as implants and cardiovascular technologies. Despite investors' cautiousness, MedTech Innovator expects interest from North American and European investors in the region, driven by the untapped potential of segments like orthopaedics. The accelerator plans to expand its presence in other Asia-Pacific markets, including Australia and India.

site_title: Olympic costs are out of control, warn Oxford academics
summary: Oxford academics warn that Olympic costs are comparable to "deep disasters" and urge the International Olympic Committee to change its approach, citing a study that shows every Games since 1960 has run over budget, averaging 172% above the original budget. The academics recommend selecting cities with existing infrastructure or hosting the Games in the same city every time to reduce costs. The Tokyo Olympics, despite a $12.6 billion budget, are the latest to wildly overshoot, prompting the IOC to take urgent action to safeguard the future of the Games.

site_title: US imposes sanctions on Chinese firm over Cambodia project
summary: The US has imposed sanctions on Union Development Group, a Chinese firm developing a complex in Cambodia, citing land seizure from local people and potential use as a Chinese military base. The Dara Sakor complex, featuring a runway for large planes, is part of China's Belt and Road initiative. The sanctions were imposed amid "credible reports" of the complex being used for military purposes.

site_title: DBS maintains 'buy' on ComfortDelGro amid extended support for industry
summary: DBS Group Research has maintained its "buy" recommendation on ComfortDelGro, with a target price of S$1.96, following the extension of the Special Relief Fund (SRF) and rental reliefs for taxi and private hire drivers. The LTA has announced a S$112 million extension of the SRF, including a S$106 million rental relief for drivers, and ComfortDelGro is extending its rental waiver from 25% to 30% until October 31. DBS views this as a progressive step down in rental waiver, indicating ridership improvement, and expects higher odds of share price appreciation over the next six to 12 months.

site_title: Singapore timber trading scion sets sights on financing business in Indochina
summary: Singapore-based Evergreen Assets Management, led by second-generation leader David Yong, plans to raise S$100 million to expand its financing business in Indochina, with a focus on micro-financing in Cambodia, Vietnam, and Myanmar. The company has already secured a financial institute (FI) licence in Cambodia and aims to double its financing business, which now makes up 60% of the group's turnover. Evergreen's goal is to transform from a timber-focused business to a broad-based enterprise with financing in Indochina and Singapore as its core business.

site_title: US charges seven in wide-ranging Chinese hacking effort
summary: The US Justice Department has charged seven individuals, including five Chinese hackers and two Malaysian businessmen, in a wide-ranging hacking effort targeting over 100 companies worldwide. The attacks resulted in the theft of source code, customer data, and valuable business information. The indictment marks a significant escalation in US efforts to combat Chinese cybercrime. Deputy Attorney General Jeffrey Rosen criticized the Chinese government's alleged tolerance of cybercrime, while Microsoft credited its efforts in blocking the intrusions. The announcement comes amid increased tensions between the US and China.

site_title: Secura unit wins S$10.7m security services contract
summary: Secura Group's wholly-owned subsidiary SOVERUS Pte Ltd secured a S$10.7 million contract to provide unarmed security services to a Singapore multinational conglomerate. The contract, worth S$10.7 million, will run from Feb 1, 2021 to Jan 31, 2024, with an option for a 12-month extension. This brings Secura's order book to about S$41.1 million.

site_title: In Berlin, the art world spreads out to stay safe
summary: Berlin's art world reopened after six months of inactivity, hosting live exhibitions and events during Gallery Weekend, the city's first significant international art fair since March. The event, anchored by Gallery Weekend Berlin, featured decentralized and localized exhibitions with a smaller, more local crowd due to travel restrictions. Dealers relied on online transactions to top up sales, with some galleries selling out their works, including a 15-foot-wide photograph by Andreas Gursky for 1 million euros. The event's spread-out format was seen as better suited to virus-conscious times, with face masks mandatory in galleries.

site_title: World economic slump won't be as sharp as OECD previously feared
summary: The OECD has downgraded its forecast for the global economic slump, predicting a 4.5% contraction this year, less than the previously feared 6%. The recovery is losing pace, but strong economic rebounds since lockdowns ended have led to the upgrade. China is forecast to grow modestly, while the US and euro area have seen revisions. Governments and central banks will need to continue supporting the economy, with assistance programs evolving to target sectors with a viable future. Uncertainty remains due to ongoing Covid-19 outbreaks and targeted local interventions.

site_title: UK government reaches deal with Conservative rebels
summary: The UK government has reached a deal with Conservative rebels to address concerns over the Internal Market Bill, which was criticized for potentially breaking international law. The bill aims to ensure free trade among the UK's four nations after Brexit. A proposed amendment by MP Bob Neill has been accepted, providing extra parliamentary oversight to prevent a rebellion. The deal was reached after a rebellion by party members threatened to block the bill's passage.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as focus turns to Fed meet
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened higher on Wednesday as investors awaited a potential pledge from the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates low. The Dow Jones rose 36.09 points, the S&P 500 gained 10.03 points, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 31.76 points. Upbeat quarterly results from FedEx also boosted sentiment.

site_title: LNG-fuelled tankers to more than double by 2030, says Petronas executive
summary: LNG-fuelled tankers are expected to more than double to 1,000 vessels globally by 2030, driven by the shipping industry's desire to cut emissions. Currently, around 400 out of 80,000 registered ships run on LNG as fuel. Petronas executive Mohd Rafe Mohamed Ramli attributes the growth to increased demand from tanker operators and cruise liners, with Europe, Singapore, and Malaysia expected to see significant increases. As LNG production capacity expands globally, prices are expected to remain competitive, making LNG a viable alternative to traditional bunker fuels.

site_title: Facebook Singapore to give S$4.75m in grants to small businesses hit by Covid-19
summary: Facebook Singapore has allocated S$4.75 million in grants to support local small businesses affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. Each grant, worth S$5,500, includes S$3,500 in cash and S$2,000 in ad credits. Eligible businesses must have 2-50 employees, be over a year old, and experience pandemic-related challenges. Applications are open until September 22. This initiative aims to help small businesses recover and contribute to the country's economy.

site_title: Indian airlines seek US$1.5b interest-free credit line from government
summary: Indian airlines have sought US$1.5 billion in interest-free credit from the government to cope with revenue losses from the coronavirus pandemic. Airlines, including IndiGo, Vistara, SpiceJet, and Air India, also want the government to ease leasing terms, defer taxes, and abolish excise duty on aviation fuel. Revenues of Indian airlines fell to US$500 million in the April-June quarter from US$3.5 billion a year ago. The government has engaged with foreign aircraft lessors to ensure no premature withdrawals of leased aircraft and established bilateral air travel links with countries like the US and UK.

site_title: As UN turns 75, the celebration is muted by calamity and conflict
summary: The United Nations is celebrating its 75th anniversary amidst global calamity and conflict. The world is facing widespread contagion, the worst economic crisis since the Great Depression, and a warming planet, with rising hunger, refugees, and xenophobia. The organization's own challenges also loom, including a new cold war between the US and China. As the UN marks its founding in 1945, its celebration is muted by the long list of global woes, raising questions about the organization's relevance and effectiveness in addressing these pressing issues.

site_title: As Opec+ meets this week, UAE emerges as main laggard
summary: The United Arab Emirates (UAE) has emerged as a major laggard in delivering oil output cuts in August, with compliance rates at around 101% according to Opec+ sources. This is significantly lower than other members, with Iraq and Nigeria making efforts to compensate for their overproduction. The Opec+ technical committee meets to discuss market fundamentals and compliance, and a higher-level ministerial meeting on Thursday is unlikely to expand oil cuts further. Demand forecasts have worsened, with Opec expecting a 9.46 million barrel decline in world oil demand this year.

site_title: Diversity and inclusion must stay front and centre
summary: A global pandemic has led to a once-in-a-generation public-health crisis, causing the greatest global economic shock since the Great Depression. Governments are adopting protectionist policies, fuelling deglobalisation, and restructuring regulatory regimes, markets, and industries. Companies are adapting to the new environment, prioritising productivity, relevance, and workforce protection. The pandemic has accelerated changes in the job market, with companies struggling to lay off employees effectively. The global economy continues to grapple with the aftermath of the pandemic, with ongoing impacts on trade, markets, and industries.

site_title: Shanmugam to make ministerial statement in Parliament on ex-maid Parti Liyani's case
summary: Singapore's Home Affairs and Law Minister K Shanmugam plans to make a ministerial statement in Parliament on the case of former maid Parti Liyani, who was acquitted of theft. The case, which involved allegations of stealing S$34,000 worth of items from a prominent businessman's family, has sparked controversy and raised questions about the justice system's treatment of low-income individuals. Several MPs, including Workers' Party chairman Sylvia Lim, have filed questions and an adjournment motion to discuss the matter further.

site_title: British Airways says pandemic may cost 10,000 jobs
summary: British Airways is expecting to cut up to 10,000 jobs due to the Covid-19 pandemic, with 7,200 people already leaving the company. The airline has reached agreements with some unions and has backed away from a plan to fire and rehire staff. British Airways operates about 25-30% of its capacity, impacted by changing quarantine rules and travel restrictions. The airline is seeking to resume flights between New York and London with new testing requirements.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore navigated through past crises by capitalizing on its strong foundations and adapting swiftly, according to Minister for Communications and Information S Iswaran. Teckwah Industrial Corporation's directors recommended accepting a S$0.65 per-share voluntary conditional cash offer. Wilmar's Chinese unit received final registration approval for its China IPO, with plans to list in mid-October. Q&M Dental Group's subsidiary secured a healthcare institution licence to conduct Covid-19 testing services. Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.78% to 2,505.15, driven by a stronger market.

site_title: Las Vegas homebuyers are bidding up prices in collapsing economy
summary: Las Vegas homebuyers are bidding up prices in the collapsing economy, with the median price of a single-family house jumping 10% to $335,000 in August, compared to 6.7% in February. Record-low mortgage rates and Nevada's lack of income tax are attracting buyers from high-cost markets, but prices may fall in less than a year as owners resell properties. The trend highlights the widening gap between real estate and the real economy in Las Vegas, where tourism is in ruins and wages are plummeting.

site_title: Indonesia imports likely to stay weak: economists
summary: Indonesia's August trade figures remain weak, with imports down 24.2% year-over-year and exports down 8.2%. Domestic demand is expected to drag on growth, with economists forecasting a 2.7% GDP contraction this year. Reimposed Covid-19 measures in Jakarta may further depress imports, while exports are expected to rise on the back of global economic recovery. The central bank may still intervene in the event of portfolio outflows, but a large drain on reserves is unforeseen at this point.

images.alt_text: Containers at the Port of Tanjung Priok in Jakarta.

site_title: US consumer spending appears to slow in August
summary: US consumer spending appears to slow in August, with core retail sales falling 0.1% after a 0.9% increase in July. This decline, attributed to the expiration of a $600 weekly unemployment subsidy, suggests the economic recovery from the Covid-19 recession is faltering. The labour market is also showing signs of fatigue, with job growth slowing further and new unemployment applications remaining high. This slowdown could put pressure on the White House and Congress to restart stalled negotiations for another fiscal package.

site_title: KKR raises over US$11b in Asia fund
summary: KKR has raised over $11 billion for its fourth Asia-focused fund, surpassing its initial target of $12.5 billion. The fund, which started marketing last year, will focus on China, Japan, India, and Southeast Asia. This is the region's largest private equity fund. KKR has been investing heavily in India, including a $1.5 billion stake in telecom operator Jio Platforms, and is also an investor in Chinese tech firm Bytedance, owner of TikTok. The final close of the fund is yet to be reached.

site_title: US$500m burglary nets stamps and calligraphy in Hong Kong
summary: A Hong Kong thief stole a collection worth $500 million in a daylight heist from an apartment belonging to Chinese collector Fu Chunxiao. The stolen items included calligraphy by Chairman Mao Zedong, rare stamps, and revolutionary items from mainland China. The thief entered the apartment through an iron gate and a wooden door, taking just two hours to steal the valuable goods, which were kept in a locked drawer. The police are investigating the heist, which occurred on September 10, 2020.

site_title: US retail sales rebound slows after extra jobless aid lapses
summary: US retail sales rebounded by 0.6% in August, but slowed from the prior month's 0.9% increase, missing forecasts. The slowdown is attributed to the expiration of $600 weekly jobless aid and slowdowns in back-to-school spending. Retail sales excluding food services fell 0.1%, and purchases at non-store retailers rose 22.4% from August 2019. Despite a shift in consumer spending, total retail sales remain above pre-pandemic levels, and momentum has faded.

images.alt_text: With many more stores and restaurants now open in the United States, the initial boost in spending driven by reopenings is moderating.

site_title: Scientists find world's oldest sperm in Myanmar amber
summary: Scientists in Myanmar have discovered the world's oldest animal sperm, frozen in tree resin 100 million years ago inside a tiny crustacean. The sperm, found in a female specimen, measures up to 4.6 times the size of the male's body, equivalent to about 7.30 meters in a 1.70-meter human. The discovery provides evidence of "co-evolution" between males and females, with giant sperm cells indicating good health and a clear advantage over asexual reproduction.

site_title: China tightens funding sources for micro lenders such as Ant
summary: China has tightened regulations on small loan companies, including those run by Ant Group, to control risk in the online lending industry. The banking watchdog has capped loans using bank funding and shareholder capital at firms' net asset value, while limiting bond sales and asset-backed securities to four times. This adds to restrictions on Ant, which relies on these funding sources to generate revenue. The new rules also limit the expansion of small loan companies to provinces and require approval from local regulators.

site_title: T-rex skeleton could fetch record price at New York auction
summary: A 12m Tyrannosaurus rex skeleton nicknamed "Stan" is set to be auctioned in New York, potentially breaking a record for a dinosaur sale. Discovered in 1987 in South Dakota, the 188-bone skeleton took three years to excavate and reconstruct. Estimated to be around 20 years old when it died, Stan has been used to create replicas for dozens of museums. The auction is scheduled to take place next month, with the exact price yet to be determined.

site_title: Wilmar gets final registration approval for China IPO, eyes listing by mid-October
summary: Wilmar International's Chinese unit, YIHAI Kerry Arawana (YKA), has received final registration approval for its listing on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange's ChiNext Board. The listing is expected to take place by mid-October and will involve the issuance of new shares to YKA, accounting for at least 10% of its issued share capital.

site_title: Amazon UK unit pays £6.3m corporation tax as sales hit £13.59b
summary: Amazon UK Services paid £6.3m in corporation tax in 2019 despite £13.59 billion in sales, citing low profits due to a competitive retail market and significant investments. The company attributes the low tax figure to the fact that corporation tax is based on profits, not revenues. Amazon UK Services reported low profits, which contributed to the low corporation tax payment.

site_title: Amazon plans to put 1,000 warehouses in US neighbourhoods
summary: Amazon plans to build 1,000 small delivery hubs in US neighborhoods, with about 1,500 facilities expected, to speed up same-day delivery and compete with Walmart and Target. The move aims to bring products closer to customers, making online shopping comparable to in-store shopping. The company is doubling down on its pre-pandemic pledge to get products to Prime subscribers on the same day, investing billions in proximity and logistics. The expansion poses a significant threat to UPS and the US Postal Service, as Amazon is duplicating their logistics operations and pulling back from long-time delivery partners.

site_title: Singapore stocks end Wednesday higher, STI climbs 0.78 per cent to 2,505.15
summary: Singapore stocks ended higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.78% to 2,505.15. Sembcorp Industries led gains, rising 8.9% to close at S$1.34, while ComfortDelgro and Wilmar International also saw significant increases. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB fell, while smaller cap stock Shinvest Holding surged 21.38% to close at S$3.35. The gains came ahead of a US Fed policy meeting and amid optimistic rhetoric about coronavirus vaccines.

site_title: Jack Ma's Ant Group wants tech analysts to help cover its stock
summary: Jack Ma's Ant Group has requested technology analysts to provide research coverage of its stock as it prepares for a potential $30 billion IPO in Hong Kong and Shanghai. The request, made to at least seven brokerages, reflects Ant's focus on technology and its plans to earn most of its revenue from providing services to other financial firms and local merchants. This move could help Ant's stock trade at a higher multiple, following the trend of technology companies trading at higher multiples than financial firms.

site_title: LCT Holdings co-founder seeks to take it private in S$21m deal
summary: Deloitte Consulting's Singapore arm sells majority stake to private equity firm for S$21 million. LCT Holdings co-founder Dr. Du Junhong made a voluntary cash offer to acquire the company, valuing it at S$0.60 per share. The deal values the company at S$21 million, with Dr. Du holding a 19.72% deemed interest. The offeror plans to take the company private to gain greater control and flexibility, with no immediate plans for major changes.

site_title: UK regulator pushes TUI over Covid-19 cancelled holiday refunds
summary: The UK's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) has ordered TUI UK, the world's largest holiday group, to refund customers for Covid-19 cancelled holidays by September 30. The regulator investigated thousands of complaints from customers who waited more than 14 days for refunds, a period under consumer protection law. TUI UK must comply with the deadline, which is expected to be enforced by the end of the month.

images.alt_text: Britain's competition regulator said TUI UK will refund customers for Covid-19 cancelled holidays by Sept 30, after it investigated consumer complaints that travel companies were dragging their heels over returning cash.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets mixed at open
summary: European stock markets showed mixed results at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index down 0.3% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 index up 0.1%. Paris' CAC 40 index rose 0.2%. The divergent performances suggest varying investor sentiment, with mining and healthcare stocks driving gains, while US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty remain a focus.

site_title: The future of events is hybrid
summary: Events are shifting to a hybrid model, combining digital and physical elements, amid the COVID-19 pandemic. This shift is expected to persist beyond the pandemic, as digital events have increased awareness of their versatility. The future of events will blend the potential of digital tools with the serendipity of in-person meetings, creating a hybrid experience that offers the best of both worlds.

site_title: Pound near two-month lows on Brexit worries; Bank of England eyed
