summary: The British pound fell to near two-month lows on Wednesday due to rising Brexit uncertainty and economic concerns. Investors are anticipating a Bank of England decision on Thursday, expecting policymakers to acknowledge downside risks to the economy. Sterling has been volatile, with its worst week in six months last week, and is now trading 0.1% lower at $1.2877. Economic data showed a rise in Britain's unemployment rate, further fueling concerns about the pound's stability.

images.alt_text: The British pound held within striking distance of a two-month low on Wednesday before a Bank of England (BoE) decision on Thursday against the backdrop of a darkening outlook for the economy.

site_title: Takeda to sell TachoSil surgical patch to Corza Health for 350m euros
summary: Takeda Pharmaceutical will sell its TachoSil surgical patch product to Corza Health for 350 million euros, reducing non-core debt. The patch generated $160 million in sales for Takeda in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020. This sale is part of Takeda's efforts to divest non-core businesses and focus on key areas such as oncology and rare diseases.

images.alt_text: Takeda Pharmaceutical said on Wednesday it would sell its TachoSil surgical patch product to Corza Health for 350 million euros (S$563.7 million) as the Japanese company continues to divest non-core businesses.

site_title: Lufthansa CEO prepares staff for deeper job and fleet cuts
summary: Deutsche Lufthansa is preparing for deeper job and fleet cuts than initially planned due to a decline in bookings and European virus cases. CEO Carsten Spohr stated that air traffic won't recover until the middle of the decade, and revenue may not return to 2019 levels. The airline plans to cut its fleet by about 100 jets and shed 22,000 full-time positions, with further measures to increase customer focus and become more sustainable.

site_title: Sweden's biggest bank says cost cuts to hit 1,000 employees
summary: Sweden's biggest bank, Svenska Handelsbanken, plans to cut its branch network by almost half and reduce costs by 1 billion kronor (S$154.8 million) through investments in technology. The move will affect around 1,000 employees in Sweden over the next two years, with negotiations and consultations initiated with trade unions. The bank expects a decline in income due to the cost cuts, which are aimed at lowering costs and improving efficiency.

site_title: Migrating whales help revive some Australian towns devastated by bushfires
summary: Migrating humpback whales are helping revive Australian towns devastated by bushfires. Following Australia's COVID-19 travel restrictions, tourists are flocking to lesser-known destinations, including Eden, where humpback whales migrate. The area was severely affected by bushfires, killing 33 people and millions of native animals. Local businesses, such as Cat Balou cruises, are seeing an increase in demand as visitors seek to experience the natural beauty of the area. This surge in tourism is providing a welcome boost to the local economy.

site_title: Asset managers, companies lagging in Libor transition: HK regulator
summary: Hong Kong's banking regulator warns that asset managers and companies are lagging behind the banking sector in preparing for the end of the London Interbank Offered Rate (Libor) benchmark, which is set to end by the end of 2021. Despite the impact of the pandemic, regulators globally have told banks to stop using Libor and shift to alternative rates calculated by central banks. The regulator urges asset managers and companies to do more to prepare for the transition, which affects derivatives contracts and loans worth $400 trillion globally.

site_title: Seadrill to suspend debt payments as restructuring talks continue
summary: Seadrill, an offshore drilling rig operator, has agreed with creditors to suspend interest payments this month as part of its debt restructuring efforts. The company has a US$7.3 billion debt and has failed to convince its 43 bank lenders to permanently adjust loan terms. Seadrill warned that a restructuring could result in minimal or no ownership for current shareholders. The move comes as the Covid-19 pandemic has led to a decline in oil and gas exploration and drilling demand, further exacerbating the industry's overcapacity issue.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end slightly lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended slightly lower on Wednesday, following three days of gains, as investors traded cautiously ahead of a US Federal Reserve meeting. The Hang Seng Index fell 7.13 points to 24,725.63, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. The moves came despite a rally in Singapore stocks, which notched a 5-day gain.

site_title: Gaming group Embracer expands in VR with Vertigo Games acquisition
summary: Swedish game developer Embracer has agreed to buy Netherlands-based virtual reality (VR) games maker Vertigo Games for 50 million euros upfront, with a possible additional payment of up to 65 million euros depending on its performance. Embracer aims to expand its activities into the fast-growing VR market, following a strong earnings performance and recent gaming studio acquisitions. The acquisition will further boost Embracer's share price, which has seen a 133% increase this year.

site_title: Sydney's new suburbs are too hot for people to live in
summary: Sydney's western suburbs are being developed to accommodate nearly half of the city's projected population growth over the next 20 years, despite the area's extreme heat. The region, which is already prone to temperatures of up to 80C, is expected to become even hotter due to global warming. Experts warn that the development process is not prioritizing environmental considerations, putting residents at risk of heat-related illnesses and deaths. Researchers are exploring solutions, such as heat-reflective paint and green spaces, to mitigate the urban heat island effect, but warn that the area may become too hot to live in within the next few decades.

site_title: Zara owner Inditex returns to profit in Q2
summary: Inditex, the owner of Zara, reported a net profit of 214 million euros in Q2, beating forecasts by 122 million euros, despite a 31% decline in sales due to the coronavirus crisis. 98% of its stores had reopened, and online sales rose 74% in the first half. The company reported a net loss of 195 million euros in the first half, mainly due to a 308 million euro charge related to platform integration.

site_title: Seoul: Shares snap four-day rally on profit taking ahead of Fed statement
summary: South Korean shares snapped a four-session rally, falling 0.31% to a near two-year high on Tuesday, due to profit taking ahead of the US Federal Reserve policy meeting. Chemical and financial stocks declined, while foreigners were net buyers of $147.35 million worth of shares. The Kospi has risen 10.84% this year, but its gains slowed, as investors focus on the Fed's statement and robust data from China.

site_title: Toyota, Dentsu team up to improve marketing strategy
summary: Toyota and Dentsu Group have formed a business alliance to improve Toyota's marketing strategy and digital transformation. The two companies will operate under a holding company, with Toyota owning 66% and Dentsu owning 34%. The partnership aims to create "exceptional customer trust" and utilize data to enhance customer relationships. The companies are set to start operations in January 2021.

site_title: EU chief executive unveils blueprint to get Europe back on its feet
summary: European Union Chief Executive Ursula von der Leyen has unveiled a plan to make the 27 EU nations more resilient for future crises. She aims to cut greenhouse gas emissions by 55% by 2030 and invest in technology to compete with China and the US. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic and economic recession, von der Leyen believes her goals will be key to Europe's survival. The EU has agreed on a stimulus plan to rescue its economies, and von der Leyen sees this as the moment for Europe to trust each other and lead the way to a new vitality.

site_title: People's Park Complex, People's Park Centre visited by infectious Covid-19 cases; man with 'false-positive' test result removed from total count
summary: The Ministry of Health in Singapore has added People's Park Complex and People's Park Centre to a list of locations visited by infectious Covid-19 cases during their infectious period. Two new community cases were reported, with one being a 50-year-old Singaporean woman who tested positive upon arrival from India. A man with a 'false-positive' test result was removed from the total case count after further investigations. The average number of new daily cases in the community has decreased, with 71 cases discharged on Wednesday, bringing the total number of recovered patients to 56,940.

site_title: Julius Baer eyes DOJ payment in FIFA matter, plans dividend
summary: Swiss bank Julius Baer is in advanced talks with the US Department of Justice over its alleged role in the FIFA corruption affair, potentially leading to a payment of tens of millions of dollars. The bank has been cooperating with the DOJ since 2015 and is seeking to settle the matter. Julius Baer plans to propose a second dividend tranche at an extraordinary shareholder meeting in November, with the bank also reprimanded by Switzerland's financial supervisor FINMA for ignoring money laundering risks of FIFA-linked payments.

site_title: Barclays to launch new FX trading and pricing engine in Singapore
summary: Barclays plans to launch a new foreign exchange (FX) trading and pricing engine in Singapore in mid-2021, its fourth electronic FX trading hub globally. The move aims to strengthen Barclays' FX presence in the Asia-Pacific and benefit local and regional market participants with increased price discovery, lower latency, and improved quality of execution. This is part of Singapore's efforts to become the top FX trading centre in the Asia-Pacific, following other global banks such as JPMorgan Chase & Co and BNP Paribas.

site_title: UK inflation sinks to 0.2% on virus stimulus
summary: UK inflation dropped to 0.2% in August, its lowest rate since records began, due to state coronavirus stimulus measures, including a restaurant discount scheme and tax cuts. The "Eat Out to Help Out" scheme, which offered 50% off meals up to £10, and a VAT cut on the hospitality sector contributed to the decline. Air fares also plummeted as fewer people traveled abroad. The data suggests the UK economy is recovering from the pandemic, but the government's efforts may have a limited impact on inflation.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close higher on hope for new government
summary: Tokyo shares closed higher on Wednesday, September 16, 2020, as investors hoped for a new government led by Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.09% and the Topix index advanced 0.21%. This follows the resignation of Shinzo Abe.

site_title: Nikola board members says startup's skeptics are too focused on past
summary: Nikola's board member Jeffrey Ubben says investors are focusing too much on the company's past and not enough on its future prospects as a hydrogen fuel supplier. He believes the company's true value lies in its ability to sell hydrogen fuel to fleets of vehicles, with a potential annual revenue of $100,000 per vehicle. Ubben regrets pushing the company to go public before it was ready and says the allegations of fraud against Nikola are "misunderstood." The US Securities and Exchange Commission and the Department of Justice are investigating the claims, but Nikola denies any deception.

site_title: China's private firms and manufacturers are investing again
summary: China's private firms and manufacturers have increased investment in August, with manufacturing investment rising 5% and private investment jumping 15.1% year-over-year. This follows a historic economic slump and the US trade war. State-led investment, however, has moderated, with infrastructure investment decelerating for a third month. Despite this, analysts expect infrastructure investment to rise in coming months due to strong government bond sales.

site_title: India's largest media group accelerating push into digital services
summary: India's largest media group, Bennett Coleman & Co, also known as the Times group, is accelerating its push into digital services to boost revenue to $1 billion by 2025. The company, which owns popular news websites and live-streaming apps, aims to capitalize on the shift to online platforms. Times Internet, its digital arm, has seen success with apps like Gaana and Cricbuzz, and is drawing interest from investors and potential buyers. The company is also exploring the sale of a 10% stake in Times Internet.

site_title: HNA Group chairman barred from flying, vacationing on firm's failure to pay court-ordered US$5,300
summary: HNA Group chairman barred from flying and vacationing due to unpaid court-ordered US$5,300 debt. The move is part of the conglomerate's restructuring efforts led by the Hainan government to resolve liquidity risks stemming from aggressive acquisitions abroad. The group has also delayed payments on several bond products this year.

site_title: Australia: Shares track US peers higher; Fed in focus
summary: Australian shares rose 1% to a one-week high, driven by tech stocks, ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy statement on the US economy. The S&P/ASX 200 index climbed, with Seek and Afterpay gaining 13% and 4% respectively. The Fed is expected to keep interest rates on hold, with investors waiting for Chairman's commentary. Tech stocks, including buy-now-pay-later firms, bounced, while the "big four" banks and biotech firm CSL also rose. New Zealand's benchmark index also ended higher, with Kathmandu Holdings and Arvida Group being top gainers.

site_title: Gold steady as markets eye outcome of US Fed meeting
summary: Gold prices remained steady at US$1,957.45 per ounce as investors awaited the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting, hoping for details on balancing interest rates against inflation. The Fed decision is due at 6pm GMT, with markets seeking clarity on monetary tools to support inflation above 2%. The US central bank has adopted a more accommodative approach to inflation, and markets expect a potential change in language regarding interest rates and inflation. Gold prices rose 0.1% despite a 0.1% decline in silver, platinum, and palladium.

site_title: Teckwah directors recommend shareholders accept privatisation bid
summary: Teckwah Industrial Corporation's independent directors have recommended shareholders accept a voluntary conditional cash offer of S$0.65 per share from Clementine Investments, a consortium of the company's three largest shareholders. The offer, which closes on September 30, is considered fair and reasonable by independent financial adviser RHT Capital. The offer price represents a premium of 17.8% over the volume-weighted average price of Teckwah shares on August 7.

site_title: Singaporeans above 18 to get S$100 domestic tourism vouchers in December
summary: Singaporeans aged 18 and above will receive S$100 digital vouchers in December to spend on staycations, leisure attractions, and local tours. The SingapoRediscovers Vouchers, worth S$320 million, aim to boost the tourism sector. Eligible individuals can use vouchers for hotel stays, attraction tickets, and tours until June 2022, with permanent residents excluded. The vouchers complement a S$45 million marketing campaign to encourage locals to holiday at home and support local businesses.

site_title: Air New Zealand plans to cut up to 385 more cabin crew jobs
summary: Air New Zealand plans to cut up to 385 more cabin crew jobs due to a decline in long-haul international flying. This would bring the airline's Covid-19 related job losses to around 37% of its workforce. The airline aims to reduce the number of cabin crew due to reduced demand on North American routes, with return flights to Los Angeles now limited to three a week. The job cuts are proposed to be carried out by December, with redundancies as the last resort.

site_title: Law firm Oon & Bazul names two recent hires as partners
summary: Law firm Oon & Bazul has named two recent hires as partners: Ng Yi Wayn and Keith Han. Ng Yi Wayn, 32, joins as partner of the firm's corporate practice, having previously advised on various acquisitions and transactions globally. Keith Han, 34, joins as partner of its restructuring and insolvency practice, citing the economic situation and Singapore's ambition to become a debt restructuring hub as areas of strong growth. The hires reflect the firm's confidence in Singapore as a "safe place to do business".

site_title: China sends satellites into space in first sea-based commercial launch
summary: China successfully launched nine satellites into orbit from a sea-based platform using a Long March 11 rocket, marking its first commercial sea launch. The satellites, including one for video-sharing platform Bilibili, were deployed from the Yellow Sea. The move aims to increase launch areas, improve efficiency, and reduce risks associated with inland launches. China's space program has prioritized catching up with the US by 2030, with sea launches offering a safer and more flexible alternative to inland launches.

site_title: Japan Parliament elects Yoshihide Suga as new prime minister
summary: Japan's parliament elected Yoshihide Suga, 71, as the new prime minister, with the former chief cabinet secretary winning 314 votes. Suga is expected to stick closely to Shinzo Abe's policies, prioritizing controlling coronavirus infections and boosting the economy. He will announce his cabinet later, retaining some ministers from Abe's government.

images.alt_text: Japan's parliament on Wednesday elected Yoshihide Suga prime minister, with the former chief cabinet secretary expected to stick closely to policies championed by Shinzo Abe during his record-breaking tenure.

site_title: Singapore LNG Corp and France's Total sign deal for solar energy system
summary: Singapore LNG Corp and Total have signed a deal for a 600 kW rooftop solar power system at the Singapore LNG terminal. The system, financed and operated by Total Solar Distributed Generation, will generate 800 MWh of renewable energy, avoiding 300 tonnes of carbon dioxide emissions annually. The installation is expected to be completed by the fourth quarter of this year, with Singapore aiming to achieve 2 GW of peak solar power by 2030.

site_title: Asia: Markets edge higher with eyes on Federal Reserve policy meeting
summary: Asian markets rose on Wednesday, driven by vaccine hopes and economic data, but investors remain cautious ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting. The Fed is expected to keep interest rates near zero and emphasize a low rate outlook to support the US economy, which contracted by over 30% in the second quarter. The meeting's outcome will be closely watched for clues on future policy. Markets in Sydney, Tokyo, and Hong Kong gained, while Shanghai and Jakarta declined.

site_title: Kodak says it mishandled CEO stock grants ahead of Covid project
summary: Eastman Kodak admitted to mishandling stock option grants for CEO Jim Continenza before a Covid-19 government loan announcement. A legal review found the grants were not properly briefed to the board on potential legal risks. The situation remains under investigation by US securities regulators and Congress. The company's general counsel was criticized for not adequately addressing these risks, but the conduct was deemed not to have violated the law.

site_title: Philippines says engaging Western pharma firms, despite Duterte anger
summary: The Philippines continues to negotiate supply deals with Western pharma firms despite President Rodrigo Duterte's criticism. Health Undersecretary Maria Rosario Vergeire confirmed ongoing discussions with vaccine manufacturers, including Pfizer and Moderna, and plans to meet CSL. The country has joined a World Health Organization-led vaccine trials and allocation plan, aiming to access vaccines. Duterte's preference for Chinese and Russian vaccines has not deterred the country from engaging with Western firms, which may be a large market due to its population of 107 million.

site_title: Global connections, digitalisation crucial for Singapore to emerge stronger from pandemic: Iswaran
summary: Singapore Minister for Communications and Information S Iswaran emphasized the importance of strengthening global connections, digitalization, and inclusive digital growth to emerge stronger from the pandemic. He urged businesses to capitalize on the digitalization journey, leveraging emerging technologies and data to access global markets, innovate, and redesign customer engagement. The government will enhance support for businesses, increase funding for small and medium-sized enterprises, and develop a secure and resilient 5G network to boost competitiveness and competitiveness.

images.alt_text: To emerge stronger from the current crisis, Singapore will need to strengthen its global connections, innovate and digitalise, and ensure inclusive digital growth in all segments of society, said Minister for Communications and Information S Iswaran on Wednesday.

site_title: LNG-fuelled tankers to more than double by 2030: Petronas exec
summary: The number of ships fuelled by liquefied natural gas (LNG) is expected to more than double to 1,000 vessels globally by 2030, driven by the shipping industry's desire to cut emissions. Currently, around 400 out of 80,000 ships use LNG as fuel. The increase in demand is driven by new rules to cut sulphur content in marine fuels and the growing need for cleaner energy. Petronas, Malaysia's state-owned oil company, expects to provide LNG bunkering services in Malaysia and Singapore, which are major shipping hubs.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS maintains 'buy' on ComfortDelGro amid extended support for industry
summary: DBS Group Research has maintained its "buy" recommendation on ComfortDelGro, targeting S$1.96, citing the transport operator's extended support for cabbies and private hire drivers. The Land Transport Authority's extension of the Special Relief Fund, providing S$112 million in rental relief, is seen as a "welcome relief" to support the industry. DBS expects ridership to improve, and the company's valuations are attractive at 1.2 times price to book value, with higher odds of share price appreciation over the next six to 12 months.

site_title: Alibaba's newest business: Modernising China's factories
summary: Alibaba Group has unveiled its newest business, Xunxi, a smart factory designed to modernize China's manufacturing sector. Located on the outskirts of Hangzhou, the factory uses data analytics and back-end technology to customize production in response to consumer demand. Equipped with cutting and sewing machines, Xunxi aims to improve profitability and reduce inventory levels for traditional manufacturers. The initiative is led by Xunxi Digital Technology, a subsidiary of Alibaba, and allows manufacturers to meet personalized needs while maintaining operational efficiency.

images.alt_text: Alibaba Group Holding helped modernise brick-and-mortar retail with consumer data and online services. Now it hopes to do the same for China's multitrillion-dollar manufacturing arena.

site_title: Cargill bets on China with deal to buy another soya crush plant
summary: Cargill, the world's largest agricultural commodities trader, has acquired a soya-processing plant in China for approximately US$62 million. This deal comes less than a year after the company bought a 34% stake in another soya bean processing plant in China, demonstrating its commitment to long-term development in the Asian nation.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on miners, tech boost; Federal Reserve meeting outcome eyed
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% to 5,933.3, driven by miners and tech stocks. The Federal Reserve's policy meeting outcome is eyed, with investors hoping for a supportive stance. Meanwhile, Victoria reported 42 new Covid-19 cases and eight deaths. Global miners BHP Group and Rio Tinto gained 1.6% and 2%, respectively, after upbeat Chinese data.

site_title: Japan commits 17.2b yen to WHO's global coronavirus vaccine programme
summary: Japan has committed 17.2 billion yen (S$221.7 million) to the World Health Organization's Covax global coronavirus vaccine programme. The funds are part of a 1.64 trillion yen reserve to bolster the government's response to the virus. Japan has also secured vaccines through independent arrangements with global pharmaceutical companies, aiming to have enough supply for the whole population by mid-2021. The Covax programme has set a September 18 deadline for contributions.

site_title: Li Ka-shing's UK carrier cuts 7% of workforce in revamp
summary: CK Hutchison Holdings, led by Li Ka-shing's UK carrier Three, is cutting 280 jobs, about 7% of its workforce, as part of a restructuring effort. The move affects head-office staff in the UK and comes amid a decline in revenue due to the pandemic and Hong Kong unrest. This is the second major cost-cutting measure by the company this year, following a 29% profit drop in the first half. The decision is part of the company's efforts to implement "stringent but flexible" cost controls.

site_title: India's coronavirus cases pass five million
summary: India's coronavirus cases have surpassed 5 million, with a record 90,000 new cases and 1,290 deaths reported on Wednesday. The country is experiencing one of the world's fastest-growing pandemic outbreaks, with experts warning that the true number of infections may be much higher due to inadequate testing and poor healthcare infrastructure. Despite a strict lockdown imposed in March, the virus has spread rapidly, infecting millions and causing significant economic damage, with India's GDP slumping nearly 24% in the first quarter.

images.alt_text: India's total coronavirus cases passed five million on Wednesday, health ministry data showed, as the pandemic extends its grip on the vast country at an ever-faster rate.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS says time to relook Singapore office Reits as China tech firms spur demand
summary: DBS Group Research has reiterated its positive stance on Singapore office Reits, citing expansion plans of Chinese tech giants such as Tencent, Alibaba, and ByteDance. The analysts see this as an inflection point, with the sector trading at a price to net asset value ratio of 0.8 times. They advise investors to "watch out" for this development, which could spur demand for Singapore office Reits.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open Wednesday's session with fresh gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose in early trade on Wednesday, extending a four-day rally, driven by a positive lead from Wall Street. The Hang Sang Index increased 0.37% to 24,823.96, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains. Traders await the conclusion of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting, which may impact global markets.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower ahead of Federal Reserve decision, new Japan PM
summary: Tokyo shares fell 0.10% to 23,431.16 ahead of a Federal Reserve decision, while Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's successor prepares to take office. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index lost 23.73 points. This move comes as investors shy away from major moves due to uncertainty.

site_title: TPG nears deal for Preferred Apartment's student-housing arm: sources
summary: Private equity firm TPG Capital is in advanced talks to acquire a student housing portfolio from Preferred Apartment Communities, valued at approximately $480 million. The portfolio consists of eight properties serving schools including Florida State University, Baylor University, and Arizona State University. Preferred Apartment's shares spiked 7.2% before paring gains. The deal is not final and talks could still fall apart, following a recent surge in the company's stock price. TPG's potential bet on student housing comes amid pandemic-related turbulence in the education sector.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, DBS, OCBC, Singapore Airlines, ESR-Reit, Sabana Reit, Q&M Dental
summary: Singapore banks UOB, DBS, and OCBC are sticking to staffing plans despite managing staff costs amid the country's recession. UOB has implemented a wage freeze. Analysts remain optimistic about UOB's organic wealth management play. Singapore Airlines is laying off staff, including cadet pilots and cabin crew trainees. ESR-Reit and Sabana Reit have seen increased investment, with Quarz Capital raising its stake in Sabana Reit. Q&M Dental Group has been granted a licence to operate a clinical laboratory.

site_title: Snowflake prices IPO above marketed range at US$120 a share: sources
summary: Snowflake, a cloud-data software maker, priced its initial public offering (IPO) at US$120 a share, above the marketed range of US$100 to US$110. The company, valued at over US$33 billion, is the biggest US IPO this year, excluding a US$4 billion offering by a special purpose acquisition company. Snowflake's shares are expected to begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol SNOW, following a successful private funding round and commitments from Warren Buffett and Salesforce Ventures.

site_title: Madonna to direct own biopic
summary: Madonna is set to direct her own biopic, with Universal Studios on board. The 62-year-old singer, actress, and cultural icon will co-write the screenplay with Diablo Cody. The film aims to showcase her "incredible journey" as an artist, musician, and human being, with a focus on music. Madonna has previously directed and co-written films like "W.E." and has sold 335 million albums worldwide, solidifying her status as a cultural icon. The project's release date has not been announced.

site_title: Propnex to roll out S$7.3m career enhancement package for agents
summary: PropNex Realty, a subsidiary of PropNex Limited, will launch a S$7.3 million career enhancement package for its 8,700 sales agents, aiming to equip them with skills for the "new norms" of the real estate industry. The package includes digital transformation tools, training subsidies, and expenses support. PropNex also announced a partnership with Mediacorp and 99.co to host the Singapore Property Show 2020 virtually, showcasing 20 new projects and offering webinars on the property market and investment strategies.

site_title: Singapore shares edge up at Wednesday's open; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 7.65 points or 0.3% to 2,493.48, with gains outnumbering losses 79 to 33. China Environment Resources led the gainers, up 23.1% after 18.7 million shares traded. Sembcorp Marine also rose 1.2%, while local lenders UOB, DBS, and OCBC fell. The market showed resilience despite global economic uncertainty, with tech shares on Wall Street and European shares reaching three-week highs.

site_title: Oracle 'very close' to deal on TikTok: Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump announced that Oracle is "very close" to a deal to become the US partner to Chinese-owned video app TikTok, aiming to avert a potential ban in the US. The deal, set to be finalized ahead of a deadline, would make Oracle a "trusted technology provider" for TikTok. This move comes after US officials confirmed the partnership, which aims to address national security concerns surrounding the app. A decision on the deal's approval is expected soon.

site_title: UN aviation task force eyes recommendation on Covid-19 testing by late October: sources
summary: A United Nations-led aviation task force is set to recommend by late October the use of Covid-19 testing as an alternative to 14-day quarantines for air travelers. The task force, led by the International Civil Aviation Organization, aims to reduce long quarantine requirements that have decimated air travel. Airlines and airports have asked for the task force to recommend countries accept negative PCR tests from passengers within 48 hours of travel from high Covid-19 infection rates. The recommendation is non-binding and may be delayed, but could help revive air travel.

site_title: Apple bundles TV, music, news and more in services push
summary: Apple has introduced an Apple One subscription bundle, starting at $15 monthly, which includes Apple Music, Apple TV+, Apple Arcade, and iCloud storage, as well as a new fitness service tied to Apple Watch. The bundle also offers an upgraded option with Apple News+ and additional cloud storage. Apple's efforts to emphasize digital content and services come as the global smartphone market slows. The company also unveiled new smartwatches, including the Series 6, and an eighth-generation iPad with the A12 Bionic chip. Analysts expect Apple's focus on services to drive success, despite the delayed release of the iPhone 5G.

site_title: FedEx wrings out profit as pandemic-fueled e-commerce deliveries surge
summary: FedEx reported a 60% jump in fiscal first-quarter adjusted net income to $1.28 billion, driven by price hikes, lower fuel costs, and efficiency gains. The surge in e-commerce deliveries, a pandemic-fueled trend, contributed to a 31% increase in average daily package volume for FedEx Ground. Revenue per package rose 2% to $9.33, and shares jumped 7.6% to $254.66 in extended trading. FedEx attributed the improvement to investments in automated sorting centers and route optimization, which reduced costs.

site_title: Disneyland and California theme parks push for reopening
summary: Disneyland and other California theme parks are urging officials to set health criteria for reopening, warning tens of thousands of jobs are at stake. Six months after 30 amusement parks closed due to Covid-19, the parks have implemented robust measures to protect visitors and staff. The California Parks and Attractions Association has called for guidance from the state, citing lost tax revenue and permanent closures of nearby local businesses. The parks, including Disneyland, are ready to reopen responsibly, following successful reopenings in the US and globally.

site_title: US removes 10% tariff on Canadian aluminum
summary: The US has lifted a 10% tariff on Canadian aluminum imports, following consultations with the Canadian government. The US Trade Representative stated that trade in non-alloyed, unwrought aluminum is likely to normalize in the last four months of 2020, with imports expected to decline sharply. The tariff, imposed in August, was a result of retaliatory measures taken by Canada in response to US tariffs on aluminum and steel. The decision is seen as a positive step towards normalizing trade relations between the two countries.

site_title: H&M cuts ties with Chinese supplier over accusations of 'forced labour'
summary: H&M has ended its relationship with a Chinese yarn producer, Huafu's factory in Anhui, due to accusations of "forced labour" involving ethnic and religious minorities from China's Xinjiang province. The company had denied having a direct relationship with the factory, but acknowledged an indirect business relationship with a mill in Shangyu, Zhejiang province. H&M will phase out its indirect business relationship with Huafu Fashion within the next 12 months. This move comes amid international pressure on China over its actions in Xinjiang, with the US and EU expressing concerns about forced labor.

site_title: Singapore must remain open to benefit from Asia's growth: Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of Singapore remaining open to Asia's growth, while forging new partnerships and evolving its approaches. The government is adjusting employment policies, upskilling workers, and strengthening social safety nets to ensure they serve the interests of Singaporeans. With the global economy facing its worst recession in a century, Heng highlighted the need for regional cooperation and bilateral relationships to promote resilience and emerge stronger from the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Women and Asian medics vulnerable to badly fitting masks: report
summary: A report published in the journal Anaesthesia found that women healthcare workers and medical staff with Asian heritage are more likely to be using face masks that don't fit properly, increasing their vulnerability to infection. The report emphasizes the importance of a tight facial seal for effective protection, citing lower fit-test success rates for women and Asians. In the US, a fit-test panel used to assess N95 masks has limited representation of women and Asians, leading to concerns about inadequate testing.

site_title: It's time to catalyse capital to boost biomed sector
summary: Singapore faces challenges in boosting its biomedical sector despite long-term investments in science. The country's R&D spending has risen to S$1.5 billion since 2002, but it still struggles with internal and external challenges. China has set its sights on drug development, with nearly all pharmaceutical labs setting up R&D centres in the country. Singapore's private biotech sector also faces difficulties in early-stage development, hindering the country's growth in the post-Covid era.

site_title: Woods has an uphill task
summary: Tiger Woods, a key figure in golf's popularity and prize money, continues to hold a significant influence over the sport. His longtime rival Phil Mickelson recently praised Woods for his impact on golf, stating that no one has benefited more from it. Woods' aura of authority and dominance on the golf course have contributed to his enduring appeal, with Mickelson acknowledging the significant role he has played in the sport's growth.

site_title: Analysts keep faith with UOB's organic wealth management play
summary: Analysts maintain UOB's conservative wealth management strategy, citing a smaller and organically built franchise compared to peers. Despite this, UOB's Q2 wealth management fee income accounts for 16.5% of its non-interest income, similar to DBS. Industry observers prioritize capital conservation during the pandemic, suggesting no need for a strategy overhaul. UOB's focus on fee income and conservative approach are seen as suitable for the current market environment.

site_title: Q&M unit gets lab licence to conduct testing services for Covid-19
summary: A subsidiary of Q&M Dental Group, Acumen Diagnostics, has received a healthcare institution licence to conduct SARS-CoV-2 PCR testing services for Covid-19 in Singapore. Acumen Diagnostics, a joint venture between Q&M and scientist Ong Siew Hwa, will use its Acu-Corona 2.0 Covid-19 PCR test kits. The company has passed an external quality assurance program and has received provisional authorization for its test. This move marks an expansion of Covid-19 testing services in Singapore.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Keppel Corp's associate Floatel International has extended its forbearance agreement with bondholders to September 30, from September 15. The company also entered a joint venture with Liquid Group to develop a customer reward program for Keppel Group entities. In other news, Axington's controlling shareholder Dorr Global Healthcare disclosed its latest shareholding, and Tritech Group's potential placement with Chinese companies has been delayed to December 15 due to COVID-19 delays.

site_title: S-Reit perps market reviving; year-to-date issues total S$575m
summary: Demand is returning to Singapore-listed real estate investment trust (S-Reit) perpetual securities, with year-to-date issuances totaling S$575 million. The low interest rate environment and market rebound have revived the market, which was earlier halted by S-Reits' heightened volatility and uncertainty over cash flow. DBS analysts expect this to bring about 1-1.9% accretion to distributions for the affected S-Reits, and potentially encourage other S-Reits to refinance their instruments at the call dates.

site_title: Singapore banks stick to hiring plans even as UOB freezes wages
summary: Singapore banks, including UOB, DBS, and OCBC, have maintained their staffing plans despite the country's recession. UOB has frozen wages but will continue hiring for strategic roles, while DBS and OCBC remain committed to hiring 2,000 and 3,000 people, respectively, by the end of the year. The banks are prioritizing cost management while investing in employee reskilling and upskilling to support their customers and stakeholders during the challenging economic times.

site_title: Oil rises over 2% as US Gulf Coast braces for hurricane
summary: Oil prices rose 2.3% on Tuesday, with Brent crude at $40.53 a barrel and US WTI crude futures at $38.28 a barrel, due to hurricane supply disruptions in the US Gulf Coast. Over a quarter of offshore oil and gas production was shut, and key exporting ports were closed. Despite concerns about demand, the increase was largely driven by the storm's impact. Energy industry forecasters predicted a slower-than-expected recovery from the pandemic.

site_title: US: Tech leads as stocks again end higher
summary: US stocks ended higher on Tuesday, with tech shares leading the way, as markets recovered from a two-week slide. The Nasdaq Composite Index rose 1.2% to 11,190.32, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 gained 0.2% and 0.5% respectively. Apple's new product launch, including a smartwatch and subscription service, was met with a "sell the event" reaction, but the market is looking ahead to a Fed meeting, where Chair Jerome Powell is expected to maintain an accommodative stance.

site_title: Messi tops football's rich list, ahead of rival Ronaldo
summary: Lionel Messi tops Forbes' rich list, surpassing rival Cristiano Ronaldo with estimated earnings of $126 million this year, largely from his salary ($92 million) and endorsements ($34 million). A contract dispute earlier this month may have hindered a potential move away from Barcelona, but Messi's wealth remains unchanged.

site_title: Japan's exports extend double-digit declines as pandemic hits demand
summary: Japan's exports declined 14.8% year-on-year in August, marking the sixth straight month of double-digit drops due to the pandemic's impact on global demand. This decline, although smaller than expected, highlights Prime Minister-elect Yoshihide Suga's challenge in driving an economic recovery. Exports to the US fell 21.3% and to Asia declined 7.8%, while imports dropped 20.8%, resulting in a trade surplus of 248.3 billion yen.

images.alt_text: Japan's exports posted a double-digit slump for a sixth straight month in August as US-bound shipments shrank due to a global demand slowdown from the coronavirus pandemic, casting a shadow over a trade-led recovery from the deep recession.

site_title: Wuhan film captures horror and humanity at coronavirus ground zero
summary: A documentary film, "76 Days," captures the horror and humanity of the early days of the COVID-19 pandemic in Wuhan, China. Shot in a claustrophobic style without voice-over or interviews, the film features harrowing footage of doctors and patients during the city's draconian lockdown. The documentary's director, Hao Wu, was motivated by his grandfather's death due to cancer complications during the outbreak. The film premieres at the Toronto film festival and focuses on personal stories of tragedy, bravery, hope, and despair, rather than politics or blame.

site_title: SingPost simplifies pricing for packages; analysts mixed on impact
summary: SingPost has simplified pricing for its local deliveries and international deliveries, with a flat fee for local packages and cheaper rates for most international customers. The changes take effect on October 15, with prices ranging from S$0.90 to S$3.50 for local packages, and S$3 for tracked packages. International deliveries will be revised into four weight tiers, with pricing ranging from S$2kg to S$20kg. The move aims to enhance customer convenience and competitiveness ahead of the year-end peak shopping season.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 hits near 3-week high as retail, mining stocks climb
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index closed near a three-week high on Tuesday, driven by robust industrial output data from China boosting mining and luxury stocks. Retail stocks rose 2.3%, with H&M surging 10.8% after beating quarterly profit forecasts. The index also gained 0.7%, led by mining, luxury, and healthcare sectors. The ZEW economic research institute reported unexpectedly rising investor sentiment in Germany, signaling confidence in a recovery from the coronavirus crisis.

site_title: Federal Reserve begins meeting as Congress pushes for new US stimulus
summary: The Federal Reserve's rate-setting committee began a two-day meeting as Congress pushes for new US stimulus to aid the battered economy. Despite the Fed's near-zero lending rate, lawmakers have stalled on a new bill, with Fed Chair Jerome Powell emphasizing the economy's need for more support. Talks between Democrats and Republicans have stalled, and the Fed is unlikely to change its lending rate. The economic downturn has been exacerbated by the coronavirus pandemic, and policymakers are under pressure to address the issue.

site_title: Marketing - the guardian of business reputation
summary: A second wave of Covid-19 infections is prompting businesses to reassess their strategies and prioritize growth. Despite the disruption, marketing remains crucial in building and protecting a company's reputation. Many businesses are at risk of hibernation, but those that lean forward during tough times and invest in marketing and R&D are more likely to succeed. According to studies by Harvard Business Review and Bain, companies that strike a balance between cost-cutting and investment in marketing and R&D tend to thrive during crises. Effective marketing can help businesses navigate difficult times, shape a recovery strategy, and seize new opportunities.

site_title: H&M expects profit to surge past analysts' expectations
summary: H&M reported a surge in profit, exceeding analysts' expectations, with pre-tax earnings reaching 2 billion kronor (S$311 million) in the three months through August. Revenue fell 16% to 50.9 billion kronor, but the company attributed the earnings to revenue exceeding expectations and more sales at full price. H&M's inventory buildup remains a concern, but the company's temporary store closures and well-received collections helped improve sales. The retailer's shares rose 13% in Stockholm, and analysts expect a significant recovery in sales over the coming six to nine months.

site_title: Chinese owners revive Thomas Cook as online-only holiday brand
summary: Chinese company Fosun Tourism Group has revived Thomas Cook as an online-only travel brand, one year after its collapse left thousands stranded. The new Thomas Cook will sell holidays to destinations on Britain's safe travel corridor list, including Italy, Greece, and Turkey. The company's UK CEO, Alan French, acknowledged the pandemic's timing poses short-term challenges but Fosun is taking a long-term view. The brand will operate under Atol protection, giving customers confidence in their bookings. The relaunch in Britain aims to support the brand's growth in China.

site_title: Temasek to take majority stake in micro-irrigation firm
summary: Temasek, a Singapore state investor, has agreed to acquire a majority stake in Rivulis, an Israel-headquartered micro-irrigation firm. The acquisition, subject to government authorization, is expected to be completed in Q4 2020. This deal marks Temasek's entry into the micro-irrigation market, expanding its portfolio of global investments.

site_title: Johnson's lawbreaking Brexit bill passes first Commons hurdle
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson's Brexit divorce deal plan, the Internal Market Bill, passed the first hurdle in Parliament with 340 votes in favor and 263 against. Senior members of Johnson's own party denounced the move, but it will proceed to the next stage. The bill's passage marks a significant step towards the UK renegeing on part of the Brexit agreement.

images.alt_text: Mr Johnson may face more rebellion as the bill passes through the Commons.

site_title: STI inches up ahead of Fed policy meeting
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.13% to 2,485.83, with Sembcorp Industries leading the gain, up 3.36%. Sembmarine, the company's former offshore arm, found a floor after several days of decline, ending 0.62% higher. IEV Holdings jumped 29.41% after announcing plans to sell its main operating unit for S$200,000. The US Federal Reserve policy meeting, scheduled for Wednesday, is expected to maintain its dovish stance.

site_title: Razer's data leak may have affected 100,000 customers globally
summary: Razer confirmed a data leak potentially affecting 100,000 global customers, exposing personal information, order details, and shipping information. The breach was caused by a server misconfiguration, discovered by cyber security consultant Volodymyr Diachenko on Aug 18. Credit card numbers and passwords were safe. Razer fixed the issue on Sept 9 and notified affected customers. Singapore's Personal Data Protection Commission is investigating the incident.

site_title: Germany has more pressing concerns than Brexit
summary: Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel has more pressing foreign policy concerns than Brexit, according to diplomatic sources. Top issues include Russia, COVID-19, the eastern Mediterranean, the US election, and China. The poisoning of Russian opposition activist Alexei Navalny has strained relations with Moscow, and Merkel is considering a reversal of Germany's Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline policy. The US presidential election is also a major concern, with a victory for Joe Biden seen as a chance to revive the western alliance. Germany sees a world of rogue superpowers threatening European unity and is working to maintain European cooperation to address global challenges.

site_title: Limber up your investment portfolio for health and wealth
summary: The worldwide wellness movement is a growing trend that investors cannot ignore. Companies like Beyond Meat and Impossible Foods are benefiting from the increased demand for plant-based foods, with sales jumping 35% during the Covid-19 pandemic. Traditional food and beverage companies, such as Starbucks and Burger King, are also pivoting towards healthier choices. The trend is expected to continue as consumers become more aware of the impact of sugar on their health, with governments considering "sugar taxes" on corporations. Investing in companies that cater to the healthy lifestyle theme is seen as a way to enjoy large returns as the world's population ages and governments emphasize staying healthy.

site_title: We need to talk about liquidity
summary: Singapore's public companies face a liquidity crisis amid the COVID-19 pandemic, with many struggling to secure strong shareholder support for recapitalizations. The Singapore government's Solidarity Budget has provided support, but with government aid unlikely to continue indefinitely, companies are seeking alternative ways to shore up their balance sheets. A rights issue can help, but it requires clear communication about the company's reasons for recapitalizing and its long-term growth prospects. Companies must articulate a compelling investment case and engage with shareholders, media, and other stakeholders to secure support for their recapitalization plans.

images.alt_text: As demonstrated by SIA, a positive shareholder vote and the announcement of a successful, oversubscribed rights issue is a ringing endorsement of a company's management and of its strategy to secure the long-term viability of the business.

site_title: In-form Johnson and Rahm stand out among 144 golfers
summary: World No.1 Dustin Johnson is favored to win the US Open at Winged Foot Golf Club, having recently claimed the Northern Trust Championship and Tour Championship. Johnson's impressive form, combined with his power and accuracy, make him the top contender. However, Spaniard Jon Rahm and Northern Ireland's Rory McIlroy, as well as American Justin Thomas, are also strong contenders, having demonstrated their skills in recent tournaments. Other notable players, such as Xander Schauffele and Webb Simpson, will also be vying for the title, which could be a closely contested event.

site_title: S'pore Convention on Mediation timely and critical to businesses, trade
summary: The Singapore Convention on Mediation, a UN treaty, has taken effect, providing a framework for businesses to resolve cross-border disputes through mediation. The convention, signed by 53 countries, including the US, China, and India, simplifies enforcement of mediated settlement agreements across borders, saving time and costs. This move aims to promote mediation as a dispute resolution option for businesses, allowing them to cultivate long-term relationships without resorting to litigation. The convention is seen as a significant step forward for mediation in the global arena, offering a more stable environment for businesses.

site_title: Wall Street firms make slow march back to the office
summary: Wall Street firms are slowly returning to their offices, with SL Green Realty Corp's new skyscraper, One Vanderbilt, set to open this week. Despite the pandemic, demand for office space in Manhattan has dropped, but many companies, including JPMorgan Chase, are encouraging employees to return. Productivity may have slipped among younger employees, with some firms citing a need for creative ideas and collaboration. American Express has reopened offices in New York, while WeWork is offering flexible options for staff.

site_title: Insurance companies face Covid-19 hit as UK court ruling favours clients
summary: A UK court has ruled in favour of policyholders on most issues in a dispute over Covid-19 claims, affecting eight insurers including Hiscox, RSA Insurance Group, and Zurich Insurance Group. The ruling could lead to further payouts, with estimated losses less than £100 million for Hiscox. The decision provides clarity for businesses and insurers handling business interruption claims, but the ruling can be appealed, potentially affecting the health of the UK economy. Insurers are expected to reexamine thousands of claims and may need to increase capital to cover potential losses.

site_title: Tencent picks Singapore as its Asia hub after US, India bans
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd has chosen Singapore as its Asia hub, following setbacks in the US and India. The company is recruiting for various positions, including tech and business development, at its new office in Singapore. This move comes as China's tech behemoths turn to South-east Asia due to growing hostility from the US and other major markets. Singapore's advanced financial and legal system, and its diplomatic stance, make it an attractive location for both Western and Chinese corporations.

site_title: China brokerage upstart East Money now bigger than Credit Suisse
summary: East Money, a Chinese online brokerage, has surpassed Credit Suisse in market value, with shares rising 78% this year to over $40 billion. Founded by Qi Shi in 2005, the firm has found success among tech-savvy youth, with revenue and net income more than doubling in the first half of 2020. East Money's unique business model, offering financial data and brokerage services, has earned it a strong following among Chinese investors, with 28 of 31 analysts following the firm having a buy rating.

site_title: Auction prices that take your breath away
summary: Contemporary artists aged 40 and under are achieving record-breaking prices at auctions, often before achieving solo museum shows. Artists like Nicolas Party, Matthew Wong, Julie Curtiss, Michael Armitage, and Amoako Boafo have seen their works sell for millions, with some fetching over $1 million in their first appearance. Experts attribute the surge to increased global buyers with deeper pockets, as well as a shift in tastes towards figural styles. However, high prices can lead to speculation and instability in the market, with galleries introducing contractual restrictions to limit "flipping" and protect young artists.

site_title: Geylang clan association building for sale with S$36m guide price
summary: A freehold 8-storey building at 26 Lorong 27A Geylang in Singapore is up for sale via expression of interest with a guide price of S$36 million. The building, which houses Nanyang Pho Leng Hui Kuan, a Chinese clan association, has a gross floor area of about 26,205 sq ft and sits on a 9,360 sq ft land plot. The sale represents a rare opportunity for buyers to acquire a freehold building with extensive redevelopment. The property is expected to attract keen interest due to its condition and location in the Geylang/Paya Lebar area.

site_title: No silver lining for Singtel, StarHub's pay-TV subscriptions
summary: Singapore's pay-TV sector is expected to continue its downward trend, with Fitch Solutions predicting 460,660 subscriptions by end-2029, down from 704,000 in 2020. The proliferation of over-the-top (OTT) streaming services and low mobile data costs are driving consumers to cut the cord, with sports programming being a key draw for pay-TV services. Netflix is expected to dominate the Singapore OTT video space, with its content portfolio and no-contract model being a major differentiator.

site_title: SIA laying off cadet pilots, cabin crew trainees
summary: Singapore Airlines is laying off its cadet pilots and cabin crew trainees due to a surplus of staff numbers. Over 400 trainees, with about half dismissed, will complete their training and be released. Retained cadet pilots will be on no-pay leave until the overseas training segment resumes. The airline is cutting 4,300 positions through various means, including a review of its network, which has led to the permanent suspension of services to Canberra, Dusseldorf, Stockholm, and Wellington.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 19.92 points to 1,531.28. Volume was 8.846 billion lots worth RM5.452 billion, with 648 gainers outnumbering 480 losers.

site_title: Investors push back on emerging Asia's record borrowing spree
summary: Bond investors in emerging Asia's top markets are rebelling against record government borrowing, a concerning sign for policymakers seeking to boost economic growth through fiscal stimulus. In India, yields surged to a two-year high, while Indonesia's latest bond auction drew the fewest bids since April. Similarly, South Korea's bond rates jumped to their highest level in five months. This trend suggests investors are losing appetite for government debt, potentially limiting policymakers' ability to finance economic growth.

site_title: Former Ghosn aide Greg Kelly pleads not guilty as trial opens
summary: Greg Kelly, a former aide to Nissan's ex-CEO Carlos Ghosn, pleaded not guilty to a charge of financial misconduct in Tokyo. Kelly, who faces up to 10 years in prison, denies any wrongdoing, arguing that no final agreement was made on post-retirement pay. Nissan, which pleaded guilty to the charge, says it illegally concealed payments of around $118 million promised to Ghosn. The trial, expected to last 10 months, centers around the question of whether Kelly and Nissan concealed payments from 2010 to 2018.

site_title: Sembcorp and Google sign multi-year renewable energy deal
summary: SEMBCORP Industries has signed a multi-year renewable energy deal with Google to provide locally-sourced renewable power for Google Singapore's operations. The deal supports Google's goal of powering its data centres with carbon-free electricity by 2030. The partnership aims to reduce Google's reliance on non-renewable energy sources and contribute to Singapore's renewable energy goals.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp Industries has signed a multi-year renewable energy deal to provide a total energy solution to tech giant Google. The deal includes energy generated from the rooftop solar installations of close to 500 public housing flats.

site_title: Recession? 2020 new home sales could top 2019's
summary: Singapore's private home market showed resilience in August, with 1,256 homes sold, a 16% increase from July. This is the fourth consecutive month of growth since the circuit breaker in April. Analysts predict that 2020 transactions may exceed 2019's 9,912, driven by stable sectors such as technology and digitalization. The market's buoyancy is attributed to cautious optimism among buyers, including those in stable employment and HDB homeowners looking to upgrade. New home sales are expected to remain positive until December, with some analysts projecting sales close to or exceeding 9,912 units.

site_title: Western banks missing out on fee bonanza from China's STAR Market IPOs
summary: Western banks are missing out on fee opportunities from China's STAR Market IPOs due to limited local presence and concerns about a unique co-investment rule. The STAR Market has seen $10.3 billion raised via IPOs from January to July, with companies paying an average of nearly 6% in fees. Chinese banks have led the majority of deals, and Western banks like UBS Group AG are struggling to compete. The co-investment rule requires lead underwriters to buy 2-5% of stock and hold it for two years, which is considered risky in volatile markets.

site_title: Data of Razer customers, potentially 100,000 individuals globally, exposed
summary: A server misconfiguration at gaming firm Razer exposed potentially 100,000 global customers' data, including personal info, order details, and shipping information. However, credit card numbers and passwords remained secure. The data breach was discovered on August 18 by cyber security consultant Volodymyr Diachenko. Razer has not commented on the incident.

site_title: Two land parcels for food farming up for sale by tender: SFA
summary: The Singapore Food Agency (SFA) has launched two land parcels for food farming at Lim Chu Kang and Sungei Tengah through public tender. Parcel LCK 114C is for general agriculture and occupies 10,000 sq m, while Parcel ST35A is for vegetable farming and spans 11,917 sq m. The 20-year lease terms are available for proposals that can achieve high production levels sustainably, with a focus on technology and innovation. The tenders aim to support Singapore's "30 by 30" goal, aiming for 30% of nutritional needs to be produced locally by 2030.

site_title: Caution should prevail on restarting cruises
summary: A cruise industry expert warns that caution should prevail when restarting cruises, citing past safety concerns and poor working conditions for seafarers. The expert, who has written extensively on cruise ship dangers, references Captain Michael Lloyd's report on the Costa Concordia disaster. They express skepticism over contracts and conditions for crew members, highlighting the need for greater transparency and accountability in the industry. The expert's comments come as the cruise industry begins to reopen after a pandemic-induced hiatus.

site_title: US violated trade rules with tariffs on China, WTO says
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) has ruled that the US violated trade rules by imposing tariffs on Chinese goods in 2018. The WTO panel said the US did not meet its burden of demonstrating that the tariffs were provisionally justified. The decision bolsters China's claims that the US tariffs broke international rules, particularly the most-favored treatment provision and a key dispute-settlement rule. The US can appeal the decision within 60 days, but the WTO's appellate body has been paralyzed, rendering the decision toothless.

site_title: Singapore still falling short for home-grown biotechs seeking IPO
summary: Singapore's biotech companies are facing challenges in going public on the local exchange, the Singapore Exchange (SGX), due to strict listing requirements, low liquidity, and a lack of institutional investor pool. Industry players prefer to list on the Nasdaq or Hong Kong Stock Exchange, citing the need for a deeper research ecosystem and more investors who understand the complexities of biotech. Despite efforts to attract biotech companies, the SGX has only eight pharmaceutical and biotech companies listed, with a combined market cap of US$28.6 billion, and faces stiff competition from other markets in the region.

site_title: Another fire in Beirut unnerves shattered residents
summary: A fire broke out in a landmark building in Beirut's commercial district, the second blaze this month, sending shockwaves through the city still reeling from a massive port blast in August. The blaze, caused by an accident, was quickly extinguished with no immediate reports of casualties. Residents expressed frustration with the nation's economic crisis and lack of government progress, with many businesses already driven out of the city centre. France continues to pressure Lebanon to form a new government to tackle corruption and implement reforms.

site_title: Potential Hyflux investor Pison says unsecured working group of seven creditor banks reluctant to engage it
summary: Potential Hyflux investor Pison Investments has received 158 tender application forms from creditors, but efforts to engage with the unsecured working group of seven banks have failed. Pison, which had made a formal cash offer for Hyflux's debts, has arranged a town hall meeting with noteholders to explain the key terms of the invitation. Despite the extended expiration deadline, Pison continues to receive submissions and may consider further extending it. Pison aims to complete the purchase of a significant portion of the eligible debt by Sept 25 and plans to facilitate a debt restructuring exercise for Hyflux's shareholders and stakeholders.

site_title: Jamie Dimon sees long-term damage if people don't get back to work
summary: JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon warned that prolonged remote work could cause long-term economic and social damage, including increased depression and overdose rates. He urged governments to cautiously reopen cities and encourage workers to return to offices. Dimon cited productivity losses and social problems exacerbated by extended lockdowns as reasons for his stance. JPMorgan plans to bring 50% of its workers back to New York offices, while other banks, such as Wells Fargo and BNY Mellon, have more cautious plans. Dimon believes "permanent changes" will occur as a result of the pandemic.

site_title: Quarz ups stake slightly in Sabana Reit
summary: Quartz Capital has increased its stake in Sabana Reit to 6% by purchasing 15,000 shares. The investment firm's chief investment officer, Jan Moermann, expressed opposition to the proposed merger between Sabana Reit and ESR Reit, citing concerns over ESR's high leverage ratio and potential land-lease term renewals. Moermann believes Sabana Reit can achieve significant DPU growth, exceeding 30%, on a standalone basis, and that the merger terms do not accurately reflect Sabana's historical trading performance.

site_title: Yuan surges to 16-month high on economic data
summary: The yuan surged to a 16-month high against the US dollar after Chinese data showed an economic recovery, with industrial output accelerating and retail sales growing for the first time this year. The Australian and New Zealand dollars also rose, while the US dollar fell. Investors are optimistic about a V-shaped global economic recovery, with hopes for a Covid-19 vaccine contributing to the positive sentiment.

site_title: JPMorgan cuts outlook for net interest income on lower rates
summary: JPMorgan has cut its forecast for net interest income in 2020 to $55 billion, down from an earlier estimate of $56 billion, due to lower interest rates. The bank expects $13 billion in net interest income per quarter in 2021. Trading revenue is expected to increase 20% from last year. This trend is attributed to banks earning less interest on loans while the Federal Reserve holds interest rates down to support the economy.

site_title: Turned pro in 2016, in world's top five within a year
summary: Jon Rahm, a 25-year-old professional golfer, credits Rolex for his success, having turned pro in 2016 and becoming one of the world's top five golfers within a year. Rahm expresses his admiration for Rolex's enduring support of golf, which began 50 years ago. He was the first signing without a Tour card and credits his management company's close relationship with Rolex for the opportunity. Rahm owns several Rolex watches, including the Oyster Perpetual Cosmograph Daytona and the Oystersteel blue-face Oyster Perpetual Sky-Dweller. He cites Phil Mickelson, a fellow Rolex Testimonee, as an inspiration, and has achieved phenomenal success in his golfing career, including reaching the top five in the world rankings.

site_title: Citi back to trimming jobs amid scrutiny on control lapses
summary: Citigroup will resume job cuts, affecting less than 1% of its global workforce, as the bank faces scrutiny over control lapses and revenue drop amid the ongoing pandemic. The cuts come despite recent hiring and a promise to maintain overall headcount. The bank is also facing public reprimands from the OCC and Fed due to continued infrastructure and control deficiencies. The reductions are part of efforts to improve risk controls and address years of expenses.

site_title: Soaring company share buybacks raises corporate leverage, warns BIS
summary: The Bank for International Settlements (BIS) warns that soaring company share buybacks have raised corporate leverage, contributing to business failures and downturns during the Covid-19 pandemic. Since 2010, corporate share buybacks have tripled, with US firms buying back $6 trillion in stock purchases. The BIS notes that high leverage, particularly among tech companies, may be out of step with economic reality, as stock prices have surged while corporate bond yields remain low. The BIS concludes that a divergence between elevated stock valuations and economic growth forecasts poses a danger, particularly in the current fragile economic recovery.

site_title: More capital flows into Asean amid pandemic and US-China tensions
summary: Capital inflows into the Asean region are expected to increase as companies diversify investments and supply chains amid US-China tensions. China's machinery exports to Asean countries are a leading indicator of this shift, with the region ramping up production capacity. Panellists at the FutureChina Global Forum noted that the trend is driven by the need for diversification in a post-pandemic world. This shift is also expected to impact global markets, with Citigroup setting a target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026.

site_title: How ByteDance's CEO baulked at selling TikTok's US business
summary: ByteDance CEO Yiming Zhang has dropped his pursuit of a sale of TikTok's US operations to Microsoft, instead opting for a partnership with Oracle Corp. Investors, including Sequoia and General Atlantic, were concerned about the financial hit of selling the app for less than its worth, leading Zhang to sell only a stake to Oracle. This decision comes amid pressure from the US and China, with President Trump threatening to ban TikTok in the US if ByteDance does not comply. The new deal would allow ByteDance to retain a minority stake in TikTok while addressing US security concerns, with Oracle taking over user data management and safety.

site_title: Green recovery is key to reviving virus-hit economies
summary: A low-carbon sustainable future is crucial for reviving virus-hit economies, with governments and private sectors collaborating to achieve climate goals. Countries like Singapore and Denmark are setting examples for a transition to a low-carbon future, with investments in research and development, carbon taxes, and green technologies. Governments can shape this transition by setting ambitious emissions-reduction targets, re-evaluating business conditions, and encouraging investment in innovative green technologies. Collaboration between governments and the private sector is key to developing and enabling decarbonisation plans, with public-private partnerships crucial for national-level change.

site_title: Mexico issues 'world's first' sovereign bond linked to UN sustainability goals
summary: Mexico has issued the world's first sovereign bond linked to UN sustainability goals, raising $1.2 billion. The 1.350% coupon is the second lowest among euro-denominated bonds issued by the Mexico federal government. The bond matures in 2027 and is part of a trend of debt issuance aimed at tackling social and environmental issues. The government did not specify how it would spend the funds, with no guarantee that disbursements would meet the UN characteristics. The bond was more than six times oversubscribed, tapping into international investment funds committed to sustainable development.

site_title: Funds and companies call for tougher 2030 EU climate target
summary: The European Union is facing pressure from investors and companies to set a more ambitious 2030 climate target of at least 55% emissions cut, warning that the current 40% target would fail to secure private financing. A report by the Institutional Investors Group on Climate Change states that this target is necessary to unlock private investment and meet the EU's goal of reaching net zero emissions by 2050. Over 120 business leaders and 30 investors have also backed the higher target, citing the need for green growth to drive Europe's economic recovery from the pandemic.

site_title: Keppel Corp unit in joint venture to develop customer reward programme
summary: Keppel Corp's unit Kepventure has entered a joint venture with Liquid Group to develop a customer reward programme for Keppel Group entities. Kepventure and Liquid Group subscribed for shares in the joint-venture company at S$1 per share, with no material impact on Keppel Corp's net tangible assets or earnings per share expected. Details on the programme's specifics were not provided.

site_title: China's industrial engine hums again as consumers open wallets
summary: China's economy rebounded in August with industrial output rising 5.6% and retail sales of consumer goods increasing 0.5% year-on-year, snapping a seven-month downturn. This growth is attributed to strong external demand, recovery from the pandemic, and pent-up demand from floods. Analysts expect a gradual recovery of the services sector and steady improvement in retail sales, but note that muted global demand and the US-China trade relationship may hamper China's economy in the near term.

images.alt_text: Part of the government's focus has been on supporting investments in telecommunications, such as rolling out 5G networks, which grew by 11.7 per cent in August.

site_title: EU parliament votes to make ships pay for their pollution
summary: The European Parliament has voted in favor of including greenhouse gas emissions from the maritime sector in the EU's carbon market starting from 2022. The move aims to make ships pay for their pollution as the EU seeks to become "climate neutral" by 2050. The EU parliament will formally approve its position with another vote on Wednesday. The plan, proposed by the European Commission, would expand the scheme to cover intra-EU maritime transport and international trips starting or finishing in an EU port, forcing shipowners to buy EU carbon permits to cover emissions.

site_title: US import prices beat expectations as inflation warms up
summary: US import prices rose 0.9% in August, beating expectations, as inflation pressures build. This increase follows July's revised 1.2% gain and July's 0.7% gain. Import prices excluding fuels and food accelerated 0.7% last month, while core import prices rose 0.9% in the 12 months through August. The US Federal Reserve is unlikely to be deterred from injecting more money into the economy to aid the recovery, despite firming inflation.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: New home sales in Singapore increased 16% in August, with 1,256 private homes sold. This follows the Hungry Ghost Festival and economic headwinds. Meanwhile, Vietnam was surprised by a Trump tariff announcement, seeking a lower rate. The Asian garment industry is bracing for higher US tariffs. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. The UK economy shrank for the second month, affecting UK Prime Minister Starmer's prospects.

images.alt_text: Including ECs, developers moved 1,307 units in August, up 14 per cent from 1,142 units in July and 12 per cent higher than the 1,168 units sold in August last year.

site_title: Hiap Seng Engineering and unit to go under judicial management
summary: MAINBOARD-listed Hiap Seng Engineering and its subsidiary HS Compression & Process (HSCP) will be placed under judicial management after having their applications granted by the High Court. The move comes after the companies posted a net profit of S$1.25 million for the first quarter, reversing a S$2.11 million net loss in the previous year. This judicial management decision is likely to have significant implications for the companies' operations and future prospects.

site_title: Auditor EY express 'regret' over failures after Wirecard collapse
summary: Ernst & Young expressed regret over its failure to uncover Wirecard's alleged fraud earlier, stating it "regretted" the delay in detecting the issue. The accounting firm acknowledged its failure to properly scrutinize Wirecard's accounts over several years, despite a policy of continuous improvement. Wirecard filed for bankruptcy in June after acknowledging 1.9 billion euros in non-existent assets. EY Chairman Carmine Di Sibio vowed to "raise the bar" to improve standards. The firm's letter to clients was first reported by The Financial Times.

site_title: GM explores market for electric 'flying cars'
summary: General Motors is exploring options for electric "flying cars" as part of its push for growth in related transportation markets. CEO Mary Barra mentioned the aerial taxi market in her first reference to the company's interest, citing the potential of its Ultium battery system. GM is weighing all options, including building, supplying, or partnering with other companies in the market, which is expected to face significant roadblocks to commercialization and profitability. The company could make an announcement early next year.

site_title: Half of SIA's over 400 trainee pilots and cabin crew let go, the rest will leave after completing training
summary: Singapore Airlines has let go of about half of its 400 trainee pilots and cabin crew, approximately 200, due to the severe downturn in the aviation industry caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. The remaining trainees will complete their training and then be released. The airline will not be able to retain them due to the current surplus staff numbers. Retrenched workers will receive their salaries until December 15 and retain medical benefits until then. SIA will be open to hiring them if demand for air travel returns to pre-Covid levels.

site_title: Amazon makes new upscale move with 'Luxury Stores'
summary: Amazon has launched 'Luxury Stores', a new online shopping experience for high-end brands, including Oscar de la Renta.
