The portal will offer 360-degree views, improved graphics, and a "store within a store" feature, allowing brands to control their inventory and pricing. The luxury stores will be invitation-only for Amazon Prime members, building on the company's success in boosting online sales during the coronavirus pandemic. The move aims to create an elevated customer experience for luxury brands and their customers.

site_title: US manufacturing production rises in August, but momentum slowing
summary: US factory production rose 1.0% in August for a fourth consecutive month, but the recovery is slowing due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and lack of fiscal stimulus. Manufacturing output remains 6.7% below its February level, and business spending on equipment has declined for five straight quarters. The Federal Reserve's policy meeting will focus on the ebbing economic recovery and firming inflation, with economists warning that the recovery may stall if no stimulus package is implemented.

site_title: South-east Asia conglomerates now underperform pure plays: report
summary: Conglomerates in South-east Asia are now underperforming pure play companies, marking a significant shift after 16 years of tracking, according to a report by Bain & Company. The report attributes this change to conglomerates' disadvantages, such as size and diversification, which have become liabilities rather than advantages. This marks the first time conglomerates have trailed pure plays in terms of total shareholder return since the report began tracking in 2004.

site_title: Pison receives 158 tenders from Hyflux creditors, puzzles over UWG's reluctance to engage
summary: Pison Investments, an Indonesian investment vehicle, has received 158 tender application forms from Hyflux creditors, but has yet to engage with the unsecured working group (UWG) of seven banks. Despite reaching out to the UWG members, they have refused to engage. Pison has proposed buying out the debt of the UWG members, offering a minimum discount of 91%. The company will review the submissions and determine which tenders to accept by September 25, with the goal of completing a debt restructuring exercise that is fair to all stakeholders.

site_title: Axington says late update on Dorr's latest shareholding is an 'administrative oversight'
summary: Axington's controlling shareholder Dorr Global Healthcare disclosed its 77.88% interest in the company following recent share placements, attributed to an "administrative oversight" in its initial announcement. Dorr acquired a 92.5% stake earlier this year, and trading in Axington's shares remains suspended. The placements were completed on August 17, but no mention was made of Dorr's new shareholding at the time. The company is controlled by cousins Nelson and Terence Loh, also co-founders of the scandal-hit Bellagraph Nova Group.

site_title: China's SMIC applies to renew licence to supply Huawei
summary: China's Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp (SMIC) has applied to renew its licence to supply Huawei Technologies, citing regulations, amid US restrictions that went into effect on Tuesday. The restrictions bar major semiconductor equipment vendors from supplying or servicing Huawei. SMIC, which generates 20% of its revenue from Huawei, relies on US equipment and may also cease servicing Huawei as the restrictions take effect. This move comes after Taiwanese chipmakers, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing and Micron Technology, announced they would no longer supply Huawei due to the restrictions.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end higher for a third straight session
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended higher for a third consecutive session, driven by vaccine hopes and improved economic data in China. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.38%, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices gained 0.51% and 0.74%, respectively. The gains come as investors look to the potential benefits of vaccination and China's economic recovery.

site_title: HKMA sells HK$2.7b into market after currency hits strong end of trading band
summary: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) sold HK$2.713 billion into the market on September 15, 2020, after the local currency reached the strong end of its trading band. The move aims to weaken the currency and keep it within the HK$7.75-HK$7.85 range to the US dollar. The aggregate balance will increase to HK$209.413 billion on September 17. This is part of the HKMA's efforts to manage the currency and maintain financial stability in Hong Kong.

site_title: Iskandar Waterfront targets US$1.2b IPO in first half of 2021
summary: Malaysian developer Iskandar Waterfront Holdings plans to list on the stock market in the first half of 2021 to raise at least RM5 billion (S$1.64 billion). The company has completed its initial deposit and advance payment, allowing it to start work on the Bandar Malaysia mega-project. The project, valued at RM20 billion, aims to serve as a terminus for a planned Kuala Lumpur-Singapore high-speed rail link. Iskandar Waterfront Holdings intends to submit its IPO application by the end of 2020 and target long-term institutional investors.

site_title: Hong Kong to open bars, pools and theme parks after mass testing
summary: Hong Kong has lifted restrictions on bars, pools, and theme parks after nearly 2 million people were tested for COVID-19, finding 42 cases. The city had previously reopened gyms and entertainment venues, increasing gathering limits to 4 people. Despite this, gatherings of more than 4 people remain banned, and public beaches are still closed. Hong Kong has reported 4,976 cases and 101 deaths, with new cases in the low single digits. Authorities have also allocated over HK$300 billion in support for struggling businesses.

site_title: US: Wall Street climbs at open as Fed meeting kicks off
summary: US stocks rose at the open on Tuesday as China's economic data boosted optimism for an economic rebound. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite opened higher, with gains of 0.52%, 0.71%, and 1.24%, respectively. Investors await the Federal Reserve's two-day meeting for potential stimulus.

site_title: Putin opponent Navalny posts photo from hospital, says he can breathe by himself
summary: Russian opposition politician Alexei Navalny, a key opponent of President Vladimir Putin, has posted a photo from a Berlin hospital showing him sitting up and breathing independently. Navalny was airlifted to Berlin after falling violently ill in Siberia and was later confirmed to have been poisoned with a Novichok nerve agent. Laboratory tests in three countries have confirmed the poisoning, prompting Western governments to demand an explanation from Russia. Navalny's recovery is seen as a significant development in the ongoing crisis.

site_title: Carousell to surpass US$900m valuation with Naver deal
summary: A consortium led by South Korean internet giant Naver has invested US$80 million in Carousell, valued at over US$900 million. The deal is a vote of confidence in the Singapore-headquartered classifieds platform. Carousell co-founder Quek Siu Rui expressed excitement to work closely with Naver, citing the company's focus on using technology to simplify and improve the buying and selling process. Naver's head of investments believes Carousell's platform will further consolidate its market leader position in the region.

site_title: STI ends Tuesday almost unchanged ahead of Fed policy meeting
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended Tuesday with a 0.13% gain, closing at 2,485.83, after US stocks had a firm overnight close. Sembcorp Industries led the gains, rising 3.36%, followed by Genting Singapore and Mapletree Industrial Trust. In the small-cap space, IEV Holdings jumped 29.41% after announcing plans to sell its main operating unit. The market awaits the US Federal Reserve policy meeting on Wednesday, expected to maintain its dovish stance.

site_title: Singapore trader Rhodium sued by Maybank for US$3m payment
summary: Rhodium Resources, a Singapore-based coal and grains trader, has been sued by Maybank for $3.16 million in unpaid bills of exchange. The lawsuit stems from Rhodium's failure to make payments for goods traded through Intra Asia Trading, a Singapore-based commodities trader. The move has exposed the risks of financing commodity trading to banks, which have been hit by a global wave of upheaval in the industry. Rhodium's founder, Srinivas Koneru, has not been accused of any wrongdoing.

site_title: Australia: Shares dip as banks drag; eyes on US Fed meeting
summary: Australian shares ended flat on Tuesday, weighed by the "Big Four" banks, which fell 1.4-1.9%. The Reserve Bank of Australia will maintain its "highly accommodative settings" and consider further policy measures to support the flagging economy. Minutes from the September meeting did not provide a clearer direction on policy actions, and investors will turn to the US Federal Reserve's meeting for further directions. The ASX 200 index ended 0.08% lower at 5,894.8.

site_title: UK jobless rate rises for first time since Covid-19 lockdown
summary: The UK's unemployment rate rose to 4.1% in July, the first increase since the COVID-19 lockdown in March. The rate is still below the 7.5% forecast by the Bank of England at the end of the year. Job losses were 36,000 in August, with 695,000 job losses between March and August. The government's job subsidy scheme is being wound down, and economists expect more job losses as it expires at the end of October. Finance Minister Rishi Sunak said protecting jobs is his top priority.

site_title: Quarz ups stake slightly in Sabana Reit, restates plan to vote down ESR-Reit merger
summary: Quartz Capital has increased its stake in Sabana Reit to 6% after buying 15,000 shares for S$5,625. The investment firm, along with Black Crane, plans to vote down the proposed merger between Sabana Reit and ESR-Reit at current terms. This move comes as the Singapore Exchange prepares to announce the transaction terms of the merger. Quartz's chief investment officer, Jan Moermann, reiterated the firm's intention to oppose the deal, citing concerns over its terms. The vote is expected to take place soon.

site_title: Mermaid Maritime exits Seadrill offshore drilling venture for US$31m
summary: Mermaid Maritime has sold its 33.76% stake in Asia Offshore Drilling (AOD) to Seadrill for $31 million in cash. The decision follows the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the offshore drilling industry, with a drought of new contracts and early terminations. Mermaid Maritime aims to minimize exposure to challenging industry conditions and protect its cash position. The deal provides additional working capital and enables the company to focus on growing its core and related businesses.

site_title: Sony cuts PS5 production forecast by 4m due to chip woes
summary: Sony has cut its estimated PlayStation 5 production forecast by 4 million units to around 11 million due to production issues with its custom-designed system-on-chip, affecting yields as low as 50%. The company had boosted orders in anticipation of holiday demand, but manufacturing issues have hindered production. This reduction may weigh on profit margins and component costs, with shares closing down 2.4% following the report.

site_title: SIA axes flights to Canberra, Dusseldorf, Stockholm and Wellington for good
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) permanently suspends flights to Canberra, Dusseldorf, Stockholm, and Wellington due to the coronavirus crisis. The airline will close stations in these cities and review its fleet and network plans to adapt to the "very different aviation landscape" caused by Covid-19. This decision comes as demand for air travel remains severely curtailed, with SIA experiencing a 92.2% decline in group passenger capacity and 98.3% decline in overall passenger carriage in August. SIA has also announced a 4,300 position cut, with 2,400 staff likely to face layoffs.

site_title: Klarna raises US$650m from Silver Lake-led investor group
summary: Klarna, a Swedish payment provider, raised US$650 million at a valuation of US$10.65 billion from a Silver Lake-led investor group. The new valuation is nearly double the US$5.5 billion valuation reached after the funding round in August last year. Existing investors, including Sequoia Capital and Commonwealth Bank of Australia, also participated in the round. Klarna plans to list in New York in the next two years and aims to expand its presence in the US and UK.

site_title: Temasek to acquire majority stake in Israeli micro-irrigation firm Rivulis
summary: Temasek, a Singapore state investor, has signed an agreement to acquire a majority stake in Rivulis, an Israeli micro-irrigation firm. The acquisition, subject to government authorisation, is expected to be completed in Q4 2020. Rivulis, which innovates smart micro and drip-irrigation solutions, aims to help growers achieve higher yields and sustainability. The deal aligns with Temasek's focus on sustainable living and agribusiness, and Rivulis's CEO, Richard Klapholz, is thrilled to have Temasek as its largest shareholder.

site_title: Keppel associate Floatel's creditors extend forbearance to end-September
summary: Keppel associate Floatel International has secured a forbearance agreement extension with creditors until September 30, following a previous extension to September 15. The agreement, made with an ad-hoc committee holding over 56% of the outstanding bonds, aims to provide temporary relief to the company. This move comes as part of Floatel's discussions with secured financial creditors.

site_title: Singapore must remain open to benefit from Asia's growth: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of Singapore remaining open to Asia's growth, while forging new partnerships and evolving its approaches. Despite the global recession and Covid-19 pandemic, Heng said Singapore can contribute to and benefit from Asia's growth by strengthening regional cooperation and bilateral relationships. The country is also exploring digital economy agreements and reopening its borders gradually. Heng noted that Asia's outlook remains bright due to strong economic fundamentals and that countries must remain open and connected to the world to remain vibrant.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rise at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Tuesday, following gains on Wall Street overnight and losses in Tokyo. London's FTSE 100 index climbed 0.4%, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices also gained 0.3% and 0.2% respectively.

site_title: UOB offers US$200m sustainability-linked loan to Wilmar International
summary: UOB has offered a US$200 million, two-year sustainability-linked loan to Wilmar International. The loan's interest rate will be pegged to Wilmar's achievement of predetermined targets in areas such as corporate governance, carbon emissions, and supply chain practices. Sustainalytics will assess Wilmar's performance annually. The loan aims to support Wilmar's commitment to sustainable operations and meeting global food demand without depleting resources.

site_title: China retail sales return to growth, economic recovery continues
summary: China's retail sales rose 0.5% in August, the first time since the pandemic, as the country's domestic consumer sector shows signs of recovery. Industrial output also strengthened, beating forecasts, and economists believe the economy is on a firmer footing. Despite international uncertainties and domestic structural problems, China's economy is expected to return to its pre-virus growth rate by the end of the year.

site_title: Tycoons line up to take their unloved companies private
summary: Billionaire owners of companies, including Japanese tycoon Masayoshi Son and French media magnate Patrick Drahi, are taking their firms private, avoiding volatile markets and vocal shareholders. This trend, up 2,500% from last year, reflects the financial benefits of staying private, including more flexibility and runway to execute plans. Companies like SoftBank Group, Altice Europe, and Rocket Internet are among those considering private deals, while private equity firms have largely stayed on the sidelines due to decreased dealmaking activity.

site_title: H&M returns to profit as decline in clothing sales moderates
summary: H&M has returned to profit in its fiscal third quarter, with pretax profit reaching about 2 billion kronor (S$311.2 million) despite a 16% decline in sales to 50.9 billion kronor. The company attributed the earnings to revenue exceeding expectations, well-received collections, and increased sales at full price. Following a temporary store closure, sales improved throughout the quarter, with only 200 stores remaining closed by the end of August. H&M shares have dropped 26% this year.

site_title: Seoul: Upbeat China data, vaccine hopes power shares to over 2-yr high
summary: South Korean shares reached a two-year high, closing at 2,443.58, driven by upbeat Chinese data and vaccine hopes. The Kospi index gained 15.67 points, or 0.65%, for a fourth consecutive session. Investors were influenced by China's industrial output growth and retail sales rise, while awaiting central bank policy decisions. Foreigners were net buyers of $214.27 million in US shares, contributing to the market's gains.

site_title: Singapore industry tie-up to offer asset management training
summary: The Wealth Management Institute (WMI) has launched an industry collaboration with the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and other firms to develop a talent pipeline for the growing asset management industry in Singapore. The collaboration aims to train 120 participants in the first year with a six to eight month program that combines on-the-job learning and rotations, and is supported by government schemes offering up to 80% funding for Singaporeans and permanent residents. The program aims to equip trainees with skills in areas such as valuation, portfolio construction, and data analysis.

site_title: Former Nissan executive Kelly's trial begins in Tokyo without Ghosn
summary: Former Nissan executive Greg Kelly's trial began in Tokyo without co-defendant Carlos Ghosn, who fled to Lebanon in 2018. Kelly denied charges of helping Ghosn hide income, stating he was not involved in a criminal conspiracy. Kelly faces up to 10 years in prison and a 10 million yen fine if found guilty. The trial is expected to take about a year and will include testimony from prominent company executives, shedding light on Nissan's inner workings.

site_title: Indonesia Parliament hears testimonies backing wider central bank mandate
summary: Indonesia's parliamentary committee heard expert testimonies calling for the expansion of Bank Indonesia's mandate to oversee economic growth, in addition to managing the rupiah. Experts, including a former finance ministry official and an economist, suggested BI take on macro-economic policy objectives to support economic growth and employment. However, concerns about undermining BI's independence and delaying debt monetization have raised concerns, with the rupiah experiencing pressure. The committee plans to integrate new recommendations into the bill, which is set for a parliamentary vote before October 9.

site_title: ComfortDelGro launches app for learners at driving centre
summary: ComfortDelGro has launched a new app called "myCDC" for learners at its driving centre, allowing users to book lessons, register for test dates, and track progress digitally. The app, available on Apple and Google stores, also enables users to cancel or reschedule bookings, top up accounts, and purchase merchandise. The launch follows the company's digital transformation efforts, which were accelerated by the COVID-19 pandemic. The app is now live, offering a range of services to learners of driving and biking.

site_title: Airbus offers exit bonus in bid to spur buyouts in France
summary: Airbus is offering French employees a two-month salary bonus to accept voluntary severance by the end of September, with the goal of reducing its workforce by 15,000 jobs. The company is also offering pension incentives for early retirement and top-up monthly wages for those moving to lower-paid jobs. Nearly 2,000 staff members have expressed interest in voluntary departure, and the company plans to update its exit package on September 24. Airbus aims to meet its job cuts target, despite CEO Guillaume Faury's warning that voluntary departures may not be enough.

site_title: SMU, Beyond Lab launch digital transformation programme for SME business leaders
summary: SMU and Beyond Lab launched "The Great Reset" programme, a digital transformation initiative for SME business leaders in Singapore. The five-week programme, offered complimentary, aims to equip participants with practical knowledge and strategies to help their businesses become more resilient and successful. The programme, targeting 60 SME leaders, includes virtual sessions and in-person workshops, with support from V3 Group and the Singapore Business Federation. The initiative follows the Covid-19 pandemic's disruption to businesses, highlighting the need for digitalisation and transformation.

site_title: Facebook launches climate science info centre amid fake news criticism
summary: Facebook has launched a climate science information center to combat misinformation on climate change. The center, available in the US, France, Germany, and the UK, features factual resources from leading climate organizations and actionable steps to combat climate change. The move comes amid criticism of Facebook's handling of climate-related misinformation, with the company exempting false claims about climate change from external fact-checking. Facebook's global policy chief Nick Clegg said the company will continue to exempt false claims made by politicians, citing the nature of political speeches.

site_title: US pulls back from broad import bans for cotton, tomatoes from China's Xinjiang
summary: The US has shelved plans for a broad import ban on cotton and tomato products from China's Xinjiang region, citing concerns about supply chains and legal analysis. Instead, narrower bans on specific entities, including five companies and two vocational centers, have been announced. The move aims to combat China's use of forced labor by detained Uighur Muslims in Xinjiang. The decision follows concerns raised by officials, including Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer.

site_title: Wuhan film captures horror and humanity at coronavirus ground zero
summary: A documentary film "76 Days" premiered at the Toronto film festival, capturing the horror and humanity of the COVID-19 pandemic in Wuhan, China. The film, shot in a cinema verite style, features harrowing footage of terrified citizens, exhausted medics, and relatives bidding farewell to infected loved ones. Director Hao Wu, who witnessed the early lockdown firsthand, aimed to document the human experience rather than place blame, and hopes the film can help China mourn its losses. The film's release has sparked debate about its potential screening in China, where news about the pandemic has been tightly controlled.

site_title: Plaza Singapura, VivoCity, Junction 8 and Hougang Mall visited by Covid-19 patients
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) in Singapore revealed that several shopping malls and restaurants were visited by Covid-19 patients while they were still infectious. Affected locations include Plaza Singapura, VivoCity, Junction 8, and Hougang Mall, with specific restaurants such as Tim Ho Wan, Secret Recipe, and Nando's at Plaza Singapura also confirmed to have cases. The MOH emphasized the importance of adhering to Covid-19 protocols to prevent further transmission.

site_title: China coronavirus vaccine may be ready for public in November: official
summary: China is developing four COVID-19 vaccines in the final stage of clinical trials, with at least three expected to be ready for public use by November or December. The vaccines, developed by state pharmaceutical giant Sinopharm and US-listed Sinovac Biotech, have already been offered to essential workers under an emergency use program. China's CDC chief, Guizhen Wu, stated that she has experienced no abnormal symptoms after taking an experimental vaccine herself in April, indicating a promising development in the fight against the virus.

site_title: New home sales in Singapore for August surprise with 16% rise m-o-m
summary: Singapore saw a 16% rise in new home sales in August, with 1,256 private homes sold, exceeding July's take-up. This marks the fourth consecutive month of increase since the circuit breaker in April 2020, and the highest sales level in 2020. Analysts attribute the strong sales to low interest rates, lack of alternative investment assets, and the fear of missing out. The increased unit launches offered buyers more choices, with 1,582 units released in August, excluding executive condominium units.

images.alt_text: Including ECs, developers moved 1,307 units in August, up 14 per cent from 1,142 units in July and 12 per cent higher than the 1,168 units sold in August last year.

site_title: Singtel, StarHub pay-TV subscriptions to shrink further: Fitch Solutions
summary: Singapore's pay-TV subscriptions are expected to decline further, with Fitch Solutions predicting a drop to 460,660 subscriptions by end-2029. The sector's gradual downward trend is attributed to the proliferation of over-the-top (OTT) streaming services, offering consumers more flexibility and convenience. Singtel and StarHub have struggled to retain pay-TV subscribers, with their total subscriptions decreasing by 27.2% since 2015. Despite efforts to reposition their content offerings, Fitch Solutions expects OTT services like Netflix to dominate the market, with sports programming remaining a key draw for pay-TV services.

site_title: Wall Street firms make slow march back to the office
summary: Wall Street firms are slowly returning to the office as the US economy recovers from the pandemic. SL Green Realty Corp's new office skyscraper, One Vanderbilt, is set to open this week, with several major banks and companies, including JPMorgan Chase, American Express, and TD Bank, signing new leases. Despite the pandemic, many companies, including SL Green, believe that employees will return to the office, citing productivity concerns and the need for creative ideas. Some companies, like WeWork, are offering flexible options for employees to work remotely, while others, like Synchrony Financial, are cutting jobs and exiting leased properties to lower costs.

site_title: Tencent picks Singapore as Asia hub after India, US bans
summary: Tencent Holdings has chosen Singapore as its Asia hub, following setbacks in the US and India. The move comes as the Chinese tech giant shifts business operations to the region due to geopolitical tensions. Tencent plans to open a new office in Singapore and recruit for various positions, including tech and business development. The company joins rivals Alibaba Group and ByteDance in establishing a presence in the region, which is seen as a key battleground for Chinese tech companies.

site_title: Gold rises on softer US dollar, investors focus on Fed meeting
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,962.78 per ounce, driven by a weaker US dollar and decreasing US Treasury yields. Investors focus on the upcoming US Federal Reserve monetary policy meeting, seeking details on inflation targeting and interest rate plans. Spot gold has gained nearly 29% this year, seen as a hedge against inflation. Platinum, silver, and palladium also rose, with platinum reaching its highest since August 18. The US Fed's policy event ends on Wednesday, with market participants seeking clarity on inflation and interest rate strategies.

site_title: Auction prices that take your breath away
summary: Contemporary artists under 40 have seen significant price increases at auctions, with some selling for millions of dollars in their first appearance. Nicolas Party's 2016 pastel "Rocks" sold for $1.1 million at Christie's Hong Kong, while Matthew Wong's 2018 oil "The Realm of Appearances" sold for $1.8 million at Sotheby's New York. Other artists, such as Julie Curtiss and Michael Armitage, have also achieved high prices, with Curtiss's 2019 oil "Pas de Trois" selling for $423,000 at Christie's New York. Experts attribute the surge to increased demand from global buyers and the growing popularity of figurative art.

site_title: Funds and firms call for tougher 2030 EU climate target
summary: Investors and business leaders in the European Union are urging the EU to set a more ambitious 2030 climate target of at least 55% emissions reduction, citing the need for private financing to support low-carbon investments. The existing target of 40% would be insufficient to meet the EU's goal of reaching net zero emissions by 2050. A report by the Institutional Investors Group on Climate Change found that weak targets would hinder the mobilization of private investors and hinder the transition to a low-carbon economy.

site_title: SingPost to introduce new price structure for package, parcel deliveries from Oct 15
summary: SingPost will introduce a new price structure for package and parcel deliveries starting October 15. The local letterbox packages will cost a flat rate of S$1.50 for items up to 2kg, while international deliveries will be simplified and cheaper for most customers. The company aims to cater to the growing e-commerce demand amid the Covid-19 pandemic, with the goal of providing cost savings and improved services for its customers.

site_title: Reserve Bank of Australia to maintain 'highly accommodative settings': minutes
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) will maintain its "highly accommodative settings" to support the country's flagging economy, according to the minutes of its September meeting. The bank held its cash rate at a record low of 0.25% and is unlikely to take further action in the near term, with interest rate futures pricing in a 15 basis point reduction to 0.1% at the next policy meeting. The RBA will continue to consider policy measures to support the economy, which has been impacted by the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Sembcorp, Google sign multi-year renewable energy deal
summary: Sembcorp Industries has signed a multi-year renewable energy deal with Google to provide locally-sourced renewable power for Google Singapore's operations. The deal involves surplus energy from rooftop solar installations of 500 public housing blocks, exported into the national grid and powering Google's operations. The agreement aims to contribute to making renewable energy more accessible for Singaporeans and supports Google's goal of running its data centers on carbon-free electricity by 2030.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start Tuesday's session with losses
summary: Hong Kong shares started Tuesday's session with losses, with the Hang Sang Index easing 0.08% to 24,621.65. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index edged down 0.05%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index on China's second exchange ticked up 0.10%. This follows a more than 1% gain in the previous two sessions.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singapore Airlines, Accordia Golf, SingPost, CapitaLand, LMIRT
summary: Singapore Airlines retrenched cabin crew and pilots, while Accordia Golf Trust's unitholders approved its sale of golf courses. Singapore Post simplified its local and international delivery rates. CapitaLand priced S$800 million in senior notes. Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust remained operational despite Jakarta's COVID-19 restrictions. Sembcorp Marine completed its recapitalisation exercise. DBS was downgraded to a negative sector outlook by Maybank Kim Eng.

site_title: Australia: Shares trade flat ahead of RBA policy meeting minutes
summary: Australian shares traded flat on Tuesday, largely unaffected by the release of Reserve Bank of Australia policy meeting minutes. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose marginally to 5,902.9, driven by cautious investors awaiting further easing of coronavirus curbs in Victoria. The RBA minutes were seen as key for clues about future policy measures, following Governor Philip Lowe's hints of additional measures. Despite the lack of significant movement, investors are now focusing on the minutes for guidance.

images.alt_text: Australian shares traded largely flat on Tuesday as caution ahead of the release of minutes from the central bank's September policy meeting offset hopes of more easing in coronavirus curbs in the state of Victoria.

site_title: Oil edges lower, shrugging off Gulf of Mexico shut-ins
summary: Oil prices slipped slightly, edging lower at $39.61 a barrel for Brent crude and $37.26 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate, amid concerns about a stalled global economic recovery. The decline comes despite Libya's potential to resume production and a storm disrupting US output. Oil prices have fallen for a second week in a row.

site_title: Oracle's TikTok bid heads for US review and Trump's verdict
summary: Oracle's bid to acquire TikTok's US operations will undergo a two-track national security review by the US government, with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin stating the deal must win President Donald Trump's approval. The proposed "TikTok Global" unit would have its US headquarters and create 20,000 jobs, potentially sweetening the deal ahead of the presidential election. The review process will assess the deal's impact on national security and US interests.

site_title: Eight-storey clan association building in Geylang for sale with S$36m guide price
summary: A freehold institutional building in Geylang, Singapore, is up for sale with a guide price of S$36 million. The eight-storey building, completed in 2017, houses the Nanyang Pho Leng Hui Kuan Chinese clan association and has a gross floor area of 26,205 sq ft. The site is zoned Residential/Institution and has a gross plot ratio of 2.8. The building offers offices, meeting rooms, and event spaces, and buyers have the option to use it for civic or cultural purposes. The sale will close on October 20.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.44% or 103.06 points to 23,456.24, and the Topix index down 0.41% or 6.85 points to 1,644.25. Investors locked in profits after three days of rallies, digesting the new government to be formed later this week.

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall Street rally but more volatility expected
summary: Asia's markets rose on Tuesday, tracking a Wall Street rally driven by merger activity and hopes for a coronavirus vaccine. The rally was fueled by progress in vaccine trials, with AstraZeneca and Pfizer reporting potential timelines for distribution. Despite this, traders expect more volatility ahead. Markets in Singapore and the US also saw gains, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records. The Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) rose 0.4% on Thursday, despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

images.alt_text: Equities mostly rose in Asia on Tuesday but fluctuated, with support coming from a Wall Street rally fuelled by merger activity and hopes for a coronavirus vaccine.

site_title: China's Aug industrial output accelerates, retail sales turn up in boost to recovery
summary: China's industrial output grew 5.6% in August, accelerating from a year earlier, and retail sales rose 0.5% for the first time this year, beating forecasts. This suggests the economic recovery is gaining pace as demand improves. Fixed-asset investment declined 0.3% in January-August, but private sector investment fell less than expected. Government stimulus and controlled virus outbreaks have contributed to the recovery, with exports marking the strongest annual gain since March 2019.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.77 points, or 0.12%, to 1,509.59. The market saw a slight edge in volume with 237.12 million lots traded worth RM159.33 million. Gainers outpaced losers 269 to 112.

site_title: Japan's new leadership agenda could make jobs a bigger Bank of Japan priority
summary: Japan's new prime minister Yoshihide Suga's focus on protecting jobs may prompt the Bank of Japan to prioritize employment in monetary policy, despite its official mandate not including job growth. The BOJ is likely to maintain its ultra-easy policy and offer a more upbeat view on the economy, with Governor Haruhiko Kuroda reiterating the central bank's commitment to working with the government to cushion the economic blow from the pandemic. Analysts expect the BOJ to focus on liquidity provision and credit easing measures to help companies and workers cope with the pandemic.

site_title: Economic output in developing Asia to shrink for first time in nearly six decades: ADB
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has forecast that economic output in developing Asia will shrink by 0.7% in 2020, the first decline in nearly six decades, due to the coronavirus pandemic. The region is expected to contract for the first time since 1962. In 2021, the region is forecast to recover and grow 6.8%, still below pre-pandemic predictions. The pandemic's impact is expected to be more severe than initially thought, with about three-quarters of the region's economies forecast to slump this year.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Tuesday's open; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.2% to 2,487.96 at 9:05am, driven by gains in Sembcorp Marine, Singapore Telecommunications, and Singapore banks. The most active stock by volume was Sembcorp Marine, which rose 1.9% after completing a S$2.1 billion recapitalisation exercise. Other active index counters included Keppel Corporation and Wilmar International. In contrast, Tokyo stocks opened lower, while Wall Street and Europe's Stoxx 600 enjoyed solid gains on Monday, buoyed by coronavirus vaccine hopes and big-ticket deals.

site_title: Citigroup to resume job cuts after pausing for pandemic
summary: Citigroup will resume job cuts, affecting less than 1% of its global workforce, as the bank faces a likely revenue drop and increased loan-loss reserves due to the pandemic. The cuts come after the bank paused staff reductions earlier in the pandemic. Despite recent hiring, Citigroup expects overall headcount to remain stable. The bank is also under regulatory scrutiny for its infrastructure and control functions, and CEO Michael Corbat's departure is seen as a result of the looming regulatory hurdles.

site_title: Sino-Malaysia ties 'on track despite Belt & Road project renegotiation'
summary: Malaysia's government has announced a renegotiation of the $10.6 billion East Coast Rail Link (ECRL) project under China's Belt and Road initiative, but has maintained its support for the project. The renegotiation aims to reroute the rail line, which was initially planned to pass through the state of Negri Sembilan, but will instead bypass it. Experts believe this move is more about local politics and priorities rather than a pushback against China. Despite tensions over the South China Sea, Malaysia's relations with China remain strong, with the two countries agreeing to cooperate on defense, economy, and trade.

site_title: Singapore businesses most digitally-ready in Asia-Pacific: poll
summary: Singapore businesses are the most digitally-ready in the Asia-Pacific region, according to a DBS survey, with 45% indicating a well-defined digital strategy. Hong Kong came in second, while Japan was third. Businesses in the Philippines and Vietnam were the least digitally-ready, citing challenges such as the speed of change, execution complexity, and lack of digital talent. The majority of Singapore businesses prefer fintech companies as digitalisation partners, and 80% expect to use application programming interfaces and enterprise cloud solutions in the next three years.

site_title: Qantas considers shifting HQ from Sydney in new cost-cutting drive
summary: Qantas is considering shifting its headquarters from Sydney as part of a cost-cutting drive. The airline is reviewing its property footprint, seeking to trim its A$40 million annual rent bill, amid the pandemic's impact on its operations. A three-month review will focus on non-aviation facilities, and the company may relocate its headquarters to a smaller campus or a single, all-purpose location. The move aims to reduce costs as Qantas scales down operations, with plans to shed 8,500 jobs and resume international flights in mid-2021.

images.alt_text: Qantas Airways is considering shifting its headquarters from Sydney in an effort to cut costs as the pandemic forces it to scale down operations.

site_title: British MPs back Brexit bill despite EU anger
summary: British lawmakers approved a bill that would override parts of the Brexit treaty with the EU, despite EU leaders' outrage and concerns at home about the move. The UK Internal Market Bill, which was backed by 340 votes to 263, aims to ensure "unfettered access" for trade within the UK's four nations after the transition period ends on December 31. EU leaders have warned Prime Minister Boris Johnson to withdraw the offending parts of the bill, threatening to disrupt post-Brexit trade negotiations.

site_title: Alibaba's entry might affect Grab-Gojek merger talks
summary: Alibaba is reportedly in talks to invest US$3 billion in Grab, a South-east Asian ride-hailing firm, potentially complicating merger talks between Grab and rival Gojek. The investment, which could include acquiring Uber's 23.2% stake in Grab, may intensify antitrust concerns and regulatory scrutiny. If successful, the deal could set the stage for future consolidation in the region, raising questions about potential investor conflict and the need for structural remedies.

site_title: Low rates breathing life into S-Reit perps space: DBS
summary: Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) are issuing perpetual securities (perps) again, with year-to-date issuances totaling S$575 million in the third quarter. The low interest-rate environment and rebound in markets have revived the perps space, with proceeds used to fund acquisitions or refinance existing perps before their first coupon reset dates. This is expected to result in 1-1.9% accretion to distributions. More S-Reits may explore the market to refinance perps at upcoming reset dates, potentially infusing confidence in investors and wider financing options for the trusts.

site_title: LMIRT's Jakarta malls remain open with 50% visitor cap during second lockdown
summary: Jakarta's partial lockdown has led to Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust's (LMIRT) seven malls remaining open with a 50% visitor cap. The trust's seven Jakarta malls, as well as Lippo Mall Puri, will operate with limited capacity, while entertainment centers and dine-in options are closed. Tenants not allowed to operate will receive rental waivers, and further support for food and beverage tenants may be provided. Outside Jakarta, LMIRT's 14 other malls continue to operate with social distancing measures, and the trust remains in compliance with debt financial covenants.

site_title: US: Vaccine hopes, dealmaking stoke Wall Street optimism
summary: US stock markets saw solid gains on Monday, driven by hopes for a coronavirus vaccine and big-ticket deals. Vaccine trials resumed after a pause, with British regulators clearing the way for AstraZeneca and Oxford to continue development. The company remains hopeful for a vaccine availability by the end of this year or early next year. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records, despite tariff uncertainty and mixed Federal Reserve views.

images.alt_text: "US stocks are rebounding noticeably from a two-week pullback from record high territory, with a flood of M&A activity and a host of news on the Covid-19 vaccine/treatment front fostering the recovery," Charles Schwab analysts wrote.

site_title: Mexico issues 'world's first' sovereign bond linked to UN sustainability goals
summary: Mexico has issued what it claims is the world's first sovereign bond linked to the UN's sustainability development goals, raising 750 million euros (S$1.21 billion). The bond, with a 1.350% coupon, is part of an emerging trend of debt issuance aimed at tackling social and environmental issues. The government did not specify how it would spend the money, and there is no guarantee that disbursements will be made for projects meeting the UN characteristics. The bond matures in September 2027 and allows Mexico to tap into international investment funds committed to sustainable development.

site_title: Private exchanges augment public markets, make financial ecosystem more complete: HGX chairman
summary: HG Exchange chairman Richard Teng believes private exchanges will play a complementary role to public markets in Asia, augmenting the financial ecosystem. Private exchanges are gaining momentum with abundant opportunities for companies to raise funding, driven by the coronavirus pandemic. HGX, a newly launched private exchange, aims to offer digital assets and lower trading costs, benefiting issuers and investors. Teng predicts robust growth for private markets, with no prediction on the number of private exchanges in the Asian market.

site_title: Uber fights to win back London licence in latest court battle
summary: Uber is set to battle in court to win back its London licence, which was revoked in 2019 over safety concerns. The company has made changes to its business model in response, including improved driver identification. This is Uber's second attempt to secure a licence in London, having previously been denied in 2017 before a judge restored it on a probationary basis. The outcome of the latest court battle will determine whether Uber can continue to operate in one of its most important markets.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler and PSA tweak merger terms due to pandemic
summary: Fiat Chrysler (FCA) and PSA have modified the terms of their mega-merger due to the COVID-19 pandemic. FCA agreed to lower its exceptional dividend to 2.9 billion euros, down from 5.5 billion euros, while PSA will distribute its 46% stake in Faurecia to all shareholders, rather than just its shareholders. The decision aims to preserve the original balance of the merger, set to be completed by the end of 2021, and was approved unanimously by both companies' boards. The merged entity, Stellantis, will be the world's fourth-largest automaker.

images.alt_text: Fiat Chrysler (FCA) and Peugeot Citroen (PSA) announced on Monday they'd modified the terms of their mega-merger in light of business disruptions caused by Covid-19.

site_title: Local firms seek new markets amid Covid-19, but change tack
summary: Singaporean firms continue to expand overseas despite the Covid-19 pandemic, with over 300 internationalisation projects in South-east Asia from January to August this year, a 7% increase from the same period last year. To adapt to travel restrictions, local businesses are shifting to expansion tactics involving less physical interaction. This shift is also seen as a long-term strategy to establish a presence in new markets and diversify revenue streams.

images.alt_text: Udders' Wong Peck Lin says it has pivoted to product export and distribution and e-commerce rather than franchised stores. These strategies also reduce the need for face-to-face training and meetings.
Acts of Life's John Cunningham says: "We knew that we'd have to be flexible and re-adjust our rollout, which could delay our timelines, but we're here (in Vietnam) for the long term.

site_title: Oil industry paints grimmer picture of pandemic's harm to demand
summary: Major oil industry producers and traders forecast a bleak future for worldwide fuel demand due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic's impact on the global economy. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) predicts a 9.46 million barrel per day decline in world oil demand in 2020, with some companies expecting a 3-2 million barrel per day reduction by 2025 and 2050. The resurgence of the virus in countries with controlled infections is sparking lockdowns, potentially hindering the recovery, and several companies are working on a vaccine, but it is likely months away from mass distribution.

site_title: Europe: Travel, tech stocks prop up stocks, energy sector takes a hit
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index rose 0.2% on Monday, driven by gains in travel and technology stocks, despite losses in the energy sector. Travel stocks led the gains, with British Airways-owner IAG jumping 4.4% and easyJet rising nearly 2%. Tech stocks also rose 0.9%, with chipmakers STMicroelectronics and Nvidia Corp making significant moves. However, the euro zone and UK stocks were up only 0.1%, with gains for the euro and sterling hurting exporters, amid concerns over Brexit and economic recovery.

site_title: YouTube tests TikTok rival in India
summary: YouTube has begun testing a short-form video format, YouTube Shorts, in India, refining its format and planning a global rollout. The new feature, limited to 15-second videos, aims to compete with TikTok. YouTube's move comes as the US government considers a ban on TikTok due to national security concerns. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin has confirmed a bid from Oracle to acquire TikTok's US operations, which could spare the app from being shut down. YouTube will refine the feature based on user feedback before a broader release.

site_title: CEOs call for deep EU emission cuts by 2030
summary: CEOs from over 150 global companies, including Apple and Google, have urged European leaders to set a 55% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 to avoid the worst effects of climate change. This aligns with the European Commission's plan to raise its target from 40% to 55% by 2030 and achieve "carbon neutrality" by 2050. The call for deeper cuts comes as the European Commission prepares to unveil its 2030 emission reduction target in its State of the Union address.

images.alt_text: The heads of more than 150 global companies, including Apple and Google, have urged European leaders to set a higher target for reducing climate-heating emissions, says the Cambridge Institute for Sustainability Leadership (CISL).

site_title: UBS chairman exploring merger with Credit Suisse: report
summary: UBS chairman Axel Weber is exploring a potential merger with Credit Suisse to create one of Europe's largest banks, dubbed "Signal". The project, driven by Weber and Credit Suisse chairman Urs Rohner, is being discussed with Swiss Finance Minister Ueli Maurer, with a possible agreement by early next year. The merger could result in 10-20% job cuts, approximately 15,000 worldwide, and would likely see Weber remain chairman and a Credit Suisse CEO taking the helm.

site_title: Tenet hits US$200m globally, Mulan has slow start in China
summary: Christopher Nolan's Tenet has grossed over $200 million globally despite a 29% drop in its second US weekend ticket sales, with $6.7 million earned. This marks a slow start for Mulan, also released during the pandemic, which struggled to draw audiences in China.

site_title: Staying open and maximising opportunities for Singaporeans go together: Tharman
summary: Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam emphasized the importance of Singapore staying open to maximize opportunities for its citizens while managing openness and ensuring citizens' stakes in society. To achieve this, the government will develop Singaporeans at various skill levels, incentivize firms to anchor themselves in Singapore, and ensure fair hiring and promotion practices. Additionally, the government will maintain a diversity of nationalities, control the number of foreigners, and work with industry, unions, and educational institutions to support small and medium-sized enterprises.

site_title: Bluebird Group on track for growth despite Covid-19
summary: Indonesian taxi group Bluebird remains committed to growth despite the COVID-19 pandemic, prioritizing people-focused initiatives. The company has cut back on expansion plans, but continues to invest in its employees and customers through scholarships and philanthropic programs. Bluebird has also expanded its services, including a digital payment system and a new delivery service, and is leveraging partnerships with Standard Chartered Bank to drive digitalization. The company is working on future-proofing its business, including IoT-enabled vehicles and data-driven loyalty systems, to capitalize on the "new normal" post-pandemic.

site_title: Smaller watches a sign of China's growing hold on luxury industry
summary: Swiss luxury watch maker Officine Panerai-Firenze is shifting its product line to cater to Chinese buyers, who prefer smaller watches. The brand, known for its bulky military-style timepieces, now sells models as small as 38 millimeters in China. This trend reflects China's growing influence on the luxury industry, as the country's buyers drive demand for more discreet products. This shift may be a sign of China's expanding luxury market, where smaller, more discreet products are in high demand.

site_title: Euro gains blunted stimulus boost to inflation: Lagarde
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde said the recent euro appreciation has partially offset the stimulus's positive impact on inflation, indicating policymakers are prepared to adjust their instruments if needed. The euro has jumped over 10% since March, while inflation remains below zero for the first time in four years. Lagarde emphasized the ECB's commitment to its price stability goal, despite the exchange rate's impact on the medium-term inflation outlook.

site_title: US dollar slips as equity market mood lifts
summary: The US dollar slipped 0.6% against major peers on Monday as global equity markets lifted due to a wave of M&A deals. Investors await a Fed meeting and the appointment of a new Japanese premier this week. The currency had its weakest week since March, but still firmed up.

site_title: French President Macron defends 5G technology
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron has defended the deployment of 5G technology, saying France will move forward despite critics who want to halt its rollout. Macron dismissed those who advocate for going back to traditional methods, calling them "suspicious" and referring to the Amish model. He emphasized France's commitment to innovation, stating that the country will not be swayed by "false ideas." Macron's comments come as nearly 70 left-wing officials and environmentalists have called for a moratorium on 5G technology due to concerns over its environmental and health impacts.

site_title: Covid-19 pushes developers to offer new perks
summary: Developers are introducing new amenities to combat the COVID-19 pandemic, including outdoor spaces, touch-free equipment, and ventilation systems. Many buildings are repurposing lounges as outdoor schools and adding cabana-lined roof decks. To maintain social distancing, some buildings are installing dividers around workspaces and cordoning off hammocks in courtyards. Others are implementing app-based reservations for outdoor spaces and limiting gym capacity. These temporary measures are expected to become permanent as concerns about density and disease transmission fade. Developers believe that amenities will never go back to their pre-pandemic state.

site_title: New York home buyers looking outside Manhattan for new development
summary: New York home buyers are shifting their focus to Brooklyn and Queens, with the two boroughs outperforming Manhattan in terms of new condo sales. Despite the city-wide decline in sales, the market is leaning towards first-time and move-up buyers, many of whom are working from home. Affluent residents who left the city during the pandemic are being replaced by those who can afford to buy, with a preference for smaller, more affordable developments. Discounts remain modest, but buyers are securing back-end concessions and better units. The shift may lead to a more balanced approach to new development, with more outdoor space and smaller price tags.

site_title: Azure-Lyte Fund finances tech startup aiming to transform the freelance ecosystem
summary: The Azure-Lyte Fund, a partnership between Azure Capital and Lyte Ventures, provides financing to Lyte, which advances commissions to freelance agents in return for a fee. This allows freelancers to receive their commissions "almost instantaneously," rather than waiting months. The fund has carried out "a few thousand transactions" with a zero per cent default rate, and the fees earned by Lyte will go to the Azure-Lyte Fund, managed by Azure Capital. The goal is to support freelancers and businesses, and make the freelance ecosystem more stable and secure.

site_title: Swedish fund shuns doomsday bets on property
summary: Sweden's US$40 billion AP1 pension fund, led by CEO Kristin Magnusson Bernard, is heavily exposed to prime real estate in city centers due to the Covid-19 crisis. Despite concerns, Bernard believes the sector won't see a systemic meltdown, citing a 1.1% return over the first six months. A recent study found 28% of office tenants in Norway and Sweden expect to continue working from home, reducing demand for office spaces. AP1 is diversifying its portfolio by stepping up private equity investments and hedge funds, with a focus on ESG goals.

site_title: Local firms seek new markets amid Covid-19
summary: Local Singaporean firms have continued to expand into new South-east Asian markets despite the Covid-19 pandemic. According to Enterprise Singapore, there were over 300 internationalisation projects from January to August this year, a 7% increase from the same period last year. These businesses are seeking new opportunities to grow and adapt to the changing market landscape.

site_title: Seek value in HK traditional sectors: Maybank KE
summary: Hong Kong's new economy stocks have surged following the pandemic-driven rally, but may be due for a correction, according to Maybank Kim Eng's portfolio strategist Sonija Li. Most new economy stocks are trading at high price-to-earnings ratios, and Li advises investors to take profits or reduce stakes while shifting focus to traditional sectors such as finance, consumer goods, and Macau gaming. The Macau gaming sector is expected to rebound as travel restrictions ease, while China's internal circulation initiative is expected to boost the consumer front.

site_title: Accidental mavens
summary: Structo, a 3D printing solutions provider born in 2012, has shifted its focus to making nasal test swabs for Covid-19 after an accidental meeting with a dentist. The startup's ability to quickly adapt to the pandemic's demand for swabs showcases its technical skills. Structo's mission is to provide a comprehensive ecosystem for chair-side 3D printing, and it has integrated with digital dental design service providers. The company has also developed a glove-free solution, Velox, which enables dentists to print surgical guides within 30-40 minutes. With support from Enterprise Singapore and SEEDS Capital, Structo has scaled up its manufacturing facility to produce hundreds of thousands of swabs per week. The company plans to continue manufacturing swabs as long as needed, while exploring other verticals in 3D printing.

site_title: Singapore stocks start week on softer note
summary: Singapore stocks ended Monday on a weaker note, with the Straits Times Index falling 7.54 points to 2,482.55, weighed down by SIA, Ascendas Reit, and Wilmar. Singapore Airlines fell 1.4% due to its plan to lay off 2,400 staff amid a protracted slump in international air travel. Meanwhile, CapitaLand Commercial Trust and CapitaLand Mall Trust rose, and Sembcorp Industries edged higher. Markets in the region were firmer, with benchmark indices in Tokyo, Shanghai, and others ending in positive territory.

site_title: UN warns of 'further war crimes' in Myanmar's Rakhine
summary: The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, Michelle Bachelet, warned of potential "further war crimes" in Myanmar's Rakhine and Chin states due to the government's continued targeting of civilians. The Rohingya minority has suffered serious rights violations, including disappearances, killings, and forced displacement, since the 2017 military operations. Bachelet demanded action to remedy these abuses and called for an independent investigation into the situation. The UN has faced genocide charges over the violence, and the situation remains dire, with many Rohingya excluded from the upcoming elections.

site_title: China issues new rules to tighten control over financial holding firms
summary: China has issued new rules to regulate financial holding companies, aiming to prevent systematic risks in the country's vast financial sector. The rules, set to take effect on November 1, 2020, name companies such as Citic, China Everbright, and Ant Financial as eligible financial holding entities. The regulations will require these firms to have at least 5 billion yuan in capital and 500 billion yuan in total assets, with a one-year grace period for compliance. Failure to meet the new rules may result in a share sale and anti-trust investigation.

site_title: Philippine central bank ready to lend govt more to fight virus if needed
summary: The Philippine central bank, led by Governor Benjamin Diokno, is prepared to lend more to the government to counter the impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The bank can lend up to 282 billion pesos (about 10% of the government's average revenue in the last three years) to support the government's pandemic relief efforts, following the signing of a new law by President Rodrigo Duterte. This move aims to boost state funding and help the country recover from the economic impact of the pandemic.

site_title: US presidential elections rife with rhetoric of vote rigging and fraud
summary: US presidential elections are increasingly focused on potential vote rigging and fraud, with only seven weeks to go before the election. Despite polls predicting a narrow victory for Joe Biden, concerns about the electoral process have grown, with some questioning whether a winner can be declared on Election Day. This has led to discussions about the potential for political paralysis and the impact on US domestic and foreign policy.

site_title: Retrenchments commence at SIA; airline and pilots union still in talks
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has begun its retrenchment exercise, affecting nearly 1,000 cabin crew and 50-60 pilots, as part of its efforts to rightsize operations due to slow travel demand. The airline is in talks with the Air Line Pilots Association - Singapore (ALPA-S) to discuss the number of retrenchments. Affected staff will receive salary in lieu of notice, bonuses, and severance pay, with some staff members also receiving additional benefits. The talks aim to avoid a potential double whammy where pilots accept deeper pay cuts and face further lay-offs.

site_title: China's reach for digital dominance a wake-up call for US
summary: China is launching a new set of global guidelines and a national technology strategy, promoting blockchain technology and accelerating its development. The strategy, China Standards 2035, aims to establish global blockchain standards through China's blockchain-based services network (BSN), which will integrate cloud computing, 5G, and other services. Beijing's top-down approach allows it to construct far-reaching networks, and the BSN is being tested in 56 cities worldwide. This move may prompt other countries to evaluate China's influence on global technology and standards, prompting the US to reassess its approach to managing technological transition.

site_title: Steady growth in China's new home prices boosts economic recovery
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.6% in August, a slight increase from July, with annual growth at 4.8%. The property market continues to drive economic recovery, but policy makers remain cautious of overheating. Many major cities have imposed restrictions on property transactions to control price rises, with some cities, like Huizhou, reporting strong monthly gains. Regulators plan new rules to control liquidity and contain property developers' debt levels. Analysts expect more price cuts and sales promotions, dubbed "Golden September, Silver October", to follow.

site_title: ZenRock, Agritrade face winding up; Hontop put under JM
summary: ZenRock Commodities Trading and Agritrade International face potential winding up as judicial managers file applications to liquidate them. Hontop Energy is also under judicial management. Both companies are heavily indebted, with ZenRock owing HSBC around US$49 million and Agritrade owing around US$1.55 billion. The collapse in oil prices has exposed financial weaknesses and alleged irregularities in the industry, leading to judicial management applications and lawsuits.

site_title: Court gives approval for Thai Airways restructuring
summary: Thai Airways International Pcl, the nation's flagship carrier, has received court approval for its business restructuring plan. The airline, which has around 350 billion baht (S$15.3 billion) of debt, aims to submit a debt plan to the court in the fourth quarter and complete the restructuring process in five years. The court's decision is a crucial step forward for the embattled company, which is facing significant challenges due to the pandemic's impact on the global travel industry.

site_title: Online materials assessment tool aims to reduce plastic use
summary: The World Wide Fund for Nature Singapore (WWF-Singapore) has launched the Alternative Materials Tool (AMT), a web-based tool to help businesses select environmentally friendly packaging alternatives. The tool analyzes and compares the environmental impact of various materials throughout their life cycle. It aims to reduce plastic use without transferring environmental costs to another system. Currently, the tool covers four countries: Malaysia, Singapore, the Philippines, and Thailand. The AMT provides a list of recommended materials, ranked by environmental friendliness, and offers explanations of each material's impact.

site_title: Restarting the engine: Asia, oil and coronavirus
summary: The novel coronavirus pandemic has significantly impacted Asia's oil demand, with a 1.7 million barrel per day (bpd) drop in 2020 due to lockdowns and economic curbs. China, the largest contributor to regional oil demand, saw a 1.2 million bpd drop in Q1 2020 but recovered in Q2. India, another major growth center, also experienced a decline in oil demand due to a nationwide lockdown. The region is expected to return to growth in 2021, with a 1.6 million bpd increase, but oil demand will still be lower than 2019 levels.

images.alt_text: China's economy has clearly been on a V-shaped recovery path so far, but faces headwinds to further growth for the rest of the year.

site_title: Asean banks' asset quality risks still high, green shoots muted: Maybank KE
summary: Asean banks' asset quality risks remain high, with operational recovery muted due to ongoing COVID-19 restrictions and potential "mini lockdowns". Maybank KE has downgraded its sector outlook to negative, citing elevated provisioning risks and valuations. The analysts expect credit charges to remain on the upside, and earnings to remain largely negative, with only a few banks showing resilience, such as DBS, Hong Leong Bank, and Techcombank.

site_title: Established businesses keep up with times by recognising trends
summary: Established Singaporean businesses, such as Lam Soon Singapore and CYC Made To Measure, must adapt to changing consumer behavior and trends to remain relevant. Despite being long-standing brands, they risk losing young consumers who prefer new and different options. To mitigate this risk, these companies have taken a multi-brand approach, introduced new products, and focused on customer service, resulting in continued growth and success.

site_title: Rare dolphins return to Hong Kong as Covid-19 halts ferry traffic
summary: Rare Indo-Pacific humpback dolphins have made a comeback in Hong Kong waters as Covid-19 halted ferry traffic, allowing the threatened species to thrive in previously avoided areas. According to marine scientist Lindsay Porter, dolphin numbers have increased by up to 30% since March, with the population likely to rebound when stressors are removed. The Hong Kong government's conservation plans, including opening marine parks, have been deemed inadequate, and a comprehensive management plan is needed to effectively protect the dolphin population. There are approximately 2,000 dolphins in the Pearl River estuary.

site_title: Tackling climate change need not be a Sisyphean task
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has called climate change "one of the gravest challenges facing humankind." The city is predicted to face "unprecedented" climate shifts by 2050, with global temperatures increasing by almost 2 degrees Celsius since pre-industrial times. Urbanization is a primary driver of climate vulnerabilities, affecting not only cities but the environment globally. To combat climate change, collaboration among countries is essential, as it has a significant impact on social and economic prosperity, health, and well-being.

site_title: Hmlet to expand into Malaysia and Thailand, widens product offering
summary: Hmlet, a Singapore-based co-living platform, is expanding into Malaysia and Thailand, widening its product offerings to include property management, interior design, and furniture subscription. The company has on-boarded over 1,000 apartments in Malaysia and 2,500 in Thailand, with developers seeking its platform for digital apartment viewing and management services.

site_title: Sembmarine slips 0.6% in second consecutive day of heavy trading
summary: Sembcorp Marine's shares slipped 0.6% on Monday, marking a second consecutive day of heavy trading. The company completed its S$2.1 billion recapitalisation exercise, with 202.4 million shares changing hands, the most traded stock by volume. The counter hit an intra-day low of 15.7 Singapore cents before recovering to finish at 16.2 cents.

site_title: Nvidia to buy chip designer Arm for US$40b as SoftBank exits
summary: Nvidia will acquire UK-based chip designer Arm from SoftBank Group Corp for $40 billion, marking a significant shift in the global semiconductor landscape. The deal, set to close by March 2022, puts a vital supplier to Apple Inc and others under the control of a single player, sparking concerns from regulators and rivals. Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang emphasized the deal's pro-competitive nature, promising to retain Arm's open approach and expand its licensing model. The acquisition is expected to boost Nvidia's data centre chip business and intensify competition in the market.

site_title: Employment in Singapore falls by record 103,500 in Q2
summary: Singapore's employment fell by a record 103,500 in Q2, four times the previous record contraction. This is attributed to cost-saving measures for an unprecedented number of workers. However, retrenchments and unemployment rates remained below past peaks. The significant drop in employment is largely due to the ongoing impact of Covid-19 on the labor market.

site_title: Huntington-Paprika merger a 'marriage of equals'
summary: Singaporean public relations firm Huntington Communications and creative agency Paprika Global have merged to form Distilleri, a new company that aims to expand its suite of services. The merger, which brings together about 50 years of experience, is not due to financial struggles but rather to capitalize on new opportunities in crisis communications and government work. The combined team of around 30 people will enable Distilleri to work more quickly and think differently, differentiating it from traditional PR agencies. The company plans to charge a basic fee and earn a bonus if it surpasses client targets, and may also consider taking a stake in startup clients' success.

site_title: Johor to double budget for walkway on Malaysian side of Causeway
summary: The Johor state government in Malaysia plans to build a 350-metre covered walkway for pedestrians on the Malaysian side of the Causeway, at a cost of RM30 million (S$9.9 million). The project, which will be built at a cost of RM30 million, aims to make the crossing more comfortable for the hundreds of people who walk across daily. The construction will involve the Home and Works Ministries, and pedestrians are prohibited on the Johor Causeway. The project is a response to the traffic congestion caused by the land link, which was previously used by over 300,000 travellers daily.

site_title: Oracle confirms it is part of proposal for TikTok
summary: Oracle has confirmed it is part of a proposal to the US government to become a technology partner for TikTok-parent ByteDance, aiming to make the Chinese-owned app a US-headquartered company. The proposal was submitted by ByteDance to Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, who said the plan will be reviewed this week. The move comes amid concerns over national security and data protection.

site_title: Millionaires would pay up under Biden's tax plans, study shows
summary: Millionaires would face higher tax bills under Joe Biden's tax plans, with the top 0.1% of earners paying 43% of their income, compared to 30.6% under President Trump's 2017 tax law. Most households below the top income brackets would see little change. Biden's plan would increase the corporate tax by $1.4 trillion over 10 years, with the middle 20% of earners seeing a slight increase in tax rates due to indirect effects. The plan would raise $3.4 trillion over the next decade, but federal debt would decrease by 6.1% and GDP would rise by 0.8% by 2050.

site_title: Businesses feel the crunch as Jakarta enters second lockdown
summary: Jakarta's 10 million residents are entering a partial lockdown for the second time, affecting businesses in the city. The lockdown is seen as a rollercoaster year for Indonesia, following the city's return to normalcy. The measures include plastic barriers, mask-wearing requirements, and handwashing stations, highlighting the ongoing COVID-19 concerns. The lockdown is expected to impact businesses, particularly in the food and tourism sectors, as the city heads into the second lockdown.

images.alt_text: Shuttered stores in a shopping centre as a partial lockdown took effect from Monday. Jakarta's tightened social restrictions - for two weeks - mean businesses, malls and houses of worship can only operate at limited capacity, while dining in at restaurants and cafes is not allowed.

site_title: Restructure or die, Cathay Pacific warns as it burns through millions a month
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd reported dismal August traffic figures, with only 35,773 passengers flown, a 98.8% slump from the same month last year. The airline continues to burn through HK$2 billion (S$350 million) a month until the market recovers from the coronavirus crisis. Cathay has completed a HK$39 billion recapitalisation plan and is undergoing a strategic review, with recommendations due in the fourth quarter. The company's shares have tumbled 37% this year, and CEO Ronald Lam warned that a restructuring will be inevitable to protect the company and its employees.

site_title: Why state of Europe's union is full of challenges
summary: The European Union is facing significant challenges, including the COVID-19 pandemic, Brexit, and rising populism. However, under the leadership of Ursula von der Leyen, Brussels may have a "window of opportunity" to achieve historic agreements, such as a post-Brexit UK-EU trade deal and a €750 billion post-coronavirus recovery plan. Von der Leyen will outline her vision for the EU's post-pandemic future, emphasizing ambition and seizing the initiative. The EU must navigate growing domestic and external challenges, including rising populism, the assertive Russia, and uncertainty from Washington.

site_title: China's rising demand for condo butler service sparks huge stock gains
summary: China's condominium market is driving a surge in demand for condo butler services, leading to significant stock gains. Property management companies have risen 60% on average, outperforming Chinese consumer stocks and technology firms. Chinese developers are seizing on the trend to list their service arms in Hong Kong, raising money to pare debt. Thirteen developers have started or flagged intentions to spin off their management units this year, with the industry's market value expected to quadruple to $180 billion by 2025.

site_title: Bigger homes bought on pandemic spree may house regret
summary: The US housing market is experiencing a surge due to low mortgage rates and the pandemic, but many buyers are regretting their decisions. A survey of 1,000 mortgage holders found that 56% of those who bought homes after March 2020 regretted taking out a mortgage. Experts warn that buying in a sellers' market, where prices are inflated, can lead to regret. They advise waiting until the economy and market stabilize before purchasing a home, citing benefits of renting, such as flexibility and avoiding down payment costs.

images.alt_text: Homeownership has always been messaged as a mandatory part of the American Dream and subsidised by the federal government, causing it to be always a bit overrated.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Accordia Golf Trust's unit holders have voted in favor of divesting the trust's 88 golf courses in Japan to its sponsor, Accordia Golf, for 65.2 billion yen (S$840.5 million). This decision follows Accordia Golf's offer in August.

site_title: Dominic Thiem claims maiden Grand Slam in wild US Open final
summary: Dominic Thiem, the No. 2 seed, claimed his first Grand Slam title by defeating Alexander Zverev 2-6, 4-6, 6-4, 6-3, 7-6 (8/6) in a 4-hour marathon match at the US Open. Thiem, 27, overcame a two-set deficit to win the championship, becoming the first currently active player in his 20s to win a Grand Slam event. This victory marked Thiem's first Grand Slam title in his fourth major final, following in the footsteps of Austrian tennis legend Thomas Muster.

site_title: The V-shaped recovery marches on
summary: The global economy is exhibiting signs of a V-shaped recovery from the pandemic-induced collapse, with many countries showing vigorous rebounds in June and July. Projected growth in real GDP is expected to be around 10-15% in the third quarter. However, concerns remain about the potential for a strong second wave of Covid-19 infections and the need for equitable vaccine distribution. Structural issues, including the balance of domestic and external growth, and the payment for current spending, also need to be addressed for a sustained recovery.

site_title: Suga on track to become Japan's next PM after winning LDP vote
summary: Yoshihide Suga has won the vote to become Japan's next prime minister, succeeding Shinzo Abe after a landslide victory with 377 out of 534 valid votes. Suga, the chief cabinet secretary, has pledged to continue Abe's policies, promising stability and a focus on containing the COVID-19 pandemic and kickstarting the economy.
