He is expected to win a parliamentary vote on Wednesday and become prime minister, succeeding Abe who has resigned due to health reasons.

images.alt_text: Mr Suga says kickstarting the economy will be a top priority, along with containing the Covid-19 virus - essential if the postponed Tokyo 2020 Olympics are to open as planned in July 2021.

site_title: Singapore eDevelopment renamed Alset International
summary: Singapore eDevelopment, a Catalist-listed company, has announced that it will be renamed Alset International. A special resolution for the name change was passed at an electronic general meeting on September 9, and the required statutory returns were lodged with the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority of Singapore. The company's shares closed up 3.33% on the day before the news, with a new trading counter name "Alset" set to take effect on September 17.

site_title: Think-tank: UK faces biggest wave of redundancies in a generation
summary: The UK is set to face its largest wave of redundancies in a generation, with around 650,000 people likely to be made redundant between July and December 2020, according to the Institute for Employment Studies. The redundancies are attributed to the novel coronavirus shock to the economy. This prediction is based on lay-off notifications by employers. The report highlights a significant increase in job losses in the UK, which is a fresh blow to the economy and Prime Minister Starmer's government.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription, while Creative Technology warned H2 revenue may be below target and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10b upgrade, and Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. Singapore stocks rallied for the 5th consecutive day ahead of GDP data, with MAS and PBOC set to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's incoming CEO.

site_title: Singapore stocks begin week on softer note
summary: Singapore stocks closed Monday on a weaker note, with the Straits Times Index falling 0.3% to 2,482.55. Airlines Singapore Airlines and Wilmar International were major losers, dropping 1.4% and 1.19% respectively. However, CapitaLand Commercial Trust and CapitaLand Mall Trust rose 2.38% and 2.03% as they prepare for a merger. Markets in other regions, such as Tokyo and Hong Kong, ended the day in positive territory, amid hopes for a correction in the US S&P 500.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust to buy US data centre for as much as US$262.1m
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) is proposing to acquire a US data centre and office in Virginia for between US$200.6 million and US$262.1 million. The deal, targeting completion in Q1 2021, will increase MIT's assets under management to S$6.9 billion and its exposure to data centres to 41% of its portfolio. The acquisition is expected to provide income stability and be accretive to its distribution per unit. MIT plans to fund the deal using debt financing, equity fundraising, and internal cash resources, and the purchase consideration was arrived at after independent valuations.

site_title: EU tells Xi that China must prove investment deal is worthwhile
summary: The European Union has stepped up demands on China to open its market further to foreign investors, urging Beijing to meet a 2020 target date for a long-sought investment deal. EU officials stated that China must follow through on recent offers to pursue fairer economic policies, and that an agreement is contingent on the bloc's perception of its worth. The EU is keen to show economic rewards from a less confrontational approach towards China, while US President Trump's administration has taken a more aggressive stance. The EU and China have been negotiating a bilateral pact since 2013.

site_title: Airbus CEO warns of compulsory layoffs as airline crisis deepens
summary: Airbus CEO Guillaume Faury has warned staff of compulsory layoffs as air travel fails to recover quickly from the coronavirus crisis. The planemaker, which has up to 15,000 posts to shed, has seen aircraft deliveries and airline finances weakened. Faury stated that voluntary departures are unlikely to be enough, and the company must prepare for a deeper and longer crisis. The warning risks friction with unions and the French government, which have urged Airbus to avoid compulsory layoffs. Airbus has 130,000 staff and the company's outlook remains uncertain.

site_title: Uber borrowing US$500m in refinancing frenzy
summary: Uber Technologies is borrowing $500 million to refinance debt, selling bonds due in 2028 at a yield of around 6.5%. The move is part of a trend of high-yield companies capitalizing on cheap interest rates to lower their interest expense. Uber's financial flexibility is supported by access to low-cost capital, allowing the company to extend its maturity profile while reducing costs. This is one of several high-yield bond sales this year, with junk-bond issuance reaching over $300 billion for the first time since 2013.

site_title: US: Wall Street rises at open on M&A activity, vaccine hopes
summary: US stocks rose at the open on Monday, driven by progress in COVID-19 vaccine development and multi-billion dollar M&A deals. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.19%, the S&P 500 gained 0.68%, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 1.44%. Oracle reportedly won the battle for TikTok's US arm, while other deals include Airalo's $220 million funding round. The market gains come despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Johor to spend S$9.9m on air-conditioned walkway for pedestrians on Malaysian side of Causeway
summary: The Johor state government plans to build a 350m covered walkway for pedestrians on the Malaysian side of the Causeway, connecting Johor Baru to Woodlands, at a cost of S$9.9 million. The project aims to make it more comfortable for the hundreds of people who walk across daily. The construction will involve the Home Ministry and Works Ministry, with escalators and air-conditioning added. The walkway's design and implementation are being handled by the Works Ministry, and Singapore Consulate officials have expressed interest in the project.

site_title: BM Mobility to be delisted
summary: BM Mobility, a Singapore-listed company, will be delisted after failing to meet conditions to resume trading. The company had requested a suspension in 2019 and was granted extensions until August 31 to sign an acquisition agreement. However, no definitive agreement was signed by the deadline, and the company did not submit a resumption proposal. As a result, its shares will be delisted, and the company must now comply with Listing Rule 1309, which requires a reasonable exit offer to shareholders.

site_title: Garda mulls hostile bid after G4S rebuffs US$3.7b offer
summary: GardaWorld has made an unsuccessful bid of approximately 2.9 billion pounds (S$5.09 billion) to acquire UK-based security services firm G4S. Despite three attempts to engage with the board, Garda claims G4S management is not willing to negotiate. Garda CEO Stephan Cretier believes an owner-operated model would offer a better future for the combined business, which would create a global security firm with over 600,000 employees. Garda is seeking support from G4S investors to force management to the negotiating table, amid concerns over job losses and pension obligations.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Monday, following a rally across Asia, with the Hang Seng Index gaining 0.56% to 24,640.28. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased, driven by fresh vaccine hopes and a trial resuming at the weekend.

site_title: Nvidia vows to invest in Britain as part of Arm deal
summary: Nvidia has agreed to invest in Britain as part of its $40 billion purchase of chip designer Arm, following complaints from an Arm co-founder that the deal would destroy the company. Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang vowed to step up investment in Britain, increasing jobs and research, but stopped short of making formal job guarantees. The UK government will scrutinize the deal, but it's unlikely to block it, with analysts expecting Nvidia to make commitments to maintain intellectual property investment and leadership.

site_title: Amazon hiring 100,000 new employees in US, Canada
summary: Amazon is hiring 100,000 full and part-time employees across the US and Canada, starting with a minimum wage of US$15 an hour. The new jobs offer benefits and sign-on bonuses, as well as access to training programs. Amazon plans to open 100 new operations buildings across fulfillment centers, delivery stations, and other sites. This hiring move comes as the company's business and market valuation have soared, with shares surging 70% this year and its market value reaching US$1.56 trillion.

site_title: London City Airport could cut 35% of staff due to Covid crisis
summary: London City Airport plans to cut up to 239 jobs, approximately 35% of its staff, due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on passenger numbers. The airport has already reduced non-essential spending and paused its expansion program. The job cuts are part of a restructuring plan to prepare for the traditionally weaker winter season.

site_title: CapitaLand unit prices S$800m fixed-rate senior notes due 2032
summary: CapitaLand has priced an S$800 million 2.90% fixed-rate senior note due 2032 under its S$5 billion euro medium-term note programme. The issue is expected to be finalized on September 21, with DBS and UOB serving as joint lead managers and bookrunners. The net proceeds will be used for refinancing existing borrowings, investments, and general corporate purposes. This comes after CapitaLand shares closed down 2 cents, or 0.73%, at S$2.73 on Monday.

site_title: SIA kicks off retrenchment exercise; affected staff told they will be paid until Dec 15
summary: Singapore Airlines has begun its retrenchment exercise, affecting approximately 2,400 staff, with those in Singapore receiving their pink slips on Monday. Affected staff will receive their salary until December 15 and retain medical and other benefits until then. They will also receive in lieu of notice pay, ranging from one to three months' salary, depending on their years of service. The airline aims to minimize stress and anxiety for affected staff, with support from unions and on-site counselors.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's total employment fell by a record 103,500 in Q2, a four-fold increase from the previous record contraction of 25,600. This marks the largest quarterly employment decline since the start of the pandemic.

site_title: Mary Chia's independent auditor flags material uncertainty, though opinion is unmodified
summary: Mary Chia Holdings, a beauty and wellness company listed on the Singapore Exchange, has faced a material uncertainty related to its ability to continue as a going concern, according to its independent auditor. The company recorded significant losses and liabilities, with net operating cash outflows and a deficit in equity. However, its directors believe it can continue as a going concern due to prudent cash flow planning and cost reduction measures. The company has also received an undertaking from a controlling shareholder to provide financial support for the next 12 months.

site_title: BT launches News Tablet Edition
summary: The Business Times (BT) has launched the News Tablet Edition, a subscription bundle that includes an Android tablet with the exclusive SPHtab e-paper app pre-installed. The bundle, priced at $39.90 a month over 30 months, offers a seamless digital reading experience similar to print. Subscribers will also receive access to the BT website and app, as well as a complimentary 128GB microSD memory card. The promotion is available until September 30, and BT will also offer a bundled Samsung Galaxy Tab A Wi-Fi tablet at $29.90 a month for 30 months.

images.alt_text: Thanks to the sharp and spacious 10.4-inch touchscreen on the Tab S6 Lite (LTE) tablet and the bundled S Pen stylus, browsing the BT e-paper is a breeze, as is zooming, clipping and sharing stories.

site_title: UBS chairman explores merger with Credit Suisse
summary: UBS chairman Axel Weber is exploring a potential merger with Credit Suisse, driven by the need to create one of Europe's largest banks amid industry consolidation. The project, nicknamed Signal, could result in 15,000 or more job cuts worldwide, equivalent to 10-20% of the workforce. Banking regulator Finma has been informed of the deliberations, and UBS chairman Weber would likely remain in charge of the combined company, with a CEO from Credit Suisse. A potential agreement could happen by early next year, according to reports.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 6.51 points to 1,511.36 on Monday, driven by a 9.570 billion lots traded worth RM6.465 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 806 to 329. The gain follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a boost in Asian markets, despite US President Trump's new threats.

site_title: Co-founder of Arm attacks sale to Nvidia as a 'disaster'
summary: Arm's co-founder Hermann Hauser criticized the $40 billion sale to Nvidia, calling it a "disaster" that will destroy Arm's business model. Hauser urged the UK government to impose conditions to protect the company's European relevance, including job guarantees and preservation of its open business model. If these conditions cannot be met, Hauser suggested the UK government help orchestrate an initial public offering to make Arm a British company.

site_title: Verizon buying TracFone Wireless service for US$6.25b
summary: Verizon Communications has agreed to buy TracFone Wireless from America Movil for $6.25 billion, expanding its mobile business into the prepaid market. TracFone, with 21 million subscribers, is the largest US prepaid service. The acquisition aims to counter pressure from T-Mobile US and AT&T's prepaid offerings. Verizon will pay $3.125 billion in cash and stock, with additional $650 million tied to performance goals. The deal is expected to strengthen Verizon's position in the US wireless market.

site_title: BIS warns of gap opening between markets and Covid-19 reality
summary: The Bank for International Settlements (BIS) warns of a growing gap between stock markets and the reality of a global economy severely impacted by Covid-19. Despite rising 50% since February, global stock markets may not accurately reflect economic prospects. The BIS' Claudio Borio notes that the withdrawal of accommodation will need to be phased out, and the most challenging phase of the crisis is still ahead. The transition from liquidity to solvency phase poses significant policy challenges, particularly in distinguishing viable from non-viable firms amidst uncertainty about future demand patterns.

site_title: Accordia Golf Trust unitholders vote in favour of proposed divestment and winding up
summary: Accordia Golf Trust's unitholders voted 97.55% in favor of divesting the trust's interests in its 88 golf courses to its sponsor, Accordia Golf, for 65.2 billion yen (S$840.5 million). Unitholders also voted 99.4% in favor of winding up the trust. The proposed divestment is expected to be completed on Sept 29, with the first special distribution of 54.57 yen per unit due on Oct 15.

site_title: Google faces US$3b UK suit over use of children's data
summary: Google faces a multibillion-dollar lawsuit in the UK over claims that YouTube breaks UK and European privacy laws by tracking children online without parental consent. The lawsuit, filed on behalf of over 5 million British children under 13, alleges "major breaches" of data rules and seeks up to $4.38 billion in compensation. The claimants argue that YouTube's methods of targeting underage audiences constitute "major breaches" of UK and European privacy and data rules, with each child potentially entitled to 100-500 pounds in compensation.

site_title: Private exchange HGX begins trading
summary: Private exchange HGX has begun trading shares of private companies, marking a significant development in the private capital markets. The exchange, backed by three founding members, leverages a network of brokers and customers to offer greater liquidity options. HGX aims to harness its strength to transform the ecosystem, allowing for the buying and selling of smaller lots using blockchain technology. This move is seen as a response to companies delaying initial public offerings, and the exchange's chairman, Richard Teng, notes that private capital markets are gaining momentum.

site_title: Suga wins party vote, likely to be next Japan PM
summary: Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) elected Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga as its new leader, making him likely to become the country's next prime minister. Suga won the vote with 377 of 534 valid votes, easily surpassing his two rivals. He has pledged to continue Shinzo Abe's policies and has been chosen by the party to ensure stability. Suga is expected to win a parliamentary vote on Wednesday and become prime minister, succeeding Abe who is resigning due to health reasons.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets climb at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.7% to 6,076.68 points, and the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices gaining 0.8% and 0.9% respectively. The gains followed Asian advances and were attributed to mining and healthcare stocks. US markets also reached fresh records, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq indices edging higher despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Alibaba in talks to invest US$3b in Grab
summary: Alibaba Group Holding is in talks to invest US$3 billion in Southeast Asian ride-hailing giant Grab Holdings, a deal that may give the Chinese e-commerce giant access to data and a stake in digital wallet and financial services. The investment comes amid growing questions over Grab's ability to live up to its lofty price tag, with existing investors frustrated by competition with rival Gojek. Alibaba's investment could also be a response to SoftBank's efforts to push Uber to unload stakes in Grab, Didi Chuxing, and Yandex.

site_title: West Mall, Liat Towers, Changi T3 and Queensway Shopping Centre among places visited by Covid-19 patients
summary: The Ministry of Health in Singapore has released a list of locations visited by Covid-19 patients while they were still infectious, including West Mall, Liat Towers, and Changi T3. There were also four visits by confirmed cases at the Anytime Fitness gym in Queensway Shopping Centre between Sept 3 and 8. The ministry is providing the list to monitor the health of those who visited these places during the specified periods.

site_title: French finance minister backs foreign minister over LVMH-Tiffany intervention
summary: French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire has backed Foreign Minister Jean-Yves Le Drian's intervention in LVMH's plans to back out of a Tiffany takeover due to US tariffs. Le Maire stated that Le Drian's decision was to protect French interests. LVMH and Tiffany are currently in a legal battle over the deal. The French government's request to delay the acquisition has been met with a counter-suit from LVMH, accusing Tiffany of mismanagement during the coronavirus crisis.

site_title: Tritech makes foray into sanitiser, disinfectant industry
summary: Tritech Group, a water and environment firm, has expanded into the sanitiser and disinfectant industry with the launch of VaVie Clean Wash Sanitize (CWS), a proprietary product using its water and membrane technology. The product, made with purified water and food-grade materials, has been tested to be effective in killing 99.9% of bacteria and viruses. With production facilities in Singapore and China, the company aims to sell the product to retail, commercial, and industrial markets, diversifying its product lines and revenue streams.

site_title: Seoul: Shares post one-month closing high on Samsung gains, foreign buying
summary: South Korean shares closed at a one-month high on Monday, driven by gains in Samsung Electronics and strong foreign buying. The Kospi index rose 1.30% to 2,427.91, its highest close since August 13. Analysts attributed the gains to improved business conditions and eased social distancing measures in Seoul, which lifted hopes for economic normalization.

site_title: Epic Suisse plans to raise 200m Swiss francs from IPO
summary: Epic Suisse AG, a Swiss commercial real estate company, plans to raise approximately 200 million Swiss francs (S$300.8 million) through an initial public offering (IPO) on SIX Swiss Exchange. The company's real estate portfolio is valued at 1.3 billion francs, and the IPO funds will be used to finance future acquisitions, development projects, capital spending, and debt redemption. Epic Suisse aims to distribute over 80% of funds from operations as dividends, with a fixed dividend of 2.60 francs per share for 2020. The listing is expected to occur in the coming months, pending market conditions.

site_title: Singapore's total employment falls by record 103,500 in Q2; retrenchments double
summary: Singapore's employment fell by a record 103,500 in Q2, with retrenchments more than doubling to 8,130. The country's total employment excluding foreign domestic workers contracted by 129,100 in the first half of the year, with foreign employment declining 5.7% and local employment 2.7%. Despite this, unemployment rates remained below past recessionary peaks, with seasonally adjusted unemployment rates rising to 2.8% in June. The Ministry of Manpower expects softness in the labour market to persist, but notes areas of strength in the electronics and precision engineering sectors.

site_title: Delta launches US$6.5b debt deal backed by frequent flyer programme
summary: Delta Air Lines is seeking to raise $6.5 billion through new bonds and loans backed by its SkyMiles loyalty program to weather the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on travel demand. The airline burns through $27 million in cash daily and will use the loyalty program as collateral to secure the new loans. This move comes as US airlines have cut costs and raised debt to survive an unprecedented industry crisis. The situation is not expected to improve until demand recovers meaningfully.

images.alt_text: Delta Air Lines said on Monday it is seeking to raise US$6.5 billion through new bonds and loans backed by its SkyMiles loyalty programme, further bolstering liquidity to weather a drastic downturn in travel demand due to the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: HK-based fintech startup XanPool raises US$4.3m in pre-Series A funding
summary: HK-based fintech startup XanPool raised US$4.3 million in pre-Series A funding led by OK Group, HashKey, and Gumi Cryptos. The funds will support expansion into 8+ South-east Asian countries and the traditional online merchant payment space. XanPool aims to build affordable infrastructure for cryptocurrency processing and local currency routing, offering instant processing without custody risk. CEO Jeffery Liu plans to use the funds to expand beyond South-east Asia and partner with Daniel De Weyer, former SWIFT director, to drive geographic and product expansion efforts.

site_title: Thai court approves Thai Air's request for restructuring
summary: Thailand's Central Bankruptcy Court approved Thai Airways International Pcl's request to restructure 245 billion baht (S$10.7 billion) worth of debt as part of bankruptcy proceedings. The airline will move ahead with restructuring plans, expected to take three to five months, following the court's decision. This comes as the coronavirus pandemic has further strained the airline, which has been struggling since 2012.

site_title: Merck inks up to US$4.5b Seattle Genetics cancer deal
summary: Merck has agreed to a US$4.5 billion deal with Seattle Genetics, taking a US$1 billion stake in the biotech firm and paying up to US$4.5 billion for two of its cancer drugs. The collaboration will co-develop and sell Seattle Genetics' ladiratuzumab vedotin with Merck's Keytruda, and Seattle Genetics is eligible for up to US$2.6 billion in milestone payments. Merck also acquired an exclusive licence to sell Tukysa in certain regions outside the US, Canada, and Europe, with an upfront payment of US$125 million.

site_title: Australian court fines NAB pension funds A$57.5m over fees for no service
summary: Australia's federal court fined National Australia Bank (NAB) A$57.5 million for charging fees to thousands of retirees with no service. The ruling stems from a 2018 civil lawsuit brought by the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) over misconduct in the financial sector. NAB's pension funds, NULIS Nominees and MLC Nominees, deducted A$100 million in fees from 677,000 retirees between 2012 and 2018. NAB admitted to "misleading" conduct and paid A$117 million to affected members.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher as miners lead, virus cases abate
summary: Australian shares ended 0.7% higher at 5,899.5, driven by gains from mining stocks such as Rio Tinto, Fortescue Metals Group, and BHP Group. Victoria reported its lowest single-day rise in new Covid-19 cases, allowing residents to exercise outside for two hours. Analysts attributed the gains to easing restrictions and top management changes at Rio Tinto. However, Macquarie Group's near 5% drop in first-half profit capped broader gains, and shares of buy-now, pay-later firms continued to slump.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up on hope for new government
summary: Tokyo stocks rose for a third consecutive session, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.65% to 23,559.30. Investors are optimistic about Japan's new government, expecting minimal policy changes. The broader Topix index also increased 0.88%. The gains come as traders brush off US President Trump's new threats, and the market remains positive despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Temasek upsizes medium-term note programme to US$25b
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singapore investment firm, has increased the limit of its guaranteed global medium-term note programme to US$25 billion, up from US$20 billion. The program, held by Temasek Financial (I) Limited, will provide net proceeds to fund Temasek and its subsidiaries. Standard & Poor's (S&P) ratings agency maintains its AAA rating, citing Temasek's diversified portfolio and government support. The increase marks the third upgrade of the program's limit since 2018.

site_title: Singapore to support precision engineering growth with 1,500 vacancies on offer
summary: Singapore aims to support the growth of the precision engineering sector, offering 1,500 job vacancies to more than 270 companies. The government has introduced measures, including a one-off boost to the Scale-up SG programme, to help companies in growth sectors "pull apart from the competition". The sector, which employed over 95,000 workers, is expected to continue growing due to sustained global demand for semiconductors and semiconductor equipment. The government is also focusing on upskilling Singaporeans, with a focus on professional, manager, executive, and technician (PMET) positions, and providing training opportunities for mid-career workers.

site_title: Singaporean taps captive market selling ant farms amid pandemic
summary: A Singaporean entrepreneur, John Ye, has launched a shop selling pet ants, "Just Ants", amidst the COVID-19 pandemic. Initially, sales were slow due to negative connotations associated with ants, but they have picked up since July. Ye hopes to collaborate with schools to teach children about ants and their life-cycle. The shop offers 30 species of ants in starter kit ant farms, with prices ranging from S$13.90 to S$300, and also sells live worms and other food sources. Ye believes ants can teach valuable lessons like perseverance and being headstrong.

site_title: Pandemic preparedness panel slams collective failure to head warnings
summary: A report by The Global Preparedness Monitoring Board (GPMB) criticizes the global response to the COVID-19 pandemic, stating that a collective failure by leaders to heed warnings and prepare for an infectious disease pandemic has led to a "world in disorder". The report, released in 2020, warned of a real threat of a rapidly spreading pandemic but saw little progress made in pandemic preparedness, citing a lack of leadership and insufficient financial and political investments. The board predicts that the next pandemic will be even more damaging if lessons from COVID-19 are not learned.

site_title: Gilead to buy cancer drugmaker Immunomedics for US$21b
summary: Gilead Sciences is acquiring biopharmaceutical company Immunomedics for $21 billion, gaining access to Immunomedics' breast cancer treatment drug Trodelvy, which received FDA accelerated approval in April. The deal provides a 108% premium over Immunomedics' last closing price and is expected to close in the fourth quarter of 2020. This acquisition strengthens Gilead's cancer portfolio and will explore Trodelvy's potential to treat various types of cancer.

site_title: Smaller watches show China's growing hold on luxury industry
summary: Luxury watchmaker Officine Panerai is adapting to China's growing luxury market by producing smaller watches, with some models as small as 38mm in diameter. This shift is driven by Chinese buyers' preference for more discreet products. The brand is also expanding its presence in China, with plans to add eight new stores by March and testing new products on the country's billion-plus affluent buyers. This trend is being accelerated by China's rebound from the COVID-19 pandemic, with luxury demand on the mainland expected to surge 10% this year.

site_title: Rare dolphins return to Hong Kong as coronavirus halts ferry traffic
summary: Rare Indo-Pacific humpback dolphins, also known as Chinese white dolphins and pink dolphins, have been spotted in parts of the Pearl River Delta around Hong Kong, increasing by up to 30% since March when ferry traffic was suspended due to the coronavirus. Scientists attribute the surge to the quiet environment, suggesting the population may rebound when stressors are removed. Researchers estimate around 2,000 dolphins inhabit the entire Pearl River estuary, with a 2019 survey finding only 52 dolphins in the waters around Hong Kong.

site_title: Singapore, Japan mediation centres sign MOU to provide expedited mediation amid pandemic
summary: Singapore's International Mediation Centre (SIMC) and Japan's International Mediation Center (JIMC) have signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to provide expedited mediation services to cross-border businesses affected by the Covid-19 pandemic. The joint protocol aims to provide an economical, expedited, and effective route for resolving commercial disputes. This collaboration marks SIMC's first overseas mediation partnership, following the launch of its Covid-19 Protocol in May. The joint protocol is designed to support businesses along the Singapore-Japan corridor.

site_title: Australia's Citadel gets S$445m bid from Pacific Equity, shares surge
summary: Australian software company Citadel Group Ltd saw its shares surge 41% after a bid of S$445 million from Pacific Equity Partners was accepted. The deal values Citadel at A$448.6 million and represents a 43.2% premium over its closing price. The company's chairman, Peter Leahy, stated that customers will benefit from access to a broader product suite and service capabilities with Pacific Equity's backing. A special dividend of up to A$0.15 per share will also be declared, allowing shareholders to receive up to A$0.06 of franking credit benefits.

site_title: Asia: Markets on front foot as vaccine hopes get boost
summary: Asian markets rose on Monday as investors gained hope from the resumption of vaccine trials and positive news from AstraZeneca and Oxford University. Despite this, concerns over high valuations, Brexit tensions, and the US presidential election kept gains in check. Markets in Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Sydney rose, while Tokyo and Seoul also saw gains. Analysts warn that the recovery remains fragile due to the ongoing pandemic and geopolitical risks, with the Federal Reserve's policy meeting this week expected to provide some guidance.

site_title: Chinese automakers announce targets to raise hydrogen vehicle sales
summary: Chinese automakers SAIC Motor and Beiqi Foton Motor have announced plans to increase sales of hydrogen fuel cell vehicles, with SAIC aiming for over 10,000 sales by 2025 and Beiqi Foton targeting 15,000 by 2025. The government is expected to announce supportive new policies, possibly this month, to encourage the development of the industry. This comes as China seeks to boost its hydrogen vehicle sales, with the current fleet of over 7,000 vehicles dwarfed by the four million pure battery electric and plug-in hybrid vehicles on the market.

site_title: ZenRock, Agritrade face winding-up; Hontop put under JM
summary: Two Singaporean companies, ZenRock Commodities Trading and Agritrade International, may be wound up due to significant debt. Judicial managers have filed applications to liquidate the firms, with Agritrade owing around US$1.55 billion. Hontop Energy, another oil trader, has been placed under judicial management. The companies' debts total around US$165 million and US$1.55 billion, respectively, and they are also being investigated by Singapore's white-collar crime buster. Court hearings are scheduled for September 21 and 28.

site_title: Gold gains on weaker US dollar, investors await Fed meeting
summary: Gold prices rose 0.4% to $1,949.92 per ounce, driven by a weaker US dollar and expectations of a dovish stance from the US Federal Reserve at its upcoming meeting. Investors anticipate the Fed's potential to trigger inflation, supporting the gold market.

site_title: Hot stock: Sembmarine down 2.5% on heavy selloff
summary: Sembcorp Marine shares fell 2.5% on Monday following a heavy selloff, amidst concerns about the impact of a large share issue. The company completed a two-stage corporate exercise last week, raising S$2.1 billion through a rights issue. The market may be weighed down in the coming weeks as the large number of new shares hits the market, following a similar trend with Sembcorp Industries' shares.

site_title: Broker's take: Maybank downgrades Asean banks to negative; DBS among top picks
summary: Maybank Kim Eng downgraded its sector outlook on Asean banks to negative due to high asset quality risks and limited operational recovery. Moratoriums unwinding from Q3 in Malaysia may lead to additional asset quality pressures. Domestic-focused banks, particularly those with slow economic activity, are expected to face higher operational pressures. DBS is among the top picks, according to the research team.

site_title: Macquarie sees H1 profit slump in virus upheaval
summary: Macquarie Group, an Australian conglomerate, expects its first-half profit to fall by around 35% due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on global economies. The company attributed the decline to delayed deals and subdued market trading, as well as provisions for business clients affected by shutdowns. Macquarie's shares fell 6% on the news, and the company's four main business units will be affected by challenging market conditions.

images.alt_text: Australia's Macquarie Group warned its first half profit will fall by around 35 per cent as the coronavirus pandemic shreds economies around the world, a rare downgrade from the financial powerhouse that pushed its shares lower on Monday.

site_title: NTU, ST Engineering launch Singapore's first barrier-free smart car park
summary: Nanyang Technological University (NTU) and Singapore Technologies Engineering (ST Engineering) have launched Singapore's first barrier-free smart car park, operating at three NTU campuses. The system, developed by ST Engineering's electronics arm, integrates automatic number plate recognition, data analytics, and mobile payment technologies, providing motorists with real-time parking information and cost savings. The system will be rolled out to all 59 NTU car parks by the end of 2021, covering over 4,000 parking lots, and aims to improve motorists' experience by reducing air pollution and traffic congestion.

site_title: AMTD fund invests S$11.5m in five Singapore-based fintech startups
summary: AMTD Singapore Solidarity Fund has invested S$11.5 million in five Singapore-based fintech startups: Funding Societies, Active.ai, CardUp, TranSwap, and PolicyPal. The fund, part of the AMTD Asean Solidarity Fund Group, aims to support fintechs in Asean countries during the pandemic. The investments will provide financial support and access to AMTD's digital platform and SpiderNet ecosystem to help fintechs maximize user experience and digital offerings to Asian consumers and SMEs.

site_title: STB, Klook ink S$2m partnership to promote domestic tourism, local businesses
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) and travel booking platform Klook have partnered for a $2 million marketing initiative under the SingapoRediscovers campaign to promote domestic tourism and local businesses. The seven-month partnership aims to encourage locals to explore and experience a "different side of Singapore" through curated promotions, content development, and digital marketing. Businesses will be encouraged to develop new products and experiences, including bundles with attractive offers for various interest groups. The partnership will also cast a spotlight on "hidden gems" and home-grown businesses in Singapore.

site_title: Taiwan holding five Hong Kongers picked up at sea: sources
summary: Taiwan has been holding five Hong Kongers who fled China by boat and were picked up by Taiwan's coast guard in the South China Sea. The individuals, who left Hong Kong by boat and reached the Pratas Islands, are currently being held at a coast guard facility in Kaohsiung. Taiwan's government has declined to comment on the case, but Premier Su Tseng-chang expressed concern for Hong Kong people fleeing persecution. Critics, including opposition parties, have called for the government to provide clearer help and amend laws to prevent people smugglers from using Taiwan as a route.

site_title: Broker's take: UOBKH upgrades StarHub to 'buy' on recovery plan
summary: UOB Kay Hian upgraded StarHub to "buy" citing recovery trends in the second half of 2020. Analysts Chong Lee Len and Chloe Tan expect the telco to defend market share through customer acquisition activities and new products. The research team maintains a target price of S$1.40 and forecasts a 4.7% to 5.2% dividend yield for 2020 and 2021, respectively. StarHub's management has guided for potential dividend increases in the second half, driven by the reopening of the Singapore economy.

site_title: Hong Lai Huat unit to buy Cambodia land plot for US$22.5m
summary: Hong Lai Huat's wholly-owned subsidiary, Public Housing Development (Cambodia), has agreed to acquire a 1.2-hectare freehold land plot in Phnom Penh, Cambodia for US$22.5 million. The transaction is part of the group's efforts to develop mixed-use properties in the region. Hong Lai Huat will finance the purchase using internal funds and bank borrowings, and the agreement is expected to be completed within 180 days. The acquisition is not expected to impact the group's net tangible assets or earnings per share for the financial year ending Dec 31, 2020.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Monday, rising 9.27 points or 0.62% to 1,514.12. The market saw a volume of 231.58 million lots worth RM187.79 million. Gainers outpaced losers 334 to 78. This trend follows a broader market rally, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching fresh records despite US-EU trade uncertainty.

site_title: Oil mixed as storm threatens US gulf production
summary: US crude futures rose 9 cents to $37.42 a barrel as Tropical Storm Sally disrupted oil production in the Gulf of Mexico. However, gains were limited by concerns about excess supply and falling demand. The US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures ended last week lower for the second consecutive week. The storm's impact on oil production, combined with a lacklustre driving season and refinery shutdowns, has led to softening demand expectations.

images.alt_text: Oil prices were mixed on Monday with US crude rising as a tropical storm in the Gulf of Mexico forced rigs to shut down, but the gains were kept in check by wider concerns about excess supply and falling demand for fuels.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open Monday's session on front foot
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened Monday on a positive note, driven by fresh vaccine hopes. The Hang Sang Index rose 0.27% to 24,569.03, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.48% and 0.61%, respectively. Investors await the Federal Reserve's policy meeting this week, with a rally in US stocks also contributing to the positive sentiment.

site_title: In new development, New York buyers favour the boroughs
summary: New York buyers are favoring Brooklyn and Queens for new development, defying the city's overall slump in sales. Despite the pandemic crippling the market, these boroughs are outperforming pre-pandemic expectations. Over 60% of new condos remain unsold, with much of that supply accumulating before the virus. This shift suggests that affluent residents who left the city for the suburbs were primarily supporting the already struggling Manhattan condo market. Brooklyn and Queens' popularity may signal a new trend in New York's real estate market.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust to buy US data centre for up to US$262.1m
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) is proposing to acquire a US data centre and office in Virginia for between US$200.6 million and US$262.1 million. The deal, targeting completion in Q1 2021, is in line with MIT's long-term strategy of focusing on growth potential. The acquisition will increase exposure to data centres and the US market, providing income stability and expected to be accretive to its distribution per unit.

site_title: Singapore stocks edge down; STI opens 0.1% lower
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.1% lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) at 2,488.33, following a 5-day rally. Gainers outnumbered losers 81 to 47, with Sembcorp Marine rising 2.5%. The benchmark index has been driven by investor positivity despite tariff uncertainty, with the Fed's split views also supporting the rally.

site_title: New Zealand to lift coronavirus curbs in most of country on Sept 21
summary: New Zealand to lift most coronavirus restrictions on Sept 21, except in Auckland, which will remain under alert level 2.5. Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern announced the move, easing physical distancing requirements on planes and allowing gatherings of more than 10 people. Masks will still be mandatory on public transport. The Auckland restrictions will be reviewed on Sept 21, with a potential increase in gathering limits if the situation stays stable. New Zealand reported one new case of coronavirus, bringing the total to 1,447 cases and 24 deaths.

site_title: SGTech starts fund to help SMEs in Singapore digitalise
summary: SGTech, a tech association in Singapore, has launched a fund to support small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in their digitalisation efforts. The "Stronger Together, Aiding Recovery" fund, starting with S$660,000, aims to help SMEs leverage technology to overcome the disruptions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The fund, which will accept applications from October 1, 2020, to March 31, 2022, is supported by Facebook and Enterprise Singapore, with a 1:2 match ratio. Eligible SMEs must meet specific criteria, including local shareholding and revenue limits.

site_title: Lufthansa's Swiss unit could cut 15% of jobs
summary: Lufthansa's Swiss unit, Swiss, may cut up to 15% of its 9,500 jobs if it fails to agree on salary cuts with staff to meet cost savings targets. The airline aims to reduce costs by 20% as part of its restructuring efforts. Swiss has already begun negotiations on temporary adjustments to working conditions and benefits. The move is part of Lufthansa's larger plan to repay a €9 billion state bailout and navigate deepening losses due to the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Stocks to watch: MIT, Keppel Reit, ST Engg, Singapore Airlines, CapitaLand, Oxley
summary: Key stocks to watch on Monday include MIT, Keppel Reit, and ST Engineering, with the latter planning a multi-million dollar "smart" network with AI and cybersecurity. Singapore Airlines may offer "flights to nowhere" in October to boost revenue. CapitaLand is a frontrunner for ABI Plaza, and Oxley Holdings clarified its handover process for mixed developments. DBS may extend its dividend cap into FY21 due to lower net interest income and uncertainty.

site_title: Moya unit to operate, maintain water supply system in Batam for six months
summary: Moya Holdings Asia's subsidiary, Moya Indonesia, has been awarded a project by BP Batam to operate and maintain a water supply system in Batam for six months starting Nov 15. The project aims to maintain a continuous water supply system after the expiry of the existing concession. Moya expects no material impact on its financials and plans to sign a cooperation agreement with BP Batam by Sept 15. The water supply system serves around 290,000 customers with six water treatment plants.

site_title: China aiming to add to its cobalt stockpile: sources
summary: China is seeking to increase its cobalt stockpile, with the National Food and Strategic Reserves Administration asking major producers to submit proposals to sell metal to the state. This move is seen as a response to the coronavirus-driven slump in commodity prices and to support struggling producers. China is estimated to hold up to 7,000 tonnes of cobalt, a key component in aerospace alloys, battery chemicals, and electric vehicle production. The stockpile could help China maintain its dominance in the cobalt market and support its growing electric vehicle sector.

site_title: China's demand for condo butler service sparks 390% stock gain
summary: China's demand for condo butler services has led to a 390% stock gain for companies offering such services. This surge is attributed to the pandemic keeping workers at home, increasing the need for property management services. Ever Sunshine Lifestyle Services Group Ltd, Yincheng Life Service Co, and Times Neighborhood Holdings Ltd have seen significant growth, with housing service stocks in Hong Kong rising 60% on average. This growth outpaces the 47% rise in Chinese consumer stocks and the 29% gain for technology firms.

site_title: Darco Water ex-CEO to contest lawsuit brought by company
summary: Darco Water Technologies has announced that its former CEO, Thye Kim Meng, will contest a lawsuit brought by the company. The lawsuit claims Meng breached his duties in two projects, resulting in losses of US$1.6 million. Despite initial attempts to serve Meng with the legal documents, he was served by personal service at his residence on September 9. Meng has acknowledged the service and entered an appearance in the lawsuit. Darco will make further announcements as the case progresses.

site_title: UK job cuts set to double last recession peak in coming months
summary: The UK is expected to see over 450,000 job losses in the autumn, more than double the number during the 2008 recession, as businesses struggle with the end of state wage support measures. The Institute for Employment Studies predicts the job losses, citing government data on insolvency notifications. The Bank of England's chief economist supports ending the furlough programme, citing the need for restructuring, while the Chancellor faces calls to extend the programme to mitigate job losses. The UK's economic contraction is expected to worsen, with government debt reaching over $3.5 trillion.

site_title: Euro gains for third straight day vs dollar
summary: The euro rose for a third consecutive day against the dollar, reaching a high of $1.1850, as investors remained optimistic about the single currency's value. European Central Bank (ECB) President Christine Lagarde stated that the bank is not targeting exchange rates, and policymakers agreed to look through the euro's rise, judging it to be in line with economic fundamentals. The dollar index remained flat, and the pound fell 0.1% against the dollar, reaching a 5.5-month low against the euro.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index rising 0.27% or 62.07 points to 23,468.56, following Tokyo's addition to a government domestic tourism campaign to boost the economy. The broader Topix index also rose 0.66%. The positive start comes despite global market uncertainty and US trade tensions.

site_title: Sinarmas, Mitsubishi, Surbana tie up for transit-oriented developments in Indonesia
summary: Sinarmas Land, a subsidiary of Sinarmas Land, has partnered with Mitbana, a joint-venture fund management company of Mitsubishi Corporation and Surbana Jurong, to develop smart and sustainable transit-oriented developments (TODs) in Bumi Serpong Damai (BSD) City, Indonesia. The project aims to transform over 100 hectares of greenfield land into TODs, including residential units, commercial properties, and public transport nodes, with the goal of expanding BSD City's existing development footprint. Mitsubishi Corporation and Surbana Jurong will lend their expertise in smart home technology and urban development, respectively, to support the endeavor.

site_title: Fossil fuel demand to take historic knock amid Covid-19 scars: BP
summary: BP forecasts a historic decline in fossil fuel demand due to the COVID-19 pandemic's lasting effects and climate policies boosting renewable energy. The company expects global economic activity to partially recover over the next few years, but with slower growth in energy consumption. By 2050, BP predicts fossil fuel consumption will shrink by 2-3 million barrels per day, with renewables growing to 20-65% of total primary energy demand. This marks an unprecedented event in modern history, with fossil fuels' share declining from 85% in 2018 to 20-65% by 2050.

site_title: China's Aug new home prices rise at slightly faster pace
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.6% in August, the fastest monthly pace since July, with prices increasing 4.8% year-over-year. This marks the latest sign of the country's economic recovery, driven by the property market. Policymakers remain concerned about speculation and overheating, and have introduced new rules to control liquidity and tightened curbs on home purchases in some cities. The robust growth in home sales and investment is expected to continue, despite regulatory efforts to rein in prices.

site_title: Europe, Britain's carmakers warn of 110b euro hard Brexit bill
summary: Europe and Britain's car industries warned of a 110 billion euro hard Brexit bill, citing a potential loss of 3 million vehicle production over the next five years, resulting in 57.7 billion euros in EU plant losses and 52.8 billion euros in UK factory losses. A disorderly Brexit would lead to tariffs, making vehicles more expensive and causing a drop in demand, with the industry associations calling on both sides to urgently secure a free trade agreement.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on easing of curbs, low new infections
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% on Monday, driven by a near-three-month low in daily coronavirus cases in Victoria and easing of restrictions in Melbourne. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 5,887.5, its fourth straight weekly decline. Mining stocks surged, with BHP Group and Rio Tinto jumping 2.7% and 3.9%, respectively. Tensions between Australia and China also influenced investor sentiment, with Canberra defending its rights to intelligence raids amid deteriorating trade relations.

site_title: Singapore Kitchen Equipment execs in graft probe
summary: Singapore Kitchen Equipment's founders, Sally Chua and Alan Lee, are under investigation by the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) for offences under Section 6(b) of the Prevention of Corruption Act. Chua, the executive director and CEO, and her husband Lee, an executive director, as well as senior sales manager Alvin Chiao, are on bail and had their passports surrendered. The investigation is ongoing, and no charges have been filed against them yet. The company's nominating committee believes the trio remains competent, but has strengthened corporate governance amid the probe.

site_title: Australia to boost domestic fuel storage, subsidise refineries
summary: Australia is investing A$211 million to boost domestic fuel storage and subsidize local refineries to prevent closures. The move aims to secure the country's long-term fuel supply amid a coronavirus-driven demand slump. The government plans to work with refineries to protect consumers from potential price increases and ensure a sovereign fuel supply for national security.

site_title: WHO reports record one-day increase in global coronavirus cases, up over 307,000
summary: The World Health Organization reported a record one-day increase of 307,930 global coronavirus cases, with the US, India, and Brazil experiencing the largest increases. Deaths rose by 5,537 to a total of 917,417. India leads the world in new cases reported each day, with total cases exceeding 4.75 million. New cases are still rising in 58 countries, but are falling in the US and Brazil.

images.alt_text: India reported 94,372 new cases, followed by the United States with 45,523 new infections and Brazil with 43,718.

site_title: SoftBank to sell chip designer Arm to Nvidia in US$40b deal
summary: SoftBank has agreed to sell chip designer Arm to Nvidia for up to $40 billion, reshaping the semiconductor landscape. The deal includes $21.5 billion in shares and $12 billion in cash, with SoftBank and the Vision Fund retaining a 6.7-8.1% stake in Nvidia. The acquisition gives Nvidia control over Arm's technology, which could be used to make its own central processor chips, intensifying competition in the data centre chip market.

site_title: Embattled SoftBank renews talks on taking the group private: source
summary: SoftBank Group executives are holding early-stage talks about taking the Japanese technology group private, driven by frustrations over the persistent discount in its equity valuation. The discussions come after the company disposed of several large assets, including its sale of British chip designer Arm to Nvidia for $40 billion. SoftBank management is divided on whether to proceed with the deal, which would mark the group's second attempt at a go-private strategy. The talks are at a preliminary stage and are not the first time SoftBank executives have discussed such a move.

site_title: Covid-19 is making flying business class feel more like economy
summary: Business class on commercial flights is experiencing a decline in luxury amenities due to COVID-19 efforts to minimize human interaction and reduce infection risk. Gone are the multi-course banquets and warm personal service, replaced by functional, hygienic options. Airlines are struggling to win back top-paying customers as the industry grapples with a near-total collapse in demand. Experts predict that premium economy may be more affected, as passengers may not be willing to pay the price differential for reduced service. Airlines may need to permanently downgrade their offerings to save costs.

site_title: Japan's Suga poised to win party race, headed for premiership
summary: Japan's Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga, 71, is poised to win a ruling party leadership election, virtually ensuring he replaces outgoing Prime Minister Shinzo Abe this week. Suga is expected to get 394 Liberal Democratic Party lawmakers' votes and likely win a majority of 141 votes from local chapters. He will serve out Abe's term as party leader through September 2021 and pursue Abe's key economic and foreign policies, including "Abenomics." Suga faces geopolitical challenges and speculation of a snap election to boost his chances of winning a full three-year term as LDP chief next year.

site_title: Microsoft says ByteDance rejected its bid for TikTok in the US
summary: Microsoft says its bid for TikTok's US operations was rejected by ByteDance, citing national security concerns. Microsoft had proposed changes to address US concerns, but ByteDance declined. Oracle, a competitor, has gained an upper hand in negotiations. Microsoft is prepared to make further changes to address security concerns and looks forward to seeing the service evolve in these areas.

site_title: Marseille beat PSG for first time in 21 matches
summary: Marseille secured their first win over Paris Saint-Germain in 21 matches, defeating the Ligue 1 champions 1-0 on Sunday. Florian Thauvin scored a close-range volley in the 31st minute, and despite PSG's efforts, including a goal from Angel Di Maria, the match ended in a 1-0 victory for Marseille. The win comes as PSG face a challenging schedule, including visits from Metz and Nice, and Neymar was sent off after a scuffle with Marseille defender Alvaro Gonzalez, resulting in five red cards.

site_title: Improving worker welfare
summary: Singapore business leaders debate whether to support measures to uplift lower-wage workers, even if it means higher costs for their organizations. Some argue that raising wages is essential for social stability, economic growth, and fairness, while others believe it could lead to job losses and increased costs. The Progressive Wage Model, adopted by Singapore, aims to raise wages in three sectors while considering the cost of living. Experts emphasize the importance of upskilling and job restructuring to improve productivity and competitiveness. The debate highlights the need for a balanced approach that addresses the needs of both workers and businesses.

site_title: Greece to boost economy with 6.8b euro stimulus
summary: Greek Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis announced a 6.8 billion euro stimulus package to combat the coronavirus's impact on the country's economy. The package includes slashing companies' social contributions, creating 100,000 jobs, and tax cuts for residents on tourist islands. This measure comes on top of a previously decided 24-billion-euro package. Greece's central bank predicts a 5.8% GDP contraction this year, while the IMF forecasts a 10% plunge, with a rebound expected in 2021.

site_title: Billionaire brothers raise US property bet with LA project
summary: British billionaire brothers David and Simon Reuben have invested US$275 million in a US$2.5 billion redevelopment project in Los Angeles, financing a senior mezzanine loan for the Century Plaza site. The brothers, who control a US$12 billion portfolio of retail, office, and residential properties, have completed several major deals in the US this year, including financing for the Time Hotel in New York and Manhattan retail property near Rockefeller Center. Their investment in the LA project demonstrates their continued interest in US real estate.

site_title: Hanwell's executive director increases stake to 18.02%
summary: Hanwell Holdings' executive director, Tang Cheuk Chee, increased her stake in the company to 18.02% after acquiring 818,200 shares between Sept 8 and 9. The shares were bought at 23.50 cents per share. The acquisition is part of the company's efforts to enhance its packaging business sector's performance.

site_title: Saudi Arabia's BinDawood sets IPO price range, aims to raise up to 2.2b riyals
summary: BinDawood Holding, a Saudi Arabian supermarket retailer, sets an indicative price for its initial public offering (IPO), aiming to raise up to 2.19 billion riyals. The company plans to offer 22.86 million existing shares at a price range of 84-96 riyals per share, targeting a valuation of 9.6-11 billion riyals. This marks another major listing for Saudi Arabia's bourse, following Aramco's record IPO last year, as the country encourages more family-owned companies to list to deepen its capital markets.

site_title: Capturing opportunities through new business models and engagement after Covid-19
summary: Economies worldwide are gradually restarting after the COVID-19 pandemic, with digital services becoming the primary choice for consumers. Businesses must adapt by rethinking their operating models and engaging customers through seamless, omni-channel experiences. Companies must prioritize customer trust by safeguarding against cyber threats and investing in digital infrastructure. The pandemic has accelerated the shift to remote work, offering opportunities for businesses to reimagine their workforce and growth strategies. To capture the opportunities in a post-Covid world, businesses must embrace new business models that serve digital-first consumers and companies.

site_title: CapLand private fund in exclusive talks to buy ABI Plaza
summary: A private fund managed by CapitaLand is in exclusive talks to buy ABI Plaza, a 12-storey office building in Singapore, for approximately S$206 million, significantly lower than the guide price of S$280 million. The entity linked to the private fund is believed to be the frontrunner for the property, which has redevelopment potential.

site_title: Airlines, devastated
summary: Airlines worldwide are severely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, leading to devastating effects. Many airlines are facing financial struggles and are forced to consider layoffs and wage cuts to stay afloat. The pandemic's economic downturn has also affected other industries, including small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), with some struggling to stay in business.

site_title: Ageing and empty: Japan next premier's hometown highlights challenges ahead
summary: Japan's next prime minister, Yoshihide Suga, hails from the remote town of Yuzawa, where nearly half the residents are over 60, and depopulation has led to a dramatic decline in tax revenue. The town, 480km northeast of Tokyo, faces significant challenges, including a low birth rate and lack of jobs, with only 442 high school students graduating last year. Suga's hometown tax policy, which allows residents to pay local taxes to an area other than where they live, is seen as a potential solution, but is not enough to turn the town's fortunes around.

site_title: Israel announces 3-week nationwide coronavirus lockdown
summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced a three-week nationwide coronavirus lockdown in an effort to curb the spread of the virus, which has reached 4,000 new cases a day. The lockdown, set to begin on Friday, will limit indoor gatherings to 10 people and outdoor gatherings to 20, close restaurants to on-site dining, and restrict movement to within 500m of one's home. Netanyahu acknowledged the measures will have a significant impact, particularly on the Jewish New Year and High Holidays.

site_title: Parliament may be dissolved soon, says Japan's Finance Minister
summary: Japan's Finance Minister Taro Aso hinted that the lower house of parliament may be dissolved soon, potentially leading to early elections, to avoid criticism of the next administration. This comes as Yoshihide Suga, the expected prime minister, is set to be elected and may call elections to improve his chances of winning a full term. A general election must be held by October 2021, and Suga has emphasized the need to revive the economy before considering elections.

site_title: Upcoming FOMC meeting expected to focus on new inflation strategy: analysts
summary: The Federal Reserve's policy-setting committee is expected to meet on Tuesday to discuss its new inflation strategy amid a deadlock in Congress on boosting the US economy. The Fed will likely focus on easy money policies and interest rates, following its deployment of trillions of dollars in liquidity lines and an emergency rate cut to near-zero in the pandemic's early days. The committee's decisions come as the US economy struggles to recover from the coronavirus downturn.

site_title: ByteDance picks Oracle for TikTok US deal: source
summary: ByteDance has chosen a consortium led by Oracle Corp for a deal to sell the US operations of short-video app TikTok, beating out Microsoft Corp. The deal will be structured as a restructuring, with Oracle handling TikTok's US user data and ByteDance retaining ownership of some operations. This comes after US President Donald Trump threatened to ban the service if it wasn't sold. The deal was made after ByteDance was in talks to sell TikTok's US business since Trump's threat last month.

site_title: Global pandemic forces central banks to turn to unconventional monetary policy
summary: Global central bankers have turned to unconventional monetary policies in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, recession, and deflation. The Federal Reserve, European Central Bank, and other international counterparts have become more aggressive and innovative in defending their economies. This shift has proven to be long-lasting, forcing central bankers to rethink their approaches. As a result, global monetary policies are becoming more conventional, and central bankers are facing new challenges in addressing economic pressures.

images.alt_text: Monetary policy will likely stay ultra-loose for years to come - even if that means central banks artificially propping up markets or sparking a run-up in prices.

site_title: Neo Group keeping eyes peeled for M&As to accelerate growth
summary: Neo Group, a Catalist-listed food caterer, is exploring mergers and acquisitions to accelerate growth. CEO Neo Kah Kiat is in talks with various parties, but is adopting a cautious approach. The group's revenue took a hit during the pandemic, with millions of dollars in cancelled buffet catering orders. Neo Group is looking to partner with regional companies, but is not rushing into deals. The company's focus on growth is driven by the need to recover from the pandemic's impact on its business.

site_title: British banks brace for deeper slump by pulling mortgage deals
summary: British banks are tightening mortgage lending restrictions for high-risk borrowers amid a looming recession and potential no-deal Brexit. HSBC, Barclays, and Natwest have reduced loan-to-income ratios and introduced stricter affordability tests. This move aims to mitigate risks in the mortgage market, where one in six borrowers has paused repayments. Economists forecast unemployment to double to 8.5% by the end of the year, putting downward pressure on incomes and mortgage payments.

site_title: Looks like game over for the giddy run of tech stocks
summary: US stocks fell last week, with the Nasdaq Composite entering correction territory, marking the end of the tech rally. The tech sector's rise, which doubled the market capitalization of "mega cap" stocks like Apple and Microsoft, was driven by a new generation of day traders and institutional investors like SoftBank Group. The rally, which added trillions of dollars in market value, was fueled by exponential growth in small lot options bets. The tech sector's momentum has come to a screeching halt, marking a significant shift in market sentiment.

site_title: Thailand tells universities to stop students' calls for monarchy reform
summary: Thai authorities have summoned university heads to stop students' calls for monarchy reform, warning of potential violence. State-appointed provincial governors have sent letters to university administrators, urging them to prevent students from reading out a list of 10 demands, which includes reducing the king's powers and controlling the royal fortune. The demands are seen as a taboo-breaking move, and authorities have threatened legal action against those involved in protests. The calls for reform come amid near-daily protests against Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha and his government.

site_title: Naomi Osaka, rallying for social justice, wins second US Open
summary: Naomi Osaka won her second US Open women's singles title, defeating Victoria Azarenka 1-6, 6-3, 6-3 in the final. Osaka, 22, became the first player in 26 years to win a US women's singles final after losing the first set, following a similar path to Arantxa Sánchez Vicario in 1994. Osaka, a social justice advocate, wore seven different masks with different names to honor Black victims of violence. The match was played in an empty stadium due to the COVID-19 pandemic, but Osaka's dominant performance and improved fitness secured her victory.

site_title: Razer Fintech, Franklin Templeton create digital wealth management platform for youth
summary: Razer Fintech, a digital bank, has partnered with Franklin Templeton, a global asset manager, to create a digital wealth management platform targeting youth and millennials in Singapore, Malaysia, the Philippines, and Vietnam. The platform aims to improve financial literacy and identify fintech startups for partnerships and co-investment opportunities. It will offer multi-asset solutions, regular savings plans, and money market funds, with a focus on making investments more accessible to young people. The platform will be developed in an app-based format, with plans to integrate it with Razer's existing digital bank offerings.

site_title: Saving the whales at Dubliners' dead zoo
summary: Staff at Dublin's "dead zoo" museum, a historic taxidermy collection, have successfully dismantled two whale skeletons that have been suspended in the air for over a century. The 65-foot fin whale and 29-foot juvenile humpback whale were carefully disassembled by a team of specialists, including experts flown in from the Netherlands. The process, which took place during the museum's 15-million-euro renovation project, was a complex and delicate task requiring hours of examination and meticulous planning. The work is expected to take three months to complete.

images.alt_text: A Leviathan task . . . dismantling a 65-foot (20-metre) fin whale skeleton, and a juvenile female humpback whale skeleton that have been hanging in the National Museum of Ireland since 1910.

site_title: Apple out to reignite growth with line updates
summary: Apple is set to unveil new products and services, including a potential iPhone 5G, at an upcoming event, aiming to reignite growth and capitalize on the holiday shopping season. The company is expected to focus on its smartwatch, iPad, and subscription services, with analysts predicting enhanced features for fitness and health uses. A separate event is also anticipated for a 5G-enabled iPhone, which is crucial for Apple's fortunes due to the disruption caused by the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: 49 new coronavirus cases; 40 from dorms
summary: There were 49 new coronavirus cases confirmed in Singapore as of Sunday, Sept 13, with 40 cases from dormitories. The majority of cases were migrant workers, and the remaining cases were imported or community cases. The number of unlinked cases in the community has decreased, and the average number of new daily cases in the community has also decreased. A total of 56,749 people have recovered from the infection, with 60 confirmed cases still in hospital.

site_title: Chasen capitalises on emerging trends
summary: Chasen Holdings, a logistics company, is capitalizing on emerging trends during the pandemic, particularly in its 3PL segment. Revenue from this segment has doubled to RM7 million in July, driven by a surge in demand for cross-border land freight due to the air cargo crunch. The company expects to see increased business in this area even after the pandemic subsides. Additionally, Chasen is expanding its warehouse and adding trucks to its fleet, and has also started a new business providing cleaning and maintenance services for critical components in the TFT LCD industry.

site_title: Healthcare firms weather crisis with overseas presences, more services
summary: Healthcare firms in Singapore are adapting to the crisis caused by the novel coronavirus by expanding their overseas presence, offering online services, and collaborating with foreign healthcare providers. Despite a halt in medical tourism, companies with international operations or services are better equipped to weather the crisis. Analysts expect patient loads to recover once travel restrictions ease, but some firms are focusing on domestic services and digitalization to mitigate losses. The pandemic has also led to increased collaboration between the private and public sectors in the national battle against Covid-19.

site_title: Disney's 'Mulan' remake collects US$23.2m at Chinese box offices
summary: Disney's live-action remake of 'Mulan' collected US$23.2 million at Chinese box offices over the weekend. The film, based on a Chinese folk story, fell short of Christopher Nolan's 'Tenet', which grossed US$29.8 million in China a week earlier. Despite the initial disappointment, the film's success in China is a positive step for Disney, particularly given the importance of this market for the big-budget epic.

site_title: India's secondary listing plan for firms joining foreign markets irks investors: sources
summary: India is considering a policy change that would require companies to list on domestic bourses after listing overseas, potentially harming valuations and investor confidence. The move, aimed at helping local firms achieve better valuations, could impact Indian unicorn startups and companies like Reliance's digital unit. Global investors, including SoftBank and Sequoia Capital, have expressed concerns about the requirement, citing risks to trading volumes and compliance needs. The finance ministry is drafting the policy, which could be finalized in coming weeks.

site_title: India's secondary listing plan for firms joining foreign markets irks investors
summary: India is considering a policy change that would require companies listing abroad to later list on a domestic bourse, a move that global investors fear will harm valuations and raise costs. The rule change aims to help local firms achieve better valuations but could harm Indian unicorn startups and deprive local investors of wealth-creation opportunities. The policy is being drafted by the finance and corporate affairs ministries, with a possible requirement ranging from six months to three years.

site_title: Money FM: Podcasts of the week (Sept 14)
summary: Money FM's Podcasts of the Week (Sept 14) discussed MNCs staying confident in the Singapore brand post Covid-19. Paktor's founder Joseph Phua shared insights on leading like a human being. Meanwhile, Market Focus Weekly analyzed Asia's markets reacting to various factors, and BT Money Hacks explored the potential of structured notes, private equity for regular investors, and the resurgence of gold in uncertain times.

site_title: BinDawood IPO said to get covered at top of range in single day
summary: BinDawood Holding, a Saudi Arabian grocery chain, successfully secured enough bids to fully cover its initial public offering (IPO) on the first day, with bids at the top end of the US$22- US$26 pricing range. The institutional part of the sale will continue until September 22, followed by a retail offering from September 27-29. This comes amid a boom in online retail spending and a surge in Saudi companies listing on the local exchange, with BinDawood's first-half profit rising 82% from the previous year.

site_title: Michael Bloomberg to spend US$100m in Florida for Biden
summary: Billionaire Michael Bloomberg plans to spend at least $100 million in Florida to help Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden's campaign against President Donald Trump in a crucial swing state. Bloomberg made the decision after learning Trump was considering spending his own $100 million in the state. Bloomberg's investment aims to boost Biden's campaign and allow resources to be used in other key states like Pennsylvania, where polls have tightened in recent weeks.

site_title: Keppel Reit acquires Sydney commercial property for A$306m
summary: Keppel Reit has acquired a 100% stake in Pinnacle Office Park in Sydney for A$306 million, fully funded with Australian dollar-denominated debt. The acquisition will increase assets under management to S$8.2 billion, with 77% held in Singapore, 19.4% in Australia, and 3.6% in South Korea. The property has a 96.3% occupancy rate and a weighted average lease expiry of 4.8 years, with an initial net property income yield of 5.25%. The deal is in line with Keppel Reit's active portfolio optimisation strategy to improve income resilience and portfolio yield.

site_title: US hospitals turn down remdesivir, limit use to sickest Covid-19 patients
summary: US hospitals have reduced their use of the Covid-19 drug remdesivir, with some turning down about a third of their allocated supplies since July. Hospitals now limit use to severely ill patients, citing adequate current supplies and concerns over the drug's high cost ($3,120 for a six-vial course). The FDA has expanded use to moderate cases, but six major hospital systems reported no change. Experts remain skeptical about the drug's benefits, and some hospitals are stockpiling remdesivir for potential winter surges.

site_title: Board guidance in layoffs
summary: Companies undergoing retrenchments during the pandemic must prioritize long-term organizational health and future success. Boards should guide companies to focus on broader picture considerations and monitor the impact of layoffs on employees. A fair retrenchment package, communicated with empathy, is essential. Companies must also support the mental well-being of remaining employees and management teams. By adopting a collaborative approach to building partnerships and alliances, businesses can position themselves for growth post-pandemic. Boards play a key role in guiding companies to achieve strategic long-term objectives amidst the pandemic disruption.

site_title: China investment to Australia drops for third year as ties fray
summary: Chinese investment in Australia dropped by about half to A$2.5 billion in 2019, marking the third consecutive year of decline, according to Australian National University. The decline is attributed to negative investor sentiment and a shift to emerging markets. The Australian government has taken steps to limit Chinese flows, including blocking Huawei from the 5G rollout and blocking a dairy acquisition plan. China has also imposed limits on citizens traveling and studying in Australia and targeted commodity imports. This decline further indicates the deterioration of economic and diplomatic ties between the two countries.

site_title: Starbucks' corrective wave is more complex
summary: Starbucks has experienced a complex corrective wave, characteristic of its super-cycle phase, following a 50% correction in mid-March 2020. Despite completing wave A of the corrective flat, the stock has yet to clear the 88.6% Fibonacci retracement level of wave A. A break above $130.00 could confirm the start of a strong super-cycle third wave.
