site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start slightly higher on Friday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with slight gains on Friday, adding 0.16% to 24,352.63, despite another sharp drop on Wall Street. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index slipped 0.28% and the Shenzhen Composite Index shed 0.44%. Investors remain nervous due to the technology sector's decline on Wall Street.

site_title: Asia: Most markets down after fresh Wall Street retreat
summary: Asian markets declined on Friday, following a tech-led downturn on Wall Street, amid concerns over high valuations and a lack of US stimulus. The failure of a $500 billion relief package to pass the Republican-led Senate has raised doubts about a second round of help for Americans. The pound also struggled, with sterling at a six-month low against the dollar due to concerns over a potential trade agreement between Britain and the EU.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 6.07 points, or 0.41%, to 1,484.05 on Friday, with volume reaching 142.71 million lots. The market opened lower, with losers beating gainers 264 to 84.

site_title: Japan firms plan to cut capex by 6.8% this fiscal year: survey
summary: Japanese companies plan to cut capital expenditure by 6.8% in the current fiscal year due to slumping profits from the coronavirus pandemic. Manufacturers expect a 4.5% reduction, while non-manufacturers plan an 8.1% cut. This decline is larger than the previously projected 4.4% fall.

site_title: Ant-backed India food delivery startup Zomato plans 2021 IPO
summary: Zomato, an Indian food delivery startup backed by Sequoia Capital and Ant Group, plans to file for an initial public offering (IPO) in the first half of 2021. The company has secured a $525 million funding round, valuing it at $3.4 billion. Zomato aims to use the funds as a "war chest" for future mergers and acquisitions and to counter competition from rival unicorn Swiggy. The IPO follows a surge in consumer internet companies raising capital in 2020, amidst the COVID-19 pandemic and smartphone boom in India.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.19% to 23,190.37, and the Topix index losing 0.16% to 1,622.27. The decline follows a similar trend on Wall Street, with investors seeking fresh cues to return to buying.

site_title: Charting a new course after Covid-19
summary: Economies globally are gradually restarting after months of Covid-19 measures, with technology playing a significant role in the shift. Digital services have become the first port of call for consumers, with online shopping increasing by over 50% in Singapore. Companies must rethink their business models and engage customers differently, with a focus on customer-centric digital channels. Security is paramount to maintain customer trust, as cyber attacks have increased during the pandemic. The pandemic has also accelerated the shift to remote work, with workplaces going virtual, and businesses must prioritize employee mental well-being.

site_title: Most Asean workers not keen to return to workplaces: Poll
summary: Most workers in Asean-6 economies, including Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand, the Philippines, and Vietnam, have actively avoided working outside their homes due to the deadly Covid-19 outbreak. The share of work-from-home enthusiasts ranged from 12% in Vietnam to 75% in the Philippines. The willingness to leave home for other reasons also reflected the number of local virus cases. The poll, conducted by YouGov, found that Singaporeans and Malaysians were more likely to venture out, while Filipinos were the most cautious, with 45% staying home the day before.

site_title: Axington's board engaging Loh cousins on 'strategic changes'; appointing executives
summary: The board of Catalist-listed Axington is engaging with controlling shareholders Nelson and Terence Loh to clarify "strategic changes" for the company. The board, aware of the Loh cousins' exploration of strategic possibilities, will assess all options in the best interests of the company. Axington previously proposed changing its core business to provide medical and consumer wellness services and invest in medical technology. The board's actions follow the company's July proposal, pending further developments.

site_title: Samsung touts 'best salesman' Lee's role in US$6.6b Verizon deal as trial looms
summary: Samsung Electronics is promoting Vice Chairman Jay Y. Lee as a key deal-maker after securing a $6.6 billion contract with Verizon, despite a trial looming over him on accounting and stock price manipulation charges. The company has highlighted Lee's role in clinching the deal through video calls and meetings with Verizon CEO Hans Vestberg. As Lee faces a separate trial on bribery charges, Samsung's public relations campaign aims to maintain his image and avoid disruption to the company's management and economy.

site_title: Trump denies lying to US about virus after bombshell book
summary: US President Donald Trump denied lying to Americans about the severity of the coronavirus after a new book revealed he deliberately downplayed the crisis. Trump acknowledged in a taped conversation with journalist Bob Woodward that he minimized the pandemic in public, despite being aware of its dangers. This admission sparked alarm just eight weeks before the election, with Trump stating "I didn't lie" when asked about his actions. The revelation has raised concerns about Trump's honesty and handling of the pandemic.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singapore Airlines, Oxley, AEM, Ossia, Sabana Reit
summary: Singapore Airlines to cut 4,300 positions due to slower-than-expected recovery in travel demand. Oxley Holdings shares remain unchanged amid concerns over transparency. AEM Holdings revised its FY2020 revenue guidance upwards, while Ossia International's shares dropped 31.1% after correcting a dividend announcement error. ESR-Reit addressed concerns over its low buyout offer for Sabana Reit, with its CEO stating it's challenging to achieve investor-desired prices in a regulated market.

site_title: Stratech to delist from SGX, provide exit offer to shareholders
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has given notice to delist Stratech Group, a surveillance technology provider in liquidation, after the company failed to submit a proposal to resume trading. The controlling shareholders, David Chew and Leong Sook Ching, must provide a reasonable exit offer to shareholders within a month. Trading in the mainboard-listed stock remains suspended. Stratech has been in liquidation since 2018, following a court order to wind up the company due to negative equity and failed debt restructuring efforts.

site_title: Mauritius oil spill ship operator to pay 1b yen
summary: The Japanese operator of the MV Wakashio, which leaked oil off the Mauritius coast, has pledged to pay at least 1 billion yen (S$12.85 million) to restore areas affected by the spill. The company plans to contribute to mangrove and coral protection projects and set up an environment recovery fund. The ship ran aground on July 25, carrying 4,000 tonnes of fuel, with over 1,000 tonnes leaking into the waters. The company's owner and the vessel's crew have also apologized for the spill, which is still under investigation.

site_title: Greenhouse gases hit new record despite lockdowns, UN says
summary: The UN reports that greenhouse gas concentrations have reached a record high this year, despite the COVID-19 pandemic's economic slowdown. Carbon dioxide levels have increased to a three-million-year high, with daily emissions in April being 17% lower than the previous year but still comparable to 2006 levels. Emissions have rebounded to within 5% of 2019 levels by early June. The report warns that the long-term accumulation of CO2 will still contribute to climate change, with global temperatures rising by 1.1 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels.

site_title: Ascendas Reit subordinated perps will not materially change credit metrics: Moody's
summary: Moody's Investors Service says Ascendas Reit's issuance of S$300 million in subordinated unsecured perpetual securities will not significantly alter the Reit's credit metrics. The agency assigns a Baa2 rating to the proposed issuance, maintaining its stable outlook. Moody's expects Ascendas Reit's credit metrics to remain within A3 ratings parameters over the next 12-18 months, citing the Reit's diversified asset portfolio and stable operating track record. However, the agency notes the Reit's liquidity is inadequate over the next 12-18 months.

site_title: Vaccine trust growing in Europe, falling elsewhere: survey
summary: Public trust in vaccine safety is growing in Europe, with increases seen in France and Britain, but declining in Poland and Serbia. The survey, which polled nearly 300,000 respondents, attributes the trend to political instability and misinformation. Trust in vaccine safety has dipped in parts of Asia and Africa, contributing to outbreaks of preventable diseases. Researchers warn that governments must invest in public information campaigns and distribution infrastructure to address public concerns and ensure the effective roll-out of COVID-19 vaccines.

site_title: TikTok owner to spend billions in Singapore after US ban
summary: ByteDance, the Chinese owner of TikTok, plans to invest billions of dollars in Singapore over the next three years, creating hundreds of jobs. The investment comes as the company faces pressure to sell its US operations due to a US ban. Singapore is seen as a strategic location for ByteDance's expansion into Asia, with the city-state offering a developed financial and legal system. The company has already established a presence in Singapore with 400 employees and is applying for a digital bank license, which could be awarded by December.

site_title: Boeing in talks with FAA about new reported 787 production issue
summary: Boeing is in talks with the US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) about a manufacturing issue found on its 787 Dreamliner, specifically excessive gaps in the vertical tail fin. The issue, reported last year, could affect 680 airplanes, with some components clamped with greater force than specified. Boeing has addressed the issue in production and is working with the FAA to finalize guidance for the in-service fleet, which may require a one-time inspection during maintenance.

site_title: South Korea's exports decline slows in early Sept, helped by Huawei chip stockpiling
summary: South Korea's exports slowed their decline in early September, edging 0.2% lower due to robust chip sales and improved demand from major trading partners. Semiconductor exports surged 43.2% and car exports rose 8.4% during the period. Analysts attribute the jump to Huawei's chip stockpiling ahead of US sanctions. However, chip sales are expected to start falling again from mid-September. Exports to China and the US also rose, with a 9.7% and 5.2% increase, respectively.

site_title: Sembcorp signs MOU to develop renewable energy solutions for data centres in China
summary: Sembcorp Industries, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Sembcorp Industries, has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with US-listed GDS Holdings to develop renewable energy solutions for GDS's data centers in China. The MOU aims to harness green energy to support technological growth in China and explore operational synergies between the two companies. The agreement is expected to have minimal impact on Sembcorp Industries' financial performance.

site_title: Fortnite creator Epic Games says gamers can use Apple sign-in system
summary: Fortnite creator Epic Games announced that Apple has granted its users an indefinite extension to log into the game using an Apple sign-in system. This comes after Epic launched its own in-app payment system in August, violating Apple's app store guidelines. Initially, gamers were warned that the Apple sign-in option would be removed on Friday, but Epic has now reversed this decision. The move is seen as a victory for Epic in its ongoing legal battle with Apple.

images.alt_text: Fortnite creator Epic Games said on Thursday Apple Inc has given its users an "indefinite extension" to log into the game using an Apple sign-in system.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at open after Wall Street resumes slide; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.4% to 2,482.60 at open on Friday, following overnight losses on Wall Street as US stocks resumed a downward trend. Losers outnumbered gainers 70 to 51, with banking stocks and Sembcorp Marine among the losers. In contrast, AEM Holdings advanced 4.6% after revising its FY2020 revenue guidance upwards. The decline in US stocks was attributed to a relief package setback in Congress, affecting Asian markets including Tokyo stocks, which also fell 0.2%.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall as ECB leaves policy unchanged with no new stimulus
summary: European shares fell 0.6% on Thursday as the European Central Bank kept policy rates unchanged and maintained existing stimulus measures, citing sufficient support for the economy. The ECB's decision was seen as less dovish than expected, with some investors anticipating more stimulus. Meanwhile, Brexit talks continued to stall, and major European bourses also reacted to news of a potential merger between Nexi and SIA.

site_title: Twitter may remove unverified election result claims
summary: Twitter may remove unverified claims of election victory as part of efforts to protect democracy. The social media firm will label or remove false or misleading information that undermines public confidence in elections, including claims of election rigging or interference. The move comes ahead of the US presidential election, amid concerns about mail-in ballots and President Donald Trump's posts. Twitter expects to take a strict approach to enforcing its new policies, which will apply equally to all users.

site_title: Klopp shrugs off rivals' spending as Premier League kicks off
summary: Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp has dismissed concerns about his team's rivals' spending, saying it's no guarantee of success. Despite splashing out £200 million, Chelsea and Manchester City are expected to face stiff competition from the Premier League champions, who retained their title with ease last season. Klopp attributes Liverpool's success to their continuity and teamwork, rather than external factors, and believes their rivals will struggle to gel quickly. The new season begins with Liverpool facing Leeds on Saturday.

images.alt_text: Jurgen Klopp has warned Liverpool's title rivals that splashing out on new signings is no guarantee of success as the Premier League champions start their new campaign against Leeds on Saturday.

site_title: Board guidance in retrenchments
summary: Retrenchments have surged in recent months as the pandemic affects businesses, prompting companies to consider the broader impact on long-term organisational health. Boards must guide companies to focus on business continuity while retaining a sufficient talent pool to support future growth. Companies should treat retrenched employees with dignity and empathy, offering fair severance packages and additional support such as outplacement counselling. Focusing on the well-being of remaining employees is crucial to maintain trust and productivity. Boards should also emphasize the need for mental health support and resilience, and encourage collaboration with partners and suppliers to build a sustainable ecosystem.

site_title: Mortgage cravings keep Saudi credit humming
summary: Saudi Arabia's mortgage market is driving credit growth, with new residential mortgages accounting for 85% of July's credit growth, equivalent to a 13.5% annual increase. This surge is helping the economy despite the COVID-19 pandemic and depressed oil prices, with the International Monetary Fund predicting a 6.8% shrinkage in the economy this year. Government subsidy programs supporting home lending are key drivers, but experts warn that mortgage growth may slow in the coming months.

site_title: Rio Tinto CEO to depart after shareholders demand action over Australia cave blast
summary: Rio Tinto's CEO, Jean-Sébastien Jacques, will step down amid mounting shareholder criticism over the destruction of Aboriginal rockshelters in Western Australia. The company also announced the departure of two senior executives, Chris Salisbury and Simone Niven, following a board-led review that resulted in cuts to executive bonuses. The review found the destruction of the sites was against the wishes of traditional owners and led to calls for greater protection of social licenses. A successor to Jacques will be identified, with the current CEO set to leave by March 31 next year.

site_title: Vinyl sales surpass CD revenue, first time since 1980s
summary: Vinyl records have surpassed CD sales in the US for the first time in over 30 years, with $232.1 million spent on records in the first half of 2020, compared to $129.9 million for CDs. Vinyl accounted for 62% of total physical music media revenues, which declined 23% year-on-year due to the coronavirus pandemic. Despite this, vinyl's resurgence was driven by nostalgia and collectors, while streaming accounted for 85% of revenue, with subscription services reaching 72 million users, a 24% increase from 2019.

site_title: US: Stocks resume downward slide, tech shares tumble
summary: US stocks resumed their downward trend, with the Nasdaq Composite Index falling 2.0% to 10,919.59, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 1.5% to 27,534.58. The tech sector was hit hard, with large tech companies like Nikola and General Motors experiencing significant losses. The US relief package failed to pass the Senate, with jobless claims remaining high, and major banks also retreated. Investors are questioning the tech sector's ability to continue delivering for the market, with concerns about the "work from home" trade.

site_title: Thai hospitals, companies hit by cyber attacks
summary: Thai hospitals and companies were targeted by hackers in a cyber attack, with hackers demanding payment to restore access to computer systems and data. The attack was similar to a previous incident at Saraburi Hospital, where a major general stated that government hospitals and companies were hacked in the same manner. The incident highlights the vulnerability of Thailand's digital infrastructure to cyber threats.

site_title: LVMH to counter-sue Tiffany for 'dishonesty'
summary: French luxury giant LVMH has accused US jeweller Tiffany of "dishonesty" after Tiffany sued LVMH over the planned $16.2 billion acquisition. LVMH claims Tiffany prepared the lawsuit months ago, aiming to mislead shareholders. LVMH also alleges Tiffany's current economic situation, which has been impacted by the pandemic, and its management of a crisis that has damaged its market value. In response, LVMH vows to defend itself vigorously and confirms the necessary conditions for the acquisition are not fulfilled, effectively ending the deal.

site_title: Maserati aim to fuel sales with new supercar, electrics
summary: Maserati is reviving its fortunes with the launch of a new supercar, the MC20, and new electric models. The MC20 features a 630 horsepower Nettuno twin-turbo V6 engine and a sleek design. The company aims to unveil 13 new models by 2024, including the Grecale SUV, with all models set to be offered in electric versions. This move is seen as a major push to attract millennials and revive the brand's flagging sales, which have been declining since 2018.

images.alt_text: Sports car maker Maserati is firing up a major push to revive the iconic Italian brand's flagging fortunes, this week unveiling a new supercar and new electric models aimed at pleasing millennials.

site_title: UK denies blocking EU trade talks, says still wants deal
summary: Britain denied blocking EU trade talks, saying it still wants a deal despite a failed negotiation round. Chief negotiator David Frost met with Michel Barnier in London, stating that discussions have taken place in all areas but significant divergences remain. Britain will meet again in Brussels next week, aiming to reach an agreement by mid-October. The talks were hindered by disagreements on fishing rights and common standards, as well as a dispute over Northern Ireland. Britain remains committed to working towards a deal, despite the lack of progress.

site_title: Darco minorities renew protests against deputy chairman
summary: Minority shareholders of Darco Water Technologies have responded to non-executive deputy chairman Wang Zhi's comments that they were hindering the company's growth. In a letter to the Singapore Exchange, they claimed Wang's comments brought mistrust and resentment, and criticized his dismissal of inquiries about management changes. The shareholders, who own a 15% stake in the company, have suggested regulators investigate the matters raised in their letter. They also resurfaced concerns about a proposed placement and an "unfair and unreasonable offer" for their shares.

site_title: Did Trump disclose secret US nuclear weapon in interview?
summary: US President Donald Trump allegedly disclosed a top-secret nuclear weapon system in a recent interview with Bob Woodward, according to a new book. Trump claims the US has built a system "nobody's ever had" and that even Russia and China are unaware of it. The revelation has sent shockwaves among military analysts worldwide, raising concerns about the potential security implications. Trump's boast appears to be a breach of defense information protocols.

site_title: ECB to consult public on digital euro: Lagarde
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is exploring the introduction of a digital euro to complement cash and will publish its findings in the coming weeks before launching a public consultation. ECB President Christine Lagarde stated that a digital euro would be useful for retail users, but no decision has been made on the matter. This move follows global efforts by major central banks to create officially sanctioned digital currencies to counter competition from cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin.

images.alt_text: The European Central Bank is exploring the pros and cons of introducing a digital euro to complement cash and will publish its findings in the coming weeks before launching a consultation, ECB President Christine Lagarde said on Thursday.

site_title: Buyers of Oxley's project in Cambodia withhold final payment in protest
summary: Buyers of Oxley Holdings' mixed-use development The Peak in Cambodia are withholding final payment for retail units due to concerns over transparency and the project's financial health. The units were handed over to buyers earlier than scheduled, but the development's facade remains incomplete and scaffolding is still up. Oxley Holdings, the developer, has acknowledged the handover process was guided by lawyers in Cambodia, but buyers question how they determined the final payment was due. This comes after Oxley recorded a net loss of $296.3 million for the second half of the financial year.

site_title: S Korean firm invents mask with 2 fans and air filter
summary: A South Korean company, LG Electronics, has invented a battery-powered filtered face mask designed to reduce breathing difficulties and fogged-up glasses associated with conventional masks. The PuriCare Wearable features two fans and high-efficiency particle air filters, weighing as much as a pair of ski goggles. The mask is designed to be more comfortable and safe, with a battery life of about eight hours on low-power settings and a case that charges the battery and disinfects the mask with UV light. The device will be available in select markets in the fourth quarter with an unspecified price.

site_title: Euro edges 0.2% higher ahead of ECB meeting
summary: The euro rose 0.2% to US$1.1829, edging higher ahead of the European Central Bank's (ECB) meeting. The euro has gained nearly 6% against the US dollar since June lows, while euro area consumer prices turned lower in August for the first time since 2016. Despite the ECB's likely decision to keep policy unchanged, President Christine Lagarde's comments on the euro's recent rise will be closely monitored. The euro's strength is seen as a result of investor confidence in the eurozone after the creation of a joint recovery fund and robust response to the pandemic.

site_title: Ascendas Reit to redeem S$300m 4.75% perps on first call date
summary: Ascendas Reit will redeem its S$300 million, 4.75% perpetual securities on October 14, 2020, at par. Payment will be made to those holding the securities as of October 7, and the securities will be cancelled and delisted from the Singapore bourse. This move aligns with conventional market expectations but goes against the precedent set by Ascott Residence Trust in May.

site_title: Bank Negara holds interest rates on tentative signs of recovery
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, maintained its key interest rate at a record low of 1.75% amid tentative signs of economic recovery from the coronavirus. The decision, the fourth consecutive rate cut this year, was in line with expectations from 6 out of 13 economists polled by Reuters. The move aims to support the economy as it slowly recovers from the pandemic's impact.

site_title: Walmart tests drone delivery as fight with Amazon heats up
summary: Walmart has started testing drone delivery of grocery and household items in Fayetteville, North Carolina, as part of its efforts to counter Amazon's dominance in e-commerce. The automated drones, from Israeli startup Flytrex Aviation Ltd, can fly 9.9km with packages up to 2.99kg. This move follows Walmart's introduction of its Walmart+ membership programme, which debuts on September 15. The company aims to make it easier for customers to purchase everyday items, reducing contact between customers and couriers.

site_title: Oil prices slide near 2% after surprise US crude stock build
summary: Oil prices dropped nearly 2% on Thursday after US data revealed a surprise increase in crude stockpiles, linked to reduced refinery activity following Hurricane Laura. Brent futures fell 1.8% to $40.06, while US WTI crude plummeted 2.0% to $37.30. The decline was attributed to reduced demand and supply chain disruptions.

images.alt_text: Oil prices slid nearly 2 per cent on Thursday after US data showed a surprise build in crude stockpiles last week related in part to ongoing reductions at refineries along the Gulf of Mexico following Hurricane Laura.

site_title: BP to spend US$1.1b to enter offshore wind with Equinor
summary: BP has agreed to invest US$1.1 billion in offshore wind projects in the US, partnering with Equinor to develop two projects, Empire Wind and Beacon Wind, which could generate up to 4.4 gigawatt of power. The deal marks BP's entry into the offshore wind market and aligns with the company's goal of increasing its renewable power generation capacity 20-fold by 2030. Equinor will remain the operator of the projects, and the deal is expected to close in early 2021.

site_title: Citi picks Jane Fraser to succeed Corbat as CEO
summary: Citi has announced that Jane Fraser will succeed Michael Corbat as CEO in February 2021, making her the first woman to head a major Wall Street bank. Fraser, a rising star on Wall Street, was previously seen as a potential CEO candidate for Wells Fargo & Co. Corbat, who will step down after 37 years with the bank, has been a key figure in Citi's transformation. Fraser's appointment is seen as a significant milestone for women in finance and a boost for Citi's leadership.

site_title: Impossible Foods launches plant-based sausage product in HK
summary: Impossible Foods, a US-based plant-based burger maker, has launched its Impossible Sausage product in Hong Kong, its first expansion outside the US. The company aims to tap into the region's high consumption of pork and capitalize on the growing demand for plant-based foods. The sausage patty, made from soy protein, will be available in Hong Kong at Starbucks cafes and restaurants, including Triple O's. The launch comes as the company seeks to enter the Chinese market, where it faces regulatory hurdles due to its use of genetically modified yeast.

site_title: The new office plan
summary: Companies are increasingly turning to coworking spaces as a flexible work solution, even for those that previously avoided them. Following the pandemic, many are seeking a balance of safety, productivity, and mental wellbeing. Flexible space is gaining popularity as it offers ease of acquisition and aligns with business priorities. According to JLL Asia Pacific, companies are likely to adopt flexible solutions as they return to their offices, prioritizing business continuity and operational resilience. This shift is driven by the need for adaptability and resilience in the post-pandemic work landscape.

images.alt_text: Increasingly, JustCo is seeing more traditional businesses adopt coworking for their employees.
Above: More businesses are now keen on coworking spaces as they know they can still have their own private suites and they no longer need to have big offices with long leases, says Distrii Singapore.
Like other coworking spaces, there are hot desks and shared spaces which allow for interaction and meeting rooms, says Workfriendly.

Working spaces with a view. At Arcc Spaces, previous membership plans required companies to take up a whole suite to fit the number of employees that required workstations. But now it offers floating memberships and shorter monthly leases.

Working spaces with a view. At Arcc Spaces, previous membership plans required companies to take up a whole suite to fit the number of employees that required workstations. But now it offers floating memberships and shorter monthly leases.
The appeal of Work in Residence at lyf Funan.
Work from Oakwood is curated for middle to senior level executives, says CEO Dean Schreiber.
At YOTELAIR Singapore Changi Airport, more and more professionals and locals are seeing the allure and efficacy of hotel workations.

site_title: Young, bold voices at Gillman Barracks
summary: Young Singaporean visual artists are gaining prominence in the country's art scene, with National Gallery Singapore showcasing their fresh perspectives. Independent galleries at Gillman Barracks, such as Yeo Workshop, Grey Projects, and soft/WALL/studs, are championing these emerging talents. Exhibitions by artists like Wong Lip Chin, Odelia Tang, and Ashley Yeo demonstrate diverse styles, from whimsical to refined, highlighting the future of Singapore's visual arts looks bright. These young artists are pushing boundaries and exploring new forms of expression, offering a refreshing alternative to traditional art.

site_title: EU urges Facebook, Google, Twitter to do more against fake news
summary: The European Commission urged Facebook, Google, and Twitter to be more effective in combating fake news, particularly related to Covid-19, two years after agreeing to a self-regulatory code of practice. The commission emphasized the need for tech rivals to be more proactive in addressing disinformation.

site_title: US sells Hong Kong consulate staff compound for HK$2.57b
summary: The US has sold a Hong Kong consulate staff compound for HK$2.57 billion (S$453.7 million) after a public tender process. The 94,796 sq ft property, used for staff accommodation, will be redeveloped as luxurious detached homes by Hang Lung Properties, with a total investment of about HK$4 billion. The sale was made despite concerns over the property's political sensitivity due to the US-China tensions, but a US representative stated it would not affect the consulate's operations.

site_title: CapitaLand Mall Trust's portfolio metrics, merger benefits yet to be priced in: DBS
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) is poised to surprise on the upside due to its improving portfolio metrics and merger benefits, according to DBS Group Research. The Reit's yield disparity with retail peers is "too large to ignore," prompting the analyst to maintain a "buy" call and target price of S$2.40.

site_title: Covid-19 renews Asia's focus on sustainable investing: UBS
summary: Wealth manager UBS expects Asian family offices to increase their sustainable investing (SI) asset allocation to 19% of their portfolios by the end of the next few years. In the past year, UBS's flagship SI cross-asset discretionary mandate saw a 50% growth in invested assets from Asian clients, with assets under management reaching $1.5 billion. UBS now recommends sustainable investments as its preferred solution for private clients investing globally, citing equal or superior returns and reduced risk.

site_title: Finding the heart of Zinfandel
summary: A recent exploration of Zinfandel wines aimed to examine the variety from a more restrained perspective, challenging the notion that the style must be extravagant and overly alcoholic. The article highlights the difficulty in determining authenticity in wine production, particularly with Zinfandel, due to the lack of historical records. Instead, old Zinfandel vineyards offer clues about the intentions of early producers, who often planted the grape alongside other varieties like Petite Sirah to balance tannins. Three examples of restrained Zinfandel wines were reviewed, showcasing the grape's potential in various styles, from the bright and fresh Broc Cellars Vine Starr Sonoma County Zinfandel to the richer and more balanced Dashe Cellars Vineyard Select California Zinfandel.

site_title: Local app takes charge of EVs
summary: A local Singaporean app, AutoApp SG, offers a door-to-door electric vehicle (EV) charging service for S$38, including electricity and a car inspection. Partnered with SP Group, the service insures customers' cars up to S$300,000. The fee will eventually rise to S$68, but the app aims to simplify EV ownership by outsourcing vehicle upkeep.

site_title: Deadly hog fever threatens to disrupt Germany's pork exports
summary: African swine fever has been confirmed in Germany's eastern state of Brandenburg, threatening the country's pork exports. The disease, which kills most infected pigs within 10 days, was detected in a wild boar near the Polish border. Germany, Europe's largest hog producer, is taking measures to contain the outbreak, including training dogs to sniff out dead wild boar and stockpiling electric fences along the border. The outbreak could benefit other European shippers, including Spain or Denmark, and sales from the US, Canada, or Brazil, potentially disrupting German pork exports to China.

site_title: STI dips 0.3% on lingering aftershock of US tech rout
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.3% on Thursday, closing at 2,492.09, marking its third consecutive day of decline. The index is expected to be influenced by US weekly jobless claims data, CPI figures, and the European Central Bank's policy meeting. Despite a 14.4% gain for Sunningdale Tech, the mainboard-listed precision manufacturer, the market was dragged down by losses from Wilmar International and Jardine Matheson. The year-to-date decline of the STI stands at 23%.

site_title: Mercedes GLA review: Closer to the Star
summary: The Mercedes-Benz GLA has undergone a redesign, featuring a more spacious interior, stylish new body, and improved suspension. The updated model has a taller and broader stance, with a larger and more practical boot, and offers more passenger space, including sliding and reclining rear seats. The GLA's interior is also more Mercedes-like, with twin widescreen displays, turbine-like air-con vents, and a sleek interface. While the driving experience lacks smoothness, it makes up for it with heart, and the GLA feels like a more premium vehicle than before, making it a suitable option for those who want to feel like driving a Mercedes.

site_title: Credit Suisse to launch fintech rival digital banking app in Oct
summary: Credit Suisse plans to launch a digital banking app, CSX, in October, targeting younger customers with free foreign transactions and fully digital wealth management. The app will offer a range of services, including online banking, mortgages, investments, and pension planning, and aims to cut costs by closing a quarter of its Swiss branches. The move challenges fintechs like Revolut and N26, which have gained popularity with cheap and user-friendly alternatives to traditional banking services.

site_title: Electric Mini Cooper SE review: Watts up
summary: The Mini Cooper SE, an electric vehicle, is praised for its lively and determined performance, accelerating to 100km/h in 7.3 seconds and 60km/h in 3.9 seconds. The review notes that while the car may not be practical, it is impossible to drive without smiling. The article does not delve into any in-depth analysis or comparisons to other vehicles, but rather highlights the car's energetic driving experience.

site_title: US set to end enhanced screening of some global travellers for Covid-19: sources
summary: The US government is set to end enhanced screening of some international passengers for Covid-19, dropping requirements for travellers from China, the UK, Brazil, Iran, and the Schengen region of Europe, starting as early as Monday. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) will prioritize other public health measures, citing a low risk of transmission among the 675,000 passengers screened at 15 airports, with fewer than 15 identified as having Covid-19. Airlines support the change, citing the low number of passengers identified as potentially having a health issue.

site_title: AGV director in CAD probe maintains innocence, unwilling to step down
summary: AGV Group's executive director Albert Ang, arrested and placed on bail, maintains his innocence amid an investigation by the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) into false trading and market-rigging transactions. The nominating committee (NC) recommended Ang step down, but he is unwilling to do so, seeking time to consider and seek counsel. The NC believes Ang is "no longer fit and proper" to continue as ED, citing concerns over the CAD's findings. AGV's board is confident the group can continue as a going concern with financial support from its chairman and lenders.

site_title: Hashida makes a comeback
summary: Chef Kenjiro "Hatch" Hashida has reopened his private dining space, 'Hashida Private Dining', at OUE Social Kitchen in Singapore. The temporary arrangement allows him to showcase his unique culinary approach before opening his new outpost in Amoy Street later this year. The menu features traditional Japanese dishes with modern twists, including omakase options priced from S$120 to S$350. Hashida's innovative use of ingredients and techniques, such as fermented miso and sake-enhanced dashi, has resulted in a memorable dining experience. The restaurant offers a unique blend of elegance and playfulness, making it a fitting comeback for the chef.

images.alt_text: Chef Hashida's sushi and contemporary Japanese cuisine add up to a couple of hours of culinary showmanship.
A gentle twist on tempura decorated with chrysanthemum leaves.
Chef Hashida's "fish head to tail" saba creation.
Squid, abalone, uni and caviar in cashew miso.
Botan shrimp sushi.

site_title: SIA to eliminate 4,300 positions
summary: Singapore Airlines plans to cut 4,300 positions, affecting 2,400 staff in Singapore and abroad, as the airline industry struggles to recover from the pandemic. The retrenchment exercise comes as the airline group seeks to reduce cash burn and is expected to significantly reduce wage costs. Affected employees will receive one month of salary per year of service, capped at 25 months, and pay in lieu of their notice period. The airline expects to operate at less than half its capacity by the end of March 2021, and shares have fallen 4 cents to S$3.54.

site_title: Surviving a financial meltdown
summary: The Glass Hotel, a novel by Emily St John Mandel, explores how people cope with the aftermath of the 2008 global financial crisis. The book delves into the lives of individuals who pick up the pieces and move forward, offering a glimpse into the resilience of the human spirit during times of turmoil.

images.alt_text: The Glass Hotel By Emily St John Mandel.

site_title: The challenges of moving a business out of crisis mode
summary: Accenture CEO Julie Sweet, the first female CEO of the global consultancy, is impatient to move beyond the pandemic-induced crisis mode. Despite the company's better-than-expected performance, Sweet wants to normalize operations, rebuild relationships with clients, and address racial inequities. She has implemented a new strategy focusing on clarity, calm, and speed, including mandatory training on speaking up about racism and increasing diversity and inclusion targets. Sweet emphasizes the importance of transparency and clear communication in leadership, citing her own personal experiences with breast cancer and drug abuse as formative lessons.

site_title: Liew Mun Leong steps down from public-service and business roles
summary: Liew Mun Leong has stepped down from his roles at Changi Airport Group, Surbana Jurong, Temasek Foundation, and Temasek International, effective immediately. The announcement comes after a High Court acquitted his former domestic helper of stealing from him and his family. This decision was made days after the acquittal.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: GKE Corp proposes to sell 65% stake in Van Der Horst Logistics for $11.7 million, with a net gain of $1.5 million expected. AEM Holdings revised FY2020 revenue guidance to $480-500 million. Ossia International corrected its dividend announcement, stating the actual dividend was 0.9 cents, not 90 cents. Silverlake Axis reported a ransomware attack on its IT service provider's servers, with no bank customer information compromised. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times.

site_title: New York to mark 9/11 anniversary amid pandemic
summary: New York City marks the 19th anniversary of the 9/11 terrorist attacks on September 11, 2020, amidst the COVID-19 pandemic. The city holds a ceremony with a minute's silence at the World Trade Center site, featuring recorded messages from victims' families instead of a traditional roll call. The pandemic has exacerbated existing problems, including rising crime, homelessness, and vacant businesses, with over 35,000 people leaving Manhattan and nearly 60 million tourists absent. City leaders emphasize the city's resilience and warn of potential social and economic challenges ahead.

site_title: Lloyd's of London says Covid claims could reach £5b
summary: Lloyd's of London has announced that it expects to pay out up to £5 billion in claims related to the COVID-19 pandemic, resulting in a pre-tax loss of £400 million for the first half of the year. The firm's profit for the same period last year was £2.3 billion. Reinsurance provisions helped cover £2.4 billion of losses from COVID claims, but the firm still faces significant financial implications from the pandemic.

images.alt_text: In May, Lloyd's predicted a torrid year for insurers with around US$203 billion in losses as shutdowns hit economies and stock markets slumped.

site_title: American Pharoah's owner files for personal bankruptcy
summary: American Pharoah's owner, Ahmed Zayat, has filed for personal bankruptcy protection in New Jersey, seeking to discharge over $19 million of debts. The Chapter 7 bankruptcy case lists $1.9 million in assets and $19.4 million in liabilities, mostly business obligations. Zayat's stables are listed as insolvent, indicating financial difficulties.

site_title: Pompeo calls on S-E Asia to stand up to China, shun its state-owned firms
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo urged South-east Asian countries to stand up to China's maritime bullying and reconsider business deals with state-owned firms, amid rising tensions in the South China Sea. Asean said it does not want to take sides, but expressed concerns over China's land reclamations and activities. Pompeo's remarks follow US sanctions on Chinese entities involved in building artificial islands, and come ahead of a November election in which US President Donald Trump will highlight his tough stance against China. Asean ministers reaffirmed their commitment to a peaceful Indo-Pacific region.

site_title: UK property funds holding £12b face reopening dilemma
summary: The UK's largest property funds holding £12 billion of commercial real estate have been given the all-clear to reopen after the Covid-19 pandemic-induced freeze, but many are choosing not to. The funds had halted trading in March, leaving investors uncertain about the value of their assets. Some managers, such as Columbia Threadneedle, plan to lift the suspension, while others, like Aviva and Janus Henderson, say they will not immediately allow withdrawals. The reopening of these funds could lead to a wave of redemptions and forced sales, potentially lifting deal volumes in the UK real estate market.

site_title: Golden Agri eyes continued downstream diversification
summary: Golden Agri-Resources (GAR) reported a net loss of US$156.9 million for the first half of 2020, compared to a net loss of US$46.4 million in the same period last year. The company's higher cost base and mature plantation profile contribute to its struggles. To offset these pressures, management plans to expand its downstream operations. This diversification strategy could help the company make up for its production costs amid a tough economic environment.

images.alt_text: A Golden Agri-Resources official says that although the palm oil sector has "traditionally been quite conservative and very manual" in most aspects of its operations, the company is now using technology to delve deeper into the operational performance of its plantations.

site_title: JC Penney reaches tentative rescue deal
summary: JC Penney has reached a tentative $1.75 billion deal with mall owners Simon Property Group and Brookfield Property Partners to rescue the department store chain from bankruptcy. The deal would carve JC Penney into three pieces, with landlords acquiring retail operations and lenders taking control of distribution centers. The company expects to emerge from bankruptcy before the 2020 holiday season and plans to operate around 650 stores.

site_title: Huge blaze at Beirut port alarms residents a month after massive blast
summary: A large fire broke out at Beirut port on Thursday, sending a column of smoke over the city just weeks after a massive blast devastated the port and surrounding area. The blaze started in the shattered duty-free zone, prompting residents to flee due to concerns of another explosion. The cause is unclear, but the fire was limited to one place, and there were no immediate reports of injuries. The public prosecutor ordered an investigation, and activists have criticized the government's handling of the crisis, calling it "gross crime, gross negligence, and gross arrogance."

site_title: What's Up This Week
summary: The Peak magazine is revamping its brand to reflect the evolving definition of luxury, embracing conscious capitalism and prioritizing values-based business strategies. The September 2020 issue marks the beginning of this journey, featuring a new section called Gourmet & Travel and a regular feature Scions of Style. The Peak is also increasing its digital presence, introducing 360-degree content, short-format videos, and digital events, aiming to help readers make better and more thoughtful decisions. The magazine seeks to continue its role in the luxury lifestyle world, fostering a community that values conscious capitalism.

site_title: Raised By Wolves delights - then degenerates
summary: HBO's sci-fi series Raised By Wolves, directed by Ridley Scott, begins with a strong start, showcasing a grandiose and surreal alien world. The show follows two androids, Mother and Father, who attempt to raise human children on a distant planet, but the series' quality declines after the first two episodes, which were directed by Scott. The subsequent episodes, including those directed by Scott's son Luke, are marred by sloppy set-ups and implausible twists, leading to a decline in viewer interest.

site_title: How can gig workers be protected?
summary: Gig workers face poor job security due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with many choosing flexibility over employment perks. To protect self-employed individuals, policymakers could implement regulations and provide benefits, such as cybersecurity measures and insurance. Companies can also take steps to secure their operational technology networks, similar to securing IT systems. The issue highlights the need for a balance between flexibility and job security, with some arguing that value investors should re-evaluate their strategies in light of changing market conditions.

site_title: Rail transportation has an important role to play in South-east Asia
summary: South-east Asia's megacities and economies rely heavily on transportation, but the region's reliance on road transport has contributed to traffic congestion, carbon dioxide emissions, and climate change vulnerability. As the region looks to rebuild and recover from the COVID-19 pandemic, rail transportation is being recognized as a critical component of sustainable development, offering a safer, faster, and more environmentally friendly alternative to air and road travel. The Asia Development Bank has committed $1 billion to green infrastructure projects, and rail operators are investing in electric and hydrogen-powered trains to reduce emissions.

site_title: Succession plans at financial firms part of new accountability guidelines from MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has introduced new guidelines requiring financial institutions to have a succession plan that is regularly reviewed and updated. The plan must identify potential candidates and outline handover policies to minimize disruptions during senior management transitions. The guidelines, which apply to all financial institutions unless exempted or have fewer than 50 employees, aim to shape ethical business practices and prudent risk-taking behavior. MAS has rejected exemptions for senior managers subject to other jurisdictions' accountability regimes, and will monitor financial institutions that use outsourcing to circumvent the guidelines.

images.alt_text: Fresh guidelines from the Singapore regulator on the financial industry state that most financial institutions should have a succession plan that is "regularly reviewed and updated".

site_title: Jakarta doctors warn of buckling health system
summary: Indonesian doctors warn that the COVID-19 pandemic is "not under control" in Jakarta, with the city's intensive care units nearing full capacity. The Jakarta administration has reported a record 3,861 positive cases and over 1,000 new cases per day, straining hospitals. ICU occupancy is at 83%, and isolation room occupancy is at 77%. The city's governor plans to re-impose a partial lockdown starting next Monday to prevent hospitals from collapsing. The health system is exhausted, with doctors forced to work overtime and facing low protection.

site_title: An all-killer, no-filler line-up from Rolex
summary: Rolex has released its 2020 novelties, including eight new Submariner models, three new gold Sky-Dweller models, and a new Oyster Perpetual collection featuring bold colors and various sizes. The Submariner, particularly the green bezel and black dial model, is highly sought after due to its timeless look and high demand. The Sky-Dweller's new models, available in gold with an Oysterflex bracelet, offer a dressier look and increased lightness. The Oyster Perpetual collection features vibrant colors and various sizes, targeting a younger demographic. Due to high demand, waitlists are expected for these models at authorized dealers.

site_title: The year of reckoning for global food systems
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has exposed vulnerabilities in global food systems, with lockdowns and government policies affecting agricultural production and supply chains. Smallholder farms, in particular, have been impacted by broken food supply chains, resulting in loss of income and food waste. According to the UN, global hunger is on the rise, with over 130 million people forecasted to suffer from chronic hunger by the end of 2020. To improve food system resilience, experts suggest improving agriculture productivity, ensuring access to finance, and helping farmers adapt to climate change.

site_title: Huawei to launch Harmony OS on smartphones next year
summary: Huawei plans to launch its Harmony OS on smartphones next year, seen as the company's best bet to replace Google's Android mobile operating system. The multi-device platform, unveiled last year, will be open to developers for smartphones in December. Huawei shipped 240 million smartphones last year, ranking second globally, but software shortages have hurt the company in recent months. The move comes as the US restricts Huawei's access to semiconductors, threatening its position as the world's largest smartphone maker. Harmony OS is billed as a platform across watches, laptops, and mobiles, not just a mobile OS.

site_title: McLaren considers sale of global headquarters to raise cash
summary: McLaren Automotive is considering the sale of its global headquarters as part of a refinancing strategy to raise cash. The UK luxury sports-car maker has struggled since the coronavirus outbreak, with a 70% revenue collapse. To address this, McLaren has appointed banks to advise on a debt restructuring and equity raise. This move comes after an unsuccessful £300 million equity raise earlier this year. The company aims to bolster its balance sheet and navigate the challenging automotive market. Details of the potential sale are not disclosed.

site_title: US mortgage rates slide to record-low
summary: US mortgage rates have dropped to a record low of 2.86% for a 30-year, fixed loan, according to Freddie Mac. This marks the ninth time since the pandemic that rates have fallen to a new low. The drop has fueled a housing market rebound, driving sales of new and existing homes and providing refinancing opportunities for borrowers. However, the rally faces challenges from persistent job losses and an inventory shortage, which may limit sales growth in the fall.

images.alt_text: Mortgage rates in the US dropped to another record low, adding fuel to a housing market that's been a key source of strength for the pandemic economy.

site_title: Saudi sovereign fund PIF weighs investing in Ant IPO
summary: Saudi Arabia's sovereign fund PIF is considering an investment in Ant Group's initial public offering (IPO), potentially raising up to $30 billion. This would be PIF's most high-profile direct investment in a Chinese company. The Public Investment Fund was approached by Ant through its advisors and is evaluating the opportunity.

site_title: Ascendas Reit prices S$300m green perps at 3%
summary: Ascendas Reit priced its S$300 million green subordinated perpetual securities at an initial annual distribution rate of 3%, exceeding the order book of S$725 million. This is the Reit's second green issuance under its S$7 billion euro medium-term securities program and the first real estate green perpetual securities in Asia. The securities are expected to be issued on Sept 17, with the first distribution rate reset on the same date in 2025.

site_title: Mentoring: fastest growing business in the world
summary: Mentoring is the fastest-growing business in the world, driven by demand for guidance in a rapidly changing, technology-driven world. The need for mentors who can address the superficial symptoms of narrow thinking, lack of confidence, and fear of risk-taking is growing. To find a good mentor, look for someone with style and values, and who has spent years studying the critical questions of mentoring. The greatest value of mentoring lies in the medium- and long-term, equipping individuals for greater confidence in the VUCA world, and helping them develop an individual rather than a processed robot.

images.alt_text: Anyone who has decent values may be a mentor to you. You can observe potential mentors if you look for style and then examine the ground rules for it.

site_title: Chinese property firms weigh cutting prices after Evergrande's deep discounts
summary: Chinese property firms are considering cutting prices in response to Evergrande's 30% nationwide discount on its properties, amid a sluggish home price recovery and ebbing appetite for speculation. The move comes as Evergrande aims to boost sales and cash flow. Other developers, including Country Garden, are weighing similar discounts, but may not offer the same level of cut due to differences in project locations. Analysts predict the discounts will be company-specific, driven by short-term debt obligations.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed 6.6 points lower to 1,490.12 on Thursday, with 1,022 losers outweighing 200 gainers. The FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index saw 8.4 billion lots traded worth RM5.489 billion.

site_title: Chinese EV makers' Tesla-like stock rally leaves market watchers puzzled
summary: Chinese electric-vehicle (EV) stocks, including NIO, Xpeng, and Li Auto, have lost over 10% in the past week, reversing a surge that was driven by investors betting on Tesla's ability to broaden the appeal of electric cars. The companies, which are unprofitable and only deliver a few thousand vehicles a month, trade at 5-7 times estimated 2021 revenue, similar to Tesla's valuation five years ago. The reversal is attributed to Tesla's profitability and expanding global presence, as well as the slow shift towards electrification in China, where fossil-fuelled cars still dominate the market.

site_title: British actress Diana Rigg dies aged 82
summary: British actress Diana Rigg, known for her roles in The Avengers and Game of Thrones, has died at 82. She passed away peacefully at home with her family after being diagnosed with cancer in March. Rigg, a classically trained actress, won multiple awards for her work in theatre and screen, including an Emmy, Tony, and Bafta. Her daughter Rachael Stirling described her as "joyfully reflecting on her extraordinary life" in her final months. Rigg's talent and legacy were praised by fellow actors and playwrights, including Tom Stoppard and David Hare.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims flattening as labour market momentum ebbs
summary: US jobless claims remain high, hovering at 884,000 for the week ended Sept 5, indicating a stalled labor market recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic. The number of Americans on unemployment benefits reached 29.6 million in August. Economists warn of significant downside risks to the economy and labor market if policymakers fail to enact another fiscal relief package. Layoffs remain widespread, and the labor market is expected to take years to return to pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: The Hut Group seeks as much as US$2.4b in London IPO
summary: The Hut Group, a British e-commerce operator, is set to raise up to $2.4 billion in its initial public offering (IPO) in London, making it Europe's second-largest listing of the year. The company will sell 374 million shares at 5 pounds each, with CEO Matthew Moulding retaining a 25.1% stake. The IPO, valued at 5.4 billion pounds, has already attracted strong demand, with cornerstone investors reserving 615 million pounds worth of shares. The stock are expected to start trading on September 16.

site_title: Lendlease to set up product development centre in Singapore
summary: Lendlease, an international property group, plans to set up a S$40 million product development centre in Singapore to accelerate digital transformation in the property and construction sector. The centre will employ 50 software developers in the first year, with plans to expand the team in the next few years. This move aims to drive innovation and growth in the sector, with the centre expected to play a key role in shaping the future of property development and construction in Singapore.

site_title: BHP will tie CEO bonus to success in cutting customer emissions
summary: BHP Group will tie 10% of CEO Mike Henry's bonus payments to the company's progress in reducing greenhouse gas emissions from its operations and customer supply chains. The goal is to cut emissions intensity by 30% in the steel industry by 2030 and 40% in the maritime sector. BHP aims to support these reductions through the use of its iron ore and coking coal.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher on tech bounce
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by gains in tech-related stocks, despite elevated weekly jobless claims. The Dow Jones rose 0.29%, the S&P 500 gained 0.40%, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 0.84%. These gains overshadowed the impact of the jobless claims, which suggested a choppy economic rebound. The tech sector's momentum helped push the Nasdaq to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Liew Mun Leong announces retirement from public service and business roles
summary: Liew Mun Leong, chairman of Changi Airport Group and Surbana Jurong, has announced his retirement from public service and business roles with immediate effect. He cited the recent acquittal of his former domestic helper and ongoing challenges from the Covid-19 pandemic as reasons for his decision. Liew expressed his commitment to assisting the organizations without compensation, if required, to prevent a distraction from their priorities.

site_title: Ossia International clarifies dividend announcement error; should be 0.9 S cent
summary: Ossia International Limited clarified its dividend announcement, correcting a typo error that stated a 90-cent dividend instead of 0.9 Singapore cents. The mistake caused the company's share price to surge 78.79% before a trading halt was lifted. The company attributed the error to a typo and confirmed the corrected dividend amount.

site_title: ECB less pessimistic on 2020 downturn despite virus 'headwinds'
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) chief Christine Lagarde expressed less pessimism about the eurozone's 2020 downturn, citing a stronger-than-expected rebound in the third quarter. However, the recent surge in Covid-19 cases poses "headwinds" for the recovery. The ECB maintained its ultra-loose monetary policy, keeping interest rates low, and will continue to provide "ample degree" of accommodation to support the economy. Analysts expect the ECB to add more stimulus in December due to uneven recovery prospects and low inflation, which is expected to climb to 1.0% next year.

site_title: Silverlake Axis' IT service provider hit by ransomware attack
summary: Silverlake Axis, a fintech firm, reported a ransomware attack on its IT service provider's servers, but stated that its enterprise network remains unaffected. The company confirmed it does not process bank customer information, and the attack only targeted servers hosted on the Microsoft platform. Investigations are ongoing, and Silverlake Axis is reviewing the incident to ensure data security. The company's shares closed down 1.61% following the announcement.

site_title: Thai hospitals and companies hit by ransomware attacks
summary: Thai hospitals and companies were targeted by hackers using ransomware, a type of malware that demands payment in cryptocurrency to restore access to data. The attack, similar to the 2017 WannaCry attack, is believed to have originated in Europe. Some organizations have paid up to $32,000 to retrieve their data, while authorities investigate the total number of affected organizations. This marks the latest in a series of cyberattacks on Thai institutions, with hospitals being particularly vulnerable.

site_title: Citigroup CEO Michael Corbat to step down; Jane Fraser named successor
summary: Citigroup CEO Michael Corbat will step down in February 2021 after 37 years with the bank. He will be succeeded by President Jane Fraser, making her the first woman to head a major Wall Street bank. Fraser, a 16-year veteran at Citi, was previously running the bank's Latin America business. She was elected to the board and has been seen as a rising star on Wall Street, with previous consideration for CEO roles at Wells Fargo.

site_title: Acromec unit enters JV with Nutura Investment for waste-to-energy plant
summary: Acromec, a specialist engineering services firm, has entered a joint venture with Nutura Investment to build, own, and operate a waste-to-energy plant in Neo Tiew Road, Lim Chu Kang. The joint venture, valued at S$10 million, will see Acropower and Nutura co-finance the project, with Acropower holding 70% equity and Nutura holding 30%. The plant will process waste from a local poultry farm into biogas, generating electricity to be supplied back to the farm. The partnership aims to promote green technology and sustainable energy.

site_title: Flawless 102-carat diamond could fetch up to US$30m at auction
summary: A 102.39-carat flawless white diamond, the second-largest oval diamond of its kind, is set to be auctioned off by Sotheby's in Hong Kong on October 5, with a predicted price range of $12 million to $30 million. The diamond, cut from a 271-carat rough discovered in Canada in 2018, is one of only seven diamonds over 100 carats to be sold at auction. Its sale is expected to rival previous records, including the 118.28-carat diamond sold for $30.8 million in 2013.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close with more losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index down 0.64% and the Shanghai Composite Index down 0.61%. The Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 2.14%. Investors are concerned about high valuations following the global sell-off. The decline follows a morning rally, with investors worried about the impact of US-China trade tensions and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Hong Kong arrests 15 people linked to Next Digital stock surge
summary: Hong Kong police arrested 15 people linked to Next Digital's stock surge, with a combined profit of about $4.9 million. The arrests were made on suspicion of using illegal funds and conspiracy to defraud. One individual has ties to organized crime, and six were unemployed. The arrests come after Next Digital's shares soared over 1,000% in August amid support for vocal critic Jimmy Lai, who was held under Hong Kong's National Security Law.

site_title: ECB's Lagarde says bank watching euro closely
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) President Christine Lagarde said the bank is closely watching the strong euro's impact on the region's economy, as it prepares to use its stimulus package to pull the region out of recession. Despite warning of "headwinds" from a second wave of coronavirus infections, the ECB upgraded its 2020 growth forecast due to improved consumer demand. The bank maintains its inflation forecast of 0.3% for the year, but expects more months of negative price movements.

site_title: China bars media coverage of Disney's 'Mulan' after Xinjiang backlash
summary: China's government has ordered major media outlets not to cover Walt Disney's "Mulan" due to controversy over the film's links to the Xinjiang region, where China has been criticized for its treatment of ethnic Uighurs. The move comes after overseas backlash and mixed reviews online. Despite this, the film is set to open in Chinese theatres on Friday, with many screens showing the movie, although capacity is limited due to coronavirus prevention measures. The film's box office performance is expected to be affected, with some predicting it will earn a dismal amount.

site_title: Century 21 files for bankruptcy, will shut down
summary: Century 21, a New York off-price department store chain, filed for bankruptcy and plans to shut down. The retailer cited nonpayment by insurance providers of approximately $175 million due to business interruption losses from the Covid-19 pandemic. The company will hold going-out-of-business sales at 13 stores in four states. Century 21 listed assets and liabilities of up to $500 million each in its bankruptcy petition.

images.alt_text: Century 21 Stores, an iconic New York off-price department store chain, filed for bankruptcy Thursday with plans to shut down, adding to the retail industry carnage exacerbated by the pandemic.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.3% lower
summary: The Singapore Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.29% lower on Thursday, marking its third consecutive day of decline. The decline was largely attributed to tech sector uncertainty, despite a brief bounce in US indices. Asian markets were mixed, with gains in Japan and South Korea offsetting losses in China and Hong Kong. The STI has lost 23% in the year to date, with leading losses in Wilmar International and Jardine Matheson.

site_title: AEM ups revenue guidance for FY2020
summary: AEM Holdings revised its FY2020 revenue guidance to between S$480 million and S$500 million, up from the previously stated range of S$460 million to S$480 million. The revision is based on improved sales-order visibility and business outlook, with capital expenditure remaining unchanged at S$4 million.

site_title: StanChart's Judy Hsu to head new global unit amid changes in organisation structure
summary: Standard Chartered has announced changes to its organisation structure, with veteran Judy Hsu taking charge of a new global consumer, private and business banking (CPBB) business from January 1, 2021. Hsu, currently regional chief executive for Asean and South Asia, will oversee a combined retail banking, private banking, and wealth management business with assets worth over $200 billion. The move aims to strengthen the bank's individual client business and expand its Asian operations. Other senior roles will be announced in due course, with the bank's results to be reported on a new combined basis starting January 1, 2021.

site_title: ByteDance is poised to miss US deadline for TikTok sale
summary: ByteDance is likely to miss a September 20 US deadline to sell its TikTok US operations due to new Chinese regulations complicating negotiations with Microsoft and Oracle. The Chinese government's regulations on exporting artificial intelligence technologies used by TikTok have led to a lack of clarity, prompting bidders to request more information from Beijing. Despite this, Microsoft and Oracle remain interested in buying the US arm of the video app. The review process is expected to be substantial and time-consuming, further delaying the sale.

site_title: BOJ to offer brighter view on economy as Covid crisis eases: sources
summary: The Bank of Japan is expected to offer a more optimistic view on the economy next week, citing a recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. However, the BOJ will also warn that any recovery will be modest and uncertain, due to concerns over renewed infections and fragile global demand. This outlook aligns with the government's view that its stimulus has helped cushion the blow from the pandemic. The BOJ's policy review is seen as a signal ahead of a ruling party election where Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga is seeking a landslide victory.

site_title: EU ponders legal action against Britain over plan to break Brexit deal
summary: The European Union is considering legal action against the UK for its plan to break Brexit deal, with EU Vice President Maros Sefcovic expressing concern over the move. Britain's plan to act outside international law by breaching the divorce treaty could lead to a no-deal exit, which would undermine trust in negotiations and make it harder to secure a free trade agreement. The EU could use the Withdrawal Agreement to take legal action against Britain, and European diplomats have warned that the plan would fail if it tries to use the breach to extract concessions from the bloc.

site_title: GSH prices S$30m two-year notes at 5.2%
summary: GSH Corp priced its S$30 million two-year notes at a fixed annual interest rate of 5.20%. The notes mature on Oct 21, 2022, and will be issued on Sept 17. The net proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes, including refinancing and capital expenditure. DBS Bank has been appointed as the dealer for the Series 4 Tranche 2 notes.

site_title: Australian banks loan deferrals shrink in July, task still 'immense'
summary: Australian banks' loan deferrals decreased by 12% to A$240 billion in July, the first decline since March. Approximately 9% of housing loans and 17% of business loans remain on deferral. The nation's largest banks, Commonwealth Bank and National Australia Bank, hold about half of the deferred balances. New loan approvals for deferrals are declining, with unfrozen loans outnumbering new approvals. Experts warn that some borrowers may face foreclosure once government support ends, posing an "immense" challenge for banks to process deferred balances.

site_title: 2 new Covid-19 dorm clusters found in Jurong, Seletar North
summary: Two new Covid-19 clusters were announced in Singapore, one at Avery Lodge Dormitory in Jurong with 35 cases and another at PPT Lodge 1A in Seletar North Link with eight cases. This brings the total number of new cases to 63, taking Singapore's total to 57,229. Of these, 55 cases are from dorms, with 26 linked to the new Avery Lodge Dormitory cluster.

site_title: Huawei to launch Harmony OS on smartphones next year
summary: Huawei plans to launch its Harmony OS on smartphones next year, seen as a replacement for Google's Android mobile operating system. The company's head of consumer business group, Richard Yu, announced the plan during its annual developers conference. A 2.0 version of the system has been developed and a beta version for smartphones is set to be opened to developers in December. The move comes after Huawei's addition to the US entity list led to software shortages and a slump in overseas smartphone sales.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: SIA to cut 4,300 positions, Singapore's SIA announced talks with unions to finalize arrangements. New guidelines for financial firms require updated succession plans, with StanChart appointing Judy Hsu to lead a new global unit. AGV director Albert Ang is under investigation and may step down, while Indonesia's Waresix raised $100m in a Series B round. Lendlease to set up a $40m product development centre in Singapore, and Ascendas Reit to redeem $300m perpetual securities. The STI closed 0.3% lower, with global markets affected by US tariffs and economic concerns.

site_title: Standard Chartered restructures business units, leadership
summary: Standard Chartered has restructured its business units, forming one large unit combining retail, private, and business banking divisions, and merging its Asian units. Judy Hsu will lead the new consumer, private, and business banking unit, while Ben Hung takes charge of the Asia-wide unit. Tracy Clarke is retiring, and the changes will take effect at the end of the year.

site_title: Hong Kong's Sun Hung Kai sees more headwinds amid pandemic
summary: Sun Hung Kai Properties, Hong Kong's largest developer, reported underlying earnings of HK$29.4 billion, missing analyst estimates due to economic headwinds from the pandemic and rising US-China tensions. The developer cited an economic slowdown, travel restrictions, and pro-democracy protests as factors. The company expects more challenges ahead, particularly for its hotel and retail businesses.

site_title: SIA to cut 4,300 positions across the group
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) Group is cutting 4,300 positions across its airlines, including 2,400 staff in Singapore and abroad, due to the ongoing pandemic's impact. The job cuts, which include a recruitment freeze and natural attrition, are part of the carrier's efforts to right-size for a post-Covid world. SIA expects to operate a smaller fleet and network, with a reduced capacity, and has begun talks with unions in Singapore to finalize arrangements. The move is seen as a necessary measure to ensure the airline's long-term survival amidst an uncertain recovery.

site_title: BP books oil tanker for storage at lowest rate this year: sources
summary: Oil major BP has provisionally chartered a supertanker to store crude oil off Malaysia at a rate of $20,500 per day for three months, the lowest rate this year. The charter is part of a flurry of ship bookings made by oil majors and trading houses due to decreased global oil trade and shipping demand. The northern hemisphere's summer driving season has slowed shipping demand, contributing to the low charter rate.

site_title: Ascendas Reit to redeem S$300m 4.75% perps on first call date
summary: Ascendas Reit to redeem its S$300 million, 4.75% perpetual securities on October 14, 2020, at par. The securities will be cancelled and delisted from the Singapore bourse on the same day. This move follows conventional market expectation and contradicts a precedent set by Ascott Residence Trust (ART), which skipped its first call in May. Other Reit perps with upcoming reset dates include Keppel Reit's and Frasers' Hospitality Reit's.

site_title: Toyota's research arm says to form an US$800m investment fund
summary: Toyota's research arm, Toyota Research Institute-Advanced Development, plans to create a US$800 million global investment fund called Woven Capital. The fund will invest in companies in autonomous mobility and smart cities. This investment is part of Toyota's efforts to develop a "city of the future" called Woven City, powered by hydrogen fuel cells, as a laboratory for autonomous cars.

site_title: Siemens launches advance manufacturing competence centre in Singapore
summary: Siemens has launched the Advance Manufacturing Transformation Center (AMTC) in Singapore, providing guidance and training to South-east Asian companies adopting advanced manufacturing. The centre combines consulting, training, R&D, and small-scale production facilities, showcasing digital-enterprise solutions, additive manufacturing, and rental labs. Siemens is partnering with SkillsFuture Singapore to offer a six-month additive-manufacturing training course, aiming to support mid-career job seekers in roles such as programmable logic controller engineers and automation engineers.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher on hopes of easing in virus curbs
summary: Australian shares closed 0.5% higher on Thursday, boosted by hopes of easing virus curbs in the state of Victoria. A decline in daily infections and the Federal Health Minister's comments sparked optimism about lifting restrictions. Investors also awaited the European Central Bank's policy decision, which is expected to keep policy unchanged. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 5,908.5, with gold and tech stocks leading gains. Tensions with China and US tariff uncertainty also impacted the broader market.

site_title: UBS makes sustainable investments the preferred solution for private clients
summary: UBS, the world's largest wealth manager, has announced that sustainable investments are now its preferred solution for private clients globally amid the Covid-19 pandemic.
