Managing $488 billion in core sustainable assets, UBS believes a 100% sustainable portfolio can deliver similar or higher returns compared to traditional investments, offering strong diversification for clients investing globally. This recommendation marks the first time a major global financial institution has made sustainable investments its preferred solution.

site_title: AstraZeneca's asthma drug succeeds late-stage study
summary: AstraZeneca's asthma treatment Fasenra has met main goals in a late-stage study for treating patients with severe bilateral nasal polyposis, a chronic inflammatory disease of the nasal passage linings. The treatment showed statistically significant improvements in treating nasal polyps and blockage in patients with chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps. Fasenra is currently approved as an add-on maintenance treatment for severe asthma in the US, EU, and other countries, and its success may provide new treatment options for patients with CRSwNP.

site_title: Darco minorities renew protests against deputy chairman
summary: Darco minority shareholders have responded to deputy chairman Wang Zhi's comments, stating he brought mistrust and resentment upon himself. The shareholders, representing 15% of the company, complained about a proposed placement that was aborted and alleged they were offered an "unfair and unreasonable" deal. They also disputed Wang's claims about independent directors being "too passive" and suggested regulators investigate further. The shareholders' concerns have been ongoing, with previous complaints about management changes in the Darco board.

site_title: Reliance offers Amazon US$20b stake in retail arm
summary: Reliance Industries, led by billionaire Mukesh Ambani, is offering to sell a $20 billion stake in its retail arm to Amazon, with the possibility of Amazon taking up to a 40% stake. This comes after Amazon expressed interest in investing in Reliance Retail. The deal follows a recent $1 billion investment by Silver Lake Partners in Reliance Retail. The news has caused Reliance's shares to rise 4% in midday trading in Mumbai.

images.alt_text: Indian oil-to-telecoms conglomerate Reliance Industries is offering to sell a roughly US$20 billion stake in its retail arm to Amazon.com, BloombergQuint reported on Thursday, citing Bloomberg News.

site_title: Lendlease to set up S$40m product development centre in Singapore
summary: Lendlease is setting up a S$40 million product development centre in Singapore to accelerate the digital transformation of the property and construction sector. The centre, which will employ 50 software application developers, aims to introduce digital products and services leveraging the firm's Lendlease Podium platform. The centre is part of Lendlease's wider digital ecosystem, which includes product development centres in Silicon Valley and Sydney. The move is expected to steer the sector towards "autonomous buildings of the future" with the aim of reducing energy consumption and improving operational efficiency.

site_title: Bank Negara holds interest rates on tentative signs of recovery
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, held its key interest rate steady at 1.75% as the economy showed tentative signs of recovery. The decision comes after four consecutive rate cuts this year. The central bank cited improved labour market conditions, household spending, and trade activity, but noted some "downside risks and uncertainty" in the pace of recovery. The bank remains committed to supporting a sustainable economic recovery, with the economy expected to shrink 3.5-5.5% in 2020.

site_title: Credit Suisse to launch digital banking app in Switzerland
summary: Credit Suisse to launch a digital banking app in Switzerland, CSX, in October, offering free foreign transactions and digital wealth management. The app aims to compete with fintechs like Revolut and N26, targeting younger customers and cutting costs by closing branches. The app will initially not cover cash withdrawals at ATMs, but clients can reduce costs with a Mastercard debit card. Credit Suisse plans to expand digital services, including "digital bars" and co-working spaces, to attract startups and event organizers.

site_title: Japan anti-trust regulator accepts Amazon Japan improvement plan
summary: Japan's Fair Trade Commission (JFTC) has accepted Amazon Japan's plan to improve business practices, following a 2018 raid on the company. The plan includes returning 2 billion yen (S$25.8 million) to 1,400 vendors who were accused of being forced to bear the cost of discounted sales on Amazon's website. The move is seen as a positive step for Amazon Japan, which had been suspected of violating anti-trust rules. The plan's implementation will help restore trust and ensure compliance with Japan's anti-trust regulations.

site_title: Lloyd's of London posts H1 loss due to Covid-19 insurance claims
summary: Lloyd's of London reported a pre-tax loss of £400 million for the first half of 2020 due to COVID-19-related insurance claims, with £2.4 billion paid out for pandemic-related claims. This compares to a £2.3 billion profit in the first half of 2019. The global bill for non-life insurers is expected to reach over US$100 billion. Despite this, combined ratio excluding COVID-19 claims strengthened to 91.7%, indicating a robust approach to performance management.

site_title: I can see loo: Tokyo park gets transparent toilets
summary: A transparent toilet block has been built in a Tokyo park as part of a project by the Nippon Foundation, aiming to alleviate concerns about cleanliness and safety. The toilets, designed by architect Shigeru Ban, are see-through when not in use but turn opaque when locked, ensuring user privacy. The project's goal is to rethink public facilities, making them more accessible and user-friendly, with the transparent units also featuring baby-changing facilities and separate units for men, women, and those with disabilities.

site_title: BP's US$1.1b deal marks first step into offshore wind
summary: BP has entered the offshore wind market with a $1.1 billion deal to purchase US assets from Equinor. The partnership marks BP's first foray into offshore wind power and follows CEO Bernard Looney's pledge to spend $5 billion a year on renewable energy. BP will receive a 50% stake in the Empire Wind and Beacon Wind developments off New York and Massachusetts, while Equinor will retain 50% and continue as operator. The deal is part of Equinor's aggressive push into the sector, with a potential to power over 2 million homes.

site_title: BHP to tie CEO bonus to success in cutting customer emissions
summary: BHP Group has tied a portion of CEO Mike Henry's bonus payments to progress in reducing greenhouse gas emissions at its operations and those of its customers. The company aims to lower supply chain emissions by 30% by 2030 and operational emissions by 30% by 2030. BHP also seeks to help the steel industry reduce emissions intensity by 30% by 2030. This approach focuses on what the company can control, with the goal of achieving net-zero emissions at its sites by the middle of the century.

site_title: New accountability guidelines seek updated succession plans from financial firms: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has released updated guidelines for financial firms, requiring them to have a regularly reviewed and updated succession plan to ensure smooth transitions of senior management. The guidelines, part of MAS's efforts to promote sound culture and conduct, apply to all financial institutions unless exempted or have fewer than 50 in-house staff. The plans must identify potential candidates, establish handover policies, and track senior managers' performance. MAS has also clarified the decision-making authority of senior managers for foreign financial institutions operating in Singapore.

site_title: New York to mark 9/11 anniversary amid the coronavirus pandemic
summary: New York is set to mark the 19th anniversary of the 9/11 terrorist attacks on September 11, 2020, amidst the coronavirus pandemic and a bitter fight with the White House. The city will hold a ceremony at the "Ground Zero" memorial with a minute's silence at the exact moments of the hijacked airplanes crashing into the World Trade Center towers. This year, families of victims have recorded themselves instead of reading out the roll call of the dead.

images.alt_text: With crime on the rise, shops and apartments increasingly vacant and homeless people on the sidewalks, New York on Friday will mark the 19th anniversary of the Sept 11, 2001 terrorist attacks in the middle of the coronavirus pandemic and a bitter fight with the White House.

site_title: Motor racing: Vettel to join Aston Martin F1 team from 2021
summary: Sebastian Vettel, a four-time Formula One world champion, will join Aston Martin F1 team from 2021, replacing Mexican Sergio Perez. Vettel, 33, expressed his excitement to become an Aston Martin driver, marking his future with the team.

site_title: China auto sales in August rise 11.6%, fifth month of gain
summary: China's auto sales in August rose 11.6% to 2.19 million vehicles, marking the fifth consecutive month of gains. This growth is attributed to increased sales of new energy vehicles (NEVs) and trucks, driven by government investment in infrastructure and emission rules. NEV sales grew 25.8% to 109,000 units, while truck sales surged 41.6%. Overall, sales for the first eight months of the year remain down 9.7% at 14.55 million vehicles.

site_title: China property firms weigh cutting home prices after Evergrande's deep discounts
summary: China's top property developer Country Garden and smaller firms are considering deeper discounts on home purchases after Evergrande's 30% nationwide discount. The move aims to boost sales and cash flow at Evergrande, which has weakened profits. Other developers are hesitant to match the discount, citing different project locations. Despite this, home transactions in 18 major cities rose 3.4% in August, with sales volume expected to be driven by discounts.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on high-tech gains
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.88% on Thursday, driven by gains in major high-tech shares, including SoftBank Group, Nintendo, and Sony. The Nasdaq Composite Index finished up 2.7%, supported by news that a vaccine trial could soon resume. Investors remained cautious ahead of the European Central Bank's meeting, which could impact currency rates. Chip-linked shares, however, remained under selling pressure. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index closed at 23,235.47, while the broader Topix index rose to 1,624.86.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rebound on US tech rally, new virus stimulus
summary: South Korean stocks rebounded 0.87% on Thursday, driven by a tech-led rally on Wall Street and a new stimulus package. The Kospi benchmark closed at 2,396.48, with Samsung Electronics leading gains. The won gained, while the benchmark bond yield fell. The country reported 155 new coronavirus cases, and a $6.6 billion supplementary budget is being prepared to aid struggling small businesses. Foreigners were net buyers of 380.4 billion won worth of shares, and the won ended trading at 1,184.9 per US dollar.

site_title: Thai central bank says housing loan rules still necessary
summary: Thailand's central bank maintains that housing loan rules, including loan-to-value (LTV) ratios, are still necessary to curb risks in the property market. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, mortgage loans increased 4.4% in the second quarter, and the central bank will closely monitor the market due to high uncertainty. The rules, relaxed twice last year, were imposed to address concerns about high household debt and will continue to help regulate the sector.

site_title: South Korea draws extra 7.8t won budget to help small businesses, households
summary: South Korea is preparing its fourth supplementary budget of around US$6.6 billion to aid struggling small businesses and households due to the resurgence of the coronavirus. The 7.8 trillion won (S$9.01 billion) budget will provide cash payments to small businesses and households for settling mobile phone bills. The unexpected resurgence of the coronavirus is delaying recovery momentum, according to President Moon Jae-in, who cited sharply contracting domestic demand and consumption.

site_title: Indonesia's Waresix closes Series B round, raises US$100m over past year
summary: Indonesian logistics tech startup Waresix has closed its Series B funding round, raising US$100 million over the past year. Existing investors EV Growth and Jungle Ventures, along with new investors SoftBank Ventures Asia, EMTEK Group, Pavilion Capital, and Redbadge Pacific, contributed to the funding. The startup's logistics platform, which offers consolidation, back-haul optimisation, and hub-and-spoke distribution solutions, can achieve 50% higher truck utilisation than traditional shippers.

site_title: Broker's take: CGS-CIMB calls Lendlease Global Reit undervalued, initiates coverage
summary: CGS-CIMB has initiated coverage on Lendlease Global Reit, labeling it undervalued with a "add" rating and a target price of S$0.85. Analysts believe the Reit is a domestic recovery proxy for the Covid-19 pandemic, with a 30.3% upside potential from acquisitions and asset enhancement initiatives. The Reit's 100% committed dividend payout and limited downside risks to its fiscal 2021 forecast dividend yield of 6.6% support its strong financial position, with a 0.77 times fiscal 2020 price-to-book ratio and healthy gearing.

site_title: Gold at one-week high as weak dollar supports; ECB meet in focus
summary: Gold prices reached a one-week high due to the US dollar's weakness, with spot gold steady at $1,945.87 per ounce. Investors are cautious ahead of the European Central Bank's monetary policy decision, which is expected to keep policy unchanged. The ECB meeting, followed by the US Federal Reserve's meeting next week, is considered a key event risk for gold prices, which are expected to reach $2,300 per ounce next year due to ample money supply, lower interest rates, and macro uncertainty.

site_title: Jakarta to reimpose partial lockdown as virus cases surge
summary: Jakarta, Indonesia plans to reimpose a partial lockdown as early as Monday due to surging coronavirus cases. The city's governor, Anies Baswedan, warned that hospitals could "collapse" if infection rates continue to rise. The lockdown will restrict office buildings, large mosques, restaurants, and public transport, with many cases going unreported due to low testing rates. The move comes three months after a previous lockdown was lifted, and Indonesia's capital has seen over 50,000 confirmed cases and 1,300 deaths.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets climb before key ECB meet
summary: European stock markets rose at the open on Thursday, with Frankfurt's DAX 30 index gaining 0.4% to 13,286.07 points, and London's FTSE 100 index edging up 0.1% to 6,020.27. Investors await the European Central Bank's (ECB) meeting to see if they will indicate a need for further eurozone stimulus to combat the economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic. The ECB's decision will be closely watched, with traders brushing off recent US threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: 73% of Singapore businesses speeding up digitalisation amid Covid-19: study
summary: Singapore businesses have accelerated their digitalisation amid the Covid-19 pandemic, with 73% of organisations speeding up their digital transformation. A study by Microsoft Asia and IDC Asia/Pacific found that 80% of business decision makers believe innovation is now "a must" to respond to market challenges, and 16% of businesses in Singapore are innovation leaders, up 30% from before the crisis. Despite this, 34% of firms think their business model will lose competitiveness in five years, and 45% of innovation leaders expect to increase market share.

site_title: Singapore competition watchdog seeks views on proposed updates to guidelines
summary: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) is seeking public feedback on proposed updates to its guidelines under the Competition Act, aiming to provide clarity and guidance on intellectual property and merger assessments. The updates include clarifying the interface between intellectual property and competition law, as well as better guiding businesses and consumers on issues related to mergers and acquisitions, particularly in the digital era. The CCCS also reviewed its e-commerce platforms market study, concluding that there are no major competition concerns, and recommended platforms to enhance measures to protect consumers.

site_title: Indonesia stocks slump on Jakarta's plans to reinstate virus curbs
summary: Indonesia's main stock index plummeted 4.1% on Thursday after Jakarta's governor announced plans to reinstate social distancing restrictions due to rising coronavirus infections. The move is aimed at alleviating strain on the capital's health system, which has the highest death toll from Covid-19 in South-east Asia. The restrictions will start on September 14.

site_title: Former Goldman Sachs banker seeks to have 1MDB charges dropped
summary: A former Goldman Sachs banker, Roger Ng, has sought to have his charges related to 1MDB-linked bonds dropped or reduced, following Malaysia's withdrawal of charges against the US bank. Ng is currently in the US to face 1MDB-related charges and is set to appear in court on November 20. His lawyer, Tan Hock Chuan, has filed a letter of representation to the Malaysian Attorney General, seeking to review the charges against Ng.

site_title: Vietnam backs US role in South China Sea, rebuffing Beijing
summary: Vietnam has backed the US role in maintaining peace in the South China Sea, rebuffing Beijing's claims that American forces are destabilizing the region. At a virtual summit, Vietnam Foreign Minister Pham Binh Minh welcomed the US's constructive contributions to maintaining peace and stability in the South China Sea. Vietnam and other South-east Asian countries are open to practical cooperation with the US in the region, amid territorial disputes with China. The US has rejected China's expansive maritime claims and sent aircraft carriers to the waters to conduct military exercises.

site_title: Former Theranos CEO Holmes may pursue 'mental disease' in her defence
summary: Former Theranos CEO Elizabeth Holmes is exploring a "mental disease" defence in her criminal fraud trial, according to a judge's ruling. The defence plan, filed by Holmes, aims to introduce evidence of her mental condition to challenge the requirement that prosecutors prove her intent to do something wrong. This could potentially impact the trial's outcome and is one of Silicon Valley's most closely watched cases. The ruling allows government prosecutors to examine Holmes' mental health plan.

site_title: US sells Hong Kong consulate compound for HK$2.57b
summary: The US has sold its Hong Kong consulate compound in Shouson Hill for HK$2.57 billion, amid escalating tensions between China and the US. The sale, handled by CBRE Group, is part of the US global reinvestment programme and will not affect its presence in Hong Kong. The compound, comprising six apartment buildings, was purchased by the US in 1948 and is located in one of the city's most exclusive neighbourhoods. The sale comes as US companies consider moving out of the city due to escalating political conflicts and disquiet over China's national security law.

site_title: WeWork appoints Benjamin Dunham as CFO
summary: WeWork appoints Benjamin Dunham as its new Chief Financial Officer, replacing Kimberly Ross, who stepped down due to personal reasons. Dunham, who was previously finance head of WeWork Americas, will assume the role on October 1. The company has slashed its cash burn rate and secured a $1.1 billion financing commitment from SoftBank, following a management shake-up and lawsuits over its business model and corporate governance.

site_title: Nomura hires UBS's Ravi Raju in Asia wealth push
summary: Nomura has appointed Ravi Raju as head of international wealth management in Asia ex-Japan, based in Singapore. Raju, formerly head of ultra high net worth and global family office at UBS, will expand Nomura's wealth management business in the region, working closely with global markets and investment banking businesses. He joins from Deutsche Bank, where he was head of wealth management for Asia-Pacific. Raju's decades of experience will be valuable in building Nomura's business in Asia and extending his expertise globally.

site_title: Perennial Real Estate to delist from SGX next Monday
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings will be delisted from the Singapore bourse on Sept 14, after Primero Investment, its offeror, completes the compulsory acquisition of the company's shares at 95 Singapore cents per share. The shares were suspended on Aug 18 and last traded at 94.5 Singapore cents. The offeror launched its bid in June, and shares were suspended as the offer closed. This marks the end of Perennial's listing on the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Impossible Foods awaits China nod as Beyond Meat muscles in
summary: Impossible Foods, a US-based fake-meat maker, is awaiting regulatory approval in China to enter the world's largest meat-consuming market. The company's CEO, Pat Brown, is confident about the science behind its products, but concerned about the timeline. Rival Beyond Meat is expanding its presence in China, and Impossible Foods plans to launch its namesake pork offering and "pretty aggressive" marketing campaign once approved. The company believes the Chinese market, with 27% of global meat consumption, is a key opportunity for growth, with sales increasing six times in Asia in 2019.

site_title: Euro clings onto gains as traders hold breath before ECB meeting
summary: The euro maintained its gains against the US dollar ahead of the European Central Bank (ECB) meeting, where policymakers will assess the euro's recent appreciation and its impact on inflation. Traders are also monitoring the situation due to growing concerns about a potential UK-EU trade deal failure, which could negatively affect sterling. Despite expectations of a policy steady stance, investors will closely watch ECB President Christine Lagarde's comments on inflation and economic growth, which could influence the euro's value.

site_title: UPS to hire 100,000 seasonal workers for extended holiday shopping rush
summary: UPS plans to hire over 100,000 seasonal workers for the winter holiday season, which is expected to extend from October to January due to retailers' early kickoff. This is similar to the number hired last year. The company aims to manage the surge in demand for package deliveries, which has been driven by pandemic-fueled online shopping. UPS also plans to invest in automation to handle the increased volume.

site_title: Broker's take: CGS-CIMB upgrades Dairy Farm to 'add' on 'palatable valuations'
summary: Brokerage CGS-CIMB has upgraded its recommendation on Dairy Farm International to "add" from "hold", citing palatable valuations. The stock corrected by 7% since the last report, and forward valuations are now at 17.2 times the price-to-earnings ratio, closer to its historical mean. The counter views near-term uncertainties as priced in, with the stock trending closer to its year-to-date trough of US$3.70.

site_title: Macquarie Group to eliminate 70 From US workforce
summary: Macquarie Group has eliminated approximately 70 US jobs, affecting employees in New York and other cities, as part of the Australian bank's restructuring efforts. The move comes after the firm warned of "challenging" market conditions and failed to provide investors with meaningful earnings guidance. The bank, led by CEO Shemara Wikramanayake, has more than 2,500 US employees. This is the latest in a series of job cuts by the bank, following a reduction of about 100 equity research and sales jobs in New York and London last year.

site_title: Carsome appoints former Dairy Farm executive as COO
summary: Carsome appoints Benjamin Koellmann as its new COO, responsible for driving synergy and operation efficiency across its markets in Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand, and Singapore. Koellmann, former director of e-commerce at Dairy Farm International, brings experience managing e-commerce platforms and as a startup founder. The appointment comes as Carsome continues its expansion in South-east Asia, reporting a V-shaped recovery since resuming business in Malaysia and launching its flagship Carsome Experience Center in Kuala Lumpur.

images.alt_text: Carsome has appointed Benjamin Koellmann as its new chief operating officer.

site_title: UK home-price growth at four-year high in rush for green space
summary: The UK's housing market saw a four-year high in August, driven by demand for homes with outdoor space as city dwellers work remotely. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors reported the highest price gains since 2016, with inquiries, sales, and new listings all rising. However, concerns about the economic fallout from the pandemic, including renewed outbreaks and the end of government subsidies, threaten the market's resilience. The Bank of England is expected to ease monetary policy in the fourth quarter, but long-term sales expectations remain uncertain due to ongoing economic concerns.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Thursday; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 0.4% or 10.03 points to 2,509.36. Gainers outnumbered losers 108 to 22, driven by Wall Street gains and local banks' rises. Sembcorp Industries (SCI) and Singapore Telecommunications (ST) were among the top gainers, while ComfortDelGro Corp and Singapore Airlines also advanced. The market followed global cues, with US stocks rebounding and European shares bouncing back ahead of the European Central Bank's policy meeting.

site_title: Brazil extends 'Car Wash' graft probe
summary: Brazil's attorney general's office has extended the country's largest-ever corruption probe, "Operation Car Wash", until January 31, 2021, despite budget shortfalls and controversy surrounding the investigation. The probe, launched six years ago, has put several high-profile politicians and business executives behind bars, including former president Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva. The extension comes as critics have accused the task force of playing politics and pushing aggressive tactics too far, undermining suspects' rights. The operation will proceed without its two most prominent figures, former judge Sergio Moro and lead prosecutor Deltan Dallagnol.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares rise at Thursday's open
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 4.96 points or 0.3% to 1,501.68 on Thursday, driven by gains. Gainers outnumbered losers 364 to 40. Volume traded was 168.4 million lots worth RM92.9 million. The rally comes ahead of GDP data, with investors brushing off new Trump threats.

site_title: GKE Corp plans to sell stake in warehousing firm for 58.5m yuan
summary: GKE Corp plans to sell its 65% stake in loss-making Van Der Horst Logistics (VDHL) for 58.5 million yuan (S$11.7 million) in cash. The sale, agreed upon in a memorandum of understanding with Hung King Holdings, is due to be finalized within six months. The move aims to focus GKE's resources on other businesses and recognizes a potential net gain of S$1.5 million.

site_title: Facebook, Google, Twitter urged by EU to do more against fake news
summary: The European Commission has urged Facebook, Google, Twitter, and other tech companies to do more against fake news, two years after agreeing to a self-regulatory code of practice. The companies have been criticized for not being effective in combating disinformation related to COVID-19. The EU is pushing for greater action from the tech giants to prevent the spread of misinformation and maintain trust in the digital economy.

images.alt_text: Two years after agreeing to a self-regulatory code of practice to tackle disinformation, Facebook, Alphabet's Google, Twitter and other tech rivals must try harder to be more effective, the European Commission said on Thursday.

site_title: Yum China shares slide as much as 4.1% in Hong Kong market debut
summary: Yum China Holdings, the operator of KFC, Taco Bell, and Pizza Hut restaurants in China, made its Hong Kong market debut with shares initially falling 4.1% from their offering price of HK$412. The company raised US$2.22 billion after selling 41.91 million shares. Yum China's shares hit a low of HK$395 before recovering, with the Hang Seng Index trading 0.24% higher.

images.alt_text: The operator of KFC, Taco Bell and Pizza Hut restaurants in China had sold 41.91 million shares at HK$412 (S$72.75) each, raising US$2.22 billion in the listing.

site_title: AGV director in CAD probe unwilling to step down
summary: The AGV Group's nominating committee has recommended that executive director Albert Ang step down amid an investigation by the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) into false trading and market-rigging transactions. However, Ang is unwilling to step down, citing a desire to seek counsel on the matter. The committee believes Ang is "no longer fit and proper" to continue as ED, citing CAD's findings of "reasonable grounds" that he committed an offence. AGV's board is confident that the group can continue as a going concern, with financial support from individual and institutional lenders, as well as its executive chairman, Damien Chua.

site_title: Broker's take: CapitaLand Mall Trust poised to surprise on upside, says DBS
summary: DBS Group Research has reiterated its "buy" call and target price of S$2.40 for Capitaland Mall Trust (CMT), citing the proposed merger with CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CMT) will drive improved diversification and scale, and the trust trades at attractive valuations. The analyst notes CMT's widening yield disparity with retail peers and believes the counter's share price weakness is an opportunity for investors to accumulate. DBS expects the combined entity to reclaim its premium over peers as it restarts growth engines after the pandemic.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index rising 0.8% to 23,215.48. This follows rallies on Wall Street, which may influence currency rates ahead of the ECB meeting. The broader Topix index also edged up 0.7%.

site_title: Baidu, investors in talks to raise US$2b for biotech startup
summary: Chinese tech giant Baidu is in talks with investors to raise up to $2 billion over three years for a biotech startup that will utilize AI technology to discover new drugs and diagnose diseases. Baidu plans to focus on areas like drug discovery and development, and early tumor diagnosis, leveraging its AI capabilities. The company is unlikely to be the controlling investor, following increased investment in the healthcare sector since the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Thursday, recovering some losses, following a sharp bounce on Wall Street. The Hang Sang Index rose 0.47% to 24,584.94, while the Shanghai Composite Index jumped 0.85% to 3,282.23. The gains come as investors brush off new US threats to extend the stocks rally, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Travellers coming from India will have to take Covid-19 test before entering Singapore
summary: Singapore will require travellers from India to take a Covid-19 test 72 hours prior to arrival, in addition to existing requirements of a two-week stay-home notice and a negative test result before the end of the notice. This measure follows reports of a resurgence of infections in India and imported cases in Singapore with recent travel history to India. The Ministry of Health will adjust border measures to manage the risk of importing more cases, and travellers may be subjected to control measures upon entry, including payment for stay at SHN facilities and tests.

site_title: Australia: Shares open higher boosted by tech shares, NZ rises
summary: Australian shares rose 1.1% to 5,941.9 on Thursday, boosted by a rally in technology stocks and a decrease in coronavirus cases in the state of Victoria, which reported 51 new infections. Tech stocks jumped 3.4% with Afterpay and WiseTech Global among the biggest gains. Miners and healthcare stocks also rose, with miners like BHP Group and Rio Tinto advancing up to 1.6% and 1.8% respectively. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 1.2% to 11,880.92.

site_title: Electric-car startup Lucid to follow Tesla Into energy storage
summary: Lucid Motors, an electric vehicle startup, is expanding into energy storage, developing home batteries and utility-scale devices similar to Tesla's Powerwall. CEO Peter Rawlinson aims to use the same battery-cell modules in stationary storage systems, citing cost-effectiveness. Lucid has agreements with LG Chem and is in talks with Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund to install industrial-scale energy storage systems. The company's move into energy storage follows Tesla's lead, but Lucid must catch up in both EVs and energy storage, with Tesla having a head start in both areas.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, Sunningdale, Sembcorp, AGV, Raffles Education
summary: Singtel shares fell 0.9% to S$2.22 after CEO Yuen Kuan Moon mentioned the telco is pacing its 5G deployment, aiming for half the island's coverage in two years and nationwide by 2025. Sunningdale Tech gained 1.6% to S$1.25 after being approached about a possible transaction involving its shares.

site_title: Ascott opens new serviced residence in London's Islington district
summary: The Ascott, a serviced residence unit of CapitaLand, has opened a 108-unit property in London's Islington district. Located in Islington Square, the property features 81 studios and 27 one-bedroom apartments, and is within walking distance to Emirates Stadium and other attractions. The serviced residence is part of Ascott's "Work in Residence" initiative, offering private workspace options. This marks the company's expansion plans, aiming to add 800 more units across Europe by 2023, with over 900 units currently in London.

site_title: Oil prices edge up off three-month lows, but demand concerns persist
summary: Oil prices rose 2.5% to settle at $40.79 a barrel, lifting them off three-month lows, but demand concerns persist due to rising Covid-19 cases globally. Brent crude and US crude rose 2.5% and 3.5% respectively, despite Saudi Arabia's Aramco cutting October oil prices, a sign of softening demand. Analysts warn that the demand recovery is fragile, inventories are high, and refining margins are low, citing grim economic figures and record supply cuts by Opec+.

images.alt_text: Oil futures on Wednesday clawed back some of the losses they sustained in the previous session, but a rebound in Covid-19 cases in some countries undermined hopes for a steady recovery in global demand.

site_title: The issue is not foreign talent but transparency in the process
summary: Singapore's employment of foreign talent has sparked controversy, with some calling for restrictions. However, experts argue that the issue lies in transparency, not the number of foreign workers. Foreigners can fill gaps in the market, particularly in high-value industries. A protectionist stance would harm the economy and lead to job outsourcing. The focus should be on ensuring that jobs go to the most qualified candidate, regardless of nationality. Transparency in the hiring process is key to addressing concerns and maintaining a merit-based system.

site_title: Europe: Shares bounce back, focus shifts to ECB meeting
summary: European shares rose 1.6% on Wednesday ahead of the European Central Bank's policy meeting, driven by a report that AstraZeneca may resume its Covid-19 vaccine trial. Telecoms, insurers, and technology stocks led sectoral advances, while travel and leisure stocks fell 0.9%. Investors are focusing on the ECB meeting, expecting no changes in rate policy, but rather commentary on inflation and the euro's strength.

site_title: JC Penney reaches tentative rescue deal, averting liquidation
summary: JC Penney Co has reached a tentative deal with landlords and lenders valued at $1.75 billion to rescue the department store chain from bankruptcy proceedings. The deal, which includes mall owners Simon Property Group and Brookfield Property Partners, will carve JC Penney into three pieces, preserving 70,000 jobs. Lenders will take control of two entities, while the landlords will acquire the retail operations. The agreement averts liquidation and avoids significant business collapse following the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Brexit endgame spurs investors to buckle up for a wild ride
summary: Investors are bracing for a potential wild ride as the UK and EU's Brexit deadline looms. Fund managers predict the pound could fall to a 35-year low, stocks may lag international peers, and bond yields could turn negative. The UK's decision to break international law has sparked a backlash, and a stalemate in trade talks has seen the pound suffer its longest losing streak since March. Economists expect a deal by the end of December, but investors are increasingly concerned about the risks of a no-deal Brexit, which could lead to a significant slump in the pound and UK assets.

site_title: Sias asks Accordia Golf Trust to address concerns over golf course divestment
summary: Sias, a Singapore investor advocacy group, has asked Accordia Golf Trust to address concerns over its planned divestment of golf courses to its sponsor Accordia Golf. The group questioned the valuation of the golf courses, which have been negatively impacted by the pandemic, and the inclusion of a lengthy claim period after the proposed disposal. Sias also raised concerns about Daiwa Group's potential influence on the voting process, given its ownership of the trustee-manager and its subsidiary's 51% stake in the trust.

site_title: Luxury London house prices rise for first time since lockdown
summary: House prices in London's most expensive areas rose 0.3% in August, the first monthly increase since February, according to Knight Frank. The luxury market has been slow to recover from the COVID-19 lockdown, with prices in prime areas falling 17% since 2015. A sales tax break and lifting of international travel restrictions could boost sales, particularly in neighborhoods popular with overseas buyers like Knightsbridge and Mayfair.

site_title: World's top 10 airline stocks are all Chinese, except one
summary: Chinese airline stocks dominate the world's top 10 airline stocks, with nine out of the 10 showing double-digit gains over the past three months. This is despite the global airline industry's slow recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic, with the International Air Transport Association predicting passenger traffic won't return to pre-pandemic levels until 2024. Chinese carriers, particularly low-cost carrier Spring Airlines, have benefited from a strong domestic market, lower fuel costs, and the removal of travel curbs. Analysts expect China's big three airlines to remain unprofitable in the second half of the year, but traffic is expected to increase in the coming months.

site_title: Strong start to 9.9 sales event keeps businesses upbeat on e-tailing
summary: E-commerce players in Singapore reported a strong start to the 9.9 sales event, with sales exceeding last year's numbers. Preliminary data showed a 25% increase in sales at Qoo10 and double sales of the first two hours of last year at Lazada. Popular items included food, beauty products, electronics, and home appliances. Despite economic uncertainty, e-commerce players remain optimistic about the online retail landscape, with Singles Day, Black Friday, and 12.12 sales events also expected to drive business. Economists attribute the surge in online shopping to the pandemic's impact on travel opportunities.

site_title: Condo, HDB rental volumes tumble in Aug: SRX
summary: Rental volumes for HDB flats and private condominiums in Singapore plummeted in August, with HDB flats seeing a 16.7% drop and private condos experiencing a 20.4% decline. Analysts attribute the decline to the weakened employment market, including job losses among expatriates. Rents for private apartments remained unchanged, while HDB rents rose 0.3% year-over-year. Experts warn of a potential "domino effect" on the rental market, with increased vacancies and downward pressure on rents expected in the coming months.

site_title: CGS-CIMB initiates coverage on Hi-P with 'hold'; flags growth opportunities via M&A
summary: CGS-CIMB has initiated coverage on Hi-P International with a "hold" recommendation and a target price of S$1.23. The analysts highlighted the company's net cash balance sheet and growth opportunities via mergers and acquisitions, citing the recent acquisition of South East Asia Moulding Company. Hi-P's management has guided that one major customer accounts for around 50% of its revenue, and the brokerage is exploring inorganic growth to reduce customer concentration risk. The target price is based on a 1.52 times price-to-book value.

site_title: Ryanair cuts passenger target by 10 million
summary: Ryanair cuts its annual passenger target to 50 million from 60 million, citing Covid-19 as a major factor. The airline, Europe's largest low-cost carrier, now expects an average of 5 million passengers per month for the winter. Fares are expected to be "aggressively down" to stimulate demand. Ryanair may close some bases and withdraw capacity in countries with ineffective quarantines, but expects to shed fewer than 3,000 jobs. The airline attributes the revised target to the "winter of 2020" being a "write-off" due to the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Move aside, Trump - these women have more money and better ideas
summary: US President Donald Trump's sexist attacks on women, particularly those in power, continue to escalate. Recently, he targeted Laurene Powell Jobs, criticizing her husband Steve Jobs' estate over her use of his wealth. However, Powell Jobs is the sixth-richest woman in the world, with a net worth of over $20 billion, and has been influential in various philanthropic efforts. Other powerful women, including Mackenzie Scott and Melinda Gates, have also been making significant impacts in the US, with Scott having donated $1.7 billion to social justice causes and Gates co-chairing the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.

site_title: US: Stocks end up after three down days, Nasdaq up 2.7%
summary: US stocks rebounded after three consecutive losing sessions, with the Nasdaq Composite Index rising 2.7% to 11,141.56. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 1.6% and the S&P 500 jumped 2% to 3,398.96. The three-day rout was attributed to profit-taking concerns over large tech companies. However, portfolio manager Gregori Volokhine noted that some valuations, such as Tesla's, had become excessive, while gains of companies like Apple and Microsoft were seen as realistic.

site_title: Burning oil tanker off Sri Lanka leaves 1 km long slick
summary: A Sri Lankan oil tanker that caught fire last week has left a 1 km long slick across the Indian Ocean, sparking environmental concerns. The blaze was brought under control, but diesel has been spilled into the sea. The incident has raised fears of an environmental disaster, but no immediate reports of damage or casualties have been reported.

site_title: Sri Lanka mulls hedging options to attract foreigners
summary: Sri Lanka is planning to offer incentives to attract overseas investors into local-currency bonds to reduce its reliance on foreign debt. The nation will provide global funds forward risk cover via a swap to protect local debt holdings. This move aims to diversify its debt portfolio and mitigate the impact of the novel coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Norwegian lawmaker nominates Trump for Nobel Peace Prize
summary: A Norwegian lawmaker, Christian Tybring-Gjedde, has nominated US President Donald Trump for the 2021 Nobel Peace Prize for his role in brokering a deal between Israel and the United Arab Emirates. This is Trump's second nomination for the award, following a previous nomination in 2019 for his diplomatic efforts with North Korea. The Norwegian Nobel Committee declined to comment on the nomination. The winner will be announced on October 9 in Oslo.

site_title: When dark clouds bring hope for prosperity in India
summary: India is experiencing a glimmer of hope amidst the economic crisis caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Low crude oil prices have saved the government billions and boosted oil refiners' profits. The country is also benefiting from a record-breaking monsoon season, which has led to a better crop. Indian exports are showing signs of rising, with the country's export share increasing to 1.71% in the first quarter of 2019. The government is capitalizing on these strengths by setting up a command centre to reverse the GDP shock and positioning itself as an alternative manufacturing hub to China.

site_title: Tan Chong sells stake in associate company for 249.7b rupiah
summary: Tan Chong International sold its stake in associate company Tifa Finance for 249.7 billion rupiah (S$23.2 million). Tifa, a multi-financing company in Indonesia, provides leasing, consumer financing, and factoring services. The sale marks the disposal of Tan Chong's interest in the company.

site_title: China's biggest airshow cancelled over pandemic
summary: China's International Aviation and Aerospace Exhibition, the country's largest airshow, has been cancelled due to the coronavirus pandemic. The biennial event, scheduled for November, will now take place in 2022. The cancellation follows restrictions on foreign nationals entering China and severe restrictions on international flights. The domestic aviation industry is recovering, but airlines have yet to return to profitability. Western aerospace companies have also reduced budgets due to the pandemic's impact, hindering progress on key aircraft programmes, including China's COMAC C919 and CR929.

site_title: Credit Suisse wins bid to stall release of rogue-banker report
summary: Credit Suisse has won a bid to temporarily halt the release of a report detailing how it failed to prevent fraud and money laundering by former banker Patrice Lescaudron. A Geneva appeals court issued a suspension order, giving judges time to decide whether the report can be shared with Lescaudron's Russian and Georgian clients. The report, which could potentially lead to a penalty of 5 million Swiss francs, has been the subject of a long-standing dispute between Credit Suisse and Lescaudron's clients, who lost tens of millions of Swiss francs due to his actions.

site_title: SoftBank Group unveils new HQ building
summary: SoftBank Group unveiled its new headquarters, designed by WeWork, in Tokyo, marking a shift away from office working amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The building features social distancing technology and WeWork-style amenities. The move comes as SoftBank is loosening ties with its wireless carrier, SoftBank Corp, with its stake expected to fall to 40%. The sell-down of core assets funds SoftBank's investments in listed tech stocks, raising concerns about the group's investing practices.

site_title: First 5G iPhone expected at Apple online event next week
summary: Apple is set to unveil its first 5G iPhone at an online event on September 15. The event, which will be streamed from the company's headquarters, is expected to feature a new iPhone model tailored for superfast 5G networks. Analysts predict a strong demand for 5G iPhones, with Daniel Ives forecasting a "supercycle" driven by the release of new models in October. However, technology analyst Rob Enderle notes that Apple may not have the necessary chip technology in place for a 5G iPhone.

site_title: Natural gas getting coal's bad rep in the rich world
summary: Natural gas, once hailed as a clean alternative to coal, is losing its appeal in rich nations, mirroring coal's decline. Despite this, it remains in demand, particularly in developing countries, where its use is expected to rise. This shift in sentiment comes as governments, utilities, and investors increasingly turn to renewable energy sources. As a result, natural gas is losing its status as a vital fuel for a low-carbon economy, similar to coal's decline.

site_title: Leaderless WTO needs to reform or risk losing further relevance
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) is facing its biggest crisis in 25 years due to the departure of its director-general, Roberto Azevedo, and the US' insistence on an American interim chief. The organization is struggling to reform global trade rules and is losing relevance amidst ongoing international tensions, protectionism, and the COVID-19 pandemic. A new director-general is needed to address the urgent task of reforming the global trade rules, and the selection process is underway with eight candidates vying for the position, but the US presidential election on November 3 may impact the outcome.

site_title: The sustainability transformation
summary: Businesses face growing pressure to improve their sustainability performance, driven by regulators, investors, and customers. Financial institutions are increasingly recognizing sustainability risks as a financial risk, leading to regulatory changes and increased investment in sustainable funds. Companies are responding by prioritizing sustainability, with 35% citing investor pressure as a top factor and 28% citing meeting customer expectations as a key factor. To accelerate their sustainability transformation, companies can look ahead to future opportunities, look inside to launch sustainability initiatives, and look around to leverage their business ecosystem, ultimately positioning themselves for long-term growth and value.

site_title: Abenomics expected to retire with Japanese prime minister
summary: Japan's longest-serving prime minister, Shinzo Abe, is expected to retire with his signature economic policy program, Abenomics, which has been in effect since 2013. Despite the program's focus on monetary policy, flexible fiscal policy, and structural reforms, Abenomics has largely failed to achieve its goals, including pushing up inflation to 2% and boosting productivity. The program's monetary policy has been particularly ineffective, with long-term interest rates remaining low. Abe's departure marks a significant shift in Japan's economic policy, with lessons from his experience that may be relevant to other ageing advanced economies, including Europe, which faces similar challenges in generating inflation and driving productivity growth.

site_title: US refinancing, delinquencies soar in divided mortgage era
summary: The US mortgage market is experiencing a widening gap between affluent borrowers and those struggling due to the pandemic. Record-low mortgage rates have enabled many homeowners to refinance, saving hundreds of dollars a month. However, this trend has left vulnerable households facing mounting threats to their homeownership. Delinquencies have surged to 2.25 million, a 450% increase from pre-pandemic levels, and over 11 million jobs remain lost. The gap in wealth and credit quality between those who can refinance and those who cannot continues to widen.

site_title: UK's new plan says it could ignore parts of Brexit divorce treaty, angering EU
summary: The UK government has published a Bill that could allow it to ignore parts of the Brexit divorce treaty with the EU, sparking anger from Brussels. The Internal Markets Bill states that certain provisions are "to have effect notwithstanding inconsistency or incompatibility with international or other domestic law," potentially breaching international law. EU leaders have warned that such a move would undermine trust and break the principle of pacta sunt servanda, or "agreements must be kept." The Bill's approval is set to be debated in Parliament, with the UK's Brexit talks with the EU in crisis.

site_title: Frozen UK property funds clear to open as value warning lifts
summary: Frozen UK property funds with £12 billion in assets are set to reopen after a trade body lifted valuation uncertainty warnings. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors judged the real estate market has recovered sufficiently, allowing managers to resume withdrawals. Asset managers, including Legal & General and Standard Life Aberdeen, will discuss next steps, with investors expected to withdraw their funds. The move aims to boost liquidity in the property market, but may lead to a rush of redemptions and sales of commercial properties into an uncertain market.

site_title: Raffles Education shares climb over 18% after Oei Hong Leong ups stake
summary: Raffles Education Corp shares rose over 18% on Wednesday after substantial shareholder Oei Hong Leong increased his stake to 13.05%, buying 2 million shares worth S$284,594. The move comes as Oei seeks to oust founder Chew Hua Seng as CEO and chairman, and has called for an extraordinary general meeting. The company's shares hit an intra-day high of 19.3 Singapore cents before ending the day at 17.8 cents.

site_title: Hollywood seeks virtual hype at 'hybrid' Toronto festival
summary: Hollywood stars will participate in the Toronto International Film Festival (TIFF) virtually due to the coronavirus pandemic and closed Canadian border. The festival, which usually attracts 500,000 attendees, will be online-only this year, featuring world premieres of early Oscars frontrunners and arthouse films. Despite the absence of in-person attendees, the festival aims to maintain its usual hype and momentum for upcoming films.

site_title: Thai protesters plan big march on PM's office next week
summary: Thai protesters plan a massive march on Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha's office next week, with an estimated 50,000-100,000 people expected to attend. The rally, set for September 19, will begin with an overnight protest on a university campus and move to a public square beside the Grand Palace if more people join. The protesters demand the government's removal, an end to harassment of opponents, constitutional amendments, and dissolution of Parliament. The rally coincides with the anniversary of a 2006 coup and marks the first time the pro-democracy movement has moved beyond speeches on stages.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sunningdale Tech has been approached about a possible transaction involving its shares. The company's board advises shareholders to exercise caution and refrain from taking any action that may be prejudicial to their interests. Meanwhile, Kimly, a CATALIST-listed coffee shop consolidator, has entered two joint venture agreements for a total consideration of S$294,000 to operate and manage coffee shops in Singapore. The agreements align with Kimly's strategy to expand its network of food outlets.

site_title: Yen rises, US dollar steadies as market slides
summary: The Japanese yen rose against the US dollar due to market concerns over the US tech sector and a delayed coronavirus vaccine candidate. The US dollar steadied as investors sought safer assets, while the euro fell to a near three-week low. The pound also declined to a six-week low due to Brexit uncertainty. The European Central Bank's meeting on Thursday is expected to be watched closely, with investors awaiting any hints of policy changes that could impact the euro and dollar.

site_title: Penrose condo's early-bird prices start from S$788,000 this weekend
summary: The Penrose condominium, a 99-year leasehold project developed by Hong Leong Holdings and City Developments Limited, will begin previews by appointment starting from September 12. Early-bird prices start from S$788,000 for one-bedroom units, with prices increasing to S$2.11 million for four-bedroom units. The development features 566 units, a childcare centre, swimming pool, and rooftop sky garden, and is located about a 15-minute drive from the central business district.

site_title: Airbus tops Boeing on deliveries, avoids order cancellations
summary: Airbus delivered 39 jets in August, surpassing Boeing's 13 planes, and avoided order cancellations despite the coronavirus crisis. Airbus delivered 35 A320-series narrow-body planes and four twin-aisle jets, while Boeing struggled with delayed 787 Dreamliner deliveries due to a manufacturing flaw. Airbus's deliveries have held up better than Boeing's, but the company's shares fell 2.4% due to declining revenue. Airbus's strategy of deferring deliveries may protect its backlog, but risks leaving production gaps.

site_title: AstraZeneca suspends Covid-19 vaccine trials after surprise illness
summary: AstraZeneca has paused global trials of its Covid-19 vaccine due to an unexplained illness in a study participant, dimming prospects for an early rollout. The vaccine, developed with the University of Oxford, was described by the World Health Organization as the world's leading candidate. The suspension, which is routine when a potentially unexplained illness occurs, may impact the vaccine's fast-track approval in the US before the presidential election. The US Food and Drug Administration defines an adverse event as one that suggests a possible relationship to the drug being tested, but the nature of the illness remains unclear.

site_title: UOB's private equity arm discloses impact investing framework
summary: UOB Venture Management, the private equity arm of UOB, has disclosed its impact investing framework, becoming the first signatory of the Impact Principles in South-east Asia to do so. The framework, launched in 2019, promotes transparency and credibility in the impact investing market. UOBVM's disclosure statement outlines how it upholds the nine principles, focusing on managing strategic impact, assessing expected impact, and conducting exits that consider sustained impact. The Asia Impact Investment Fund, a double-bottom-line fund, aims to achieve both financial and social returns in South-east Asia and China.

site_title: Employers urged to step up flexi-hours to ease crowding risk
summary: Singapore employers are urged to introduce flexi-working hours to ease crowding risk and help the country's safe return to the workplace. This comes as the government considers allowing more people to return to work. The move also aims to reduce the risk of coronavirus transmission.

site_title: 'Self-sufficient' Chinese city to reflect on coronavirus lessons
summary: China is designing a self-sufficient city near Beijing with features such as rooftop farms, renewable energy, and drone-friendly terraces to mitigate the impact of future pandemic outbreaks. The city, Xiong'an, aims to provide residents with all necessary amenities, including food and resources, in case of confinement. The design, inspired by the COVID-19 lockdowns, prioritizes sustainability, circular bio-economy, and green spaces. The city's goal is to serve as a model for post-pandemic urban development.

site_title: SoftBank said to get 1.3 trillion yen in wireless stock orders
summary: SoftBank Group Corp's domestic wireless unit has received 1.3 trillion yen ($16.8 billion) in wireless stock orders, exceeding initial expectations. The orders, led by Nomura Holdings and Daiwa Securities Group, were fully covered on Tuesday. The sale, which includes an over-allotment, will likely be priced on September 14. This comes after SoftBank's founder, Masayoshi Son, announced plans to sell a third of the domestic wireless operation and other assets to raise cash. The company's stock has tumbled this week, but the sale is seen as a way to replenish its cash reserves.

site_title: LVMH drops planned US$16b Tiffany takeover; bitter battle expected
summary: LVMH drops its planned $16 billion takeover of Tiffany & Co. amid the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the luxury industry. The deal, which would have been the biggest in the luxury industry, was struck last year but faced opposition due to US tariffs on French products. Tiffany is suing LVMH in Delaware, seeking a court order to complete the transaction on agreed terms. The luxury industry is expected to see a 35% revenue slump this year, with revenues returning to 2019 levels in 2022-23.

site_title: The new office plan - coworking spaces
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic is reshaping the way companies approach office spaces, with a growing demand for coworking spaces from large corporations and businesses. After an initial setback due to the Circuit Breaker, coworking spaces are experiencing a resurgence. This shift is part of a broader trend towards alternatives to working from home, including workations at hotels.

site_title: SCI shares jump on Day 1 of ex-entitlements trade; Sembmarine inches lower
summary: Sembcorp Industries (SCI) shares surged on the first day of trading excluding entitlements, reaching a closing price of S$1.17, a 21.6% increase. This value more than compensated shareholders for the fall in Sembmarine's shares. Analysts at PhillipCapital expect SCI's return on equity to improve and its profitability to increase, leading to a positive re-rating. The demerger from SMM is expected to unlock value for SCI shareholders and enable the conglomerate to focus on growth opportunities in energy and urban sectors.

site_title: COE premium for Cat B cars tops S$40,000
summary: Singapore's certificate of entitlement (COE) premiums for cars ended higher, with the premium for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp reaching S$37,766, up from S$35,710 three weeks ago. The premium for open COE, which can be used for any vehicle type except motorcycles, closed at S$40,790, up from S$38,110. This marks the third consecutive round of increases, sending car premiums across the S$40,000-mark for the first time since November 2019.

images.alt_text: Despite widespread news of businesses reeling from the Covid-19 pandemic, the commercial vehicle COE price finished at S$26,644, and its highest since August 2019.

site_title: MAS to step up 'supervisory engagement' to ensure banks meet Sora transition timelines
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will step up supervisory engagement to ensure banks meet the transition timelines for the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (Sora) by the end of 2021. The transition is necessary as Sora replaces the Swap Offer Rate (SOR), a key interest rate benchmark, due to the discontinuation of the London Interbank Offered Rate (Libor) at the end of 2021. MAS will expand its Sora floating-rate notes issuance and provide guidance on specific deadlines to cease SOR usage in new financial products. Banks and corporates must prepare for a smooth transition by identifying risk exposures and understanding Sora products.

site_title: Temasek contributes to US$100m water innovation fund as cornerstone investor
summary: Temasek contributed to a US$100 million water innovation fund as a cornerstone investor, alongside strategic investors such as SKion Water, Ecolab, and Microsoft. The fund aims to support technologies addressing global water challenges, including conserving resources and adapting to climate change. With the demand for fresh water expected to outpace supply by 40% in under 10 years, the fund will accelerate innovations in the water sector to solve this pressing global challenge.

site_title: Singtel to pace out investment for 5G technology, unveils 5G-powered pop-up store
summary: Singtel, a Singaporean telco, is pacing its 5G investment, aiming to roll out coverage to half the island in two years and nationwide by 2025. The company's CEO, Yuen Kuan Moon, emphasized a cautious approach to ensure customer needs are met while generating a return on investment. This strategy will allow Singtel to serve its customers effectively while managing costs.

site_title: Super rich get richer on Ant after striking early deals with Jack Ma
summary: Jack Ma's Ant Group has secured significant investments from the world's richest people, including Hong Kong's Li Ka-shing and Thailand's Chearavanonts, totaling nearly $700 million. The investments, which could yield 50% returns, demonstrate the growing trend of super-wealthy families investing in fintech. Ant is set to raise $30 billion in an October listing, which could make Jack Ma one of the world's 10 richest people, and boost the returns of US private equity firms.

site_title: Joint bank accounts may come under more scrutiny in debt chase
summary: Singapore's High Court ruled that creditors can now seize money from joint bank accounts under certain circumstances, departing from a previous position that such accounts cannot be garnished. The ruling aims to enhance equity in bad debt cases, but some lawyers note that the high burden of proof required may limit the number of applications. The decision may lead to increased scrutiny of joint bank accounts in debt chases.

images.alt_text: In Singapore, a creditor can take various steps to enforce a judgment against a debtor if the latter refuses to comply, such as serving a garnishee order.

site_title: August new home sales surge to 11-month high on pent-up demand
summary: Singapore new home sales surged to an 11-month high in August, with 1,227 units sold, exceeding expectations. Despite the Hungry Ghost month, buyers pushed prices upwards amid worsening economic conditions and rising unemployment. The sales were driven by pent-up demand, with 84.7% of buyers being Singaporeans. The median unit price increased across top nine projects, with some selling at 4.6% higher than their launch price. Forett At Bukit Timah, launched on August 8, contributed significantly to the sales.

site_title: UBS partners Beyond Social Services to help low-income families
summary: UBS Singapore has committed S$85,000 to Beyond Social Services, supporting low-income families with refurbished laptops and contract-free SIM-only plans. The funds, raised through a fundraising campaign, will help at least 100 families with home-based learning activities, video calls, and government-funded IT initiatives. The partnership aims to bridge the digital divide exposed by the Covid-19 crisis, highlighting the need for universal digital access in a technology-driven society.

site_title: Are smaller enterprise players ready to digest the 5G fibre market?
summary: Smaller enterprise players in Singapore may challenge the dominance of major mobile network operators (MNOs) in the 5G fibre market, particularly in the non-residential segment. Companies like NetLink NBN Trust and Colt Singapore are exploring opportunities in the enterprise space, which could lead to increased competition and new business models. The Singapore regulator's approach to promoting "facilities-based competition" and capping the number of spectrum players may also favor smaller fibre players, creating a more level playing field in the market.

site_title: Sunningdale Tech issues holding announcement about possible transaction
summary: Sunningdale Tech has issued a holding announcement regarding a possible transaction involving its shares. The company's board stated that there is no certainty of a specific or definitive transaction materializing. Shareholders are advised to exercise caution and refrain from taking any actions that may be prejudicial to their interests. The company will make further announcements as necessary.

site_title: IMF chief warns global economic crisis 'far from over'
summary: IMF chief Kristalina Georgieva warns that the global economic crisis is "far from over" despite a sharp rebound in output, consumption, and employment since the pandemic. A full recovery is unlikely without a vaccine, and governments must continue to support workers and businesses to prevent job destruction. The recovery remains fragile and uneven, and some companies will inevitably fail, especially in industries like travel. Governments must devise multilateral solutions to ensure adequate vaccine supply and distribution, and be cautious in distributing resources.

site_title: TraceTogether tokens to be distributed free to all S'pore residents from Sept 14
summary: Singapore will distribute TraceTogether tokens nationwide starting Sept 14, initially in Jalan Besar and Tanjong Pagar districts, to aid seniors in using the app. The government will also launch a pilot programme requiring users to check in with either tokens or the app at certain venues, such as crowded places or those with mask exemptions.

site_title: Kardashian television reality show to end after 14 years
summary: The E! network announced that "Keeping Up With The Kardashians" will end after 14 years, with its last season set to air in 2021. The family made the decision without giving a reason, but stated they wanted to live their lives without cameras. The show, which debuted in 2012, helped launch the careers of Kim, Kylie, Kendall, Khloe, and Kourtney Kardashian, and spawned 12 spin-off series. Audiences have declined in recent years, with viewership dropping to under one million from four million at its peak.

site_title: Vaccine politics demand more from Big Pharma
summary: Nine major COVID-19 vaccine developers, including Pfizer and Moderna, have signed a pledge to wait for large-scale trials before submitting their inoculations for FDA approval. This move comes after President Trump's calls for a speedy vaccine, sparking concerns about a rushed process. The companies agree to demonstrate safety and efficacy through a Phase Three clinical study and will make data publicly available. The pledge aims to build trust in the process, but critics argue that more can be done to ensure public confidence, such as committing to delay applications until trials are complete.

site_title: Oscar academy explains new diversity rules for best picture contenders
summary: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has introduced new diversity rules for Best Picture contenders starting with the 96th Oscars in 2024. Films must meet at least two of four standards, including on-screen representation, off-screen creative leadership, apprenticeship opportunities, and diversity in marketing and distribution departments. To meet on-screen representation, at least one lead or significant supporting actor must be from an under-represented racial or ethnic group, or 30% of secondary actors can come from under-represented groups. The move aims to improve inclusion within the organization and in the movies it honors.

site_title: Cloud-data company Snowflake attracts Berkshire, Salesforce to technology IPO
summary: Snowflake Inc, a cloud-data company, plans to raise up to $2.38 billion in its technology IPO, attracting investors like Warren Buffett. The San Mateo, California-based company will market 28 million shares at $75 to $85 each, valuing it at $23.7 billion, nearly twice its last private funding round of $12.4 billion.

site_title: STI slips 0.2% on double whammy of US tech sell-off, vaccine delays
summary: The Straits Times Index in Singapore fell 0.22% to 2,499.33 after a tech sell-off on Wall Street and news that AstraZeneca has paused its Covid-19 vaccine trials. Analysts attribute the market's recent rally to vaccine hopes, which are now derailed. US tech stocks are in a technical correction, with no material changes to justify the rout, and the impact on other asset classes is uncertain.

site_title: Brexit in crisis: UK's new plan admits breach of international law
summary: The UK has published a bill that admits breaching international law by ignoring parts of the Withdrawal Agreement with the European Union. The Internal Markets Bill allows ministers to override international law if it conflicts with domestic law, sparking concerns from Brussels and other EU leaders. The move could jeopardize trade talks and undermine trust in the UK's commitment to international law. The bill, if approved, would give the government the power to modify certain provisions of the Withdrawal Agreement, potentially threatening the peace in Northern Ireland.

site_title: Saudi government taps into Aramco for cash, forcing it to stall projects
summary: Saudi Arabia's state-owned oil company, Saudi Aramco, is facing pressure from the government to pay a $75 billion dividend this year, despite the company's struggling cash flow due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The government's reliance on Aramco as a cash cow is forcing the company to stall strategic projects and rack up debt. This move has raised concerns among global fund managers and experts, who warn that it may limit Aramco's ability to invest in maintaining oil fields and developing new technologies. The company has already cut capital expenditure and laid off workers to meet the government's demands.

site_title: Mulan, once a sure money-spinner, becomes a problem for Disney
summary: Disney's live-action remake of Mulan has become a political hot potato due to its filming in China's Xinjiang province, where the government has detained up to one million ethnic Uighurs in camps. The film's credits thank local authorities for allowing the company to film there, sparking international criticism. The move has led to an online boycott and criticism from politicians, including Senator Tom Cotton, who accused Disney of being "addicted to Chinese cash." The film's release has been impacted by the coronavirus and online piracy, and its financial success remains uncertain.

site_title: Frozen property funds with US$16b aren't rushing to reopen
summary: The UK's largest property funds, holding almost US$15.6 billion of commercial real estate, have been given the all-clear to reopen after the coronavirus pandemic-induced freeze. However, managers including Aviva and Janus Henderson are choosing not to reopen immediately, citing concerns over potential redemptions and the risk of selling assets into a uncertain market. This decision may lead to forced sales, potentially lifting deal volumes in the UK real estate market, particularly for retail properties.

site_title: Second wave of floating storage triggered by ailing oil market
summary: A global economic recovery from the coronavirus pandemic is stalling, leading to a fresh build-up of global oil supplies and triggering a second wave of floating storage. Major oil producers, including Saudi Arabia and Russia, have cut back output, while refineries have slowed operations, resulting in a surplus of crude oil and refined fuels. As a result, traders have chartered tankers to store millions of barrels of oil, with Trafigura booking at least five of the largest tankers. Brent crude oil futures have declined to around $40 a barrel, with the spread between prompt and future deliveries near its lowest since May.

site_title: JPMorgan makes debut in green bond market with US$1b deal
summary: JPMorgan Chase, the largest US bank by assets, has made its debut in the green bond market with a $1 billion deal. The four-year bonds, which yield 0.65 percentage points above Treasuries, will fund environmentally-friendly projects such as green buildings and renewable energy. This move follows similar initiatives by other top Wall Street banks, including Citigroup and Bank of America. The deal is part of JPMorgan's sustainability commitments, which include exiting existing credit exposure to coal companies by 2024. The financial sector has raised a record $140.4 billion in green bonds this year.

site_title: Walmart tests drone delivery amid escalating battle with Amazon
summary: Walmart has begun testing drone delivery in Fayetteville, North Carolina, as part of its efforts to counter Amazon's dominance in e-commerce. The drones, from Flytrex Aviation, can carry packages up to 3kg for 10km. This move follows Walmart's launch of its Walmart+ membership service, which aims to compete with Amazon's Prime. The test marks the latest step in Walmart's expansion into drone delivery technology, which the company first mentioned in 2017.

site_title: German car parts maker Schaeffler cuts 4,400 jobs
summary: German car parts maker Schaeffler is cutting 4,400 jobs due to the impact of the coronavirus on the automotive sector. The company aims to save around $354.5 million annually by 2023 through downsizing capacity and factory closures. The restructuring will mainly affect 12 locations in Germany and two in Europe. CEO Klaus Rosenfeld described the move as "unavoidable" to improve long-term competitiveness. The move follows similar job cuts by Continental and comes amid a slow recovery for the car sector, with global vehicle production forecast to be 20% lower than in 2019.

site_title: Asean-China talks on South China Sea to start soon
summary: ASEAN and China are set to resume talks on a Code of Conduct for the South China Sea by November, amid rising tensions in the region. The talks aim to de-escalate the rivalry between the US and China, with the US seeking military restraint and China defending its maritime claims. Regional leaders, including Vietnam and Indonesia, are calling for international law and multilateral institutions to be upheld, while also seeking cooperation on global threats and the COVID-19 vaccine. The meetings will include representatives from Russia, Japan, Australia, South Korea, and India, and will focus on finding a balance between the US and China's influence in the region.

site_title: Ex-VW CEO to face charges of organised commercial fraud
summary: Former Volkswagen CEO Martin Winterkorn faces charges of conspiracy to commit organised commercial fraud with a high likelihood of conviction, related to the diesel emissions scandal. He and other executives allegedly allowed cars with illegal emissions-masking software to hit the road, leading to over $35 billion in costs. The court has expanded charges to include tax evasion and false advertising. Winterkorn's lawyer denies the charges, stating they are limited in scope and time. Volkswagen emphasizes that all accused are innocent until proven guilty, and the company has taken steps to improve compliance.

images.alt_text: Former Volkswagen chief executive Martin Winterkorn will face charges of conspiracy to commit organised commercial fraud with a high likelihood of conviction, a court probing the carmaker's diesel emissions scandal said on Wednesday.

site_title: Axington to allow shareholders to withdraw acceptances of its rights issue
summary: Axington, a CATALIST-listed company, will allow shareholders to withdraw acceptances of its rights issue if they wish, following the voluntary suspension of its shares since August 31. Shareholders who have applied, accepted, and/or paid for the rights shares or excess rights shares can withdraw their acceptances by providing written instructions to the Central Depository and/or the Share Registrar. The decision comes as Axington awaits an announcement related to strategic changes to the company's business direction.

site_title: Malaysia's 5G delay can let telcos build up mobile market: Report
summary: Malaysia's 5G rollout has been delayed to 2022, putting it behind regional peers Singapore and Thailand. However, the delay is seen as beneficial for telecom operators, allowing them to expand 4G and fibre networks and monetize existing 4G networks.
