Analysts from Fitch Solutions believe rural areas will benefit from increased investment in 4G services, creating opportunities for digital economy growth and smart city infrastructure. The delay is also expected to give 3G operators time to save for 5G capital expenditures.

site_title: LVMH drops US$16b Tiffany takeover, battle lines drawn
summary: French luxury goods giant LVMH is dropping its planned $16 billion takeover of US jeweler Tiffany, citing a request from the French foreign ministry to delay the acquisition due to potential additional US tariffs. Tiffany has filed a lawsuit against LVMH, accusing the company of deliberately stalling completion of the deal as agreed. The deal, which would have been the largest in the luxury industry, must be completed by November 24, but LVMH will not meet this deadline, setting the stage for an acrimonious dispute.

site_title: Utico extends deadline for Hyflux to accept its rescue offer
summary: Utico has extended the deadline for Hyflux to accept its proposed rescue package to October 15, up from the original August 30 deadline. The extension comes after shareholders requested Utico reconsider, citing the offer as the only viable restructuring plan for Hyflux. Hyflux had previously requested Utico revise its terms to achieve the best possible outcome for creditors.

site_title: Kimly's unit enters joint venture to run coffeeshops in Bukit Batok and Aljunied
summary: Kimly Makan Place, a subsidiary of CATALIST-listed coffeeshop consolidator Kimly, has entered two joint-venture agreements to operate and manage coffeeshops in Aljunied and Bukit Batok for approximately S$2.5 million. Kimly will hold 49% stake in each JV company, while partners Joo Seng Holdings and Hong Kah Holdings will hold 51%. The joint ventures align with Kimly's strategy to expand its network of food outlets and diversify revenue streams.

site_title: Singapore shares fall 0.3% on US tech rout and dashed vaccine hopes
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.22% to 2,499.33 on Wednesday, as the US tech sector plummeted 10% over three sessions, dashing hopes of a Covid-19 vaccine. The decline was exacerbated by news that AstraZeneca paused clinical trials after a participant fell ill. Trading volume was higher than Tuesday's, with the Nasdaq leading a broad risk reduction across assets, including oil and gold. Analysts believe tech stocks are in a technical correction, but the Brexit impact and potential effects on other asset classes remain uncertain.

site_title: Indonesia's capital to reimpose restrictions over coronavirus
summary: Indonesia's capital, Jakarta, will reinstate social restrictions due to a surge in coronavirus infections, threatening its health system. The city has recorded over 1,000 new cases daily and 43,400 infections and 1,330 deaths since the pandemic began. Restrictions, similar to those from April to June, will include limited public transport, dining bans, and working from home, starting Monday. The move aims to prevent hospitals from reaching full capacity, with experts predicting a death toll of 3,000 by October if stricter measures are not imposed.

site_title: Microsoft Xbox Series X will launch in November at US$500
summary: Microsoft has announced the release date and price for its next-generation Xbox Series X console, set to launch on November 10 at US$499.99. The device boasts 4K graphics and a solid-state drive for faster loading times. A lower-priced model, the Xbox Series S, priced at US$299.99, will also be available on the same date.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher after three-day selloff as tech stocks stabilise
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Wednesday, ending a three-day selloff, as technology stocks stabilized. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.77%, the S&P 500 gained 1.14%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 2.00%. Investors shrugged off news that AstraZeneca had paused global trials of its experimental coronavirus vaccine. The market's recovery was attributed to a stabilization in tech shares, despite uncertainty surrounding US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Darco Water Technologies files writ of summons, statement of claim against ex-director
summary: Darco Water Technologies has filed a writ of summons and statement of claim against former director Thye Kim Meng, alleging breach of duties in two projects resulting in US$1.6 million in losses and damages. The legal documents were attempted to be served on September 4 and 6, but were unsuccessful. Thye has also failed to respond to a letter of demand issued on August 12. Darco will continue efforts to effect service, seeking relief for the breach of duties.

site_title: SoftBank is said to get 1.3t yen in wireless stock orders
summary: SoftBank Group's domestic wireless unit is selling 1.3 trillion yen ($16.43 billion) of stock, with orders fully covered by domestic and international investors. The sale, to be finalized on September 14, may include an over-allotment of 100 million shares. This follows SoftBank's asset sales and its founder Masayoshi Son's efforts to raise cash, which he plans to use for further investments and share repurchases.

images.alt_text: SoftBank Group's bankers have received orders for all 1.3 trillion yen (S$16.43 billion) of the domestic wireless unit's stock they are selling and will probably place an over-allotment, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Deputy AG to lead review of case linked to Liew Mun Leong; AG recused
summary: Deputy Attorney-General Hri Kumar Nair will lead a review of the case linked to Liew Mun Leong, who was acquitted on charges of stealing from Changi Airport Group chairman and his family. Attorney-General Lucien Wong recused himself from the review due to past affiliations with Liew's company, CapitaLand. The Attorney-General's Chambers stated that Wong did not have a personal relationship with Liew and was not involved in prosecutorial decisions. Home Affairs and Law Minister K Shanmugam expressed concern over the judge's comments and vowed to deal with what went wrong in the process.

images.alt_text: The Attorney-General's Chambers said AG Lucien Wong had "for personal reasons" recused himself from the review of this case.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei down more than 1% at close
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index dropped 1.04% or 241.59 points to close at 23,032.54 on Wednesday, amid US high-tech shares slumping and fears of a coronavirus vaccine delay. The pause in a trial temporarily halted hopes of a vaccine, contributing to the decline. The broader Topix index fell 0.96% or 15.49 points to 1,605.40.

site_title: US money manager VanEck eyes China mutual fund licence
summary: US-based money manager VanEck is seeking a mutual fund license in China, allowing it to tap the country's $2.6 trillion retail fund market, which Beijing opened up to foreigners in April. The company also plans to launch Qualified Domestic Limited Partnership (QDLP) products to facilitate mainland Chinese investments offshore. This move comes as China's mutual fund sector is expanding rapidly, with VanEck looking to capitalize on the opportunity.

site_title: Norwegian lawmaker nominates Trump for Nobel Peace Prize
summary: A Norwegian lawmaker, Christian Tybring-Gjedde, nominated US President Donald Trump for the 2021 Nobel Peace Prize for his role in brokering a deal between Israel and the United Arab Emirates. This is the second time Trump has been nominated for the award, following a nomination in 2019 for his diplomatic efforts with North Korea. The Norwegian Nobel Committee declined to comment on the nomination, which closed on January 31 and will be announced on October 9.

site_title: S&P Global affirms 'BBB' rating for Frasers Centrepoint Trust; takes it off CreditWatch
summary: S&P Global has affirmed its "BBB" long-term issuer credit ratings on Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) and removed the ratings from CreditWatch, citing the trust's proposed acquisition of the remainder of Asia Retail Fund (ARF). The agency expects the trust's portfolio quality to improve significantly, offsetting higher leverage. However, it notes increased headwinds over the next six to 12 months due to the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on Singapore's economy and consumer spending. The trust's units closed at S$2.67, down 1.48% on Wednesday.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: MAS to increase supervisory engagement with banks to ensure a smooth transition to Sora by end-2021. UOB's private equity unit issues a disclosure statement on its impact investing framework. AGV executive director Albert Ang is under arrest and bail, but not formally charged. Singapore shares fell 0.3% on a US tech rout and dashed vaccine hopes. Vietnam was surprised by a US tariff announcement, while the Asian garment industry braces for higher US tariffs. China's GDP growth is set to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Thai protesters plan big march on PM's office next week
summary: Thai anti-government activists plan an overnight protest on September 19, followed by a march of up to 100,000 people to Government House, the seat of government. This marks the first time the pro-democracy movement has moved beyond speeches and stages. The protest aims to pressure the military-backed administration to step down. The event will be held on university campuses and is led by Panusaya Sithijirawattankul, a leader of the United Front of Thammasat and Demonstration. The protest is part of the growing pro-democracy movement in Thailand.

site_title: Britain's Lloyds Banking Group cuts 865 jobs
summary: Britain's Lloyds Banking Group is making 865 redundancies as part of cost-cutting measures amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The job losses, affecting 860 staff, come alongside the creation of 226 new roles. The cuts primarily reflect simplifying non-customer facing parts of the business, with impacted colleagues set to leave the group until November at the earliest. Union Unite criticized the move, citing challenging times for staff.

site_title: UK property valuers to ease warning, posing test for funds
summary: The UK's Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) has reached a consensus with property valuers to ease warnings about valuation uncertainty, allowing frozen UK property funds to reopen for withdrawals. The move affects nearly £12 billion of assets, with most commercial properties, including shopping malls and stores, now eligible for valuation. The decision is expected to prompt investors to withdraw their funds, potentially forcing fund managers to sell properties into a uncertain market. The change is seen as a test for funds and investors.

site_title: Virgin Australia to cull a third of its Boeing 737 fleet under Bain ownership
summary: Virgin Australia Holdings plans to return a third of its Boeing 737 fleet to lessors under new owner Bain Capital's turnaround plan. The airline has renegotiated financing terms for 56 of the 85 737s, with the remaining 29 to exit its fleet. As part of the plan, Virgin aims to cut a third of its workforce and focus on domestic and short-haul international flights, competing with Qantas Airways. The airline's CEO, Paul Scurrah, expects to lose domestic share to Qantas as it exits unprofitable routes, with Qantas potentially gaining a 70% market share in the domestic market.

site_title: Sri Lanka to take legal action against tanker's owner after fire
summary: Sri Lanka plans to take legal action against the owner of the oil supertanker New Diamond, which caught fire last Thursday, due to a large leakage of bunker oil. The country will decide on claiming criminal or civil liability under laws protecting the marine ecosystem. The vessel is owned by Greece-based Porto Emporios Shipping, and the manager is New Shipping. No immediate comment has been received from the companies involved.

site_title: Australia July home loans jump sharply as mobility restrictions eased
summary: Australia's owner-occupied home loan commitments surged 10.7% in July, the largest increase in a year, as social distancing restrictions eased. Investor housing loans rose 3.5% in the same period. The easing of restrictions, which began in May, led to a revival in housing inspections and sales. However, a second wave in Victoria's lockdown in August may impact the trend.

site_title: Nine strata units at Pantech Business Hub up for sale with S$11.6m guide price
summary: Nine ground-floor strata units at Pantech Business Hub in Singapore are up for sale via expression of interest with a guide price of S$11.6 million. Located in an industrial development with 63 years remaining on its leasehold tenure, the units are priced at S$650 per square foot. The sale is exclusive to marketing agent CBRE, and the property can be sold individually or collectively.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 22.6 points lower to 1,496.72 on Wednesday, with a trading volume of 7.696 billion lots worth RM4.890 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 846 to 314.

site_title: Europe: Shares inch higher; AstraZeneca tumbles on halting vaccine trials
summary: European shares edged 0.1% higher, despite AstraZeneca halting global Covid-19 vaccine trials due to an unexplained illness in a study participant. The company's shares fell 1.3%. Travel and leisure stocks declined, while mining and healthcare stocks rose. The Stoxx 600 index recovered from previous day's declines.

site_title: World's top 10 airline stocks are all Chinese, except one
summary: Chinese airline stocks dominate the world's top 10, with nine carriers posting double-digit gains over the past three months. The exception is InterGlobe Aviation's IndiGo, which operates in India. Despite the global airline industry's slow recovery, Chinese carriers have bounced back due to a large domestic market and eased travel restrictions. Analysts forecast the big three Chinese carriers will remain unprofitable in the second half of the year, but traffic is expected to increase with the National Day holiday and potentially 15% higher in 2021 compared to 2019.

site_title: Huawei to share progress of Google Android OS rival amid US tensions
summary: Huawei is set to share its progress on developing HarmonyOS, a proprietary operating system seen as its best bet to replace Google's Android OS, amid US technology restrictions. The company's head of consumer business, Richard Yu, will deliver a keynote speech at its annual developers conference, marking its first official response to the Trump administration's efforts to bar its access to chips. Huawei will focus on HarmonyOS's application in wearables and smart screens, rather than smartphones, and may not present it as a genuine Google alternative ahead of the US election in November.

site_title: Russia's RDIF to sell 32m Covid-19 vaccine doses to Mexico firm: source
summary: Russia's sovereign wealth fund, RDIF, will sell 32 million doses of its potential Covid-19 vaccine "Sputnik-V" to a Mexican pharmaceutical company, marking the country's second vaccine export deal. This follows a deal with Kazakhstan, where more than two million doses are initially planned, with the option to increase to five million doses. The vaccine, developed by Moscow's Gamaleya Institute, has been in late-stage trials involving 40,000 participants since August 26.

site_title: COE prices continue to climb with smaller quota, longer bidding period
summary: COE prices in Singapore have continued to rise, with premiums for cars above 1,600cc and 130bhp reaching S$41,510, up from S$38,802. The open COE premium also increased to S$40,790, marking the third consecutive round of increases and the first time since November 2019 that premiums have surpassed S$40,000. Meanwhile, the commercial vehicle COE price rose to S$26,644, its highest since August 2019, despite a smaller quota for the August-October period.

site_title: Former NTU staff who visited 3 places in university campus tested positive for Covid-19
summary: NTU in Singapore confirmed a former employee tested positive for Covid-19 while on campus, visiting three locations: Quad Cafe, Paik's Bibim, and the North Spine Food Court. The employee, who had not shown symptoms, was swabbed at a foreign airport and informed NTU of his infection on Sept 4. The university has worked with MOH to issue quarantine orders to close contacts and carried out deep-cleaning at the affected areas. MOH also announced 75 new cases, including 60 in dormitories and 14 imported cases.

site_title: Sias asks Accordia Golf Trust manager to address concerns over planned divestment
summary: The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) has expressed concerns over Accordia Golf Trust's planned divestment of its golf courses to its sponsor Accordia Golf. Shareholders are worried about the valuation of the golf courses, which have decreased by 5.4 billion yen (S$70.8 million) since December 2019 due to the pandemic. Sias has asked the independent committee to consider delaying the transaction or including an earn-out based on future profits. Additionally, Sias questions the inclusion of a lengthy claim period and whether Daiwa Group, a significant shareholder, should abstain from voting in the upcoming extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end sharply lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted, with the Hang Seng Index falling 0.63% to 24,468.93, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 1.86% to 3,254.63. Global markets reversed following another Wall Street rout. The Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 3.22%. The losses come as investors reacted to global market uncertainty and US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Lipsticks out, lotions in: beauty industry set for facelift and comeback, says DBS
summary: The global beauty industry is expected to experience a facelift and comeback, driven by shifting consumer preferences and the post-COVID-19 work-from-home trend. With employees no longer commuting to the workplace frequently, cosmetics are seen as less important, while skincare and personal care products are gaining popularity. DBS Chief Investment Office predicts a surge in online beauty shoppers and skincare-mask fanatics, with demand for beauty products expected to rebound once a COVID-19 vaccine is discovered. The industry is also poised for a digital transformation, with e-commerce becoming a major channel for sales.

site_title: ECB keeps up pressure on banks to deliver on Brexit preparation
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has urged banks to accelerate preparations for Brexit, stating that some lenders still need to strengthen their European Union operations before the transition phase ends at the end of the year. The ECB wants banks to move staff and assets to their EU units, achieve structural profitability, and be operationally self-standing. While some banks have made significant progress, others need to step up their efforts to retain clients in the EU after the UK's departure. The ECB aims to ensure the new operations can withstand turmoil and manage local risk.

site_title: Raffles Education jumps nearly 20% after tycoon ups stake
summary: Raffles Education Corp's shares surged 19.3% after tycoon Oei Hong Leong increased his stake to 13.05% by buying 2 million shares for S$284,594. Oei has been trying to oust founder Chew Hua Seng as CEO and chairman, calling for an extraordinary general meeting. The rally comes after a 31.6% gain on Tuesday, prompting a trading halt, and follows another notice of requisition from Oei and Shantanu Prakash calling for a special auditor to review the company's joint venture with Educomp Solutions.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon down 0.5% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Wednesday afternoon down 0.5% as the Straits Times Index (STI) fell to 2,492.35, with decliners outnumbering advancers 226 to 129. Banking stocks, such as DBS, UOB, and OCBC, also declined. The decline in Singapore shares follows a similar sell-off in Asian and US markets, with the MSCI's broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan falling 1.1%. Investors are cautious amid concerns over the tech sector and Brexit headlines, with few eager to buy the dip.

site_title: Microsoft launches programme for more inclusive employment in Asia-Pacific
summary: Microsoft has launched the Microsoft Enabler Programme in the Asia-Pacific, aiming to increase employability for people with disabilities (PwDs) by partnering with six non-profit organizations and 14 employers. The programme will provide training and job opportunities in cloud and AI for PwDs, and conduct workshops on inclusive design and assistive technologies. The initiative is expected to contribute to a rise in gross domestic product in the region, with Microsoft citing a UN ESCAP report estimating a 1-7% increase.

site_title: Condo, HDB rental volumes tumble in August; rents hold: SRX
summary: Rental volumes for HDB flats and private condominiums in Singapore dropped in August, with 20.4% and 16.7% declines respectively, according to SRX Property. Rents remained steady for private apartments but fell 1% for private apartments and 0.1% for HDB flats year-over-year. Experts attribute the decline to an economic slowdown, rising unemployment, and job support schemes that may deter foreign employment.

site_title: Gold dips on stronger dollar ahead of ECB meeting
summary: Gold prices slipped 0.3% to $1,925.20 per ounce, as the US dollar rose to multi-week highs ahead of the European Central Bank meeting. The dollar's strength made gold more expensive for holders of other currencies, while a sell-off in technology shares provided some respite. Investors are awaiting the ECB's inflation forecasts and the Bank of Canada's policy meeting.

site_title: Funding Societies hires GoBear co-founder, expands C-suite
summary: Funding Societies, a digital financing platform for small and medium enterprises in South-east Asia, has appointed a chief financial officer, chief technology officer, and chief product officer to help drive growth and recovery post-COVID-19. The Singapore-based fintech startup recently raised US$40 million in Series C funding and is preparing for larger funding rounds. The changes in senior management aim to lay the foundation for "outsized recovery" once the macroeconomic situation improves. Funding Societies continues to grow cautiously in 2020 with improved financial performance.

site_title: Australia: Shares close over 2% lower as coronavirus cases surge in hotspot
summary: Australian shares fell 2.2% to 5,878.6, their lowest in over two months, amid a tech-led rout on Wall Street and a surge in coronavirus cases in Victoria, Australia's hotspot. The state reported its biggest daily rise in cases in three days, boosting contact tracing efforts. Local tech stocks fell 2.4%, while energy stocks dropped 4.7% due to steep oil price losses. AstraZeneca's pause in a COVID-19 vaccine trial also weighed on sentiment, but the Australian deputy chief medical officer downplayed concerns.

site_title: Penrose condo early-bird prices start from S$788,000 at preview this weekend
summary: The Penrose condominium, a 99-year leasehold development in District 14, Singapore, will begin previews by appointment from September 12. Early-bird prices start from S$788,000 for one-bedroom units, increasing to S$2.11 million for four-bedroom units. The development features 566 units, a childcare centre, swimming pool, and rooftop sky garden, and is a 15-minute drive from the central business district. Temporary occupation permit is expected in July 2024, with nearby amenities and growth areas including Kampong Bugis and the Kallang River precinct.

site_title: CapitaLand's Rochester Commons in one-north slated for completion in Q4 2021
summary: CapitaLand announced the completion of Rochester Commons in one-north, Singapore, slated for Q4 2021. The development features a Grade A office tower, a hotel, 12 heritage bungalows, and Catapult, an executive learning centre. The office tower offers 17 storeys with over 200,000 sq ft of traditional office spaces. The project combines workspaces, amenities, and social spaces, catering to corporates and executives.

site_title: Airbus tops Boeing on deliveries, avoids order cancellations
summary: Airbus delivered 39 jets in August, surpassing Boeing's 13-plane delivery, while avoiding order cancellations. The European company's deliveries have held up better during the pandemic, with airlines such as EasyJet and Qatar Airways deferring rather than canceling orders. Airbus has generally managed to persuade airlines to delay deliveries, but analysts warn that this strategy risks leaving gaps in production lines. The company reported only one new order, a corporate version of the A320.

images.alt_text: Airbus delivered 39 jets last month while avoiding order cancellations as it battles to keep revenue flowing in a market battered by the coronavirus crisis.

site_title: Asian summits underway amid US-China friction
summary: Southeast Asian foreign ministers are attending a series of regional summits to seek collaboration on global threats and de-escalate tensions between the US and China. The summits, hosted by Vietnam, bring together 27 nations, including Russia, Japan, and India, amid concerns about rhetoric and accidental conflict. The US and China have been engaged in a tit-for-tat rivalry, with the US accusing China of bullying its neighbors and China describing its actions as lawful. ASEAN aims to promote military restraint and de-focus on the rivalry, while also discussing code of maritime conduct and COVID-19 vaccine development.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall 1% on Wall Street tech selloff
summary: South Korean shares fell 1% on Wednesday, following a tech-led plunge on Wall Street overnight. The Kospi benchmark closed at 2,375.81, snapping a two-day winning streak. The decline was attributed to increased volatility ahead of the expiry of Kospi futures and options contracts. This came after a tech-and-stimulus-led rally on Wall Street, which saw the Nasdaq fall 9.9% from its record closing high.

site_title: MAS to ramp up supervisory engagement with banks to ensure smooth transition to Sora by end-2021
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to step up supervisory engagement with banks to ensure a smooth transition from the Swap Offer Rate (SOR) to the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (Sora) by the end of 2021. MAS Deputy Managing Director Jacqueline Loh warned that banks that fail to keep pace with industry timelines may face additional risks. To encourage market participants to shift from SOR to Sora, MAS will expand its S$500 million SORA floating-rate notes issuance and provide guidance on specific deadlines to cease SOR usage in new financial products. A coordinated approach, including communication with customers, is key to a smooth transition.

site_title: Cloud data startup Snowflake looks to raise US$2.38b in US IPO
summary: Snowflake, a cloud data startup backed by Sequoia, plans to raise approximately US$2.38 billion in its initial public offering (IPO) in the US. The IPO, which will see the company list on the New York Stock Exchange under the ticker SNOW, comes after a 173.7% revenue jump to US$264.7 million for the fiscal year ended January. Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, and others are underwriting the offering. This marks another major public listing for a Silicon Valley startup, following other high-profile IPOs this year.

site_title: US firms in China increasingly fear soured ties will last for years: survey
summary: US companies in China are increasingly concerned that trade tensions will last for years, with half believing soured ties will last at least three years and 27% thinking they will last indefinitely. The survey found that 29% of firms plan to decrease investment in China this year, down from 47% in 2019, and only 29% plan to increase investment. Despite this, over 90% of respondents said they are committed to remaining in China. US President Donald Trump's proposal of separating the US and Chinese economies has further intensified tensions.

site_title: Junk bonds boom as coronavirus lures investors to risk
summary: Investors are seeking higher yields due to the coronavirus pandemic, leading to a surge in demand for "junk" or non-investment grade bonds. By mid-August, US$274 billion in junk bonds had been issued, exceeding the total for 2019. Central banks are supporting companies by buying their bonds, and investors are becoming more willing to take on risk. This has raised concerns about "zombie" companies that may default on their loans, with a speculative-grade corporate default rate expected to more than triple to 8.5% by mid-2021.

site_title: AG Lucien Wong has recused himself from review of ex-maid Parti Liyani's case
summary: Deputy Attorney-General Hri Kumar Nair will lead the review of the case of former maid Parti Liyani, who was acquitted of stealing from Changi Airport Group chairman Liew Mun Leong and his family. AG Lucien Wong had recused himself from the review due to personal reasons, citing his past connection to Liew as president and CEO of CapitaLand. The Attorney-General's Chambers stated that Wong and Liew did not have a personal relationship and that Wong was not involved in prosecutorial decisions. The government will assess what further action is needed in light of Justice Chan Seng Onn's comments.

site_title: UOB's PE unit issues disclosure statement on impact investing framework
summary: UOB Venture Management, the private equity arm of United Overseas Bank, has issued a disclosure statement on the Operating Principles for Impact Management, becoming the first signatory in South-east Asia to do so. The statement outlines how UOBVM upholds the nine principles of impact investing, which aim to promote transparency, credibility, and discipline in the market. The statement follows the launch of UOBVM's Asia Impact Investment Fund, which focuses on investments in education, healthcare, and agriculture in South-east Asia and China, with a target fund size of US$100 million.

site_title: Cash squeeze looms for Malaysia's frenzied amateur stock traders
summary: Malaysia's amateur stock traders are facing a cash squeeze as a six-month moratorium on loan repayments set to expire at the end of September threatens to leave many struggling to continue investing. The moratorium, part of the government's stimulus package, allowed individuals to put extra funds into shares during the lockdown. However, with trading volumes surging to a record in August, many are now looking to drop out of the market, potentially disrupting the benchmark equity index's rebound from March lows.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks plunge after fresh Wall Street sell-off
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.34% to 24.295.42, following another Wall Street sell-off that hit tech firms. The Shanghai Composite Index dropped 1.07% to 3,281.00, while the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 1.33% to 2,218.40. The decline is attributed to the tech sector's weakness on Wall Street, with investors expressing caution despite some regional markets showing resilience.

site_title: Tan Chong sells stake in associate company for 249.7b rupiah
summary: Tan Chong International sold its 44.5% stake in associate company Tifa Finance for 249.7 billion rupiah (S$23.2 million) to the Korea Development Bank (KDB). The sale was part of an agreement to dispose of 80.7% of Tifa's equity for 452.8 billion rupiah. Tan Chong recorded a gain of 78.2 billion rupiah from the disposal. The deal is considered fairly valued and in the interests of the company and its shareholders.

site_title: Japan's Suga says strong economy necessary to pursue fiscal reform
summary: Japan's Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga emphasized the need for strong economic growth to pursue fiscal reform. In a debate, Suga stated that a strong economy is crucial for social welfare, national security, and fiscal reform. He also plans to focus on revitalizing regional economies, a key aspect of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's "Abenomics" stimulus policies. Suga's comments come as Japan's economy continues to grow, and he is a frontrunner to become the next prime minister.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower following rout in US
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on September 9, 2020, due to sharp US stock falls amid renewed Brexit tension and a lacklustre economic outlook. The Nikkei 225 index fell 1.22% and the Topix index fell 1.28%.

site_title: Samsung, LG Display to stop supplying panels to Huawei due to US restrictions: Chosun
summary: Samsung Electronics' display unit and LG Display are expected to stop supplying panels for premium smartphones to Huawei Technologies due to US restrictions, effective September 15. The US move, which tightened restrictions on Huawei in August, bans suppliers from selling chips made using US technology without a special license. The restrictions include chips needed to operate displays, and both companies have limited panel shipments to Huawei. LG Display stated the impact will be minimal, while Samsung Display declined to comment. The decision will likely affect Huawei's premium smartphone production.

images.alt_text: Samsung Electronics' display unit and LG Display are expected to stop supplying panels for premium smartphones to Huawei Technologies due to US restrictions, South Korean online media Chosun Biz reported on Wednesday.

site_title: Hot stocks: Sembcorp shares rise on ex-entitlements basis; SMM sinks 13.5%
summary: Sembcorp Industries (SCI) shares rose 21.6% to S$1.17, making it the second most heavily traded stock on the Singapore bourse, following a demerger from Sembcorp Marine (SMM). The conglomerate's shares climbed after excluding entitlements, while SMM's shares fell 13.5% to S$0.176. Analysts say SCI is now more attractive without SMM's weight, and the stock is expected to gain more over the next 12 months.

images.alt_text: Investors piled into shares of Sembcorp Industries (SCI) on the counter's first day of trading excluding entitlements, while its marine arm's stock tumbled.

site_title: Three conservation shophouses along Craig Road for sale with S$36m guide price
summary: Three conservation shophouses on Craig Road in Singapore's Duxton Hill/Keong Saik F&B enclave are up for sale by expression of interest with a guide price of S$36 million, or approximately S$2,936 per square foot. The adjoining shophouses, totaling 12,260 sq ft, boast a 55-meter-wide dual road frontage and are leased to F&B operators and multinational corporations. The property has a "distinctive" facade and "rich" architectural heritage, and owners can explore changing the use of the space or acquiring a flagship property in the central business district.

site_title: Blockchain players beat gold, Bitcoin in pandemic
summary: Blockchain companies have outperformed gold and Bitcoin, returning 54% over the past year, despite the recent global tech stock rout. Elwood Asset Management's Blockchain Global Equity Index, which tracks 45 companies in the blockchain ecosystem, has seen its top performers return over 54% and some up to ninefold. Companies like Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, Kakao, and Monex Group have benefited from the pandemic-driven demand for technology and cryptocurrency, highlighting the potential of the blockchain revolution.

site_title: CMLV garment industry expected to be a coronavirus casualty
summary: The global Covid-19 outbreak has put the regional textile industry, particularly in Cambodia, under threat. According to Oxford Economics, lockdowns have severely impacted manufacturing and exports in Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, and Vietnam (CLMV), with the textile industry bearing the brunt. Cambodia is expected to bear the brunt, with 66% of its exports coming from the clothing industry. The industry's growth is expected to be muted due to weak global demand for apparel and the partial withdrawal from the 'Everything But Arms' scheme with the EU, which will stymie Cambodia's post-pandemic export recovery.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 20.35 points, or 1.34%, to 1,498.97. Volume was 388.07 million lots worth RM97.01 million. Losers beat gainers 387 to 65.

site_title: Indonesian minister says economic policies must align better to tackle crisis
summary: Indonesian Coordinating Minister of Economic Affairs Airlangga Hartarto emphasized the need for synchronized monetary and fiscal policies to tackle the economic crisis caused by the pandemic. The government aims to strengthen financial reforms, but does not support a proposal for a monetary board to oversee the central bank, Bank Indonesia. Hartarto stressed the importance of maintaining BI's independence while aligning policies to stimulate growth and reduce poverty. Indonesia's economy is forecast to contract this year, but is expected to rebound in 2021 if COVID-19 vaccines are rolled out.

site_title: Japan's households, firms keep hoarding cash at record pace as Covid-19 strains broaden
summary: Japan's households and firms are hoarding cash at a record pace, with currency in circulation and bank deposits rising 7.1% in August from a year earlier. This surge in cash reserves is a sign of caution amid the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, which has led to a decline in economic activity. The Bank of Japan's M3 money stock has not seen such a significant increase since 2004. The hoarding of cash is expected to hinder economic growth as companies and households are reluctant to spend, despite the economy's gradual reopening.

site_title: US options investors pull back on tech bets, but SoftBank's trade looms large
summary: US investors are pulling back on tech bets amid a sell-off in the tech-heavy Nasdaq, which has dropped 10% from its highs. Skew, a measure of demand for protective put options, has risen sharply for companies like Amazon, Salesforce, and Facebook. However, institutional investors, including SoftBank, remain committed to buying tech-related call options, which may exacerbate volatility in the coming months. SoftBank's $4 billion profit from its options purchases is expected to remain open, potentially inducing turbulence in later months.

site_title: Rex inks options agreements to fund Norway exploration
summary: Rex International, an oilfield services firm, has signed options agreements to partially fund Lime Petroleum's participation in Norway's exploration drilling of two wells. Trace Atlantic Oil has options to receive shares of Lime's potential dividends if the wells are successful. Option fees totaling $1.1 million will be used to fund part of Lime's participation. The agreements allow Rex to reduce its financial exposure and will not dilute its 90% stake in Lime.

site_title: Asia: Markets tumble as Wall Street tech rout spreads
summary: Asian markets plummeted as Wall Street's tech rout spread, with investors fleeing technology and energy firms amid concerns over lofty valuations and vaccine and Brexit trade deal fears. The US Nasdaq's record highs were halted, and analysts say the selling is broadening. The perfect storm of factors has led to a perfect storm of market volatility, with Asian investors taking a hit as they return from the weekend.

site_title: CAD finds 'reasonable grounds' that AGV exec director committed offence
summary: The Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) has found "reasonable grounds" that AGV Group's executive director Albert Ang committed an offence under the Securities and Futures Act (SFA) related to false trading and market-rigging transactions between July 2017 and March 2018. Ang was called for an interview with the CAD but has not been formally charged. The investigation has not affected AGV's business operations, and the company remains unaffected despite uncertainty created by the investigation.

site_title: Liquidation business booms in South Korea as wave of small retailers close due to virus
summary: South Korea's liquidation business has seen a surge in demand as small retailers close due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Liquidation specialist You Young Sik is busier than ever, collecting furniture and equipment from shuttered businesses to sell to recycled kitchenware stores. The country's self-employed population, about 25% of the job market, makes it vulnerable to downturns, with data showing only 38% of businesses survive three years. Social distancing restrictions have further exacerbated the issue, with new start-ups struggling to operate and profit margins thinning.

site_title: Broker's take: CGS-CIMB initiates coverage on Hi-P with 'hold', S$1.23 target price
summary: CGS-CIMB has initiated coverage on contract manufacturer Hi-P International with a "hold" recommendation and a target price of S$1.23. The company has a net cash balance sheet and is exploring inorganic growth opportunities to reduce customer concentration risk. Hi-P's management has guided that one major customer accounts for slightly less than 50% of its revenue, while another three companies account for 7-8%. The brokerage derived the target price based on its estimate of a 1.52 times price-to-book value for FY2020.

site_title: Europe: Equities sapped by Brexit fears, energy and tech stocks slide
summary: European shares fell on Tuesday due to Brexit fears, with energy and tech stocks among the biggest decliners. The Stoxx 600 slid 1.2%, with declines in Total and SAP dragging down the index. Analysts warn that a trade agreement may not be reached, citing the "prisoner's dilemma" scenario. The European Central Bank's policy meeting on Thursday may act as a catalyst for further market movements.

site_title: China's August PPI -2.0% y-o-y, CPI up 2.4% y-o-y
summary: China's factory gate prices fell 2.0% in August, the seventh straight month of decline, but at the slowest rate since March. The producer price index (PPI) dropped 2.4% year-over-year in July. Meanwhile, the consumer price index (CPI) rose 2.4% year-over-year in August, in line with expectations. The data suggests China's industries continue to recover from the COVID-19 outbreak, but the country's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: South Asian migrant workers seek justice as wage theft worsens under coronavirus
summary: South Asian migrant workers are struggling with wage theft and job losses amid the COVID-19 pandemic, with many left without payment or end-of-service benefits. According to a Business and Human Rights Resource Centre report, wage theft cases in Gulf countries rose three-fold between April and July 2020. Lawyers and unions are calling for an overhaul of the system to cope with the challenges of large-scale migrant returns. Many workers, like Bhoomaiah Motapalkula, have lost significant amounts, with estimates suggesting up to 1 million South Asian migrant workers have returned home since April.

site_title: China signals lenient launch for national carbon trading
summary: China is set to launch the world's largest national carbon market, offering a more lenient approach to controlling emissions compared to its existing regional systems. A proposal for the rules governing the national programme is being circulated for feedback, with some of the most concrete examples yet on how the trading scheme would work. The plan has not been finalized, and details may change, but it suggests a more fossil-fuel friendly approach.

site_title: Super rich get richer on Ant after striking early deals with Jack Ma
summary: Hong Kong's Li Ka-shing, Thailand's Chearavanonts, and several other wealthy families have invested in Ant Group, a Chinese online payments provider, ahead of its potential $225 billion valuation. They have collectively invested over $700 million, with potential returns of up to 50%. The investment is part of Ant's $30 billion IPO in Hong Kong and Shanghai, which could boost the returns of US private equity firms and make Jack Ma, Ant's founder, one of the world's 10 richest people.

site_title: Microsoft says small Xbox S game console on the way
summary: Microsoft confirms the launch of the Xbox Series S game console on November 10, priced at US$299. The console is designed for online game services and software, and its release follows a new-generation Xbox Series X, also set for November with an unspecified price. This move aims to compete with Sony's PlayStation 5 and counter the threat of cloud gaming, with Microsoft's cloud video game service debuting this month for Xbox Game Pass Ultimate subscribers. The new consoles are expected to launch during the holiday season next year.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, Keppel, Sembcorp, CapitaLand Mall Trust, UG Healthcare
summary: Several Singaporean companies have seen notable developments on Wednesday, including UOB, Keppel Corp, Sembcorp Industries, CapitaLand Mall Trust, and UG Healthcare. UOB plans to issue US$600 million in subordinated notes, while Keppel Corp will issue eight billion yen worth of five-year notes. Sembcorp Industries' shares are expected to fall, but may be more attractive without the weight of Sembcorp Marine's shares. CapitaLand Mall Trust has obtained a S$200 million sustainability-linked loan, and UG Healthcare has started work on a new manufacturing facility in Malaysia.

site_title: Britain plans hiring spree to harness big data in pandemic recovery
summary: Britain plans to hire 500 data scientists by 2021 as part of a new strategy to drive economic recovery after the pandemic through smarter use of data and technology. The National Data Strategy aims to put data at the heart of policy-making, with the goal of boosting growth across the economy. The move follows criticism of the government's handling of data during the pandemic, including difficulties in sharing infection details with local authorities. The strategy also includes new fellowships to work inside the prime minister's office and sharing information with the private sector.

site_title: New Zealand's ruling party plans higher tax for top income earners
summary: New Zealand's ruling Labour Party plans to implement a new 39% tax rate for individuals earning over NZ$180,000, affecting approximately 2% of the population. The tax increase is expected to cost NZ$23 a week for an individual earning NZ$200,000. The party promises no further tax hikes if it is re-elected in the upcoming election on October 17.

site_title: US: Stocks end sharply lower, Dow -2.3%, Nasdaq -4.1%
summary: US stocks ended sharply lower on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 2.3% and the Nasdaq Composite Index plummeting 4.1%. The selling was broad, affecting energy and financial companies, and was attributed to concerns over a weak economic recovery and mounting US-China tensions. Analysts also cited profit taking following earlier gains, while economic data showed a jobs report that generally topped expectations.

site_title: Thai airport staff sue over pay dispute as virus hammers travel sector
summary: Thai airport workers are suing a security company hired by state-owned Airports of Thailand (AOT) over a pay dispute, alleging they were pressured into accepting worse terms and conditions. Ten security staff at Bangkok's Suvarnabhumi Airport claim they were coerced into resigning from ASM Management and signing new contracts with AOT Aviation Security (AOT AVSEC) in May, resulting in lower pay and lost benefits. The lawsuit, filed in July, seeks compensation for wrongful dismissal and unpaid severance pay. Labour rights campaigners warn of a growing trend of labour rights violations among outsourced companies at airports.

site_title: Apple seeks damages from Fortnite maker in App Store dispute
summary: Apple is seeking damages from Epic Games, the maker of Fortnite, over a dispute regarding the App Store's 30% commission fee. In a court filing, Apple claims Epic breached contract and that the game developer is not entitled to claim Apple abuses its dominance. Apple is seeking unspecified "compensatory and punitive damages" for the breach. Epic previously sued Apple, claiming the company's commission fees are unfair and stifle competition. The case is ongoing in a US federal court in California.

site_title: Oil prices stumble, hit June lows on Saudi price cut, Covid-19 flare-ups
summary: Oil prices plummeted on Tuesday, with Brent crude falling below US$40 a barrel and US crude dropping nearly 8% after Saudi Arabia cut its October selling prices amid rising Covid-19 cases worldwide. The rebound in illnesses weakens the global economic recovery and fuel demand. US West Texas Intermediate crude settled at US$36.76, its lowest since June 15. Analysts attribute the selloff to speculative net long positions and a herd mentality. OPEC+ is set to review supply cuts on September 17.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit five-week low on Wall Street tech rout
summary: Australian shares fell 2.4% to 5,866.1, their lowest in five weeks, on Wednesday due to a US tech rout. The decline followed overnight losses in US blue-chip technology firms like Apple and Microsoft. Financials and energy stocks were the top drags, with Commonwealth Bank of Australia and Westpac Banking Corp shedding 3.3% each. AstraZeneca paused a COVID-19 vaccine trial after an unexplained illness, and CSL shares dropped 3.1%. The decline was mirrored in New Zealand, where the S&P/NZX 50 index fell 1.2%.

images.alt_text: Australian shares fell to their lowest in more than five weeks on Wednesday, with tech stocks getting hammered the most as investors took cues from declines in the US blue-chip technology sector that sent the Nasdaq into correction territory.

site_title: StanChart's global head of commodities business to leave as bank restructures unit
summary: Standard Chartered's global head of commodities business, Cengiz Belentepe, is leaving the bank as part of a restructuring effort. The move follows a series of commodity trader collapses, including Hin Leong, which has affected StanChart's trade finance divisions. Belentepe's departure will see the commodities business integrated with the bank's financial markets unit, with Roberto Hoornweg re-aligning the structure. The restructuring aims to cut risk and follows a trend among global banks reducing their commodities businesses.

site_title: Euro edges down ahead of Thursday's ECB meeting
summary: The euro edged down ahead of the European Central Bank's post-summer meeting, while the pound sank nearly 1% due to renewed Brexit warnings. US President Donald Trump warned of "decoupling" the US and Chinese economies, causing the yuan to dip. The euro briefly returned to US$1.18 but the pound fell to US$1.3050. Analysts expect no policy change from the ECB but are watching for its inflation forecasts and potential verbal intervention.

site_title: JPMorgan Chase probing fraud in US stimulus programmes
summary: JPMorgan Chase is investigating potential fraud in US government pandemic relief programmes, including the Paycheck Protection Programme. The bank has received complaints about customers misusing funds and employees engaging in unethical conduct. A memo to employees warned of "conduct that does not live up to our business and ethical principles" and urged confidential reporting of suspicious activity. The probe marks the latest controversy surrounding the Small Business Administration's PPP programme, which has helped support tens of millions of jobs.

site_title: A stable euro requires an ambitious industrial policy
summary: A European industrial policy is necessary for the survival of the euro, as the industrial share of the economy has declined in southern members since the introduction of the single currency. The EU's southern members, particularly Italy and Spain, need to embark on an industrial revival to increase productivity and competitiveness. The recently adopted Next Generation EU recovery package offers an opportunity to revive southern European industry and position it for a digital, sustainable future. EU leaders should establish clear goals for making European industry globally competitive and geographically balanced, focusing on key sectors such as health, energy, and digital technology.

site_title: Australian Sept consumer sentiment surges in 'pleasant surprise'
summary: Australian consumer sentiment surged 18% in September, a significant rebound from an 18% drop in August. The Westpac-Melbourne Institute index, which measures consumer sentiment, rose due to the containment of the coronavirus outbreak in Victoria and the prevention of a second wave in other states. Despite the gains, pessimists outnumbered optimists, with the index still down 4.5% from last year. The outlook for the economy over the next 12 months and five years also showed improvement.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at open after US rout; STI down 0.7%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (TSI) fell 0.7% to 2,487.77 as it opened weaker on Wednesday following sharp losses on Wall Street overnight. The US Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 2.3%, the S&P 500 shed 2.8%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index slumped 4.1%. The decline in US stocks was attributed to large tech shares suffering another beating, as well as renewed Brexit tension and a lacklustre economic outlook.

site_title: Shipping guide that's just in time
summary: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) has released a new guide, the Just In Time Arrival Guide, to facilitate low-carbon shipping by optimizing ship speed and reducing waiting time at anchorage. The guide aims to increase port efficiency and environmental impact through reduced greenhouse gas emissions. It provides a holistic approach to JIT arrivals, considering contractual and operational aspects, and is intended to be a useful toolkit for various stakeholders in the shipping industry. The guide is expected to help reduce congestion in ports and minimize the risk of collisions, particularly in foggy conditions.

site_title: AstraZeneca puts Covid-19 vaccine trial on hold over safety concern: report
summary: AstraZeneca has paused its late-stage trial of its Covid-19 vaccine candidate after a suspected serious adverse reaction in a study participant. The trial, conducted in the US and UK, is testing a vaccine developed by AstraZeneca and University of Oxford researchers. The participant is expected to recover, but the pause is having an impact on other trials. Nine leading vaccine developers, including AstraZeneca, have pledged to uphold scientific safety and efficacy standards despite the pandemic's urgency.

site_title: Laying the foundations for Asia's digital workforce
summary: Singapore's government is working to develop a digital-ready workforce through collaborations with public and private sectors. The country has implemented programs such as SkillsFuture Singapore, which provides training and upskilling opportunities for individuals, and Skills Frameworks for 34 industry sectors. Singapore aims to be a leader in the digital economy and has partnered with other countries, including the Philippines, India, and South Korea, to advance regional collaboration and share best practices. The government emphasizes the need for a mindset shift towards embracing change and lifelong learning, and encourages individuals to take charge of their learning journey.

site_title: Alcohol-free karaoke outlets among proposals to help nightlife players reopen
summary: The Singapore government is reviewing proposals from the nightlife business association to support the reopening of the industry, which has been closed since March due to the coronavirus pandemic. Suggestions include allowing family-themed karaoke joints with safe management measures, quicker approvals for temporary business licensing changes, and extending drinking hours. The government aims to provide assistance to help businesses adjust and take advantage of the economy's recovery.

site_title: No pandemic pause in Ikea's US shopping mall plans
summary: IKEA's US shopping mall plans remain on track, with the company aiming to open its first mall in San Francisco within a year. Ingka Centres, a major mall owner, initially focused on locations in New York, Los Angeles, San Francisco, and Chicago. Despite the coronavirus crisis affecting many retailers, IKEA is pushing forward with its expansion plans, marking a positive move for the company.

site_title: Employment outlook for Q4 worsens among firms in Singapore
summary: Singapore's employment outlook for Q4 worsened among firms, with the employment indicator declining to -13.19 percentage points, the most negative for 2020. Weakened sentiment is attributed to a tepid global economic outlook and firms turning to hiring digitally-savvy talent and investing in technology to keep costs low. The financial and manufacturing sectors showed significant declines, while the wholesale sector remained positive. Overall business sentiment remains contractionary, with no clear prospects of recovery in sight within the short term.

site_title: 'We've to... deal with what went wrong', Shanmugam weighs in on case involving Liew Mun Leong's former helper
summary: Singapore's Home Affairs and Law Minister K Shanmugam has acknowledged that something went wrong in the case of former domestic worker Parti Liyani, who was acquitted of stealing from Liew Mun Leong's family. Shanmugam vowed to review the case and deal with the issues, ensuring a fair process and accountability. The Attorney-General's Chambers, police, and Ministry of Manpower are reviewing the judgment, which found the trial judge's conviction against Ms Parti to be unsafe due to inconsistencies in the evidence and improper motives.

site_title: Grab to train 3,000 food-delivery merchants
summary: Grab is launching an online training program, Grab Merchant Academy, to help 3,000 food-delivery merchants grow their businesses by the end of 2020. The program features over 20 modules on online store management, menu optimization, and marketing. To aid merchants with limited digital resources, Grab is also launching an online repository of images for menu listings and promotions. A pilot project found that merchants with menu images saw a 2x increase in sales. The program aims to help merchants adapt to the increasingly crowded online food scene and improve their digital skills to stand out.

site_title: Spike in virus cases dents hopes of reviving S-E Asia's holiday hotspots
summary: A spike in novel coronavirus infections in Indonesia's Bali and Thailand's Phuket has dealt a blow to South-east Asia's hopes of reviving its tourism industries. Plans to reopen Bali to foreign tourists from September have been postponed, while Thailand's proposal for Phuket's cautious reopening has come into doubt. The developments come as the region struggles to contain the virus, with Thailand's first locally transmitted case in 100 days reported. The setbacks raise concerns about the long-term viability of the tourism industry in the region.

images.alt_text: Experts said tourist arrivals in Bali underscored shortcomings in fighting the pandemic, namely a lack of testing and contact tracing.

site_title: Trump ready to pay own cash in uphill fight for reelection
summary: President Donald Trump is considering using his own funds to finance his reelection campaign, which is struggling to attract donors. With eight weeks until the election, Trump acknowledged that his fundraising machine may need help, stating "Whatever it takes. We have to win." This comes as the Republican faces significant obstacles, including a dwindling voter base and a lack of financial support. Trump's willingness to use his own money to fund the campaign highlights the challenges he faces in securing a narrow electoral college victory.

site_title: Election countdown starts in Myanmar under coronavirus shadow
summary: Myanmar's election campaign began on September 8, 2020, with Aung San Suu Kyi's party, the National League for Democracy (NLD), expected to win, despite the COVID-19 pandemic. Suu Kyi's popularity remains high in the Bamar majority, but ethnic minority parties may gain ground. The military, which controls key ministries and seats, is opposed to the NLD and may try to undermine the election. The pandemic has limited campaign events, but Suu Kyi is determined to secure a landslide victory to counter the military's influence.

site_title: BOE chief economist hails UK's recovery from lockdown
summary: BOE chief economist Andy Haldane praised the UK's economy recovery from the coronavirus lockdown, stating it has "bounced back" largely due to consumers' resilience and adaptability. This contradicts recent concerns from fellow interest-rate setters that the economy might take longer to recover. The UK economy contracted by 20% between March and June, the worst performance on record. Haldane's optimistic tone suggests a shift in the BOE's stance on the economy's recovery.

site_title: Airbus jet deliveries slip in August, stays ahead of Boeing
summary: Airbus delivered 39 jets in August, down from 49 a month earlier, but remained ahead of Boeing, which delivered 13 jets, its lowest August total in years. Airbus' deliveries were also lower than last year's 41. The company's 2020 deliveries were down 43% from 2019, while Boeing's deliveries were down 51%. Airbus cited production flaws at Boeing as a reason for its lower deliveries, while Boeing warned of delays to its 787 Dreamliner production.

site_title: US: Nasdaq slides 3% as tech rout deepens
summary: The Nasdaq Composite fell 3.65% to 10,900.70, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.74% to 27,925.23, due to tech routs and US-China tensions. Simmering tensions and concerns over an economic rebound also weighed on sentiment.

site_title: Investing with the conundrum of low interest rates and low inflation rate
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a global recession, with the US unemployment rate reaching near 15% and the Federal Reserve injecting $2 trillion into the economy through low-interest rates and bond purchases. This has resulted in asset price inflation, low bond yields, and a weakening negative correlation between equities and fixed income. The low-interest rate environment is expected to benefit risk assets, with equities and high-yield debt potentially outperforming fixed income. Investors should position their portfolios for a low-rate environment, focusing on sectors and styles that benefit from low real rates, such as growth and momentum strategies, and small- to mid-cap value stocks.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sunningdale Tech's largest shareholder, Quarz Capital Asia, now holds 5.001% of shares after purchasing 4,600 shares. UG Healthcare has started construction on a new manufacturing facility in Malaysia, expected to boost production capacity by 1.2 billion pieces of gloves per year. Wing Tai Holdings plans to repurchase up to S$85 million of notes. Raffles Education Corp's stock rose 31.58% after SGX queried the company about "unusual price movements."

site_title: Real estate fund for homeless plans London IPO
summary: Home Reit, a real estate fund for the homeless, plans to raise £250 million (S$447.4 million) by listing on the London Stock Exchange. The fund, backed by Alvarium Investment, aims to acquire or create new accommodation for the homeless, addressing a significant demand in the UK. The company targets a net total shareholder return of at least 7.5% per year, investing in facilities for vulnerable populations, such as women fleeing domestic violence and individuals with mental health issues. The IPO is expected to be completed by mid-October.

site_title: The options-enhanced stock money machine is going global
summary: A global rally in US technology shares is driven by a surge in options trading, particularly bullish calls, by both individual and institutional investors. SoftBank Group, a Japanese conglomerate, has reportedly made $4 billion in unrealised profits from options bets tied to $30 billion in tech stocks. Retail investors have shelled out $40 billion in call premiums in a month, dwarfing SoftBank's outlay. The trend is attributed to a "money machine" strategy popularized by the Reddit forum r/wallstreetbets, which has led to market volatility.

site_title: UOB prices US$600m subordinated notes due 2031 at 1.75%
summary: UOB priced its $600 million subordinated notes due 2031 at 1.75% and saw strong investor interest, with a peak orderbook of $4.25 billion. The notes, expected to qualify as Tier 2 regulatory capital, were priced below par at 99.739% and will have a fixed interest rate reset after the first call date. Asian investors, including 74% of orders, and fund managers, insurers, and pension funds, took significant allocations. The deal was seen as a significant achievement, given the persistent low rate environment, and will bolster UOB's capital base.

site_title: Sembmarine carve-out should make Sembcorp attractive versus peers
summary: Sembcorp Industries (SCI) shares began trading without Sembcorp Marine (SMM) entitlements, making it more attractive compared to peers. Analysts expect SCI to do better, with nine out of 11 calls being "buy" and an average target price of S$2.24. The company's energy business is expected to grow, particularly in renewables, and its urban development business has attracted significant investments. SCI's lower valuation may be due to a negative return on equity, but excluding SMM could help improve its profitability and leverage metrics.

site_title: Quest Ventures to nurture Malaysian startups in partnership with accelerator
summary: Singapore-based venture capital firm Quest Ventures has partnered with accelerator ScaleUp Malaysia to invest in and nurture top Malaysian startups, bringing in US$1 million in foreign direct investment. Applications for the program, the second intake of ScaleUp Malaysia, began on September 8, 2020. The partnership aims to support regional growth of Malaysian startups, providing them with access to funding and resources to drive innovation.

site_title: Sustainability at the core of everything we do, including investments: Temasek
summary: Singapore's state investor Temasek Holdings aims to deliver a net zero carbon emissions portfolio by 2050, with sustainability at the core of its investment approach. The company has "mainstreamed sustainability considerations" in its investment and portfolio management processes. Temasek plans to engage portfolio companies on carbon-reduction plans and explore new investments with better carbon intensity and efficiency. The company has also increased investments in plant-based protein makers and lab-grown meat producers to address growing demand for proteins.

site_title: Return of the green agenda
summary: The European Union (EU) and the US are investing heavily in the fight against global warming. The EU has set ambitious targets for carbon dioxide emissions by 2030 and has allocated €600 billion for sustainable energy over the next decade. Meanwhile, US President Joe Biden has proposed a $2 trillion plan to make the US a country of net zero emissions by 2050. This bold plan could be a game-changer in the fight against global warming, potentially combining economic stimulus with environmental efforts. If the EU and Biden's plans are embraced by voters, it could break the link between oil prices and sustainable energy investment, and signal a shift in politics towards environmental values.

site_title: Temasek posts negative 1-year return; ups exposure to China, private markets
summary: Temasek Holdings reported a one-year total shareholder return (TSR) of -2.28% for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020, due to the sharp market correction in response to the Covid-19 pandemic. Despite this, the firm's exposure to China has surpassed that of Singapore for the first time, at 29% compared to 24%. Temasek remains cautious due to geopolitical tensions and will continue to invest in the local ecosystem. The firm has increased its exposure to private markets, with investments now making up 48% of its portfolio.

site_title: US passenger airline traffic rising, but still down sharply over 2019
summary: US passenger airline traffic has rebounded, carrying 21.4 million passengers in July, a 73% decrease from 2019 levels. The Transportation Security Administration screened 968,673 people at airport checkpoints, the highest daily number since March 16, but still down 60% from 2019.

site_title: Singapore condo resale volume hits two-year high in Aug: SRX
summary: Singapore's condo resale volume reached a two-year high in August, with 1,052 units sold, a 7% increase from July. Resale prices edged up 0.4% month-over-month and year-over-year. The market recovery is attributed to pent-up demand, with new home sales exceeding 1,200 units in August, the highest in the past 12 months. Condo prices in the outside central region rose 2.8%, while those in the core central region declined 3.1% year-over-year.

site_title: Resilient GCB market can weather market shocks
summary: The Good Class Bungalow (GCB) market in Singapore has shown resilience in the face of market shocks, including the 2018 cooling measures. Despite a reduction in profitability, the market remained stable, with a 6.5% increase in total transacted value of all types of bungalows. Investors were willing to pay more for bungalows in terms of land rate, and the average gross profit margin increased to 94.8% post-cooling measures. The market's ability to weather shocks is attributed to the financial strength of high-net worth individuals, who tend to hold onto properties for long periods.

site_title: A bubble scarier than Big Tech is brewing in China
summary: A rapidly growing bubble in China's food and beverage industry, driven by institutional investors, has surpassed the country's tech sector in terms of market capitalization. Foshan Haitian Flavouring & Food, a blue chip with an $81 billion market cap, has seen its stock price tumble 14% in two days, leading to a sell-off in the entire sector. This bubble is fueled by predictable cash flows and high growth rates, but concerns over market depth and high price-to-earnings ratios have raised questions about its sustainability.

site_title: Swedish fish dish is so pungent it should be opened outdoors
summary: A Swedish chef, Malin Soderstrom, serves surstromming, a fermented herring dish notorious for its pungent smell, to a small group of friends and colleagues in her restaurant. The dish, which should be opened outdoors due to its odor, was enjoyed with accompaniments such as bread, potatoes, and onions. Soderstrom defends the delicacy's reputation, stating that the smell is not as overwhelming as it appears when served with other flavors. The chef believes that the experience of eating surstromming is essential, with the setting, company, and preparation method all playing a role in appreciating its unique taste.

site_title: Three game changers Trump is counting on in US presidential election
summary: US President Donald Trump is relying on three potential game-changers to boost his chances in the upcoming presidential election: positive news on the economy, a vaccine for COVID-19, and a strong showing in presidential debates. Despite low television ratings from the Republican convention, Trump's ego remains intact, and he continues to attack Democratic nominee Joe Biden as an ally of violent protesters. However, Biden's allies worry that the ongoing unrest could hurt him in key electoral states. The economy, which has been in recession, may also provide a turning point, with a recent drop in unemployment rate and public opinion polls favoring Trump.

site_title: Prudential gives out S$3.5m in cash benefits, donations amid Covid-19
summary: Prudential Singapore has distributed S$3.5 million in cash benefits and donations to over 3,400 individuals and the community as part of its Covid-19 relief measures. The amount includes hospitalisation allowances for nearly 500 customers and their family members, as well as one-time payments to over 2,900 individuals under quarantine orders. The life insurer also pledged S$210,000 to The Courage Fund and The Invictus Fund to support vulnerable individuals. CEO Dennis Tan said the Covid-19 pandemic has taken a toll on Singaporeans, and Prudential aims to offer financial relief and comfort to affected customers and groups.

site_title: Despite pandemic, Singapore's golfers remain busy on and off the course
summary: Singapore's golf association has successfully kept its golfers busy despite the pandemic, with High Performance Manager Joshua Ho working out schemes to keep the national and development squads engaged. Ho, a former national golfer, has drawn up a timetable to keep golfers active, including virtual settings, and is helping them balance school and golf. His experience as a national player has been invaluable in motivating the players and keeping them focused.

site_title: Japan wants progress on UK trade deal
summary: Japan is urging the UK to make progress on a trade deal before a change in government, which could impact the bilateral agreement's implementation on January 1, 2021. The UK seeks to finalize a trade deal with Japan by the end of the year, with a successful agreement potentially benefiting other trade talks. However, the UK is also facing challenges in negotiations with the EU, with the EU warning that a trade deal is unlikely if the UK alters the Brexit divorce treaty. Japan's ruling party is set to choose a new leader next week, potentially affecting the trade talks.

site_title: Singapore Exchange can offer diversity as other exchanges enter Reit game
summary: Singapore's Reit market may face competition from emerging markets, including China, the Philippines, and India, as they launch their own Reit regimes. China's Reit pilot will focus on infrastructure assets, while the Philippines and India are also developing their Reit markets. Singapore's 18-year lead has allowed it to develop a mature market with significant depth and breadth, attracting listings from China, Europe, and the US. However, to grow, Singapore's Reit market needs to enhance its brand reputation, enlarge its ecosystem, and address recent "egregious conflict of interest" problems.

site_title: Straits Times Index dips 0.26% in directionless cruise
summary: The Straits Times Index fell 6.45 points or 0.26% to 2,504.76 on Tuesday due to lacklustre trading volumes and concerns over the global economy and the US-China spat. The index was also affected by overnight calm, including holidays in the US and Canada, and a data vacuum. Major Asian bourses posted gains, except for Singapore. The three banking stalwarts DBS, OCBC, and UOB led the losses, with eight counters rising and 18 closing down.

site_title: Singapore's business hub goal needs global talent: Chan
summary: Singapore aims to remain open to top international talent as it accelerates its economic transformation efforts, focusing on becoming a global hub for trade, finance, technology, and talent. Minister of Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing emphasized the importance of attracting the world's best and brightest to augment local skills and capabilities, while ensuring fair hiring practices. The country will prioritize building deeper links with the world for markets, supplies, and talent, and accelerate economic transformation efforts through productivity, innovation, and upskilling.

site_title: US recovery is bypassing those who need it most
summary: The US economy is experiencing a recovery, with stocks up, jobs added, and GDP growth, but the benefits are not being shared by those who need it most. The lives of many Americans have gotten worse due to the pandemic, with millions of families losing income and struggling to make ends meet. The unemployment rate remains high, with workers in the leisure and hospitality sector still down 25% and unemployment rates over 20%. Rising average wages also indicate that low-wage workers are not getting jobs, and the safety net that provided extra unemployment benefits has been torn down, leaving families vulnerable to hardship.

site_title: Singapore faces far graver issues than foreign workforce in our midst
summary: Singapore faces more significant challenges than the foreign workforce issue, including the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic and global deglobalisation and protectionism. The country's economy, which relies on trade, investment, and talent from around the world, is under threat. Despite the need to protect jobs for Singaporeans, the government must balance this with the need to stay open to trade and investment. Singapore's role as a global hub and trusted broker in international trade and relations is also at risk. The country must find a way to live with Covid-19 while preserving the safety of its people.

site_title: Australia to examine competition between Apple, Google
summary: Australia's competition regulator, ACCC, will examine competition between Apple and Google's app stores, focusing on data sharing and pricing transparency. The inquiry is part of a five-year review, which will produce reports every six months. This comes amid a legal battle between Apple and Epic Games over in-app purchases, and a recent decision by Australia to make Google and Facebook pay for local news. The ACCC aims to understand how data is used and shared in the app ecosystem, and how it affects consumers.

site_title: Thailand approves job measures, calls for economic revamp
summary: Thailand's government approved plans to create 260,000 jobs, primarily through hiring new graduates, as part of its efforts to mitigate the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The country aims to diversify its economy, which relies heavily on exports and tourism, through large investment projects. The government also plans to study a land bridge project to link the Gulf of Thailand to the Andaman Sea. These measures are part of a broader economic revamp, which includes stimulus plans worth 68.5 billion baht and a focus on long-term growth.

site_title: New 5G iPhone expected at Apple online event Sept 15
summary: Apple is set to host an online event on September 15, where a new-generation iPhone tailored for 5G telecom networks is expected to be introduced. The event, streamed from Apple's Silicon Valley headquarters, follows a pattern of Apple holding similar events to unveil new iPhones. Analyst Daniel Ives believes the release of new models in October could kick off an "iPhone 12 supercycle." The event marks the first time Apple has revealed details of a new iPhone model through an invitation, sparking anticipation for the device.

site_title: Iran building new production hall for centrifuges in mountains near Natanz
summary: Iran has begun construction on a new production hall for centrifuges near its Natanz nuclear site, replacing a damaged facility hit by sabotage in July. The hall, located in the mountains, aims to produce advanced uranium enrichment centrifuges. The move is seen as a response to the damage and US sanctions, which Iran claims have crippled its economy. The Natanz site, a key component of Iran's enrichment program, has been the subject of international scrutiny and tension with the US since 2018.
