site_title: Moody's changes FCT outlook to stable, affirms Baa2 rating on PGIM Asia Retail Fund deal
summary: Moody's has changed Frasers Centrepoint Trust's (FCT) outlook to stable from negative, affirming its Baa2 issuer rating. The change reflects FCT's planned equity issuance and asset disposal, which will enhance liquidity and maintain its credit profile. The proposed acquisition of PGIM Real Estate Asia Retail Fund (ARF) will also improve FCT's business profile, but its leverage is expected to remain elevated for the next 12-18 months. The trust's asset size will increase by 70% to S$6.6 billion, making it the second-largest mall owner in Singapore.

site_title: Japan funds buy record amount of Italian debt after EU stimulus
summary: Japan's investors bought a record amount of Italian debt, purchasing 372.7 billion yen (S$4.8 billion) in July, amid easing concerns over Italy's fiscal issues following the European Union's stimulus package. This marks a fifth consecutive month of purchases. Japanese funds also added 465.4 billion yen of Australian debt and were net buyers of US sovereign bonds for the second month in a row. The purchases were driven by high yields on Italian bonds relative to other countries, according to senior economist Tsuyoshi Ueno.

site_title: Startup Melio raises US$144m to fund expansion
summary: Melio, a payments startup focused on small businesses, has raised US$144 million to fund expansion, backed by American Express Ventures and Bessemer Venture Partners. The New York-based firm plans to hire more engineers and sales staff to target the US$25 trillion annual market for business payments, with 40% still processed with cheques. Melio aims to simplify business payments, stating "Business payments shouldn't be more complicated than paying a friend with your phone."

site_title: Keppel Reit to issue S$150m 3.15% fixed-rate perps
summary: Keppel Reit is issuing S$150 million of 3.15% fixed-rate subordinated perpetual securities, with net proceeds used to refinance existing S$150 million bonds. The new securities will be listed on the Singapore bourse on or around September 14. The Reit received over S$350 million of orders for the issuance, with most coming from Singapore-based fund managers, insurers, and banks. The issue is under Keppel Reit's S$1 billion multicurrency debt issuance programme, with OCBC appointed as the sole lead manager and bookrunner.

site_title: More savings products, insurance for gig workers
summary: DBS has introduced more savings products and insurance options for gig workers in Singapore, aiming to support financially vulnerable customers during the pandemic. The bank has widened the definition of income, easing qualification requirements for its Multiplier accounts, and increased healthcare insurance plans. Gig workers can now earn 0.5% interest on their balances under DBS Multiplier, with the option to pay bills and shop from over 80,000 merchants. DBS has also partnered with healthcare providers to offer bundled deals and exclusive member consultation rates.

site_title: US to block cotton, tomato product imports from China's Xinjiang over forced labour
summary: The US will block imports of cotton and tomato products from China's Xinjiang region due to allegations of forced labor, according to a move expected to be formally announced by US Customs and Border Protection. The ban, part of a series of import restrictions, applies to entire supply chains involving cotton textiles and tomatoes, and follows US pressure on China over its treatment of Uighur Muslims in the region. China denies mistreatment and claims the camps are vocational training centers. The move is seen as a significant escalation in US pressure on China.

site_title: Alliance Healthcare and DBS to collaborate on marketing activities
summary: Alliance Healthcare Group announced a two-year collaboration with DBS Bank to promote each other's products and services. Alliance will provide a health and wellness program to DBS customers who purchase insurance, leveraging its digital health app, HeyAlly. The collaboration aims to leverage each party's strengths in their respective fields, with Alliance gaining access to DBS's financial technology and distribution, and DBS benefiting from Alliance's healthcare expertise. The agreement is not expected to impact Alliance's financial results for the current financial year.

site_title: Keppel prices 8b yen worth of five-year notes at 0.88%
summary: Keppel Corporation priced 8 billion yen ($103.5 million) worth of 5-year notes at 0.88% per annum. The notes are expected to be issued on September 15 under Keppel Corp's US$5 billion multi-currency medium-term note programme. Net proceeds will be used for general corporate or working capital purposes, including refinancing existing loans. Mizuho Securities Asia Limited has been appointed as the dealer for the notes.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 2.94 points to 1,519.32. Volume reached 9.035 billion lots worth RM4.570 billion, with 867 losers outnumbering 309 gainers.

site_title: Boeing records first 737 MAX order in 2020, cancellations rise
summary: Boeing secured its first 737 MAX order in 2020 from Poland's Enter Air for two 737-8 aircraft, while also recording 17 more cancellations, bringing the total to 445 for the year. The company delivered 13 aircraft in August, down from 18 in August last year, and 87 planes in the first eight months of the year, a 68.5% decline from 2018. Boeing has been hurt by the 737 MAX grounding and the coronavirus crisis, with deliveries expected to be 138 in 2020, down from 380 last year.

site_title: Indonesia adds Twitter, Zoom to tech companies that must pay 10% VAT
summary: Indonesia added Twitter and Zoom to a list of internet-based companies required to pay 10% value-added tax (VAT) on sales. The move aims to ensure tech giants pay their fair share of taxes globally. This follows previous additions of Google, Netflix, and Facebook. The decision is part of Indonesia's efforts to increase tax revenue from online businesses.

site_title: GM takes US$2b stake in Nikola and partners developing pickup model
summary: General Motors (GM) has taken a $2 billion stake in Nikola, a semi-truck maker, and partnered with the company to develop and manufacture its Badger pickup model. GM will receive an 11% stake in Nikola and nominate a director to the board. The partnership is expected to yield $4 billion in benefits for GM, including the production of the Badger and supply of batteries and fuel cells. The Badger is set to start production by the end of 2022, and Nikola's legitimacy is expected to be boosted by the partnership.

images.alt_text: General Motors took a US$2 billion equity stake in Nikola and partnered with the semi-truck maker to engineer and manufacture its Badger pickup model, sending its shares soaring in early trading.

site_title: Burning oil tanker leaks diesel off Sri Lanka
summary: A burning oil tanker, the New Diamond, has begun leaking diesel off Sri Lanka's coast, sparking environmental concerns. The Panama-flagged vessel, carrying 270,000 tonnes of crude oil and 1,700 tonnes of diesel fuel, has been burning since Thursday. A diesel oil slick was observed near the crippled vessel approximately 55km off the eastern coast in the Indian Ocean. The incident has raised fears of a major environmental disaster.

site_title: Cross-border payments startup Thunes raises US$60m led by Helios
summary: Thunes, a cross-border payments startup, has raised US$60 million in a Series B funding round led by Helios Investment Partners. The round brings Thunes' total funds raised to US$70 million, which will be used to expand its network in Africa, Asia, and Latin America. The company's network connects mobile wallet providers, banks, and technology companies, enabling fast and secure cross-border payments. With a projected US$45 trillion emerging markets cross-border payments market, Thunes expects transaction volumes to double annually.

site_title: Uber promises 100% electric vehicles by 2040, commits US$800m to help drivers switch
summary: Uber has pledged to transition its global ride-hailing platform to 100% electric vehicles by 2040, committing $800 million to support drivers in switching to battery-powered vehicles. The company has partnered with General Motors and the Renault-Nissan-Mitsubishi alliance to achieve this goal. In the US, Canada, and Europe, Uber aims to have zero-emission vehicles by 2030, with plans to reduce the overall cost of ownership for electric vehicles. The move follows years of criticism over the environmental impact of ride-hailing vehicles.

site_title: UG Healthcare to set up third manufacturing facility in Negeri Sembilan
summary: UG Healthcare Corporation has started construction on a new manufacturing facility in Negeri Sembilan, Malaysia, expected to increase production capacity by 1.2 billion pieces of gloves per annum. The facility will boost the company's total production capacity to 4.6 billion pieces, a 59% increase from its current capacity. The new facility, valued at RM5 million, is expected to be completed by June 2021, allowing UG Healthcare to narrow the gap between its manufacturing supply and downstream distribution market demand.

site_title: Diginex raises US$20m before planned Nasdaq debut
summary: Diginex, a Hong Kong-based parent of the institutional cryptocurrency exchange Equos, has raised US$20 million from private investors ahead of its planned listing on the Nasdaq Stock Market. The funds will be used for capital expenditures, with plans to relocate its staff from Hong Kong to Singapore. This move comes as digital assets have outperformed this year, with the Bloomberg Galaxy Crypto Index up 67% in 2020. Diginex aims to list on September 23, pending shareholder approval and SEC clearance. The company's CEO, Richard Byworth, stated the funds will ensure the company's capitalization for its core businesses.

site_title: CapitaLand Mall Trust secures first sustainability-linked loan
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) has secured its first sustainability-linked loan of S$200 million from UOB, with interest rates tied to the trust's GRESB Real Estate assessment achievements. The loan marks a milestone in CMT's ESG journey, with CEO Tony Tan stating that it will help create long-term value for stakeholders. The sustainability-linked loan is part of CMT's efforts to continually strengthen its ESG standards.

site_title: Disney's 'Mulan' sparks backlash over Xinjiang
summary: Walt Disney's live-action remake of "Mulan" has sparked backlash over its star Liu Yifei's support of Hong Kong police and its filming locations in the Xinjiang region, where China has faced criticism for its treatment of ethnic Uighurs. Critics, including Hong Kong democracy activist Joshua Wong, have called for a boycott of the film, which will be released in Chinese cinemas and on Disney's streaming platform. Disney has not commented on the backlash.

images.alt_text: Walt Disney's release of "Mulan", which is set in China and meant to appeal to audiences there, has provoked a backlash on social media over its star's support of Hong Kong police and for being partly filmed in the Xinjiang region.

site_title: Russia has to regain global oil market share once demand heals, Novak says
summary: Russian Energy Minister Alexander Novak emphasized the importance of regaining global oil market share once demand recovers. He stated that it would be crucial for Russia and other oil producers to quickly regain or increase their market share to prevent a loss. Novak also mentioned that Russia has a plan to launch unfinished oil wells once the output reduction agreement expires in 2022, to ensure market share retention.

site_title: FSL Trust resolves claim against charterer
summary: FIRST Ship Lease (FSL) Trust has resolved its claim against Torm Singapore, a bareboat charterer, for $1.89 million. FSL claimed Torm breached redelivery obligations, causing vessels to be delivered in an untradeable condition. The claim was settled amicably, with the settlement payment offsetting repair costs and litigation fees. The settlement has no material impact on FSL's current financial year, and its units closed unchanged at S$0.075.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed in positive territory on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.14% to 24,624.34, driven by bargain-buying and plans to ease virus containment measures. The Shanghai Composite Index also gained 0.72%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.38%. The gains followed recent losses and come ahead of the city's government announcing further easing of virus measures.

site_title: SK Jewellery's privatisation offer hits 90% threshold in irrevocable undertakings
summary: SK Jewellery's privatisation offer has reached 90% threshold with over 508 million shares accepted, exceeding the minimum acceptance condition. The offer, valued at S$0.15 per share, aims to take the company private, providing greater control and management flexibility. Delisting will also save on listing expenses, allowing the company to channel resources to business operations. The offeror, OroGreen Investment, plans to compulsorily acquire remaining shares not acquired under the offer.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Temasek Holdings reported a one-year total shareholder return of -2.28% due to the sharp market correction in response to Covid-19. Singapore aims to remain a hub for businesses and stays open to global talent. The government is reviewing nightlife operators' suggestions to restart the industry. Employment expectations worsened among businesses in Singapore, while DBS launched savings and healthcare solutions for gig workers. The LTA plans to install on-board units for its new ERP system from H2 2021. The Straits Times Index fell 0.26% to 2,504.76 on Tuesday.

site_title: Japan wants to reach broad agreement on trade talks with UK this week
summary: Japan aims to reach a broad agreement on trade talks with the UK this week, under Foreign Minister Toshimitsu Motegi, to ensure a pact can be sealed before a change in government. The UK seeks a trade agreement by the end of the year, as its no-change transition arrangement with the EU will expire. A new Japanese government will form after Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's step-down, potentially leading to a new foreign minister and altering the trade talks' timeline. A failure to reach an agreement could delay the pact's January 1, 2021, effective date.

site_title: NTU food court, eateries among new places visited by Covid-19 patients; new cluster at S11 Dormitory in Punggol
summary: NTU food court, eateries, and the Quad Cafe at NTU's School of Biological Sciences were visited by a Covid-19 patient while infectious. The Ministry of Health (MOH) added these locations to the list of places visited by patients. A new cluster was also announced at S11 Dormitory @ Punggol, with 13 linked cases. Singapore reported 47 new cases, including 46 migrant workers and one imported case, with 53 discharged and 56,446 recovered.

site_title: Wing Tai Holdings proposes to buy back up to S$85m of notes
summary: Wing Tai Holdings has proposed to repurchase up to S$85 million of notes from its S$1 billion medium-term note programme. The repurchase will involve buying back S$30 million of 4% notes due 2021, S$25 million of 4.5% notes due 2022, S$15 million of 4.25% notes due 2023, and S$15 million of 4.7% notes due 2024 at prices ranging from 102.55% to 106% of the principal amount. The proposed repurchase will start on Sept 9 and end on Sept 18, with DBS acting as the buy-back agent.

site_title: Vietnam importers offer sales bonus to cut diesel inventory as virus hits demand
summary: Vietnam oil importers are offering a 2,500 Vietnam dong (S$0.15) sales commission per liter of diesel to retailers to clear high inventories amid the coronavirus pandemic's impact on demand. The move aims to digest the huge inventory, but sales remain sluggish. Diesel demand has been severely disrupted in industrial factories, and refineries are maintaining normal operations despite higher fuel inventories. This unusual tactic underscores the difficulties faced by oil importers in emerging economies like Vietnam, which has posted the lowest second-quarter economic growth in decades.

site_title: India, China accuse each other of firing in the air on tense border
summary: India and China have accused each other of firing in the air during a confrontation on their border in the western Himalayas, escalating military tension between the nuclear-armed nations. Hundreds of troops are in proximity along the border, which has been tense since June after a clash killed 20 Indian soldiers. Both sides claim a portion of the disputed territory, and military commanders have held talks to reduce tension. The incident occurred in the Ladakh sector, where China's PLA troops allegedly fired in the air to intimidate Indian troops, while India says Chinese troops crossed the informal border and fired shots.

site_title: Singapore to ensure it remains as preferred hub for businesses, stays open to global talent
summary: Singapore aims to maintain its position as a preferred hub for businesses and global talent by implementing four strategies: remaining open to top international talent, keeping seaports, airports, and supply lines open, investing in connectivity, and accelerating economic transformation efforts. Minister Chan Chun Sing emphasized the importance of quality over quantity in talent acquisition and ensuring businesses can access regional and global opportunities. These initiatives aim to enhance Singapore's competitiveness and position it as a critical node in global value chains.

site_title: Brexit 'trash talking' lifts UK debt demand to US$99b
summary: The UK has successfully sold 8 billion pounds of 15-year debt, attracting bids exceeding $99.2 billion, its first syndicated bond offering since June. The sale was influenced by rising tension between the UK and EU over trade, dampening risk appetite and prompting investors to favor safer assets. Benchmark UK gilts extended gains, with yields falling to 0.22%, supporting demand for the debt sale. The issuance is part of the UK's plan to raise 385 billion pounds in debt this financial year to fund fiscal spending.

site_title: Temasek cautions against jumping to judgment over Liew Mun Leong, ex-maid case
summary: Temasek has defended its senior international business advisor Liew Mun Leong, stating that he has contributed to Singapore and its people, despite a recent court acquittal of a former maid accused of theft by his family. The acquittal raised questions about the motivation of Liew and his family in lodging a police report against the maid. Temasek's CEO, Dilhan Pillay Sandrasegara, said the company will not comment further on the issue, citing ongoing proceedings, and advised against jumping to judgment until all sides have been heard.

site_title: Ex-maid acquitted of stealing from CAG chairman: Shanmugam says good to see justice delivered
summary: A former domestic worker, Parti Liyani, has been acquitted of stealing from a family, including Changi Airport Group chairman Liew Mun Leong, due to a High Court's judgment citing inconsistencies in evidence and improper police handling. Home Affairs and Law Minister K Shanmugam stated that the authorities will review the case to determine what went wrong, emphasizing the need for a fair process and accountability. Justice has been delivered, with Shanmugam commending the lawyer who acted pro bono for the acquitted woman.

site_title: On-board units for new ERP system to be installed from H2 2021: LTA
summary: Singapore's Land Transport Authority (LTA) has delayed the installation of on-board units for the next-generation Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) system from H2 2021 to the second half of next year due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on global supply chains. The existing cordon-based and point-based congestion pricing framework will remain, with ERP rates reviewed based on traffic speeds and congestion levels. The new OBU will provide real-time road traffic updates, and two designs will be available, with the first unit being free for existing Singapore-registered vehicles.

site_title: Agritech startup Aerospring raises S$1m led by Sirius Venture Capital
summary: Agritech startup Aerospring Gardens has raised S$1 million in a pre-Series A round led by Sirius Venture Capital. The Singapore-based company uses a patented vertical-gardening system with aeroponics to grow up to 27 edible plants at a time, using 90% less water than traditional methods. The funds will be used to expand distribution, develop new facilities, and boost sales and marketing efforts in overseas markets. Aerospring aims to empower urban dwellers to be self-sufficient and gain access to nutritious produce, aligning with Sirius Venture Capital's focus on food innovations and local food systems.

site_title: Grab in talks with Prudential, AIA for fintech investment: sources
summary: Grab, a Southeast Asian ride-hailing and services company, is in advanced talks with Prudential and AIA for a US$300-500 million investment in its financial services unit. Insurers are expected to provide half of the target, with potential fundraising rounds set to begin as early as October.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.3% lower on directionless trading
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 6.45 points, or 0.26%, to 2,504.76 on Tuesday due to lacklustre trading volumes and directionless trading. Worries over the global economy and US-China spat contributed to the cautious atmosphere. Despite this, some optimism emerged from a Morgan Stanley report predicting a faster V-shaped recovery and a return to pre-Covid-19 output levels. Other Asian markets, such as Japan, Hong Kong, and China, posted gains, while Singapore's three major banking stocks led the losses.

site_title: Government reviewing Singapore nightlife operators' suggestions to help industry restart
summary: The Singapore government is reviewing suggestions from nightlife operators to support the industry's restart. The suggestions include allowing family-themed karaoke joints, quicker approvals for temporary business changes, and extending drinking hours to midnight. The nightlife industry has been closed since March due to the pandemic, with many operators experiencing a "complete loss of income." The government aims to help businesses adjust and support the industry's recovery when the economy recovers.

site_title: Thailand to revise gold trading rules to shield baht
summary: Thailand aims to revise its gold trading rules by the end of the year to prevent the baht from appreciating when gold prices rise. The move is expected to shield the currency from volatility, with the baht down 4.5% against the dollar this year. The new regime will require gold investors to place their money in foreign-currency deposits, which will be used to trade with gold brokers. The Bank of Thailand Governor plans to monitor the currency closely to ensure it is conducive to economic recovery, but denies any manipulation or currency management for trade benefits.

images.alt_text: Gold exports represent about 1 per cent of Thailand's gross domestic product.

site_title: China says Australian TV anchor detained on 'national security' grounds
summary: China has detained Australian TV anchor Cheng Lei on "national security grounds" since August 14. Foreign Ministry spokesman Zhao Lijian stated that authorities are investigating her as part of an unspecified case, but did not provide further details. This is the second high-profile Australian detention in Beijing, following writer Yang Hengjun's arrest in 2019. The detention is the latest blow to deteriorating relations between the two countries, which have seen warnings of travel risks for citizens. Two other Australian reporters, Bill Birtles and Michael Smith, have also fled China.

site_title: Quarz Capital ups stake in Sunningdale Tech, becomes substantial shareholder
summary: Quartz Capital Asia has increased its stake in Sunningdale Tech, becoming a substantial shareholder with a 5.001% interest in the precision manufacturer. The fund manager purchased 4,600 shares via a market transaction. Quartz Capital Asia's Chief Investment Officer, Jan Moermann, expressed pride in Sunningdale's progress, including its continued dividend payments and strong growth in its healthcare segment, which contributes to Singapore's self-sufficiency in medical consumables.

site_title: Australian watchdog to examine competition between Apple, Google app stores
summary: Australia's competition regulator, the ACCC, plans to examine the competition between Apple and Google's app stores, focusing on data usage and sharing. The inquiry, part of a five-year review, will produce reports every six months until March. The move comes amid a legal dispute between Apple and Epic Games, and follows the ACCC's efforts to rein in US tech giants, including Facebook and Google. The regulator aims to increase pricing transparency in the country's mobile apps market.

site_title: Trafigura launches US$500m funding platform for low-carbon aluminium
summary: Trafigura launches a US$500m funding platform for low-carbon aluminium, partnering with Natixis and Rabobank. The platform aims to secure long-term low-carbon aluminium supply for customers while supporting decarbonisation efforts. Aluminium is a vital material for the transition to a low-carbon economy, particularly in the auto sector. Trafigura's move follows a growing trend among energy and commodity traders to adapt to the energy transition. The platform sets parameters for low-carbon aluminium production, aligning with EU and Aluminium Stewardship Initiative standards.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS expects iFast's growth to outpace industry, ups target price
summary: DBS Group Research has increased its target price for iFast Corp to S$2.60 from S$2.35, maintaining its "buy" call. The research team expects iFast to grow more quickly than the industry, driven by its scalable business model and expanded product range. DBS analyst Ling Lee Keng believes the company will be a "clear beneficiary" of the growing adoption of fintech services, with its assets under administration (AUA) growth assumption increased to 15% for FY20 and FY21. iFast is also bidding for large-scale projects, including a digital pension system in Hong Kong and a digital wholesale bank licence in Singapore.

site_title: India's economy to contract 11.8% in current fiscal year
summary: India's economy is projected to contract 11.8% in the current fiscal year, according to a report by India Ratings and Research. This contraction is attributed to the adverse impact of the coronavirus pandemic, with the economy shrinking 23.9% in the quarter from April to June. The projection is higher than an earlier forecast of 5.3% contraction. The report also suggests a federal fiscal deficit of 8.2% of GDP, driven by economic contraction and increased government spending. A recovery is expected in the next fiscal year.

site_title: Japan's service sector sentiment improves in August
summary: Japan's service sector sentiment index rose 2.8 points to 43.9 in August, signaling some improvement in business confidence despite ongoing pandemic concerns. The index hit a record low in April. The Cabinet Office noted that while the index is picking up, the pandemic's impact remains severe.

site_title: Japan fast-food group Colowide succeeds in hostile bid for rival Ootoya: reports
summary: Japanese fast-food group Colowide has successfully completed a hostile bid for rival home-style dining chain Ootoya, acquiring a 46% stake in the company. Colowide offered a 46% premium to Ootoya's earlier value of 3,081 yen (S$39.65) per share, convincing investors despite concerns over food quality. The acquisition aims to promote efficiency by introducing Ootoya to Colowide's central kitchens, a move Ootoya had initially opposed. The deal reflects a growing trend of hostile deals in Japan's traditionally consensus-driven business culture.

site_title: Beyond Meat signs deal to open production facility near Shanghai
summary: Beyond Meat signs a deal to open a production facility near Shanghai, China, marking the company's first major production facility in the country. The facility, expected to begin trial production in months and reach full output in early 2021, aims to tap into China's growing market for plant-based meat products. This move follows Starbucks' decision to roll out a plant-based menu in China, and comes as rival Impossible Foods also seeks to expand into the mainland Chinese market.

site_title: Mega water and waste treatment facility at Tuas begins construction
summary: Singapore's Tuas Nexus, a mega water and waste treatment facility, has begun construction and is set to be completed in phases from 2025 onwards. The integrated facility, which includes the Tuas Water Reclamation Plant and the Integrated Waste Management Facility, aims to optimize land use and maximize energy and resource recovery. The facility is expected to reduce CO2 emissions by over 200,000 tonnes annually, equivalent to taking 42,500 cars off the road. It will also save up to 2.6 hectares of land and be energy self-sufficient, powering up to 300,000 four-room HDB flats.

site_title: In-flight WiFi boom shows travel is changing in Covid era
summary: In-flight internet usage has surged amid the COVID-19 pandemic, with data traffic over Inmarsat Group Holdings Ltd's European Aviation Network reaching a record high in August. Despite a 80% decline in global airline traffic in July, the increase suggests a partial recovery in short and medium-haul flights. Users are now 2-3 times more likely to connect and stay connected on board, forming new internet habits. This trend may reassure investors who bet on surging airline connectivity with a $3.4 billion acquisition deal in 2019.

site_title: Silver Lake invests in Indian startup Byju's at US$10.8b valuation
summary: Private equity giant Silver Lake led a US$500 million funding round for Indian online education platform Byju's, valuing it at around US$10.8 billion. Existing backers including Tiger Global and General Atlantic also participated. Byju's is locked in negotiations over additional funding, including a reported US$400 million from Yuri Milner's DST Global. The funding signals strong investor interest in India's edtech startups amid the pandemic. Byju's, founded by Byju Raveendran, simplifies math and science concepts for K-12 students through games and videos, boasting 64 million registered users and 4.2 million paid subscribers.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher after European markets rally
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.80% to 23,274.13, following a rally in European markets. The Topix index gained 0.69% to 1,620.89. The rally came after two days of declines, as investors bought back shares. This is a result of European markets rallying, with mining and healthcare stocks driving gains.

site_title: Australia: Shares finish higher on stimulus hopes
summary: Australian shares rose 1.1% to 6,007.8, driven by hopes for stimulus measures to combat the economic damage from the Covid-19 pandemic. Banks will be required to take up A$240 billion of new government debt, cutting government borrowing costs and boosting emergency liquidity levels. The "Big Four" banks rose between 1.3% and 1.7%, while New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.3%. Markets shrugged off soft August business conditions data and weak employment figures, with investors looking forward to a possible rebound in US stocks.

site_title: Grab aims to train 3,000 food-delivery merchants by end-2020
summary: Grab is launching an online training program, Grab Merchant Academy, to help its 12,000+ food-delivery merchants in Singapore grow their businesses. The program, which started in mid-September, features over 20 free modules on topics such as online store management and marketing. The company aims to train 3,000 merchants by the end of 2020. Additionally, Grab is launching a digital repository of images for merchants to use on their menu listings and promotions, which has been shown to increase sales by up to 200%.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: UK's easyJet cuts capacity as quarantine restrictions widen
summary: British airline easyJet reduced its flying schedule due to decreasing demand caused by constantly changing government travel restrictions, including wider quarantine measures. The airline now expects to fly slightly less than 40% of planned capacity in the final quarter of its financial year. EasyJet also cannot provide earnings guidance for 2020 or 2021. This move follows similar adjustments made by other airlines, with Delta Air Lines offering an upbeat outlook on travel demand and lifting its shares.

site_title: Staycations and home office equipment boost UK spending in August
summary: The UK economy experienced a 0.2% annual increase in spending in August, marking the first rise since February, driven by "staycation" holidays, home office equipment, and shopping for clothes. Spending on restaurants and pubs also rose due to the government's Eat Out to Help Out scheme. However, travel-related spending plummeted 61% and unemployment is expected to rise sharply as the government scales back its job protection scheme.

site_title: Europe: Stocks diverge at open
summary: Europe's major stock markets diverged on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.2% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 index down 0.2%. Paris CAC 40 shed 0.3% in the eurozone. US markets also reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging towards new highs.

site_title: UK opens books on launch of new 15-year bond
summary: The UK has opened order books for a new 15-year bond maturing in July 2035, worth several billion pounds, to help pay for its response to the coronavirus crisis. The 0.625% bond is priced to yield between 13 and 13.5 basis points more than existing bonds. Bankers BofA Merrill Lynch, Citi, JP Morgan, Lloyds Bank Corporate Markets, and RBC Capital Markets are acting as joint bookrunners on the transaction.

site_title: US dollar bides time ahead of ECB, Brexit woes hit sterling
summary: The US dollar maintained stability against a basket of currencies, with a slight edge over the euro at $1.1809. Meanwhile, the pound weakened due to Brexit uncertainty, falling 0.2% against the US dollar. The European Central Bank's policy decision on Thursday is expected to have a limited impact, with analysts anticipating no change in policy stance but potential downward revisions to inflation forecasts. The pound also faced pressure due to a report suggesting Britain might legislate to override its Brexit withdrawal agreement.

site_title: Seoul: Samsung-led tech rally boosts South Korea shares for second session
summary: South Korean shares rose for a second consecutive session, driven by Samsung Electronics' surge 3.89% after winning a US$6.64 billion supply contract from US-based Verizon. The Kospi benchmark closed up 17.69 points or 0.74% at 2,401.91. The country reported 136 new Covid-19 cases, but the daily tally has steadily dropped since reaching a peak last month. Foreigners were net sellers of 30.5 billion won worth of shares, while the won strengthened to 1,186.4 per US dollar.

site_title: Hot stock: SGX queries Raffles Education after shares jump 26%
summary: Raffles Education Corp's shares jumped 31.58% to 15 cents after the Singapore Exchange (SGX) queried the company about unusual price movements. The counter began the day at 11.4 cents and rose to an intraday high of 15.8 cents. Raffles Education said it was unaware of any reasons for the price movements and confirmed compliance with listing rules. The company is also facing a notice of requisition from several shareholders calling for a special auditor to review a joint venture with Educomp Solutions, alleging forgery and extortion.

site_title: European Union resumes LSE, Refinitiv deal probe, decision by Dec 16
summary: The European Union's antitrust regulators have set a new Dec 16 deadline to decide on the London Stock Exchange's US$27 billion takeover of data company Refinitiv, resuming their investigation into the deal after a temporary halt. The EU has voiced concerns over the deal's impact on European government bond trading, prompting LSE to consider selling its Italian stock market Borsa Italiana. The company may need to make further concessions to address these concerns, with a decision expected by Dec 16.

site_title: Temasek posts negative one-year return, portfolio value dips
summary: Temasek Holdings reported a one-year total shareholder return (TSR) of -2.28% for the 12 months ended March 31, 2020, due to the Covid-19 market correction. This is a further decline from the previous fiscal year's TSR of 1.49%. The company's net portfolio value dropped to S$306 billion, 2.2% below the year-ago S$313 billion. The decline marks a significant drop from Temasek's 14% annualized returns over 46 years.

site_title: IAG airline's Walsh hands control to Gallego with crisis in mid-air
summary: Willie Walsh, CEO of IAG, will pass control to Luis Gallego at the airline's annual meeting, amid a coronavirus crisis. IAG shareholders will vote on a 2.75 billion euro rights issue to raise funds, backed by Qatar. Gallego will face cost-cutting, damaged union relations, and restoring services, which were severely impacted by the pandemic. The airline's shares have been boosted by the potential funding, but the plan has sparked opposition from unions and the British government, which views the access to state funds as a breach of faith.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS, UOBKH deem CapitaLand Reits' merger attractive
summary: DBS Group Research and UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) have expressed optimism over the proposed merger of CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) and CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT), citing benefits such as a larger scale, reduced asset concentration risk, and increased attractiveness of integrated developments. The merger, if successful, will create CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT), which will be the largest Reit in Singapore and second-largest in Asia-Pacific. Analysts believe the transaction will be attractive for unitholders, given the lower price-to-net asset value.

site_title: More firms setting up LNG desks in Singapore: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore's trade minister Chan Chun Sing said more firms are setting up liquefied natural gas (LNG) desks in the city-state to capitalize on growing demand in Asia. Currently, over 50 companies have an LNG presence, with Osaka Gas setting up a trading operation. The growth of LNG derivatives trading is expected to increase spot trades and price influence in Asia, with Singapore being a natural hub due to its existing presence and favorable business environment. The city-state will continue to develop the use of LNG as a marine fuel and establish standards for its storage and handling.

site_title: Malaysia seeks to reroute US$10.6b belt-and-road rail project
summary: Malaysia's government plans to reroute a $10.6 billion Belt and Road rail project across the peninsula, aiming to revert to the original 2017 route with minor changes near Kuala Lumpur. The decision was made to reassess the cost and schedule with Chinese contractor CCC-ECRL. The project's cost is expected to remain similar to the current estimate, and no return to the original higher cost plan is anticipated. The government will renegotiate with China and the contractor to finalize the route and project implementation schedule.

site_title: Alternative-asset price warning riles a US$110b investor
summary: Denmark's US$110 billion PFA Pension fund is reevaluating its alternative asset portfolio due to regulatory concerns over valuation accuracy and market risks. The move comes amid extreme monetary easing, which has led to a surge in alternative assets. Regulators, including the Financial Supervisory Authority, are scrutinizing pension managers' strategies for managing market fluctuations. The fund's decision highlights the challenges of navigating alternative assets in a low-risk environment, where traditional asset classes are often preferred.

site_title: China set to be top world corn buyer on crop woes and demand
summary: China is poised to become the world's top corn buyer due to crop woes and increasing demand for hog and poultry feed. The country's northeastern provinces, normally the largest corn producers, are experiencing severe weather conditions, including typhoons, which are reducing corn yields. China's purchases from the US and Ukraine are expected to exceed 20 million tons, surpassing the US as the world's largest importer. This surge in imports is driven by the country's growing hog and poultry industries, which are expanding to meet increasing demand and counter African swine fever.

site_title: Swedish fish dish is so pungent it should be opened outdoors
summary: A Swedish chef, Malin Soderstrom, defended the notorious delicacy surstromming, a fermented herring dish known for its pungent smell, by serving it outdoors to a small group of friends and colleagues. The dish, likened to rotten eggs, is traditionally opened outdoors due to its strong odor. Soderstrom, who grew up eating surstromming, believes the whole meal experience, including the setting and company, is essential to appreciating the dish's unique flavor. Despite its divisive reputation, some restaurants dedicate days to serving it, and a museum has been dedicated to the dish in recent years.

site_title: Indonesia's giant video game market gets extra pandemic boost
summary: Indonesia's video game market experienced a significant boost, with estimated revenue increasing by over 50% since early March, driven by pandemic-related lockdowns and improved connectivity. The country is also the top spender in South-east Asia, with the gaming boom accelerating due to rising smartphone ownership. This growth is attributed to factors beyond the pandemic, including increased internet access and gaming popularity.

site_title: Tourist hotspot Phuket's reopening delayed by new virus case
summary: Thailand's plan to reopen Phuket to foreign visitors has been delayed due to a new local coronavirus case. The reopening, initially set for next month, is now uncertain, with concerns from some groups that it may lead to infections. The delay follows a 100-day streak of no local community transmission, and authorities are weighing the cost between public health and economic benefits. The tourism sector, which accounts for two-thirds of Phuket's income, is heavily reliant on international visitors, and a prolonged closure could lead to significant job losses and economic losses.

site_title: Exxon downsizes global empire as Wall Street worries about dividend
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp, the top US oil company, is facing a potential shortfall of around $48 billion through 2021 due to ill-timed bets on rising demand. The company must make deep cuts to its staff and projects, which may include a cut to its dividend, sparking concerns among Wall Street investors. Exxon has borrowed nearly $23 billion to finance its operations and posted its first back-to-back quarterly losses. Analysts believe the company's once-sacrosanct dividend is now under threat, and a cut could be "cataclysmic" for Exxon's stock.

site_title: Australia crop output bounces back as rains ease drought
summary: Australia's winter crop production is expected to increase 64% due to much-needed rainfall easing a drought that affected the country's southeast. The agriculture department projects a 20% rise in output, surpassing the 10-year average. Major winter crops such as wheat, barley, and canola are expected to see substantial increases, with New South Wales production forecast to be 14.8 million tonnes. However, drought conditions persist in Western Australia, and the area planted is forecast to rise by only 194% in summer.

site_title: Quest Ventures to nurture Malaysian startups in partnership with accelerator
summary: Singaporean venture capital firm Quest Ventures has partnered with ScaleUp Malaysia to invest $1 million in Malaysian startups, bringing $60,250 in funding to 12 selected companies. The program, starting in October, will support top tech talent and help startups grow in post-pandemic emerging Asia markets. The partnership aims to drive the digital economy's adoption and create economic possibilities, with applications now open for the second intake of ScaleUp Malaysia.

site_title: Trees, birds, ponds: Mexico City's ancient lake reclaims scrapped airport
summary: Mexico City is transforming a scrapped airport into a massive park, reclaiming an ancient lake that was once drained by Spanish colonizers. The abandoned construction zone is part of a project to conserve 12,200 hectares of marsh, with about half slated for public use, including sports and events space. Officials aim to open a portion of the park by March 2023 and full access by 2024, showcasing nature's resilience in the area.

site_title: Employment expectations for Q4 worsen among businesses in Singapore
summary: Employment expectations among businesses in Singapore have worsened for the fourth quarter, declining to -13.19 percentage points from -3.29 percentage points in the previous quarter, according to a survey by the Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau. This is the most negative outlook for 2020, attributed to a tepid global economic outlook and firms turning to digitalization and technology to reduce manpower costs. The financial, manufacturing, and transport sectors have seen the biggest decline in employment sentiment, while the wholesale sector remains positive.

site_title: HK residents arrested at sea 'will have to be dealt with' by mainland China: Lam
summary: Hong Kong residents arrested at sea for seeking political asylum in Taiwan will "have to be dealt with" by mainland China, Chief Executive Carrie Lam said. Twelve people, including those facing prosecution for involvement in pro-democracy protests, were intercepted by Chinese authorities off the coast of Guangdong province. Lam stated her government will provide assistance to Hong Kong residents abroad, but the mainland authorities will handle the situation according to their laws. The arrests have raised concerns about Hong Kong's autonomy and the city's separation of powers.

site_title: TikTok owner doles out bonuses to assuage beleaguered staff
summary: TikTok's Chinese parent, ByteDance, has announced a half-month's salary bonus for its 60,000-plus employees worldwide, aiming to calm staff amid negotiations over the sale of its US operations. The bonus, to be paid out in September, is a rare move for the company, which has been known for lavish pay packages. The move comes as ByteDance faces uncertainty over a potential sale to Microsoft or Oracle, amid concerns over the app's security and the Trump administration's deadline for a sale by September. The bonus aims to reward employees for their efforts during the Covid-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: TikTok's Chinese parent has declared a rare half-month's salary bonus for employees, hoping to calm a 60,000-plus workforce across the globe as negotiations around the sale of the video service's US operations approach the Trump administration's September deadline.

site_title: New chartered fintech professional qualification to groom Singapore, China talent
summary: A new Chartered FinTech Professional (CFtP) qualification is being launched by the Global FinTech Institute, Singapore University of Social Sciences, and Shanghai Institute of International Finance Center to develop fintech professionals in Singapore and China. The qualification aims to build a sustainable pipeline of international fintech talent, addressing the growing demand for skilled professionals in the sector.

site_title: Singapore condo resale volume hits two-year high in Aug: SRX
summary: Singapore's condo resale volume reached a two-year high in August with 1,052 units resold, a 7% increase from July. Resale prices edged up 0.4% month-on-month and year-on-year. The market recovery is attributed to pent-up demand and positive sales trends in other segments, including HDB resale and Build-To-Order sales. Sellers are not cutting prices significantly, while buyers are cautious due to economic uncertainty, but may still opt for stable returns through residential investments.

site_title: France's pioneering black opera star Christiane Eda-Pierre dies
summary: Christiane Eda-Pierre, France's pioneering black opera star, has died at 88. Born in Martinique in 1932, she broke ground as the country's first black woman to perform on the international opera stage. Eda-Pierre studied piano in Paris, debuting at the Opera de Nice in 1958, before going on to perform at prestigious opera houses in Paris, London, New York, and Vienna. A vocal advocate for black artists, she believed that increased representation on stage would eventually lead to greater acceptance.

site_title: Australia employment eases again, weekly payroll data shows
summary: Australia's employment rate eased again, falling 0.4% in the month to Aug 22, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Payroll jobs in Victoria decreased 2% and rose 0.1% for the rest of Australia. The rate of job losses in the state slowed from a month ago. Payroll jobs in Victoria are 7.9% below the pre-pandemic level, while the rest of Australia remains 2.9% below.

site_title: China unveils global data security initiative, says some countries bullying others
summary: China has announced a global data security initiative to establish standards on data security, amid criticism of US actions against Chinese tech companies. The initiative calls for technology firms to prevent backdoors and respect data management rights of other countries. China claims individual countries are "bullying" others and "hunting" companies, and seeks universal participation in global data security rules. The move comes after the US purged "untrusted" Chinese apps under its "Clean Network" program.

site_title: Eyeing China, Taiwan urges alliance against 'aggressive actions'
summary: Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen called for an alliance of democracies to counter "aggressive actions" by China, citing threats to regional stability in the South China Sea and Taiwan Strait. China claims democratic Taiwan as its own, increasing military activities around the island. Tsai urged like-minded countries to discuss a framework for cooperation, transparency, and dialogue to deter unilateral aggressive actions. This comes as Taiwan seeks closer ties with democracies like the US, Australia, and Japan, which have moral support but no formal diplomatic ties.

site_title: Financial health - the foundation for Singapore's workforce and the future of work
summary: Singapore's workforce is shifting towards a more flexible and autonomous future, with the gig economy and automation on the rise. The country's financial health is crucial for workers to adapt to these changes. A study by PayPal found that 60% of Singapore companies are investing in automation, and 43% are redesigning jobs to focus on critical skills. To support workers, tailored financial products and financial literacy are essential, with a focus on underserved segments such as entrepreneurs and freelancers. The government and financial institutions must partner to create personalized experiences and educate users on financial products.

site_title: Jump in hottest Hong Kong IPO makes founder China's second richest
summary: Hong Kong-based bottled water company Nongfu Spring's IPO has made founder Zhong Shanshan the second-richest person in China, with a net worth of nearly $54 billion. The company's stock surged 85% in its debut, making it the hottest IPO in Hong Kong this year. Zhong, who owns 84% of the company, has a unique background, having dropped out of school during the Cultural Revolution and worked in construction and journalism before founding Nongfu in 1996. The IPO has also created at least 68 new millionaires.

site_title: EMA invites proposals that could help firms improve energy efficiency by 50% by 2030
summary: The Energy Market Authority (EMA) in Singapore is launching the Singapore Energy Grand Challenge (SEGC) to improve energy efficiency by 50% by 2030. The challenge invites proposals in three areas: energy-efficient technologies, system design optimization, and digitalization. Selected proposals will receive a grant to develop and commercialize solutions. The challenge aims to support Singapore's sustainable energy future and is aligned with the Singapore Together initiative. Proposals must be submitted by December 1, 2020.

site_title: US may ban cotton from Xinjiang region of China over rights concerns
summary: The US is considering a ban on cotton from the Xinjiang region of China due to alleged human rights violations. The move, potentially implemented as soon as Tuesday, would punish China for its crackdown on Muslim minorities. The ban could affect a wide range of apparel products and has significant implications for global clothing brands relying on Xinjiang cotton. The Trump administration has taken a harder stance on China ahead of the presidential election, citing human rights abuses and national security risks.

images.alt_text: The Trump administration is weighing a ban on some or all products made with cotton from the Xinjiang region of China, a move that could come as soon as Tuesday as the United States looks to punish Beijing over alleged human rights violations, three people familiar with the matter said.

site_title: Yanlord's contracted pre-sales more than double to 12.03b yuan in August
summary: Yanlord Land Group saw its contracted pre-sales more than double to 12.03 billion yuan in August, from 4.81 billion yuan a year ago, with total contracted GFA rising 75.6% to 280,819 sq m. Pre-sales for the eight months ended August increased 73.5% to 47.77 billion yuan, with key contributors being five Chinese cities. The company's shares closed at S$1.16, down 0.9% before the announcement.

site_title: New virus cases knock hopes of reviving Southeast Asia's holiday hotspots
summary: Southeast Asian holiday hotspots, particularly Indonesia's Bali and Thailand, face setbacks in reviving their tourism industries due to a spike in coronavirus infections. Indonesia's plans to reopen Bali to foreign tourists have been postponed, and Thailand's proposal to reopen Phuket island has come into doubt. The increase in domestic tourism in Bali is seen as a contributing factor to the spike in cases, with experts citing the country's shortcomings in testing and contract tracing, as well as the arrival of the more infectious D614G mutation.

site_title: Asia: Markets edge back after rout, pound struggles
summary: Asian markets edged higher on Tuesday, rebounding from last week's steep drops, despite US President Donald Trump's latest anti-China remarks. Sterling struggled to recover from Brexit-related losses, but analysts believe the UK and EU will reach a trade deal. Central banks' support for monetary policy and the ongoing economic recovery efforts have kept investors cautious, with tech firms benefiting from the pandemic. Markets expect a slower sell-off than earlier in the year, with the Federal Reserve providing a safety net for investors.

site_title: Gold eases on firmer dollar; recovery worries limit losses
summary: Gold prices fell 0.2% to $1,925.09 per ounce, weighed down by a stronger US dollar, but fears over the global economic recovery from the coronavirus crisis limited losses. A stronger US dollar has been a significant factor, according to currency strategist Ilya Spivak. Despite this, gold prices remain stable due to concerns over the economic recovery, which has been a major driver of gold prices in recent months.

site_title: Syrian olive trees put down roots in Kurdish Iraq
summary: Tens of thousands of olive trees, smuggled from Syria, have been planted in Kurdish Iraq, providing a new homeland for the trees and a thriving olive oil business. The trees, now mature, are ready to be picked, and their caretaker, Suleiman Sheikho, is proud to have brought the industry to Iraq's autonomous north. This move is seen as a symbol of hope and resilience for the Syrian Kurdish community.

site_title: DBS rolls out savings and healthcare solutions for gig workers
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, has launched financial and healthcare solutions to support gig economy workers amid the pandemic. The bank's DBS Multiplier programme now allows gig workers to earn higher interest on their balances with lower transaction thresholds and easier access to healthcare insurance plans. DBS has also partnered with healthcare providers to offer exclusive member consultation rates and bundled deals for gig workers and their families. The bank aims to provide accessible solutions to financially vulnerable customers and help them safeguard their financial and healthcare interests.

site_title: Generator maker VibroPower proposes S$1.3m placement
summary: VibroPower Corporation, a power generator set manufacturer, is proposing a private placement of up to 9.5 million shares to two subscribers, Wong Kim Siong and Wong Chong Heng, for an aggregate cash consideration of S$1.3 million. The issue price is 13.2 Singapore cents per share, a 10% discount to the volume-weighted average price on Monday. Following the placement, Wong Kim Siong will hold an 11% stake and Wong Chong Heng a 3.9% stake. The proceeds will be used for working capital or financing acquisitions or investments.

site_title: Starbucks adds plant-based items to Asian menus from Beyond Meat, others
summary: Starbucks is introducing plant-based food and beverages to its Asian menus, starting in September, in markets such as Hong Kong, Singapore, and Taiwan. The new items, including Impossible Foods and Oatly products, will cater to environmentally conscious diners and suit local tastes. The Seattle-based coffee chain has already begun offering plant-based meals in Canada and will expand to China. The initiative aims to reduce the environmental impact of its food offerings.

images.alt_text: Starbucks said on Tuesday it will add plant-based food and beverages to menus across Asia from September, including products from Impossible Foods, Oatly and Beyond Meat, as it targets more environment-conscious diners.

site_title: Moody's changes FCT outlook to stable, affirms Baa2 rating on AsiaRetail Fund deal
summary: Moody's has affirmed Frasers Centrepoint Trust's (FCT) Baa2 issuer rating and changed its outlook to stable from negative. The rating agency considers the trust's planned equity issuance and asset disposal, which will enhance liquidity and improve tenant sales and shopper traffic at its malls. FCT's proposed acquisition of the PGIM Real Estate Asia Retail Fund and its increased asset size to S$6.6 billion are expected to improve its business profile, but its leverage will remain elevated for 12-18 months.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.56 points to 1,516.94. Volume reached 153.21 million lots worth RM57.80 million. The market saw a slight edge in gains over losses, with 232 gainers outpacing 62 losers.

site_title: Standard Chartered fined 1b rupees in India for 2007 deal
summary: Standard Chartered has been fined 1 billion rupees (S$18.6 million) by India's anti-money laundering agency for violating foreign exchange rules in 2007. The bank worked on the takeover of Tamilnad Mercantile Bank, and senior officials saw an investment as a potential larger ownership. Standard Chartered acted as a custodian and transaction agent, and some shares were transferred without permission from India's central bank. The eight-year probe found the bank's actions constituted a breach of the foreign exchange management act. The bank is evaluating the fine and has not commented further.

site_title: US aviation authority investigating Boeing 787 manufacturing flaws
summary: The US aviation authority is investigating Boeing 787 manufacturing flaws after the company reported eight planes did not conform to its production standards. The issue involves quality control errors potentially lasting 10 years, and the regulator may inspect hundreds of planes. Boeing has notified airlines and temporarily removed the affected planes from service for repairs. The investigation could lead to enhanced inspections and potential Airworthiness Directives, although the FAA has declined to speculate on the nature of the proposed directives.

site_title: StanChart's global head of commodities business to leave as team restructured
summary: Standard Chartered's global head of commodities business, Cengiz Belentepe, is leaving the bank as part of a restructuring effort. Belentepe's departure follows a four-year stint and coincides with changes to the bank's financial markets division. The bank's commodities business will be integrated with the financial markets unit, with some commodities staff members switching divisions. This move comes as global banks restructure their commodities businesses to cut risk following a series of commodity trader collapses and the impact of the coronavirus crisis.

site_title: Japan ruling party launches race for Abe's successor
summary: Japan's ruling party has begun the process of selecting Shinzo Abe's successor, with Yoshihide Suga leading the race after securing support from major factions. Suga, a 71-year-old former aide to Abe, faces opposition from former defense minister Shigeru Ishiba and policy chief Fumio Kishida. The winner will likely win a parliamentary vote on September 16 and become the country's next prime minister, facing challenges such as the coronavirus pandemic and a tanking economy. Suga plans to carry forward Abe's policies, with Ishiba and Kishida proposing targeted stimulus measures to address the crisis.

site_title: Bank of England chief economist warns against extending furlough programme
summary: Bank of England chief economist Andy Haldane warned against extending the UK's furlough programme, citing the risk of prolonging the "inevitable" process of job adjustments. He suggested UK firms consider wage restraint or reduced hours instead of job cuts. The BOE forecasts unemployment could nearly double to 7.5% by the end of the year. Chancellor Rishi Sunak faces pressure to continue subsidizing wages beyond October 31, when the programme is scheduled to end, amid Germany's extension of its equivalent programme until 2021.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, driven by rallies in European markets. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.33% to 23,165.57, while the Topix index gained 0.16% to 1,612.34. The US markets were closed for the Labour Day holiday.

site_title: Keppel Reit to issue S$150m 3.15% subordinated perps
summary: Keppel Reit has priced S$150 million of fixed-rate subordinated perpetual securities at 3.15% per annum. The securities are expected to be issued at par on Sept 11 and listed on the Singapore bourse on or around Sept 14. Net proceeds will be used to refinance existing S$150 million subordinated perps. The perps have no fixed final redemption date, and the issuer may opt to redeem them at par on Sept 11, 2025, or on any distribution date thereafter.

site_title: Australia: Shares extend gains on Covid-19 vaccine optimism
summary: Australian shares rose for a second session, driven by optimism over potential Covid-19 vaccines, with the S&P/ASX 200 index climbing 1% to 6,007.10. The country agreed to buy 85 million vaccine doses and CSL will manufacture them, with miners and financials leading the charge. Heavyweight firms like BHP, Rio Tinto, and Commonwealth Bank rose 1-1.4%, while CSL added 1.5%. The Australian government also reported its lowest one-day rise in new Covid-19 cases since June 26.

site_title: Striking trainee doctors return to work as South Korea battles second virus wave
summary: Thousands of trainee doctors in South Korea returned to work after a two-week strike, amid a surge in new daily coronavirus infections. The Korea Center for Disease Control and Prevention reported 136 new cases, a three-week low. The strike, launched by 16,000 intern and resident doctors, aimed to protest government medical reform proposals. The daily tally has steadily dropped since a peak in August, but cluster infections have increased fivefold. Authorities are weighing whether to extend social distancing curbs ahead of the Chuseok holiday, which would see tens of millions of people travel nationwide.

site_title: UK recovery from lockdown deserves more credit: BoE's Haldane
summary: Bank of England chief economist Andy Haldane has expressed optimism about the UK's recovery from the coronavirus lockdown, stating that the economy has "bounced back" due to consumers' resilience and adaptability. This contradicts some colleagues' concerns that the economy may take longer to recover than forecast. Haldane believes extending the job retention scheme would hinder the necessary labor market adjustment, and some businesses may not survive. The Bank of England has backed the plan to wind down the scheme by the end of next month.

site_title: Hong Lai Huat inks MOU for livestock, seed production in Cambodia
summary: Hong Lai Huat Group, a Singapore-based real estate and agriculture firm, has signed a non-binding memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Denmark-based farm equipment supplier Skiold to collaborate on a proposed Cambodia-Singapore Agriculture Special Economic Zone with an estimated investment value of US$1 billion. The two companies will focus on setting up livestock and seed production in the next six months, with the goal of enhancing trade, economic cooperation, and job opportunities in the poultry, cattle farming, and seed processing sectors.

site_title: Singapore shares edge up at Tuesday's open; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.2% to 2,515.36 at Tuesday's open, driven by a gain of 4.15 points. Despite private-sector economists expecting a 6% GDP contraction this year, the market edged higher. Oceanus Group and Kitchen Culture were among the top gainers, while DBS and OCBC were among the local lenders to make gains. Asian banks are seen conserving capital but may have opportunities to raise debt from yield-starved investors.

site_title: Espressif seeks talent for Singapore R&D office
summary: Espressif Systems, a China-based fabless semiconductor firm, plans to hire 80 engineers over the next two years for a research and development centre in Singapore. Founded by Singaporean Teo Swee Ann, the company has already started hiring in the city-state but has no specific launch date. This move aims to strengthen the company's presence in the region and tap into Singapore's growing tech industry.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Tuesday, following a healthy gain in Europe. The Hang Sang Index rose 0.80% to 24,785.26, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased. The gains came after last week's sharp losses, with traders picking up bargains.

site_title: Trump, Biden trade blows as White House race hits final stretch
summary: US President Donald Trump and Democratic challenger Joe Biden engaged in a heated exchange on Monday, trading insults and criticizing each other's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic. Trump accused Biden of lacking "guts" to tackle the pandemic, while Biden called Trump "stupid" and questioned his safety record. The exchange came as the two candidates focused on key battleground states, including Pennsylvania and Wisconsin, with the US presidential election just over a month away.

site_title: UK ramps up no deal preparations as EU trade talks stall
summary: The UK government will inform the EU that progress must be made in trade talks by Tuesday or preparations for a no-deal Brexit will be stepped up by the end of the year. The UK has been in talks with the EU since January, but disagreements over state-aid rules and fishing rights have hindered progress. Britain's main EU trade negotiator, David Frost, stated that the UK will trade on terms similar to Australia's if no agreement is reached, and Prime Minister Boris Johnson has set a deadline of October 15 for a deal.

site_title: How a Vietnamese logistics giant is staying nimble during a pandemic
summary: Vietnamese logistics giant Scommerce has navigated the challenges of the COVID-19 pandemic relatively unscathed, thanks to its nimble operations and strategic partnerships. The company credits Standard Chartered, its banking partner, for providing essential financing solutions and support. Scommerce has leveraged its early-mover advantage and technology-driven approach to maintain its market position, despite increasing competition from regional players and e-commerce platforms. With investments in automation and technology, the company aims to continue providing reliable services to online merchants and omnichannel businesses, staying ahead of the curve in the rapidly evolving logistics landscape.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembmarine, Sembcorp, Keppel Reit, Yanlord, Top Glove
summary: Sembcorp Marine's rights issue of shares to recapitalize the company was undersubscribed, with valid acceptances and excess applications for 90.2% of available shares. Keppel Reit priced its subordinated perpetual securities at 3.15%. DBS, UOB, and OCBC are expected to consider rights issues and private placements to raise fresh equity amid the pandemic. Top Glove submitted an audit report on its labor practices, and Yanlord Land Group saw its contracted presales more than double to 12.03 billion yuan.

site_title: Logos prices S$120m three-year guaranteed notes at 6%
summary: LOGOS Holdco Pte Ltd issued S$120 million in three-year senior unsecured notes at a 6% coupon rate, guaranteed by Logos Property Group. The notes mature on Sept 15, 2023, and come under Logos Holdco's S$1 billion multicurrency debt issuance programme.

site_title: India palm imports drop from 10-month high on weak food demand
summary: India's palm oil imports dropped 11% in August to 734,000 tonnes, the lowest in 10 months, due to a slow recovery of the food services industry. This decrease may boost stockpiles in top growers Indonesia and Malaysia, potentially curbing gains in palm oil prices. The decline follows replenishing reserves in July and comes as optimism for steadily rising demand for palm oil has led to a 22% price increase this quarter.

site_title: Japan's Suga signals chance of calling snap election: Asahi
summary: Japan's Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga signaled the possibility of calling a snap election if he becomes the country's next prime minister, according to a report by the Asahi newspaper. Suga, a frontrunner to succeed Shinzo Abe, emphasized the need to contain the pandemic before making a decision. He also expressed resolve to host the 2021 Tokyo Olympic Games despite the pandemic challenges. Suga is expected to win the Liberal Democratic Party's leadership election on September 14, solidifying his position as prime minister.

images.alt_text: Japan's chief cabinet secretary Yoshihide Suga signalled the possibility of calling a snap election if he were to become the country's next prime minister, the Asahi newspaper reported on Tuesday.

site_title: China tension may hit half of Australia's benchmark stock index
summary: Tensions between Australia and China, fueled by a dispute over the origins of the coronavirus, are impacting the nation's benchmark stock index, the S&P/ASX 200. The deterioration of their relationship affects around 55% of the index, including banks, consumer firms, and tourism-related stocks. Analysts predict declining demand for Australian products, such as wine, infant formula, and coal, may negatively impact companies like Treasury Wine Estates, Seek, A2 Milk, Blackmores, Aurizon Holdings, and Qantas Airways. The economic impact is expected to worsen if China's immigration and tourism decline, which could affect house prices and financial firms.

site_title: Biden has 71.1% chance of winning US election: FiveThirtyEight
summary: Joe Biden has a 71.1% chance of winning the US Electoral College, according to FiveThirtyEight's election forecasting model, with a predicted 334 electoral votes. Donald Trump's chances are at 28.4%. Biden is also predicted to win the popular vote with 84.1%, while Trump's chances are 15.9%. The models' predictions are based on national polling averages, with Biden at 50.6% and Trump at 42.9%.

site_title: Saudi Khashoggi ruling far from expectations: Turkey
summary: Turkey expressed disappointment with a Saudi court ruling that overturned five death sentences in the 2018 murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, stating it fell short of global expectations. The ruling handed jail terms of 7-20 years to eight unnamed defendants, following the sons of Khashoggi pardoning the killers in May. The verdict came after a trial in absentia for 20 Saudi nationals, including two former aides to Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, who denies involvement. Turkey urges Saudi authorities to cooperate with its investigation into the killing.

site_title: Swift response, adaptable workforce needed to innovate amid pandemic
summary: Business leaders emphasize the need for companies to have a swift response and adaptable workforce to innovate amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Companies that have embraced digitalization have seized new opportunities, with AirAsia and DBS Bank showcasing their digital transformation strategies. The panel highlighted the importance of having a clear purpose, adaptable employees, and a strong social conscience to navigate the changing landscape. The Asean region is expected to see growth driven by population growth, middle-class consumption, and regional integration, but closer collaboration among member countries is needed to unlock its full potential.

site_title: STI ends on a flat note as caution prevails
summary: The Singapore Straits Times Index (STI) ended on a flat note at 2,511.21, with a 0.06% gain, amid a wait-and-see stance due to pandemic-induced economic concerns and escalating US-China tech war risks. Key Asian markets had mixed performances, with China's Shanghai Composite losing 1.9%. Trading volume was 1.32 billion shares worth S$780.8 million, with OCBC and Capitaland Commercial Trust (CCT) contributing to the gains.

site_title: Europe: Shares end higher for first time in three sessions
summary: European shares rose for the first time in three sessions, driven by economic green shoots and Covid-19 vaccine developments. The Stoxx 600 index gained 1.7%, with AstraZeneca jumping 4% and Sanofi rising 2.4% after a coronavirus vaccine price estimate. Autos led sectoral gains, while telecoms rose the least, indicating a risk-on mood. Despite data showing German industrial output rose less than expected, the market lifted from a Wall Street-led rout in technology stocks.

images.alt_text: European shares rose for the first time in three sessions on Monday, bouncing from a Wall Street-led rout in technology stocks in the previous week as investors focused on economic green shoots and Covid-19 vaccine developments.

site_title: Mbappe to miss Croatia match after positive Covid-19 test
summary: Kylian Mbappe has been ruled out of France's Nations League game against Croatia due to a positive Covid-19 test. Mbappe, the seventh Paris Saint-Germain player to contract the virus, will self-isolate for eight days and miss PSG's Ligue 1 opener and potentially Sunday's clash with Marseille. This is the fourth player to be withdrawn from the France squad following a positive Covid-19 test, following Paul Pogba, Houssem Aouar, and Steve Mandanda.

images.alt_text: Kylian Mbappe has been ruled out of France's Nations League game against World Cup runners-up Croatia on Tuesday after testing positive for Covid-19, national team management said on Monday.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Camsing Healthcare's shares remain suspended as the company works to meet conditions set in three notices of compliance. A special audit report by RSM Corporate Advisory identified internal control lapses and potential breaches of listing rules, recommending external professionals for internal audits. The company's audit committee aims to appoint an independent firm by December 1 to conduct an independent review.

site_title: Oil falls after Saudi cuts prices, China slows imports
summary: Oil prices fell Monday after Saudi Arabia cut prices for Asia by the most in five months, with Brent crude trading at $42.03 a barrel and US crude at $39.10 per barrel. China, the world's biggest oil importer, slowed its imports in August, casting uncertainty over the market's recovery. Analysts attributed the price cuts to a slowing demand recovery in Asia and a lack of optimism over the Chinese economy. US companies also increased drilling for new supply, putting downward pressure on prices.

site_title: 5G deployment, cloud computing to drive Asian technology sector: Credit Suisse
summary: Credit Suisse analysts predict the Asian technology sector will remain resilient despite the Covid-19 pandemic, driven by accelerating 5G deployments and increased adoption of cloud computing. The sector is expected to see a more robust recovery next year, with broader economic growth. However, supply-chain risks loom on the horizon.

site_title: Japan's Q2 GDP revised down to annualised 28.1% contraction
summary: Japan's economy shrank 28.1% in the second quarter, more than initially estimated, due to a 4.7% drop in capital expenditure. This marks the worst postwar contraction. Household spending and wages also fell in July, highlighting the pandemic's impact on consumption. The data poses a challenge for the new prime minister, who must balance pandemic control with business restrictions. The Bank of Japan is set to review monetary settings next week, with no expected changes. The economic contraction is a concern for policymakers and the country's third-largest economy.

site_title: Spain's property portals register record usage despite real estate slump
summary: Spain's property portals, Fotocasa and Idealista, have reported record user activity despite a real estate slump. User traffic on Fotocasa increased 40% year-over-year in June, while online mortgage requests jumped 20% higher than normal. However, house sales plummeted 43% to 75,000 in the second quarter, and prices stagnated, with average quarterly growth rate at 0.44%. Financing remains hard to come by, and rising household debt has led to reluctance to sell properties, while prospective buyers struggle with tougher lending requirements.

site_title: US$200b IPO for Ant will be a cheap buy
summary: Ant Group, a Chinese fintech company, is set to become the largest IPO in history with a valuation of over $200 billion.
