Despite being a young company, Ant generated $17 billion in revenue in 2019 and a profit of $2.5 billion. The company's success can be attributed to its product Alipay, which has captured a large share of China's mobile payments market. Ant's diversification into financial services and its focus on integrating third-party providers have made it a profitable and scalable company. The IPO is seen as a strategic move to expand into underbanked markets in Southeast Asia and India, and to provide technologies and operational expertise to other mobile startups.

site_title: The case of the missing ESG
summary: Investors seeking clean investments are increasingly scrutinizing companies' environmental, social, and governance (ESG) credentials, with demand surging for companies that perform well on these issues. ESG-focused funds now manage over $1.1 trillion, up from $550 million in 2016. However, the system has flaws, with inconsistencies between ESG scores and reality, and some providers relying on self-reporting by companies. Experts, like Sasja Beslik, are taking a hands-on approach, conducting on-the-ground investigations to uncover issues and push companies to improve their ESG practices.

site_title: Djokovic out of US Open after accidentally hitting line judge
summary: Novak Djokovic was disqualified from the US Open after accidentally hitting a line judge in the throat during a match against Pablo Carreno Busta. The incident occurred when Djokovic reacted angrily to having his serve broken, and he was later found to have hit the ball recklessly and angrily. Djokovic apologized and was fined $250,000 and lost ranking points, ending his 26-match winning streak in 2020. The disqualification was deemed correct by the tournament officials and former champions, who considered it a breach of Grand Slam rules.

site_title: HSBC Life Singapore appoints CIO, chief product officer
summary: HSBC Life Singapore has appointed Philip Pang as chief investment officer and How Chee Koon as chief product officer. Pang, with over 15 years of experience, will oversee investment strategy, while How, with nearly 15 years of life insurance experience, will implement new product developments. The appointments aim to drive growth and improve customer experience, supporting HSBC's wealth ambition to become the top wealth management provider in Asia. The move also enables closer collaboration with HSBC's retail, private banking, and asset management units to develop innovative solutions for customers.

site_title: A closer Asean will help region thrive post-pandemic
summary: ASEAN nations need better coordination and integration to recover from the pandemic and thrive post-Covid. Stronger cooperation on health infrastructure, supply chains, and regulations will help the region avoid a long recovery. While policymakers have taken steps to support economies, a solvency crisis remains a risk if economic activity doesn't recover before support measures expire. ASEAN's economic recovery is expected to be bumpy and long-drawn out, with real GDP only recovering to pre-Covid-19 levels in late 2021 or early 2022. A successful conclusion to the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) by the end of the year will demonstrate Asean's commitment to multilateralism and boost recovery prospects.

site_title: China's Aug exports rise at fastest pace in nearly 1.5 years, but imports slump
summary: China's exports rose 9.5% in August, the fastest pace in nearly 1.5 years, beating expectations of 7.1% growth. Imports slumped 2.1%, extending a 1.4% fall in July. The strong exports suggest a faster and more balanced recovery for the Chinese economy, but imports' decline points to softer domestic demand. China's trade surplus rose to $58.93 billion, despite ongoing US-China tensions and heightened external risks.

site_title: SoftBank shares slide as its bets on tech stock options unnerve investors
summary: SoftBank shares plummeted 7% as investors grew uneasy over the conglomerate's aggressive bets on tech stock options, despite generating $4 billion in trading gains. The group's options exposure of $50 billion made investors uncomfortable, with some analysts warning of a tech bubble. Despite a record share buyback, SoftBank's shares fell below 6,000 yen for the first time in two months, closing at 5,881 yen. The decline was the biggest loser on the benchmark index, which closed down 0.5%.

site_title: Tourism spillover from Mice restart will be minimal: analysts
summary: Singapore will allow Mice events from October with an attendance cap of 250, aiming to boost the economy and retain jobs. However, analysts warn that the economic spillover to industries like food and beverage services will be minimal due to limited international travel. The sector's reopening is seen as a "baby step" with significant constraints still in place, and business tourism may precede mass-market tourism recovery, yielding only "muted economic spin-offs" in the near term.

site_title: Facebook campus hotel a bet on comeback for business travel
summary: CitizenM, a tech-forward hotel brand, is betting on a future for business travel despite the pandemic's impact on corporate travel. The company plans to open hotels across the US, focusing on tech companies and remote workers who will need hotel rooms for periodic visits to headquarters. This approach is seen as a way to increase demand for hotels, which have been battered by Covid-19. CitizenM aims to double its footprint in the next five years, developing properties with automated check-ins and social spaces.

site_title: Johnson sets Oct 15 deadline for Brexit deal
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has set an October 15 deadline for a post-Brexit trade agreement with the European Union, warning that talks will fail if no agreement is reached by then. The UK's chief negotiator, David Frost, has refused to compromise on London's red lines, and Brussels has indicated that mid-October is the latest for a deal. If talks break down, Britain will have an "Australia-style" deal with the EU or similar agreements with other countries, with no tariffs or quotas. Johnson's warning compounds criticisms from pro-EU "remainers" that his government envisaged a "no-deal" scenario.

site_title: Saudi Telecom seeks to cut US$2.39b offer for Vodafone Egypt
summary: Saudi Telecom is discussing a potential reduction of its non-binding $2.39 billion offer for a stake in Vodafone Egypt, which was first made in January. The deadline for STC to move forward with the offer is nearing due to the coronavirus pandemic. Egyptian market regulations require STC to submit a mandatory tender offer for all of Vodafone Egypt, including the stake held by Telecom Egypt. The company had previously valued the Egyptian business at $4.35 billion. Details of the negotiations remain unclear.

site_title: Australia turns to idled factories to pull it out of Covid-19 slump
summary: Australia is reviving its manufacturing sector by leveraging idled factories to boost the economy amid the COVID-19 slump. This move comes three years after the last car was produced in the country, marking a shift in industry support. However, businesses emphasize that reforms are necessary to make manufacturing competitive globally. Policymakers aim to drive growth through this initiative, which is expected to help the country recover from its record-low slump.

site_title: FWD acquires minority stake in financial advisory firm IPP Financial Advisers
summary: FWD Insurance has acquired a minority stake in financial advisory firm IPP Financial Advisers, bolstering its growth and expansion in Singapore and the region. The partnership will integrate FWD's technology solutions, simplifying customer processes, and strengthen IPPFA's professional staffing and technology capabilities. The alliance aims to expand IPPFA's financial services business in Singapore and design life insurance products that meet evolving client needs. IPPFA will retain its open architecture status, and FWD will benefit from enhanced market knowledge and expertise.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: All 4,700 slots for virtual OCBC Cycle taken up
summary: OCBC Cycle Virtual Ride has reached maximum capacity with all 4,700 slots taken up, a month ahead of the scheduled closing of registration. The event, which takes place from Nov 1-15, offers three categories: Sportive VR (42km), The Straits Times Ride VR (23km), and The Mighty Savers Kids VR (5km and 800m). The virtual cycling fiesta aims to provide a safe and enjoyable experience for participants, despite the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Samsung Elec wins US$6.6b Verizon order for network equipment
summary: Samsung Electronics won a $6.64 billion contract to provide wireless communication solutions to Verizon in the US, a major win in the 5G network market. The order, which includes network equipment, is for a period of 5 years. The deal is seen as a boost to Samsung's global prospects, particularly after US sanctions on rival Huawei. Analysts say the order could give Samsung leverage to negotiate with other countries, expanding its telecom equipment business abroad.

site_title: Global solidarity: The way forward for a green recovery
summary: The article highlights the importance of global solidarity in building a better future after the Covid-19 pandemic. The European Union has proposed a green recovery plan, Next Generation EU, to invest 25% of its budget in climate investments. The plan aims to accelerate the transition to a safer, more resilient economy and promote multilateralism. The EU is also engaging with partners like Singapore to drive green recovery, sharing lessons and promoting a global green recovery in international settings. The article emphasizes the need for collective responses and staying true to values, listening to science, and rebuilding economies to build a better future.

site_title: Job policies seen as key to supporting re-hiring, even as layoffs re-entry rate holds up
summary: The re-employment rate for laid-off workers in Singapore held steady at 39% in the first half of 2020, despite the Covid-19 downturn. While hiring slowed in the second quarter, a significant number of retrenched workers found jobs, with most staying in the same occupation. However, some workers had to switch industries or take pay cuts. Experts attribute the strong re-employment trend to government job support measures and the hiring intentions of thriving industries. The Ministry of Manpower expects the re-employment rate to pick up with the extension of hiring incentives and other measures to support retrenched workers.

site_title: Airplane cabins could look different the next time you fly
summary: Airlines are considering installing new seat modifications, such as headrest canopies and fabric barriers, to reassure passengers about flying during the coronavirus pandemic. Companies like Recaro Aircraft Seating GmbH are designing temporary cabin makeovers to keep passengers apart and protect them from infection. With a potential vaccine years away, airlines aim to prove flying is safe, despite sporadic outbreaks on flights. Revenue for Recaro is expected to drop 60% this year, but the company sees interest from across the regions for its designs.

site_title: China's first homegrown nuclear reactor begins loading fuel
summary: China's first homegrown nuclear reactor, the Hualong One, began loading fuel at the Fuqing No 5 reactor on September 4, marking a significant step forward in the country's nuclear technology. The reactor, developed by China National Nuclear Power Co, secured an operating license from the Ministry of Ecology & Environment. This development is closely watched, as the success of Hualong One could lead to a nuclear revival in China, potentially surpassing France and the US as the world's top nuclear generator.

site_title: A no-deal Brexit comes into view again
summary: A new round of UK-EU Brexit negotiations is set to begin, with no major progress made on key issues such as 'level playing field' rules and fishing rights, potentially leading to a no-deal Brexit. The UK and EU have been preparing for a no-deal scenario since 2018, with preparations including publishing technical notices on how public bodies, businesses, and individuals need to prepare. A no-deal would have significant impacts, including increased border checks, tariffs, and disruptions to transport and flights, and could tip the UK economy into recession.

site_title: Singapore investors snapping up Australia commercial properties despite pandemic
summary: Singapore investors have continued to show interest in Australian commercial real estate despite the COVID-19 pandemic, with a total of A$1.2 billion (S$1.19 billion) poured into assets in the first half of 2020. This represents a significant increase from the same period last year. The trend is attributed to Singapore investors' attraction to the relative strength of the Australian economy, high market transparency, and attractive returns. Despite the economic downturn, investors remain optimistic about the long-term potential of the Australian office sector, with many seeking to capitalize on the increased demand for long-term leases.

site_title: Navigating the shifts in commercial landlord-tenant dynamics
summary: The Singapore office market has shifted from a landlord-friendly to a tenant-friendly market due to the COVID-19 pandemic and the rise of working from home. Leasing activity has softened, and many corporate occupiers are reviewing their footprint needs and looking to consolidate space. Landlords are responding by focusing on client needs and exploring co-working or club space as a solution. The market is also expected to see a rise in smaller, fit-for-purpose offices tailored to specific functions, with a focus on wellbeing, intelligent building management, and amenities.

images.alt_text: Some landlords are proactively engaging with tenants on their needs. The net result is the landlord-tenant relationship will, by necessity, become more fluid.

site_title: Worst is over for Singapore listcos' earnings: DBS
summary: DBS Group Research says the worst is over for Singapore-listed companies' earnings, despite a 14.9% FY20 cut in forecast earnings due to global Covid-19 lockdowns. Analysts expect a 17.9% upside for the Straits Times Index, with Maybank Kim Eng raising its target to 2,995. The Q2 results season has ended, and companies have reported deep cuts in earnings, but DBS believes the worst is now behind them.

site_title: SGInnovate to create more jobs, traineeships in deep tech industry
summary: SGInnovate has launched initiatives to create more job opportunities in the deep tech industry, including over 200 apprenticeships and full-time roles in 30 companies and startups. The "New Frontier: Deep Tech Opportunities and Jobs" event will feature panel discussions, workshops, and virtual booths to help participants understand the industry and receive training in areas such as AI and cyber security. Additionally, SGInnovate has launched Power X, a 9-month full-time traineeship programme to equip Singaporean talents with essential skills in deep-tech domains, with the first run focusing on robotics engineering.

site_title: Private-sector economists lower full-year growth forecast to -6%
summary: Private-sector economists in Singapore have lowered their full-year GDP forecast to -6% due to a worsening economic contraction. The expected recovery in 2021 is now predicted at 5.5%, up from 4.8% previously, with a significant degree of uncertainty attached to the outcome. Key sectors such as construction, private consumption, and accommodation and food services are expected to contract more sharply, while finance, insurance, and manufacturing are forecast to grow. Non-oil domestic exports are predicted to grow 4.5%, driven by a brighter electronics exports outlook.

site_title: Auditor-General flags public agencies' lapses in IT controls, procurement
summary: The Auditor-General's Office in Singapore has flagged weaknesses in IT controls, procurement, contract, and operations management at various government agencies, including JTC Corporation, PUB, and Workforce Singapore. The issues include misconfigurations of operating system user accounts, excessive rights granted to private-sector partners, and inadequate contract management and oversight. Despite these lapses, no confidential data was compromised, and remedial actions have been taken to address the issues.

site_title: The strange grief of losing my sense of taste
summary: A writer, who tested positive for Covid-19, lost her sense of taste and smell, leaving her with a sense of grief and longing for familiar flavors and aromas. Despite searching for solutions, including smell training, her abilities have yet to return. The loss of taste has affected her connection to life and her appreciation for the pleasures of Las Vegas, a city centered around taste. The writer reflects on the impact of anosmia, or smell blindness, as a metaphor for the world during Covid-19, where many have lost their sense of normalcy and pleasure.

site_title: Full steam ahead: Legend still on expansionary path despite Covid
summary: Legend Logistics, a Singapore-based integrated logistics group, remains on an expansionary path despite the challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic. The company attributes its continued growth to its innovative approach and continuous investment in technology. Legend's specialised logistics arm has secured a major milestone, winning a line haul contract for Australia's West Gate Tunnel project. The company is also exploring opportunities in the wind power sector and is expanding its presence in Indonesia and Southeast Asia. Legend is looking to build up its talent pool through Enterprise Singapore's Global Ready Talent Programme and is planning to deploy management associates to its overseas offices.

site_title: Growing non-aviation revenue streams will be key for Sats in near to mid-term
summary: Sats Ltd, a ground-handler and caterer, reported a net loss of S$43.7 million for the three months ended June 30, 2020, due to low aviation volumes and losses from associates in India and China. However, its non-aviation businesses saw a 73% revenue jump to S$96.9 million, driven by growth in new customer segments and the consolidation of Country Foods. The company is focusing on growing its non-aviation revenue to offset the decline in aviation businesses, with promising areas including institutional and commercial catering, and cargo services.

site_title: Singapore must stay open to talent to keep discovering its future
summary: Singapore's focus on curbing foreign workers is misguided, as the country relies on talent to discover its future. Historically, foreign workers, including those from Malacca, contributed significantly to the island's population growth. The current emphasis on a "Singaporean Core" may lead to stagnation, as businesses that rely on global supply chains and talent are crucial to the economy. Policymakers should instead focus on identifying future growth drivers and attracting talent from around the world to sustain Singapore's growth.

site_title: Asian banks have ample room to beef up capital: analysts
summary: Asian banks have sufficient capital to boost their reserves, but may consider issuing debt or equity to shore up their capital adequacy. Analysts predict that banks in the region will issue Tier 2 and AT1 instruments to refinance maturing debt and improve their capital ratios. Some banks, such as OCBC, have already raised significant amounts through debt issuance. However, equity issuance is less likely, as banks seek to avoid dilutive effects on minority shareholders. Moody's and Fitch Ratings suggest that banks will prioritize capital conservation over equity raising under current challenging operating conditions.

site_title: ECB slows bond purchases further in August lull
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) reduced its bond purchases in August by 26% to 78.6 billion euros, likely due to improved market conditions and seasonal patterns. This marks a decrease from July's 159 billion euros. The ECB has 850 billion euros left to spend under its Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme by next June, with no immediate plans to boost stimulus measures. Market conditions have improved since the pandemic-induced crash, reducing the need for further emergency purchases.

site_title: Euro falls as recent US dollar selling pauses
summary: The euro fell 0.2% to $1.1815 against the US dollar, after recent multi-year highs, as traders took a breather ahead of the European Central Bank's meeting on Thursday. The US dollar steadied, boosted by a slowdown in US employment growth and a rise in the jobless rate to 8.4%. Investors are watching the ECB meeting for signs of further stimulus, but no major policy changes are expected. The pound slid 1% to $1.3145 after Britain threatened to override its EU divorce deal.

site_title: Electric car warning signals as Denmark calculates cost of switch
summary: Denmark's government commission warns that a rapid switch to electric cars to meet climate targets will leave a massive gap in its finances, with a net loss of 5.7 billion crowns (S$10.8 billion) in 2030. The country relies heavily on car and road taxes to fund its welfare system, and increasing the number of electric cars to 1 million by 2030 would result in a significant problem for the economy. Denmark aims to cut emissions by 70% by 2030 and become climate neutral by 2050.

site_title: China plans cap on Ant's lending rates: sources
summary: China's financial regulators plan to cap interest rates on quick consumer loans made by Ant Group and other consumer lenders, potentially curbing the fintech giant's biggest revenue driver as it prepares for a mega IPO. The cap, linked to a benchmark rate of 15.4%, is part of a China Supreme Court ruling. The impact on fintech firms like Ant is unclear, but the move aims to curb high-interest lending.

site_title: China Evergrande offers 30% discount on all real estate properties
summary: China Evergrande Group has launched a nationwide sales promotion with a 30% discount on all real estate properties, part of its effort to boost sales and meet its debt reduction target. The promotion, which began on September 7 and will last until October 8, is the company's deepest ever discount since 2011. Evergrande aims to cut its debt by half by 2022, but has fallen short of its pledge, with total debt rising 4% to 835 billion yuan as of June 30.

images.alt_text: Hui Ka Yan, chairman of China Evergrande, has unveiled a sales target of at least 100b yuan for Sept and Oct respectively.

site_title: Merkel may impose sanctions on Russian gas pipeline
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel is considering imposing sanctions on Russia's Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline in response to the suspected poisoning of Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny. Merkel's chief spokesman, Steffen Seibert, said the chancellor shares Foreign Minister Heiko Maas' views that Russia must help clear up the circumstances surrounding Navalny's poisoning or face the possibility of Germany withdrawing support for the pipeline. The project, which is 90% complete, has split the European Union and may prove difficult to halt late in the project's development.

site_title: Siemens considers Bentley systems bid in new digital push
summary: Siemens is considering an acquisition of Bentley Systems, a developer of software to manage engineering projects, as part of its digital push. The deal, which would see Bentley become part of Siemens's digital industries division, has not been finalized and could still fail. Bentley generates $700 million in annual revenue and has over 3,500 employees. The acquisition would mark Siemens's first major software deal under incoming CEO Roland Busch, who is set to take over in February.

site_title: Welcome to the Annual General Lecture
summary: Singapore's annual general meetings (AGMs) have shifted to virtual "lectures" due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with only one company, Azeus Systems Holdings, using live Q&A and voting technology. Associate Professor Mak Yuen Teen advocates for a hybrid model, allowing shareholders to choose between in-person and online attendance. He believes the benefits of face-to-face meetings, such as interacting with directors and assessing their body language, should not be dismissed. The Ministry of Law plans to extend the timeframe for alternative arrangements until June 30 next year, but experts urge companies to improve the quality of AGMs to be more interactive.

site_title: Price transparency guidelines to fight misleading practices kick in from Nov 1
summary: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) has issued guidelines to combat misleading price practices in advertisements by businesses, effective November 1. The guidelines cover four areas: drip pricing, price comparisons, discounts, and free offers, requiring businesses to be transparent and upfront about fees, prices, and promotions. Errant retailers have up to two months to comply, with fines and court action possible for non-compliance, and the guidelines aim to build trust and credibility in the marketplace.

site_title: Nestle on track to meet sustainable packaging goal
summary: Nestle has made progress towards its goal of using 100% recyclable or reusable plastics in its packaging by 2025, increasing the share to 87% as of now. The company plans to reduce its use of new plastics by a third and spend up to $2.19 billion on recycled plastics. Nestle has also introduced innovative solutions, such as a refillable system for pet food in Chile and a new recyclable paper for Maggi bouillon cubes. Despite acknowledging plastic's role in packaging, the company aims to balance sustainability with product integrity and safety.

site_title: Top Glove submits audit report to US Customs and Border Protection
summary: Top Glove Corporation has submitted an audit report to the US Customs and Border Protection (CBP) regarding its labor practices towards migrant workers. The report, prepared by an independent consultant, covers interviews with 1,100 workers and is part of the company's efforts to resolve a detention order related to foreign labor issues. Top Glove has made remediation payments to migrant workers who joined before the company implemented a new recruitment standard in 2019, with the first payment of RM4.4 million (S$1.4 million) made on August 10.

site_title: Swiber and Rawabi extend term sheet discussions to Oct 6
summary: Swiber Holdings has extended discussions with Rawabi Holding Company by a month to Oct 6, a month after the binding term sheet for a US$200 million cash investment was set to expire. The discussions were due to a 90-day deadline after the June 8 term sheet entry. Swiber shares have been suspended since 2016.

site_title: Learn how to stay relevant from seasoned businesses
summary: Singaporean household brands CYC Made to Measure and Lam Soon adapted to the pandemic by going digital and expanding their product range, including reusable masks. Meanwhile, specialist centre Royal Healthcare plans to open in Tokyo or Osaka, and NUS researchers are working on halving the price of sustainable marine fuel. OCBC targets S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028, while Shatec cuts 42 staff and puts its Orchard campus up for sale.

site_title: Dutch to invest 20b euros in economy through long-delayed fund
summary: The Netherlands is set to invest 20 billion euros over five years through a long-delayed national investment fund. The government aims to improve infrastructure, spur research and development, address an aging population, climate change, and low productivity growth. This move marks a shift away from austerity and will be funded by a national investment fund. The investment plan was announced several months before the coronavirus outbreak worsened the country's economic outlook.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore stocks see a 5-day rally as investors await GDP data. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Creative Technology warns of possible below-target revenue and operating loss in H2. Meanwhile, Indonesia detains a Trafigura employee in a graft case. MAS and PBOC plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's new CEO.

site_title: Munich Re sees slowdown in Covid-19-related losses in Q3
summary: Munich Re, the world's largest reinsurer, reported a slowdown in Covid-19-related losses in Q3, with estimated losses of 1.5 billion euros in the first half of the year. However, the company expects losses from North American hurricanes and the Beirut explosion, totaling around 100 million euros. California wildfires have not resulted in significant losses. The company withdrew its profit guidance for the year due to the pandemic-related losses.

site_title: Southeast Asia's GDP growth to contract by 4.2% in 2020; Vietnam recovery prospects brightest: ICAEW
summary: Southeast Asia's GDP growth is expected to contract by 4.2% in 2020, according to a report by Oxford Economics commissioned by ICAEW. Vietnam is forecasted to be the only South-east Asian economy to record positive growth this year, driven by a strong rebound in economic activity. The region's recovery prospects remain uncertain due to ongoing US-China tensions, a slowdown in global trade, and the prolonged Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Chinese bottled water giant Nongfu eyes US$1b Hong Kong listing
summary: Chinese bottled water giant Nongfu Spring plans to raise over $1 billion in a Hong Kong listing, with shares priced at HK$21.50 ($3.79). The company, which supplies mineral water and holds around a quarter of China's bottled water market, aims to raise nearly $1.1 billion, making it the second-biggest IPO by a food and beverage company this year. This move follows Beijing's efforts to encourage Chinese companies to list domestically amid rising tensions with the US.

site_title: US markets closed for Labour Day
summary: US stock markets closed for Labor Day, marking a brief pause in trading. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks rose 5 days in a row ahead of GDP data. Popiah king Sam Goi made a mandatory offer for PSC shares at S$0.40 per share. Despite new Trump threats, traders continued to rally stocks, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records. eSIM platform Airalo raised US$220 million in funding, lifting its valuation past US$1 billion.

site_title: 13,000 workers barred from returning to work after missing Covid-19 testing deadline
summary: Singapore authorities have barred 13,000 workers from returning to work after missing a Covid-19 testing deadline. The workers' AccessCode status remains red, preventing them from returning until they undergo testing. The authorities had previously warned employers of the consequences of failing to schedule workers for testing, with some 16,000 workers left without appointments on the deadline night. The testing is mandatory for workers in higher-risk settings, with the first test due by September 5.

site_title: Temasek to mop up 1b Sembmarine shares after rights issue ends undersubscribed
summary: Temasek, a subsidiary of Sembcorp Industries, will mop up 1.03 billion unsold shares from Sembcorp Marine's rights issue, following the issue's undersubscription. The rights issue, aimed at recapitalizing Sembcorp Marine, received 9.4 billion valid acceptances and excess applications for 90.2% of the available shares. Temasek's acquisition of the unsold shares will increase its stake in Sembcorp Marine. The issue was undersubscribed due to Sembcorp Marine's shares trading near S$0.20, making it less attractive for shareholders to take up the rights.

site_title: No pandemic pause in Ikea's US shopping mall plans
summary: Ikea's shopping centers business plans to open its first US mall in San Francisco within a year, despite the coronavirus crisis. Ingka Centres, a division of Ingka Group, acquired the 6X6 San Francisco mall for $260 million and will anchor it with an Ikea store. The company aims to double its investment in US markets and provide support to city centers struggling with market conditions. Ingka Centres' general manager, Gerard Groener, believes demand for meeting, shopping, and leisure will remain despite the pandemic.

site_title: Germany may not need another Nord Stream pipeline right now
summary: Germany may not need the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline, analysts say, as Europe is flooded with gas and demand is likely to remain stable over the next few years. The pipeline's construction has sparked concerns about Russia's leverage over Germany and allies, but with Europe's biggest glut of gas already being supplied through other pipelines and tankers, its completion is no longer seen as crucial. The International Energy Agency estimates natural gas demand to stay flat for at least five years, and Germany may need to diversify its energy sources, including liquefied natural gas.

site_title: Camsing Healthcare to appoint independent firm by Dec 1; shares remain suspended
summary: Camsing Healthcare shares remain suspended as the company works to meet conditions from the Singapore Exchange Regulation. The audit committee has set a Dec 1 deadline for appointing an independent firm to conduct an independent review of internal controls and governance practices. A special audit report by RSM Corporate Advisory listed numerous internal control lapses and recommended entrusting the internal audit function to external professionals. The company must address and implement RSM's recommendations to lift the suspension.

site_title: Navalny out of medically induced coma: Berlin hospital
summary: Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, poisoned with a Novichok nerve agent, has been transferred out of a medically induced coma and is being weaned off mechanical ventilation. The Charite hospital in Berlin reported an improvement in his condition, but it's too early to determine the long-term impact of the poisoning. Germany's toxicology tests have found "unequivocal evidence" that Novichok was used on Navalny, prompting Chancellor Angela Merkel to demand answers from Russia. The Kremlin has denied any involvement in the poisoning, calling it "absurd."

site_title: Emirates airline returns US$1.4b in pandemic refunds
summary: Emirates airline has returned $1.4 billion in COVID-19 related travel refunds to customers, representing 90% of its backlog since March. The airline, the largest in the Middle East, posted a net profit of $1.1 billion for the financial year ending March. Despite a sharp downturn in global travel, Emirates expects to resume flights to all destinations by summer 2021. The airline has gradually expanded its network after Dubai eased travel restrictions to revive its tourism industry, which is a key economic mainstay of the city.

site_title: Fresh blaze on stricken oil tanker off Sri Lanka
summary: A massive fire on the Panamanian-registered oil tanker New Diamond, carrying over 270,000 tonnes of crude and diesel, has reignited off Sri Lanka due to strong winds. The blaze was extinguished Sunday but re-emerged Monday, with firefighters continuing to douse the tanker with water and dry chemicals. The cargo has not been affected, and authorities have secured the ship to prevent it from moving closer to the shore. Legal action could be taken against the owners, Liberian-registered Porto Emporios Shipping, if the worst happens and the ship breaks up.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down at close after weekend protest
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined on Monday, extending last week's retreat, following fresh protests over the weekend. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.43%, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 1.87% and the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 2.22%. The decline follows weekend protests in the financial hub, with investors taking a cautious stance amid ongoing protests and economic uncertainty.

site_title: AirAsia aims to raise US$602m, to evaluate Japan operations
summary: AirAsia Group plans to raise up to US$602 million by year-end to weather the Covid-19 crisis. The airline's CEO, Tony Fernandes, said the group could raise up to 1.5 billion ringgit from bank loans and 1 billion ringgit from investors. AirAsia is also reviewing its Japan operations, but its partnership in India remains unchanged.

site_title: Sembcorp Marine rights issue undersubscribed; Temasek to mop up 1b shares
summary: Sembcorp Marine's (SMM) rights issue to recapitalize the company was undersubscribed, with 90.2% of available shares accepted. Sembcorp Industries (SCI) subscribed for 72% of shares, and 1.03 billion unsubscribed shares will be mopped up by Temasek, a S$1.5 billion loan repayment. The muted interest may be due to SMM shares trading close to S$0.20 before the issue closed. The recapitalization aims to help SMM ride out industry downturn, strengthen its balance sheet, and reposition for long-term viability.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's private-sector economists now expect the country's GDP growth to decline 6% this year, slightly worse than earlier expectations of 5.8%. The re-hiring rate for retrenched workers slowed to 39% in H1 2020 from 2018. Mice events in Singapore can resume from October with a limit of 250 attendees. The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore has issued guidelines to protect shoppers from misleading discounts and price comparisons. KrisEnergy received its fourth debt moratorium extension, while a healthcare startup plans to launch corporate programs and expand its user base.

site_title: Thai court releases key anti-government activists
summary: Thai activists Anon Nampa and Panupong Jadnok, arrested for their roles in anti-government rallies, were released from prison after spending five days for bail breaches. Police revoked their detention request, stating there was no need to hold them after an investigation showed no grounds for detention. Both activists participated in near-daily protests demanding the military step back from politics and the removal of Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha. They vowed to continue their fight, despite recent arrests and charges, with a major protest planned for September 19.

site_title: China shows off Covid-19 vaccines for first time
summary: China has displayed its homegrown Covid-19 vaccines, developed by Sinovac Biotech and Sinopharm, for the first time at a Beijing trade fair, with hopes for approval and production of 300 million doses per year. The vaccines are among nearly 10 worldwide in phase 3 trials, and China is emphasizing domestic vaccine progress as a sign of leadership in the fight against the virus. The country aims to make any potential vaccine a "global public good" and has reported promising results, including a vaccine candidate that can deal with mutations in the coronavirus.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed higher on Monday, rising 0.52 points to 1,516.38. The index saw a volume of 6.972 billion lots worth RM3.427 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 764 to 361.

site_title: Singapore shares close flat on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended flat on Monday at 2,511.21, up 1.57 points or 0.06% from the previous day. The market maintained a wait-and-see stance ahead of the US Labor Day holiday, with investors relieved that the recent US tech stocks' rout did not spill over to the following day. The index has rallied for five consecutive days, and investors are now focusing on the upcoming GDP data release.

site_title: Japan says it offered Mauritius 'unprecedented' support, including financial
summary: Japan has offered Mauritius "unprecedented" support, including financial aid, after a Japanese-owned ship, MV Wakashio, spilled oil off the country's southeast coast in July. Foreign Minister Toshimitsu Motegi discussed the offer with Prime Minister Pravind Jugnauth, who expressed gratitude but denied Japan's involvement in the accident. Japan's support includes a maritime navigation safety system, fishing gear, and trade and tourism promotion. The exact amount of financial support was not disclosed, with Motegi stating the discussion was about outlining Japan's support, not specific figures.

site_title: KrisEnergy receives 4th extension of debt moratorium
summary: KrisEnergy, an upstream oil and gas company, has received its fourth extension of a debt moratorium until October 27. The moratorium is aimed at protecting the company from its creditors, including DBS Bank and Keppel Shipyard, as it seeks to restructure a debt of US$476.8 million. KrisEnergy shares have been suspended since last August.

site_title: Southeast Asia's GDP growth to contract by 4.2% in 2020; Vietnam recovery prospects brightest: ICAEW
summary: Southeast Asia's GDP growth is expected to contract by 4.2% in 2020, according to the ICAEW report. Vietnam is predicted to be the only South-east Asian economy to record positive growth this year. The country's recovery prospects are brightest due to its strong economic structure and effective containment of the Covid-19 outbreak. In contrast, Indonesia and the Philippines are expected to experience slower recoveries due to weaker public health infrastructure and lower fiscal support.

site_title: German funds and insurers take aim at rating agency data fees
summary: German investment funds and insurers are urging the European Union to force credit rating agencies to provide more transparency on their data fees. The Big Three rating agencies, Moody's, S&P Global, and Fitch Ratings, have no immediate comment. German funds association BVI and insurance industry body GDV claim the US agencies are exploiting their market position to set high fees, hindering EU regulators from taking action. Fund managers rely on ratings data for risk assessment and regulatory compliance, but currently, all data providers within the same rating group are not subject to EU rules.

site_title: UAE planning first official visit to Israel on Sept 22
summary: The United Arab Emirates plans its first official visit to Israel on September 22, following a US-brokered deal to normalise diplomatic relations. The trip is in reciprocation of a recent visit by senior Israeli and US envoys to Abu Dhabi. The UAE delegation's visit comes after Israel and the UAE signed the agreement on August 13, which was met with criticism from the Palestinians. The trip is expected to solidify the countries' agreement and boost annual trade between Israel and the UAE to $4 billion.

site_title: Euro-US dollar steadies as rally pauses ahead of ECB meeting
summary: The euro-US dollar exchange rate steadied above US$1.18 on Monday, following a brief rally, ahead of the European Central Bank (ECB) meeting on Thursday. US jobs data showed slowed employment growth and a decrease in the jobless rate to 8.4%, supporting the dollar. Investors expect no policy changes at the ECB meeting, but will be monitoring comments on the euro. Sterling fell 0.5% after Britain reportedly threatened to override its EU divorce deal.

images.alt_text: The euro-US dollar exchange rate steadied above US$1.18 on Monday as traders took stock of the latest US jobs data and prepared for the European Central Bank (ECB) meeting on Thursday to see if policymakers will introduce yet more stimulus.

site_title: Epic Games asks court to force Apple to reinstall Fortnite
summary: Epic Games is seeking a California court's order to force Apple to reinstate Fortnite on the App Store, citing "public interest" and potential irreparable harm to the game. The request comes after Apple removed Fortnite due to a revenue-sharing dispute. A previous court rejected Epic's bid, stating the eviction was a "self-inflicted wound." Epic claims the removal has led to a 60% drop in daily active users and a hit to its reputation, with fans no longer able to access the latest game updates. The case continues amidst a battle over Apple's App Store control.

site_title: HSBC Life Singapore appoints CIO, chief product officer
summary: HSBC Life Singapore has appointed Philip Pang as chief investment officer and How Chee Koon as chief product officer. Pang, with 15 years of experience, will oversee the investment strategy, while How, with 15 years of life insurance experience, will lead new product developments. The appointments aim to drive growth initiatives and improve customer investment returns and experience. This move supports HSBC's wealth ambition to become the top wealth management provider in Asia, with close collaboration between its insurance arm, retail and private banking units, and asset management arm.

site_title: Egypt may sell surplus power to Europe and Africa
summary: Egypt has begun talks with European and African countries to sell its surplus electricity, capitalizing on its renewable energy production and becoming a regional export hub. The country has a surplus of 50 gigawatts and is targeting 20% renewable energy by 2022 and more than doubling that by 2035. Egypt is in talks with European infrastructure investors and energy traders to assess the viability of its plan to supply Europe via a sub-sea cable to Cyprus and Greece, with the potential to earn a lucrative earner.

site_title: SGInnovate to create more jobs, traineeships in deep tech industry
summary: SGInnovate has launched initiatives to create more job opportunities in the deep tech industry for Singaporean students and professionals. Over 200 apprenticeships and full-time roles will be offered in 30 companies and startups, with positions in software development, robotics engineering, sales, and business development. A new full-time deep-tech traineeship program, Power X, has also been launched, focusing on robotics engineering, with the first run, Power X Robotics, accepting applications until October 4. The program aims to equip trainees with essential skills and real-world experience in the deep-tech space.

site_title: Italy's Gualtieri sees stronger-than-forecast economic rebound
summary: Italy's economy is expected to rebound more than 9.5% in the third quarter, according to Finance Minister Roberto Gualtieri. The country's GDP will return to pre-coronavirus levels in 2022, and the government plans to set a "significant" long-term target for reducing its debt. The recovery will be driven by government fiscal measures and European Union recovery funds.

images.alt_text: Italy's economy will rebound more powerfully than expected in the third quarter, Finance Minister Roberto Gualtieri said.

site_title: Thailand hunts for new finance minister to tackle economy in crisis
summary: Thailand is searching for a new finance minister to steer its economy through the coronavirus crisis. After Finance Minister Predee Daochai's surprise exit, Deputy Finance Minister Santi Promphat has thrown his hat into the ring, citing his expertise and ability to handle the economic pressure. Other potential candidates include Pailin Chuchottaworn, a former PTT CEO, and Veerathai Santiprabhob, the outgoing central bank governor, who has expressed interest in doing academic work and serving on boards, rather than seeking a full-time job. The government aims for a suitable appointment to maintain policy continuity and build confidence.

site_title: Singapore issues retail guidelines for price comparisons, discounts and free offers
summary: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) has issued guidelines for retailers and suppliers to follow when making price comparisons, discounts, and free offers. The guidelines, effective November 1, cover drip pricing, price comparison, discounts, and "free" offers. Suppliers must include all mandatory charges, such as taxes and service fees, in the headline price and clearly disclose subsequent fees. Suppliers are also encouraged to alert shoppers to optional add-ons through an "opt-in" or "opt-neutral" approach. The guidelines aim to protect shoppers from misleading information and promote fair trading practices.

site_title: Russian ex-Gulag town on China's doorstep eyes rebirth
summary: Russia's ex-Gulag town of Svobodny, with a population of 54,000, is set to undergo a major transformation by 2030 with the launch of new mega-projects, including a 50 billion ruble (S$900 million) plan to build two huge industrial plants, one with China's energy giant Gazprom. The town, once a notorious Soviet-era Gulag camp, aims to become one of Russia's fastest-growing cities and a top industrial hub. Despite initial resistance from some locals, the mayor believes that the massive overhaul is necessary to improve the town's quality of life.

site_title: PizzaExpress's creditors agree to restaurant closure plan
summary: PizzaExpress's creditors have approved a company plan to reduce rents and close 73 UK restaurants as part of a debt restructuring effort. The plan, which received over 90% support from creditors and landlords, will see owner Hony Capital cede control to creditors. Total debt will be cut by more than half, with bondholders taking over the company and Hony retaining control of Chinese operations. The restructuring follows the company's struggles amid changing consumer habits and the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: China plans caps on Ant's lending rates to control risk: sources
summary: China's financial regulators plan to cap Ant Group's interest rates on consumer loans at 15.4%, linked to a benchmark rate, as part of a China Supreme Court ruling. This move aims to curb Ant's largest revenue driver and could impact its IPO plans, which are set to raise $30 billion. The cap does not apply to licensed financial institutions, but its impact on fintech firms like Ant is unclear.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain as investors bet on potential Covid-19 vaccine
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% to 5,944.8, driven by firmer job advertisement numbers and prospects of a Covid-19 vaccine by early next year. The government's deal with CSL to manufacture two vaccines outweighed the extension of lockdowns in Melbourne. Job ads rose for a third straight month in August, boosting sentiment, although economists remain cautious about the outlook for jobs. Analysts believe the vaccine will be a significant confidence booster, enabling the economy to reopen.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares fall with dearth of fresh trading cues
summary: Tokyo shares fell 0.50% on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index dropping 115.48 points to 23,089.95. Investors digested the US market's closure for a holiday, seeking new cues. The broader Topix index also declined 0.42%.

site_title: Seoul: Shares rise on Samsung-Verizon contract, fewer coronavirus cases
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.7% on Monday, with the Kospi index closing at 2,384.22, driven by a $6.64 billion order from Verizon and a decline in domestic coronavirus cases. Samsung Electronics jumped 3.1% after securing the wireless communication solutions contract. The won and bond yield also strengthened, contributing to the market's gains. This marks the fourth consecutive rise in the Kospi index over the past five sessions.

site_title: Brexit adds extra hurdle for UK pilots striving to keep jobs
summary: UK pilots face uncertainty as the country's split from the EU nears completion on December 31. The lack of an agreement on pilot licensing for EU-registered planes could lead to job losses for UK pilots serving European airlines. EasyJet, which has its headquarters in the UK but flies from multiple European bases, is considering removing a third of pilot positions. The Civil Aviation Authority has agreed to recognize EU documentation for two more years, but a bilateral agreement on mutual recognition of pilot licenses is still pending.

site_title: Facebook plans to label posts 'more aggressively,' Clegg says
summary: Facebook plans to label posts more aggressively to combat misinformation and voter suppression ahead of the US presidential election. According to Facebook's vice president for global affairs, Nick Clegg, the social network will now label posts meant to manipulate or mislead US voters "much more forcefully" between now and November 3. The company has also banned new political ads on its platform in the week before Election Day and added labels to posts from politicians who claim victory before official outcomes are known.

site_title: UK house prices hit new high after Covid lockdown: Halifax
summary: British house prices reached a record high in August, with a 5.2% increase compared to August 2019, according to Halifax. The surge is attributed to a temporary tax cut, pent-up demand, and buyers seeking larger properties after the Covid lockdown. This marks the largest increase in house prices since 2016, fueling concerns of a post-lockdown housing boom and potential sharp rises in unemployment.

site_title: Reit focused on accommodation for the homeless plans London IPO
summary: Home Reit, a real estate investment trust focused on accommodation for the homeless, plans to list on the London Stock Exchange, raising around £250 million. The company aims to invest in properties providing shelter to vulnerable groups, including those fleeing domestic violence, people leaving prison, and foster care leavers. Home Reit targets inflation-protected income and capital returns, with shares priced at £1 each. The company's goal is to contribute to alleviating homelessness in the UK.

site_title: Several malls across the island visited by infectious Covid-19 patients
summary: Several Singapore malls, including VivoCity, Lucky Plaza, and Gardens by the Bay, were visited by infectious Covid-19 patients, according to the Ministry of Health (MOH). The MOH provides a list of locations visited by patients for 30 minutes or more, allowing for close contacts to be monitored. The country reported 22 new cases, the lowest daily figure in over five months, with 35 of the 57,044 cases being migrant workers in dormitories. The number of unlinked community cases has increased, but the overall trend shows a decrease in new daily cases.

site_title: Gold gains as global growth worries support demand
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,935.50 per ounce, driven by concerns over a slow economic recovery from the coronavirus pandemic and expectations of lower interest rates. Weak US data raised hopes that the Federal Reserve would maintain its monetary policy stance, supporting gold demand. Central banks have rolled out stimulus measures, helping gold climb 28% this year, and investors await the European Central Bank's monetary policy decision on Thursday.

site_title: Surging repayments drive Australian credit card loans to 15-yr low
summary: Australians' credit card debts fell to a 15-year low in July, with total interest-incurring credit card balances decreasing 3.2% month-on-month to A$22.5 billion. This marks the lowest level since July 2005, driven by a surge in repayments globally due to the pandemic. Experts warn that this trend will negatively impact banks, as consumers reined in spending and prioritize debt repayment, reducing credit growth and fee income.

site_title: Eurozone yields edge higher on debt supply, economic green shoots
summary: Eurozone bond yields rose on Monday due to improved global economic signs, including China's August exports rising 9.3% and Germany's industrial production increasing 1.2%. This indicates the economies of major trading partners, such as the eurozone, are recovering from the Covid-19 crisis. The increased borrowing requirements to fund the response to the crisis also contributed to the rise in yields.

site_title: Japan tycoon regrets losing 4.4b yen in stock trading
summary: Japanese billionaire Yusaku Maezawa lost 4.4 billion yen (S$56.6 million) in stock trading amid pandemic-driven market volatility. In a tweet, Maezawa expressed regret over the loss, saying he was "blinded" by the market swings and vowed to recover the money through his business. His net worth dropped to US$3.5 billion this year. The tweet received mixed responses from his followers, with some showing sympathy and others expressing awe at the extent of the losses.

site_title: Typhoon Haishen threatens Korea after battering Japan
summary: Typhoon Haishen is threatening South Korea after battering Japan, where four people are missing following a landslide. The storm brought top sustained winds of up to 112 km/h, cutting power to over 17,500 households and causing landslides and flooding. At least one person was injured, and over 1,600 people were evacuated. The storm is expected to draw near North Korea's port city of Chongjin, where it may impact the country's already vulnerable agriculture sector and tenuous food situation.

images.alt_text: South Korea hunkered down as Typhoon Haishen travelled northwards along the country's east coast on Monday, a day after the powerful storm battered Japan's southern islands where four people are missing following a landslide.

site_title: Yum China adds spice to its tech credentials
summary: Yum China has raised US$2.2 billion in a secondary listing at a valuation higher than Alibaba, with shares trading at a 26 times forecast 2021 earnings. The company's "digital ecosystem" of KFC and Pizza Hut apps has attracted 240 million members, with online orders accounting for 61% of total sales. However, volatility in internet stocks and the company's uneven recovery from pandemic pains may deter buyers, and the upcoming initial public offering of Alibaba-backed fintech Ant may also draw away demand and liquidity.

site_title: FWD acquires minority stake in financial advisory firm IPP Financial Advisers
summary: FWD Insurance has acquired a minority stake in financial advisory firm IPP Financial Advisers, entering into a strategic partnership. The partnership aims to enhance IPPFA's growth, expand its financial services business in Singapore, and strengthen its professional staffing and technology capabilities. FWD's technology solutions will also be integrated to simplify customer processes. IPPFA will retain its open architecture status, while FWD plans to design life insurance products meeting evolving client needs. The alliance is expected to bolster customer confidence in IPPFA's growth and commitment to the region.

site_title: Travellers arriving in Malaysia under longer-term travel scheme can no longer serve quarantine at home
summary: Malaysia has changed its quarantine policy for travellers arriving under the Periodic Commuting Arrangement (PCA) due to a recent COVID-19 case. A 35-year-old man who entered Malaysia under the PCA scheme tested positive for the virus, and as a result, travellers under the PCA will now be required to undergo quarantine at designated quarantine centres rather than at home. Those staying in quarantine centres will be responsible for the costs. Over 3,000 people have entered Malaysia under the PCA and RGL schemes since their reopening on August 17.

site_title: Japanese government exposed to 40% of 713b yen Nissan loans: sources
summary: The Japanese government has guaranteed over 40% of a 713 billion yen loan to Nissan Motor from the Development Bank of Japan, taking its guarantee to 104 billion yen. This move suggests financial firms are cautious about lending to Nissan as it seeks to return to profitability and stop bleeding cash. Nissan has secured additional loans from other banks, but the government has not guaranteed any portion of those loans. The guarantees put the government on the hook for 43% of Nissan's total pandemic-era loans.

site_title: Tokyo Olympics will go ahead 'with or without Covid': IOC's Coates
summary: IOC vice-president John Coates says the Tokyo Olympics will proceed with or without the COVID-19 pandemic, starting on July 23, 2021. Despite Japan's borders remaining closed to foreign visitors and a vaccine being months or years away, Coates believes the Games can still be held. A task force has been set up to assess scenarios in 2021, including border controls and fan attendance, amid concerns about the pandemic's impact on the event.

site_title: Australia turns to idled factories to pull it out of Covid-19 slump
summary: Australia is reviving its manufacturing sector to boost its economy, driven by the need for domestic production of essential goods amid strained relations with China. The government aims for manufacturing to account for 15-20% of GDP, up from 5% in 2019. Industry support is growing, with startups like H2X planning to produce hydrogen cars and Visy Industries expanding into glass manufacturing. Reforms are proposed to reduce energy costs, cut red tape, and encourage innovation, with a focus on attracting foreign investment and leveraging Australia's high-tech capabilities.

site_title: Brexit showdown as UK threatens to undermine divorce treaty
summary: Britain is threatening to override the EU's Brexit Withdrawal Agreement unless a free trade deal is agreed by October 15. The UK plans to introduce legislation that could eliminate key parts of the agreement, potentially stoking tension in Northern Ireland. Prime Minister Boris Johnson will say that if no deal is agreed, both sides should "accept that and move on." The move has been condemned by parties on both sides of the Irish border, and Johnson will claim that a no-deal scenario would be a "good outcome" with Britain having full control over its laws and fishing waters.

images.alt_text: Brexit trade talks plunged into crisis on Monday after Britain warned the European Union (EU) that it could effectively override the divorce deal it signed unless the bloc agrees to a free trade deal by Oct 15.

site_title: China Evergrande offers 30% discount to boost property sales
summary: China Evergrande Group launched a nationwide sales promotion with a 30% discount on all residential properties until October 8. The move aims to boost sales and meet its debt reduction target of 150 billion yuan per year. Despite increasing its debt by 4% to 835 billion yuan as of June 30, the company has fallen short of its pledge. The promotion is part of Evergrande's efforts to cut its debt load by half.

site_title: Primark shoppers buying more clothes, lifting AB Foods profit
summary: Primark shoppers are buying larger baskets of clothes since stores reopened, bolstering parent company AB Foods' profit. The company expects its full-year adjusted operating profit to be at least £300-£350 million (S$537-628 million). However, sales in the UK, Primark's largest market, are still expected to be 12% lower on a comparable basis, and earnings per share are expected to decline significantly. Stores that depend on tourists, which account for 8% of sales, are struggling after reopening.

images.alt_text: Primark shoppers have kept buying larger baskets of clothes since stores of the low-cost fashion chain reopened, bolstering profit at parent company Associated British Foods Plc.

site_title: Private-sector economists lower Singapore full-year growth forecast slightly to -6%
summary: Singapore's private-sector economists have lowered their full-year growth forecast to -6% due to a slight worsening from earlier expectations of a 5.8% decline. The economy is expected to contract by 7.6% in the third quarter, with construction and private consumption forecast to decline by -23% and -11.8%, respectively. However, non-oil domestic exports are expected to grow 4.5%, and unemployment is forecast to be 3.5% by the end of the year.

site_title: China's compulsive gamblers climb out of 'bottomless pit'
summary: A Chinese man, Huang Chunhao, swears to quit his compulsive gambling addiction after losing over two million yuan, thanks to the help of a Shanghai rehabilitation center. The center, established in 2017, uses a mix of education, psychological treatment, and lifestyle changes to help participants overcome their addiction. With the growth of online gambling, authorities are cracking down, and the central government is planning to impose restrictions on Chinese citizens traveling to overseas destinations with casinos.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares start on back foot
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Monday, extending last week's retreat, following fresh demonstrations in the city. The Hang Sang Index dropped 0.30% to 24,621.02, while the Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.16% to 3,349.92.

site_title: India overtakes Brazil with second-highest virus cases
summary: India has overtaken Brazil to become the second-worst affected country in terms of coronavirus cases, with 4.20 million infections and 71,642 deaths, according to health ministry data. Experts warn that the real numbers may be higher due to inadequate testing and death recording. India has reported a 27% increase in infections over the past two weeks and plans to increase daily testing to 15 million. The country has been steadily reopening its economy, with metro trains in major cities reopening after a six-month hiatus.

site_title: China exports beat forecasts in August, imports falter
summary: China's exports exceeded forecasts in August, growing 9.5% year-over-year, driven by eased virus containment measures in key markets. However, imports unexpectedly fell 2.1% due to a push to boost domestic demand. China's trade surplus with the US surged by more than a quarter. Economists caution that a resurgence in new infections in some regions casts doubt on the outlook. Despite this, agricultural imports may provide support to future readings, given the phase one trade deal with the US.

site_title: Re-hiring rate for retrenched workers slows to 39% in H1 2020 from 2018: MOM
summary: Singapore's re-hiring rate for retrenched workers slowed to 39% in H1 2020, down from 47% in 2018, according to data from the Ministry of Manpower. Despite a "weaker employment market" and the "circuit breaker", job prospects for retrenched workers held up, with most rehired workers staying in the same profession and taking pay cuts. The government expects the Jobs Growth Incentive to boost re-entry efforts, but acknowledged that some employers may still need to carry out retrenchments.

site_title: Hong Kong tycoons, banks claimed millions in virus subsidies
summary: Hong Kong's government-funded wage subsidies, meant to protect jobs during the pandemic, have been claimed by tens of millions of dollars by tycoons and global firms, sparking concerns about fairness. Companies, including property developers and banks, received subsidies by promising not to reduce headcount and using all proceeds to pay salaries, unlike other countries' programs that required a drop in revenue. Critics argue the subsidies benefit big, powerful conglomerates while low-skilled workers continue to struggle, with many job losses concentrated in retail, accommodation, and food services.

site_title: Oil drops more than US$1 after Saudi price cuts, demand optimism fades
summary: Oil prices dropped over $1 a barrel, reaching their lowest since July, after Saudi Arabia made the deepest monthly price cuts for supply to Asia, amid cooling optimism about demand recovery. Brent crude fell 2.1% to $41.75 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 2.3% to $38.86 a barrel. Despite Opec+ supply cuts and efforts to stimulate the global economy, refiners reduced output and producers made deep price cuts due to elevated inventories and lacklustre demand.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall as tech weighs, Melbourne extends lockdown
summary: Australian shares fell 0.9% on Monday, following a 3.1% decline in the previous session, due to technology stocks' 2.4% drop. The Nasdaq index's 1.3% fall on Friday contributed to the losses. Melbourne extended a coronavirus-led lockdown until late September, with Victoria reporting 63 new cases and five deaths. Tech firms Afterpay and Xero declined, while CSL rose 2.8% after signing agreements with the Australian government to produce COVID-19 vaccines.

site_title: NY Philharmonic is back, pandemic-style - playing in the streets
summary: The New York Philharmonic is adapting to the pandemic by playing outdoor pop-up concerts in the streets, with small ensembles performing at surprise locations throughout the city. The concerts, which began in September, feature musicians wearing masks and playing in front of a pickup truck, often with a socially distanced crowd of onlookers. The event aims to connect people through music and reinvent the concert-going ritual, with the goal of eventually covering all five city boroughs.

site_title: China's first homegrown nuclear reactor begins loading fuel
summary: China's Hualong One reactor, a domestically developed nuclear technology, began loading fuel at the Fuqing No 5 reactor on September 4. This marks a significant milestone in China's nuclear power development, with the country aiming to become the world's No 2 nuclear generator by 2022. The reactor's success could lead to a nuclear revival in China, with the country having already approved four Hualong One reactors and two more projects. This development is seen as a challenge to Western nuclear developers, including Westinghouse and Electricite de France.

images.alt_text: China's homegrown nuclear technology took a significant step forward as a Hualong One reactor began loading fuel for the first time.

site_title: Australia expects to receive AstraZeneca's Covid-19 vaccine within months
summary: Australia expects to receive its first batches of the AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccine in January 2021, with 3.8 million doses expected to be delivered. The vaccine, AZD1222, is undergoing late-stage clinical trials globally and is seen as a frontrunner. If successful, Australia will spend A$1.7 billion for nearly 85 million doses. The country's Victoria state has seen a 10-week low in new daily infections, with a hard lockdown in Melbourne extended until September 28.

site_title: Healthcare startup HealthifyMe to launch corporate programmes, expand user base
summary: HealthifyMe, a Singapore-based healthcare startup, plans to expand its user base to 2 million by 2022 and launch corporate health programs for companies. The platform, which has 500,000 users in Singapore and Malaysia, offers personalized fitness and nutrition solutions, including localized content and AI-powered coaching. The startup aims to quadruple its user base and employ 150 dieticians and trainers, while expanding to Indonesia, Australia, and the Middle East within the next two years. This expansion comes as the platform has seen a 30% surge in user traffic amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Asia: Shares on shaky footing amid elevated valuations; oil skids
summary: Asian shares fell on Monday, with China's blue-chip index slipping 0.5% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng easing 0.2%. The MSCI Asia-Pacific shares index was barely changed, ending two days of losses. Oil prices dropped sharply, with Brent crude skidding 1.1% to $42.16 a barrel, amid fading optimism about demand recovery amid the coronavirus pandemic. US stock futures opened in the red, with analysts at Jefferies expecting the equities market correction to extend further.

site_title: Australian banks start asking for loan repayments after six-month virus grace period
summary: Australian banks have started asking customers to pay back loans after a six-month coronavirus grace period, prompting concerns about borrowers being forced to sell their homes. The Australian Banking Association has contacted 260,000 mortgages and 105,000 business loans, requiring borrowers to resume repayments once deferrals expired in September and October. Struggling customers may be offered interest-only repayments or loan extensions, while those unable to pay long-term may receive "tailored assistance." The move aims to balance profit growth with community support, amid a technical recession and high jobless rates.

site_title: Ascott rewards members get more perks, status-match programme
summary: Ascott, a CapitaLand subsidiary, is offering more perks to its Ascott Star Rewards (ASR) loyalty programme members. Members can now exchange points between ASR and CapitaStar, and existing members can get their status matched with other hospitality groups. The elevated membership status is valid for a year, with minimum spend required to retain membership. Additionally, CapitaStar members can receive a platinum status upgrade and 25% discount vouchers at ASR properties. The partnership aims to expand ASR's reach globally, with potential extension to 11 million CapitaStar members in China.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS says worst over for listco earnings; Maybank likes Wilmar, ComfortDelGro
summary: DBS Group Research predicts the worst is over for Singapore-listed companies' earnings, citing a sharp 14.9% FY20 cut in forecast earnings. Analysts recommend investing in companies with upward earnings revisions or upgrades, such as Wilmar International, ComfortDelGro, and Hutchison Port Holdings Trust. DBS favors travel and leisure stocks, as well as manufacturing and trade-related names, anticipating a swift recovery in air travel once COVID-19 vaccines are widely available. The brokerage maintains its year-end target for the Straits Times Index at 2,850, despite the steep earnings cut in Q2.

images.alt_text: DBS's picks in the travel and leisure space are ComfortDelGro, SIAEC, China Aviation Oil, Ascott Residence Trust, and Far East Hospitality Trust.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Monday, rising 2.14 points or 0.14% to 1,517.99. Volume was 228.64 million lots worth RM64.32 million, with 213 gainers surpassing 121 losers. The market trend was not directly linked to any specific event, but may be influenced by global market movements.

site_title: Mice events in Singapore can resume from October with higher limit of 250 attendees
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board has announced that meetings, incentives, conventions, and exhibitions (Mice) events can resume from October with an increased attendance limit of 250 attendees, up from the previous limit of 50. This move aims to revive the Mice industry, with Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing stating that Singapore wants to remain the top business hub in Asia and strengthen its position as the Mice location of choice.

images.alt_text: Organisers can once again apply to hold meetings, incentives, conventions and exhibitions (Mice) events in Singapore, subject to attendance caps, from Oct 1.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Monday's open; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2% to 2,505.13 at the start of the week, following a US tech stocks pull-back that spooked Asian markets. Decliners outnumbered advancers 58 to 49, with financial stocks down and some shares, such as Medtecs International and Synagie, rising. The US market is closed on Monday for Labour Day, with European shares also lower, and Tokyo stocks opening down.

site_title: Hong Kong shares of China's SMIC plunge as Trump considers adding firm in blacklist
summary: Hong Kong-listed shares of Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp (SMIC), China's top chipmaker, plummeted 15.2% to HK$20.02 after a US official said it was considering adding the firm to a trade blacklist. This move could prevent US companies from supplying goods and services to SMIC, which relies heavily on US-based suppliers. The potential measures recall those placed on Huawei Technologies and could impact SMIC's production volume and technology, further lagging behind its rival Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing.

images.alt_text: Shares of Hong Kong-listed Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp (SMIC) fell as much as 15.2 per cent to HK$20.02, the lowest since June 16, after a US official said it was considering adding the Chinese firm to a trade blacklist.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Tokyo shares fell 0.32% on Monday, closing at 23,131.15, amidst global market uncertainty. Investors digested Wall Street's losses and sought new cues. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 74.28 points, while the Topix index lost 4.39 points. The decline follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and comes as traders brush off new US threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: MinLaw, IPOS seek public feedback on exceptions in Copyright (Excluded Works) Order
summary: MinLaw and IPOS are seeking public feedback on exceptions in the Copyright (Excluded Works) Order (EWO) until October 2, 2020. The current EWO 2017 expires on December 31, 2020, and will be reviewed to ensure it remains relevant. The exceptions include allowing users to circumvent technological protection measures for legitimate use of copyrighted works, such as print disabilities and educational purposes. The public consultation aims to gather feedback from creators, users, and the general public on whether the exceptions should be retained, expanded, or limited.

site_title: Oceanus invests in deep-tech firm to breed prawns
summary: OCEANUS Group has invested in Universal Aquaculture, a deep-tech firm specializing in indoor farming, to breed vannamei prawns. The investment aims to drive business growth through aquaculture. Universal Aquaculture's hybrid biological recirculation system reduces energy consumption, water change, and feed conversion ratio, creating optimal water conditions for prawn breeding. The move is seen as part of Oceanus's strategies to strengthen its aquaculture pillar and support Singapore's food security and self-sufficiency goals.

site_title: Malaysia's currency faces two key risks after beating Asia peers
summary: Malaysia's ringgit has outperformed most Asian peers, but faces two key risks. The currency may lose support if FTSE Russell decides to remove Malaysian bonds from its World Government Bond Index, potentially drying up debt inflows. Additionally, Bank Negara Malaysia is expected to cut interest rates, which could boost the currency but also signal economic growth jitters. The ringgit has gained over 3% since July, but its long-term prospects depend on the FTSE decision, set to be announced on September 24.

site_title: SoftBank shares slide 5% after news on tech stock options bet
summary: SoftBank shares fell 5% after news on tech stock options bets made investors uncomfortable. The conglomerate has made significant options purchases in tech companies, generating a $4 billion exposure of about $50 billion, resulting in $4 billion in trading gains. SoftBank's aggressive bets, led by CEO Masayoshi Son, have raised concerns among investors.

site_title: Pressures build on UK's Johnson as Covid cases surge
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson faces pressure to balance the economy and contain the COVID-19 surge, as the country reported a 64% jump in new cases, predominantly among young people. Health Secretary Matt Hancock warns of a potential resurgence, while labor unions push for COVID-secure measures to kick-start the economy. The government is also under scrutiny over its plan to pay for stimulus measures, with Chancellor Rishi Sunak promising temporary tax hikes and potential tax cuts ahead of the 2024 general election.

site_title: Australian job advertisements rise 1.6% in August
summary: Australian job advertisements rose 1.6% in August, marking the third consecutive month of growth, despite a coronavirus lockdown in Victoria.
