The total job ads reached 109,103, up from a low of 63,939 in May. This moderate pace follows a bounce of 41% in June and 19.1% in July, following a record decline in April.

site_title: Imagining jobs of the future in the post-Covid-19 world
summary:
The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the shift to digital payments, with real-time decision-making, experiences, and customer service becoming the norm. However, current payment systems are not equipped to handle these changes, leading to a need for modernization. Three new jobs are emerging to address this gap: 

1. CEO of a Cashless Society, responsible for developing and tracking cash-to-cashless ratios, integrating voice and contactless payments, ensuring data protection, and implementing awareness programs.
2. Cyber Fraud Forecaster, tasked with predicting instant payment fraud trends and developing machine-learning driven statistical models to improve security.
3. Payment Experience Officer, focused on enhancing and innovating instant payment services to create a seamless and frictionless experience for customers.

site_title: Samsung Electronics wins 7.9t won Verizon order for network equipment
summary: Samsung Electronics' US unit has secured a 7.9 trillion won (S$9.14 billion) order from Verizon to provide wireless communication solutions, including network equipment. The contract, signed from June 30, 2020 to Dec 31, 2025, marks a significant win for Samsung, which has been a customer of Verizon since before the order. Verizon, known for not using Huawei equipment, is believed to be Nokia's largest customer, according to JPMorgan research.

site_title: As protests rock US cities on holiday weekend, Jacob Blake speaks out
summary: US cities experience protests over racial justice and policing during the holiday weekend, with Jacob Blake speaking out from his hospital bed after being shot in the back by a police officer in August. Blake, 29, described constant pain and difficulty breathing due to the shooting, which left him paralyzed from the waist down. The protests coincide with the ongoing coronavirus pandemic and have moved to the forefront of President Donald Trump's re-election campaign. Clashes have also erupted in other cities, including Rochester, Louisville, and Portland, with numerous arrests and injuries reported.

site_title: Djokovic 'sad and empty' after US Open disqualification
summary: Novak Djokovic was disqualified from the US Open after hitting a line judge in the throat with a ball during his match against Pablo Carreno Busta. Djokovic expressed remorse, stating he was "sad and empty" and apologized for his behavior. He cited the incident as an opportunity for growth and vowed to work on his disappointment. The disqualification occurred after 12 minutes of discussion between Djokovic and tournament officials.

images.alt_text: Novak Djokovic said he was "sad and empty" after a being disqualified from the US Open on Sunday after hitting a line judge in the throat with a ball during his fourth-round match against Spain's Pablo Carreno Busta.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sabana Reit, CapitaLand Mall Trust, CCT, StarHub, Boustead Projects
summary: Stocks to watch: Sabana Reit, CapitaLand Mall Trust, CCT, StarHub, Boustead Projects. Quarz Capital Management and Black Crane Capital called for Sabana Reit's senior management to resign if its merger with ESR-Reit falls through. CapitaLand Mall Trust and CapitaLand Commercial Trust's managers announced deal sweeteners for their proposed merger, including higher accretion to their distribution per unit. StarHub was fined S$210,000 for its internet service disruption. Boustead Projects received a letter of demand for S$17.8 million in relation to liquidated damages.

site_title: Equity management platform Qapita raises US$1.8m in seed round led by Vulcan Capital
summary: Qapita, a Singapore-based equity management platform, has raised US$1.8 million in seed funding led by Vulcan Capital, the investment arm of Vulcan Inc. Founded in 2019 by Ravi Ravulaparthi, Lakshman Gupta, and Vamsee Mohan, the platform aims to digitize ownership records and facilitate employee equity ownership in startups. The fresh funding will be used to strengthen the team, accelerate product development, and build the client base, with plans to expand into other markets, including Indonesia and Hong Kong.

site_title: HK police make arrests as protests return
summary: Hong Kong police arrested at least 90 people, including prominent pro-democracy activists Figo Chan, Raphael Wong, and Leung Kwok-hung, as protests returned to city streets on Sunday. The arrests were made on charges including illegal assembly and disorderly conduct, amidst a delayed Legislative Council election. Protesters defied social distancing restrictions, marching through Kowloon and blocking streets with barricades, and chanting pro-democracy slogans. The unrest came as the city starts to ease social distancing measures, raising concerns over increased surveillance among activists.

site_title: Italy's Costa Cruises joins liners' return to sea
summary: Italy's Costa Cruises has resumed operations with the return of its ship, Costa Deliziosa, after a five-month coronavirus furlough. The ship is carrying only Italian residents and following a strict protocol to minimize the risk of transmission. Costa Deliziosa will sail on an all-Italy itinerary with social distancing measures in place, including limited use of restaurants, bars, and swimming pools. This marks the return of the cruise industry, which has faced significant losses due to the pandemic, with estimated worldwide financial losses totaling $50 billion.

site_title: Founders of Singapore's food ordering app Oddle look to exit
summary: The founders of Singapore's food ordering app Oddle are working with an adviser to exit the company, according to people with knowledge of the matter. Oddle has raised S$5 million in funds and is projecting a gross profit of S$8 million for fiscal year 2021. The startup has gained popularity since the Covid-19 outbreak, boosting revenues at companies like Oddle. Oddle counts Michelin-starred restaurants and brands like bubble tea and ice cream among its customers, and has an order management system used by over 3,000 brands in 10 countries.

images.alt_text: The startup, co-founded by Jonathan Lim, Pua Yong Xiang and Jeremy Lee, has reached out to potential suitors to gauge interest, said the people, asking not to be named as the process is private. Sale documents show that Oddle has raised total funds of S$5 million over the past three years and is projecting a gross profit of S$8 million for fiscal year ending March 2021, the people said.

site_title: Axington extends offer period for rights issue
summary: Axington, a professional advisory services group listed on the Catalist, has extended the offer period for its rights issue until the time its shares resume trading after a suspension. The deadline for accepting and paying for rights shares and excess rights shares was initially set for September 9, but has now been pushed back. The company aims to provide shareholders with time to consider their actions and trade in nil-paid rights after the shares resume trading. The rights issue aims to raise approximately S$9.4 million.

site_title: Australia to extend bankruptcy protection rules until end 2020
summary: Australia will extend its bankruptcy protection rules until the end of 2020, providing businesses a lifeline to recover from the coronavirus pandemic. The rules, which were set to expire on September 30, will allow creditors to issue bankruptcy notices for debts below A$20,000 and extend the notice period to help firms restructure or wind down operations. The move aims to prevent further business failures as the economy recovers from the pandemic, which has resulted in over a million job losses and a recession.

site_title: Bukit Timah condo Verdale attracts 268 viewings during weekend preview launch
summary: VERDALE, a 258-unit condominium in Bukit Timah, Singapore, drew 268 viewings during its weekend preview launch. All appointment slots were filled, with interest strong across unit types. Public sales begin on Sept 19, with prices starting from S$791,000 for one-bedroom units and S$998,000 for two-bedroom units. The development is located near nature sites and transport hubs, with Smart Space Solutions receiving positive feedback from prospective buyers.

site_title: Airplane cabins could look different the next time you fly
summary: Airlines are exploring modifications to airplane cabins to reassure passengers about the safety of flying amid the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. Companies like Recaro Aircraft Seating GmbH are designing new seat arrangements, including headrest canopies and fabric barriers, to keep passengers apart. These temporary cabin makeovers aim to address concerns about infection risk and could include disinfectant coatings. Airlines are also considering installing these modifications to increase the appeal of flying, which has been impacted by global traffic downturns and social distancing measures.

images.alt_text: Headrest canopies and fabric barriers between seats could start appearing in airplane cabins as the embattled industry tries to ward off the coronavirus.

site_title: CSE Global on the lookout for M&As
summary: CSE Global, a tech-solutions provider to the oil and gas sector, is exploring mergers and acquisitions (M&As) to strengthen its position in the downturn. The company, which has recently acquired a 25% stake in CSE via a married deal with Malaysian engineering services provider Serba Dinamik International, is eyeing opportunities in the US, Singapore, and Australia. CSE aims to offer a complete solution package to its customers and is exploring collaboration with its new major shareholder, Heliconia Capital Management, to pursue new growth areas.

site_title: Call for Sabana Reit top management, IDs to quit if ESR deal falls through
summary: Funds managing over 10% of Sabana Reit have called for top management and independent directors to resign if a proposed merger with ESR-Reit falls through. Quarz Capital Management and Black Crane Capital, advising funds with significant stakes in Sabana Reit, wrote a letter to the trust's manager and board, citing potential conflicts of interest. They proposed replacing the current directors with those who can develop alternative strategies to grow the trust. The merger requires a 75% majority vote from independent unitholders, but those abstaining include ESR-Reit's manager and its sponsor, ESR Cayman.

site_title: After 740 races and 16 world titles, Williams family affair comes to an end
summary: The Williams family, after 740 F1 races and 16 world titles, ended their association with the sport on Sunday at the Italian Grand Prix. The team, sold to American investment group Dorilton Capital, marked the end of an era for F1 under British ownership. Drivers Nicholas Latifi and George Russell paid tribute to the family, with Latifi waving Claire out of the garage before the race. The team's founder, Frank Williams, and Claire, who had been deputy team principal, severed their connection, with Claire calling it an "honour" to work with the team.

site_title: Money FM: Podcasts of the week (Sept 7)
summary: No relevant podcasts were listed for the specified date of September 7, 2020.

site_title: Trump on defensive as critics seize on reports he insulted US veterans
summary: US President Donald Trump faced criticism over reported comments disparaging US veterans, with critics calling them "despicable" and "a pattern" of disrespect. The comments, which included calling soldiers buried in Europe "losers," were reported by The Atlantic and have been seized upon by Trump's opponents, including former Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel and Democratic Speaker Nancy Pelosi. The controversy could harm Trump's re-election campaign, particularly among military supporters.

site_title: UK PM gives October 15 deadline for Brexit deal
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson has set an October 15 deadline for a post-Brexit trade agreement with the European Union, warning that talks will fail if no deal is reached by then. Johnson, who has promised a "zero tariff, zero quota" regime, insisted a "no-deal" scenario would still be a "good outcome" for Britain, similar to an "Australia-style" deal. The talks resume in London this week, with both sides showing increasing intransigence, amid disagreements over fishing rights and state aid rules.

site_title: Pennant formation marks inflection point for NZDUSD
summary: The NZDUSD currency pair has reached an inflection point, with various indicators suggesting a potential reversal. The pair has recovered from its losses at the start of the year, but is now hovering at a key resistance level, which has historically led to a downturn. A rising wedge pattern and an overbought stochastics oscillator further validate the bearish move. The MACD indicator also shows a loss in bullish momentum, limiting further upward movement.

site_title: UK coronavirus cases verge on 3,000 in 24 hours
summary: The UK reported almost 3,000 new coronavirus cases over 24 hours, the highest number since late May. Two more people died from the virus, bringing the overall UK toll to 41,551. Health Secretary Matt Hancock expressed concern over the rise, urging people not to spread the illness to the elderly. The government will tighten local restrictions in areas with sharp rises in cases, rather than imposing a second national lockdown. Total UK cases now stand at 347,152.

site_title: Hong Kong tycoons, banks claimed millions in virus subsidies
summary: Hong Kong's government-funded wage subsidies, meant to protect jobs during the coronavirus pandemic, have been criticized for favoring large corporations and property tycoons over low-skilled and low-paid workers. The program, which received billions of dollars in funding, has been used by companies such as Victor Li's CK Asset Holdings and New World Development, despite their high profits. Critics argue that the subsidies have not done enough to support vulnerable workers, who have seen unemployment rise significantly during the pandemic. The government has vowed to boost deterrence against companies laying off employees in the next tranche of the program.

site_title: NTUC Income raises S$60,000 in support of mental health
summary: NTUC Income raised S$60,000 in support of mental health through a virtual Family Day event, where over 700 participants clocked a total of 5,884 km to raise funds for the Singapore Association of Mental Health. The event, held on a rainy day, aimed to champion a zero-waste lifestyle and boost staff morale, with participants running, jogging, or walking near their residences while adhering to social distancing measures. The funds raised will support creative therapeutic interventions for youths facing stress and anxiety during the pandemic.

site_title: Acquittal of Liew Mun Leong's former maid prompts AGC to look further into case
summary: The Attorney-General's Chambers (AGC) is reviewing the acquittal of Parti Liyani, an Indonesian maid falsely accused by Liew Mun Leong of stealing items from his homes. High Court Judge Chan Seng Onn found the Liew family took pre-emptive action to fire Ms Parti, preventing her from reporting her employer's illegal deployment. The AGC is considering further action, following Judge Chan's comments on the case, including concerns over police investigations and evidence handling.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for September 4, 2020, reveals a mixed market for tankers and dry bulk ships. The Capesize market experienced a technical correction, with the timecharter average dropping to $16,252. The North Atlantic market remained short of enquiry, while the Panamax market saw a sell-off, with the five timecharter average returning a loss of $1,179 to close at $13,260. The Supramax/Ultramax market had a level week, with limited period activity. Handysize rates declined, with the weighted time charter average having a minor decline. The Clean market saw rates ease in the Middle East Gulf and USGulf/UKC trades.

site_title: China cannot afford to let property market crash
summary: China's government has imposed leverage thresholds for developers, limiting bank borrowings and restricting new bond issuances to refinance existing debt. This policy aims to curb a glut of unsold homes and prevent a property market crash. Despite this, the overseas debt market remains open, and companies such as China Resources Land and Kaisa Group Holdings have successfully raised funds. The government will continue to fine-tune regulatory measures to control credit growth and avoid a run-up in prices, prioritizing the importance of the property industry to China's economy.

site_title: China Life Singapore to hire more than 500 consultants in next five years
summary: China Life Singapore plans to hire over 500 consultants in the next five years to provide a dedicated service to clients, moving away from traditional bank partnerships. The new consultants will undergo training and exams to ensure they meet the company's expectations. This move aims to improve the customer experience and create a high-tech service system, serving high net-worth clients with customizable insurance plans. The company is leveraging technology to optimize insurance business practices and improve overall service standards.

site_title: China vows to expand stock investments in further opening of markets
summary: China has vowed to expand stock investments and deepen reforms to attract more foreign investors, with plans to revise existing market-opening measures. The China Securities Regulatory Commission will expand the scope of investments allowed in the stock connect program with Hong Kong and allow foreign investors to trade more commodities futures products. These moves aim to further open up China's capital markets and boost foreign investment.

site_title: Singapore confirms 40 new Covid-19 cases, including four in community
summary: Singapore reported 40 new COVID-19 cases, including four in the community, bringing the total to 57,022. The four community cases are all work pass holders, while 13 imported cases were placed on stay-home notice. New clusters linked to dormitories were announced, with nine, 17, and 11 cases reported. The government provides a list of locations visited by infectious patients to monitor their health.

site_title: Investors left guessing how ECB will tackle strong euro
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to tackle the euro's strength, with investors awaiting its response to the currency's recent breach of US$1.20. The ECB chief economist, Philip Lane, mentioned the euro-dollar rate's impact, and market expectations point to a potential 10 basis-point rate cut by September. A stronger euro hinders the ECB's inflation target, but a dovish stance is unlikely, with most economists forecasting increased stimulus by December. The ECB may consider more stimulus to curb the euro, potentially weakening it and raising inflation.

site_title: DBS named best bank globally for third consecutive year
summary: DBS Bank has been named the best bank globally for the third consecutive year by New York-based financial publication Global Finance. The Singapore-headquartered bank received the accolade for its investments in digital banking services, inclusive culture, and resilience during the pandemic. Global Finance considers factors such as growth, profitability, and management excellence in selecting the world's best bank. DBS CEO Piyush Gupta attributed the recognition to the bank's purpose-driven approach and commitment to serving customers in need.

site_title: Goldman Sachs joins syndicate for Ant IPO: sources
summary: Goldman Sachs has joined the syndicate for Ant Group's initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong, which is expected to be the world's largest IPO. The IPO, valued up to $30 billion, will be listed simultaneously in Hong Kong and Shanghai. The Hong Kong leg is being sponsored by China International Capital Corp, Citigroup, JPMorgan, and Morgan Stanley, with Goldman Sachs acting as a joint lead manager. The IPO is set to be completed by October, with Ant Group's Alipay being the largest player in China's third-party mobile payments market.

site_title: An incentive or disincentive?
summary: Singapore's tightening of Employment Pass and S Pass criteria aims to control foreign workforce numbers and protect local jobs. Business leaders have differing views, with some seeing the move as necessary to anchor local talent and others as protectionist. The government's goal is to balance protecting jobs for Singaporeans with attracting specialized foreign talent. Experts emphasize the need for reliable data, careful analysis, and cooperation from stakeholders to strike the right balance. The tightening may impact businesses, particularly those in sectors with high labor costs, and could lead to increased costs for employers.

site_title: Saudis cut oil pricing in sign of struggling demand recovery
summary: Saudi Arabia's state-owned oil producer, Saudi Aramco, cut oil pricing for October, signaling struggling demand recovery amid the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. The cuts, including a larger-than-expected reduction for Asia, aim to boost fuel demand. Oil demand has plummeted this year due to lockdowns, cancellations, and low refinery demand. Despite a 10% output cut by OPEC+ producers, oil prices remain down 35% this year, with Brent crude falling to $42.66, its biggest weekly loss in almost three months.

site_title: Riverstone's Lee Wai Keong trims stake from 10.92% to 8.82%
summary: Riverstone Holdings' co-founder Lee Wai Keong trimmed his stake in the company from 10.92% to 8.82% after selling 15.496 million shares at S$3.95 per share. This follows his previous disposal of 5.5 million shares in 2017. The Straits Times Index (STI) declined 0.5% over the five trading sessions, with the iEdge S-Reit Leaders Index up 2.2%. Other notable transactions include QT Vascular's CEO selling shares to reduce his stake, and SingHaiyi Group acquiring shares of SingHaiyi Group to increase its managing director's interest.

site_title: CMT, CCT push ahead with union amid closer regulatory scrutiny of intra-group mergers
summary: Singapore-based CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) and CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) are moving forward with their merger, despite the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on retail and office properties. The merger, announced in January, will create one of the largest Reits in the region, with a S$22 billion property portfolio and annual net property income of S$1 billion. The combined entity will have a stronger position to raise funds for acquisitions and enhance property value. Unitholders will receive 0.72 of a unit in CMT plus S$0.259 of cash for each unit owned, with no change in terms.

site_title: Safe-haven greenback jumps after job growth slows in the US
summary: The US dollar rose to its highest in a week after the Labor Department reported slower job growth in August, with financial assistance programs for businesses and unemployment aid expiring. This led investors to buy into the safe-haven asset, reversing a week of losses. Despite the short-term rally, economists predict the dollar will continue to decline due to the Federal Reserve's monetary policy outlook. The euro rose above the $1.20 level but was later capped by the European Central Bank, which is set to meet next week.

site_title: Amazon bans foreign sales of seeds in US amid mystery packages
summary: Amazon has banned foreign sales of seeds in the US amid thousands of unsolicited packages, mostly from China, containing non-native plant species that could harm commodity crops. The US Department of Agriculture warned Americans not to plant the seeds. Amazon will only permit seed sales by US-based sellers, and those not following guidelines may face account removal. The move comes after a "brushing" scam investigation found few problems with the seeds, with the US and China working jointly to investigate.

site_title: Wilmar among top buys of some analysts for its diversified earnings base
summary: Wilmar International's share price fell 10% after its second-largest shareholder, Archer Daniels Midland, reduced its stake in the agri-commodities company. However, analysts see this as a buying opportunity due to Wilmar's diversified business and upcoming catalysts, including the listing of its China unit Yihai Kerry Arawana and potential gains from its investment in Perennial Real Estate Holdings. Analysts expect these factors to offset weakness in other businesses and drive the stock's growth. Despite concerns about the IPO's certainty, many analysts remain bullish on Wilmar's prospects.

site_title: Germany re-engineers Europe's most important river
summary: Germany is re-engineering the Rhine River, Europe's most important waterway, to ensure reliable shipping and maintain its industrial competitiveness. The river's low water levels in 2018 led to a significant disruption in shipping, prompting the government to invest in new locks, boat designs, and dredging projects. The goal is to optimize the river's flow and capacity to transport goods, particularly coal, iron ore, and natural gas, while also addressing environmental concerns. The project is crucial for Germany's economy, particularly as China targets its position as a leader in advanced manufacturing.

images.alt_text: The Rhine is an intrinsic part of Germany's mystique and a key part of its modern-day competitiveness. Around 30 per cent of the country's coal, iron ore and natural gas is transported along the river.

site_title: Singapore investors see strong long-term fundamentals in Australian commercial property
summary: Singaporean investors, including sovereign wealth fund GIC and smaller property players, are optimistic about the long-term fundamentals of Australia's commercial property market. Despite the pandemic, investors see opportunities in infrastructure upgrades and office buildings, particularly in Sydney, Melbourne, and Brisbane. GIC has committed A$400 million to a new Australian develop-to-hold logistics fund, while Keppel Capital is eyeing a A$300 million office building in Sydney. The market's stability, regulatory framework, and skilled workforce make Australia an attractive destination for long-term investments.

site_title: China to roll out new supportive policies for hydrogen fuel cell vehicles, official says
summary: China plans to introduce a new policy package to support hydrogen fuel cell vehicle manufacturers, focusing on breakthrough technologies and long-distance logistics such as heavy-duty trucks. The policy aims to improve the industry's supply chain and encourage city governments to develop a hydrogen fuel cell vehicle industry with local companies. This move is part of China's efforts to become the world's leading market for new energy vehicles.

site_title: Savills Residential, Huttons Asia to merge in further sector consolidation
summary: Savills Residential, a residential arm of Savills Singapore, will merge with Huttons Asia, strengthening Huttons' capabilities in clinching appointments for residential projects. The move will see 582 Savills commission-only residential brokers join Huttons, enhancing its pool of 3,044 brokers. The post-merger business will trade as "Huttons - in association with Savills" and will focus on strengthening services to clients through a newly expanded agency force and access to international markets. The deal is expected to accelerate Huttons' growth as a leading agency in Singapore.

site_title: 3M Moves @ South East 2020 aims to raise over S$110,000 in product donations
summary: 3M's "3M Moves @ South East 2020" campaign aims to raise over S$110,000 in product donations and accumulate 5,000 hours of exercise from the community. The two-month campaign, which started on September 4, 2020, involves 3M staff and internal stakeholders participating in virtual workouts, with one 3M product donated for every 20 minutes of exercise clocked. The goal is to support 3,000 beneficiaries in the South East District with daily necessities, with the campaign's completion scheduled for November 4, 2020.

site_title: DBS named world's best bank for third consecutive year
summary: DBS Bank has been named the world's best bank for the third consecutive year by Global Finance, a New York-based financial publication. The Singapore-headquartered bank received the accolade for its investments in digital banking services, inclusive and efficient culture, and resilience during the pandemic. Global Finance considers factors such as growth, profitability, geographic reach, and innovation in products when selecting the world's best bank. DBS CEO Piyush Gupta said the bank's focus on serving customers in need is its core focus, and the recognition is a testament to its efforts.

site_title: China vows to expand stock connect in further market opening
summary: China plans to expand its stock connect program with Hong Kong, allowing foreign investors to trade more commodities futures products and increasing qualified foreign institutional investors. The move aims to attract more foreign capital, with China currently holding only 4.7% of its stocks in circulation. China is also opening its financial markets to Wall Street giants, seeking fresh investments and a more competitive local industry. The participation of foreign investors has helped make the Chinese stock market more rational, with valuations becoming more reasonable.

site_title: North Korea blames officials' inaction for typhoon casualties
summary: North Korea's ruling party blamed officials for "dozens of casualties" during recent typhoons, citing inaction and red tape. The typhoons, part of a record-breaking rainy season, hit the Korean peninsula. Officials in Wonsan and surrounding Kangwon Province failed to secure buildings and prepare for evacuations, according to the state newspaper Rodong Sinmun. The party held a meeting to punish officials and repair damaged areas, including farms and homes. The impoverished country braces for another potentially powerful typhoon, Haishen, set to hit the east coast on Monday.

site_title: Singapore's new VCC Act the main event drawing funds here
summary: Singapore's new Variable Capital Companies (VCC) regime is drawing funds from Hong Kong, attracting them with its game-changing benefits for the fund management industry. Since its introduction in January 2020, 109 VCC funds have been established, exceeding initial estimates of 100-150. The regime has taken the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) by surprise, with assets under management (AUM) in Singapore reaching S$3.4 trillion in 2018. The VCC regime is expected to continue to attract fund managers and family offices, despite concerns over anti-foreigner protectionism sentiments, as it offers better access to South-east Asia and a viable alternative for investments outside North Asia.

site_title: US tech sector leading volatile market in September
summary: The US tech sector led the stock market in August, with the Standard & Poor's 500 reaching a record high. However, the market experienced a volatile start to September, with the S&P 500 retreating from its record high. Analysts attribute the correction to a surge in day trading on the options market, fueled by a new generation of traders. The market's "V-shaped" economic recovery narrative is also being questioned, with the jobs report showing a more crooked "L" shape. Stimulus talks remain ongoing, but the strong jobs report may reduce the incentive for a deal, leading to further market volatility.

site_title: UK PM, finance minister agree to cut personal taxes before next election
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson and Finance Minister Rishi Sunak have agreed to cut personal taxes before the next election. The finance minister plans to outline a tax "arc" in the November budget, where the wealthy will pay heavier taxes, with cuts to follow in 2023 or 2024. There are no plans for changes to inheritance tax or increases in income tax, national insurance, or value-added tax.

site_title: Judge's findings in Parti Liyani case involving CAG chairman warrant further investigations: AGC
summary: A Singapore court's findings in the Parti Liyani case warrant further investigations, according to the Attorney-General's Chambers. Justice Chan Seng Onn's report found improper motive by the Liew family in accusing domestic worker Parti Liyani of theft. The AGC will assess further action, with the Ministry of Manpower consulting with the AGC. Parti Liyani was acquitted of the theft charge and cleared by the High Court following an appeal. The findings raised questions about the Liew family's motives, including their alleged attempt to prevent Parti Liyani from lodging a complaint about illegal deployment.

site_title: Ikea's shopping centres arm buys San Francisco mall in its first US real estate deal
summary: Ikea's shopping centres arm, Ingka Centres, has made its first US real estate acquisition, buying the 6X6 mall in San Francisco. The mall was previously owned by Alexandria Real Estate Equities and TMG Partners. This marks Ingka Centres' first US deal, following a May announcement of interest in acquiring inner-city malls in the US. The acquisition is part of Ingka Centres' shift towards city-centre locations, a focus that has also led to the purchase of Kings Mall in London.

site_title: Financial advisers give women worse advice than men, study finds
summary: A two-year study in Hong Kong found that financial advisers tend to give women worse investment advice than men, pushing them towards riskier investments. The researchers, led by Utpal Bhattacharya, suggest that this bias is due to the assumption that women are less financially literate than men and are more likely to buy products that align with their desires. The study's findings have significant implications, as women who experience negative experiences with their financial advisers are more likely to fire them.

site_title: Britain begins work on new high-speed railway
summary: Britain has begun construction on HS2, its new high-speed railway, with a projected cost of over £100 billion. The project aims to create around 22,000 new jobs and boost connectivity between London and major cities in the north. The first stage, connecting London to Birmingham, is expected to open by 2028-2031, with a second phase extending to Manchester and Leeds by 2035-2040. Despite concerns over environmental impact, the project's electric trains are expected to be more environmentally friendly than planes making similar trips.

site_title: Goldman Sachs joins syndicate for Ant IPO of up to US$30b: sources
summary: Goldman Sachs has joined the syndicate for Ant Group's initial public offering (IPO) of up to US$30 billion, set to list simultaneously in Hong Kong and Shanghai. The Hong Kong leg is being sponsored by China International Capital Corp, Citigroup, JPMorgan, and Morgan Stanley, with Goldman Sachs acting as a joint lead manager. If successful, the IPO would be the world's largest and rival Saudi Aramco's US$29.4 billion raise last December.

site_title: Trump administration weighs blacklisting China's chipmaker SMIC
summary: The US Trump administration is considering adding China's top chipmaker SMIC to a trade blacklist, which would force US suppliers to seek a license before shipping to the company. This move comes as the US escalates its crackdown on Chinese companies, particularly those related to the Chinese military. SMIC's relationship to the Chinese military is under scrutiny, and a potential entity listing could impact US companies like Lam Research and KLA Corp, which supply key chipmaking equipment.

site_title: Volkswagen's labour chief rules out four-day week to save jobs
summary: Volkswagen's labor chief, Bernd Osterloh, has ruled out implementing a four-day workweek to secure jobs despite the shift to electric cars, which require fewer workers. The company's existing cost-cutting plan, including reducing the workforce by up to 7,000, is deemed sufficient to overcome the coronavirus crisis. Osterloh stated that the four-day week is not an issue for Volkswagen, citing the company's ability to maintain production levels with extra shifts. The proposal by Germany's largest trade union, IG Metall, is seen as significant in setting benchmarks for wage negotiations in the industry.

site_title: StarHub and M1 fined S$610,000 in total for service disruptions during circuit breaker
summary: Singapore's Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) has fined StarHub and M1 a total of S$610,000 for Internet service disruptions during the circuit breaker period. StarHub was fined S$210,000 for a five-hour disruption affecting 250,000 subscribers, while M1 was fined S$400,000 for two incidents: a 23-hour disruption affecting 18,000 subscribers due to a corrupted database, and a six-hour disruption affecting 20,000 subscribers due to a software fault. Both companies were found to have failed to follow prescribed procedures and provide good service recovery measures to affected customers.

site_title: Suga says consumption tax cut not an option: Mainichi
summary: Japanese Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga stated that cutting the consumption tax is not an option, citing the need for tax revenue to support education and young people. He also expressed caution over an early snap election, suggesting it shouldn't occur until coronavirus infections subside. Suga emphasized the need for policies to protect employment and business operations to counter the virus's impact.

site_title: 'Made in Hong Kong' brand suffers as US-China tensions deepen
summary: The "Made in Hong Kong" brand is suffering due to US-China tensions, with the US Customs imposing a new rule requiring all products exported to the US to be labeled as "Made in China" instead. This change affects Koon Chun Sauce Factory, a century-old family-owned factory, which has been forced to re-label hundreds of thousands of bottles and adjust its shipments to the US. The move is part of Washington's response to Beijing's imposition of a tough new security law on Hong Kong, and has significant implications for the city's manufacturing base and economy.

site_title: Forget TikTok. China's powerhouse app is WeChat, and its power is sweeping
summary: WeChat, China's dominant social media app, has become a powerful tool of social control, guiding and policing what users say, who they talk to, and what they read. Built to be all-in-one, WeChat serves as a bridge for Chinese diaspora members, but its censored and monitored content is also used to spread propaganda and surveillance. The app's influence extends beyond China's borders, with secret police issuing threats on WeChat and military researchers using it to coordinate with China's embassies. The US has proposed banning WeChat, along with TikTok, due to concerns over national security. Users outside of China have found WeChat to be filled with gossip, conspiracy theories, and outright lies, highlighting the limitations of its global reach.

site_title: Saudis reduce oil pricing in sign demand recovery struggling
summary: Saudi Arabia reduced oil pricing for October, cutting Arab Light crude by a larger-than-expected amount for Asia and US buyers. The move suggests fuel demand is waning amid rising coronavirus cases. Oil prices have plunged 35% this year, with Brent crude falling to $42.66. The cuts are the second consecutive month for Asia and the first for US refiners since June, amid a global demand recovery in China.

site_title: South Korea posts fewest Covid-19 cases in three weeks after tightening distancing
summary: South Korea reported 168 new Covid-19 cases, the lowest in three weeks, as of midnight Friday. The country has imposed stricter social distancing rules, including banning onsite dining after 9pm in the Seoul metropolitan area. The total infections rose to 21,010, with 333 deaths. Health Minister Park Neung Hoo said the numbers are on a downward trend but urged caution. The government extended the rules until September 13 to further reduce new infections, amidst a strike by trainee doctors opposing the government's medical sector reform plans.

site_title: SoftBank partners with India's Oyo in move for more oversight
summary: SoftBank is taking a more direct role in managing Oyo's operations in Latin America through a joint venture called Oyo Latam, which will control 1,000 hotels in Brazil and Mexico. SoftBank will invest part of its $5 billion Latin America fund and have equal representation on the board. This move comes as Oyo has reduced its hotel footprint and laid off employees due to the COVID-19 pandemic. SoftBank aims to ensure Oyo's success and avoid a similar fate as its failed investment in WeWork.

site_title: Europe: Shares end whipsaw session lower on tech rout
summary: European shares ended lower in a wild trading session on Friday, with the Stoxx 600 index settling 1.1% lower, amid a technology rout that saw the sector fall 2.7% to a one-month low. Despite this, the banking index rose as merger talks between two major Spanish lenders lifted the sector. Basic resource stocks also gained, while real estate stocks sank. The European Central Bank is expected to maintain an accommodative stance to support inflation, according to analysts.

site_title: Stricken oil tanker pushed away from Sri Lankan coast
summary: A fire-stricken oil tanker, the New Diamond, was successfully pushed away from Sri Lanka's coast into deeper waters after a 36-hour operation. The 330-metre vessel, carrying 270,000 tonnes of crude, drifted dangerously close to Sri Lanka's eastern shores before being towed 60km away. The blaze was contained, and there is no immediate danger of the tanker breaking up. Rescuers successfully contained the fire, and no oil slick has been reported. The vessel's owners, Porto Emporios Shipping Inc, may face legal action if the ship breaks up.

site_title: US says US$1.8b needed to replace Huawei, ZTE parts
summary: US regulators estimate that it could cost small telecoms firms over $1.8 billion to replace Huawei and ZTE parts due to security concerns. The Federal Communications Commission has classified these Chinese tech giants as national security threats, barring carriers from using the Universal Service Fund to buy their equipment. The estimated cost is based on an FCC assessment of networks supported by the federal fund, which rely on Huawei and ZTE hardware and services. FCC Chairman Ajit Pai urges Congress to provide funding to reimburse carriers for replacing the equipment.

site_title: Oil falls 3%, posts weekly drop on demand concerns
summary: Oil prices fell 3% on Friday, posting their biggest weekly decline since June, amid concerns over weak oil demand due to a slow economic recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Brent crude and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) prices dropped 3.2% and 3.9% respectively, with Brent falling 5.3% and WTI losing 7.4% from last week. Market analysts attribute the decline to extended US equities market falls and a report showing US job growth slowed further in August.

site_title: Trump team pushes social media limits as election looms
summary: US President Donald Trump's team is using manipulated social media content, including digitally-altered images, to close the gap on his Democratic rival Joe Biden ahead of the November 3 election. Despite Twitter's crackdown and Facebook's decision to ban new political ads, the Trump campaign claims its strategy is working, citing a tightening of the election. Experts, however, say the approach is polarizing and may not be effective, with some attributing the shift to the "fear factor" created by the internet.

site_title: Ghosn's alleged escape helpers can be extradited: judge
summary: A US judge authorized the extradition of two American men, Michael Taylor and his son Peter, to Japan to face charges for helping former Nissan Chairman Carlos Ghosn escape prosecution. The men, who have been jailed outside Boston since their arrests in May, could still make a last-ditch court appeal. However, experts say it's unlikely a judge would rule in their favor. The final decision rests with US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, who has already vetted the extradition request by officials in the State Department and Justice Department.

site_title: Charges dropped against US black man tried six times for one crime
summary: US prosecutors dropped charges against Curtis Flowers, a black man who spent 23 years in prison for a quadruple murder in Mississippi, after six trials. Flowers maintains his innocence and was released on bail in December. The prosecutor, Doug Evans, was accused of trying to keep black people off the jury and resigned from the case. Mississippi's attorney general dismissed the charges, citing prosecutorial misconduct. Flowers said he is "finally free from the injustice" and called the day of his release "the day I've prayed for."

site_title: Virtual AGMs, shareholder meetings can continue until June 30 next year
summary: Singapore's Parliament has passed amendments to the Covid-19 (Temporary Measures) Act, allowing virtual annual general meetings and shareholder meetings to continue until June 30 next year. The move aims to lower the risk of Covid-19 transmission by giving companies and organizations the option to hold virtual meetings even when physical gatherings are allowed. The extension will also provide flexibility for entities currently allowed to hold virtual meetings until September 30.

site_title: Trump, Biden could feud or make peace at 9/11 event
summary: US President Donald Trump and Democratic challenger Joe Biden may face off in a tense 9/11 event next Friday, with both scheduled to visit Shanksville, Pennsylvania, where a hijacked plane crashed in 2001. Biden expressed willingness to share the stage with Trump, while the two rivals have been largely separated in months. Trump's recent comments about fallen soldiers sparked a firestorm, further highlighting the divide between the president and his challenger. The event could be the closest the two have been to each other since their debate preparations.

site_title: Typhoon Haishen closes in as Japan braces for record wind, rain
summary: Typhoon Haishen is approaching Japan's southern mainland, prompting authorities to recommend evacuation for over 100,000 households. The typhoon is forecast to bring record-high winds, waves, and rainfall, with sustained winds of up to 252 km/h. Over 3,000 homes have lost power in Okinawa, and airlines have cancelled over 500 flights. Authorities urge caution and warn of potentially devastating conditions, with the typhoon's centre moving north at 20 kph. Two injuries have been reported, and the typhoon follows Typhoon Maysak, which caused damage in the Korean peninsula.

site_title: Tesla falls after anticipated S&P inclusion proves illusory
summary: Tesla's shares fell as much as 8% in postmarket trading after missing the anticipated inclusion in the S&P 500 Index, despite posting a fourth consecutive quarterly profit. The company's shares had surged 400% this year, but investors were deterred by questions about its "profitability metrics" and murky full-year forecast. Etsy, Teradyne, and Catalent were added to the S&P 500, while Tesla will have to wait for another day.

images.alt_text: Tesla Inc. shares tumbled as much as 8 per cent in postmarket trading Friday as investors who contributed to its jaw-dropping rally this year in anticipation it may join the S&P 500 Index will have to wait for another day.

site_title: Russia's Covid-19 vaccine 'passes early trial test'
summary: A Russian coronavirus vaccine, "Sputnik V," has shown encouraging results in early trials, with 76 participants developing antibodies within the first three weeks. The vaccine, developed by the Gamaleya research institute, was found to be "safe, well tolerated, and does not cause serious adverse events" in healthy adult volunteers. However, experts emphasized that larger and longer trials are needed to establish its long-term safety and effectiveness. The vaccine is expected to enter industrial production in September, with plans to supply it to an international market, but the World Health Organization has urged Russia to follow established guidelines and go through all necessary stages to develop a safe vaccine.

site_title: Chip-fuelled creativity
summary: Shanghai-based Espressif Systems' CEO, Teo Swee Ann, has created a significant impact on the DIY tech community with his microchips, particularly the ESP8266. Released nearly a decade ago, the Wi-Fi chip has garnered a cult following, with makers creating numerous online tutorials and innovative projects. Teo credits the maker community for helping Espressif refine its software and identify new applications. He aims to leverage this spirit to drive Espressif's future direction, prioritizing both profit and social impact. With a net worth of $990 million, Teo has become one of Singapore's richest individuals, and his company has grown rapidly, with a market capitalization of over $2 billion.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: GIC has joined a consortium to invest US$418 million in I-Mab, a clinical stage biopharmaceutical company, through a private placement. I-Mab aims to fund research and clinical programs globally and develop commercialization capabilities in China. Boustead Projects E&C received a letter of demand from Veolia ES Singapore Industrial for S$17.8 million in liquidated damages, but intends to dispute the claim. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed, amid a lower opening on Wall Street due to Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada.

site_title: More than half of young Americans live with parents
summary: More than half of young Americans, specifically 18-29 year-olds, live with their parents, with 52% of the population in this age group living with at least one parent as of July. This trend, linked to the COVID-19 pandemic, reflects a deeper pattern of rising living arrangements, with 26.6 million young adults in the US having their parents as roommates. The proportion of young adults living with parents has been rising over the past decade, with the 47% before the pandemic being the highest rate since the Great Depression in the 1930s.

site_title: Cordlife sees growing adoption of cord-blood banking
summary: Cordlife Group, a Singapore-based cord blood banking services company, sees growing adoption of its services in Asia, particularly among the middle class. Despite low penetration rates in most countries, the company expects significant growth due to rising healthcare spending by affluent families. Cordlife has reported a 50.2% year-on-year jump in net profit, driven by cost-cutting measures and the expansion of its diagnostics and digital healthcare business segments. The company aims to leverage its mobile app, Moms Up, to expand its reach and increase touchpoints with customers.

site_title: Singapore tests 200,000 'higher-risk' individuals every two weeks for Covid-19: Gan Kim Yong
summary: Singapore conducts regular Covid-19 testing on approximately 200,000 high-risk individuals every two weeks, including migrant workers and frontline workers. In the last cycle, about 200 individuals tested positive, with most cases likely being past infections. The Ministry of Health is expanding testing to more community groups, including taxi drivers, food delivery personnel, and hawker center vendors, to better understand the population's prevalence of Covid-19. The government is also accelerating the development and distribution of Covid-19 vaccines through international collaborations, including the Covax Facility, and supporting local efforts to develop a vaccine.

site_title: Live-streaming House proceedings given go-ahead in principle
summary: The Singapore government has agreed "in principle" to live-streaming Parliamentary proceedings, citing global trends and technological advancements. Minister for Communications and Information S Iswaran announced the move during a debate on the President's Address, noting that other countries' legislatures are already live-streaming proceedings. However, the government still has reservations about Members playing to the gallery and emphasizes that Hansard, the full record of proceedings, is available for those interested.

site_title: US: Wall Street ends lower as tech shares tumble amid selloff
summary: US stocks ended lower Friday, with tech shares tumbling amid a selloff ahead of the holiday weekend. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.6% to 28,133.31, while the S&P 500 dropped 0.8% to 3,426.96. The Nasdaq Composite Index fell 1.3% to 11,313.13, following a 5.0% decline on Thursday. Despite a decline in US unemployment in August, the tech-heavy market was weighed down by concerns.

site_title: CMT, CCT sweeten merger deal for unitholders
summary: Capitaland Mall Trust (CMT) and CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) have sweetened their merger deal, offering higher accretion to their respective distribution per unit (DPU) and waiving the acquisition fee for CMT. The deal, which includes an 88% equity stake in CCT, has been extended to Nov 30. Unitholders will receive 0.72 new CMT units and S$0.259 in cash for every CCT unit. The proposed merger aims to take advantage of the trend towards mixed-use precincts and integrated developments post-Covid-19, with both managers recommending that unitholders vote in favor of the deal.

site_title: Ryanair boosts balance sheet with 400m euro share placement
summary: Ryanair raised 400 million euros (S$646 million) from shareholders to strengthen its balance sheet, bolstering its cash pile to over 3.9 billion euros. The move comes as the airline eyes potential market opportunities post-Covid-19 pandemic, capitalizing on competitors' struggles. Ryanair's debt, though significant, is manageable, and the airline expects growth opportunities for its low-cost model in the next year. The funds will provide financial flexibility to capture these opportunities and de-risk debt repayments over the next 12 months.

site_title: Tech selloff seen as removal of froth rather than a warning sign
summary: A 5.2% decline in the Nasdaq 100, its worst since March, was attributed to profit-taking after a strong run in the tech sector. Most market participants believe the decline is not a warning sign of a larger pullback, citing robust downside hedges and potential for positive news on the US labor market. Some strategists expect tech shares to remain supported, while others point to areas of concern, such as rising volatility and the potential for a vaccine-related sell-off.

site_title: China's Xi supports Beijing free trade zone
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping announced his support for a pilot international free trade zone in Beijing's service sector and digital economy, aiming to promote scientific innovation and ease market access. A negative list for cross-border services trade will be set up by the end of the year to regulate foreign investment. Xi also expressed support for a global alliance of trade and services, further easing market access for the service sector.

site_title: Gold gains as stocks retreat
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,935.10 per ounce, driven by a pullback in global equities and falling US Treasury yields. Demand for the safe-haven metal increased ahead of US non-farm payrolls data. However, a strong dollar is expected to limit gold's advance, putting it on track for a weekly decline. Non-farm payrolls data showed a 1.371 million job increase in August, while the dollar index held steady against its rivals, fueling the decline.

site_title: Reits (September 5-6, 2020)
summary: Reits (September 5-6, 2020) reported mixed trends. S-Reits saw a decline in prices, while US mortgage rates rose after five weeks of declines. In Singapore, a Q3 wave of condo launches is expected to test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf. Global trends include record Manhattan rents, rebounding UK homebuyer demand, and Goldman's acquisition of Seoul hotel and retail assets. New World is selling China property assets and WeWork secured new tenants at 21 Collyer Quay, Suntec City, following its bankruptcy.

site_title: Buffett's Berkshire slashes Wells Fargo stake
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway has cut its stake in Wells Fargo to 3.3% from 4.3%, reducing its US$32 billion investment to US$3.4 billion. This move comes after a series of scandals affecting the bank, prompting Buffett to further reduce his stake since 1989.

site_title: Pent-up demand can't return retail sales to growth: analysts
summary: Singapore's retail sales declined 8.5% year-on-year in July, despite a 27.4% increase from the previous month, due to a low base effect. The decline was driven by a slump in sales at department stores, clothes, and shoes, as well as a 25.4% year-on-year drop in food and beverage services. Analysts expect annual turnover to come in lower this year than in 2019, with some predicting a full-year contraction of 15%. Experts attribute the decline to the ongoing impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and safety measures limiting premises to five diners at each table.

site_title: UK names Australia's Abbott as trade adviser
summary: The UK has appointed Tony Abbott, former Australian prime minister, as a trade adviser despite criticism over his personal views. Abbott will advise the government on trade and investment but won't be involved in striking deals. His appointment has sparked criticism from the opposition Labour party and campaign groups due to his past use of sexist language and scepticism on climate change. International Trade Secretary Liz Truss said the new board will promote open markets and free enterprise, while Prime Minister Boris Johnson defended the appointment, citing Abbott's election by the Australian people.

site_title: Pull-back in US tech stocks spooks Asian markets
summary: US tech stocks plummeted 3.5%, 5.0% for the Nasdaq, and 2.8% for the Dow Jones, spooking Asian markets and causing a 0.87% decline in Singapore's Straits Times Index. Tech-heavy stocks like Venture Corp and AEM Holding fell 4.5% and 3.7%, respectively. Despite the sell-off, Gorilla Trades strategist Ken Berman believes the underlying bullish trend remains intact, potentially marking the start of a new phase of the recovery.

site_title: One in seven UK homes sold every week since tax cut
summary: The UK property market is experiencing a boom, with one in seven homes sold within a week since Chancellor Rishi Sunak raised the stamp duty threshold in July 2020. Demand is highest for three-bedroom houses, and Scotland is seeing the fastest sales, while London is the slowest. The stamp-duty holiday, which ends March 31, 2026, has ignited a market with pent-up demand. However, concerns remain about sustaining momentum as government support programs are withdrawn, potentially triggering unemployment.

site_title: Self-employed relief expect to total S$2b, more than budgeted S$1.2b
summary: The Self-Employed Person Income Relief Scheme in Singapore is expected to cost S$2 billion, exceeding the initial budget of S$1.2 billion. Over 190,000 individuals have received payouts, with 100,000 qualifying automatically and 90,000 after application. The scheme has been flexible, approving about 2 in 3 applications, but rejecting those with high incomes or properties. The government is studying ways to support vulnerable self-employed individuals beyond existing schemes.

site_title: Quarz, Black Crane ask Sabana Reit trustee to form opinion on whether manager failed to follow trust deed terms
summary: Fund managers Quarz Capital Management and Black Crane Capital have asked the trustee of Sabana Reit to form an opinion on whether the trust's manager failed to follow the trust deed terms while pursuing a merger with ESR-Reit. They claim the merger is "unattractive" and will result in a distribution per unit dilution for unitholders. The managers also raised concerns about corporate governance and potential conflicts of interest, citing overlapping investment mandates and a shared sponsor.

site_title: UK commercial property exchange eyes first five listings this year
summary: UK commercial property exchange IPSX plans to list its first five initial public offerings (IPOs) this year, offering real estate investors an alternative to traditional listings. The exchange will debut with the £115 million Mailbox office and retail complex in Birmingham, with a 45% stake retained by current owner M7 Real Estate. IPSX's listings will be in real estate investment trusts (Reits), providing a more liquid alternative to open-ended property funds. The exchange also aims to list office buildings and social housing portfolios in northern England and Britain.

site_title: Transcorp says EGM requisition notice is invalid
summary: CATALIST-listed Transcorp Holdings has stated that a notice by two shareholders to requisition an extraordinary meeting (EGM) to remove two directors and appoint new ones is invalid. The company believes that valid notice was not given for the proposed EGM on September 10. Transcorp will seek clarification from the shareholders and assess the proposed changes to ensure they are in the best interest of the company.

site_title: 5,280 Singaporeans retrenched in first half of 2020
summary: In the first half of 2020, 5,280 Singaporeans were retrenched, with 11,000 citizens affected by temporary layoffs, compared to 33,000 non-citizens. Manpower Minister Josephine Teo reported these numbers in Parliament, amid concerns about employment issues and fair consideration. The government has helped place 24,000 people into new jobs, with a focus on modern services and lifestyle sectors.

images.alt_text: Mrs Teo said that 400 firms are on the Fair Consideration Framework (FCF) watchlist for reasons related to foreign hiring practices.

site_title: Bringing talent back into workforce
summary: A returner program, which allows professionals to resume careers after an extended break, can help companies win the war for talent. The Covid-19 crisis has pushed unemployment in Singapore to its highest level in over a decade, affecting women more than men. A successful example of a returner program is General Electric's Return to Career (R2C) initiative in Dubai, which had a 50% success rate and provided one-on-one mentoring and flexible work arrangements. The program helped returners feel psychologically safe and empowered, and companies can tap into squandered human capital by implementing returner programs correctly.

site_title: Appropriate records can help you out of a sticky situation
summary: Investment managers are required to maintain records substantiating their research and conclusions to support investment recommendations. These records can include new media formats such as e-mails, text messages, and social media posts. Records are considered the property of the firm and cannot be taken to a new employer without consent. Local regulators may also impose record retention requirements, with the CFA Institute recommending a minimum retention period of seven years. Failure to maintain adequate records can lead to fiduciary breaches and compliance issues.

site_title: China developers face harsh liquidity test with looming curbs
summary: China's 50 largest listed homebuilders face their largest liquidity test in over four years due to stringent funding restrictions and a prolonged profitability drop. Their cash reserves barely covered short-term debt as of June 30, with eight companies having less than 0.5 times in cash reserves, signaling greater risk. Renewed financing restrictions and a record maturity of debt in the first quarter next year may heighten repayment pressure for builders, particularly those with annual sales lower than 100 billion yuan.

site_title: Modern takes on familiar flavours
summary: The Elephant Room, a culture-forward cocktail bar in Singapore, offers unique drinks inspired by Little India. The bar's menu features stories behind each cocktail, with ingredients like cardamom, rose petals, and vetiver. The bar's spirits, including whisky, rum, and gin, are sourced from India. New additions to the menu include the King of Toddy, a tribute to a local colonial-era tycoon, and modern takes on familiar flavors, such as Gobi Manchurian cauliflower fritters. The bar aims to be an ambassador for Little India, sharing its stories and culture through its drinks and food.

site_title: Asian bourses trail Wall Street's bloodbath but analysts upbeat
summary: Asian stock markets declined on Friday, mirroring a Wall Street bloodbath, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500 index, and Nasdaq plummeting 2.8-5%. Analysts believe the US market's correction, led by a pullback in technology equities, is a long-overdue adjustment rather than a sign of a losing steam. Despite this, some analysts note the rotation out of tech leaders may not be complete, and further declines are possible. However, many remain optimistic about the bull run, citing resilience in Asian markets and a strong rebound narrative.

site_title: Pence says deal has been reached to fund US government past month's end
summary: US Vice-President Mike Pence announced a deal has been reached to fund the government past September's end, averting a potential shutdown. The agreement allows for a continuing resolution to keep the government funded without including controversial items, with funding levels remaining at current levels. This separate deal from a potential relief bill will focus on addressing the COVID-19 pandemic, allowing lawmakers to move forward on other issues. The government faces a September 30 deadline to fund operations or face a shutdown.

site_title: Family-owned companies outperform: Credit Suisse study
summary: A study by Credit Suisse Research Institute found that family-owned companies outperformed non-family-owned peers in the short and long term, with an average annual outperformance of 370 basis points since 2006. The strongest family alpha is in Australia, with an average annual outperformance of 23%, followed by Chinese and Japanese companies. Family-owned companies have proven more resilient amid the Covid crisis, with lower leverage and stronger cash flow generation, and are more likely to restructure existing businesses rather than diversify.

images.alt_text: The study included 14 Singapore family-owned companies with a total market cap of US$76.3 billion. Europe accounted for 25 per cent, and North America 14 per cent.

site_title: Throw Covid-19 to the wind
summary: The Nasdaq set a milestone by breaking above February 2020 highs in June, driven by the tech-heavy nature of the index, which benefited from the COVID-19 lockdown. The S&P followed in August, and the Dow surpassed its February 2020 highs three months later. A key strategy involves trading the Nasdaq leader, as it tends to show trend weakness first. The Shanghai Index is also showing strong trend strength, with a potential breakout above a double-top pattern, indicating a longer-term sustainable uptrend.

site_title: Naomi Osaka is steadfast in winning, and her message
summary: Japanese tennis star Naomi Osaka continued her dominance at the US Open, defeating Camila Giorgi 6-1, 6-2 and advancing to the next round. Osaka, the 2018 champion, has used her platform to highlight racism and police violence, sparking praise and criticism from players and fans. She has been vocal about her stance, wearing a mask with the names of victims of police violence during matches. Osaka's coach, Wim Fissette, attributes her focus to her self-belief and perfectionism on the court, saying she is "100 per cent focused on the tennis."

site_title: AirAsia X says Singapore-based lessor files US$23m claim for outstanding dues
summary: AirAsia X, a Malaysian long-haul carrier, says Singapore-based lessor BOC Aviation has filed a US$23 million claim against the company for outstanding dues related to a lease agreement and guarantees. The airline is reviewing the documents and seeking legal advice. This comes as AirAsia X has been struggling financially due to travel restrictions caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The airline has also taken steps to raise capital and is seeking payment deferrals and concessions from creditors.

site_title: McLaren GT: Quick beyond question, but quietly quotidian
summary: The McLaren GT is a supercar that balances performance with daily usability, defying the typical expectation of impracticality. With a mid-engine design and scissor doors, the GT features a height-adjustable suspension and Proactive Damping Control, which adjusts suspension stiffness based on road conditions. In Comfort mode, the car rides smoothly, while Sport mode unleashes its full potential, delivering exceptional grip, poise, and acceleration. The GT also offers ample space and practicality, with a spacious trunk and rear cargo area, making it suitable for both track days and daily use.

site_title: Curevac gets US$300m grant to hurry up Covid-19 vaccine
summary: German biotech firm Curevac has secured nearly US$300 million in government funding to accelerate its COVID-19 vaccine development and production. The grant, valued at 252 million euros, will support the company's efforts to produce and develop a safe and effective vaccine in high volume. Curevac aims to produce 100 million doses by the end of this year and may expand its cooperation with Tesla to develop RNA printers for decentralized production. The company's CEO, Franz-Werner Haas, believes the funding will substantially support their efforts to develop a vaccine quickly.

site_title: Will healthcare-related manufacturers sustain growth in a post-pandemic world?
summary: Healthcare-related manufacturers, such as glove makers, are expected to sustain growth even in a post-pandemic world due to increased hygiene awareness and stricter mandates for masks and gloves. Demand for personal protective equipment (PPEs) is likely to remain robust, driven by government restocking efforts and growing glove consumption in developing countries. Analysts predict strong growth in 2020 and 2021, with a slight decline in 2022, before returning to a normalised growth rate in 2023. Established players with integrated supply chains and diversified production capabilities are expected to be more resilient against demand fluctuations.

images.alt_text: The widespread demand for gloves has resulted in a supply squeeze, driving the average selling price up.

site_title: Party's over for money-losing fintechs as funding tap shuts
summary: Fintech companies are facing a crisis as investors pull back, cutting global funding by 35% to $25.6 billion in the first half of 2020. Companies like Monzo and Revolut reported significant losses, while N26 shut its UK business. Investors now prioritize profitability and sustainability over rapid expansion. Industry experts say pivoting to traditional profit drivers, such as deposits and lending, is key to making a profit in banking. Companies like Oaknorth Bank, which reported an 88% increase in profit, are finding success with a credit-focused mindset. Consolidation is expected as the market faces cash shortages and a potential downturn.

site_title: Virtual AGMs, shareholder meetings can continue until June 30 next year
summary: Singapore's Parliament passed amendments to the Covid-19 (Temporary Measures) Act, extending alternative arrangements for virtual annual general meetings and shareholder meetings until June 30, 2021. This allows companies to hold virtual meetings even when physical meetings are allowed. Other amendments include extending deadlines for collective sales and clarifying dispute resolution processes. The move aims to reduce the risk of Covid-19 transmission and provide more flexibility for entities to conduct meetings.

site_title: Firms to get up to S$30,000 for each new worker if they hire more locals in next 6 months
summary: Singapore has launched a new scheme to encourage firms to hire more locals, offering up to S$30,000 in payouts per worker over 12 months. The Jobs Growth Incentive (JGI) scheme aims to help firms grow their local workforce, particularly among workers under 40 and those aged 40 and above. The payouts will be based on the firm's Central Provident Fund contributions and will be automatically computed each month. The scheme is part of a larger effort to boost job creation and support local workers, with Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announcing the initiative in August.

images.alt_text: Firms which hire more locals in the next six months stand to get up to S$15,000 for each worker under 40 years old, and up to S$30,000 for each aged 40 and up.

site_title: VW unit plans to resume Navistar takeover push: sources
summary: Volkswagen's heavy-truck business, Traton, plans to restart negotiations with Navistar International after talks were put on hold due to the pandemic. Traton is seeking to acquire Navistar for $35 a share, or $2.9 billion, to secure a foothold in the US heavy-truck market. VW already owns 16.7% of Navistar, and the deal remains on the table despite initial doubts among investors. The US$35-a-share offer may satisfy Navistar's largest shareholder, Carl Icahn, and the company's valuation has surpassed VW's original offer, now at $35.28 a share.

site_title: US job growth slows further in August; unemployment rate falls to 8.4%
summary: US job growth slowed further in August, with non-farm payrolls increasing by 1.371 million jobs after 1.734 million in July. The unemployment rate fell to 8.4% from 10.2% in July, as government assistance programs that supported businesses and workers expired. Companies are announcing layoffs, putting pressure on the White House and Congress to restart fiscal package negotiations. With the presidential election looming, the jobs situation is expected to provide political ammunition for both Democrats and Republicans. Employment growth peaked at 4.791 million in June.

images.alt_text: US job growth slowed further in August as financial assistance from the government ran out, threatening the economy's recovery from the Covid-19 recession.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore retail sales declined 8.5% in July, the first full month with shops reopened after the "circuit-breaker" shutdown. This marks a setback in the sector's recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: How Disney should handle 'Black Panther 2' after Chadwick Boseman's death
summary: Marvel Studios is considering how to handle the sequel to "Black Panther" after Chadwick Boseman's death, with some suggesting honoring his legacy by passing the mantle to Shuri, played by Letitia Wright, or celebrating his character's return as the Black Panther. The film's cultural impact and Boseman's performance have sparked a dilemma, with some arguing that recasting the role would undermine the film's message of diversity and inclusivity. Disney and Marvel have declined to comment, instead focusing on paying tribute to Boseman, who died at age 43.

site_title: Malaysia's Petronas to reshape portfolio after quarterly loss
summary: Malaysia's state-owned energy giant Petronas reported a quarterly loss of RM21 billion due to a coronavirus-related demand slump and lower oil prices. The company's revenue fell 42% to RM34 billion. In response, Petronas will reshape its portfolio, focusing on expanding its renewable energy portfolio and reassessing its oil and gas positions. The company's full-year performance is expected to be severely affected by volatile oil prices and a supply glut.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust's proposed acquisition of AsiaRetail Fund comes as suburban malls show resilience
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) has proposed acquiring the remaining 63.1% stake in AsiaRetail Fund (ARF) for S$1.06 billion. The acquisition will boost FCT's suburban portfolio and is seen as a positive move despite the ongoing impact of Covid-19 on suburban malls. Analysts expect suburban malls to recover more strongly than centrally located peers. The sale of underperforming Bedok Point will also contribute to the Reit's growth.

site_title: Yum China guides Hong Kong listing price at HK$412 each
summary: Yum China Holdings raised HK$17.3 billion (S$3.04 billion) in its Hong Kong listing, pricing 41.91 million shares at HK$412 each. The offer represents a 4.9% discount to its US closing price of US$55.92. The company, which operates KFC and Pizza Hut in China, joins a growing list of US-listed Chinese firms seeking a trading foothold in Hong Kong amid strained US-China relations.

site_title: US: S&P 500 rises after open as unemployment dips below 10%
summary: US stocks rose after the opening bell on Friday, driven by a lower-than-expected US unemployment rate in August. The S&P 500 opened higher, rising 0.04% to 3,453.60, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.17% to 28,341.05. The Nasdaq Composite fell 0.54% to 11,396.24. The unemployment rate drop exceeded expectations, contributing to the market's positive reaction.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed higher on Friday, up 0.46 points to 1,515.86, driven by a volume of 7.014 billion lots worth RM4.071 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 657 to 388.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end week on negative note
summary: Hong Kong shares ended the week on a negative note, falling 1.25% as global markets reversed due to concerns over high valuations. The Hang Seng Index closed at 24,695.45, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also declined. The decline follows months of strong gains, with investors wary of overvaluation.

site_title: Britain's Co-op to create 1,000 jobs in stores expansion
summary: Britain's Co-operative Group plans to open over 65 new and extended stores this year, creating up to 1,000 jobs, as it capitalizes on the popularity of local convenience shopping during the pandemic. The £135 million investment program aims to capitalize on changing grocery shopping habits, with smaller convenience stores being the mainstay of the Co-op's business. This expansion follows market leader Tesco's announcement to create 16,000 permanent roles to meet the surge in demand for home deliveries.

site_title: Singapore government agrees 'in principle' to live streaming of Parliament
summary: Singapore's government has agreed "in principle" to live stream parliamentary proceedings, a decision made after studying technical and implementation details. The move aims to achieve transparency, accountability, and accessibility while preserving the integrity and dignity of parliamentary proceedings. The decision comes despite initial reservations, with the government noting that demand for live broadcasts is relatively low, around 10% of free-to-air television news. The details of the implementation will be announced later.

site_title: Singapore tests 200,000 'higher risk' individuals every two weeks for Covid-19: Gan Kim Yong
