The book, featuring 60 interviews with workers from different professions, highlights the struggles and aspirations of those in the workforce. Despite some interviewees expressing frustration with their jobs, many remain determined to move forward and find meaning in their work. The book provides an authentic and relatable perspective on the realities of work life in Singapore.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust to raise up to S$1.39b to buy rest of AsiaRetail Fund
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) plans to raise up to S$1.39 billion through a private placement and/or preferential offering to acquire the remaining 63.1% of AsiaRetail Fund (ARF) for S$1.06 billion. The acquisition includes five Singapore retail malls and one office property, expanding FCT's portfolio to 11 retail properties and increasing its net lettable area by 64%. The deal is expected to provide 8.59% distribution per unit (DPU) accretion and unlock value to redeploy to higher-yielding assets.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq slip from record levels as tech-rally cools
summary: US stocks slipped from record levels on Thursday as a tech rally cooled. The S&P 500 fell 0.45%, the Nasdaq dropped 1.61%, and the Dow Jones fell 0.03%. Elevated jobless claims and a decline in tech stocks contributed to the downturn. Despite this, some Asian markets, such as Singapore, continued their upward trend. The cooling tech rally has raised concerns about the sustainability of recent market gains.

site_title: Thai Airways opens diner for customers craving in-flights meals
summary: Thai Airways has opened a pop-up restaurant in its Bangkok office, offering customers a taste of in-flight meals. The restaurant, which serves 2,000 meals per day, aims to recoup lost revenue during the coronavirus pandemic. Diners can interact with cabin crew and enjoy meals cooked to order, using airplane parts as decorations. The move is part of Thai Airways' restructuring plans, with a bankruptcy court decision set for September 14. The airline has been grounded due to travel restrictions, but this pop-up restaurant provides a unique experience for those craving airline food.

site_title: No change to components on the Straits Times Index
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) constituents remain unchanged following the September 2020 quarterly review. The STI reserve list, consisting of Keppel DC Reit, Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust, Suntec Reit, NetLink NBN Trust, and Keppel Reit, will replace ineligible constituents as needed. The STI is reviewed quarterly to accurately represent the investable universe and facilitate the inclusion of eligible IPO stocks. The next review is scheduled for December.

site_title: United Airlines' Singapore staff not affected by carrier's plan to cut 16,370 workers
summary: United Airlines' Singapore staff are not affected by the airline's plan to furlough 16,370 US-based employees when federal aid expires on Oct 1. The airline had warned of job losses due to the Covid-19 pandemic, but employees in Singapore are not included in the cuts. United had over 90,000 employees globally before the pandemic and is seeking a second stimulus package to protect jobs. Airlines in the US are collectively losing over $5 billion a month due to low passenger travel demand.

site_title: Qualcomm ramps up 5G smartphone, laptop bets
summary: Qualcomm is ramping up its 5G smartphone and laptop efforts, launching 5G-ready Snapdragon 4 chips for affordable phones priced $125-$250. The company also unveiled a 5G platform for connected laptops, targeting those working from home due to the pandemic. Qualcomm forecasts 750 million 5G smartphones will ship in 2022 and 1 billion connections by 2024, two years ahead of 4G projections. The company is partnering with manufacturers and Acer to bring 5G-enabled PCs to market, featuring multi-day battery life and high-end security.

images.alt_text: Qualcomm, the world's biggest supplier of mobile phone chips, says 5G networks are being built far faster than previously expected.

site_title: Axington board says rights issue to proceed as planned
summary: Axington Inc's two-man board has announced that a planned rights issue will proceed as planned despite recent controversy. Five directors had quit the board following the announcement on August 21. The company's shares have been suspended since August 31. The remaining directors have reached out to controlling shareholders to seek clarity on the company's direction. The board's decision was made without any changes to the planned issue.

site_title: Nintendo to re-release Mario games in 35th anniversary year
summary: Nintendo is re-releasing classic Mario games, including Super Mario 64, Super Mario Sunshine, and Super Mario Galaxy, on the Nintendo Switch for a limited time to celebrate the 35th anniversary of Super Mario Bros. The collection, titled Super Mario 3D All-Stars, will be available from September 18 until the end of March. This move aims to bolster the Switch's gaming pipeline and provide relief to investors, who have been waiting for Nintendo to release more of its back catalogue titles.

images.alt_text: Nintendo said on Thursday it would re-release classic titles featuring popular character Mario for a limited time on its hit Nintendo Switch console to mark 35 years since the launch of landmark game Super Mario Bros.

site_title: SoftBank to consider bid for TikTok in India
summary: SoftBank is exploring assembling a group of bidders for TikTok's India assets, with talks held with Reliance Jio Infocomm and Bharti Airtel. The move comes after India banned 59 Chinese internet services, including TikTok, citing national security concerns. SoftBank, which owns a stake in TikTok's Chinese parent ByteDance, is seeking local partners to consider a bid. This follows a similar process in the US, where SoftBank previously formed a consortium with Google and Walmart to bid for TikTok's assets.

site_title: Vaccine group says 76 rich countries now committed to 'Covax' access plan
summary: Seventy-six wealthy nations, including Japan and Germany, have committed to joining the Covax global Covid-19 vaccine allocation plan, which aims to fairly distribute vaccines worldwide. The plan, co-led by the World Health Organization, will allow countries to procure vaccines through the facility for their populations, with the goal of securing 2 billion doses by the end of 2021. The US has opted out, while China is in talks to potentially join, with the European Union now allowing its member states to buy vaccines through Covax.

site_title: Trump urges residents of North Carolina to vote twice in the Nov 3 election
summary: US President Donald Trump urged North Carolina residents to vote twice in the Nov 3 election, once by mail and once in person, sparking concerns about potential voter fraud. Trump claimed the system would not allow duplicate votes if mail-in voting is expanded due to the pandemic. However, experts say voter fraud is rare in the US. Voting more than once is illegal in North Carolina and a felony, prompting criticism from Democrats, including the state's Attorney General, who vowed to uphold the will of the people.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump has urged residents of North Carolina to try to vote twice in the Nov 3 election, once by mail and once in person, causing a furor for appearing to openly urge a potential act of voter fraud.

site_title: Leader Environmental Technologies raises S$8.7m from fully-subscribed rights issue
summary: Leader Environmental Technologies (LET) has successfully raised S$8.7 million from a fully-subscribed rights issue, with 45.9 million rights shares allotted to satisfy excess applications. The issue, announced in June, offered four rights shares for every five existing shares at S$0.015, and the company plans to expand into municipal sludge treatment and industrial wastewater treatment. The allotment will be listed on the Mainboard, increasing LET's share capital to 1.3 billion shares.

site_title: Race consciousness in Singapore cannot, should not be erased: Edwin Tong
summary: Singapore Minister for Culture, Community and Youth Edwin Tong emphasized that the country's consciousness of race cannot be erased. He noted that while Singaporeans are less race-conscious than their parents and grandparents, this has been achieved through consistent and systematic efforts. Tong acknowledged that race and religion remain fault lines, but stressed the importance of recognizing individuality within diversity. He also highlighted the role of ethnic self-help groups in serving vulnerable communities across racial and ethnic lines, and emphasized the need for youth involvement in the discourse on race and other issues.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 22.14 points to 1,515.40. Volume reached 9.406 billion lots worth RM5.427 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 872 to 315.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust to raise up to S$1.39b to take over AsiaRetail Fund
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) plans to raise up to S$1.39 billion through a private placement and/or preferential offering to fund the acquisition of AsiaRetail Fund (ARF) for S$1.06 billion. The acquisition will increase FCT's retail properties to 11 and its net lettable area by 64%. The deal is expected to provide 8.59% DPU accretion and expand FCT's portfolio size to approximately S$6.65 billion. The acquisition fee is approximately S$19.3 million, with stamp duties and other expenses estimated at S$32.1 million.

site_title: Blaze breaks out again on supertanker off Sri Lanka, cargo area intact
summary: A new fire broke out on the supertanker New Diamond, carrying 2 million barrels of oil, off the east coast of Sri Lanka. The fire spread to the bridge, and one crew member is missing while another is injured. Despite the flames, the cargo area remains intact, with no damage reported. Two Russian warships have arrived to assist in the firefighting efforts. The incident occurred about 20 nautical miles off the coast of Sri Lanka, where the ship was en route to India's Paradip port.

site_title: Facebook bans Indian ruling party politician for policy violation
summary: Facebook has banned Indian ruling party politician Raja Singh for violating its policies covering violence and hate, citing his hate-speech content against Muslims. The move comes after a Wall Street Journal report revealed that an employee opposed applying hate-speech rules to profiles in Singh's name. Facebook will remove pages, groups, and accounts set up to represent Singh, but will allow discussion of him. The company claims its evaluation process led to the decision, sparking a public-relations and political crisis in India.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Biofourmis raises $100m in Series C round led by SoftBank, valuing the company at over $1 billion. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) introduces a new SGD funding facility for banks to boost liquidity. The Workers' Party proposes a national minimum wage, citing studies that Singaporeans are willing to pay more for essential services. CapitaLand secures a $200m SORA-SOFR loan from UOB, while PSA and HMM launch a joint venture for container terminal operations in Singapore. Frasers to launch an e-commerce marketplace in October.

site_title: Review and adapt policies as needed to tackle inequality, sustain mobility: Maliki
summary: Singapore must review and adapt its policies to tackle inequality and sustain social mobility, said Second Minister for Education and Foreign Affairs Maliki Osman. The government should prioritize a basic standard of living, ensure absolute mobility, and provide equal opportunities. This includes investing in education, jobs, housing, and retirement, as well as promoting a societal consensus on a basic standard of living. Maliki also emphasized the need for a strong economy, greater equality of opportunity, and values such as egalitarianism and humility.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close with losses
summary: Hong Kong shares declined on Thursday due to a weak US jobs report and geopolitical tensions. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.45%, and the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.58%. These losses overshadowed hopes for a coronavirus vaccine.

site_title: Asian Healthcare Specialists completes issuance of shares to Encyclia and Vanda
summary: ASIAN Healthcare Specialists (AHS) has issued 25 million shares to Encyclia and Vanda at a conversion price of S$0.1602, as agreed. The shares, representing 5.48% of the enlarged share capital, are expected to be listed on the Catalist board on Sept 7. This follows the original holders of AHS' convertible bonds converting their bonds into shares.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing still in growth mode in August; electronics snaps losing streak
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector continued to grow in August, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) reading at 50.1 points, up from 49.9 in July. The electronics industry rebounded, reaching a two-year high of 50.6 points, while factory output growth improved. This marks the second consecutive month of expansionary territory. The positive sentiment suggests that the sector remains resilient despite global challenges.

site_title: K-Pop band BTS to become multimillionaire shareholders with label's IPO
summary: BTS members are set to become multimillionaire shareholders after receiving 478,695 common shares each from Big Hit Entertainment, their label, in anticipation of an initial public offering (IPO) that could raise up to 962.6 billion won. The IPO would value the company at up to 4.8 trillion won, with the label relying heavily on BTS, generating 87.7% of its revenue in the first half of 2020. The stock gift aims to strengthen the long-term partnership with major artists and boost morale among the members.

site_title: GM, Honda join hands to develop cars in North America
summary: General Motors and Honda Motor have formed an alliance to develop vehicles in North America, sharing common platforms and propulsion systems to reduce costs and meet demand for cleaner vehicles. Talks on co-development will begin immediately, with engineering work starting in early 2021. The partnership aims to create a range of vehicles, including electrified and internal combustion models.

site_title: Dubai seeks to attract wealthy foreign retirees as expats leave
summary: Dubai is seeking to attract wealthy foreign retirees as expats leave due to the coronavirus pandemic and low oil prices. The government will grant renewable five-year visas to residents over 55 with a monthly income of 20,000 dirhams (S$7,414) or cash savings of one million dirhams, or property worth two million dirhams. This move aims to boost the economy and attract new talent.

site_title: SGX RegCo blocks Spackman Entertainment's proposed divestment
summary: SGX RegCo blocked Spackman Entertainment Group's proposed divestment of its 43.88% interest in Spackman Media Group, pending a review of past acquisitions. The regulatory arm requires SEG to assess if its previous dealings were on normal commercial terms or prejudicial to minority shareholders. SEG had announced plans to sell its stake to substantial shareholder Spackman Equities Group on August 18.

site_title: Norwegian fintech Vipps in payments deal with Visa
summary: Norwegian fintech company Vipps has struck a deal with Visa to expand in Europe, giving banks and card issuers access to a mobile wallet. The partnership aims to increase digital payments adoption. DNB, the largest Vipps shareholder, is a Norwegian bank. The deal will provide a convenient mobile payment option for users, enhancing the company's presence in the European market.

site_title: US trade deficit swelled to biggest since 2008 in July
summary: The US trade deficit widened to $63.6 billion in July, the largest since 2008, driven by a decline in services surplus to $17.4 billion, the lowest since 2012. Exports increased 8.1% to $168.1 billion, while imports rose 10.9% to $231.7 billion, resulting in a combined value of $399.8 billion below pre-pandemic levels. The data suggests a bumpy economic recovery ahead.

images.alt_text: The US trade deficit swelled to the widest in 12 years in July, with the surplus on services plunging to the lowest since 2012, pointing to a bumpy economic recovery ahead.

site_title: Daimler makes green bond debut
summary: Daimler, the parent company of Mercedes-Benz, is offering its first green bond sale, aiming to raise funds for developing emission-free vehicles. The euro-denominated 10-year notes are priced at 160-165 basis points above midswaps. This sale follows Germany's successful green bond sale earlier in the week, which received bids for 33 billion euros. The offering is part of Europe's rebounding green bond market, with year-to-date sales reaching about 105 billion euros. Daimler's sale is expected to price later on Thursday, with several banks arranging the deal.

site_title: Aramco shelves US$20b petrochemical plan after oil's crash
summary: Saudi Aramco is shelving its US$20 billion petrochemical project in Yanbu, citing the crash in energy prices and a determination to preserve its dividend. The company is also reviewing its plans to buy 25% of Sempra Energy's liquefied natural gas terminal in Texas. Aramco's CEO Amin Nasser has already reduced investment to US$25 billion for 2020 and is likely to cut it further. The company is reviewing all major greenfield projects and will focus on existing assets instead. This move comes as the oil industry navigates a turbulent period, with excess supply in the market and a possible shortage of gas around 2025.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng converts US$4.95m loan into 33.3% stake in Cybint International
summary: Chip Eng Seng's wholly-owned subsidiary, CES Edutech, has converted a US$4.95 million loan into shares of Cybint International, acquiring a 33.33% stake in the company. The conversion resulted in Cybint International becoming an associated company of Chip Eng Seng. The net asset value of the conversion shares is approximately negative US$0.52 million, based on Cybint International's unaudited management accounts as of June 30, 2020.

site_title: McDonald's takes action against Australia's Burger King over 'Big Jack'
summary: McDonald's has filed a trademark infringement notice in Australia against Hungry Jack's, the local unit of Burger King, over its "Big Jack" burger, which bears similarities to McDonald's "Big Mac". Hungry Jack's allegedly "deliberately adopted or imitated" the distinctive appearance and ingredients of the Big Mac, including a tagline and construction. McDonald's is seeking damages, interest, and costs, as well as an order to destroy promotional materials. The matter is currently before the Federal Court in Australia.

site_title: US-based Radco sells US$315m of apartments, building cash for deals
summary: Radco Cos, a US-based multifamily building owner, has sold $315.6 million worth of apartments, leaving it with 28 of its 59 purchased properties since 2011. The company is building a cash pile to capitalize on future opportunities, with 18 more rental communities currently marketed for sale. CEO Norman Radow aims to sell these properties to build a cash reserve for potential deals, indicating a shift in the company's strategy.

site_title: Singapore shares lack mojo as India-China border tensions escalate
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.32% amid escalating India-China border tensions and Sino-US rivalry. The Straits Times Index opened at 2,546.01 and closed at 2,531.79, down 8.15 points. Parkway Life Reit bucked the decline, hitting a new high and settling at S$3.89. The Reit's inclusion in the FTSE EPRA Nareit Global Developed Index, set for September 21, contributed to its gains.

site_title: Qualcomm ramps up 5G smartphone and laptop bets
summary: Qualcomm is expanding its 5G offerings with the launch of a 5G-ready version of its Snapdragon 4 chips, priced at $125-$250, set to hit markets in the first quarter of 2021. The company aims to make 5G mobile phones accessible to billions of people and is partnering with smartphone makers like Motorola, OPPO, and Xiaomi. Additionally, Qualcomm is backing connected laptops with the Snapdragon 8cx Gen 2 5G platform, targeting the growing demand for work-from-home devices.

site_title: Zara-owner Inditex starts online sales at budget brand Lefties
summary: Inditex's budget brand Lefties has started online sales in Spain and Portugal, giving it a digital advantage over discount fashion chain Primark in its second-biggest market. Lefties sells low-priced clothing for women, men, and children and is present in six countries. The brand, first set up in 1999 to clear Zara clothing, now has its own designers and ranges. This move aims to increase Lefties' digital presence and compete with Primark in the market.

site_title: Chevron delays restart of Gorgon LNG unit to Oct for extra repairs
summary: Chevron has delayed the restart of its Train 2 unit at the Gorgon LNG plant in Western Australia to October due to additional repairs needed for welds on propane heat exchangers. The unit had been shut since May for maintenance, which was extended after cracks were found in production units. The company now expects to complete repairs and restart production at Train 2 in October.

site_title: Enterprise Singapore, energy firms launch innovation challenge for SMEs, startups
summary: Enterprise Singapore launched the inaugural Energy Open Innovation Challenge (EOIC) 2020, partnering with energy firms Chevron, ConocoPhillips, ExxonMobil, and Shell to seek innovative solutions from SMEs and startups addressing 19 challenge statements. The challenge offers grant support of up to S$1 million and S$25,000 for winning startups. The EOIC aims to facilitate partnerships between large and small companies to adopt new technologies and reduce manual work, creating higher-value jobs. The call for entries closes on November 6.

site_title: StanChart to charge S$5 fee for credit card and loan bills paid over branch counters
summary: Standard Chartered Singapore will charge a S$5 service fee for credit card and loan payments made over branch counters, as part of its efforts to bring digital convenience to customers. This move affects over 98% of credit card payments, which are now directed to digital channels. The bank aims to redirect staff to assist clients with more complex services. Other banks, such as DBS and Maybank Singapore, do not charge similar service fees at their branches.

site_title: Discuss minimum-wage idea now, even if it's to be implemented later: Jamus Lim
summary: Singapore Parliament - Workers' Party Member of Parliament Jamus Lim proposed discussing the idea of a national minimum wage, despite the current crisis, to prepare for its implementation in the future. Lim argued that studies show Singaporeans are willing to pay more for essential services, and a minimum wage would have minimal impact on unemployment. However, the government warned that a national minimum wage could lead to higher costs and lost jobs. Lim countered that a minimum wage provides a social safety net and should not be removed during a crisis.

site_title: Amazon, Verizon may invest over US$4b in India's Vodafone Idea
summary: US wireless carrier Verizon Communications and Amazon.com may invest over US$4 billion in India's Vodafone Idea, a joint venture between Britain's Vodafone Group and India's Idea Cellular. The investment comes after the Indian Supreme Court ruled that mobile carriers must settle government dues within 10 years, providing Vodafone Idea with some relief. The company still owes roughly 500 billion rupees to the Indian government and is among India's top three telecom firms by subscribers.

site_title: Swedish startup Volta unveils electric truck, to manufacture in UK
summary: Swedish startup Volta Trucks has unveiled its 16-tonne electric truck, the Volta Zero, with plans to start production in the UK in 2022. The company aims to put 500 vehicles on the road by 2022, with trials set to begin with parcel delivery companies in the UK and Europe. The first Volta vehicle was manufactured by Prodrive in Warwick, England, and the company is in discussion with suppliers for contract manufacturing. Volta is seeking funding to fuel its capital-intensive business, with seven or eight other customers already on board.

site_title: Record CO2 emissions for Arctic wildfires: EU
summary: Arctic wildfires have surpassed the 2019 record for CO2 emissions, with over a quarter of a billion tonnes released since January 2020, according to the European Union's Earth observation programme. The majority of the fires are in Russia's Eastern Federal District, which emitted over half a billion tonnes of CO2 from June to August. The fires, fueled by freakishly warm weather and low soil moisture, have broken records for scale and intensity, adding to humanity's need to curb carbon pollution.

images.alt_text: This year's Arctic Circle wildfires, still ablaze, have already surpassed the record set in 2019 for CO2 emissions, adding to the carbon pollution humanity needs to curtail, the European Union's (EU) Earth observation programme said Thursday.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks jump over 1% as chipmakers rally
summary: South Korean shares rose over 1% on Thursday, extending a third consecutive gain, driven by strong foreign buying of chip stocks. Chipmakers Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix surged, with Samsung ending 3.7% higher after Nvidia's announcement of new gaming chips. The Kospi index closed at 2,395.90, boosted by a government plan to create a $16.84 billion fund for President Moon Jae-in's "New Deal" programme, which also drew 194 billion won worth of foreign buying.

site_title: Nissan's China sales slow in August when Toyota, Honda surge
summary: Nissan's China sales declined 2.4% in August, contrasting with Toyota's 11.1% and Honda's 21.3% increases. Nissan sold 126,592 vehicles, up 4.7% from the previous month, as sales recover from coronavirus lockdowns. The company aims to boost sales in China, which is crucial for its recovery following Carlos Ghosn's expansion drive. Nissan's struggles in China come as rival automakers capitalize on the market's growth.

site_title: Europe: Stocks extend rally at open
summary: European stocks continued their rally at the open on Thursday, with the FTSE 100 up 0.6%, DAX 30 up 0.9%, and CAC 40 up 1.3%. Analysts attribute the gains to central bank stimulus, saying market participants remain comfortable with the idea of global support. The rally is expected to continue as long as central banks maintain their support, according to AvaTrade analyst Naeem Aslam.

site_title: Robinhood faces SEC probe related to deals with high-speed traders: report
summary: Robinhood Markets Inc faces a US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) probe over its practice of selling clients' orders to high-speed traders, potentially resulting in a fine exceeding $10 million. The investigation is at an advanced stage, following a similar probe into the company's handling of a system outage in March. Robinhood has been credited with popularizing trading among millennials, but the SEC investigation highlights concerns about the company's transparency and regulatory compliance.

site_title: Cattle ship capsized in storm off Japan, rescued crewman says
summary: A Panamanian-flagged cattle ship, the Gulf Livestock 1, capsized off Japan's Amami Oshima island in a storm, with one crew member rescued so far. The 139-meter vessel, carrying 43 crew and nearly 6,000 cattle from New Zealand to China, lost an engine before being hit by a wave and capsizing. Japan's coastguard is continuing the search for the missing crew members, while the Philippines government coordinates with the coastguard ahead of another typhoon in the region. The incident highlights concerns over the live animal export trade.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end higher on US rallies
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.94% to 23,465.53, following a rally on Wall Street. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index advanced 218.38 points, while the Topix index rose 7.84 points. Investors sought new trading cues amid few market-moving events, with few other stocks reporting significant changes.

site_title: Amazon bucks UK labour market gloom with 7,000 new jobs
summary: Amazon is creating 7,000 new permanent jobs in the UK in 2020, bringing the total new hires to 10,000. This move aims to meet growing customer demand and enable small and medium-sized enterprises to scale their businesses. The jobs will be in various roles, including warehouse workers, engineers, and HR professionals. This is a positive development for Britain's labour market, which has been affected by the coronavirus pandemic. Amazon's total UK workforce is expected to reach over 40,000 by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Amazon brought a little cheer to Britain's troubled labour market on Thursday, saying it will create a further 7,000 permanent jobs in 2020, taking total new hires this year to 10,000.

site_title: MAS introduces new SGD funding facility for banks, boosts access to liquidity
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) introduced a new SGD Term Facility to boost Singapore dollar and US dollar funding for banks, promoting stable funding conditions and sector resilience. The facility will offer SGD funds in one-month and three-month tenors, complementing the existing overnight MAS Standing Facility. Additionally, domestic systemically important banks can pledge eligible residential property loans as collateral, and the MAS USD Facility will expand its eligible collateral pool to provide greater flexibility in managing USD liquidity.

site_title: Philippines' jobless rate eases as economy reopens from lockdown
summary: The Philippines' unemployment rate decreased to 10% in July, with 4.6 million jobless people, from a record-high 17.7% in April. The easing of lockdowns allowed more businesses to reopen, generating jobs. The unemployment rate is expected to ease further to 6-8% next year. Despite the improvement, the economy is still facing challenges from surging infections and tepid consumption and investment. Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has kept partial restrictions in place until the end of September.

site_title: Vietnam to resume some Asian flights as curbs on business travel ease
summary: Vietnam plans to resume international commercial flights to and from six Asian cities, including Guangzhou, Seoul, and Tokyo, from mid-September. The flights will be limited to 5,000 travelers per week, with those arriving required to undergo two weeks of quarantine unless their visit is under 14 days. The move aims to revive Vietnam's economy, particularly tourism and transport, which have been severely impacted by travel restrictions. The country has not yet reopened to tourists and will continue to enforce strict health measures.

site_title: Japan defence chief Kono backs Suga for prime minister, but keeps eye on top job
summary: Japan's Defence Minister Taro Kono backs Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga as the country's next leader, citing the need for continuity in tackling the coronavirus crisis. Kono, who had considered entering the leadership race, now predicts he will one day be prime minister. He emphasized the importance of containing Covid-19 while restarting the economy, highlighting the need for a stable leadership. Suga's announcement to run has led to Kono's endorsement, but Kono's future ambitions remain a key consideration.

site_title: Nex, VivoCity and Suntec City visited by infectious coronavirus patients
summary: Three Singapore shopping malls - Nex, VivoCity, and Suntec City - were recently visited by infectious Covid-19 patients, according to the Ministry of Health (MOH). The MOH also announced two new clusters in dormitories and two community cases, with 137 patients discharged and 801 recovering in community facilities. The number of new daily community cases has increased to three, while the number of unlinked cases has risen to two. Singapore has a total of 56,908 cases, with 52 patients in hospital and 15 who died of Covid-19 complications.

site_title: Gold recoups some losses as US dollar steadies
summary: Gold prices recouped some losses, rising 0.2% to $1,945.59 per ounce, as the US dollar steadied. This follows a 1.4% drop on Wednesday, its largest one-day decline since August 19. Despite this, gains were limited by increased risk appetite due to better-than-expected economic data, particularly in China's services sector. The US Federal Reserve's "Beige Book" report highlighted sluggish economic growth, but investors remain optimistic about gold's long-term prospects due to ultra-loose monetary policy.

site_title: Hot stock: Hosen gets SGX query after shares surge 70.3%
summary: Hosen Group's shares surged 70.3% during morning trading, prompting a query from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) about unusual price and volume movements. The company's board replied it was unaware of any unannounced information that might explain the trading activity. Hosen's shares reached a five-year high of seven cents, driven by higher demand for its packaged food products due to consumer stockpiling during the "circuit-breaker" period. The company reported a 20.8% increase in revenue to S$40.5 million for the six months ended June 30, 2020.

site_title: Mall operator Frasers to launch e-commerce marketplace in Oct
summary: Frasers Property Retail, a Singaporean mall operator, will launch an e-commerce marketplace, Frasers eStore, in October, featuring 200 merchants and accessible via the Frasers Experience app. The move aims to tap into the pandemic-driven shift to online shopping, leveraging its existing 800,000-strong loyalty app membership base. The eStore will be integrated with AsiaMalls' loyalty platform, expanding Frasers' digital offerings and supporting tenants in adapting to changing consumer behaviors.

site_title: Singapore-South Korea fast lane for essential business, official travel to start on Sept 4
summary: Singapore and South Korea are set to launch a fast lane for essential business and official travel on September 4, allowing eligible travelers to bypass standard immigration procedures while adhering to public health measures. The fast lane will require pre-departure and post-arrival testing, as well as a controlled itinerary for the first 14 days in the receiving country. This agreement aims to restore connectivity and support economic recovery between the two countries, with operational details to be published on the SafeTravel website.

site_title: Demand for HDB resale flats remains strong in August: SRX
summary: Singapore's HDB resale flat market remained strong in August, with 2,435 flats sold, a 23.5% increase from the same month last year. Prices grew at the fastest monthly rate since February, with a 0.7% increase. The majority of sales were of four-room flats, followed by five-room and three-room flats. Despite the Hungry Ghost Festival, which typically sees lower sales activity, market sentiment appears to be slowly recovering. The resale price index increased by 0.7%, with prices in non-mature estates rising by 3.3% year on year.

site_title: Thailand's Aug headline CPI drops 0.50% y-o-y, smaller than forecast fall
summary: Thailand's headline consumer price index (CPI) declined 0.50% in August from a year earlier, beating the forecasted 0.65% drop. The core CPI index rose 0.30% from a year earlier. These results indicate a smaller-than-expected economic contraction. The data suggests that inflation is under control, providing a positive signal for the Thai economy.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Thursday; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.3% or 8.42 points to 2,531.52. Weaker bank stocks amid discussions on the Republic's foreign worker policy contributed to the decline. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of welcoming talent and investments. Meanwhile, US stocks jumped, with the Nasdaq reaching a record high, while Tokyo stocks opened higher.

site_title: Virtual star of Porsche ads gets real venture backing
summary: A Japanese startup, Aww, has raised $1 million in a seed round from Coral Capital to develop technologies for virtual influencers, including Imma, a computer-generated celebrity with over 250,000 Facebook followers. Aww aims to use the funds to create real-time rendering and services using 5G wireless standards, virtual and augmented reality. The company joins a growing trend of digital-beings companies, including Lil Miquela and KFC's virtual Colonel Sanders, as virtual influencers become increasingly photorealistic and blur the line between reality and virtual reality.

site_title: Broker's take: Jefferies upgrades Mapletree Commercial Trust, Suntec Reit to 'buy'
summary: Jefferies Singapore upgraded its recommendation on Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) and Suntec Real Estate Investment Trust (Suntec Reit) to "buy" from "hold", citing diminishing COVID-19 cases, growing vaccine headlines, and easing travel norms. Analysts raised price targets for MCT to S$2.25 and Suntec Reit to S$1.70, citing attractive asset portfolios and strong execution records. While valuation is relatively expensive, asset positioning and execution justify the premium, with MCT's assets positioned to weather a slowdown in consumer spending.

site_title: South Korea plans to create 20t won fund for 'New Deal' economic initiatives
summary: South Korea's finance ministry announced plans to create a 20 trillion won (S$22.9 billion) fund over five years to support President Moon Jae In's "New Deal" programme, focusing on technology sectors for jobs and growth. The fund will be partly financed by policy banks and retail investors, aiming to boost economic initiatives. This move is part of the government's efforts to stimulate the economy and create jobs.

site_title: PSA, HMM launch JV for container terminal operations in Singapore
summary: PSA Corporation Ltd and South Korea's HMM have formed a joint venture (JV) in Singapore to drive operational excellence and efficiency in container operations. The JV, HMM-PSA Singapore Terminal (HPST), will hold 58% stake with HMM owning 42%. The partnership aims to provide "long-term hubbing certainty" to HMM's global vessel fleet and collaborate on operational technology developments. Subject to regulatory approvals, the JV is scheduled to commence operations before the end of this year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares drop at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks started Thursday slightly lower, extending the previous day's losses, following a well-below-forecast reading on US private-sector jobs. The Hang Sang Index dropped 0.37% to 25,026.99, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined marginally. This decline is attributed to the US private-sector jobs data, which fell short of expectations, sparking uncertainty in global markets.

site_title: New cybersecurity platform in Singapore to groom talent, run annual summit
summary: A new cybersecurity platform, @-Wise Cybersecurity Centre of Excellence, has been established in Singapore to develop cybersecurity talent, build a cybersecurity ecosystem, and raise awareness among fintechs and financial institutions. The platform is a collaboration between the Singapore FinTech Association, AMTD Foundation, AMTD Digital, the University of Waterloo, and workforce platform iQ4. The centre will be headquartered in Singapore and aims to foster a cybersecurity community in the city-state.

site_title: Typhoon Maysak drenches North and South Korea
summary: A powerful typhoon, Typhoon Maysak, drenched both North and South Korea, killing at least one person in the South and leaving over 2,200 evacuated and 120,000 homes without power. The storm made landfall in Busan, packing gusts of up to 140kmh, before moving northwards to North Korea, where it brought heavy downpours and flooding. Authorities lifted the typhoon warning as the storm weakened, but another typhoon, Typhoon Haishen, is expected to hit the peninsula on Monday.

site_title: Ant's mega IPO sets up Jack Ma to escalate war with Tencent
summary: Ant Group's upcoming IPO is set to make it the world's largest stock debut, with a valuation of around $225 billion. However, investors should focus on the long-term threat to its core businesses from rival Tencent Holdings. Tencent is expanding its e-commerce and payments services, potentially encroaching on Ant's turf, and has attracted merchants and brands away from Alibaba's online marketplaces. The two companies are engaged in a battle for traffic and users, with Tencent's WeChat app gaining an edge over Ant's Alipay due to its wider ecosystem and user base.

site_title: Asia: Stocks track Wall Street records on vaccine, recovery hopes
summary: Asia's stocks rose on Thursday, tracking Wall Street's record session, driven by hopes for a global economic recovery fueled by new vaccine developments and central bank support. Investors overlooked a weak US private-sector jobs report and China-US tensions, instead focusing on potential returns. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records, with the STI up 0.4% as investors remained positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

images.alt_text: Equities rallied in Asia on Thursday following another blow-out session on Wall Street as investors bet that the global economy is on the right track, fuelled by new vaccine hopes and central bank largesse.

site_title: Property investors tap mobile home parks for Covid-era returns
summary: Real estate investors are shifting their focus to alternative properties due to the pandemic's impact on traditional commercial property markets. Mobile home parks saw a 23% increase in sales in the second quarter, with over $800 million in transactions, according to JLL. This surge is part of a broader decline in commercial property purchases, which dropped 68% to $45 billion in the same period. Investors are seeking Covid-era returns in non-traditional assets, as traditional commercial property markets face challenges.

site_title: Alibaba Pictures inks pact with Youku to produce variety shows, movies
summary: Alibaba Pictures has signed a three-year cooperation framework agreement with Youku, a Chinese online video platform, to produce variety shows, movies, and dramas. The deal allows for joint investments and collaborations, with caps on total investment and fees payable. Alibaba Pictures aims to integrate its content with Youku's platforms, making it available to more users and strengthening its market competitiveness. The agreement runs from September 2, 2020, to March 31, 2023.

site_title: JC Penney lenders consider teaming up with outside bidders
summary: JC Penney's lenders are considering a plan to join forces with an outside bidder to buy the retailer after efforts to find an independent owner stalled. The hedge funds that hold JC Penney's loans would become co-owners of the business, partnering with a third party that could include a potential buyer. This plan comes after the lenders were unable to line up an independent owner, and a representative for JC Penney declined to comment on the matter.

site_title: Airlines removing seats to make space for gadgets, seafood
summary: Airlines are adapting to the coronavirus pandemic by increasing air cargo operations, as passenger flights remain grounded. With increased demand for medical supplies, electronics, and other goods, freight rates have soared, with some airlines removing seats to make space for cargo. Qantas, Fiji Airways, and others are now flying fresh produce, seafood, and other goods, generating significant revenue. Analysts predict that air cargo will remain a bright spot for carriers, with limited capacity and no let-up in demand. Airlines that adapt are seeing profits, while others struggle financially.

site_title: Neymar one of three PSG stars to test positive for Covid-19
summary: Paris Saint-Germain (PSG) stars Neymar, Angel Di Maria, and Leandro Paredes have tested positive for COVID-19 after a holiday trip to Ibiza. The cases are linked to the Champions League final defeat by Bayern Munich. PSG's Ligue 1 campaign may be affected, with a game against Lens potentially postponed. The French league has strict rules regarding collective team training sessions and match postponements due to positive tests.

site_title: China's services sector sustains recovery as hiring picks up: Caixin
summary: China's services sector continued its recovery, with the Caixin/Markit services PMI at 54.0 in August, down from 54.1 in July. This marks the fourth consecutive month of growth, as companies hired more people for the first time since January. The sector's growth was driven by domestic demand, but new orders growth slowed to the weakest in four months. Analysts expect China to be the only major economy to post positive annual growth in 2020, citing ongoing economic recovery and policy support needed to bolster the economy.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 5.01 points, or 0.33%, to 1,542.55. Trading volume reached 247.78 million lots worth RM96.52 million. The market saw 254 gainers and 98 losers, with a net gain of 154.

site_title: Trendlines, Agriline to invest US$3.8m in four medtech, agritech startups
summary: Trendlines, a startup incubator, and Agriline, an investment vehicle owned by Trendlines' controlling shareholder, have approved investments in four medical and agrifood technology startups. Agriline will invest US$3 million, while Trendlines will invest US$800,000. The four portfolio companies, Arcuro Medical, ProArc Medical, Phytolon, and FruitSpec, have achieved significant success in their respective fields, including the launch of a new meniscus repair system and a fruit yield estimation technology. The investments follow earlier funding rounds for eight other portfolio companies this year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on US rallies
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, following Wall Street's rally. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 1.18% or 273.99 points to 23,521.14, while the Topix index advanced 0.87% or 14.14 points to 1,637.54. The rally comes with few market-moving events, with investors continuing to trade despite US tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Top Federal Reserve staffer, whose research helped guide policy in recent years, dies
summary: Thomas Laubach, a top Federal Reserve staffer, has died at 55 due to pancreatic cancer. Laubach, who headed the Fed's monetary policy division, contributed to the development of the central bank's new strategy to encourage higher employment. His research on the natural rate of interest is considered a benchmark in monetary policy discussions. Fed Chair Jerome Powell praised Laubach as a world-class economist and committed public servant. Laubach had previously worked at the European Central Bank and Germany's Bundesbank, and received his PhD in economics from Princeton University in 1997.

site_title: Twitter confirms account of India PM Modi's personal website hacked
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's personal website was hacked, with tweets asking followers to donate to a relief fund through cryptocurrency. Twitter confirmed the incident and took steps to secure the compromised account. The tweets were taken down after the hack, which follows several other high-profile hacking incidents, including hijacking of accounts of prominent personalities like Joe Biden and Elon Musk. Twitter is investigating the incident and is not aware of additional accounts being impacted.

site_title: OCBC prices US$1b subordinated notes due 2030 at 1.832%
summary: OCBC Bank priced US$1 billion subordinated notes due 2030 at 1.832% and received almost six times subscriptions, with net proceeds used for general corporate purposes. The notes are expected to qualify as Tier 2 capital and will bear a fixed rate of 1.832% until 2025, then reset to the 5-year US Treasury Rate plus 1.58%. The offering, under OCBC's US$30 billion global medium term note programme, attracted US$5.8 billion in investor interest, with 63% coming from Asia.

site_title: Japan's Aug service sector activity worsens as pandemic stymies recovery
summary: Japan's services sector activity contracted at a faster pace in August, marking the first decline in four months, due to the ongoing impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The Jibun Bank Japan Services Purchasing Managers'Index (PMI) fell to 45.0, down from 45.4 in July, due to weakening new business and business expectations. Employment conditions remained sluggish, with job cuts mainly attributed to reduced workloads. The contraction is a concern for policymakers, who are counting on a pickup in domestic spending to aid the economy's recovery from a sharp recession.

images.alt_text: Activity in Japan's services sector contracted at a faster pace in August for the firs time in four months, as uncertainty from the coronavirus pandemic weighed on sentiment, hurting business at home and from abroad.

site_title: Livspace raises US$90m in Series D round for Asia-Pacific expansion
summary: Livspace, an interior design and home renovation platform, has raised US$90 million in its Series D round led by Kharis Capital and Venturi Partners. The fresh funds will be used to expand into new markets in Asia-Pacific, develop its current platform, and create new products. The company aims to establish a presence in dozens of cities in India and other markets such as Australia, Malaysia, and Indonesia. Livspace has quadrupled its revenue and doubled its margin since its last funding round, with a gross revenue run rate of over US$200 million.

site_title: White House slams WHO over criticism of push for Covid-19 vaccine
summary: The White House has criticized the World Health Organization (WHO) for expressing concerns over a potential coronavirus vaccine authorization without full trials. The US will not join the WHO's COVAX vaccine plan due to WHO involvement. About 172 countries are participating in the plan to ensure equitable access to vaccines.

site_title: CapitaLand obtains two-year S$200m SORA-SOFR loan from UOB
summary: CapitaLand has secured a two-year S$200 million term loan from UOB, referencing both the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (SORA) and the Secured Overnight Financing Rate (SOFR). This is the first dual-tranche loan of its kind in Singapore, with loan proceeds used for general corporate purposes. The loan aims to enhance market confidence in adopting SORA, a key interest rate benchmark in Singapore, as the country transitions away from the Swap Offer Rate (SOR).

site_title: Jordan to reopen main airport from next week
summary: Jordan's main airport, Queen Alia International, will reopen to regular flights starting from September 8, after a nearly six-month shutdown due to the novel coronavirus. The move aims to revive the country's economy, which has been heavily impacted by the pandemic. Authorities will set rules for incoming passengers, including testing for Covid-19 on arrival, and will depend on the epidemiological situation in their countries of origin. This reopening is expected to boost the tourism industry, which was severely affected by the pandemic, generating 14% of Jordan's GDP and employing 100,000 people.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, CapitaLand, OCBC, Alibaba Pictures, SK Jewellery, Oceanus
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singaporean stocks saw new developments on Thursday, including UOB and CapitaLand entering a two-year term loan agreement, OCBC Bank announcing a rate revision for its 360 account, and Alibaba Pictures Group entering a cooperation framework agreement with Chinese online video platform Youku. SK Jewellery reached a two-year high after its co-founders offered to take the company private, while Oceanus Group saw heavy trading volume after appointing former minister Yaacob Ibrahim as an independent director. The STI rose 0.4% on Thursday despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Moody's puts LMIRT's ratings on review for downgrade
summary: Moody's Investors Service has placed the B1 corporate family rating of Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) on review for downgrade. The review focuses on LMIRT's proposed acquisition of Lippo Mall Puri, its funding structure, and its ability to refinance debt due in August 2021. The credit rating agency will also examine the potential impact of the sponsor's weaker credit profile and the linkages between LMIRT and the sponsor. The review is expected to be completed within 60-90 days.

site_title: US dollar extends gains; euro drops from US$1.20 high
summary: The US dollar extended its overnight gains, strengthening 0.4% to US$1.18645, after positive US manufacturing data and technical factors. The euro fell 0.4% from its previous high of US$1.20, while the Australian dollar lagged behind due to the country's recession confirmation. Analysts attribute the dollar's strength to the US economy's relative performance and potential shift in monetary policy.

site_title: JPMorgan set to boost stake in China securities venture to 71%
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co is set to increase its ownership stake in its Chinese securities joint venture to 71% after emerging as the qualified buyer of a 20% stake. The stake will be sold for 178 million yuan, following Beijing's decision to allow foreign banks to take full ownership in China's financial market. With full control, JPMorgan will be able to set strategy and direct capital in China's vast financial market, marking a significant milestone for the US bank's expansion into the country.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan Chase & Co is poised to raise its ownership in its Chinese securities joint venture to 71 per cent, bringing it a step closer to becoming the first foreign bank to attain full ownership of a firm as the country opens its US$49 trillion financial market.

site_title: Microsoft unveils 'deepfake' detector ahead of US vote
summary: Microsoft has unveiled its Video Authenticator software, a tool designed to detect "deepfake" photos and videos that can be manipulated using artificial intelligence. The software analyzes images and videos for signs of manipulation, which could be invisible to the naked eye. This move comes ahead of the US presidential election, where deepfakes have already been targeted by initiatives on social media platforms. The Video Authenticator is the latest effort to combat deepfakes and ensure the authenticity of online content.

site_title: Mobile games platform Skillz to go public
summary: Mobile games platform Skillz plans to go public by merging with Flying Eagle Acquisition, a New York Stock Exchange-listed company, without an initial public offering. The deal values Skillz at $3.5 billion, more than six times its projected 2022 revenue. Skillz facilitates competitive esports events for mobile games and expects over 2 billion tournaments this year with $1.6 billion in entry fees. The company plans to use the funds for growth, citing the mobile gaming market's predicted $150 billion growth by 2025. The deal must be approved by shareholders and regulators.

site_title: Oil drops 2%, reversing course as US petrol demand slumps
summary: Oil prices dropped 2% on Wednesday, reversing early gains, after a report showed a decline in US petrol demand. Crude inventories fell 9.4 million barrels, while petrol demand dropped to 8.78 million barrels per day. This news comes amid concerns about the economic recovery from the coronavirus pandemic, which may be slowing down. Oil prices had previously recovered from historic lows hit in April due to a record supply cut by the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries.

site_title: Singapore must guard its reputation for openness: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of maintaining the country's reputation for openness, despite a depressed economic climate. He assured that the government will continue to welcome foreign talent and investment, which has kept projects flowing. Lee highlighted recent articles implying Singapore might turn inward, warning that such a reputation would harm the country. Business associations praised the assurance, stressing the need for Singapore to remain a global hub for business and talent, with a balanced approach to foreign labor.

site_title: Australia: Shares follow Wall Street higher on recovery, stimulus hopes
summary: Australian shares rose 0.9% to 6,101.2, tracking a Wall Street rally, driven by stronger US data and hopes for additional stimulus. Blue-chip financial firms and healthcare stocks led gains, while gold stocks declined 1.6%. New Zealand's benchmark index also rose 1% to 12,020.6, driven by gains in Fisher & Paykel Healthcare and a2 Milk Co. The rally follows a US factory orders rise and expansion in private payrolls, but sluggish sector recoveries add to expectations for US stimulus.

images.alt_text: Australian shares extended gains on Thursday, tracking a rally on Wall Street as stronger data from the world's top two economies and hopes of additional US stimulus lifted investor sentiment.

site_title: Europe: Shares snap four-day losing streak on tech, chemical sector gains
summary: European shares closed higher on Wednesday, snapping a four-day losing streak, driven by gains in the tech sector and a recovery in global manufacturing activity. The Stoxx 600 index rose 1.7% as chemical stocks reached a record high. Local technology stocks mirrored US gains, ending at their strongest level since 2001. Despite weak inflation data and pandemic concerns, analysts see the recovery as a corrective phase, with central banks and governments supporting economies.

site_title: US growth, job gains slowing: Federal Reserve
summary: The US economy continues to experience slowing growth and job gains, with spending remaining below pre-pandemic levels. The Federal Reserve's beige book survey highlighted "rising instances of furloughed workers being laid off permanently" as demand remains soft, especially in services industries. Employment increased overall, but job growth and hiring volatility persisted. The report also noted lingering uncertainty due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, with the US government debt and deficits projected to surpass the national economy by 2023.

site_title: US government debt to pass 100% of GDP in 2021: CBO
summary: The US government debt is expected to surpass 100% of GDP by 2023, the highest in the nation's history, according to the Congressional Budget Office (CBO). The debt will increase to 107% of GDP by 2023 and reach 109% by 2030. The budget deficit this year is expected to triple to $3.3 trillion, or 16% of GDP, the largest since 1945. This surge in debt is largely due to the coronavirus pandemic and rising deficit spending.

site_title: Oil rises to US$46 on US inventory drop, economy hopes
summary: US crude oil prices rose to $46 a barrel, gaining for a third day, after the American Petroleum Institute reported a 6.4 million barrel drop in US crude inventories. Stronger manufacturing surveys and hopes for a recovery from the coronavirus pandemic also supported the price increase. The US economy is showing signs of improvement, with oil prices rising despite concerns over the impact of US President Trump's tariffs on Canada and other countries.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq end at records, extending Wall Street rally
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday, with the Nasdaq ending above 12,000 for the first time and the S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average reaching fresh records. Despite disappointing employment data and a cautious Federal Reserve report, investors shrugged off concerns, attributing the surge to positive market momentum and optimism about coronavirus therapeutics and vaccines. The Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 1.0% to 12,056.44, its fourth straight record, while the S&P 500 won 1.5% to close at 3,580.84.

site_title: Virus plunges Australia into recession
summary: Australia has plunged into its first recession in almost three decades, with its economy shrinking 7% in the second quarter due to the pandemic. The contraction follows a 0.3% dip in the previous quarter and is attributed to vast economic shutdowns and a significant drop in household spending on services. The government has provided billions of dollars in support, but the country's record run of 28 consecutive years of economic growth has officially come to an end.

site_title: DBS gets regulatory nod to set up JV securities firm in China
summary: DBS Group has received regulatory approval from China's China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) to establish a joint venture (JV) securities company, DBS Securities (China), with a 51% controlling stake. The JV will provide onshore products and services for domestic and international customers, marking an important part of DBS's strategy in China. The move is part of China's efforts to open up its financial sector, with the aim of increasing competition and addressing US criticism of perceived unfair trading practices.

site_title: Google, Apple to install contact tracing directly on smartphones
summary: Apple and Google plan to integrate contact-tracing software directly into smartphones, making it easier for public health authorities to use the system without building their own apps. The technology, first launched in April, aims to alert people through their smartphones when they come into contact with someone infected by the coronavirus. The integration will allow for faster adoption, with Apple and Google emphasizing user privacy and requiring participants to opt-in. This change is expected to help combat the coronavirus, particularly in the United States where adoption has been slow.

images.alt_text: Apple and Google plan to directly integrate contact-tracing software into smartphones as they aim to broaden a jointly developed initiative to combat the coronavirus.

site_title: Prince Harry and Meghan sign sprawling Netflix deal
summary: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle have signed a multi-year deal with Netflix to produce impactful films and series, focusing on creating content that informs and inspires audiences worldwide. The couple, who recently moved to California, aims to create content that shines a light on people and causes, as well as inspirational family programming. The deal is exclusive to Netflix and is part of their efforts to produce scripted series, feature films, and children's programming through their non-profit organization Archewell.

site_title: Abe's successor has much work to do
summary: Japan's longest-serving prime minister, Shinzo Abe, has announced his resignation due to deteriorating health. His successor, Yoshihide Suga, faces a challenging task in addressing the country's stagnant economy, demographics, and public debt. Despite Abe's efforts with "Abenomics," the economy has struggled to meet its ambitious targets, with average real GDP growth at 1% and inflation less than 1%. The next leader must focus on digitalization, addressing demographics, and promoting renewable energy to transform Japan's economy.

site_title: Germany gets 30 billion euros of orders for its debut green bond
summary: Germany has received 30 billion euros in orders for its debut green bond, surpassing expectations. The 10-year securities were sold at a price one basis point lower than conventional bonds. This move is seen as a significant step for Germany to dominate the growing green bond market and build a more liquid market. The country aims to be the benchmark issuer for green debt in Europe, with plans to twin the bonds with conventional securities.

site_title: OCBC to make third round of rate revisions on 360 account
summary: OCBC is revising its 360 account interest rates starting October 1, introducing a third tier with balances up to S$25,000 earning 0.4% bonus interest. The maximum effective rate has been raised to 2.68% on the first S$75,000, with balances between S$50,000 and S$75,000 earning 1.2% interest. This change comes as interest rates continue to trend lower due to the ongoing low interest rate environment.

site_title: GCB land in Queen Astrid Park for sale with S$126.8m guide price
summary: A Good Class Bungalow (GCB) residential redevelopment land in Singapore's Queen Astrid Park is up for sale by tender with a guide price of S$126.8 million. The site, currently home to a 999-year leasehold condominium, offers opportunities for a single mansion or subdivision into up to four GCB parcels. Knight Frank Singapore notes that the land's elevated grounds and regular shape command good premiums, making it an attractive proposition for home-seekers and investors. The tender closes on October 7.

site_title: SGX's multi-asset strategy needs to address IPO drought
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has successfully diversified its multi-asset strategy, growing its derivatives and market data businesses, but local retail investors have been left with limited stock options. The recent US stock market rallies have highlighted this gap, with tech and software stocks reaching record valuations. SGX's strategy needs to address this issue to meet the needs of local retail investors.

site_title: PropertyGuru bags S$300m from TPG, KKR to boost growth
summary: US private equity firms TPG Capital and KKR have invested an additional S$300 million in PropertyGuru, a South-east Asia-focused property technology firm. The fresh funding will accelerate the company's growth strategy across its key markets, including a new mortgage marketplace, sales enablement solution, and data capabilities. PropertyGuru will further invest in identified areas of growth, aiming to meet the "rapidly evolving needs in the property ecosystem." The company continues to hold the largest market share in South-east Asia at 57 per cent.

site_title: Snapshot of Airbus jet use shows China propping up fragile recovery
summary: Airbus jet use shows a tentative recovery, but one still dependent on China, with almost two-thirds of its planes flying in the past five days. The recovery is lopsided, with Chinese travel bouncing back while the rest of the world struggles. The company's wide-body aircraft, including the A380, remain grounded, with only 69% of its A320-series fleet in use. The A350 is the only bright spot, with over 75% usage globally. The industry faces ongoing challenges and job cuts amid a downturn in air travel, with passenger traffic down 80% in July.

site_title: Pandemic sending chefs off beaten track
summary: The pandemic has led to a shift in the mindset of millennial chefs in Singapore, with many opting to strike out on their own rather than following traditional restaurant careers. This trend is driven by the insatiable appetite for new dining experiences, resulting in the emergence of new business opportunities for young chefs. The F&B scene has seen a surge in vibrancy, with chefs exploring new flavors and ideas.

site_title: Covid fallout accelerating financial sector tech race
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic is accelerating the technology race in the financial sector as companies adapt to new operating parameters. Fintech innovations, such as artificial intelligence and machine learning, are becoming increasingly important for companies to remain competitive. Many financial institutions are turning to Application Programming Interfaces (APIs) and hybrid cloud capabilities to integrate their legacy systems and access smart analytics and core operational solutions. Regulators are also leveraging automation to monitor and control risk. As the sector continues to evolve, companies must prioritize data and control transparency to comply with increasing data requests from regulators.

site_title: Aspiring TikTok buyers pursue four options in effort to revive talks: sources
summary: TikTok's prospective buyers are discussing four ways to structure an acquisition from Chinese owner ByteDance, including buying US operations without key software, seeking Chinese approval, licensing the algorithm, or a transition period from a US national security panel. ByteDance had planned to finalize a deal by mid-September to comply with President Donald Trump's order to divest US assets due to concerns over US citizen data safety.

images.alt_text: TikTok's prospective buyers are discussing four ways to structure an acquisition from its Chinese owner ByteDance, which include buying the app's US operations without key software, after Beijing stalled a deal which could be worth US$30 billion, sources said.

site_title: Adnoc inks US$5.5b deal with Apollo-led consortium
summary: Adnoc, the state-owned oil company of Abu Dhabi, has entered into a US$5.5 billion real estate investment partnership with an Apollo-led consortium. The deal, expected to close before the end of 2020, will result in upfront proceeds of US$2.7 billion and will leverage rental income streams from select Adnoc real-estate assets. Adnoc will retain a 51% majority stake, while Apollo will acquire a 49% stake in Abu Dhabi Property Leasing Holding Company, a wholly-owned Adnoc affiliate. The deal aims to unlock value from non-oil and gas assets and reinvest in core business.

site_title: Leveraging infrastructure investments for faster recovery
summary: The infrastructure sector has been a crucial backbone of economies during the pandemic, keeping essential services operational despite disruptions. However, the global cost of COVID-19 is estimated at $5.8-8.8 trillion, putting fiscal strain on governments. To drive economic recovery, governments should prioritize infrastructure project investments, leveraging shovel-ready projects, alternate financing sources, and technology. This includes tapping local capital markets, joint ventures, and pre-funding priority projects through staple financing. By doing so, governments can boost job growth, stimulate innovation, and create smart urban infrastructure projects, ultimately contributing to a post-pandemic economic growth.

site_title: US factory orders rise more than expected in July
summary: US factory orders rose 6.4% in July, exceeding expectations of a 6.0% gain, as the manufacturing sector continues to recover from the Covid-19 pandemic. This is the second consecutive month of growth, indicating a steady recovery.

site_title: Directors should disclose intent on rights issue: CGAC
summary: Singapore's Corporate Governance Advisory Committee (CGAC) recommends that directors of listed companies disclose whether they intend to subscribe to a rights issue, providing material information to shareholders. The committee notes that directors' participation in rights issues should be transparent, even if they choose not to subscribe. This comes after Singapore Airlines' directors let their rights mandatory convertible bonds lapse without exercising them, sparking investor concerns over lack of transparency.

site_title: Big tech credit can help safeguard economy from shocks: BIS
summary: The Bank for International Settlements (BIS) suggests that loans from big tech companies, such as Ant Group, can help safeguard economies against market shocks by providing more stable credit based on data analysis. This type of credit correlates less with macroeconomic factors, unlike traditional bank credit. The BIS believes this can support smaller companies during times of stress, and potentially cushion economies against economic downturns.

site_title: Britain must move now to bag new EU deal this year, EU Brexit negotiator says
summary: The EU's Brexit negotiator, Michel Barnier, says Britain must engage with EU demands on fair competition, fisheries, and dispute resolution by the end of October to seal a new trade deal. The UK has shown insufficient flexibility and creativity, Barnier said, warning that a deal without a "long-term, balanced and sustainable" agreement on fish is unlikely. A deal by October 15 is crucial for approval at the EU summit, and Barnier believes a deal is still possible, but difficult, to replace decades of close cooperation after Brexit.

site_title: SIIC bags new China wastewater treatment project, three expansion agreements
summary: SIIC Environment Holdings, a Singapore-based water and solid-waste treatment company, has won a wastewater treatment project in China's Heilongjiang province and signed three expansion agreements for similar projects across the mainland. The company's indirectly-owned subsidiaries have secured agreements for projects with a combined capacity of 110,000 tonnes, with water tariffs ranging from 1.35 yuan to 5.96 yuan per tonne. The new project is expected to contribute positively to the group's performance, with two other projects commencing commercial operations earlier this year.

site_title: UK house prices surge to new high
summary: UK house prices surged to a 16-year high in August, rising 2% to £224,123, driven by a tax cut that fueled post-lockdown demand. This represents a 3.7% annual increase. However, experts predict that activity will weaken due to rising mortgage rates and increasing affordability concerns. The Nationwide Building Society reported the biggest price increases since 2005, sparking concerns about the sustainability of the housing market.

site_title: Oceanus sees active trading after Yaacob Ibrahim joins board
summary: Oceanus Group, a Singapore-based abalone producer, saw significant trading activity after appointing former Minister Yaacob Ibrahim as an independent director. The company's shares were the most actively traded by volume on the Singapore bourse, with 154.8 million shares changing hands. Oceanus' stock price remained stable within the 0.7-0.8 Singapore cent range. Dr. Yaacob's appointment is seen as a strategic fit, bringing greater diversity and depth to the company's board with his experience in environment, communications, and information. The company has until March 1, 2021 to meet financial exit criteria.

site_title: Global companies still keen on Singapore despite pandemic
summary: Despite the "depressed economic climate" due to the Covid-19 pandemic, major investment commitments remain strong in Singapore, with multinational companies (MNCs) adding local headcount and expanding facilities. The Economic Development Board (EDB) reports a higher pipeline for this year compared to last year, with companies like Hyundai, Zoom, and Tata Consultancy Services opening new facilities in Singapore. The government attributes the interest to Singapore's reputation as a trusted location in a troubled world, with opportunities arising from the pandemic, such as vaccine manufacturing and pandemic risk insurance.

site_title: Small hotels will be in vogue after pandemic: Oyo chief
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic is expected to shift travel preferences towards smaller hotels and home rentals, according to Ritesh Agarwal, CEO of Oyo Hotels and Homes. This fundamental change in travel nature is anticipated to be a long-term trend, as holiday-goers opt for boutique establishments and alternative accommodations over larger hotels. This shift is driven by the pandemic's impact on the hospitality industry, with smaller, more personalized options becoming increasingly popular.

site_title: A step in the right direction for Williams
summary: Serena Williams won her 102nd singles victory at the US Open, beating Kristie Ahn 7-5, 6-3, in a straightforward match. The win marked a step in the right direction for Williams, who had struggled in recent matches, including a third-round loss to Maria Sakkari. Williams is now one victory away from tying Margaret Court's record of 24 Grand Slam singles titles and will face Margarita Gasparyan in the next round.

site_title: Singapore leads in innovation for Asia-Pacific, and ranks eighth globally
summary: Singapore has led the Asia-Pacific region for the seventh consecutive year in the Global Innovation Index (GII), ranking eighth globally. The GII, co-published by Cornell University, Insead, and WIPO, evaluates 131 economies using 80 indicators. Singapore's strong innovation performance is attributed to its emphasis on research and development, intellectual property protection, and a favorable business environment. The city-state's eighth-place ranking globally underscores its position as a hub for innovation in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Singapore share gains up against high US tech valuations
summary: Singapore shares ended the day with a slight gain, closing at 2,539.94, up 1.39 points, or 0.05%. Despite high US tech valuations, analysts expressed cautious optimism, citing positive earnings surprises from tech companies. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's parliamentary address provided support, particularly for Reits, with Mapletree Commercial Trust and Keppel DC Reit seeing price advances. The market remains cautious ahead of the US Fed's Beige Book report.

site_title: SK Jewellery shares up 56.8% after co-founders' privatisation bid
summary: SK Jewellery shares surged 56.8% to a two-year high of 14.9 cents after the company's co-founders offered to take the company private at 15 Singapore cents per share, valuing the company at $84 million. The offer is conditional on achieving a 90% shareholding threshold and is seen as a premium over the last traded price. The co-founders believe going private will give them greater control and cost savings, while also enabling the company to focus on digital transformation and cost control.

site_title: Trump trying to change election narrative
summary: US President Donald Trump is shifting his election narrative from focusing on the COVID-19 pandemic to concerns over street violence under a potential Biden presidency. Following the death of George Floyd and subsequent protests, Trump's campaign strategy has emphasized the need for law and order, with the President claiming that Democrats are fueling chaos and violence. In response, Joe Biden has accused Trump of fanning the flames of hate and failing to address the underlying issues. The election narrative has become increasingly polarized, with Trump painting Biden's America as one of social chaos and Biden portraying Trump's America as one of anarchy and bloodshed.

site_title: Lego sales surge as housebound families spend more time on it
summary: Lego sales surged 14% in the first six months of 2020 due to increased time spent on the toy at home during the coronavirus lockdown. This growth trend continued into the second half of the year, with the company outpacing the overall toy market. Lego's revenue rose 7% to 15.7 billion Danish kroner ($3.4 billion), driven by increased online sales, despite temporarily shutting production in Mexico and China. The company's operating profit grew 11% to 3.9 billion kroner.

site_title: The many sides to Dan Brown
summary: Dan Brown, author of bestselling thrillers like "The Da Vinci Code," has released a children's album called "Wild Symphony" alongside a classical music album for kids, which he composed 30 years ago.
