Claroty, a New York-headquartered company, uses products to monitor industrial control systems (ICS) and operational technology (OT) networks, which are becoming increasingly vulnerable to cyber threats. Vardi notes that OT systems, initially designed to operate in isolation, are now being connected to IT networks, making them more susceptible to attacks. Claroty works with customers to identify vulnerabilities, deploy continuous threat detection systems, and provide alerts and notifications. The company is growing rapidly, with a focus on partnerships and converging with other security vendors.

images.alt_text: "Legacy operational tech systems have not been designed with cybersecurity in mind," said Yaniv Vardi, CEO of Claroty.

site_title: Goldman-backed startup Optimizely to be bought by Episerver
summary: Episerver Inc is set to acquire Optimizely Inc, a 10-year-old technology company backed by Goldman Sachs and actor Ashton Kutcher, for less than its previously valued $600 million. The acquisition price was not disclosed, but Optimizely's valuation was reportedly lower than its funding round in June. The deal, expected to close in the fourth quarter, is Episerver's largest to date. Optimizely helps companies manage and test website versions to maximize clicks, and its founders have a history with Google.

site_title: Europe's stock markets going strong despite fears of second pandemic wave
summary: Europe's stock markets continue to perform well despite fears of a second pandemic wave, with the euro gaining 11% against the US dollar and major stock indices in Germany, Italy, France, and Spain rising by 20-29%. The eurozone's GDP contracted by 15% in the second quarter, but investors believe a V-shaped recovery is underway due to pent-up demand and stimulus packages. However, recent economic indicators suggest a W-shaped recovery may be more likely, with the Eurozone service sector's PMI falling below 50. The European Central Bank has pledged to continue providing support through quantitative easing and low interest rates.

site_title: No increase in public transport fares; rise will be carried over to fare review exercise next year
summary: Singapore's Public Transport Council announced that public transport fares will not increase this year due to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic. The 4.4% fare hike, scheduled for normal circumstances, will be carried over to the next fare review exercise next year.

images.alt_text: Public transport fares will not rise this year to help commuters amid the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Gigged out
summary: Singapore's freelance community is struggling due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with many experiencing income loss and reduced work opportunities. Freelancers, including those in the arts and creative industries, are facing financial challenges, with some turning to temporary work or taking on multiple jobs to make ends meet. The government's Self-Employed Person Income Relief Scheme (SIRS) has provided some support, but many are calling for an extension or more comprehensive protection. Insurers and fintech firms are also offering policies tailored to freelancers, but uptake has been low. Experts recommend better protection, including contracts and dispute resolution assistance, to safeguard freelancers' interests.

site_title: Soilbuild Reit's sponsor signs term sheet for possible transaction of interests
summary: Non-executive director Lim Chap Huat of Soilbuild Business Space Reit's manager has signed a non-binding term sheet for a possible transaction involving his interests and those of his three sons. The signing may or may not lead to a transaction for the Reit's units, with no certainty or assurance that a deal will occur. The Reit's manager emphasized that the term sheet is non-binding and does not guarantee a transaction.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher on US Fed survey, stimulus hopes
summary: Australian shares rose for a second consecutive session, driven by a positive US Federal Reserve survey and hopes of additional stimulus. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed 0.8% higher at 6,111.60, with heavyweight financials leading gains. However, the rally was somewhat tempered by a surge in COVID-19 cases in Victoria, which may delay lockdown easing.

site_title: What job seekers need to land their next WFH job
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the shift to remote work, with the Singapore government offering SkillsFuture credits to support lifelong learning. Job seekers need to upskill and highlight digital collaboration and remote work skills to succeed in today's digital workplace. Employers also have a role to play in providing opportunities for employee upskilling and investing in digital collaboration tools. By embracing digitalization, both job seekers and employers can futureproof their businesses and careers in the post-pandemic era.

site_title: Taking power: Chinese firm to run Laos electric grid amid default warnings
summary: Laos is set to cede majority control of its electric grid to a Chinese company, China Southern Power Grid, amid warnings of a potential debt default. The deal comes as Laos struggles to repay loans taken out under China's "Belt and Road" infrastructure initiative, with critics accusing Beijing of "debt trap diplomacy." The agreement binds the landlocked country closer to its giant neighbor, giving the Chinese company better bargaining power with regional countries and potentially making a profit.

images.alt_text: The poor, small South-east Asian country of Laos is set to cede majority control of its electric grid to a Chinese company, as it struggles to stave off a potential debt default, people with direct knowledge of the agreement said.

site_title: UAE commodities firm shuts trading desks
summary: A UAE commodities firm, Aster, has shut its trading desks amid market volatility. The move comes as gold prices rise following US President Trump's announcement of fresh tariffs on Canada and potential threats to other countries. This news occurred after a series of market shifts, including a potential sale of Exxon Singapore stations to Aster and a decrease in oil demand projections by Opec for the next four years. The move may indicate increased market uncertainty and a shift in investor confidence.

site_title: Verizon bids big to win US bandwidth for 5G network
summary: Verizon has bid US$1.9 billion to acquire 535 megahertz of mid-band spectrum for its 5G network, beating Dish Network's US$913 million bid. The spectrum, spanning 3450-3550 MHz, balances range and data speed, addressing the US's lag behind other countries in deploying 5G technology. The Federal Communications Commission's auction aims to provide ultra-speedy 5G networks for applications like self-driving vehicles and virtual reality. Verizon's win increases the mid-band spectrum available for 5G networks, but still lags behind countries like China and South Korea.

site_title: Europe: Shares start week on firm footing, vaccine developments eyed
summary: European shares rebounded on Monday after a Wall Street-led decline in technology stocks, with investors focusing on Covid-19 vaccine developments. Australia is expected to receive its first vaccine batches in January, boosting the healthcare sector. AstraZeneca rose 1.5% and the European healthcare sector index jumped 0.9%. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.8% as insurers, banks, and automakers also gained more than 1%.

site_title: Dwayne Johnson says he and family have recovered from Covid-19
summary: Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson announced on social media that he, his wife Lauren, and their two young children have recovered from COVID-19 after testing positive about 2-1/2 weeks ago. The family, who contracted the virus from close family friends, was "incredibly disciplined" about following safety measures. Johnson, 48, urged people to wear face masks to limit the spread of the virus, saying it's a "fact and the right thing to do." He expressed relief that his family is healthy and no longer contagious.

site_title: Japan's hottest tech IPO in 5 years shows retail trading fever
summary: Japan's tech IPO, Neural Pocket, has surged 622% since its listing last month, making it the country's hottest tech IPO in 5 years. The company, which uses AI to analyze photos and videos, has reached a valuation of over $1 billion. The surge is attributed to amateur investors, who have become more active in Japan's stock market due to the coronavirus pandemic. This trend is supported by market analyst Tomoichiro Kubota, who notes that retail investors are driving demand for technology stocks.

site_title: US CDC issues sweeping halt on residential evictions to combat virus
summary: The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has issued a nationwide order temporarily halting millions of US renters from being evicted due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The order, which lasts through December 31, applies to 43 million US residential renters who meet income eligibility requirements. Renters must file sworn declarations and attest they have sought government assistance for rent or housing. The move aims to reduce the spread of COVID-19, but the National Apartment Association warns it will further harm the economy and housing affordability crisis.

site_title: Biofourmis raises US$100m in Series C round led by SoftBank
summary: Biofourmis, a digital therapeutics startup, has raised US$100 million in a Series C equity round led by SoftBank Vision Fund 2, valuing the company at close to a "unicorn" status. The deal brings the company's total funding to US$145 million, as it seeks to expand its operations and develop digital therapeutics solutions. The startup, which is cash-flow positive and Ebitda-positive, aims to capture a significant surge in demand for virtual care in the face of the pandemic.

site_title: Much ado about minimum wage
summary: Singapore's minimum wage debate resurfaced amid a global recession, with proponents citing its need for social safety nets and progressive wage models. However, the government has dismissed calls, citing concerns about unemployment and the potential for firms to hire fewer workers. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat expressed openness to considering the idea, but emphasized the need for careful consideration of its merits and potential trade-offs. The Progressive Wage Model (PWM), introduced in 2012, has been touted as a better alternative, with workers in its sectors experiencing cumulative wage growth of around 30%. Critics argue that the PWM is inefficient and ineffective, and that a national minimum wage could be a more effective solution.

site_title: South Korea imports oil from China storage
summary: South Korean refiners have bought nearly 2 million barrels of Omani crude from Chinese storage tanks in the past two months, taking advantage of low prices and high inventories. The cargoes were lifted from bonded storage tanks operated by Shanghai's International Energy Exchange, with buyers including SK Trading International and GS Caltex. The trend reversed from July, when Shanghai crude futures were at a premium over global benchmark Brent, prompting refiners to buy crude at lower prices. This unusual trade highlights the complexities of the global oil market.

site_title: SK Jewellery co-founders offer S$0.15 per share in cash to privatise company
summary: SK Jewellery Group's co-founders, Lim Yong Guan, Lim Yong Sheng, and Lim Liang Eng, have made a voluntary conditional cash offer of S$0.15 per share to privatise the company, valuing it at S$84 million. The offer, made by OroGreen Investment, represents a 70.5% premium over the last traded price and a 90% shareholding threshold for its success. The co-founders and shareholder Soo Kee Capital, holding 82.6% of the shares, have agreed to tender their shares in acceptance of the offer, providing a clean cash exit opportunity for shareholders.

site_title: Strengthening Singapore's place in the financial world: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore is strengthening its financial sector to improve its global standing and create better lives for its citizens. The country has seen 22,000 financial sector jobs created over the past five years, with 15,000 going to Singaporeans. Despite concerns that foreigners in senior positions may crowd out Singaporeans, the number of Singaporeans in these roles has increased, and the overall size of the sector has grown. To address concerns, the Monetary Authority of Singapore is working with financial institutions to promote merit-based hiring practices and support local talent development.

site_title: Robinhoods of the art world lure scores of investors in pandemic
summary: Masterworks, a startup allowing investors to buy tiny stakes in paintings by world-class artists, has seen a surge in demand during the pandemic, with 10,000 new users per month. The company has bought 15 artworks since March, including a KAWS piece that sold out in hours after a $1.52 million initial public offering. Fractional ownership in luxury assets like art, collectibles, and racehorses is gaining popularity, with companies like Acquicent and MyRacehorse also experiencing growth. While the concept isn't new, the pandemic has heightened the appetite for these investments, which are often considered high-risk and lacking in a track record.

site_title: Black franchisees sue McDonald's for discrimination
summary: More than 50 Black former McDonald's franchisees have sued the fast food chain, claiming a "systematic" pattern of racial discrimination that hindered their success and forced some out of business. The lawsuit accuses McDonald's of steering Black franchisees to poor locations, requiring higher security and insurance costs, and suffering from lower-volume sales. McDonald's denies the claims, stating it is committed to diversity and equal opportunity, and predicts it will prevail in the litigation. The franchisees seek compensation of $4-5 million per store for 20 stores, in addition to punitive damages.

images.alt_text: More than 50 Black former McDonald's franchisees have sued the fast food chain claiming a "systematic" pattern of racial discrimination that hindered their success and forced some out of business - claims the company strenuously denies.

site_title: Thailand announces US$2.2b worth of additional stimulus in handouts, job measures
summary: Thailand announced a US$2.2 billion fiscal stimulus package to support its economy, which has been severely impacted by the coronavirus pandemic. The package includes cash handouts and job measures, such as 3,000 baht handouts for 15 million people and 23.5 billion baht to help the private sector hire new graduates. The government expects the economy to shrink by 8.5% this year, with 2 million job losses due to the tourism slump. The stimulus measures are part of a 1.9 trillion baht coronavirus response package.

images.alt_text: Thailand announced on Wednesday US$2.2 billion worth of fiscal stimulus in cash handouts and job measures to support Southeast Asia's second-largest economy which has been battered by the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Singapore shares lacklustre save some medical-related ones
summary: Singapore shares closed at 2,538.55, up 6.04 points or 0.24% from Monday's close, with 1.80 billion securities worth S$903.25 million traded. Medical-related stocks, such as Medtecs International and QT Vascular, drew interest, while property counters like City Developments and Hotel Royal benefited from the cut in development charge rates. The Straits Times Index (STI) has notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, but geopolitical tensions and a spike in the VIX suggest a potential technical pullback in the market.

site_title: China Environment lapses referred to the authorities; SGX RegCo reprimands company, former executives
summary: China Environment and its former executives, including CEO Wu Jida and CFO Chiar Choon Teck, have been publicly reprimanded by Singapore's SGX RegCo for making false statements and failing to disclose financial information. The regulator referred the non-existent trade receivables and false financial statements to authorities. Former executive chairman Huang Min was also reprimanded. The reprimand follows China Environment's shares being suspended from trading since 2016. SGX RegCo advised Singapore-listed firms to consult with the regulator before appointing unqualified directors or executive officers.

site_title: Toshiba top investor calls for probe as vote counting scandal widens
summary: Toshiba's top investor, Effissimo Capital Management, has called for a probe into a botched shareholder meeting, alleging that several investors were deprived of their vote. The issue has widened into a larger problem for corporate Japan, with multiple banks revealing counting errors affecting over 1,300 firms. Toshiba's board is urged to establish an independent committee to investigate the fairness of the July meeting, which saw over 1,000 postal voting forms go uncounted.

images.alt_text: Toshiba's top investor has called for a probe into a botched shareholder meeting, alleging several investors were deprived of their vote, a letter to the Japanese conglomerate's board seen by Reuters shows.

site_title: MAS orders Wirecard to stop payment services in Singapore
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has ordered Wirecard entities in Singapore to stop their payment services, effective immediately, due to the firm's collapse into insolvency in June. Thousands of merchants in Singapore use Wirecard's payment terminals, and customers are expected to make alternative arrangements. Wirecard must return all customers' funds by October 14. The move aims to provide certainty to customers, who have already found alternative service providers in some cases.

images.alt_text: The latest directive by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) for Wirecard entities in Singapore (Wirecard SG) to cease their payment services here comes as thousands of merchants in Singapore are users of Wirecard's payment terminals here.

site_title: Mid-autumn dreams
summary: Top hotels and restaurants in Singapore unveil their latest celestial offerings for the Mid-Autumn Festival, featuring classic and contemporary mooncakes. Raffles Hotel Singapore offers handcrafted snowskin mooncakes with unique flavors such as Apricot and Sour Plum, and Champagne Truffle Snowskin. Orchard Hotel Singapore showcases its Hua Ting Restaurant's new range of mooncakes, including Sour Plum with Roasted Organic Hazelnut Snowskin and White Lotus Paste with Champagne Ganache Snowskin. Crystal Jade Group offers a classic and contemporary range of mooncakes with less sugar, while TWG Tea presents the Sky Lantern Tea Mooncake Collection with handcrafted mooncakes delicately blended with the unique flavors and aromas of the finest tea blends.
